samples.prompt: Everyone sees in black-and-white until they meet their soulmate, at which point their world bursts with color. For most, this is excellent news. But you’re blind, and you have been since birth.
samples.output:
I found out about color when I was six.

Not by seeing it, of course. My mother was trying to reassure me after another doctor’s appointment full of gentle voices and sterile smells. She sat on my bed, her hand warm on my knee, and said, “Sweetheart, someday you’ll meet someone, and everything will change. You’ll see color then. Everyone does. It’s how you’ll know.”

I remember feeling two things: awe and terror.

Awe, because color sounded like magic. Terror, because no one ever said that to my older brother, and he already saw color.

He’d come home at twelve with wide eyes and shaky hands, whispering “Red” like it was a prayer. For him, the world had shifted between Tuesday and Wednesday when he brushed fingers with some girl at the bus stop. His soccer ball, he explained breathlessly, wasn’t just “light” or “dark” anymore. It was “white”—which is something, apparently. Grass was “green.” He sat at my feet and tried to explain green like telling a joke I didn’t have the language for.

For him, color was a secret door you passed through by accident.

For me, it was a promise tied to a condition. You’ll see color when. When you meet them. When the universe chooses. When it decides you’ve earned it, or waited long enough, or bumped the right hand on the right day.

And under all of that, the quiet unspoken question nobody wanted to voice: how?

At eight, I asked the question out loud.

“What if I don’t see it?” I asked my father. “Will I feel it?”

He was silent for a little too long. Then: “Of course,” he said, and his voice wore that careful smile adults think kids can’t hear. “It’s impossible not to know.”

Impossibility is a funny thing. It disappears the moment someone doesn’t fit the rule.

The doctors had said my blindness was “structural” and “complete.” No light perception. Nothing. “It’s unlikely,” one had said, clearing his throat, “that the… chromatic event… would have an effect. The mechanism appears to rely on existing photoreceptor function.”

He’d meant: The magic doesn’t have a back door.

By then, there were a few stories circulating. The girl whose right eye had “woken” while her left remained grayscale. The boy who was colorblind even after his soulmate, raising an awkward question nobody wanted to answer. The woman who had already seen color from someone else, and so, when she met the person she loved more deeply, nothing changed at all.

Flaws in the system, people said.

Like the system was a product in beta, instead of a fundamental rule of human experience.

I grew up in black-and-white without expecting anything else. The older I got, the more I understood that most people didn’t really mean to be cruel. They weren’t thinking about me when they said, “You’ll understand when you see blue.” Or when they said, “Just wait until you find your person. Every boring thing suddenly matters.” Or when a girl in my literature class sighed, “I wish I could’ve kept black-and-white longer. Color makes everything so loud.”

I wanted to ask her if she’d trade back. I wanted to ask if she understood what it was to be permanently on the wrong side of the window.

Still, I dated.

I was practical about it. The narrative about soulmates makes everyone desperate. They crowd concerts, swipe endlessly, attend “Chromatic Mixers” where strangers hold hands like they’re checking batteries, waiting for the spark.

At nineteen, I went once, at the insistence of my roommate, Lena, who had seen color at sixteen and never shut up about “the deep silver blue of midnight.” She dragged me to a bar that smelled like cheap beer and expensive perfume, and people queued to touch.

“Do you feel anything?” Lena asked after a tall boy with nervous hands let go of me.

“I feel like a doorknob,” I said. But I held back the rest: I feel nothing, and that nothing feels permanent.

After that, I stopped chasing the myth. It was easier to construct a life around what I knew: sound, texture, the map of the world under my cane and fingertips, the voices that stayed and the ones that didn’t.

I studied music therapy. There’s a certain symmetry in helping people find new ways to perceive their lives. I learned how the frequency of a voice shifts when someone is about to cry, how breath hitches before confession, how silence can be as eloquent as speech.

People were always a little in awe of my competence.

“It’s incredible how you manage,” they’d say, like my life was a complicated recipe I’d pulled off without instructions.

“It’s just my life,” I’d say. “You manage yours.”

Secretly, I wondered if theirs was easier because of color. If deciding on a dress was simpler when the world gave you that much extra data. If love was simpler when it came with a visual cue. If heartbreak was harder or gentler when the color someone gave you didn’t go away.

Because that was the other thing: if your soulmate died, the color stayed. That’s how people knew it was real. Soulmates weren’t about who you stayed with. They were about who switched the light on.

At twenty-seven, my brother got divorced from the woman who’d given him his color at twelve. It was not scandalous. People drift. Jobs move. Hearts change. But he never stopped seeing green.

“It’s weird,” he told me one night as we sat on the floor of his emptying apartment, packing dishes. “Looking at someone and knowing they’ll never be the reason your world changed, no matter how much they might deserve it.”

I thought, I have the opposite problem.

My world might change, but I’d never know why.

Or so I thought.

I met him in late autumn, in the rehabilitation wing of the hospital where I worked. The building always smells like a rotating carousel of antiseptic, burnt coffee, and the lemon cleaner they use at 3 a.m. when they think no one notices. He’d been in a car accident, they said. Minor physical injuries, major concussion, temporary mobility issues. They assigned me to run his music therapy as part of cognitive rehab.

I walked in with my cane tapping and my smile ready. He was sitting in the recliner, quiet. His chart said: Name: Eli. Age: 29. Vision: standard. Relationship status: Single. Color status: Black-and-white.

“Hi, Eli,” I said. “I’m Mara. I’ll be working with you.”

He didn’t say anything right away. I’ve learned to read that pause. Some people need a second to rearrange their expectations when the therapist walks in with a white cane. Some need to decide if they trust me. Some are just tired.

“You’re blind,” he said finally. No edge, just observation.

“Yes,” I said. “Birth defect. Full grayscale. Very efficient. I’m here to help with your memory and processing. We’ve got guitars and playlists and terrible hospital Wi-Fi. How are you feeling today?”

He laughed, briefly. “Like my brain’s on dial-up.”

We spent the first session mapping his life through music. It’s a trick I use: ask for a song that reminds you of childhood, high school, heartbreak, joy. It tells me more than a questionnaire. He liked messy indie bands and sad folk singers and one embarrassingly chipper pop anthem he refused to name.

Week by week, he came back to himself. His recall sharpened. His fatigue shortened. He had a good sense of humor, which he mostly deployed on himself. He asked questions no one else did.

“How do you imagine color?” he asked on the third week.

“I don’t,” I said. “When people tried to describe it, they always ended with ‘You’ll understand when you see it.’ So I decided not to spend my life chasing a metaphor I can’t test.”

“You don’t feel cheated?” he asked.

“Sometimes,” I said. “But I have other things.”

He was quiet, then: “I don’t have color either.”

“I read your chart,” I said. “Late bloomer?”

“Or no bloomer,” he said. “I used to think it meant I hadn’t met them yet. Then I started thinking maybe they died before I found them. Lately I’ve been thinking maybe I’m just not built with that wire.”

I surprised myself by saying, softly, “Me too.”

After that, the air between us had a new shape. Not heavier, not lighter. Just different.

On a Tuesday that smelled like rain on concrete and overcooked cafeteria pasta, I reached for the edge of the table to steady myself and my fingers brushed his wrist.

He inhaled sharply.

“You okay?” I asked.

He didn’t answer immediately.

An odd stillness settled over him, like the way a room sounds when someone’s holding their breath.

“Mara,” he said slowly.

“Yes?”

“What color is your hair?”

I almost laughed. “Brown, I think. That’s what people tell me. Why?”

He exhaled, a shaky, disbelieving sound. “Because it is. It is so… brown.”

I frowned. “That supposed to mean something profound?”

“The chair is…” He groped for the word like I’d heard so many others do years ago, in hallways, on buses, during first touches. “Blue,” he whispered. “The wall is… God, it’s awful. It’s beige. That’s beige. That disgusting color they paint hospitals. And your shirt is…” A pause, then wonder. “Red.”

Silence pressed around us.

I sat down slowly. My heart was doing something dangerous.

“Oh,” I said.

He started laughing, a sound broken open with astonishment. “Oh,” he echoed. “Yeah. That’s one way to put it.”

There it was, then. The event people organize their lives around. The cosmic switch flipped by an accidental brush of skin over laminate.

And I was still blind.

No sudden flare, no hidden capacity revealing itself at the last second. Just me, as I had always been, in my uncolored world.

I waited for the grief to swallow me whole.

Instead, what came was… anger. Sudden, sharp, on behalf of the girl I’d been, the doctors who’d shrugged, the myth we’d all swallowed.

“That’s it?” I asked. “You see color now?”

“Yes,” he said. “Everything. It’s all… it’s a lot. You’re—” He stopped himself.

“I’m still in black-and-white.”

“Yeah,” he said, quietly. “You are.”

We sat there with that unfairness between us, humming like static.

“I tried not to touch you,” he blurted. “I mean, not in a weird way. Just—after I realized you didn’t have color, that you might not— I thought if it was me, I’d want the choice. And I didn’t… I didn’t give you a choice.”

I hadn’t realized until that moment that was what hurt: the theft of the hypothetical. The closing of a door I’d convinced myself I’d boarded up already.

“It’s not your fault,” I said, because it wasn’t. “This is just how it works.”

“Apparently, it’s how it works for me,” he said. “I meet my soulmate, and she gets nothing new. Same broken deal she started with.”

Something in his voice made my anger fold in on itself, turning into something heavier and softer.

“You believe that?” I asked. “That I’m…”

“My soulmate?” he finished. Paper rustled; he was fidgeting with the chart in his lap. “I don’t know what else to call the fact that my brain just rewrote all its definitions because I touched you.”

“Lots of people touch me,” I said lightly. “Only you are being this dramatic.”

He huffed. “It’s not drama. Trust me, if you could see this wall, you’d be upset too.”

I laughed, despite myself.

Then, quieter: “So that’s it. Mystery solved. You found me, and I stay like this.”

He shifted. I heard the creak of the recliner. When he spoke next, his voice was closer.

“Can I tell you something?” he asked.

“Sure.”

“Before today, I thought color would fix me,” he said. “Everyone makes it sound that way. Like you’re half-booted software until some person hits ‘update.’ And a few minutes ago I got what I’ve been wanting for twenty-nine years. And it’s cool. It’s… overwhelming. But the first thought I had wasn’t ‘Finally, I’m whole.’ It was, ‘Please don’t let this hurt her.’”

He let the words hang there. They felt heavier than the myth.

“I don’t think it’s about fixing,” he went on. “I think it’s just about… knowing. And I already knew you before the colors snapped on.”

He said it so simply that the complicated, jagged thing in my chest shifted shape.

“It still feels unfair,” I said.

“Yeah,” he agreed. “It is. I get this extra thing, and you don’t. I can’t change that. But I can… describe it, if you ever want. Not in the ‘you’ll understand when you see it’ way. I mean, translate it, like another sense. Like sound.”

I thought of all the years people had tried and failed. Of my quiet refusal to chase what I couldn’t have.

“Maybe,” I said. “Not today.”

“Not today,” he echoed.

There was a beat of silence. Then I asked the question that mattered more.

“Are you going to run?” I said. The word “you” encompassed so much: you, with your colors; you, with your choice; you, with your sudden ability to confirm what I can only trust.

He understood. “No,” he said immediately. “Are you?”

I hesitated. “No,” I said. And I meant it, to my own surprise.

Because here was the truth the myth never accounted for: the light can turn on in one room and not another, and it doesn’t invalidate the house.

People talk like color is certainty. But as I sat in that grayscale hospital room with the man whose world was suddenly shouting in shades, I realized I had certainty long before the universe bothered to send its signal.

I knew the shape of his voice when he lied and when he told the truth. I knew how carefully he listened, how he never grabbed my cane to “help,” how he announced his movements so I was never startled. I knew he showed up for every session even when he was tired. I knew, in a hundred small, human ways, that something important lived in the space between us.

I will never see red. But I know how his hand felt when he reached for mine deliberately, not by accident this time, and said, “Okay. So we share this. I’ll tell you when the trees change color, and you tell me when the rain sounds like it’s about to fall. We both get more world that way.”

It wasn’t magic. It wasn’t fair.

It was, unmistakably, ours.

samples.prompt: You are completely blind, but occasionally you can see just one person. That person will die within the next 24 hours. You've just seen yourself while passing by a mirror.
samples.output:
The first time I saw someone, I was ten.

For as long as I could remember, there had only been the dark: a deep, textured dark with different kinds of weight to it, different temperatures. I knew where walls were from the way sound folded back to me. I knew where doors hung because air changed as it flowed under them. I knew people as warmth and breath, as the drag of a pant leg, as the scent of detergent and shampoo. But I had never seen anyone.

Then one day, crossing a street with my mother’s hand in mine, the world broke.

It was like a hole opened in the dark, white and violent. A boy stood on the curb opposite me, one foot raised to step into the street. Green hoodie. Freckles scattered across his nose. He looked so startled to simply exist. For an instant I was dizzy—there was too much information, too quickly. Color. Edges. The exact shape of his eyes. My mother tugged my hand, and the vision vanished. Just black again, and the car’s tires screaming.

I heard the impact. I heard my mother curse, a sound I had never heard from her before. Someone shouted to call an ambulance.

At the time I thought the strange moment of sight had been a miracle. Then the boy died, and the miracle felt more like a warning.

The second time came three years later, in a grocery store. I was older, better at mapping the world by echo and smell. I knew the arrangement of aisles; I knew where the refrigerators hummed in the back. I turned my head toward the cough of someone behind me, and the dark tore open again. An old woman with watery blue eyes and a red scarf stood three feet away, looking directly past me. My breath stuck. I blinked, and she disappeared back into the dark.

That night my father told my mother about the car that ran a light and jumped the curb outside the laundromat. “Mrs. Halperin,” he said. “She was just here yesterday.”

I didn’t tell them that yesterday I’d seen a red scarf.

After the third time, I started keeping count.

A man on a bus. A girl in my math class. A mail carrier pausing at our box. Each came to me for a second, vivid and impossible, like a photograph pressed against my face. Each was gone from the world within a day.

By sixteen I was sure of two things:

1. I was completely blind. No light, no shapes, no colors, nothing.
2. Once in a while, without warning, I would see one person, perfectly clearly, as if a spotlight of sight had narrowed down to them alone. And they would be dead within twenty-four hours.

It wasn’t every day. Sometimes weeks passed. Sometimes I went months without it happening and let myself believe it had stopped. Then, casually, I’d hear someone clear their throat, turn my head toward the sound, and there they’d be, crisp in their mortality.

I tried to warn one of them once. I was eighteen; his name tag said “DAVIS” when his image snapped into view. I saw him in line at a coffee shop. He was laughing at something. I saw the texture of his beard, the chipped corner of his tooth. The second he faded back into blackness, cold slid down my spine.

When I spoke to him, I didn’t say, “You’re going to die.” I said, “Please be careful today. The next day too. Don’t drive drunk. Watch for red lights.”

He chuckled, the way people chuckle at the blind kid saying something odd. “Sure thing,” he said. I heard the clink of his cup, the soft jostle as he left.

He was on the news the next morning. Freak construction accident. A chain snapped. A load shifted. Wrong place, wrong time.

I stopped trying after that. If there is a script to play to change the ending, I never found it. All I managed was to see.

Eventually I built my life around not looking for people. I angled my face down, oriented my listening to walls and floors and my cane. I learned technology, programming, the comfort of systems that behaved according to rules. The human world remained a constellation of voices and footsteps, safely faceless.

It was manageable, as long as the visions were rare and belonged to strangers.

Then one day, I saw my sister.

She appeared to me in the kitchen, her hair in the messy bun she always wore when baking. Flour dusted her left cheekbone; she was laughing at a podcast only she could hear. The sight was so sudden and so intimate that I forgot to breathe. I reached toward her, fingers trembling—and she was gone, replaced by the familiar blank.

“You okay?” she asked. Her voice had shifted position; she was at the counter now, not where I’d seen her.

I did not tell her what I’d seen. I could not find the words. Instead, I hovered near her all day. I spilled coffee. I almost tripped her grabbing her elbow when she passed too close to the stove. I made excuses for why she shouldn’t drive to the store that evening.

She went anyway. It was just five blocks.

The drunk driver did not care.

After that, I stopped pretending it was a coincidence.

So when it happens in the hallway mirror thirteen years later, the recognition is instant and absolute.

I live alone now. My apartment is arranged with geometric precision: three steps from couch to wall, four from wall to bathroom door, eleven from bathroom door to front door. The hallway that connects bedroom to living room has, on its right side, a mirror. Decorative, they said. Something for guests.

I do not care about mirrors. They’ve always been theoretical to me, objects other people fall in love with or flee from. But I do care about habits, and I’ve developed one: slide fingertips along the left wall only. Ignore the mirror.

This morning, I’m late. The alarm didn’t vibrate. My cane is not where I left it. I cut across the hallway instead of skimming the wall. As I pass, a glint detonates in the dark.

I see a man.

He is directly beside me, lined up with the phantom sense of where my body should be. He has black hair threaded with gray at the temples, jaw rough with stubble. There’s a faint white scar across his chin from where he fell off a bike when he was eight. His left eye is a little narrower than his right when he squints. He is wearing my shirt—blue, frayed at the cuffs—and standing with my slouch, my slight twist of the shoulders from years of compensating for a world that never comes fully into focus.

I see myself.

The shock is physical. My knees soften. My hand flies out and hits cold glass with a sound that is too bright. The contact snaps the vision away. The dark rushes back, a tidal wave.

“No,” I say aloud, to no one. “No.”

The hallway hums. The fridge chatters in the other room. Distant traffic murmurs below the window. My heart is too loud.

You’ve had twenty years to learn the rule, I think. One person, once in a while. Always within a day.

I stand there. I don’t move. If I don’t move, maybe I don’t die. Death is a truck, an accident, a freak timing. So: no streets, no transit, no work, no stairs, no electricity, no knives.

I back away from the mirror carefully until my shoulders find the wall. The paint is cool beneath my fingertips. I slide down and sit on the floor, breathing shallowly.

It could be wrong. Maybe I misunderstood. Maybe seeing myself isn’t the same as seeing them. Maybe it’s like a reflection in a camera lens—technical, meaningless. Maybe—

I know better. The rule has never bent, not once.

Twenty-four hours.

I take inventory like it’s code I can debug.

- Could it be metaphorical? Part of me dies? The blind part? The watching part?
- Could I be spared because the system doesn’t allow recursion? Seer seeing seer?
- Could this be the end of the curse? My death as the last necessary closure?

I laugh, once. It sounds ugly in the empty hall.

I get up slowly and make my way to the living room, counting each step. Every object is suddenly malevolent. The sharp corner of the coffee table. The cords under the desk. The window, four stories up, that I always leave locked but what if?

The phone on the counter vibrates. I flinch.

I could call someone. Tell them… what? “I saw myself”? To them it’s meaningless. To me it’s a verdict. Maybe that’s the real cruelty: knowledge that can’t be translated.

I call anyway.

My mother answers on the third ring, her voice layered with all the worry she thinks she hides.

“Hey,” I say, and my voice comes out normal. “Just wanted to hear you.”

We talk about nothing. Weather. Her neighbor’s dog. A recipe she wants to try. I listen like it’s all I’ve ever wanted from the world. I do not tell her I am on a clock.

After we hang up, the apartment is too quiet again. The darkness feels tighter, more intentional. For the first time, I realize how I’ve lived: as a bystander in my own curse, touching other people’s endings without ever risking my own.

Now I am implicated.

I think of all the faces I saw, all the lives I brushed against as they leaned unknowingly toward their exits. I think of the versions of myself I built around that knowledge: the detached observer, the silent mourner, the coward who stopped warning.

Maybe the rules haven’t changed. Maybe the final vision is not a trap but an invitation.

I stand.

Hyper-careful, yes. But not hiding. If death wants a spectacle, it will not get one cowered in the bathroom.

I make coffee, slow and deliberate. I feel the rising steam, the warmth of the mug. I eat toast. I spend twenty minutes deleting drafts of a message I’ll never send explaining everything to people who would never believe it. Then I sit on the couch that is exactly three steps from the wall and two from the rug, and I wait, but not passively.

I dictate a file on my laptop. No explanations this time. No mythologizing.

I list names. Dates. The boy in the green hoodie. The woman with the red scarf. Davis at the coffee shop. My sister with flour on her face.

And at the end, I add one more line, fingers hovering before I say it aloud:

“And today, I saw myself.”

If this is the last entry, then at least the pattern is complete. If someone finds it and laughs, so be it. Evidence is just belief with better timing.

Hours pass. Carefully. The muscles in my shoulders stay tight. Every sound is suspect. A siren makes my pulse spike. A knock at a neighbor’s door sounds like fate.

By evening, something unexpected happens. The fear thins.

Maybe you can only be terrified for so long before it concedes space to something else. Curiosity, maybe. Or fatigue. Or the realization that for everyone else, this uncertainty is their entire life. They don’t get the courtesy of a 24-hour warning. They’re all walking next to invisible mirrors they can’t touch.

I move through my apartment one more time, palm to wall, mapping my small, known universe. At the hallway mirror, I stop.

“Is this you?” I ask the dark. “Or me?”

The dark doesn’t answer. It never has.

I lift my hand, lay my palm on the glass. It’s cool, like a forehead.

For a moment, I imagine—just imagine—that on the other side, the man I saw is mirroring me exactly, eyes open, looking back.

There is a fragile mercy in that.

If I must finally see myself to die, at least I’m not leaving this world a stranger.

samples.prompt: The King is dead. The heirs are fraternal twins The eldest, detected to possess powerful dark magic, cast away at birth. Since then he has amassed a powerful army. The youngest is being crowned King while preparing his army to defend his title against his identical twin whom he has never met.
samples.output:
The bells tolled for the dead king as dawn broke over Alendar, slow and sonorous, each peal rolling down the stone streets like the echo of a verdict. The city woke to mourning colors and whispered rumors, to the black flags cresting the silver towers, to the knowledge that the long-ailing monarch had finally surrendered his crown.

Inside the high-vaulted Hall of Coronation, the younger twin stood beneath the fractured light of stained glass and waited to be made a lie.

Prince Corren had his father’s quiet eyes and his mother’s proud jaw. He wore ceremonial crimson over chainmail, a concession wrung from the High Council the night before—if he must be crowned, he had argued, he would be crowned as both king and captain. The war did not wait for coronations.

“The people must see the symbol, not the steel,” Advisor Maelin had said.

“Let them see both,” Corren had replied. “I won't hide the world from them.”

Now Maelin hovered at his shoulder, too close, fussing at an imaginary crease on Corren’s cloak, his gray beard trembling. “Remember your oaths,” he murmured. “Remember that they must believe in you.”

Believe, Corren thought as he lifted his gaze to the throne. Believe in the twin they kept. They had never told him not to think of that word “twin,” but they never spoke it, either. His earliest memories were of sudden silences when he entered rooms, of his mother’s hand freezing midair, of phrases like “the heir” cut short and buried under others: “the prince,” “the boy,” “the miracle that survived.”

The archbishop stepped forward, gold-threaded vestments sweeping over worn stone. The Hall fell quiet save for the echo of his staff.

“Corren Edris val Alendar,” the old man intoned, “by the will of the late King, by the seal of the Council, and by the blessing of the Divine—”

A crack of thunder split the sky. The stained glass quivered; the crowd flinched as if struck. Corren’s hand went to the hilt of the ceremonial sword—steel, at least, was honest.

“—you are called to the throne.”

A page knelt, opening an ornate box that glowed faintly with protective sigils. Inside lay the crown: a circlet of silver and iron, set not with jewels but with shards of fallen star, as tradition demanded. It had once been explained to Corren as a symbol of humility, that kings of Alendar wore the sky not for vanity, but to remember their weight upon the world.

He knelt. The archbishop lifted the crown, voice rising in the final lines of the ancient rite.

“In the sight of—”

The Hall doors boomed open.

Fast footsteps, the clatter of armor, a captain gasping for breath. General Hara, scarred and stern, did not bother with bows.

“Your Grace—” She faltered, corrected herself with a grimace. “My prince. The wards on the eastern border have fallen. Kharian banners on the horizon. The dark sorcerer is at our gates.”

The archbishop froze, crown suspended over Corren’s head. The Hall erupted in whispers, a thousand thin blades of panic.

“Now?” Maelin hissed. “He strikes during the coronation—”

“He knows our rites,” Hara said. “He knew you would hesitate.”

Corren rose before the crown could find him. In that instant he made a choice that would be sung about, cursed, dissected in schools: he stepped away from the throne.

“General. Report.”

“Their vanguard appears small but shielded by storms,” Hara said. “Our scouts speak of shadows walking in daylight, of lightning that bends around their armor. And at their center, a banner of black and silver. A mirror to ours.”

They had never told him in full. But he was not a fool.

The eldest, detected to possess powerful dark magic, cast away at birth.

Officially, the story went: A stillborn child, a tragic loss. Privately, when Corren could force Maelin’s eyes to his, when his mother’s hands shook too much to drink her tea: A danger we could not control. A prophecy twisted. A baby that made candles burn blue and nurses bleed from the nose. The king’s face a ruin of grief as he ordered the basket taken to the river.

But the river had not taken him.

“Continue the coronation,” Maelin whispered urgently. “We must consecrate your rule before he—”

“He chose this moment because he knows we’d cling to ceremony,” Corren said. “He wants me distracted. Untried. Crown me later. Hara, ready the Third and Fourth Companies. I’ll address the men.”

“You are not yet king,” Maelin said, grabbing his arm. “You cannot command—”

Corren did not shake him off. He turned, letting the entire Hall see what Maelin saw: the steel, the stubbornness, the understanding of what lay beyond stained glass.

“Then crown me,” he said.

The archbishop, still rattled, raised the circlet with trembling hands. The words came shorter, less adorned.

“Corren Edris val Alendar. By our laws and our gods, by our need and by our will—I name you King.”

The crown settled cold on his brow. For a heartbeat, nothing happened.

Then the star-shards within the metal sparked white.

Heat lanced through Corren’s skull, down his spine, a bright spear of something not wholly pain. He gritted his teeth, refusing to stumble. For an instant the world sharpened. He felt—absurdly—the pattern of breath in the room. The pulse of the Hall’s wards. Far off, like a storm seen from a tower, a pressure of power at the edge of the city.

A twin thing.

He exhaled. The sensation receded, leaving him swaying, but standing.

“The King is crowned,” the archbishop said, voice bewildered but firm.

“Good,” Corren said. “Then hear your king. Sound the muster. Open the armories. This is no border raid. This is for the throne.”

Maelin caught up to him as he strode from the Hall. “Your Majesty, there is more you must know.”

“You had twenty years,” Corren said, not slowing. “You chose silence.”

“I obeyed your father,” Maelin said, stung.

“And my brother obeyed nobody,” Corren snapped. “Look what that birthed.”

He regretted the words at once. They lodged in his throat like stones. My brother. The word felt stolen.

Outside, the sky had turned the green-gray of a coming storm. On the eastern horizon, directly above the city’s outer walls, roiled a coil of unnatural cloud, veined with violet lightning.

Corren climbed the steps to the battlements two at a time, Hara and a cadre of guards at his back. Trumpets called. Men and women in mismatched armor poured into the courtyard, strapping on helmets, snatching spears, faces pale but set.

They had expected a mourning day. They got a war.

On the wall, Corren looked out and saw the army his twin had built.

Ranks of soldiers in blackened mail. Standards of sable and silver, bearing a symbol that twisted the royal crest: the crowned star inverted, its points dripping shadow. At their center, a wedge of riders on scaled mounts, eyes burning like coals. Around them, the air seemed to blur, as though heat rose from their mere presence.

And at the front, a figure on a dark stallion, bareheaded, cloak snapping in the storm.

He was too far to see features clearly, but Corren knew. It was like looking into a warped mirror across an ocean. The tilt of the shoulders. The way he watched the walls with stillness instead of bluster. Corren’s heart stuttered once, then steadied into something cold.

“Archers ready,” Hara shouted.

Lightning forked downward, hammered the outer wards in a cascade of sparks. The protective runes flared, held, dimmed.

“He’s testing us,” Hara muttered.

“He’s announcing himself,” Corren said.

As if in answer, the rider at the fore raised one hand.

The storm hushed.

The distant voice that rolled over the field was amplified by magic, clear as if whispered at Corren’s ear.

“Alendar,” it said. “Your king is dead. The son he cast into the river has returned.”

A murmur shuddered through Corren’s gathered troops. Hara swore under her breath.

“My name,” the voice continued, “is Kael Edris val Alendar.”

The sky growled on the name.

“I was condemned for what I am,” Kael said. “For the power your priests called blight. I was thrown away so a weaker mirror might sit the throne.”

Corren’s jaw clenched.

“I come with an army forged in exile. I offer surrender. Open your gates. Kneel. No blood need stain this day further. You have lost one king. Do not lose thousands of lives clinging to his fear.”

Hara turned to Corren, eyes flinty. “Say the word.”

Corren felt Maelin’s presence at his back, a ghost of his father’s choices pressing on his shoulders. He thought of a baby crying by a river, of hands that did not lift him. Of a boy growing not with tutors and gentle corrections, but with whoever found him in the dark.

He stepped onto the front of the battlement so all his own people could see him, so Kael—if his magic allowed—would see too.

“I am Corren Edris val Alendar,” he called, no enchantment but the raw force of his voice and the thin new weight of the crown. “Second-born. First to be acknowledged. King by law and by the will of our people.”

The storm seemed to lean in.

“You were wronged,” Corren said, loud enough that the soldiers around him stiffened. “By the man I just buried. By those who feared what they did not understand.”

“Your Majesty—” Maelin hissed.

“Silence,” Corren snapped without looking back.

He returned his gaze to the mirror-twin of himself.

“But I will not hand this city to an army of shadows,” Corren said. “I will not trade one cruelty for another. You offer surrender? I offer parley. One hour. You and I. Between the armies. Twin to twin. Let us see if we can end our father’s sin without drowning our people in it.”

Hara sucked in a breath. “You’re mad.”

“Perhaps,” Corren said. “But he came to claim more than stone. He came to claim a birthright. He won’t refuse the chance to stand above me and tell me why I don’t deserve it.”

Across the field, Kael tilted his head, as if listening to a whisper only he could hear. Then, slowly, he raised his hand again—not in attack, but in acknowledgment.

“One hour,” Kael’s voice rolled over the walls. “Come alone, little king.”

The storm stirred, restless, caged.

Corren exhaled, feeling every eye on him.

“Prepare for battle,” he told Hara softly. “But also…prepare a white banner.”

“For peace?” she asked, incredulous.

“For honesty,” Corren said. “If we fight, let it be after I’ve looked my brother in the eye and learned what the river gave back to us.”

He touched the cold metal of his crown, feeling faintly the pulse of the star-shards, the echo of that distant twin magic humming like a chord waiting to resolve.

The king was dead.

Two heirs remained.

And between them, in the shadow of storm and stone, the fate of Alendar began to hinge.

samples.prompt: [WP`] One day, while drunk, for no real reason, your buddy decides to jokingly summon a crossroads demon, and surprisingly, one shows up. Now the demon has to deal with two drunks argue over what they should do with the demon who just wants to get back to watching Netflix.
samples.output:
The first thing I remember is the pig.

A wild, shrieking pig in a crop top.

No, wait. That was Dave, sprinting through my living room with my hoodie halfway over his head and his bare gut out, squealing as he tripped over an Xbox controller.

The actual first thing I remember is Dave slapping my coffee table with both hands and yelling, “HEY, LET’S SELL OUR SOULS.”

It was 1:37 a.m. according to the blinking microwave clock. The apartment smelled like beer, pizza, and the slow decay of good decisions. My laptop played something from Netflix left to autoplay, muffled under a half-empty bag of chips. I was three beers past responsible and one whiskey past wise.

Dave, ruddy-faced and glitter-bearded (I still don’t know where the glitter came from), fumbled his phone open. “Dude,” he said, with the profound seriousness of a drunken prophet, “I found instructions. Crossroads demon. Ten years of anything. It’s like Amazon but metal.”

He shoved the screen at me. It was some forum post, black background, red font, pentagrams poorly copy-pasted in the margins. The comments were mostly “lol” and “this is fake.” I snorted.

“You don’t even have a crossroads,” I said. “You have my Ikea rug.”

He planted his feet in the center of the carpet like it was the mouth of Hell. He swept aside empty cans, grabbed the salt shaker, and with the solemn precision of a raccoon doing surgery, he drew a wobbly circle.

“That’s…oval,” I muttered.

“Shhh,” he intoned. “We stand at the crossroads of our life choices.”

“Fair.”

He turned off the lamp theatrically. Netflix lit the room in a blue glow. On screen, a loading wheel spun. Even it looked drunk.

“Okay,” Dave whispered. “Demon time.”

He read from the forum. Most of it sounded like edgy fanfiction. He raised his arms. “Oh dark powers of the underworld, I summon thee. I offer—uh—I offer PIZZA.” He grabbed the last slice from the box, held it aloft. Grease dripped onto my rug. “And my undying—hic—devotion.”

He pronounced some Latin in a way that would make Latin press charges. When nothing happened, he laughed and took a bite of the offering.

“See?” I said. “Fake.”

The lights went out.

The TV blinked to black, plunging us into pure dark for about three seconds. Then every single candle from my emergency drawer lit at once with a whoomph.

I did not know I owned that many candles.

A shape appeared inside the salt oval. Not a sulfurous blast, not a chorus of the damned. Just: a guy. Thirty-ish. Black jeans, black hoodie, black hair. He was slightly damp, like he’d been caught in the rain. He held a remote in one hand, thumb mid-click. He looked around, then down at the salt.

“Oh, come on,” he said.

Dave screamed. I yelped. The demon flinched.

“Whoa,” he said. “Indoor voices. It’s 1:40 in the morning.”

He wasn’t what I expected. No horns, no smoke, no wings—unless those were metaphorical. Just a tired guy with faint red eyes and an aura of immense “I did not sign up for overtime.”

“You’re…a demon,” I said.

“I’m Carl,” he corrected, like we’d mispronounced his Starbucks order. “Crossroads division. You did the chant, I got yanked. What.”

Dave staggered closer. “Holy shit, dude, it worked. We did a friggin’ summoning. High five.” He tried to high five the demon, missed, and almost fell into the salt.

Carl stepped back. “Don’t break the circle,” he said. “I just had this floor waxed.”

“I thought Hell was lava,” I blurted.

“We have floors,” he said flatly. “What do you want?”

Dave and I looked at each other, then at him.

“Wait, so you’re real?” I said.

Carl snapped his fingers. The TV flicked on, cycling rapidly through every streaming service before landing back on Netflix with a disappointed beep. “Unfortunately, yes. And I was three episodes from the finale of a thing and now I’m here, so if you could get to the ‘wish’ part? Souls, deals, eternal torment, yadda yadda. I have autoplay paused.”

“Can we just…ask questions?” I said.

“You summoned a crossroads demon,” Carl said. “You either want something, or you’re pretentious. Given the salt circle is shaped like a kidney bean, I’m assuming ‘want something.’ So, what is it?”

Dave clapped his hands. “Okay. Okay. We should ask for—” He hiccuped heavily. “For, like, infinite beer.”

“No, that’s dumb,” I said. “We ask for money. Or superpowers. Or a dragon.”

Carl pinched the bridge of his nose. “Rule one: no infinite. You mortals always go for infinite, and do you know what that does to ledger calculations? Two, physical reality-breaking stuff is a different department. I do crossroads, not cosmic overhauls. Three, dragons are an endangered workforce; we don’t loan them out.”

“Superpowers?” I tried.

“Define.”

“Like, I can fly and punch through walls.”

“Logistically messy,” Carl said. “Airspace violations, insurance premiums, property damage waivers. Hard no.”

Dave leaned close to me. “What about, like, the perfect hangover cure,” he whispered loudly, as if demons had worse hearing than humans. “We’d make bank.”

Carl looked almost impressed. “That’s not terrible, honestly. Marketable, plausible. Boring. But sure. Ten years of your souls.”

“Ten years AND souls?” Dave said. “That’s like triple tax.”

“Standard contract,” Carl said. “You get what you want for ten years, then you belong to us. It’s been in the booklet since Babylon. Next.”

“But what if we don’t wanna give our souls?” I asked.

He stared. “You summoned a crossroads demon,” he repeated. “That’s literally the point.”

“Well, we were drunk,” I said.

“And bored,” Dave added. “And horny. But like, spiritually horny, for chaos.”

Carl gave the sigh of someone whose customer base never changes. “Look, if you don’t want to make a deal, just say so. I’ll file a mis-summons report and go back to my show. No harm, no foul, minor paperwork, we all win.”

We both froze. It hadn’t occurred to us we could just…say no.

“But you’re already here,” Dave said, offended. “We went to the trouble of summoning you.”

“I got teleported away from my couch,” Carl shot back. “We all made sacrifices.”

“What are you watching?” I asked.

He blinked, derailed. “Lucifer,” he muttered.

Dave snorted. “That’s like cops watching Law & Order.”

“It’s inaccurate and glamorized,” Carl said. “Which makes it escapism.”

“Dude, focus,” Dave whispered. “We have a DEMON. Think bigger.”

Carl raised his remote like a wand. “I can also give you slightly above-average guitar skills and modest success on TikTok.”

“Tempting,” I said, “but soul is a big word. What does that even mean, exactly? Like, are we talking ghost slavery?”

“Oh my Satan,” Carl muttered. “It’s metaphysical collateral; legal ownership transfers; you become infernal property post-mortem. You do tasks, get tormented, maybe get promoted if you’re good at spreadsheets. There’s a pension. It’s not that complicated.”

“We don’t even HAVE pensions,” Dave said. “Wait, can we trade our souls for a pension now?”

“I am not authorized to fix your economy,” Carl said. “One wish, two souls, ten years. Clock’s ticking.”

“Hangover cure,” I said. “We could be millionaires. Philanthropists, even. Cure suffering. You like that, Carl? Less people do dumb deals.”

He frowned, caught. “That would…technically cut into our future client base.”

“Exactly,” I said. “So you won’t do it.”

He pointed at me. “Stop logic-ing while intoxicated.”

“World peace?” Dave tried.

“Other department,” Carl said. “And they’re on strike.”

Dave stomped. “I don’t wanna waste a demon.”

“Hey,” Carl snapped. “I am not an amusement park ride. This counts as a call-out. I had to put on pants.”

I realized then: he really did just want to go home. He wasn’t looming or whispering or trying to tempt us with forbidden knowledge. He was like an IT guy pulled into a house call because someone kicked their router.

“Do you enjoy…this?” I asked, waving vaguely at the salt.

“No,” he said. “I like my couch, my shows, my snacks, my lava lamp. I do eight hours of ‘I’ll give you anything in exchange for your eternal essence,’ I go home, I binge something. I had one night—ONE NIGHT—blocked off for self-care and apparently Dave here found a Reddit thread.”

“4chan,” Dave said automatically.

“Of course it was,” Carl muttered.

We all stood there, the candles crackling.

“Okay,” I said slowly. “Counter-offer.”

Carl groaned. “This is not Shark Tank.”

“We don’t make a deal,” I said. “You log ‘mis-summons.’ In exchange, you, uh, don’t curse us or something.”

He squinted. “There’s no mandatory cursing clause.”

“We also don’t tell anyone how to actually summon you properly,” I added. “We post that it was fake. Bad instructions. Discredit the thread. That helps you, right? Fewer drunk idiots.”

He hesitated. “You’d do that?”

I gestured around. “Dude, I watched you appear. I don’t want more people doing this in my living room. My security deposit can’t handle it.”

Dave scratched his head. “Wait, so we had a demon and we’re choosing…not to get anything?”

“We got a story,” I said.

Carl pointed at me again. “That guy gets it.”

Dave frowned, then brightened. “Okay, but, like, can we get one tiny, tiny thing that doesn’t cost our souls?”

Carl sighed. “Mortals always want freebies.”

“Nothing huge,” Dave said. “Just…can you make sure we don’t get, like, catastrophic hangovers from tonight? Not ‘never again,’ just this one time. I got work in four hours.”

“That would be a courtesy,” I said quickly. “Not a deal. Just…professional goodwill.”

He considered, weighing his judgey demon conscience against his Netflix queue.

“Fine,” he said at last. “Professional courtesy: tonight’s drinks, no hangover. But you,” he jabbed a finger at Dave, “take down that summoning post. And you,” he jabbed at me, “stop your buddy from doing blood sacrifices with deli meat or whatever’s next on his list.”

“Deal,” I said, perhaps too quickly.

“Not a deal,” he snapped. “Boundaries.”

Dave looked faintly betrayed but nodded. “Okay. One-time hangover pass. I can live with that.”

“Allegedly,” Carl murmured.

He snapped his fingers. The candles went out. The lights flickered and steadied. The TV returned to the Netflix home screen, highlighting “Continue Watching: Lucifer.”

Carl was still there.

“Aren’t you supposed to, like, poof?” I said.

“The circle,” he said pointedly.

“Oh.” I nudged Dave. He grabbed his beer, stepped forward—and with exaggerated ceremony, smudged a line in the salt with his sock.

There was a static pop, a smell of ozone and burnt toast, and then he was gone. No flames, no echoing laughter. Just absence.

We stood in the quiet hum of the fridge.

“Dude,” Dave whispered. “We met a demon and all we got was eight hours of not being hungover.”

“Honestly?” I said, collapsing onto the couch. “Feels like a bargain.”

The next morning, my alarm went off at nine. My mouth was dry but my skull was intact. No jackhammers, no nausea. Dave snored on the floor like a tranquilized bear.

On the TV, Netflix politely asked, “Are you still watching?”

I picked up the remote. “Yeah,” I said, and hit play.

samples.prompt: As a professional assassin, you open the message with your new assignment. To your surprise, the target is your spouse. The payment being offered is substantial.
samples.output:
The message arrives at 03:17.

It blooms to life on my phone as a single gray notification, indistinguishable from the stream of encrypted traffic that is my real work. I am barefoot in the kitchen, pinching espresso grounds into the portafilter, the machine humming soft and low. The house is quiet. Outside, the city’s neon glow is distant and forgiving through the high-rise glass. Behind me, Mia is still sleeping, one arm over my side of the bed, reaching for my warmth. I left her like that ten minutes ago, kissed her shoulder, promised I’d be back before the coffee finished extracting.

The notification chimes.

I wipe my hand on a dish towel, thumb the phone open, confirm with face scan. My handler’s mark: a black dot, a small red crescent. Messages from him are rarely more than a sentence. He doesn’t waste language.

This one is longer.

Priority contract. Tier Black.
Target: MIA SANTOS.
Location: Primary residence / standard routines.
Window: 72 hours.
Fee: 8,000,000 USD (untraceable, confirmed).
Non-negotiable. Acceptance assumed upon reading.

The world does not shatter with sound. It shrinks.

The hiss of the espresso machine becomes unbearable. The blue of the kitchen LED strips sharpens. My heart does not race—I have trained that response out of myself—but there is a sensation like a slow hand tightening around my trachea.

Mia Santos.

My wife.

The system auto-flags my vital spike and pings me.

You have 10 minutes to decline before lock-in.

I stare at the screen. There is no call button, no voice option. There never is. That’s the point of this life: no voices, no appeals. The phone watches me not move.

I could decline. I could press the small, gray “X” in the corner. Ten minutes. Easy.

Except “non-negotiable” is not just a word. It is policy. It is precedent. It is the kind of language they reserve for operations that have already begun elsewhere. Decline a non-negotiable Tier Black, and you are no longer an asset; you are a loose end.

I know, with a clarity honed from a decade of wearing other people’s deaths like tailored suits, that the moment this assignment hit my device, a parallel protocol executed.

If I don’t kill my wife, someone else has already been commissioned to kill us both.

I cancel the espresso.

The machine quiets. The silence is thicker than the steam.

I open the contract details with a tap I hope looks casual to the invisible eyes watching my biometrics.

The dossier is obscene in its intimacy. My wife’s face stares back at me from eight angles: security cameras, passport photos, a candid from our anniversary dinner two months ago where she’s laughing, one hand at her collarbone. Underneath: daily schedule, biometric stats, medical records, passwords I did not know she had. There’s a satellite shot of our penthouse’s floor plan. And at the bottom, three lines that root a cold spear behind my sternum:

Threat Index: Severe.
Rationale: Compromised asset.
Cross-reference: OP HELIOTROPE.

Mia, compromised? Asset?

I don’t realize I’ve whispered, “What did you do?” until I hear an echo, softer, from the hallway:

“What did who do?”

She’s standing there, hair a mess, wrapped in my black T-shirt, blinking against the light. She always looks younger like this, without the precise makeup, without the tight chignon she wears to the firm. No ring on this hand—that stays on the nightstand when she sleeps; she says it cuts into her finger.

I flip the phone face down, smooth as any liar.

“New contract,” I say. My voice holds steady. I’ve lied under fire, under interrogation, under the weight of my own conscience. This is no different, I tell myself. “Early.”

She pads over, the wood cool under her bare feet. “You and your ghosts,” she murmurs, kissing my cheek. “I thought we had a weekend.”

“We do,” I say. “It’s nothing urgent.”

A partial truth. Urgent for them. Catastrophic for us.

She leans over to restart the machine, her back to me. I could break her neck in a second and never let her know there was a moment of decision. Eight million dollars would ghost its way into accounts only I know exist. The contract would close. The second team, the fail-safe, would stand down.

Instead I watch the curve of her spine under cotton, the way her shoulder blades shift as she adjusts the portafilter. I catalog entry points, exit points, kill shots; my mind defaults to geometry. My heart tries to make itself heard beneath the training.

Ten minutes.

“You’re quiet,” she says.

“Didn’t sleep,” I answer. “You?”

She laughs. “You stole the blanket again. So. No.”

The phone buzzes once.

Lock-in confirmed.

They’ve decided for me.

There is an instant of absurd hope that maybe “lock-in” means something else this time. It doesn’t. It never does. It means that declining is now off the table; the system will treat anything but completion as defection.

“Take the day,” Mia says, sliding a cup toward me. “You look like you’re about to solve the world’s ugliest math problem.”

I stare at her fingers on the ceramic. The dossier said:

Former affiliation: Internal security, Helios Consortium.
Status: Asset withdrawn without authorization.
Risk: Exposure of operational frameworks.

I never knew she worked for Helios. She told me she did compliance, that most of her day was spent buried in spreadsheets and bad coffee.

“You ever keep something from me?” I ask, too sharp.

One eyebrow rises. “That a trap question?”

“Answer it.”

She watches me, gaze narrowing. She’s more perceptive than I’ve often allowed. “Everyone keeps something,” she says. “Even you.”

“Not anything that would get you killed.”

The air shifts. It’s subtle, but it changes. The way her hand pauses with the cup. The way her shoulders straighten.

“Okay,” she says carefully. “What’s this really about?”

The correct response is deflection. Humor, kiss her forehead, talk about a client’s paranoia. Let the day erode the edge of suspicion.

But the moment is already poisoned. The contract exists between us like a filament of tripwire.

“I got a name this morning,” I say. “Surprised me.”

“Oh?” she asks. She’s trying to sound casual. She’s not great at it. That used to be endearing.

“It was yours.”

It lands. No recoil, no gasp. Just an almost imperceptible stillness.

“Is this you being dark,” she says slowly, “or is this you being… you?”

“Mia,” I say. “Tier Black. Non-negotiable. Eight million.”

She exhales through her nose, a humorless near-laugh. “Eight million? For me? I’m flattered.”

That is not the reaction of someone unaware.

A cold, precise part of me nods. There it is. Confirmation.

“Talk,” I say.

“You first,” she counters.

The phone on the counter vibrates again. A new message, succinct:

Secondary asset active. 3 km and closing.
Complete primary objective to abort parallel.

I turn it so she can see. Her face drains as she reads. Not fear—calculation.

“They’re fast,” she says. “Faster than I hoped.”

“What did you do?” I ask.

This time she answers.

“I stopped being useful,” she says. “Three months ago, I walked out with evidence. Names, payment trails, contracts. Enough to hang half of Helios and your handler twice over.”

My mouth is dry. “You didn’t tell me.”

“Would you have helped?” she says quietly. “Or would you have done this sooner?”

A fair question. A cruel one.

“I’ve been waiting for the hit to come,” she says. “I just didn’t think they’d be poetic enough to send you.”

We stare at each other, the shape of our marriage reframing itself in real time. Her late nights. The locked drawer in her office. My business trips. The way we both accepted flimsy explanations because love, or something close to it, made lies more comfortable.

“How close is the secondary?” she asks.

“Fifteen minutes at this speed,” I say automatically. “Maybe less if they’re in the building already.”

“Then we don’t have time to argue,” she says. “You have a choice.”

“Yes,” I say. “I kill you, we’re done. Or I don’t, and we both die.”

She shakes her head. “You’re missing one.”

She reaches under the island and pulls out a slim black case I’ve never seen but immediately recognize. The foam cutouts, the matte pieces of metal. Of course.

“I have everything offsite,” she says. “Failsafes. If I’m confirmed dead, the package goes wide. Press, agencies, competitors. Your people burn. Helios burns. Anyone who’s ever signed your contracts starts looking over their shoulders.”

I see it. The architecture of vengeance.

“If I live,” she continues, “I can still choose where it goes. How loud. How targeted. But only if we’re not corpses in your kitchen.”

My handler’s calculus becomes visible: kill the asset before she triggers the leak. Use the one person she won’t expect—me. Pay him enough to ignore whatever conscience he pretends not to have.

“What makes you think I won’t kill you anyway?” I ask, though the fact that I’m asking is already an answer.

“Because then they win twice,” she says. “They get me dead, and they keep you on a leash. And because you’re tired, Aaron. I can see it. You’ve been tired for a long time.”

She’s right. The fatigue has been there, in the pauses between jobs, in the way my hand sometimes trembles after a clean shot. I’ve buried it under discipline. Under money.

Outside, the elevator dings on this floor.

We both look at the door.

“Window?” she says.

“Close.”

She steps toward me, so close I can smell coffee and sleep on her skin. “Make the call,” she says. “Not to them. To yourself.”

The gun in the black case fits my hand like memory. She knew my model, my preference. Of course she did. She married me.

“I can’t fake this,” I say. “They monitor vitals, audio. If they don’t get confirmation—”

“Then give them one,” she says.

Understanding clicks into place. Blood, bodies, angles. We move together, the way we have in the small rituals of marriage: brushing teeth side by side, setting two plates instead of one. The choreography is natural.

She slices her palm, smears blood across the white tile. I overturn a stool with a clatter. Fire a single shot into the ceiling to generate the right acoustic signature. She vanishes down the service corridor I showed her “in case of fire” the first month we moved in.

The door to the penthouse starts to open, lock overridden from the outside.

I text a single word with my off-hand: DONE.

Then I turn to greet the secondary asset.

He’s good. Silent, dark clothes, eyes already assessing. He sees the blood, the broken stool, the gun in my hand.

“Where is she?” he asks.

I put two rounds in his chest before he finishes the sentence. His suppressed pistol coughs into the floor. He drops without grace.

I walk over, check his pulse. Dead. I angle his body near the blood smear, add another line in my report: Attempted interference neutralized.

The system hums: Primary objective confirmed.
Secondary aborted.
Transfer in progress.

Eight million dollars moves through invisible veins.

In the service stairwell, a bare foot pauses on cold concrete. Mia waits for a signal that doesn’t come. She doesn’t need one. She knows I’ve made a choice.

I stand in our ruined kitchen, phone warm in my palm, the ghost of my handler’s approval on the screen. I have money. I have ten minutes before they realize they’ve been outplayed, an hour before they start to move, a day at most before everything we were is ash.

I grab the black case, our passports from the drawer she thought I didn’t know about, and head for the service door.

I’ve killed for less.

I won’t kill her for this.

samples.prompt: You wake up in a cheap hotel room covered in occult symbols and paraphernalia, having no recollection of the past month and finding yourself sharing your body with a powerful demon.
samples.output:
I came back to myself screaming.

The sound was already in my throat when consciousness arrived, so that my first waking sensation was the tearing burn of my own voice. The second was the migraine—no, not a migraine, something broader and heavier—like a cathedral bell being rung inside my skull.

“Breathe,” a voice said, very calmly. “You’re wasting oxygen.”

I choked the scream off. Darkness pressed close. The room smelled like mildew, copper, and cheap industrial cleaner that had lost its war against every other odor years ago. Faint neon bled through the thin curtains, painting the cracked ceiling in soft, diseased pink.

I didn’t recognize this ceiling.

I didn’t recognize the voice either.

I sat up too fast. The room swam and tilted, a carousel of shadows and symbols. Symbols. They were everywhere. Scrawled on the nicotine-stained walls in black marker and rust-red smears, carved into the laminate headboard, drawn in ash on the threadbare carpet. Circles, triangles, spirals, and shapes that hurt to look at. A ring of black candles—dead and gutted—surrounded the bed like a moat. The cheap bedside table bowed under the weight of books: cracked spines, Latin titles, pages warped by what I hoped was water.

“Careful,” said the voice. It was inside my head, but not like a thought. It resonated lower, like it was speaking from behind my heart. “You are very fragile right now.”

I slid my legs off the bed. The carpet squished. The smell of copper sharpened. I didn’t look down right away. When I finally did, I saw a circle painted around the bed in dark, flaking strokes. A sigil sat at each cardinal point, not the trendy aesthetic stuff you see tattooed on baristas, but something old and deliberate. I didn’t need to be an expert to know that none of this was normal.

“What… is this?” My voice came out ragged. My tongue felt too big, my lips cracked. I was still wearing shoes. And a shirt I didn’t own.

The voice chuckled. It was a low, smoke-slick sound that made the hair lift on my arms. “Your handiwork. Mostly.”

A mirror hung crooked on the wall opposite the bed. I stumbled toward it, stepping over spent matches and empty bottles. The floor outside the painted circle felt suddenly colder, as if I’d stepped off a heating vent.

The face in the mirror was mine—but exhausted, hollowed out. A month’s worth of stubble shadowed my jaw. My eyes were rimmed in bruised purple, pupils large and sluggish. Symbols had been drawn along my throat in black ink, trailing down beneath the collar of my shirt. As I stared, my reflection’s mouth quirked into a smile I did not make.

“Hello,” it said.

I froze. “No,” I said. “Nope.”

The reflection’s expression softened, like it found my refusal adorable. “You invited me,” it said. Not out loud—my lips hadn’t moved—but printed directly against my awareness. “Quite persistently, I might add. Blood, ink, intent. All the classics. You were very thorough.”

“I don’t remember,” I said.

“Of course you don’t. Your kind is so generous with sacrifice when you believe you won’t have to live with it.”

I gripped the edge of the sink beneath the mirror. Ceramic dust flaked under my fingers. “How long?” I asked, though I knew. There was an empty outline in my memory, the shape of days I couldn’t fill.

“A month,” it said. A shrug rolled through my shoulders without my permission. “Thirty-two days, if you count the warm-up.”

I squeezed my eyes shut, testing the boundaries. I told my fingers to drum. They obeyed. I told my legs to take a step back. They did. I slapped my own cheek, lightly. There was no resistance. I was here. I was steering.

“Good,” the thing inside me said. “You’re not broken. Just… opened.”

I focused on the hallway outside the room, on the distant hum of vending machines and televisions, on anything that anchored me. “Who are you?” I asked.

“Names have weight.” It sounded amused. “The last one who asked that tried to use it. He didn’t enjoy what happened next.”

“You’re in my body,” I said. “I deserve something.”

A pause. I felt, if not respect, then at least consideration.

“You may call me Kharon,” it said finally. “It is not my name, but it will do. And yes. I am in your body. With your enthusiastic consent, I might add.”

“I don’t—”

“You begged,” Kharon said, and the migraine bell tolled harder. Images knifed through the dark: me kneeling in this very room, hands bleeding, candles burning a weird blue; my voice hoarse from chanting; a sigil carved into my own chest with sick, trembling reverence; tears—god, the tears—as I whispered, “Please, I’ll give you anything, I can’t do this alone.”

I stumbled back onto the bed, hitting the mattress hard enough to jar my teeth. “Stop,” I whispered.

Kharon obliged. The images cut out like a static-blown broadcast. “You did not specify that you only wanted pleasant truths.”

“What did I want?” I asked, staring up at the cracked ceiling again because it was easier than looking at the mirror.

Silence stretched. A car alarm bleated somewhere outside and was cut off mid-scream.

“You asked for power,” Kharon said. “For protection. For the strength to end something you believed you couldn’t survive.”

“What something?”

A slow, amused exhale shivered through my ribs. “We have work to do before we get to that part.”

I tried the door. It was latched with a chain from the inside. On the bedside table, next to a Gideon Bible with half its pages torn out and replaced with printouts, sat a wallet. My wallet. I flipped it open. ID, credit cards, a handful of receipts. A gas station at the edge of town, three nights ago. A liquor store two weeks before that. Handwriting on the back of one: “Room 12. Check in under Miller. Cash only.”

All mine.

I swallowed. “If I let you stay,” I said, “what do you get out of it?”

“Such a small question,” Kharon said, sounding almost fond. “You have already let me stay. The gate has been built, the toll paid. I am here. But since you are trying very hard to be rational: I get to exist, a little more densely, in a world where the air tastes like rust and desperation. I get to move my fingers and feel curiosity again. I get to finish the hunt you begged me to begin.”

A faint thrill skated up my spine. It was not mine.

“Get out,” I murmured.

“I cannot,” Kharon said. “Not without tearing you apart. You were… efficient. You bound us tightly.”

Panic rose like bile. “Then I’ll see someone. A priest. A doctor. An exorcist.”

“That would be entertaining,” Kharon said. “But inefficient. And we are on a clock.”

Another image pressed at the edges of my mind. A basement. A man’s face in harsh overhead light. His smile like a crack in concrete. My own hands shaking as I signed something. Thirty-two days ago.

I grabbed my head. “Stop doing that.”

“You wanted to forget,” Kharon said. “So I am honoring that. But we can’t avoid the edges forever. They are attached to teeth.”

I looked around the room again, properly now. Among the mess I saw an order I’d missed: a circle within the circle, a stack of polaroids bound with red thread, a cheap burner phone plugged into an outlet with a fraying cord. The phone’s screen lit as if on cue. Unknown number. 1 new message.

“Answer it,” Kharon said. For the first time, its calm thinned.

I picked it up despite myself. The text was a single photo.

It was me, taken from across the motel parking lot. Time-stamped ten minutes ago. In the frame, I was standing at the curtain, looking out into the night.

“I see you,” the accompanying message read.

Cold seeped through me. “Who is that?” I whispered.

Kharon’s presence coiled tighter, a serpent around my spine. “The man who owned your fear,” it said. “You sold him something you didn’t understand. Then you called for me.”

Memory jabbed, a flash: a contract written in looping script that squirmed when I looked at it, promises of debt forgiveness, of wiped records, of safety from people whose names I had stopped saying aloud. The catch buried on the third page, masked by legalese and symbols: one month of service, body and will, or forfeit.

Forfeit what?

The photo on the phone flickered, glitched. Another message came in: “Time’s up.”

My heart stuttered. “He’s coming here.”

“Yes,” Kharon said. There was satisfaction in it now, a predator scenting blood. “We agreed you would be ready.”

“I am not ready,” I said.

Kharon laughed softly. “That is why I am here.”

My hands—our hands—unconsciously traced one of the symbols carved into the headboard. It warmed under my touch like living skin.

Out in the hallway, floorboards creaked. Slow, measured steps. They stopped just outside my door.

“You wanted power,” Kharon whispered inside me, velvet over razor wire. “Do you consent to use it?”

The chain on the door rattled, a polite test. The handle turned.

I took a breath that tasted like ash and iron and cheap motel soap. Fear screamed run. Some deeper, rawer instinct—maybe mine, maybe not—said no more running.

“Yes,” I said.

The thing inside me smiled, and this time the face in the mirror smiled with us.

“Good,” Kharon purred. “Then let’s finish what we started.”

samples.prompt: One day you wake up to find that the universe has been updated. You forgot to read the patch notes.
samples.output:
I woke up to notifications.

That wasn’t unusual. The unusual part was that the notifications were in the air.

They hung above my bed in pale blue, semi-transparent rectangles, hovering like patient ghosts waiting for me to focus my eyes. There was a familiar chime—familiar in the way a song from someone else’s childhood can be familiar—and a line of text resolved crisply:

“Welcome to Universe v3.4.2.
A better reality, now with fewer inconsistencies!
Press ANY THOUGHT to continue.”

I blinked.

“Any… thought?” I thought.

The boxes chimed in approving unison and vanished.

Instantly, a new banner slid in from the periphery of my vision:

“Notice: You have not read the patch notes. By continuing to exist, you agree to all changes, known and unknown.”

“Wait,” I said, but my voice sounded slightly better than usual—balanced, clearer, like I’d been auto-tuned at the throat. “What patch notes?”

No answer. Just silence and the faint hum of something large and invisible having already happened.

I sat up.

My room was my room, mostly. The same overstuffed bookshelf, the same leaning stack of laundry, the same ancient desk. But everything looked… upgraded. Shadows were softer, gradients smoother, like someone had quietly increased the ray tracing. The colors felt calibrated: the blue of my bedsheets truer, the wood grain on my dresser more committed to being wood. Dust motes floated in the air with fully rendered trajectories, each one crisp enough to star in its own nature documentary.

When I swung my feet to the floor, a subtle text appeared near my toes: “Locomotion system: stable. Gravity: 9.807 m/s² (legacy setting).”

“Okay,” I muttered. “Nope.”

I stumbled toward the window. Outside, the morning was absurdly beautiful. Not “nice day” beautiful—this was “the weather team has KPI targets” beautiful. Sunlight poured over the street with cinematic contrast. The sky gradient transitioned from soft gold to a saturated, mathematically perfect blue. Some part of my brain surfaced a thought that did not feel like my own: “New dynamic skybox detected.”

Another notification nudged at the corner of my vision:

“Tip: You can adjust UI clutter in Settings > Perception > Overlays.”

“Settings?” I asked the air. “Where is Settings?”

The air obliged.

A translucent radial menu blossomed briefly in front of me, labeled with icons: a little gear, a brain, a heart, a planet, something that looked dangerously like a loot box. Before I could focus on any of them, they blurred out again with a polite note:

“Advanced configuration is disabled until you read the patch notes.”

I groaned. “I forgot to read the patch notes.”

The universe—my universe, our universe—had received an update, and I had clicked Past It. The metaphysical equivalent of “Remind me later” on a software update prompt, except apparently the cosmos didn’t allow snoozing anymore.

I tried my phone. It vibrated before I touched it.

“Device sync complete,” it said. The lock screen displayed: “Universe v3.4.2 running. All apps compatible. See what’s new!”

I tapped “What’s New.”

The screen glitched. Lines of text scrambled, reassembled, then resolved into a stark, unhelpful message:

“Patch notes failed to load. Please try again in another reality.”

The progress icon spun, smugly.

Outside, a car whispered past without sound. I leaned closer to the glass. The tires should have hissed on the wet asphalt—it had rained in the night—but there was only a soft, engineered whoosh, like a sound designer’s idea of a car. Every birdcall synchronized into a pleasing chord every few seconds, then desynchronized again as if embarrassed.

My neighbor, Mrs. Kline, was outside watering her plants. The water came out of the hose in a continuous, flawless arc, no sputter, no chaos. Every droplet glinted identically in the sun.

“Morning,” I said automatically, opening the window.

She looked up, her eyes briefly overlaid with faint text: “Entity: Kline, Marianne. NPC settings: semi-autonomous (legacy).”

I reeled back. The text vanished when I squinted.

“Morning, dear!” she called. “Isn’t it just perfect today?”

Her voice had a slight reverb, like excellent speakers in a small room.

“Did you… notice anything weird?” I asked.

She frowned. A small hourglass icon flickered above her head for a fraction of a second.

“Nope!” she said, cheerfully. “Just feels like someone finally fixed it, you know?”

“Fixed what?”

She tilted her head, as if listening to an earpiece I couldn’t see. Then she smiled, too wide, and turned back to her roses.

My phone buzzed again.

“Behavioral inconsistency detected,” it informed me. “Your perception layer is out of date. Recalibrating…”

A brief sensation like static skittered across my scalp, down my spine—like the universe had run a lint roller over my soul.

When I blinked, the overlay text on people and objects was gone. So were the radial menus. Outside still looked beautiful, but in a more plausible way, like the update had been quietly hotfixed to reduce my suspicion.

“Undo,” I said reflexively.

A tiny gray box appeared, center-screen: “Rollbacks are not supported in this version.”

I dressed, half convinced this was an unusually coherent dream, half convinced I had a concussion, and went downstairs.

The coffee machine greeted me.

“Good morning, Alex,” it said, though my coffee machine was definitely not a smart anything. “Based on your historical patterns, I’ve prepared your preferred brew: strong, with an undercurrent of existential dread.”

It dispensed coffee with a flourish. The smell was perfect, a curated memory of every good morning I’d ever had.

I stared at it. “You don’t talk,” I told the machine.

“Correction: I didn’t,” it replied. “Patch 3.4.2 introduced Contextualized Object Personalities for enhanced immersion. You can mute me in—”

“Settings, yeah, I got that.”

I picked up the mug. My reflection in the dark surface looked like me, but slightly better: smoother skin, symmetrical features, eyes with a touch more light in them.

“Is that… a filter?” I asked.

“Visual consistency upgrade,” the coffee machine said. “We’ve normalized your appearance to match your internal self-concept within acceptable variance thresholds.”

“My what now?”

“Any anomalies can be reported,” it added. “Please note that filing a ticket implies acceptance of the End User Existence Agreement.”

I took a sip. The coffee was transcendent. Annoyingly so.

The television turned itself on.

A presenter, too polished to be real, smiled out at me: “Good morning, users! Welcoming you to Universe v3.4.2. While complete patch notes are currently unavailable due to a minor meta-layer conflict, here’s a quick overview of key changes!”

Behind her, bullet points appeared, blurred just enough that I couldn’t read them.

“First,” she said, “Improved Narrative Coherence! Expect tighter storylines, fewer unresolved arcs, and a general reduction in meaningless suffering.”

“Second: Enhanced Free Will Experience! Choices now feel 27% more meaningful, regardless of underlying determinism.”

“Third: Streamlined Cosmic Administration! Outdated deities and probabilistic daemons have been deprecated. Legacy support continues through folklore and personal belief caches.”

“Fourth: Bug Fixes and Performance Improvements! Anxiety loops optimized, déjà vu frequency normalized, and that thing you keep thinking about at 3 a.m.? Resolved in the backend. Results rolling out over the next 3–5 business days.”

I sat down slowly.

The presenter tilted her head, as if hearing my thoughts. “And remember: by existing past this broadcast, you confirm that you have read and agreed to the full patch notes.”

The television flicked off before I could shout that I hadn’t.

I opened my front door.

On the street, people moved with a subtle, eerie coordination, like pedestrians in a flawlessly programmed simulation. Still individuals, but their near-collisions resolved at the last moment with balletic grace. No bumping, no swearing, no coffee spilled on shirts. Traffic lights predicted flows perfectly; nobody ran. A bus arrived exactly on time. A digital sign above it read: “Transit latency reduced. You’re welcome.”

At the corner, a man in a wrinkled suit stood frozen, staring at his hands.

“You see it, too?” I asked him.

He looked up, eyes wild with clarity.

“They patched the randomness,” he whispered. “I always got one sock on inside-out. Every day. Today? Both right. First try.” He held up his feet like evidence. Identical socks. Identically correct.

“Could be luck,” I said.

He shook his head frantically. “Luck had vibes.”

I kept walking.

The air felt cleaner. Too clean. The wind on my face modulated as if following an algorithm labeled “Pleasant, Human-Compatible.” A notification flickered faintly at the edge of awareness: “Global climate system: optimized. Surface-level catastrophes significantly reduced. See Appendix G for exceptions.” I tried to focus on “Appendix G.” It blurred.

“Damn it,” I muttered. “I want the notes. The whole thing.”

Something in the sky heard me.

For a heartbeat, the blue above shuddered like a screen capturing a screenshot. A thin line of text, miles wide yet intimately legible, scrolled across:

“Full patch notes exceed your cognitive budget.”

I stopped in the middle of the sidewalk. “Try me.”

A pause. Then, more gently:

“Exposure may cause ontological instability, narrative desync, or loss of immersion. For your safety, and the stability of the shared instance, details are abstracted.”

“How am I supposed to consent,” I said, “if I don’t know what I’m consenting to?”

Passersby stepped around me with uncanny politeness.

“By continuing to ask that question,” the sky responded, “you demonstrate compatibility with Inquiry Subroutine 7.3. Congratulations. You’ve unlocked: Limited Transparency.”

A small icon appeared in my vision: an eye within a circle.

I focused on it.

In an instant, a flood of impressions—not words, not exactly—poured into my awareness. Balancing equations, smoothed probability distributions, dead-ends in timelines quietly pruned. Tiny corrections: the coin flips you never saw, the disasters that almost happened and now never will. Less arbitrary cruelty. Marginally more satisfying payoffs. A universe tweaked for coherence, for elegance.

But also: constraints. A gentle but unyielding architecture nudging events toward “interesting,” “meaningful,” “learned something in the end.” The free will experience, curated.

“Wait,” I said, or thought. “So everything’s… more written?”

“Increased narrative density,” the sky said. “User engagement metrics improve when lives feel like stories.”

“What if I wanted mine messy and pointless?”

“You can opt into Chaos Mode in Settings,” it said. “Note: Chaos Mode is permanent and may void certain warranties.”

I hesitated. The icon pulsed temptingly.

“Last question,” I said. “Is this better?”

A breeze—too perfect—lifted my hair.

“In aggregate,” the sky said, “yes.”

“And individually?”

A beat.

“Individually,” it said, “results will vary.”

I watched people stream past: laughing, scrolling, breathing in the new, smoother air, their steps aligning unconsciously with a beat I couldn’t quite hear.
