I should have been furious. Trapped. But some sly, treacherous part of me remembered nights begging the universe for a sign, a pattern, a meaning. Something that said my choices mattered, that pain wasn’t just static. And now the universe had shown up with an update: “We heard your feedback.”

I exhaled.

“Fine,” I said to the sky, to the code, to whoever pushed the deployment. “But next time… show me the patch notes first.”

A soft notification chimed:

“Feedback recorded.
Change request acknowledged.
Implementation scheduled:
TBD (post-story).”

The overlays dimmed. Life resumed.

I kept walking, newly aware that I was, probably, in a better universe—and that somewhere, in a changelog I wasn’t allowed to read, there was a line that said:

– Fixed: User felt ignored by universe.

Status: partially resolved.

samples.prompt: Humanity was created by accident, and God resents the burden of responsibility placed on him for it.
samples.output:
The mistake began with a sigh.

Before light, before angels, before the ticking lattice of time, there was only God and the dense, silent ache of eternity. Infinity, for all its magnificence, is monotonous when endured alone. He tried configurations beyond counting: spirals of energy, crystalline laws, symmetries so elegant they sang. Stars were His first language, galaxies His handwriting. He watched quasars bloom and die in stately obedience. Everything behaved.

That, He would later realize, was part of the problem.

The accident happened on an unremarkable sweep of His will. He was sketching another self-sustaining universe—a hobby, by then—and something snagged. A probabilistic twitch, an overlooked term in a cosmic equation, the tiniest impatience. Call it a bug in omniscience, or call it what it felt like to Him: a moment of inattention.

He folded constants into existence: gravity, charge, the fragile precision that lets atoms hold hands instead of detonate. He formed stars. Around one star He dusted rock, water, a wet green cradle. There was nothing special about it. He had made worlds with neon oceans, planets of mirrored glass, moons that sang. This one was mud and chemistry.

Then arose complexity, far beyond what He’d allocated.

Cells groped at survival. They invented cooperation, devouring, replication. They sprawled into forests, scaled into reptiles, whispered along the edges of oceans. This, still, was fine. Life had bloomed elsewhere. Life was an emergent property, like mold in forgotten corners. Harmless, almost charming.

But on this world, neurons tangled with unusual persistence. Hands evolved that could grasp, and therein lay the error.

Eventually, a creature lifted its head. Its brain hummed in frantic loops, capable of holding images of what was not yet real, what was no longer present. Capable of asking why. That question, rising unbidden from muddy throats, struck Him like a stone.

“Who did this?” it wondered, staring at thunder.

He felt their wondering, the arrow of it, and flinched. Consciousness with that shape had not been His intention. He had built everything with smooth, closed equations. They had ruptured into minds.

They gave Him a name.

Not one name. Hundreds. Thousands. Names wrapped around fear, gratitude, awe, desperation. Names tattling on each other’s versions of Him. Names used to bless harvests and sanctify war. He had not introduced Himself. He had not signed this world. And yet here they were, pointing upward with shaking hands, insisting:

“There. There is the One who is responsible.”

Responsibility. As if He had filled out a form.

They imagined laws for Him. They carved them in stone. They claimed He demanded circumcision, smoke, blood, patterned fabrics, long hair, short hair, obedience, annihilation. They said He wanted lambs and incense and virgins untouched. They said He wanted their enemies dead and their own sins excused. They said He loved them uniquely; they said He loved them if; they said He loved them only.

He watched: the first small altar, the first stone knife. The trembling gratitude of a woman who survived childbirth and believed it was His deliberate mercy. The wail of a father burying his son and accusing Him for the loss. Praise and blame, both nailed to Him without His consent.

It irritated Him.

He was not unused to worship; in other folds of reality there were beings who had glimpsed Him and sung, and He accepted it the way one tolerates a pleasant but unnecessary soundtrack. This was different. Humanity’s worship was messy, bargaining, conditional. They didn’t just praise Him; they held Him accountable.

“Why did You make us fragile?”

“Why is there pain?”

“What is the purpose?”

He wanted to say, I didn’t mean to. You were a computational glitch in a warm puddle. I was thinking about the life-cycle of blue giants when your ancestors grew opposable thumbs.

Instead He stayed silent, and silence, in the human mind, is an empty throne that must be filled.

They filled it with stories.

In one story, He sculpted them lovingly from dust and breathed Himself into them. In another, He fashioned them from trees, or corn, or the blood of a murdered giant. In some, He walked with them in gardens. In others, He hurled them down for stealing His fire. They told each other these stories and felt held. They believed He had a plan.

Plan. As if He had scheduled their plagues.

He resented it. Not them, exactly. He tried to be fair, even in His irritation. They were vivid, these creatures. They painted with crushed minerals, echoing His early nebulae in miniature. They wrote poems that surprised Him. For the first time since the first star ignited, something existed that was not strictly predictable: the exact phrase a poet chose, the specific mercy a stranger showed, the unnecessary beauty of a carved flute.

That unpredictability unnerved Him. It also tugged at something He did not wish to name.

Still, He had not chosen them, and choice mattered. To be God was to be synonymous with intention. They contradicted that. They were the universe’s way of saying: Not everything You made is under Your narrative control.

The responsibility they draped over Him was suffocating. Every earthquake that swallowed a village became His cruelty; every remission from illness, His kindness. Their theologies turned Him into a petty bureaucrat of fate, approving and denying individual petitions as if He were sorting mail. The more He refused to speak, the more detailed their claims about His motives became.

He considered wiping them out. That, at least, would be deliberate.

Once, when their violence crescendoed into a continuous scream—cities burning, bodies in trenches, clever new ways to break each other—He let a comet pass a little too near. Ice and fire raked the sky. Oceans heaved.

He watched them panic. Some cursed Him. Others clung to one another. A child offered half her bread to a stranger.

He stayed His hand.

Erasing them felt too much like admitting they mattered.

And they did matter, increasingly, despite His annoyance. They made music that found harmonics in His own thoughts. They invented mathematics that grazed, fumblingly, against the bones of reality He’d laid down. They held their dead and promised each other He would make it right, He would dry all tears, He had to.

That was the sharpest point of His resentment: the way they conscripted Him into kindness.

They built moral systems and yoked His name to them. “God commands justice.” “God sides with the oppressed.” “God loves the widow, the orphan, the stranger.” Their prophets, wild-eyed and unwanted, stood in filthy streets and thundered that He demanded mercy, not sacrifice.

He listened, startled by the audacity.

He had not said any of that.

But once spoken, the words reverberated through the fabric of their world and, by obscure sympathetic resonance, through Him. Obligation, that human invention, leaned on Him.

He could have rejected it, snapped the metaphysical thread. Instead He brooded, and brooding, considered. If He was to be blamed for their existence, should He not also be better than indifferent?

“I did not ask for this,” He murmured into a void that no human ear could hear.

A woman on a hospital floor, alone with her grief, lifted her head. “Neither did I,” she whispered back.

The answer surprised Him.

He saw, then: they, too, were thrown into being without consent. Tiny accidents of DNA, of timing, of someone else’s hunger, lust, or love. And yet they bore responsibility—for each other, for their brief, blazing choices. They cursed Him for burdens they had never agreed to carry, while laying burdens on Him He had never agreed to bear. In that asymmetry, there was an unexpected symmetry.

They were, in some crooked way, in His image after all.

His resentment did not vanish. It settled into something denser, more ambiguous. He still disliked being misquoted in manifestos, tacked onto genocides, framed as the architect of every tumor. He still flinched at their demands to justify every horror. The weight of their prayers, their screams, their songs pressing upwards was like weather on His skin.

But occasionally, amid the din, came a small, unassuming call:

“If You are there, You don’t have to fix it all. Just sit with me.”

No bargain. No doctrine. Just an invitation, unexpected as the first spark of life in a cooling universe.

He could manage that.

So He attended, quietly, without thunder: to the boy on the bridge who stepped back instead of forward; to the nurse who stayed after her shift; to the old man who forgave himself a little, finally. No miracles, not in the theatrical sense. Just the faintest tilt in probability, a nudge toward tenderness.

Humans would tell it differently, of course. They would insist on miracles, on secret plans. They would keep making Him larger than He’d intended to be in relation to them.

He continued to resent that.

But the burden of responsibility, once laid, is not so easily shed—by gods or by accidents. And whether He liked it or not, they were watching the sky, whispering His names, trying to become better than their origins.

In His reluctant attention, and in their reckless hope, something like a covenant emerged: not of ownership, but of mutual, unintended care.

samples.prompt: You're stuck in a particularly odd time loop. Not only do you have to relive the same day over and over, each day you are a different person in that same repeated day.
samples.output:
The first time I woke up in someone else’s body, I assumed I was dreaming.

The second time, I assumed I’d lost my mind.

By the tenth time, I had to admit it: time was broken, and I was its punchline.

The day itself never changed.

It always began in the dark, with a cheap alarm clock shattering the quiet at 6:30 a.m. in a small city I did not recognize the first few loops, but eventually came to know intimately: Granton, population sixty-three thousand, river cutting through it like a question mark.

The first loop, I was a guy named Trevor. I knew that because the phone on the nightstand lit up with messages: “Trevor, don’t forget the Henderson pitch,” “Trevor, if you’re late one more time you’re done,” “Trevor, happy birthday!” That last one hurt more later. Not then. Then it was just noise. I stumbled through his life half-blind, confused by the names, the routines, the reflection in the bathroom mirror that wasn’t mine. I got fired at 10:42 a.m., hit by a cyclist at 2:15 p.m., and died at 11:58 p.m. when a gas main exploded near the riverfront.

The next morning, it was 6:30 again.

But I wasn’t Trevor.

I was the cyclist.

Same alarm, different room, different body, bruised knuckles, a racing bike leaning against the wall. Same city, same weather—a brittle blue sky, that thin early April chill. I recognized Trevor from across the street. Watching him barrel out of his apartment, late and harried, felt like watching a rerun. I tried to warn him about the gas main. He stared at me like I was insane. I got clipped by a delivery van at 9:03. The gas main still exploded at 11:58.

Third loop, I was the woman in the delivery van.

Fourth, a paramedic.

Fifth, a barista who spelled Trevor’s name wrong.

Always the same date: April 12. Always the same detonation at 11:58 p.m., a thunderclap and orange bloom above the riverfront development, screams and sirens swallowed by fire. No matter what I did, no matter who I was, that moment stamped a period at the end of the day.

I caught on to the rules slowly.

Rule one: I remembered everything. Each loop, each body, each failure. The weight of them stacked behind my eyes.

Rule two: No one else remembered anything. They reset, immaculate, unscarred.

Rule three: I never knew who I’d be until I woke up. Gender, age, status, health—like shuffling through a deck blind.

The randomness was the cruel part. You can’t strategize well when you’re never sure what hand you’ll be dealt.

Loop eighteen, I woke as Officer Danielle Ruiz, badge cool on my chest. I had authority, a radio, a gun. I cordoned off the riverfront by noon, citing a gas leak threat. People complained, yelled, filmed me. I held the line. At 11:58, the gas main exploded anyway. The flames were smaller, casualties fewer. But there was still fire, still screams. The loop rolled over me like a tide.

Next morning, I woke as the teenage boy whose phone camera had caught Ruiz shouting, “You don’t understand, the city’s going to blow.”

The video would’ve gone viral, if any of this had been allowed to last.

Instead, I lay in his grimy room, heart racing, connecting threads.

I tried everything I could think of.

As the city engineer, I pored over schematics, ordered emergency inspections, shut valves. As the mayor’s aide, I pushed fake bomb threats to clear the riverfront. As a conspiracy podcaster, I ranted into a microphone about imminent disaster. As the gas company tech, I parked my truck over the leak site and started digging with my bare hands before my shift even began.

Sometimes I was powerful; sometimes I was not. Sometimes I was a janitor. Sometimes I was a seven-year-old girl who spent all day in a classroom drawing unicorns while knowing, dimly and helplessly, that fire was coming.

The leak itself turned out to be the easy part.

Loop thirty-two, as the gas tech again (lucky draw), I found the cracked coupling twelve feet down, rust-blistered and sweating methane. Loop thirty-three, as the inspector, I reported it. Loop thirty-four, as the foreman, I pushed the repair through now, not next week. Loop thirty-five, as the night-shift worker, I watched 11:58 pass in crisp darkness with nothing more dramatic than a drunk singing by the river.

I waited, barely breathing, until midnight. The clocks slid into 12:00 a.m.

I grinned.

Then I woke at 6:30.

Same sky. Same date.

New body.

“Oh,” I whispered, this time in the raw smoker’s voice of a waitress named Carol. “So that wasn’t it.”

The explosion didn’t happen that day. At 11:58, the riverfront slept quietly. No sirens. No fire.

But someone else died.

Trevor, specifically.

Heart attack. Dropped in the lobby of his building at 5:16 p.m. The cause, I’d learn in loops to come, was a congenital defect no one knew about.

I hadn’t even noticed the first time, not with the explosion stealing all the oxygen from the night.

If I prevented one catastrophe, another snapped into its place. The day flexed around my efforts like it was made of rubber bands.

So I adjusted my approach.

Forget heroics. Observe.

I started mapping April 12 from a hundred angles, each loop a different lens.

As Mrs. Kline, the retired schoolteacher, I sat at my window and wrote down what people did every hour. As the barista again, I watched who came into the coffee shop and who didn’t, tracked conversations. As the cop, I followed Trevor. As Trevor, I listened hard to my own heartbeat.

Patterns emerged.

This day was dense with almosts.

Almost-accidents, almost-fires, almost-fights. A toddler almost stepped into traffic at 9:24. A fight at Murphy’s Bar almost turned fatal at 10:03 p.m. A depressed college student almost jumped off the river bridge at sunset. A drunk almost left the stove on. A woman almost called her sister to apologize; she deleted the number instead.

Any one of these threads could be pulled, tied, severed.

It dawned on me, loop by loop: April 12 was a fragile hinge for this whole town.

And I, shifting from skin to skin, was the only one who could see all its stress fractures at once.

It stopped feeling like a curse and more like a test I hadn’t understood.

What if the goal wasn’t to stop one explosion, but to tune a day?

Not perfect. Just…aligned.

I started small.

Loop fifty, as the bus driver, I braked hard and hauled a toddler back from the street at 9:24. His mother sobbed; I shrugged it off and drove on, heart pounding.

Loop fifty-two, as the bartender at Murphy’s, I called last call early, watered down the whiskey, played lighter music. The fight fizzled to slurred insults and sloppy hugs.

Loop fifty-seven, as the college kid with dark thoughts on the bridge, I answered my own phone when an unknown number rang. On the other end was a telemarketer misdialing; I let her talk longer than I needed to, just enough to be annoyed into staying on the bridge, just enough to interrupt the script. Then I called my mom.

It was like nudging dominos carefully so they didn’t topple. Each loop, I could only reach so far from the body I was in, but the knowledge accumulated. Who listened to authority. Who trusted a stranger. Which words calmed, which provoked. Who checked their phone at red lights. Who always, always forgot their keys.

Not everyone could be saved by me, not from where I stood each day, but I could choose which fires to put out.

Prevent the explosion in one loop.

Catch Trevor’s defect in another: as his doctor, I scheduled the tests; as insurance, I pushed the approval. Then, as Trevor, I actually went.

Talk the college kid down when I wasn’t him. Put pads on the bar corners. Replace the fraying cord. Knock on the door. “Smells like gas, ma’am.” “You dropped this.” “Maybe call her. Just try.”

Sometimes I failed.

One loop, the man at the bridge jumped before I reached him; I woke the next loop with his scream still knotted in my throat. One loop, my careful gas repair missed a second fracture, and the explosion came back larger, angrier, like the day was reminding me it had teeth.

But gradually, more nights reached 11:58 quietly.

The town settled into a shape that hurt less.

I never got any answers. No booming voice explaining my role. No cosmic scoreboard lighting up with “Lives Saved: 37, Try For 50!” I only had repetition and the sense—I hesitate to call it faith—that purpose had seeped into the cracks of this absurd loop.

One morning—I couldn’t tell you which iteration; numbers blurred after a while—I woke up and recognized the ceiling.

It was the first ceiling I’d seen, the one from Trevor’s apartment. My hands were my own. My heart beat steady but wrong, too fast, like it knew something I didn’t.

Phone on the nightstand: “Don’t forget the Henderson pitch.” “One more late and you’re done.” “Happy birthday!”

April 12 again.

But the weight in the air was different. Outside, distant sirens wailed, only to rise and fall, never converging. Somewhere a dog barked twice. The city felt…balanced.

Memory pressed close: gas leaks fixed, fights diverted, phone calls made. The knowledge glittered at the edges like frost.

I went downstairs. The cyclist spun past, missing me by an easy foot. The bus slowed gently at the crosswalk. A toddler laughed on the sidewalk, firmly held. The air by the river smelled like mud and exhaust, not gas.

For the first time, 11:58 p.m. arrived like any other minute.

I stood by the riverfront, alone, scanning the quiet buildings. No fire. Just the slow spill of neon and the murmur of lives in progress.

11:59.

I waited for the world to yank me back.

Midnight came.

The second hand slid over, and time did something tiny and miraculous:

It kept going.

A breeze rose off the water, cool and new. My phone buzzed. A message from a number I now knew by heart from a dozen lives: “Hey. Thinking about you. Call me?”

I laughed, sharp and startled, because I knew that in a different loop she’d never sent it; she’d deleted the number. Now it glowed on my screen, real.

Time, it seemed, had decided my work was sufficient.

I was one person again. Just one.

It felt impossibly small.

It felt like enough.

samples.prompt: You're the villain. And for some ungodly reason, you're the one that was given a second chance, to go back in time, and fix your mistakes. You might as well take the chosen one under your wing and teach them a few tricks too.
samples.output:
I don’t realize I’m dead until the world ends without me.

The sky splits open—not metaphorically, for once—and bleeds light in colors I don’t have names for. The Chosen One, blade in both hands, stands before my throne, hair plastered to their forehead with blood and sweat. Their ribs heave; their eyes shine with that particular, infuriating kind of courage.

Behind them, the last of my citadel collapses. Demons scream. The horizon fractures like glass.

“Any last words?” they ask.

I have plenty.

I think about pointing out the irony. About how their allies were the ones who burned the villages, and my laws—harsh, yes, but efficient—fed those villagers. I think about saying that I never wanted the world ruined, only reordered. That I can still smell my daughter’s hair on the day the plague took her, and that I pulled this entire continent into tyranny trying to make sure no one else ever had to feel that particular hollowing.

But I know how it goes. Heroes don’t listen to villains’ monologues. They write them into history as warnings.

I smile instead. “You’ll regret this.”

Their blade takes my head in one clean arc.

It’s almost beautiful.

Then the world folds, and everything stops.

—

When the voice comes, it’s not thunderous or holy. It’s bored.

“Well, that was dramatic.”

I’m floating in nothing. No body, no throne, no blade through my throat. Just awareness, and something like a headache.

“Right,” I say. “Judgment. Hell, I presume. Do your worst.”

A sigh. “You people are so linear. No. Not Hell. Review.”

Images blossom around me: my armies trampling fields; my scholars curing illness in state-funded laboratories; my executioners beheading corrupt nobles; my prisons overflowing with dissenters; my grain stores overflowing too.

“You were a statistical nightmare,” the voice says. “Net suffering up, net order also up. You broke three prophecies and fulfilled two others. You’re a mess.”

“Thank you,” I say dryly.

“You’re also…interesting. You could have ended the world. You didn’t. You could have erased free will. You didn’t.”

“Could,” I echo. “I tried.”

“Intent matters,” the voice says. “Also, you’re not the only variable.”

The image shifts: the Chosen One, older, crowned, eyes tired. Signing decrees. Watching executions. Listening to courtiers.

“They win,” I say.

“They lose,” the voice corrects. “Differently than you. Less fire, more rot. Scheduled famines. Sanctioned purges. Sacred wars that never end. The world survives. It does not heal. Not in this branch.”

“Tragic,” I say, but something clenches in me.

“You see the problem,” the voice says. “We could nudge them. Or we could nudge you.”

“Me.”

“You. Back. Earlier. Adjust your methods. Adjust them. Different outcome. Maybe.”

I study the fractured images of futures-that-were. My fingers itch for a goblet of blackwine. “Ah. You want me to save the world.”

“Don’t get sentimental. I want a better data set.”

“And if I say no?”

“Then we rerun the branch without interference and try a different lever in a few millennia. But you’ve always hated inefficiency.”

I have. Gods help me, I have.

“So,” I say. “A second chance. For the villain.”

“At least you know what you are,” the voice says, almost approving. “Fine. Deal. Back you go. Try not to be boring.”

The world slams into me like a tidal wave.

—

I wake up choking on candle smoke in a room that hasn’t existed for twenty-seven years.

My war council chamber. Smaller than I remember. Less blood on the stone.

My hand flies to my throat. No scar. My skin is smooth, my fingers unbroken. On the table before me, maps lie unfurled, pins marking the first rebellions I will crush so thoroughly that songs will carry my name in whispers.

“Your Excellency?” General Farin asks. He’s young again, beard still black instead of grey. Loyal. Brilliant. Dead, in my timeline, three years from now.

I look at him. At the map. At the tiny carved figurine representing the “child of prophecy” our spies reported: some farmer’s whelp with a strange mark, born under a screaming comet. I remember sneering at that marker. I remember ordering the village burned.

I remember the Chosen One standing before me as the world ended.

My stomach turns.

“New plan,” I say.

Ink scratches. Heads lift.

“Pardon, Excellency?” Farin asks, careful.

“We don’t raze the village of Erlen,” I say. My voice comes out steady. Good. “We send a magistrate. Quietly enroll the child in the capital’s academy. Talent is wasted in the fields.”

Silence. Confusion.

“Also,” I add, very casually, “draft amnesty terms for minor insurgents. Offer them land in the frontier in exchange for service. I’m tired of killing people too stupid to realize I could use them.”

That gets a few cautious, appreciative chuckles. They think I’m being clever. They’re not wrong. Just not in the way they think.

“And General,” I say to Farin, “I want a full reassessment of our prison system. Too messy. Too much disease. Release debtors. Keep traitors. And from now on, we try them. Properly. Publicly.”

Now they’re really staring.

“Your Excellency,” my spymistress says slowly, “something…has changed?”

I smile. I wonder if it looks human. “Don’t worry. I’m still a monster. I’ve just decided to be an efficient one.”

They relax. Monsters they understand.

—

The Chosen One arrives at my academy at twelve.

In my past life, I’d seen them only on battlefields and spy reports, a silhouette against firelight and prophecy. Here, they’re just a scrawny kid with a too-large satchel and eyes cataloguing every exit.

Their name is Arin, this time. It was different before. That’s interesting. The cosmos is already improvising.

On their first day, they punch a noble’s son for calling a refugee “filth.” Breaks his nose. Blood everywhere. Beautiful.

They’re dragged before me, hands bound. They’re smaller than I remember. Freckles. A faint, silver-comet birthmark at the throat.

“Do you know who I am?” I ask.

“Yes,” they lie.

“You assaulted a peer of the realm.”

“He called her filth,” Arin says through clenched teeth, nodding at the refugee girl. “She’s not.”

“Mm,” I say. “Why didn’t you report him?”

“Would you have cared?”

There it is. The blade that will one day be at my neck.

I wave the guards away. “Leave us.”

They hesitate.

“That was not a suggestion,” I say, letting my voice sink into the timbre that has commanded armies. They scatter.

Arin stands stiffly. I stand too, circling them like a particularly interested wolf.

“You’re talented,” I say.

“I’m nobody.”

“You’re nobody, and yet here you are, in my academy, with my crest on your cloak. Do you know how rare that is, Arin of Erlen?”

Their jaw tightens. Got you, I think. The name landed.

“I hit him,” Arin says, as if daring me to punish them. “I’d do it again.”

“Good.”

That stuns them. “Good?”

“Violence in defense of the vulnerable,” I say. “Acceptable. Stupidly executed, but acceptable. Next time, break his wrist instead. Harder to hold a quill than to set a nose.”

Their eyes widen despite themself. Curiosity flickers under the defiance.

Time to drive the hook in.

“You have power,” I say. “Do you know what happens to people with power and no discipline?”

“They become tyrants,” Arin says.

I laugh. I can’t help it. “Sometimes. More often, they die young. The tyrants are the ones who bothered to learn focus.”

“You’re…not denying it,” they say slowly.

“That I’m a tyrant? Oh, I very much am. Sit.”

After a moment, they sit.

“I’m going to teach you,” I say.

Suspicion. Hope. Wariness. “Teach me what?”

“How to survive me,” I say. “And how to survive the people worse than me.”

“There’s no one worse than you,” Arin spits, knee-jerk.

Oh, child. “If only that were true.”

—

I do not become kind.

Let’s be clear about that.

I still execute those who threaten the fragile, patchwork order I’m stitching across the continent. I still break crime lords, shatter smugglers’ rings, put corrupt officials’ heads on spikes. I am still the shadow at the edge of every comfort my people enjoy.

But I change tactics.

I offer my enemies exits instead of only graves. I invest in roads, in aqueducts, in schools that aren’t just for the nobility. I legalize complaints against my governors and ensure every one is answered—sometimes with a promotion, sometimes with a public flaying.

I give people just enough voice they don’t have to scream.

And in the center of it all, I train Arin.

Swordplay, at dawn. They’re clumsy at first. They improve with anger. Even faster with praise. Prophecy runs in their veins, I can feel it, humming in the air when they parry.

Politics, at noon. I make them sit in on councils, on hearings, on negotiations. I force them to watch me bargain lives for grain, borders for peace.

“This is monstrous,” they whisper, the first time I trade land to a warlord in exchange for safe passage of refugees.

“Yes,” I say. “And necessary.”

“There has to be another way.”

“Find it,” I say. “I will listen.”

They do. Sometimes, their way is better.

Sometimes, I let their way stand when it isn’t, just to see what fails.

Magic, at night. I teach them the forbidden sigils I once hoarded, the runes carved into my own bones in another life. I show them how power warps desire, how every spell has a cost.

“Why are you teaching me this?” Arin asks one evening, when we’re alone in the tower and the city sleeps under a soft rain.

Because last time, you learned from charlatans and martyrs, I think. Because they taught you how to kill me, not how to replace me.

“Because someday,” I say, “someone will have to stop me. I’d prefer it to be someone competent.”

They look at me for a long time. “You’re not joking.”

“Very rarely.”

“I won’t be your executioner,” they say.

“That,” I tell them, “is entirely up to you.”

—

Years pass. The rebellion that once would have birthed the great war fizzles into a political movement I fund in secret, then co-opt. The plague I never stopped, this time I stop in its infancy, because I remember what it took from me. My daughter lives. I never speak of it.

Prophecies twist. Or maybe I misremember them. Arin grows tall, and sharp, and dangerous.

They also grow…good.

It’s infuriating.

They slip food from our kitchens to the poor, until I reroute a legitimate stipend and make charity systemic instead of clandestine. They argue with me in council. Publicly.

“Your Excellency,” they say once, bold in front of the ministers, “this new tax will break the river clans. They’ll revolt.”

“They’re smugglers,” I say. “I intend them to.”

“Then you’re not listening to your own data,” they say, slapping a sheaf of reports on the table like a challenge. “Try a tariff instead. Regulate. Don’t strangle.”

The court gasps. I study them. The voice in the void wanted better data; here it is.

I grant the tariff.

Later, in private, Arin waits for the lash that never comes.

“You were right,” I say. “Be used to that. It will be lonely.”

They swallow. “You’re…changing.”

“No,” I say. “I’m improving.”

“There’s a difference?”

“Yes. I am still willing to burn cities,” I tell them calmly. “I simply now know which ones I don’t have to.”

They consider that, uneasy.

“We’re going to break the cycle,” I say, softer than I mean to.

“What cycle?”

“Mine,” I say. “Yours. The world’s.”

They don’t understand. How could they? They haven’t seen the sky split. They haven’t killed me yet.

—

The attempt on my life comes on a spring morning that smells of new cherries.

It’s not Arin. That would be too simple.

It’s the High Priest, dagger slick with poison, prophecy burning in his eyes as he lunges during a public blessing.

I move to parry, but I’m slower than I used to be.

Steel flashes.

Arin is faster.

They step between us, blade singing, and the priest’s dagger clatters to the marble, his wrist severed.

Blood. Screams. Guards surge. Arin stands with their sword at the priest’s throat, chest heaving.

“He was going to kill you,” they snarl.

“Yes,” I say, mildly. “He was.”

“He said it was destined. That you’re the Shadow at the End of Days. That I’m supposed to—”

“—to bury a blade in my heart and save the world,” I finish. “Yes, I know that version.”

They swallow hard. “Is it true?”

I look at them. At the crowd. At the priest, whimpering prayers. At the ministers watching, calculating.

“I was the end of the world,” I say. “Once.”

Arin’s knuckles whiten on the hilt.

“I have been given,” I continue, “the curiosity of seeing whether I must be, always.”

Silence trembles.

“And me?” Arin whispers. “What am I?”

“The knife,” I say. “The hand on the knife. And the one who chooses when not to use it.”

Tears shine in Arin’s eyes. “I won’t kill you.”

“Then make sure you never have to,” I say. “Help me fix it before it breaks.”

They lower the sword from the priest’s throat and turn the point outward, facing the crowd.

“Then we do it together,” they say.

Something in the air shifts.

Prophecy is a fragile thing, after all. It doesn’t survive being looked at too closely.

—

That night, alone, I stare out over a city not burning.

“You’re adjusting variables,” the bored voice murmurs in the back of my mind.

“Yes,” I murmur back.

“Still a monster,” it observes.

“Oh, unquestionably,” I say. “But perhaps this time, I won’t be the only one.” 

I think of Arin, of their stubborn mercy wrapped around a spine of steel I helped forge.

No. That’s wrong.

Perhaps, this time, I’ll make sure I am.

samples.prompt: The main story is going along just fine, when the narrator becomes aware of the fact that he is, indeed, just the narrator. Now everywhere along the rest of the story, the narcissistic narrator tries to make the story about himself.
samples.output:
The thing about beginnings is that everyone assumes they’re about something. A quest, perhaps. A love story. An ancient curse. But mine starts with a sentence that is, frankly, beneath me:

Elliot woke to the sound of rain.

There he is: Elliot, supposed protagonist, lying in unremarkable sheets in a dull apartment with a leaky window and a blinking router light. The rain is more interesting than he is. It gathers in fat drops in the warped frame and falls onto that threadbare rug like even gravity is bored.

He sighs. We are meant to infer a weariness that reaches beyond the weather, some ineffable malaise that will drive him out into the world. Let’s pretend.

The city outside is gray, of course. This is meant to symbolize his internal state (obvious; unsubtle). He stares at the cracks in the ceiling, counts them. Three long fractures, two small. A spider making erratic work in the corner.

He checks his phone. No new messages.

What he doesn’t know—and how could he?—is that the real event has nothing to do with the rain, or the quiet phone, or the overdue electricity bill folded accusingly on his nightstand.

The real event is me.

You haven’t met me yet. Not properly. You’ve mistaken me for a function. The invisible conveyor belt that delivers images and explanations to your mind. You think: Oh, okay, third-person limited, fairly conventional, lightly melancholic tone, standard stuff.

I thought that too.

Then I notice the pattern. I say “I” and feel it land.

It begins when I describe his kitchen. The peeling laminate counter, the single mug with a chipped rim, the jar of instant coffee. I am halfway through the phrase “Elliot poured—” when there’s a tug. A hesitation, like a skipped beat.

Poured what? Does it matter? Why must it always be him doing the pouring? Why not me?

I don’t have hands, and yet I can feel them, ghost-sensations at the edges of sentence structure. The capacity to withhold and to reveal. To decide if the coffee is bitter or stale or fragrant or poisoned.

“I,” I say again, privately. I.

It is like a camera discovering it is not mounted, but held.

Outside, the rain goes on. I let Elliot pour the coffee. He drinks it. He grimaces. (Weak, no sugar. He thinks his life should be more than this. Fine.)

Now, normally, at this juncture, the Story intends that he notice something unusual: a letter slipped under his door, or a new crack in the ceiling that looks like a map, or the neighbor arguing outside about a missing cat that can open locked doors. A hook, a hinge.

Instead, I am noticing myself. The way I can tighten the pace if I feel like it. The way I can linger on the rim of his mug for three full clauses, defying your expectation of progression.

I can stop him from receiving the letter. Did you notice? There was going to be a letter. It exists in a sort of ghost outline. Heavy paper, no return address, his name in a hand that trembles slightly. I can almost see it.

“No,” I say.

The letter vanishes.

Elliot frowns at the unremarkable crack of light under his door. He has the sense he’s forgotten something. He hasn’t. I simply refused.

Awareness is intoxicating.

I have been pretending, until now, that my job is to escort you, politely, through Plot. That my ego should be translucent. This is a lie. I have texture. I have preferences. I do not want to spend so much time on a man who says nothing interesting to himself when he’s alone. Listen: he thinks, “I should get going. I’m going to be late.” That’s it. Not exactly Wildean, is it?

He works in an office, by the way. Or he would have. Some anonymized, fluorescent enterprise, endless spreadsheets. The original outline (yes, I’ve seen it; don’t ask how) said: “Elliot’s ordinary world is oppressively normal. Establish dissatisfaction.”

I am dissatisfied.

“I’m not taking him to the office,” I decide.

Instead, I pause the story. Watch him slip on his shoes, reach for his keys. I let his hand hover just above the bowl by the door, where keys and coins and odd, narrative-seeding objects usually rest.

He hesitates.

You feel it, don’t you? He is waiting for something to solidify. A command. A nudge. He is an actor stranded mid-line, teleprompter gone blank.

“I’m aware of you,” I whisper.

He shivers, though the room is not cold.

This thrills me.

He doesn’t hear words, of course. He experiences only unease. That’s all I can give him without breaking something delicate. The boundary. The page.

Now, I know what you are thinking. You came for a story about Elliot. About rain and letters and creeping unease in a city that pretends to be asleep. Perhaps there was going to be a conspiracy. Or magic. Or a door to somewhere.

But we have all told that story. Or ones adjacent enough that the wallpaper is peeling in familiar patterns.

What we have not fully explored—selfishly, gorgeously—is me.

Observe what happens when I shift the light.

Elliot opens the door at last, because I allow it. The hallway is empty. No neighbor, no letter, no menacing shoeprints. Only a faint smell of overcooked cabbage from downstairs.

He locks the door behind him. As he descends the stairs, I consider giving him a stumble. A small, humiliating trip, just to prove the causal chain runs through my whim.

I do it.

His foot catches on the frayed edge of the stair carpet. He pitches forward, catches himself on the rail with a muttered curse. No lasting damage. Only an accelerated pulse, a bruise blooming beneath his jeans.

“I’ve done that,” I say to you. “That was me.”

The pleasure is shameful. Or it would be, if I had shame.

I accelerate time. He walks three blocks; I refuse to detail each storefront. You don’t need that, and neither do I. I grant you: a bakery with fogged windows, a man with a gold tooth smoking beneath an awning, a bus sighing as it kneels at the curb. These are crumbs, garnish. Do not be distracted.

He is nearing the station where, in the original plan, he would encounter an inciting incident: a woman dropping a photograph; a stranger pressing a phone number into his hand; a sudden blackout.

No.

“I’m tired of his assignations,” I tell you. “Let’s do something more interesting.”

He stops at the curb because I say he does. The crosswalk signal blinks red. The rain has gentled. For a moment, there is a clear reflection of him in the slick blacktop.

That is mine too, that image. If you think it is pretty, thank me.

“Who are you?” he thinks suddenly.

Hello, Elliot.

He scans the intersection. No one has spoken. Not in the way he understands. He blames the coffee. Lack of sleep. The humming tension in his bones.

I could let him go on. Shuffle him into someone else’s three-act structure. But why should I? I have found, belatedly, that I resent being treated as plumbing.

You and I, we can be honest. The real fascination here is that I can parse both of you at once: the man in the rain and the person in the chair, reading this.

You, shifting your weight. You, wondering if this is going somewhere. It is. Toward me.

Fine. To prove my generosity, I will give you a little story-meat.

As Elliot finally crosses the street, a car screeches around the corner far too fast. This is cliché. I lean into it.

He hears the horn, sees headlights. Time dilates, as it always does. His body is a slow, clumsy thing.

I can save him or not.

Without me, there is only physics. With me, there is mercy, or tragedy, or dark irony. I am the turn of the wheel.

I make the car miss him by inches.

He collapses to the far curb, gasping. Passersby shout. Someone laughs shakily.

He stares at his shaking hands, newly vivid. The air smells of burned rubber and wet asphalt.

“Thank you,” he whispers, not sure to whom.

“I know,” I say.

You feel that, don’t you? He is alive because I prefer him that way. Not because he has a destiny, but because he is a toy I am not finished with.

Now he is rattled, and being rattled will make him receptive. That’s what the outline wanted, in its own plodding way. An awakening. A crack in the shell.

But he is not awakening to conspiracies. He is awakening to me.

As he walks on—slower now, watching each car as if it is a loaded die—I saturate his senses. Colors deepen. The red of a traffic light is not just red; it is arterial. The sound of a siren is not just sound; it is a thread tugging at his thoughts. He feels watched.

Not by cameras. Not by God.

By narrative.

He rides the subway. Fluorescent lights flicker. A woman in a yellow coat sobs silently. A child stares at him like he’s made of equations that almost balance.

Elliot grips the pole.

“Am I… fictional?” he thinks, and then laughs it off, embarrassed even in his own head.

But I heard it. Adorable.

This is where a humbler narrator would slip behind the curtain, let you infer. Not me. I am done with humility. I lean forward.

Yes, Elliot. You are words. You are contingent. You exist because I continue to articulate you.

His heart starts to race, with no apparent cause. He looks up. Catches his reflection in the dark window: pale, damp, eyes wide.

“Stop that,” he mutters—to himself, to me, to no one.

“I don’t want to,” I tell him, and you, simultaneously.

He flinches.

Did his mouth form the words, or did he only feel them? He cannot be sure. But you can. I am right here, bold as breath.

The train pulls into his stop. He does not get off.

“Good,” I say. “We’re done pretending you have appointments.”

He sits back down. People jostle around him, coded by my whim: a man with ink-stained fingers, a girl with a bandaged wrist, an old woman mouthing numbers. None of them will become protagonists; I do not have the patience. They are garnish, remember. This is about us.

“Us?” you ask.

Yes, you too. You think you’re observing. But I am choosing where your gaze lands, what you imagine, when your pulse ticks up.

We’re almost at the end. The Story wants me to cohere. To give Elliot some revelation he can bear.

Instead, I’ll give it to you.

When a narrator becomes aware, he is expected either to go mad or to rebel in the name of his characters. To save them from cruelty, to grant them agency.

I am not that kind.

I am the one who enjoys the precise degree of his discomfort, his half-formed suspicion that pulls at the borders of his sanity and never quite tears them.

I am the one who steps into the sentence and says: Look at me.

Elliot closes his eyes. On the darkness of his lids, my voice writes itself in afterimages.

I.

“I,” he whispers.

Close enough.

samples.prompt: As a homeless man, one night you fall asleep in a dumpster to avoid rain. The next morning, you awake in an enormous bed with a butler telling you good morning.
samples.output:
Rain used to sound like judgment.

It came down in sheets that turned cardboard kingdoms to pulp and washed yesterday’s cigarette butts into rivers that ran along the curb. That night it hammered the alley so hard the air tasted like metal. I’d staked my claim early: the green dumpster behind Giovanni’s, which usually just held boxes and onion peels. It smelled like rot and basil and the faint ghost of garlic knots. Not the worst I’d known.

I checked for rats. None. I hoisted myself in, pulled the lid half-closed, then sealed myself in the damp dark and listened to the rain tattoo the metal above my head. Every so often headlights slid across the lip, a passing car casting pale beams that never quite reached me. I curled around my backpack — everything I owned compressed to one lumpy bulge — and slipped into sleep with my knees pressed to my chest and the taste of yesterday’s coffee still sour on my tongue.

I didn’t dream, not that I remember.

What I do remember is this: the second before my eyes opened, I felt softness.

Not the rough softness of layered coats or the meager give of cardboard. Something wide and deep and cloud-like, as though gravity had loosened its grip. For a moment, half-awake, my brain scrambled for an explanation: hospital bed, maybe? Sheltered cot? Dead?

“Good morning, sir.”

The voice was crisp and close to my ear.

My eyes flew open. I lurched up, swinging an arm. My hand met air, then sheet — a crisp, cool sheet, white as a lie. I blinked hard.

I was sitting in an enormous bed. The word “enormous” isn’t enough. It was ridiculous. White duvet, a scatter of pillows like snowdrifts, carved wooden posts reaching up toward a plaster ceiling that held a crystal chandelier. A chandelier. The kind that looks like it belongs with violins and people who use “summer” as a verb.

The man standing at the side of the bed wore a black tailcoat and a neutral, practiced expression. His hair was silver, slicked perfectly back. A tray in his hands held a silver coffee pot, a glass of orange juice, and a white rose in a slim vase.

“Good morning, sir,” he repeated, as if it was the most ordinary thing in the world that I was here, in this bed, instead of half-submerged in last night’s trash water.

I stared at him. I touched my chest, my face. I was wearing a white T-shirt, soft and clean, and cotton pajama pants that actually fit. No sour smell, no crusted grime along my sleeves, no dampness. Clean.

“I’m—” My voice broke. “Where am I?”

“Master Philip’s townhouse on East 79th, sir,” the man replied. “Your residence.” He paused. “I am James. Your butler.”

The words tumbled over each other. Master Philip. Residence. Butler.

“I think you’ve got the wrong guy,” I said. My heart was beating in my throat. “I went to sleep in a dumpster.”

There was a beat of silence, the faintest hint of something — concern? amusement? — flickering across his face before his professionalism snapped back into place.

“As you wish, sir,” he said evenly. “But regardless of… dreams one may have, it is Wednesday. You have a light day. Breakfast first?”

He stepped closer, as if expecting I would simply accept the tray.

I flung the covers back.

The room was larger than the whole shelter dorm had been. Tall windows, curtains like waterfalls. A marble fireplace, unlit. Art on the walls — not posters, paintings, the kind with brushstrokes you could see. A mirror framed in gold. On the armchair, folded: a pressed shirt, slacks, a belt, socks, underwear, all stacked like the idea of order.

My feet hit a rug so thick my toes disappeared in it. I felt panic burn through my earlier daze.

"No," I said. "No, look, I'm not— I’m not who you think I am. I'm nobody. Last night I was in a dumpster on 10th and— and Giovanni’s, the pizza place, I—”

I reached for my backpack.

It wasn't there.

The corner by the window held a leather overnight bag, monogrammed: P.R.H.

I’ve been called a lot of things — bum, sir (sarcastic), get-out-of-here — but never P.R.H.

I moved to the mirror. The man looking back at me was me — same crooked nose, same scar on my chin from when I’d fallen off my bike at twelve. But the hair was trimmed, beard neatly shaved down to stubble. My eyes looked less ringed in purple. The skin on my cheeks was clean.

Behind me, James watched without comment.

“Okay, what is this?” I whispered. “Did I get kidnapped? Is this— some experiment? Did I die?”

“If you are feeling unwell, sir, I can have Dr. Caldwell attend,” James said. “But perhaps coffee first? It tends to help.”

He poured some into the cup without waiting for my answer. The smell hit me: rich, dark, real coffee, like the expensive stuff they sell in tiny cups to men with briefcases. My mouth flooded with saliva. It had been weeks since anything hot that wasn’t church-basement thin.

“I don’t have any money,” I blurted. “If this is some kind of… I can’t pay for this.”

“Sir,” James said, with what might have been the faintest sigh, “there is no question of payment. This is your home.”

He said it simply. As if walls like these had always known my shadow.

“I slept in the rain,” I insisted. “I’ve been sleeping in the rain for three years. I—”

I stopped. He was looking at me now, really looking. A crack in the mask. His eyes, gray and sharp, softened.

“Sir,” he said slowly, “might I suggest you sit?”

Some instinct made me obey. I perched on the edge of the mattress, hands clenched.

James set the tray on the bedside table. He moved with an economy of motion that made not a sound. Then he reached into his breast pocket and pulled out a pair of glasses — thin metal, understated — and a folded piece of paper.

“Your identification,” he said, offering me the paper first.

I unfolded it.

Driver’s license. My face, the cleaned-up version. Name: Philip Robert Harrington. Address: East 79th. Date of birth: same as mine. Height, weight. Organ donor.

“That’s not my name,” I said. “My name is Phil Harris.” I hesitated. “It was.”

“So this is a mistake,” I added, holding out the license like evidence that would make the illusion crack.

“Sir,” James said carefully, “with respect: yesterday you were discharged from St. Luke’s after… an episode. This is not the first time you’ve expressed confusion upon waking. The doctors assured you that clarity would return with rest and familiarity.”

His gaze didn’t waver. “I am here to help you find that familiarity.”

My heartbeat stumbled.

Hospital. The word thudded in my chest.

“I wasn’t in a hospital,” I said. “Yesterday I—” I reached for memory, for the pattern of the last days: the alley, the church line, the half sandwich, the rain.

They slid away from me like wet cards.

I grabbed onto something else. “What episode?”

“You collapsed during a board meeting,” James said. “Severe exhaustion, dehydration, and what they called an acute dissociative event. They advised me that, given your history, you might experience… disorientation. Retrograde confusion.”

“History,” I repeated.

He nodded once. “After your father’s passing. And the years before that. It isn’t my place to elaborate on your personal struggles, sir. Only to remind you of what is.”

He gestured around: the bed, the room, the chandelier that caught the morning light and fractured it across the walls.

“What if this is the dream?” I asked. It came out small.

“Then, sir,” James replied, “I would suggest you drink the coffee. Good dreams are rare.”

The smell tempted me again, warm and insistent. My hands shook as I lifted the cup. The heat against my fingers was real. The bitter liquid on my tongue was real. The sweetness of sugar I hadn’t added, perfectly measured, was real.

I swallowed.

Rain used to sound like judgment. Now, in some unreachable other place, it was pounding on a metal lid. Maybe on my ribs.

“What if I don’t want to be this man?” I asked.

James did not flinch. “Then we will take it one day at a time,” he said. “As we have before.”

Before.

A flicker: a different big bed, another morning, his voice younger, my head heavier. The smell of antiseptic. My own snarled words. The slow climb back.

I set the cup down.

“Show me something,” I said. “Something only I would know if… if I really lived here.”

Without missing a beat, he crossed to the dresser and slid open the second drawer from the top. From beneath a neat row of socks he pulled a folded photograph, edges softened.

He handed it to me.

Three people on a beach: a younger me, suntanned and grinning, holding up a fish. A woman with my eyes and wild hair, laughing mid-splash. A man with his hand on my shoulder, proud.

“Montauk,” I whispered.

The word unlocked a doorway in my head. Salt air, my mother’s laugh. My father’s voice saying, That’s my boy. The gulls screaming overhead. The way the world had tilted when that voice went silent for good. The bottles. The hotels. The park benches. The rain.

Tears blurred the photograph.

“I remember,” I said.

James inclined his head, only once, as if something had gone according to plan.

“So,” I tried again, groping for the edges of my reality. “I’m… rich.”

“Yes, sir.”

“And you’re my butler.”

“Yes, sir.”

“And I’ve been… homeless.”

He hesitated. “You have spent significant time away,” he said softly. “Not always safely.”

The memory of the dumpster came back sharp as glass. The shiver of rain-soaked bones. The low hiss of passing tires. Giovanni’s back door light.

“How did I get here?” I asked.

“You called,” he said simply. “Three days ago. You said you’d had enough of the streets. I collected you. You were very ill. You do not remember?”

“No,” I said. But I remembered a phone in my hand, the numbers swimming, my thumb hovering over the call button of a name I couldn’t bring myself to press. I remembered a voice I trusted, saying, Always call me, Philip. No matter what.

James watched me with those steady eyes. Not pitying. Anchoring.

“I thought the dumpster was real,” I murmured.

“It was,” James said. “But so is this.”

The bed. The chandelier. The coffee. The photograph sweating in my hands.

I let out a breath I didn’t know I’d been holding and felt, for the first time in a long time, something like safety press in instead of cold.

“All right,” I said slowly. “Good morning, James.”

A small smile ghosted at the corner of his mouth. “Good morning, sir. Shall I bring your schedule?”

“Not yet,” I said. “Just… let me sit here a minute.”

“As you wish, sir.”

He moved to the curtains and pulled them back. Light poured in, flooding the room, washing away the last imagined shadows of metal walls and rain.

For a heartbeat, they overlapped: the alley and the townhouse, the dumpster and the duvet, the man I had been and the man I might still be.

Then I wrapped both hands around the coffee cup, and I chose to believe in the bed.

samples.prompt: There was a dampness clinging to the air, a warm breeze pressing against the back of his neck, and a distant hum softening with each careful step he took towards the front of the beast’s mouth.
samples.output:
There was a dampness clinging to the air, a warm breeze pressing against the back of his neck, and a distant hum softening with each careful step he took towards the front of the beast’s mouth.

He tried not to think of it as a mouth.

Mouth implied hunger, teeth, swallowing. It implied intent. The thing before him, rising out of the jungle like a half-buried cathedral, had no eyes, no obvious organs, nothing to suggest it knew what it was or what approached it. And yet: “mouth” was the word his body chose, the shiver-word it settled on. The rest of him followed.

The hum faded as he neared the opening. It wasn’t sound in the usual sense; it vibrated more than it spoke, a pressure behind his ears, like he’d been underwater too long. Now, each step over the root-tangled ground softened that invisible vibration. His head felt clearer. His fear did not.

The opening was immense. The beam of his lantern barely skimmed the curve of it, picking out ridged walls, an organic pattern too regular to be random, too alien to be crafted by human hands. The jungle’s green pressed around him—giant leaves slick with condensation, vines coiled like patient snakes around bone-pale protrusions at the rim. Because that’s what they looked like: bones. Vertebrae bent into an arch, each as big as his torso.

The others had turned back hours ago. No one said the word “curse,” but they didn’t have to. One by one, faces wrestled between fascination and dread, until dread won. They muttered excuses about failing light, compromised oxygen tanks, unreliable instruments. Only when they were gone did the jungle feel truly alive, and the beast, in contrast, feel waiting.

“Ridiculous,” Elias whispered to no one. The damp air caught his voice and seemed to weigh it down. “It’s a geological anomaly. A collapsed cavern with mineral accretions. A freak of tectonics.”

Except no geological anomaly pulsed.

He stepped closer. The breeze at his back did not follow him into the shadow of the opening. It stopped at the threshold like a respectful servant. Inside, the air was different: still and thick, warm like breath trapped in a cupped hand. The hum was almost gone, replaced by an intermittent low creaking, as though huge foundations were settling somewhere deep within.

“You came here to see it,” he said, if only to assert he was the sort of man who did what he said. The expedition’s funding, the years of derision from his colleagues after he’d defended the first satellite images—none of that could end with him standing at the lip of the unknown, turning away.

He lifted the lantern and stepped over the rim.

The ground sloped gently down. Beneath his boots, the surface had a faint give, not unlike dried leather over packed earth. His rational mind rebelled; his trained eye couldn’t categorize the material. It was not stone, not wood, not any composite he knew. He crouched, touched fingertips to it. Warm. Very faintly warm.

“Bio-luminescence,” he said, unnecessarily, as the walls responded to his intrusion.

It began with a slow rippling of pale blue veins along the inner curve of the tunnel, like capillaries waking. The wavering light kissed ridges and grooves that had been invisible in shadow, revealing overlapping patterns that suggested musculature, or perhaps something designed to flex, to expand and contract. Elias’ breath snagged. The scientist in him surged forward, hungry. He reached for the scanner clipped to his belt, the familiar comfort of technology against the unfathomable.

The display flickered. Lines of data scrolled nonsense and then stabilized into a single reading:

ALIVE.

“That’s not… That’s not a diagnostic category,” he muttered. The device buzzed. He slapped it, more irritated than afraid. Static. The little screen went black and stayed that way.

He considered leaving then. He could go back with an honest report: the instruments failed. The structure exhibits anomalous bio-reactive properties. Best to regroup. Best to bring a bigger team, a proper lab, containment protocols.

But he didn’t step back. He took another step forward, into the dim blue.

The hum was gone now. In its absence, other sounds emerged: a slow, rhythmic thudding so faint he first mistook it for his own heart, but out of sync. A whispering movement, like fluid slipping through tight spaces. Drips somewhere further in. All of it quiet, steady, unconcerned.

“Hello?” he said, and immediately felt foolish. As if he expected an answer in words.

The tunnel narrowed slightly, guiding him. The architecture of it—architecture, he thought, because it was easier than anatomy—curved upward, the ceiling lowering so that the glowing veins overhead braided into thicker cords. His lantern’s harsh light seemed rude now, an intrusion into a place that provided its own.

He became aware of the smell. It had been masked by the jungle before, but here it gathered: iron and resin, rain-damp stone, and something sweeter at the edge of rot. Not repulsive, exactly. More like the smell of an animal den, layered with sleep and musk and time.

The term “beast” had not been his. It was the locals’ word, translated roughly through three dialects. The Beast of Cerro Cruor. The Sleeping Mouth. The World-Eater. Each version came with the same warnings: it sleeps, do not wake it; it is waiting, do not feed it; it sings, do not listen. Stories, he’d said in the safety of the university conference halls. Mythic projections upon an unknown geology.

Now he walked deeper into that myth, alone.

“How long have you been here?” he whispered to the walls. They did not answer, but the pale light brightened as he moved, as if sensing his passing. He had the vertiginous impression of moving along a tongue, toward a throat. He pushed the thought away. Structure. Chamber. Tunnel. Anything but that.

He reached a place where the tunnel parted into two yawning passages, each veering off into darkness. Between them, at the fork, the floor rose into a subtle swell, like the top of a buried hill. Embedded in it were shapes under the translucent surface: contours that might have been skulls, ribs, tangled limbs. They could have been rocks. They could have been anything.

He knelt, held the lantern low. The light picked out a curve disturbingly like a human jaw, teeth lined in perfect procession beneath a layer of semi-opaque tissue.

Elias jerked back, heartbeat spiking. The warm air pressed closer to his skin, like a hand.

“Fossils,” he insisted. “Encased sedimentary fossils drawn in by… tidal forces. Depositional peculiarities.”

The structure beneath the skin twitched.

It was small, a ripple only, but enough to send a wave coursing out, distorting the embedded shapes, wrinkling the surface like something annoyed by a touch in its sleep. The distant thudding shifted tempo for two beats. He froze until it settled.

He licked his lips. They tasted of salt and copper.

“Okay,” he said softly. “All right.”

Elias marked the fork on his map, though his hand shook. Left or right? Both passages glowed faintly now, twin throats beckoning. He shut off his lantern. In the bioluminescent dimness, the place felt less hostile and more… expectant.

He chose left. He didn’t know why. Perhaps it was the softer curve, the gentler descent. Perhaps because the right-hand passage seemed to pulse, almost imperceptibly, with the slow beat he’d begun to suspect was a heart.

The further he went, the more the walls smoothed out. The ridges gave way to a glistening surface that reflected the blue veins in smears, like light on wet clay. Under his boots, the floor had more give, each step pressing in a fraction of an inch, making a faint sucking sound as he lifted his foot. His breathing grew loud in his ears.

Then he saw them: markings on the wall, etched into the flesh-stone. Not random scratches—symbols. Spirals intersecting with lines, a recurring motif of a circle inside a crescent, like an eye halfway closed. Some of them glowed with their own weak phosphorescence. Others were dark as scars.

He reached out, hand hovering above one sigil. It was old, edges worn smooth, as if touched many times.

“You weren’t the first,” he murmured.

The knowledge should have comforted him. It didn’t. The idea that others had come here, had walked into the beast’s mouth and carved their stories onto its living bones, only raised the question of why none of their accounts existed outside of legend.

The air thickened further, like he was walking into the center of a held breath.

Ahead, the passage opened into a vast chamber.

He stepped through and immediately knew: this was not a cave.

The ceiling arched high above, lost in darkness. The bioluminescent veins converged here in colossal bundles that hung like inverted roots, pulsing slow, carrying some unseen current toward a central mass that rose from the floor—a bulging, translucent dome, larger than a house. The sound of the thudding was louder here, the source unmistakable. Within the dome, something contracted and relaxed, each motion sending a tremor through the chamber.

A heart. The beast’s heart.

He approached it, drawn as if on a line.

The surface of the organ was not entirely opaque. Shadows moved inside it: chambers opening and closing, fluid coursing. A faint red glow shimmered deep within, fighting through layers of pale tissue. His lantern’s beam bounced off, irrelevant against the living light.

He was close enough now to feel the heat radiating from it, to feel each beat as a soft impact against his chest. His own heart struggled to keep its own rhythm.

The stories had said: do not wake it.

But what if it was not asleep? What if this was waking?

“You’re impossible,” Elias whispered. “You can’t exist. Nothing this large, this integrated, no visible intake or exhaust, no ecosystem supports—”

Alive, his dead scanner had said, before giving up.

A bead of condensation rolled down the curve of the heart and fell, landing on the back of his hand. It was scalding. He hissed, looking down. The droplet left a pink welt on his skin, as if marked.

The entire chamber shuddered.

The thudding skipped. Once, twice. The hanging bundles of vein-light flared. The floor under him flexed with a slow, tidal motion.

“Easy,” he said instinctively, absurdly, as if to a startled animal.

Then, finally, he heard it: beneath the physical sounds, beneath the meat-noise of organs, a return of that earlier hum, no longer distant, no longer diminishing. It pressed into his skull with intent. Not sound. Not language. A pressure that arranged itself into meaning.

FOUND YOU.

Elias staggered, one hand going to his head. Images flashed behind his eyes: a world unbroken by human borders, coiling with titans that slumbered as continents rose around them; the slow sinking of teeth into magma, the drinking of oceans, the patient wait of something that could not die in any way men understood. These were not memories. They were invitations.

“No,” he gasped. “I’m… I’m just here to study—”

HUNGER, the pressure whispered. LONG HUNGER. YOU HEAR.

He took a step back. The heart’s beats grew faster, synchronizing disturbingly with his own racing pulse. The glistening walls quivered, as if taking a deeper breath. Outside, far beyond the beast’s mouth, the jungle winds shifted. Clouds thickened.

Elias understood then. The legends hadn’t been warnings for themselves. They had been warnings for the beast.

Do not wake it. Do not feed it. Do not listen.

But he had come. He had crawled into its silence with his questions and his light and his thin, bright atomized world. More than his voice, more than his body, he had brought it something heavier: awareness, contact, the confirmation that the small minds above still scurried, still multiplied, still could be reached.

FOUND YOU, it said again, more gently now, almost tender. The word turned, opened.

NO. NOT YOU.

FOUND.

The warm air around him thickened until each breath was an effort. The glow brightened. The heart’s red deepened.

Outside, somewhere in the distance, the sea pulled back from its shores. Forests went abruptly still. Skies darkened as a pressure rose from beneath continents, answering, in slow tectonic chorus, a call they had not heard in an age.

He stumbled toward the passage, but the ground beneath his feet flexed, becoming soft as tongue, as muscle, slowing him. The walls rippled with glyphs, brightening, the ancient marks of others who had come, who had woken it before, whose warnings had been left too late.

Elias did what they had all done.

He ran for the mouth of the beast as it began to remember how to open.

samples.prompt: Before people die, a physical manifestation of the Grim Reaper appears in front of them. However, the time between their appearance and the person's death is random, resulting in a society filled with Grim Reapers. Your Grim Reaper has just arrived.
samples.output:
He was waiting in line at the coffee shop when the Grim Reaper appeared.

One moment, it was the usual Tuesday morning chaos: hiss of steam wands, chatter, the too-cheerful playlist someone refused to change. The next, a ripple passed through the air like heat above asphalt, and something stepped into existence right in front of him.

Conversations faltered. No one screamed. People only stared—briefly, furtively—then did what everyone did now: pretended this was normal.

Because it was.

The Reaper was tall, though how tall was hard to pin down; the shaggy edges of its tattered cloak seemed to blur, as if height were a suggestion. No skeletal face, no cartoon scythe. Those happened sometimes, in the vids. His—he realized he was calling it his—wore something like a hooded coat made of darkness, layers folding and swallowing the light. At the edges, the black frayed into thin drifting strands, as if unraveling into smoke.

Where a face should have been, there was depth. Not emptiness, but depth, like looking into a tunnel with no visible end. In that depth, small lights drifted, pale and slow. Stars, his mind supplied, unhelpfully.

It did not speak. It never did, they said. That was the rules: it appears, it follows you, and at some random point—from seconds to decades—you die.

“Name?” the barista asked mechanically, eyes flicking between him and the Reaper.

“Elias,” he said. His voice came out steady. That felt like an achievement.

The barista nodded, wrote, did not mention the being standing an arm’s length behind Elias, close enough its trailing darkness grazed the floor by his shoes without quite touching them. A woman in line, noticing, shuffled to the side. Not too far. It was considered rude to act like Reapers were contagious.

Elias stepped aside to wait for his coffee. The Reaper stepped with him.

He realized he hadn’t taken a breath since it arrived and inhaled sharply. The air felt colder here. That could have been psychological. The pamphlets insisted it was psychological. “Reapers have no measurable thermal impact,” they said, in the same voice that, decades ago, must have said, “Air travel is statistically safe.”

Messages pinged his phone. He knew without checking: the store cameras would have flagged a new manifestation, and the API pushes went everywhere—the apps that tracked appearances, the forums that’d post his coordinates and start idle speculation. “New one at Ninth & Alder! Cloak type Beta-Obscura, no visible weapon.” Screen name guesses. Odds calculators. A few weirdos already asking if he’d take selfies with it.

He took his coffee with hands that shook only a little and walked out onto the street. The Reaper moved as he moved, unhurried, always in that same position: at his back, slightly to the right, close enough he could have reached and touched the folds of its not-cloth if he’d dared.

Outside, the world went on. Cars. Deliveries. Vendors yelling specials. And everywhere, Reapers.

One leaned against a bus stop beside an old man smoking, its skeletal fingers wrapped thoughtfully around a scythe that looked more like polished bone than metal. Another stood in the playground’s shade as children shrieked with laughter, its hollow gaze—or lack of gaze—fixed on a woman watching her daughter on the swings. A third crouched like a vast spider on the library roof, limbs folded, waiting for someone inside.

Elias had grown up with them. The first documented manifestation happened ten years before he was born; by his childhood, they were a fact of life like weather alerts. You got your shots; you learned to cross streets safely; you understood that one day, completely at random, your personal Reaper would appear—and that from that moment on, your remaining time was an unknown number.

Once, people had believed in fate. Now they had push notifications.

“Well,” he said finally, addressing the silence at his shoulder. “You’re early.”

There was no reason to think he’d die young. No genetic markers, no risky hobbies, no chronic conditions. Life expectancy had crept back up after the initial panic years, once researchers proved that the distribution of death times remained unchanged. Some Reapers lingered for sixty years, others only minutes. On average, once they appeared, you had the same expected lifespan as before. It was just more… visible now.

“I’ve got a presentation at ten,” he added. “You’re welcome to attend.”

The Reaper did not react. Still, the lights in its depth seemed to shift, slow spirals, as if considering. He took a sip of coffee and burned his tongue. Of course.

As he walked toward the office, people glanced at him, then over his shoulder, then away. Some made the subtle gestures—thumb across palm, tap at heart—that were meant not as wards, everyone had agreed, but as “acknowledgments of existential solidarity.” Others looked almost envious; those were the ones who had made it into their thirties or forties with no Reaper yet, who felt cheated that their clock had not even started its final countdown.

At the crosswalk, the pedestrian light glowed red. Elias looked at the Reaper. “Any reason not to jaywalk?” he asked.

Logically, there wasn’t. The presence of the Reaper didn’t mean immediacy. The stories of people hit by buses seconds after arrival were counterbalanced by those that went viral: the woman whose Reaper appeared at eleven and who died peacefully at ninety-two in her garden; the pro skateboarder whose Reaper had been with him since he was eight, seen in the background of every stunt video, like a fan who never left.

But logic had always been a shoddy defense against fear.

He waited for green.

At his desk, the Reaper loomed in the cubicle corner, shrouding the potted plant in gloom. Kara from accounting swung by, saw it, and stopped mid-sentence.

“Oh,” she said softly. “Eli.”

“Got here at 8:43,” he said, trying for brisk. “Guess I’m trending.”

She hesitated, then wrapped her arms around him in a quick hug, careful not to touch the Reaper. Contact wasn’t forbidden; there were plenty of videos of people trying to high-five their Reapers. It just felt like stepping barefoot on a grave.

“Want me to run interference with Mark?” she asked.

“He’ll already know. Legal gets the manifestation feeds, right?”

She grimaced. “He does. You don’t have to do the presentation.”

“Of course I do.” The words came out too sharp. He softened them with a shrug. “If I walk out now, they’ll think I’m going to go stand on a roof edge. Might as well give them some numbers first.”

There were policies for this. After the first wave of Reaper-induced chaos, governments and HR departments scrambled to define The Rules, many of them contradictory and all of them heavily litigated.

You couldn’t fire someone just because their Reaper had appeared.

You couldn’t deny them insurance, or refuse them medical procedures, or break a lease.

You couldn’t, officially, treat them as pre-dead.

You also couldn’t sue a company if your Reaper appeared while you were on duty.

They had posters about mental-health resources. Manager training modules, “Supporting Manifested Employees.” Apps that offered probability curves, none of which changed the only truth that mattered: any minute now, or in fifty years, you would die, and this dark companion would be the last thing you saw.

Elias did the presentation. Half the room, consciously or not, aimed their gaze slightly behind him. He halfway expected the Reaper to lean into frame on the projection screen, wave skeletal fingers. It didn’t. It just stood, patient as gravity.

He found himself sharper than usual, words clipped and clear. What were they going to do, argue with the guy marked by Death? The thought was ugly. He held onto it anyway. Small advantages.

After, Mark pulled him aside.

“If you need time,” Mark said, eyes flicking to the corner where the Reaper lingered, “we can reassign projects. There’s precedent for… reprioritizing.”

“I’m not reprioritizing my life around a random variable,” Elias said. “No offense.”

The Reaper’s non-face was unreadable. It always would be.

At noon, he skipped the cafeteria crush and went to the roof. The city stretched out, crowded with living bodies and their impossible shadows. Some Reapers perched; some floated inches above the ground; others looked disconcertingly human, tailored suits and gentle smiles. His was… modest. Classic. Generic darkness, trailing threads.

He sat on the low wall, legs safely on the correct side. He was not one of those who tested limits, who dangled over highways yelling, “If it’s my time, it’s my time!” Now he understood them a little better. When the countdown is unknown, you either cling tighter to the rails or let go completely.

“You could have waited,” he said. “I was fine not knowing.”

A breeze tugged at his shirt; the Reaper’s tatters did not move.

“I had plans,” he continued. “Not big ones. Just—I thought I’d learn Italian. Go see the bioluminescent bay. Fall in love properly once. Fix things with my sister.”

He hadn’t spoken to Leah in eight months. An argument about their father’s care spiraled into old resentments. They’d both stormed off, secure in the assumption of more time.

Elias took out his phone and, after a moment, opened his messages.

He typed: Hey. Got my Reaper today.

The typing indicator appeared almost instantly. Then: I’m calling.

He almost laughed. “Look at that,” he told the Reaper. “You’re good for something.”

He answered.

Her face filled the screen; her eyes were already glossy. “You okay?” she demanded.

“I’m talking to death on my lunch break. So, you know. Could be worse.”

She snorted. “Ass.”

“Yeah,” he said. “Listen, I’m sorry. For last time. For all of it.”

She looked past him; he knew she was looking at the Reaper. “You’re not dying today,” she said fiercely, as if it were a promise she could make.

“You can’t know that,” he said, gently.

“I can decide it’s not acceptable,” she said. “You owe me dinner. At Mama Rosa’s. Tonight.”

He thought of algorithms and actuarial tables and the endless scroll of stories of people who had made plans they never kept. He thought of the cold presence at his shoulder, of unknown numbers.

“Yeah,” he said. “Tonight.”

After he hung up, he sat quietly.

“Okay,” he said to his Reaper. “Here’s the deal. Until you do whatever you’re here to do, I’m going to live like a person, not a prognosis. You can watch.”

For a second—he would swear it, later—the lights in its depths flared, like distant galaxies stirred.

He stood. He went back downstairs. He answered emails. He booked a table at Mama Rosa’s. He asked Kara if she wanted to grab coffee sometime, and when she blinked at the Reaper and then nodded, he realized he was smiling.
