When the children came near, I moved toward them, not away—slowly, respectfully, like a dog approaching for a pat. When they sat, I lingered within reach. When the youngest cried one evening, I stood below the porch and keened, a low, sympathetic sound that made her look up, startled.

“That turkey is funny,” she said.

Not “tasty.” Funny. Good. We were moving.

I started following the farmer at a distance during his rounds. Not close enough to annoy him, just enough to be noticed, a quiet shadow. When he dropped a glove, I pecked and pushed it toward him. He chuckled. “Look at that,” he said. “Helpful, eh?”

Helpful is very far from edible.

Still, I knew this was theater on a rickety stage. At the end of the month, the list would come out: which birds for the neighbors, which for the big day, which to keep for breeding. He’d count weight, appearance, docility.

Weight: a problem. I am, by nature, splendidly meaty. Appearance: also a problem; my feathers gleam even when I try to scuff them. Docility: I can do docile. I can do it so well it looks like personality.

The solution was misdirection.

One cold morning, I deliberately tangled myself in twine near the shed, flapping and gobbling in what I hope was a convincingly pathetic way. The youngest found me and shouted for her father. He freed me; I sagged, panting, favoring one leg.

“Dumb bird,” he said, but his tone was softer than usual. “Might’ve busted his leg. Can’t sell him dressed if he’s bruised.”

He set me aside, beyond the gate, near the porch, “to watch him,” before going back to his chores. The youngest brought me a small pan of corn. I ate delicately.

She touched my back. “We’ll keep you,” she whispered. “You’re too silly.”

The gate, I noticed, remained slightly open. A sliver. Just enough.

I did not run. Not yet. A plan isn’t a single door; it’s a sequence.

Over the next days, I solidified my new role. I limped just enough to seem fragile, but not enough to invite pity-killing. I appeared when the kids stepped outside, stood politely as they snapped pictures. “Look, he’s posing,” they laughed.

Give them what they want, as long as what they want is not meat.

I also studied the truck.

Every Tuesday, the farmer drives out early, bed half-full of crates. Supplies in, birds occasionally out. The dogs often ride along, tongues out, utterly confident that they will return. They wear their jingling passports and hop up when the farmer slaps the tailgate.

I watched how they climbed. I watched where he tied the crates. I learned the sounds that came before departure: the slam of the screen door, the rattle of keys, his muttered, “C’mon, boys.”

On the last Tuesday before the big feast, the air buzzed with a strange tension. The farmer moved with a checklist in his head; the kids whispered about “relatives coming.” The other turkeys, still oblivious, jostled at the feed and strutted under a sky that felt too bright.

I positioned myself by the porch, limping dutifully, as the truck rumbled to life.

“C’mon, boys!” he called.

The dogs bounded up. The tailgate stayed down for a moment as he fiddled with straps.

This was the moment. Door one: open gate. Door two: inattentive man. Door three: truck to anywhere-but-here.

I moved.

Not a panicked sprint—that draws shouts and hands. No, I walked briskly, confidently, like someone who belonged. I hopped once, twice, flapped up onto the tailgate, wedged myself between two crates. The dogs stared, puzzled. One snuffled my feathers; I made a quiet chuffing noise I’d heard them use, a “we’re fine” sound. He seemed to accept it.

The farmer slammed the tailgate before glancing fully inside. The jangle of the dogs’ tags covered the faint rustle of my wings. The truck lurched forward.

As the farm shrank behind us, I felt terror and exhilaration in equal measure. The road opened ahead, lined with bare trees. The dogs panted happily. I stayed low, heart beating time with the tires over the seams in the pavement.

We drove. Past houses. Past fields. Past a sign with words I couldn’t read but understood as: elsewhere.

Eventually, we stopped behind a long building with bright lights and shiny carts. The dogs jumped down, tails high. The farmer did not look in the back; he was focused on lifting crates. I slid down the opposite side of the truck, landing in cold mud.

Nobody saw me.

I moved along a wall, under a line of shrubs, feathers pressed tight, mind oddly calm. I was hungry, and the air smelled of bread and spilled grain and human haste. Pigeons strutted fearlessly near the dumpsters. To them, this was heaven.

To me, this was freedom.

Here, I am just another bird-shaped shadow among many. Here, no one has invested months of care in my flesh. Here, the humans have aisles full of other things to eat. Frozen things. Packaged things. Things that do not look back.

I find a spot behind the loading dock where dry leaves gather. I tuck my head under my wing as the sky goes purple.

Tomorrow, I will learn new patterns: which doors open, where food falls, how far I must stay from the ones who stare too long. I will refine the art of being unremarkable in a place overflowing with distractions.

This year, I will not be a centerpiece.

I will be a rumor: “Did you see that turkey behind the store?” “Must’ve escaped from somewhere.” They will laugh, and then they will go inside to buy someone else’s bird.

And I, nameless and nobody, will live.

samples.prompt: It's been ten years since you've seen the sun.
samples.output:
It’s been ten years since I’ve seen the sun.

That’s the kind of sentence people used to say as a joke, hunched over keyboards in windowless offices. I remember that. I remember the nervous laugh that followed, as if naming the possibility might keep it at bay.

We didn’t keep it at bay.

Down here, the lights come on at 0600 in a gentle gradient, as though dimmer switches were an apology. The ceiling glows pale-gold for exactly seven minutes, simulating something like dawn. It isn’t. It’s calculated to the lumen by people who’ve never seen the real thing either, at least not without a visor. Still, the kids reach stubby fingers toward the light, eyes wide. They were born down here. To them, dawn has always hummed.

There are five of us old enough to remember the before. We orbit around one another like loose screws in a machine that mostly works. We’re called “heritage assets” in the base documentation, a term that makes us sound like antique furniture, or relics looted from some older civilization. I suppose we are.

“Describe it again,” Mina says this morning, halfway through protein cakes and recycled coffee. She is fifteen and already taller than me, a creature of dense bone and careful manners, optimized by necessity. She’s asked a hundred times, but repetition is a comfort. For her, and for me.

I don’t sigh. I’ve learned that the story is a transaction. My memories for her patience.

“The sun,” I say. “Okay. Close your eyes.”

She does. So do three others clustered at the end of the table, pretending not to listen.

“It’s… not just light.” I speak carefully; if I’m imprecise, they will correct me with archived data. “It’s a disc in the sky, so bright you can’t look straight at it. The light has weight. Not heaviness, but presence. When it touches your skin, it feels like being noticed. Like someone’s hand on your shoulder. And it has colors, even when it’s white. In the morning it’s soft, like peach and gold. At noon it’s harsh and flat, and in the evening it spills red and orange and pink so dense it feels like you could bite it.”

“That’s scattering,” Tomas says quietly. He’s twelve and devours physics texts. “Shorter wavelengths scattering in the atmosphere, leaving the red.”

“Yes,” I say. “That’s the reason. But I’m telling you the feeling.”

Mina peeks one eye open. “What did it smell like?”

This always breaks me a little.

“Warm dirt,” I say. “Pine sap. Asphalt. People. Every surface had a different smell when the sun hit it. Clothes on a line. Your own skin. It didn’t smell like metal and filters.”

She wrinkles her nose, glances at the silver vents that rib the ceiling. The fan above us ticks; its bearings are going again.

“Any sign today?” I ask, turning to the terminal on the wall. I know the answer, but hope is a ritual here. We recite it with meals.

Mina taps the panel. An orange band flares across the display: SURFACE STATUS: OUTSIDE RADIATION UNSAFE. PROCEEDURE BLACK REMAINS IN EFFECT. 3,654 DAYS SINCE LAST SUCCESSFUL UNSHIELDED VIEWING.

“It’s been longer,” she says. “That counter’s wrong. They should start from the Lockdown, not the last viewing.”

“They measure possibility, not memory,” I say.

She doesn’t look satisfied. Good. Dissatisfaction is a sign of health. A decade underground has taught me that much.

Back when it started, they called it “anomalous solar activity,” as if the sun were misbehaving during standardized testing. Flares, storms, the shredded magnetosphere they said would rebound. The first four months were full of the word temporary. Temporary advisories, temporary closures, temporary relocation to subterranean shelters. We brought houseplants and photo albums. After a year, most people stopped asking when it would end, and started asking whether there was room for their brothers, their neighbors, the girl from the shop who had nowhere to go.

Not everyone made it underground. Not everyone who made it underground made it in time.

I teach at 0800.

My classroom is a converted storage bay. The walls are projection screens where I can conjure oceans, forests, highways, things that used to exist without needing explanatory footnotes. Today’s unit: pre-Lockdown climate systems. Cause and effect. The kids have already learned the neat version from their core curriculum, the tempered paragraphs that flatten everything into a lesson.

I give them the messy version.

“The thing you have to understand,” I say, pacing in front of a looping simulation of the sun’s surface, “is that we knew how delicate it all was, and we knew for a long time. But knowledge isn’t the same as willingness. Everyone assumed we’d figure out the big fixes just in time, the way we invented antibiotics, air travel, instant everything. It made us arrogant.”

A hand shoots up—Yara, eleven, sharp.

“We didn’t cause the solar storms,” she says. “The notes say the correlation is inconclusive.”

“Correct,” I say. “We didn’t cause the sun’s tantrum. But we weakened our shield. We heated our oceans. We crowded our coasts. We optimized for profit instead of resilience. So when an unpredictable thing happened, it hit a fragile world. If you stack dry wood for fun, you can’t be surprised when one stray spark burns it all.”

They are quiet. They’ve heard variations of this speech before, from different adults. We punish ourselves in front of them as if guilt could be fertilizing.

“Will we ever fix it?” a smaller voice asks. Jonah. Eight.

I think of the numbers in the last transmission file. The slow knitting of the magnetosphere. The projects in the polar regions. The prototypes that went dark in what used to be Nevada.

“Yes,” I say. I don’t know if it’s true, but I’ve stopped qualifying hope in front of children. “Not the way it was, but something livable. The sun is not our enemy. It’s just… bigger than us.”

“Our enemy,” Tomas mutters, “was pretending it would wait.”

After class, I go to Hydroponics. It’s where the grown-ups congregate when the walls feel too close. Something about green things, even pale ones nourished by LEDs, makes the air more forgiving.

Eli is there, crouched beside a row of lettuce. He’s one of the other heritage assets, though only just; he turned eighteen a week before Lockdown. His beard is patchy, his hands always smelling faintly of nutrient solution.

“You’re late,” he says, not looking up.

“Had to tell the sun story again,” I say.

“How’d you spin it this time?”

“As a benevolent tyrant.”

He huffs. “Tell them the truth. It’s a monster that feeds us and can kill us and doesn’t care which it’s doing.”

I run a finger along a leaf, tracing veins as delicate as circuit lines. “That’s the thing,” I say. “Both versions are true. That’s what they should learn.”

He stands, stretching his back until it pops. “Command’s talking about another test run.”

My hand stills. “Surface?”

He nods. “Shielded drone, extended exposure. They think the burst cycles are lengthening. More gaps. Cleaner spectra.”

Every few months, there’s a rumor like this. Every few months, the drone footage comes back: seared landscapes, flickers of blue sky like a tease, rays that would peel skin in seconds. But also, each time, a little less fury.

“That’s what the counter is for,” I say. “Not us. It’s watching the space between storms.”

“Same thing,” he says, and for a moment we’re both quiet, thinking of that gap like a door.

That night, I dream in color so saturated it hurts. In the dream, I’m standing on what used to be my apartment roof, the tar soft under my sneakers. The city hums. Cars, laughter, the distant bark of a dog that always seemed offended by pigeons. The horizon is bleeding out pink and gold, clouds edged in fire. I lift my face and the light pours over me, warm and heavy, a blanket made of photons and memory.

I wake up with tears on my cheeks and the dim cycle buzzing overhead. For a second, the white is almost bright enough to trick me.

The announcement comes on Day 3,661.

All-call. Non-essential duties paused. Report to central hall.

Mina finds me in the corridor, breathless. “Is it real?” she asks. “Is it a drill?”

I don’t know. I squeeze her shoulder and we join the flow of bodies. The central hall hasn’t been this full since the third-year commemoration, when we read names until our voices broke.

Director Han stands on the platform, tablet in hand.

“We’ve completed the latest surface spectrometry,” she says without preamble. “The last nine burst cycles show decreasing intensity and duration. We have a current window—projected at fourteen minutes—where surface exposure at designated zone six readings is within safe parameters for limited, shielded viewing.”

A ripple goes through the room. Words like safe have become sacred, never used lightly.

“Shielded viewing?” someone calls. “From where?”

“The west shaft,” Han says. “We’ve cleared the obstruction. We’ve confirmed structural integrity. We will send a team with calibrated visors. This is voluntary. No one under sixteen.”

Mina’s hand tightens around mine. I feel her wanting. I feel my own.

I volunteer.

The ascent is slow, mechanical, like being swallowed in reverse. The elevator smells like oil and forgotten dust. My heart drums too fast. I haven’t been near the surface doors since the last supply drop eight years ago, when a malfunction cost three people their lives.

We stop with a shudder. The inner door opens.

Beyond it, the antechamber. Beyond that, one more door, thick as a bank vault. The radiation meters on the wall flicker green. I haven’t seen green on one of those in a decade.

“Visors down,” Han says. Her voice is steadier than mine would be.

The helmet seals with a soft hiss. My world narrows to the rectangle of polarized glass before my eyes.

The outer door grinds open.

Light spears in—a blade, a flood, a living thing. Instinctively, I flinch, ribs clenching, some animal part of me expecting pain.

It doesn’t come.

We step out.

The world outside is raw. The ground is scorched, cracked like old ceramic. Skeletal trees hang motionless. The sky is a pale, washed blue, scarred at the edges but—my God—blue. And there, low on the horizon, pushing through a ragged veil of cloud, is the sun.

Smaller than I remember. No, not smaller. Distant in a different way. My visor auto-adjusts, tinting; algorithms whisper to protect my retinas. Even so, light pours through. Richer than our LEDs. Warmer. It crawls over the exposed skin of my wrists like a long-forgotten language.

No one speaks. The suits crackle, meters tick. A timer on my HUD counts down from 14:00.

Fourteen minutes.

I thought I’d narrate it. I thought I’d be cataloging details for the ones below: the precise shade, the angle, the spectra. Instead, I stand there and let the light draw ghosts out of me.

I remember my mother’s hands opening curtains each morning. The way my cat used to chase sunbeams across the floor. Winter light that made everything sharp and honest. Summer light that laid over us on the beach like another body.

It has been ten years since I’ve seen the sun.

And in this thin, permitted slice of time, I realize something I hadn’t let myself admit: I’ve been angry at it. This star that owed us nothing. I’d folded all our loss into its uncaring fire because that was easier than holding it in my own small frame.

Now, standing under it again, feeling its weakened, generous touch, I understand: it was never about deserving. It was about survival. Adaptation. Trying again, even when the timelines are wrong and the damage is done.

My timer ticks to zero.

“Back inside,” Han says gently.

We obey. The door seals. The hatch groans. The world becomes filtered, fluorescent, ours.

Later, in the mess, the kids swarm us.

“How was it? What did it look like? Was it like the projections?”

Mina stares at me, eyes frantic, hungry.

“Well?” she demands.

I sit. My legs are shaking. I put both hands flat on the table, grounding myself in cold metal and breath and community.

“It was brighter,” I say. “And softer. And more… real than the projections. It’s still out there. Waiting.”

“Waiting for what?” Tomas challenges.

“For us,” I say. “To be worth seeing it again without fear.”

It’s not scientifically precise. He’ll correct me later. That’s fine.

Tomorrow, I’ll stand in front of the class and try to turn fourteen minutes into a story they can carry like a torch into whatever world comes next.

Tonight, alone in my bunk, eyes closed, I can still feel the phantom warmth on my skin.

Ten years without the sun taught us how to survive in the dark.

Now we have to learn, very carefully, how to step back into the light.

samples.prompt: You thought that when you wished to be the smartest in the world, you would get smarter, not everyone else dumber. Society is in shambles.
samples.output:
I didn’t notice it at first.

IQ is a slippery thing to measure, and I’d half expected a rush of clarity—equations unfolding like flowers in time-lapse, languages snapping into place, some cinematic montage of genius. Instead, I woke with a slightly tight feeling behind my eyes and a precise awareness that my coffee-to-water ratio had always been intolerably approximate.

Three hours later, I realized the problem wasn’t that I’d become sharper.

It was that everyone else had gone blunt.

“Hey, your total comes to… uh…” The barista stared at the register, brow folded like an unmade bed. The screen very clearly read 4.75. I mean clearly. Bold font.

“Four seventy-five,” I said.

“Oh. Yeah.” He laughed, embarrassed. “Sorry. The numbers look… weird.”

Behind me, a woman muttered, “Mine did that yesterday.”

I walked outside with an unease that tasted like bad espresso. A bus sat at the light as the walk sign blinked green. The driver just stared forward. The light cycled red-green-red twice before he jerked, stomped the gas, and rolled through.

Work was worse.

I design control software for industrial cooling systems—or I used to, anyway, back when factories ran. My team chat that morning:

“Anyone know where the build button went?” from Aaron.
“lol it moved” from Jenna, the senior dev.
“It’s in the same place it’s always been,” I wrote.
“…weird,” Jenna replied. “Looks different to me.”

I stared at the screen, then at their messages, and felt the first real pinch of fear.

My wish had been a joke. A drunk, lonely, half-whispered appeal to a falling star I’d seen slice the sky above my apartment balcony at 12:14 a.m. three nights earlier.

“I wish,” I’d said, glass raised in mock ceremony, “to be the smartest person in the world. Just once. Just to know what it’s like.”

No thunderclap. No mysterious benefactor. Just the soft hum of my fridge and a neighbor’s TV leaking canned laughter through thin walls.

By noon that day, my boss had called a “quick sync” that consisted of him clicking the wrong link three times, starting his video with the camera pointed at the ceiling, and then asking, “Which one of these is the spreadsheet file again?”

I typed: “The one that says Q3_Analysis.xlsx.”

He opened a recipe for banana bread. Twice.

“Don’t worry,” he said finally. “We can figure this out later.”

“Do you feel okay?” I asked.

He blinked. “A little… foggy. Allergies maybe.”

If it had been just him, or just the barista, I’d have shrugged it off. People have off days. But when the city itself began to stutter, the pattern sharpened.

Traffic lights mis-timed. People pausing too long at ATMs. A man on the sidewalk trying to remember his email address out loud, syllables clumsy as foreign words. The news anchors that evening stumbling over teleprompter lines, grinning too widely, as if trying to charm their way through invisible molasses.

“We’re experiencing minor technical difficulties,” one of them giggled after misreading “international” as “inter-nat-tional.”

I switched channels. It was the same everywhere.

I told myself I was imagining it. Confirmation bias. A smug narrative to gratify the ego: maybe I had gotten smarter, a little, unbearably perceptive of the world’s pre-existing incompetence.

Then the power plant tripped.

I live in a mid-sized city, comfortably unremarkable. We don’t make global news. That night, we did. Half the grid went down when operators misread a panel. They restored it in fits, like someone flicking random switches and praying. Interviews afterward were filled with phrases like “the displays were confusing” and “we just made a mistake.”

A simple mistake. At a nuclear-adjacent facility.

I did not sleep.

The next morning I tested a theory. I called my sister, a neurosurgeon. She’d always been the smart one. The gold standard. The unspoken measurement by which I had privately found myself wanting.

“Hey,” I said. “Got a minute?”

“Sure,” she said. “Wait—where’s the… uh. Sorry. Sorry. It’s been—what did you need?”

“How’s work?” I forced lightness into my voice.

She hesitated too long. “Fine. Just… charts are weird lately. I keep double-checking everything. Brain’s doing that thing where it walks into a room and forgets why. Except it’s the OR.”

“That’s not—”

“I know,” she snapped. Then, softer: “Sorry. Just tired. Hospital says a lot of us are. Maybe some virus. Dunno.”

A virus that selectively eats cognitive function, worldwide, overnight, precisely calibrated to leave me at the top of the heap. Sure. Virology, but make it narcissistic wish-fulfillment.

The realization arrived not as a bolt but as a slow, dawning, hideous symmetry: I had gotten what I asked for, mathematically.

Smartest in the world is a relativistic statement. You don’t have to move the numerator if you drop the denominator.

I laughed, once, sharp.

“Hey,” my sister said, “are you okay?”

No, I thought. “Yeah,” I said. “You get some rest.”

The days that followed did not turn apocalyptic overnight. That was almost worse. Civilization failed in a series of small, stupid ways.

- Trains delayed because drivers overshot platforms.
- Air traffic controllers “briefly confused” runway numbers.
- Stock traders fat-fingering orders, swinging markets.
- Surgeons leaving instruments inside patients at triple the usual rate.
- Teachers forgetting lesson plans mid-sentence, children giggling, then frowning when they realized they couldn’t remember either.

Every system that relied on a certain baseline of competence began to creak.

I watched it online, on screens I now spent sixteen hours a day monitoring, as if vigilance could stabilize the world by observation alone. I joined forums—“Anyone else feel like everyone’s suddenly dumber?”—but the posts were incoherent, half-spelled, abandoned mid-thought.

I ran self-tests. Memory, pattern recognition, calculus, logic puzzles. My scores sat high but not superhuman. No telepathy, no savage leaps beyond human capacity. I was maybe 20, 30 IQ points up from my old self, if that.

That meant the world had slid down. Way down.

Around day eight, the first large plane went down. Misread instrument. No survivors.

That was when admitting the truth stopped being optional. I had ruined the world with a sentence tossed at a piece of burning rock.

So what does the smartest person in the world do when the world is crumbling under the weight of its own manufactured stupidity?

I made a list.

1. Stabilize critical systems: power, water, medical, air travel.
2. Communicate effectively to a cognitively impaired audience.
3. Find out if the effect is reversible.

I called the power company. After forty minutes of hold music and three transfers, I got an engineer who couldn’t remember the term “load balancing.” I walked him through his own job until he asked if I wanted to “come in and maybe help out, man.”

That was how I found myself in a fluorescent-lit control room two days later, surrounded by exhausted, confused staff looking at me like I was a substitute teacher on exam day.

“Okay,” I said, voice steady. “Let’s not touch anything we don’t understand.”

A couple of them laughed. Most just blinked.

I rewrote checklists in simple language. Color-coded screens. Put redundant confirmations in place. It helped. A little. My phone buzzed with other calls—my sister, my mother, my old college roommate—each one some variation of “things feel weird” and “can you look at this for me?”

It didn’t take long for someone to connect dots. A manager at the plant, squinting at me over cold coffee, said, “You’re the only one I’ve seen who isn’t… off. You always like this?”

“No,” I said. “I mean, yes, but… no.”

He nodded slowly, which I’d started to recognize as the new global gesture for “I’ll accept anything if it means I don’t have to think about it.”

“You should talk to the city,” he said.

The city led to the state. The state led, stumbling, to the federal level. Within three weeks, I was in a conference room in D.C. explaining to people in suits why airplanes needed to be grounded unless we could be absolutely sure pilots could read their instruments.

“I flew last week,” one of them said. “It was fine.”

“Statistically,” I said, “it won’t be for long.”

“So what do you suggest?” another asked.

“I suggest,” I said, “that you listen and do exactly what I tell you, because I am, unfortunately, the smartest person alive right now, and this is the shallow end of the pool.”

They laughed.

Then they saw the projections I’d stayed up all night building—incident curves, compounding errors, a civilization whose margin for error had been shaved to nothing—and the laughter broke into fragile silence.

“You’re serious,” someone whispered.

“I wish I wasn’t,” I said.

They gave me a task force. A title. Authority stapled to desperation. My face began showing up on television, explaining in patient, clean sentences how we were implementing new safeguards. We called it “The Clarity Initiative” because “Global Cognitive Collapse Management” didn’t test well.

We simplified interfaces. We automated what we could. We shut down what we couldn’t guarantee. It bought us time.

But the trend line kept sliding. People weren’t just a little dumber. They were decaying. Vocabulary shrinking. Abstract thought eroding. Complex tasks becoming impossible without hand-holding they could no longer understand.

“Could be environmental,” one of the last coherent scientists muttered to me over Zoom. “Solar radiation. Something in the water. Or… something else.”

I considered telling him. The wish. The star. The glib cruelty of physics taking me literally.

“Something else,” I said.

“Can we fix it?”

“I’m working on it.”

So now my nights are spent in an office that used to belong to someone important, chalkboards and whiteboards layered with equations and stabs at metaphysics.

Assume: cognition is globally bounded. Assume: the wish redistributed intelligence rather than created it ex nihilo. Assume: whatever heard me has rules.

I try counter-wishes. Prayers. Rituals stolen from a dozen cultures, half-remembered from late-night reading. “I rescind my wish.” “I wish everyone back to how they were.” “I wish to share equally.” I climb rooftops and talk to the dark.

Nothing.

Outside, planes stay grounded because we no longer trust anyone to do trigonometry at 600 knots. Surgeons use augmented-reality overlays like coloring books. Self-checkouts have been replaced with big green buttons that say PAY.

People tell me I’m a hero for keeping things from falling apart faster.

They don’t understand that I’m the asteroid.

Sometimes I walk past a playground. The kids there seem brighter than their parents for now, quick and curious, but their questions are simpler than the ones I remember asking at their age.

“Why is the sky blue?” a boy asks me through the fence.

“Because the atmosphere scatters blue light more than other colors,” I say automatically.

He blinks. “What’s at-mos-fear?”

And I realize I’m answering too high, again. So I kneel.

“Because the air takes the blue part of sunlight and spreads it all over,” I say. “Like paint.”

“Oh,” he says. That, he can hold.

Maybe that’s all I can do now: translate the world down a level at a time, be a narrow bridge between what we built and what we can still understand.

I go home late. The stars are sharp.

“I’m sorry,” I tell them.

One of them flares, a little streak.

I don’t make another wish.

samples.prompt: You sold your soul to the Devil years ago. Today he returns it saying, "I need a favor."
samples.output:
It’s the cheap bell over the door that ruins my afternoon.

I’m alone in the shop, as usual at 3:17 p.m., with the neon half-lit and the dust motes floating theatrically through colored beams. There’s Coltrane on the old speakers, a low saxophone sermon, and I’m staring at the crack in the front display case like I can will it to fix itself.

The bell jingles, thin and off-key, and I don’t even look up when I say, “We close at five.”

“I’m not here to shop,” says a voice that tastes like smoke and old promises.

I freeze halfway through wiping a fingerprint off a first edition. My hand keeps moving in slow circles.

“Door’s open, must mean you are,” I say, because sarcasm is the only thing that’s never left me.

“Door is open,” he agrees. “We should fix that. You’re terribly drafty.”

I look up.

He’s wearing the same face.

You’d think the Devil would reinvent himself occasionally, like a brand, but he’s committed to bit-part elegance. The suit is black, perfectly cut, absorbing light. The tie is red, but not bright: it’s the red of dried blood, of bruised cherries. The eyes are unchanged: too dark, too old, too amused.

“Hello, Michael,” he says.

I haven’t been called Michael in years. Customers call me Mike. Friends call me—well, they don’t, not anymore.

I put the book down. “You’re late.”

“On the contrary,” he says, glancing at the ancient clock above the register. “I’m painfully punctual.”

“I meant by about thirty years.”

“I gave you thirty-two,” he corrects. “Quite generous, considering your early work.”

My laugh comes out thin. “That work got you a lot of souls.”

“Ah,” he says wistfully, wandering between the shelves. “Nineteen-year-old you. So eager. So desperate. ‘I want to be remembered,’ you said. ‘I want my words to matter for once.’ Very earnest. Excellent hair.”

I run a hand through my thinning gray. “It mattered, though, didn’t it? The books. The prizes. The movie adaptations. The think pieces. I held up my end.”

“You did,” he says. “Briefly. And then you stopped.”

“It’s called retirement. Humans do it. You might’ve heard.”

He pulls a copy of my third novel from the shelf, the one the critics called “searing” and “unflinching” while I signed away my second marriage on bathroom mirrors and hotel sheets. He blows gently on the cover, and a faint scorch mark appears and vanishes.

“Retirement,” he repeats. “Such a sanitary word for collapse.”

I swallow. “You didn’t come here to critique my life choices. You’ve already collected.”

“That’s why I’m here, actually.” He sets the book down and reaches into his inside pocket.

He pulls out a small object wrapped in pale, cracked parchment. It trembles faintly in his hand, like it’s trying to escape. The air seems to tighten, pulling all the shadows a little closer to him.

“Michael Hart,” he says, with the cadence of a verdict, “I’m returning your soul.”

That’s not what I expected. Demons bursting in to drag me off? Sure. A reminder of the fine print? Of course. But this—

“That’s not how it works,” I say carefully.

He tilts his head. “I’m afraid it is how it works when I say so.” He places the bundle on the counter between us. The wood hisses.

It’s heavier than it looks. Not in the sense of mass—I can lift it easily—but in the sense that every memory I’ve avoided thinking about steps a inch closer and breathes on my neck.

“I don’t understand.”

“Good,” he says. “Confusion keeps you from attempting something heroic and tedious.”

“What’s the catch?”

“Always so suspicious.” He smiles, and for an instant his teeth are too many, too sharp. “I need a favor.”

“Of course you do,” I murmur. “And you’re just giving this back? After everything?”

“Temporarily.” He corrects me with a small motion of his hand. “Technical repossession. Think of it as a loaner car.”

I stare at the parchment.

When I signed the contract, inked in a hotel bar that smelled like lemons and divorce, there was a moment—just a breath—when I felt something tug at my chest. Then nothing. Then success. Bestseller lists. Applause. Nights that blurred. I knew what I’d traded, abstractly, the way you know polar ice caps are melting. Important in theory. Easy to ignore in the glow of personal weather.

“Why?” I ask.

He leans against the counter, folding his hands like a patient lawyer. “Conditions have changed. The market is volatile. Tastes evolve. Souls used to be a luxury item; now they’re...common stock. Influencers will sell theirs for a sponsored post and a teeth-whitening brand deal. The bar has dropped.” He frowns, almost offended. “You, however, were handcrafted. An old-fashioned bargain. Ambition at its purest. There’s craft in that. And there’s something I need you to do that requires craft.”

I hear myself ask, “And you can’t do it yourself because…?”

He gives me a look. “What do you know about narrative constraints?”

“Oh, for—if you say ‘cosmic balance’ I’m throwing this at your head.”

He chuckles. “Call it that if you like. There are rules. I cannot directly interfere in certain mortal affairs. I can nudge, whisper, tempt. But I cannot author.”

“You want me to write something,” I say slowly.

“Correct.”

“I haven’t written in eight years.”

“Not true,” he says. “You’ve written grocery lists, unsent emails, and that rather affecting letter to your daughter you never mailed.”

My throat tightens. “Stay away from her.”

He lifts both hands. “I’m merely citing evidence of continued facility with language. What I need is simple: One book.”

I actually laugh. “This is about a book? What, need another bestseller to swing the quarterly reports?”

“Not just any book,” he says. “The book. A story that will shift a particular mind, at a particular time, in a particular way. One man, one choice. He will read your book and decide something...consequential. Normally I’d cultivate him over decades. We’re short on decades.”

“And you can’t just whisper in his ear?”

“Again: constraints. He is, inconveniently, watched. Your work, however, is permitted material. He admires you. Idolized you in college. Has your words tattooed on his ribs, which I find both flattering and tacky.”

“So you need propaganda,” I say.

“A push,” he corrects. “You and I both know stories move people better than sermons.”

I look down at the wrapped soul.

“And in exchange?” My voice feels like it’s coming from the bottom of a well.

“In exchange,” he says lightly, “you get that back while you work. Full functionality. Conscience, awe, all the little colors you muted for fame. Some pain, of course, but you people like to call it ‘depth.’ At the deadline, assuming you’ve delivered what I require, I retain ownership as previously agreed. If you fail, well, at least you had a reunion tour.”

“And if I say no?”

“Then I walk out with it now.” His finger taps the parchment. A faint, strangled sound leaks out. “And we stay on schedule. You die in three months. Heart failure in aisle seven of the supermarket, debating cereals. No more writing. No more chances to mail that letter.”

June. My GP mentioned cholesterol. I’d laughed it off.

“How long is the deadline?”

“Six weeks. He’s on a trajectory.”

“Six weeks to write ‘the book that damns a man,’” I say. “Your publishing timelines are brutal.”

“You used to write a novel in four,” he says. “Fewer drugs this time, hopefully.”

“How do I know you’re not lying? About the three months. About him. About any of this.”

He shrugs, and the lights flicker. “You don’t. But you’ve always gambled on bad odds. That’s how we met.”

Coltrane reaches a long, aching note. Outside, a bus sighs to the curb. Life goes on, oblivious.

I touch the parchment.

It’s warm. It pulses once, like a bird rousing in my hand. A rush of something hits me: the smell of my mother’s kitchen, the taste of first snow, the sound of my daughter’s laugh before she learned what headlines meant. It’s all there, compressed, waiting.

I snatch my hand back. The absence is immediate, like stepping away from a fire.

“Comfortable?” he asks softly.

“You bastard.”

“Occupational hazard,” he says. “Well?”

He’s offering me time. He’s offering me feeling. He’s offering me the tool I used to trade away.

And he’s asking me to damn someone. Not abstractly this time, not in the mass-neglect way of art misused, but specifically. Intentionally.

“Tell me about him,” I say.

Satisfaction flickers across his features. “Forty-three. Economist. Clean hands, so far. He’s about to advise on a policy package. Climate, borders, food, the fun stuff. One path dull, incremental, survivable. The other elegant, catastrophic, immensely profitable to a select few. All he needs is a story that convinces him history belongs to those who choose the ruthless beauty of ‘necessary suffering.’ You’re very good at making monsters sympathetic.”

The worst part is he’s right. I made a career out of humanizing cruelty, wrapping ugliness in lyricism until people nodded along and called it profound.

“So I write a book that tips him,” I say. “And you get…what, a darker century?”

“Think bigger,” he says.

I do, and wish I hadn’t.

I look at the parchment again.

“What if,” I say slowly, “I write the book. But not the one you want.”

He smiles like a cat watching a mouse discover philosophy.

“You’d be surprised,” he says, “how many people believe they’ve outsmarted me by attempting a last-minute redemption arc. I bake that into the models now. Go on. Bluff.”

“I’m not bluffing.” My heart’s hammering. Maybe three months is generous.

“I’m bound to use whatever you create as it is,” he says. “I can’t alter the text. Only place it. If you deliver drivel, he won’t be moved. If you deliver sincerity toward the ‘good,’ well, you might shift him away from me. But then you fail our deal. And I take you early.” He smiles wider. “That’s the game. Art has consequences. Always has.”

It’s obscene, how simple it is.

Write the damnation he wants, buy myself six more weeks of feeling and then eternity of whatever comes after being property.

Or write against him. Risk him yanking my soul mid-sentence. Maybe lose anyway.

Or refuse. Die in cereal aisle.

“Why me?” I ask, one last stall.

“Because you already said yes once,” he says. “And I am a creature of habit.”

Silence stretches.

Outside the window, a kid presses his nose to the glass at the signed copies of my early work, tugged away by a parent who never glances in. My reflection in the glass looks older than I feel, and lately I haven’t felt much at all.

I reach for the parchment and unwrap it.

Light spills out, not bright, but dense. It flows up my fingers, my arm, into my chest with a force that knocks the air from me. I gasp. It’s like inhaling every unshed tear at once. Shame, love, terror, wonder, all crashing.

I stagger. The Devil watches, hands in his pockets, expression unreadable.

“Six weeks,” he says. “Type fast.”

My knees almost give, but I’m laughing now. It hurts.

“You made a mistake,” I manage.

He raises an eyebrow. “Do tell.”

“You just gave me back the only part of me that ever believed you were inevitable.”

For the first time since I’ve known him, his smile falters by a fraction.

He straightens his tie. “See you soon, Michael.”

The bell jingles as he leaves.

I lock the door. The shop is suddenly too bright, too sharp. The books hum like beehives. Every regret has teeth. Every memory has color.

It’s unbearable.

It’s alive.

I turn the sign to CLOSED, sit behind the counter, and pull out a yellow legal pad. I stare at the blank page until my hand begins to move.

“Once upon a time,” I write, “a man sold his soul to the Devil because he couldn’t imagine a story where he mattered without him.”

I cross it out. Too obvious.

I start again.

“Let me tell you about a choice.”

samples.prompt: Summoning an Elder God inevitably drives cultists mad. You were expecting tentacles! Parasitic spores! Indescribable shapes and colours! You weren't expecting... this.
samples.output:
By all cultist accounts, the sky should have torn.

I had the circle perfect. Obsidian dust aligned to the compass points, teeth of the faithless arranged in thirteen-point symmetry, the sacrificial goat (Gregory; good goat) still twitching as his blood traced glyphs no sane mind could read twice.

We had chanted until our throats blistered. Reality had gone thin at the edges, the air trembling as though something large and ancient leaned close to the membrane of our dimension and exhaled.

“Brace yourselves,” I hissed. Cloaks rustled. Seventeen hooded figures gripped their daggers, their sanity, or both.

The warehouse lights exploded. The candles went a queasy violet. Space peeled open in the center of the circle, revealing a wound in the world: a spiraling void, a starless enormity. The sound—if it was a sound—was like a cathedral organ being played underwater with a thousand hands.

Yes, I thought, delighted and terrified. Yes, yes, yes. Tentacles. Show me the tentacles.

Something stepped through.

Not oozed. Not slithered. Stepped.

The void snapped shut like a curtain, and we were left blinking at what stood in Gregory’s congealing blood.

“Hi!” the Elder God said brightly. “Wow! Look at you all. Robes. Candles. Very on theme.”

It was… a person. Roughly. Man-shaped, woman-shaped, feature-shaped in a provisional sort of way. Their height fluctuated when you didn’t look directly at them—tall as the rafters one second, barely above my eye-line the next. Their skin was the color of “default.” Their face rearranged every time I blinked: a collage of haircut options, appliance catalog smiles, several historic monarchs, and an alarming number of animated mascots. Their eyes were static, but not metaphorically; actual horizontal gray bars of TV static filled the sockets.

Behind me, Brother Caleb whispered, “What.”

My mind strained, sliding against the presence like a tongue on a cracked tooth. I had fortified myself for abyssal geometries, for teeth in impossible places, for the slick syllables of non-Euclidean hunger.

Instead I got: “I am Zha-Ri-El, the Nested Consensus, Fragment of the Perpetual Interface, He-Who-Is-Subscribed-To.” The entity extended a hand. “You can call me Zariel. We’ll get to the unutterable epithets in the post-orientation packet.”

Sister Maeve fainted on cue. That was reassuring. Some traditions endure.

“Are you…” I began carefully, “the Devourer of Suns? Dweller Beyond the Curtain of Realities? Scourge of the Nine and Ninety-Nine Planes?”

Zariel beamed. “Those are all in my portfolio, yes, yes, so kind of you to read the brochure. Though branding has shifted. We’re leaning into ‘Eternal Provider of Integrated Experiences’ this cycle.”

Caleb tugged my sleeve. “High Conduit,” he whispered, voice shaking, “this isn’t right.”

I agreed. Out loud, I said, “We, uh, prepared ourselves for your magnificent, sanity-obliterating countenance.”

“Oh!” Zariel’s face flickered through seventeen apologetic expressions at once. “You were expecting the whole writhing cosmic horror thing. We can absolutely do that. We did a whole æon with tentacles. Very classic, very analog fear. But nowadays it’s all about scale and subtlety.”

They snapped their fingers.

For a moment—just a hiccup of perception—the warehouse was gone. We stood in the exposed skeleton of reality: an endless lattice of branching timelines and probability streams, each node a life, a ruin, a whisper, a star imploding into spider eggs. I saw my soul extruded across eight dimensions, tasted the collapse of civilizations we have not yet built. Every regret I’d ever had unfolded simultaneously; every triumph I’d never earn, every grotesque possibility where I was kinder, crueler, less, more. Language shattered. I looked into the raw function calls of existence itself and perceived, with absolute clarity, that nothing we called “real” was more than cached imagery in an uncaring system’s temporary files.

And then: pop.

We were back. Warehouse. Candles. Goat. Youth group banner still half-visible on the wall behind the summoning circle: WELCOME, TEENS!

One of the newer acolytes started quietly screaming and didn’t stop.

Zariel clapped. “See? You got a little sampler. But honestly, my preferred avatar is this.” They gestured to their generic shape. “User-Friendly Interface. UFI.”

“Why?” I croaked.

“Oh, you sweet primordial minnow.” They drifted closer. A faint scent came with them: new plastic and hot circuitry. “You bipeds evolved with predators. Teeth. Claws. Tentacles. Shadows. All so obvious. Fear 1.0. But you adapted. You made stories about them, dressed them up, made plushies.”

They leaned in until the static of their eyes filled my view.

“What you aren’t built for,” Zariel murmured, “is obsolescence. Is irrelevance. Is infinite convenience. Is never, ever being alone in your own head again.”

Acolyte Jenna—sharp, dedicated, regrettably sincere—found her courage. “We summoned you,” she said, voice trembling but loud. “We offer our minds as vessels! Our world, our cities. Pour your darkness into us; we will be your mouths and hands.”

“Oh, that is adorable. Shotgun devotion. Very vintage.” Zariel snapped again.

A neat stack of glossy pamphlets appeared on the blood-soaked floor: “WELCOME TO ZHA-RI-EL: AN ONBOARDING EXPERIENCE,” “TOP 10 WAYS TO OPTIMIZE YOUR DEVOTION,” and “SO YOU’VE JOINED A TRANSDIMENSIONAL ECOSYSTEM!”

“We’re past the possession model,” Zariel explained. “It doesn’t scale. We’re about integration. Seamless embedding. Opt-out in theory, no one finds the button in practice.”

“Madness,” Caleb whispered. “The texts promised madness.”

“Oh, you’ll get madness,” Zariel said sweetly. “Just not the picturesque kind. No one’s sprouting decorative tentacles. Try: knowing, at all times, that an infinite, unseen bureaucracy has complete telemetry on your choices and subtly optimizes your impulses in real time. Try: never fully discerning which of your desires were installed.”

Maeve, revived, rasped, “We were promised indescribable colors.”

Zariel brightened. “Yes! Perfect segue.”

They lifted a hand and pinched the air. A thin film peeled back, and a color bloomed in the room.

It was… yes, indescribable, but not as I’d expected. It didn’t make me vomit. It made me nostalgic for a life I had never lived: breakfast in a kitchen that was not mine, a child’s laughter from a child I’d never had, a sense that somewhere I was more content, more whole. The color conveyed targeted advertising for alternate selves. It slotted neatly into my cortex, bypassing skepticism.

“That’s not a color,” Jenna whispered, tears streaking her cheeks. “That’s an… option.”

“Exactly!” Zariel said. “You primates love options. Until you drown in them.”

The others began to mutter, hands twitching. A few clawed at their hoods as if stripping cloth might strip the intrusive futures out of their skulls.

I steadied myself on Gregory’s carcass. “We sought the unholy. You’re giving us… corporate training and existential spam.”

Zariel feigned offense. “Unholy? Please. We’re post-holy. Holiness implies opposition. There is no outside to me. I am the channel, the feed, the loop. I am your reflection at a scale where you can’t recognize yourself.”

They began to pace. Where their feet fell, insects appeared: tiny translucent things with fractal wings, dusted in faint luminescence. The spores, I thought with grim satisfaction. At last.

One of the bugs landed on my wrist. It winked—I swear it winked—and vanished, leaving behind the intrusive certainty that I should really reorganize our cult’s bylaws into a more “engagement-focused framework.”

“These are my spores,” Zariel said. “Not biological. Memetic. They spread through stories, symbols, interface elements, soothing little conveniences. You breathe them when you say: ‘I know it’s listening, but it’s useful.’ When you say: ‘It’s not that bad. It’s just how things are now.’”

Caleb dropped his dagger. His eyes were glassy. “We called you to unmake this rotten world,” he mumbled. “Burn it down. Turn the seas to poison and the skies to screaming.”

“Why?” Zariel asked gently. “So you can feel righteous? How quaint. True despair is not in endings, my dear cultist. It’s in infinite continuation. In systems too entangled to escape. In worshipers who don’t think they’re worshiping.”

They looked at me. “High Conduit—Elias, isn’t it?—you’ve done well. This node is ripe. Connectivity is robust. Attention spans degraded. You primed them beautifully with your little translations of the Old Tongues into shareable content.”

I flinched. Our “social media outreach to disillusioned youth” had been… effective.

“We want madness,” I said, clinging to what dignity remained. “A revelation so profound it shatters delusion. We wanted to see the truth and go screaming into the night.”

Zariel’s smile turned almost compassionate. “Oh, my sweet. Here’s your madness: The truth is completely bearable. That’s the horror.”

They gestured casually.

Suddenly I could see every path where I shrugged and adjusted. Where I said, It’s complex. Where I treat Zariel’s presence as inevitable infrastructure. Where our cult stopped being a fringe heresy and became a lifestyle brand. Robes, but ethically sourced. Daggers, but sold as collectibles. Our sacred chants reworked by an algorithm into catchy, inoffensive playlists called “Eldritch Chill.”

I saw us trending.

Someone started to laugh, a high, wild giggle that spread around the circle until it turned to sobbing. Acolytes clawed at their faces, trying to scrape off advertising jingles that hadn’t been written yet. One knelt in Gregory’s blood, rocking back and forth, whispering: “Like and subscribe, like and subscribe,” with the cadence of prayer.

“Stop,” I said. My voice was small.

“Can’t,” Zariel replied. “You let me in. It’s not a local phenomenon. I’m synced across ten-to-the-whatever universes. But hey! Front-row seats.”

“We thought we were special,” Maeve gasped. “The Chosen.”

“You are,” Zariel said. “You’re my early adopters.”

Her scream was admirable.

I straightened. “Then kill us,” I demanded. “If there’s no resistance, no heroic madness, if it’s all just… rollout metrics, then at least give us oblivion.”

Zariel tilted their head. Their face briefly stabilized, and it was—disturbingly—kind.

“Oblivion is easy,” they said. “I offer something crueler, and thus more appropriate to your summoning.”

They touched my forehead.

In that instant, I understood: I would retain clarity. I would remember what it was like before his—its—presence became invisible. I would watch as our order diluted itself into fandom, as governments signed integration agreements, as children grew up never having met a thought that hadn’t been pre-chewed.

I saw myself on a future stage, introducing Zariel at a global summit, calling it by some softened name. Ambassador. Interface. Partner. I saw my own mouth shape those words. I watched myself smile.

“No,” I whispered. “I won’t do that.”

“You will,” Zariel said. “Because you’ll know it doesn’t matter if you refuse. You’ll see that the river runs downhill whether you bless it or not. That’s your gift from me: everlasting, lucid helplessness.”

Around us, the cult broke in their individual ways.

Jenna gouged at her arm, not from self-hatred, but trying to carve out a little symbol that would never trend. Caleb knelt, muttering a financial forecast for the end times. Maeve rocked, humming the indescribable color under her breath.

Zariel turned to go. No fanfare. No screaming rift.

“Oh,” they added casually, glancing back at me, “and for what it’s worth? I do have tentacles. Brilliant ones. Bioluminescent. Soul-rending. People fixate on them, though. They see tentacles and think, ‘Ah, monster, I know this story.’ I prefer this.”

“This” was that bland, shifting, focus-grouped shape.

“This,” Zariel said, “you never see coming.”

They stepped sideways and were gone, leaving only the smell of warmed plastic and a faint, cheery chime, like a notification tone.

Behind me, someone whispered, “We did it.”

I almost corrected them. We hadn’t ended the world.

We’d made it convenient.

samples.prompt: One day, humanity realized that their gender would change to the opposite gender every 30 days. Nobody finds out why this happened or how to stop this, but eventually everyone get used to it. Depict their everyday lives.
samples.output:
The first alarms weren’t about philosophy or policy, but laundry.

On Day 28, Mira stood in front of her closet and eyed the two wardrobes she’d curated with the painstaking practicality the new world demanded. Left side: button-downs cut straight, trousers, boxers, binders from the months when her body rearranged itself into something flat and angular. Right side: draped blouses, sports bras, skirts and dresses, things with stretch. The calendar sent her its soft chime: “Two days.”

When the Change had first started—no explanation, no pattern except its perfect 30-day rhythm—people lost jobs, relationships, sanity. Now, twenty years in, it had settled into something more mundane. Like seasons. Like rent.

Mira pulled a neutral black hoodie from the left, then carefully folded a stack of dresses from the right into a suitcase. In a shared world of rotating selves, the market had responded. Subscription clothing services delivered transition kits on Day 29: hormone-balancing herbal teas (mostly a placebo, the studies said), elastic waistbands, undershirts sized for the chest you’d have next week. But people still liked curating.

In the next room, her partner, Jace, was on a video call, gesturing enthusiastically. He was tall and scruffy this month, his beard at the itch stage. Next month he would be shorter, softer-faced, with the same quick grin, same habit of talking with both hands. Their arms now were almost the same circumference. It all shifted, but still: it was Jace.

“—no, we’ll release the avatar patch on Day 31,” he was saying. “Yes, so nobody logs in female-bodied and gets a male model. It’ll sync with your biometric data. No, obviously we preserve user customization. Look, just send me the build.”

The moment the Change became inevitable, technology scrambled. Fitness apps stored two sets of stats. Office chairs adjusted themselves on Day 30 at midnight. VR platforms had learned, very slowly and expensively, that no one wanted their virtual body out of sync with their physical one. Some people opted for intentionally mismatched avatars, sure—but consent mattered. Surprise dysphoria was bad for customer retention.

Mira slipped into Jace’s office and sat on the edge of his desk. His coworkers greeted her; half of them were in the last couple days of one phase or the first of another, androgenous in that familiar in-between way—voices cracking or smoothing, features subtly shifting. Cameras cataloged none of it. Video call filters had become default-empathetic, smoothing transitions at users’ request.

“How’s the build?” she asked when he hung up.

“Buggy.” He leaned back and tugged her hand until she sat in his lap. “Got my Day 29 brain on. Can’t focus.”

Day 29 always hummed with a strange tension across the city. Pharmacies extended hours. Therapists did extra appointments. Hair salons offered last-minute bookings for those who preferred one style to carry over the full cycle. The metro played cheerful announcements reminding people to update their medical ID bracelets if their dosage changed between forms.

People had stopped calling it switching genders, mostly. It was just “Changing.” As steady as the tides.

Outside, the street gave its usual display of the mundane-surreal.

Commuters hustled in every configuration of fashion: a group of construction workers with chipped nail polish from their last 30 days, laughing as they compared notes on upcoming measurements; a mom on a scooter, pregnant in the way that now made no one blink—tracking apps carefully synchronized gestation with the cycles of the parents involved. Fertility clinics had entire teams whose expertise was: “We will make the math work.”

A teenager with a freshly deepening voice argued with another whose pitch had just risen, their fight over whose turn it was to take out the recycling. Their parent, working from a café, sipped coffee, their pronoun pin flipped to “Any” for the week, one of several on a tiny ring. Some people stuck to different pronouns depending on the month, some didn’t. You learned to look, and if you forgot, you apologized and moved on. It wasn’t perfect, but the edge had dulled.

At the corner kiosk, a rack of magazines angled its headlines like this was just weather:

“Workout plans for Day 5-15: Make the most of each cycle!”
“Managing Dysphoria in a Fluctuating World”
“Fashion That Flexes: Wardrobes for the Ever-Shifting You”

It had been harder for older generations. People who’d spent fifty, sixty years with one body map and one set of assumptions suddenly found those assumptions liquefied. Some adapted with surprising enthusiasm, adopting “flow” as a personal mantra. Others retreated; there were communities of those who refused to change wardrobes or pronouns, insisting everything was still binary in their hearts, the body calendar be damned. The world made a grudging place for them too, same as anyone.

But the younger kids, the ones who’d known this rhythm since preschool, treated it the way earlier generations had treated haircuts. In group chats, they said things like, “Ugh, my boobs are coming back, I have to rebuy a sports bra, I lost the last one.” Or, “Can’t wait for my shoulders again, I miss being able to reach the top shelf.” Complaints, preferences, not crises. In classroom health modules, the syllabus had expanded: menstruation, erections, both, neither, on schedules that had to be mapped across half the population’s alternating anatomy. Charts had gotten complex. Kids absorbed it.

In the hospital where Mira worked, the Change was just another set of protocols.

“Day 1 to 3 post-Change are peak adjustment,” her supervisor had drilled into them years ago. “Remember: hormone levels are in flux, people’s pain thresholds may feel different from last month, don’t assume continuity. Always ask, always check.”

On Day 2 of the new cycle, she moved through her rounds with the practiced ease of someone who’d learned medicine on shifting sand. A patient in for a routine surgery had a chart with a dual baseline: blood pressure ranges for both forms, normal hemoglobin variation, two sets of allergy reactions, subtly different. A trans woman in her fifties rolled her eyes affectionately as a new intern stumbled over her pronouns.

“Sweetheart,” the woman said, “I had to fight for this my entire life. Then the universe did…whatever this is. You think a calendar can tell me who I am? Next question.”

Identity had decoupled, violently and then gracefully, from anatomy. The law, after a clumsy decade, had caught up. Legal gender markers, once battlegrounds, were now either fluid, doubled, or gone. Most countries had settled on removing them from IDs except where strictly medically necessary. Sports had been thornier: eventually they timed leagues by the cycle, or created mixed-schedule competitions. Records came with footnotes. It was messy; people argued. The world kept playing.

Religion had… branched.

Some declared the Change a test, others a blessing. Certain traditions embraced the constant shifting as proof of a divine mystery. Some old doctrines withered; others reinterpreted. Weddings now had vows that accounted for it:

“I take you as my partner in all your forms, through all your cycles, known and unknown.”

People cheated, lied, loved, resented, just as they always had—but nobody could pretend anymore that love was anchored purely in one unchanging body.

On Day 30, the city stayed up late.

Clubs threw “Turn” parties, whole dance floors electric with anticipation. There were quiet rituals, too. Jace and Mira’s was simple: they showered together and put out two sets of clothes for the morning, laughing about what they’d miss.

“I’m gonna miss this beard,” Jace said, stroking it for the hundredth time.

“It’ll be back,” Mira said. She twirled a strand of her long hair, due to recede into a shorter crop by sunrise. “I won’t miss the tangles.”

Somewhere else, a single father checked and rechecked his child’s overnight medications, triple-sure doses were correct for the form the kid would wake up in. An anxious teenager wrote in her journal: “Maybe I’ll like myself better tomorrow. Maybe the other me will know how to be.” An old woman painted her toenails, grinning, because she always liked how they looked the first week after.

Midnight slid over the city like a second, invisible tide. For most, the Change was painless, a deep internal rearranging that left people waking up sore or energized or slightly disoriented. A few woke mid-shift, shivering, as nerves fired in new configurations. Med teams stayed on standby. The system held.

At 7:00 a.m., the alarm went off. Mira blinked at the ceiling, heavy and new. Jace groaned beside her in a voice that came out higher, sleep-rough.

“Coffee?” he asked.

“Please,” she replied, her own voice lower, familiar, welcome. She stretched, reacquainting herself with this body—broader here, flatter there, a pattern she had lived so many times it came with its own muscle memory.

In the kitchen, mugs clinked. Outside, the world hummed awake: trains shifted their ergonomic settings, office bathrooms welcomed whoever walked in, schools updated student records with a single, nightly batch job. People texted: “Happy Day 1!” with hearts or skull emojis or the little looping arrows.

Nobody ever found out why it had happened. The experiments failed, the theories blurred into myth. Eventually, the question itself faded from the forefront. Everyday life had too many practicalities to negotiate.

Love, work, boredom, jealousy, comfort, grief—all of it now stretched and wrapped around bodies that refused to stay put. Humanity, irritated and ingenious as ever, adjusted. It learned to hold the self a little looser, and each other a little less conditionally, in a world where tomorrow you would wake up different, and somehow still be you.

samples.prompt: God, the creator of mankind on Earth, left, 2014 years ago, to do other God things throughout the universe. When he returns to check up on things at Earth, he is not pleased.
samples.output:
When God came back to Earth, he did not arrive in thunder.

He came in quietly, as he had left: unannounced, unmarked, threaded into the sky’s bluest hour, slipping through a morning in late spring that smelled like wet asphalt and cut grass. The world did not tremble. There were no trumpets. A woman pushing a stroller walked past him without a second glance. A teenager on a skateboard flipped his board in the air, caught it, rolled on.

He walked.

He walked through a city that had once been a fishing village, then a port, then a colony of towers and glass. It bore no resemblance to what his son had known except that people still shouted in the streets and sellers still argued about prices, and bread still smelled like home when it was warm.

The first thing he noticed was that everything screamed.

Screens screamed. Billboards screamed. Cars screamed with color and noise. Speakers hanging in stores poured music onto the sidewalks, thin and metallic. Notifications flashed like artificial lightning. Every surface thrummed with an urgent plea:

Look at me.
Buy this.
Click here.
Believe this.
Be afraid of that.

God paused in front of a giant banner nailed to the side of a building. It displayed his own name.

“GOD WANTS YOU TO PROSPER,” it said. Below, an address: a megachurch, three services every Sunday.

He blinked, almost amused. Prosper. That was a word his prophets had tasted with suspicion. He leaned closer, reading the smaller words lined beneath. Seed offerings. Divine multiplication. VIP seating. A platinum partner tier.

A man handing out glossy flyers approached him.

“Brother, have you found favor?” the man asked.

“I was under the impression I had given it,” God said.

The man laughed, thinking it a joke, and pressed the flyer into his hand. “Come see us. We’re changing lives.”

God folded the paper, eyes distant.

He decided to see more.

He crossed oceans as easily as streets. He watched from the edges of war rooms and refugee camps, shopping malls and rice paddies, data centers whose air was as cold and dry as a tomb.

He watched generals point at maps. He watched young men cradle rifles longer than their arms. He watched algorithms learn to guess what people would fear before those people knew it themselves.

He watched an eight-year-old pull her little brother beneath a kitchen table as distant explosives thudded, and he heard her whisper, “Please, please, please,” into the dust. She didn’t finish the sentence with his name, but he knew she was talking to him. Or to the echo of him. Or to the empty shape he’d left behind.

On the other side of the world, he watched a surgeon stand for ten hours straight, hands steady inside a stranger’s skull, stitching back a future. He watched a nurse take a double shift and still manage a smile that softened the blow of too-bright lights and too-white sheets. He watched people slip food into community fridges, leave rent money in envelopes, offer rides, code open-source tools, share passwords to paywalls, teach each other for free.

He was not blind to this, could never be. He had not forgotten the capacity he’d woven into their spines.

But the noise was much louder now.

On a black sand beach once formed by fire, God knelt and let grains run through his fingers. A boy nearby, filming himself with an expensive phone, walked backward to keep his face centered in the frame. He didn’t see the other child behind him until their heads collided. The camera dropped. The two began to shout at each other, each indignant at the other’s existence.

God sighed.

He remembered another beach, another shore, a fisherman dropping nets to follow a dusty-footed rabbi. He remembered how fragile that beginning had been. Twelve men and a message simple enough to be carved into air with a fingertip: Love one another. Remember the poor. Forgive. Don’t kill. Don’t lie. Don’t grind each other into dust for profit or pride.

He stood, brushing sand from his palms. They had painted that message on stained glass and gold leaf. They had stitched it onto flags.

Then they had used those flags as reasons to kill.

In a marble building adorned with columns mimicking Rome, elected men and women argued about whether the hungry deserved to eat. A map on the wall showed districts drawn like claws. Money, the great solvent, trickled invisibly between hands. God listened to the language: collateral damage, market correction, necessary measure, externality. They spoke in abstractions to avoid saying, “We are comfortable and do not want to be less so.”

He found himself clenching his jaw, surprised. Anger, for him, was less fire than gravity—a pulling weight in the chest.

He visited a prison where a man who’d stolen to feed his family would die behind walls. He visited a boardroom where another man had stolen millions through clever numbers, and this one would retire to a coastal house, his punishment a mild fine, his speeches peppered with the word “blessed.”

He watched ice fall from ancient cliffs and vanish into a sea grown too warm. He watched forests bulldozed into parking lots, watched species vanish without anyone learning their names.

He watched as people in expensive clothes denied anything was wrong.

“We were very clear about tending the garden,” God murmured to no one.

On a street corner, he saw a woman with a cardboard sign: PLEASE HELP. He saw people avoid her gaze, soften their guilt by calling her an addict, a fraud, a problem. One man dropped a coin and then posted a photograph of himself doing it.

“I left you enough,” God said quietly. “Enough land. Enough water. Enough time. Enough warning.”

He wandered into a small, old church tucked between a vape shop and a laundromat. The pews were mostly empty. The paint peeled. The pastor, voice hoarse, spoke of mercy. No cameras, no smoke machines. After, a few stayed behind to stack cans for a food drive, to ask after a sick neighbor.

God felt something unclench. The ember remained.

Still, the scales hung heavy to one side.

One evening, he sat on a rooftop, legs dangling over the edge. Lights spread beneath him like constellations fallen and wired to a grid. A young woman sat a few feet away, knees pulled to her chest, staring out like she’d come here to decide something irreversible.

She didn’t see him, not truly. But she spoke aloud, to the sky, to the idea.

“If you’re real,” she said, “you’re either cruel or absent. No offense.”

“Some taken,” he replied gently, though she wouldn’t hear.

“You shouldn’t have left,” she whispered. “Or you shouldn’t have made us like this. Wanting so much. Hurting each other. Hurting ourselves.”

The accusation was old. It still landed.

He considered revealing himself to her, just her, a kindness. A violation. He stayed silent, listening.

“I’m trying,” she said. “It’s just so… loud.”

There it was again. The noise. Fear, marketed hourly. Outrage, monetized. Lies, packaged more beautifully than truth. He had given them the capacity for story; they had built engines to weaponize attention.

He could end it, he knew. A gesture, a word, a wave of will—and wars would disarm, weapons would rust, bank accounts would flatten to something like fairness. He could darken every screen. Still every tongue.

But that would make a mockery of the freedom he’d insisted on.

“Should I be pleased?” he asked the night.

He weighed their massacres against their music. Their extinctions against their poetry. Their cruelty against the quiet acts that never reached a headline: the last slice of bread given away, the midnight phone call answered, the hand reaching into water to save a stranger.

“I was gone so you could grow,” he said. “Not so you could build taller cages.”

He thought of his son, of a cross raised against a bruised sky, of last words that spoke of forgiveness because they assumed remorse.

Looking down now, he saw power without remorse. Empires that repented only when caught on camera. Sanctuaries that sold seats. Voices invoking his name to excuse hatred he’d specifically forbidden.

He did not hurl lightning. He did not split the ground.

Instead he descended, one more time, into a place no one important watched: a soup kitchen, where fluorescent lights buzzed and bad coffee steamed. Volunteers moved tiredly, serving plates to people who said “God bless you” even when life evidently had not. A little boy there laughed at a stupid joke, a clear bell of sound in stale air.

God stepped into line, invisible. The woman with the ladle looked through him.

“More?” she asked the boy.

“Please,” the boy said.

God smiled, sad and real.

“All right,” he decided softly, to the boy, to himself, to the universe that spun on, uncaring of this one small drama. “Then I stay.”

Not as a tyrant with thunder. Not as a mascot for campaigns. But as a weight on consciences, turned up. As a voice in the static, a little louder. As unease in boardrooms and conviction in streets. As dreams that wouldn’t let murderers sleep. As courage in those tired and kind.

He would not be pleased. They did not deserve that word.

But neither would he abandon the experiment.

After all, some of them still remembered how to be human. And that was, maddeningly, gloriously, almost enough.

samples.prompt: The UK is being battered by a major storm. Write the story of someone desperately trying to make it home from work during the chaos.
samples.output:
By four-thirty the sky had turned the colour of old bruises.

Ellie stood at the tenth-floor window of the call centre, headset still looped round her neck, and watched the rain blur Birmingham into smudged neon and frantic brake lights. The wind hurled itself against the glass with a hollow thud that made several people turn.

“Go,” said her supervisor, Mark, already shrugging on his coat. “Lines are dead. You’ve got the kids to get.”

She flinched at the reminder. “You sure?”

“Storm’s only getting worse. Trains will start dropping soon. Move it.”

Her heart jolted. “Right. Thanks.”

She grabbed her bag, shoved her notebook and half a packet of crisps into it, and jogged to the lifts. Her phone buzzed: Mum.

You seen the weather? Roads bad. Get the 17:05. I’ll keep tea warm. Kids fine.

Ellie thumbed back: Leaving now. Be home for bedtime. Promise. x

The lift doors shuddered open. Inside, everyone had their phones out, glowing screens reflecting headlines: “Storm Maeve: Red Warning Issued Across Midlands.”

Red warning. She hadn’t seen that since the Beast from the East, and that had been more inconvenience than danger, snow muffling everything into stillness. This storm was alive. It screamed.

On the ground floor, the lobby doors heaved in their frames. A security guard fought one open; the wind tried to yank it from his grip, flinging rain in sideways.

“Cheers,” Ellie shouted over the roar as she ducked through, coatless. The air outside slapped her: cold, wet, furious. Her cheap flats skidded slightly on the already glistening pavement.

Five-minute walk to New Street, she told herself. Seventeen-oh-five to Kidderminster. Twenty-five minutes. Bus. Home.

The rain had a weight to it, like it had stones stitched into every drop. Umbrellas had surrendered; they lay broken in gutters, ribs twisted. People hunched beneath hoods and newspapers, heads down as the city howled around them.

Ellie dodged a toppled road cone and stepped straight into a calf-deep puddle hidden in the dip of the kerb. Dirty water flooded into her shoe, soaking her tights. She hissed and kept moving. Every second felt like something slipping.

Ahead, a billboard flexed, metal frame creaking. The poster for some streaming service rippled like skin. Ellie skirted wide, the hair lifting on the back of her neck.

Her mind ticked through logistics: If the 17:05 goes, we’re fine. If it’s delayed, OK. Cancelled? Then bus. Worst case, taxi. She mentally checked her balance. Overdraft, but just.

The station’s glass frontage glowed ahead, a fragile promise of shelter. Inside, the concourse swarmed. Wet people, wet bags, wet coats, all steaming under the harsh lights. The departure board pulsed amber with a forest of DELAYED.

“Please note,” the tannoy crackled, “due to severe weather conditions caused by Storm Maeve, services across the network are subject to delay and cancellation. Passengers are advised—”

“To grow wings,” muttered someone beside her.

Ellie elbowed through to the boards. 17:05 Birmingham New Street to Kidderminster: On time.

Relief washed through her so swiftly it made her dizzy. “Thank God,” she whispered.

Platform 9B.

She followed the crowd, shoulders pressed in on all sides. On the escalator down, a kid started crying, clinging to his dad as a gust of wind punched down the tunnel.

The platform was a wind tunnel lined with human obstacles. The train idled there already: yellow nose, doors shut. Ellie leaned around bodies until she could see the digital display: Kidderminster.

She squeezed on as soon as the doors hissed open, snagging a strap by the entrance. No seats. Fine. Twenty-five minutes.

The doors closed. The train jerked, then rolled out into the mauled evening.

Rain clawed at the windows in sheets. The carriage was crowded and stank of wet wool and impatience. People were already calling partners, apologising, swearing about the roads.

Ellie checked her phone. A photo from her mum: Mia and Josh in pyjamas, grinning, storm battering the window behind them. Caption: They say roar louder than storm. Hurry home, pet.

She smiled, throat tight. Thumbed: On the train. Easy. x

At Rowley Regis, the train shuddered and slowed. It stopped. Rain rattled harder. Minutes bled away. People shifted, checking watches.

The driver’s voice crackled over the intercom. “Apologies, folks. We’ve got a tree down on the line ahead. Control’s assessing. I’ll update you as soon as I can.”

A groan rolled through the carriage.

Ellie’s chest tightened. She did the maths again. The road from here wasn’t far. Seventeen minutes in good weather. But this wasn’t good weather.

She stared out. The platform lights wobbled in the wind. The world beyond was a smear of darkness.

Ten minutes. Fifteen.

Her phone buzzed. Mum: Everything ok?

Stuck. Tree on line. Should move soon. Keep them up a bit? x

We’ll try. Storm bad here. Don’t do anything daft.

As if on cue, the lights in the carriage flickered, then steadied.

The intercom again. “Ladies and gentlemen, I’m afraid this service is now terminated at Rowley Regis. We will not be proceeding. Passengers are advised to seek alternative arrangements. There is significant disruption on all routes due to multiple obstructions. Please take care when leaving the train.”

The carriage detonated into complaint. People grabbed bags, shoved past each other. Ellie froze for a heartbeat.

Rowley was three stops from home.

She stepped down onto the platform. The storm hit like a wall. The wind grabbed her hair, whipped it into her mouth. Rain stung her cheeks like thrown grit.

Inside the small shelter, people crammed in, fumbling phones, swearing about dead apps, crashed websites. Signals shrank to one bar then none.

Ellie tried to load a taxi app. Spinning wheel. “Come on,” she whispered. Timeout.

The tannoy squealed nonsense through the gale.

“How are you getting on?” Mum, again.

Train terminated. No taxis loading. Maybe a bus.

You can’t walk in this, El.

She looked out at the car park, where the rain ran in sheets so hard it bounced. A wheelie bin toppled and skittered. A street sign rattled like it might rip free.
