He laughed, then stopped when it hurt.

Solace shifted, the light off her costume flickering. “You know they chant your name out there?”

“I’m familiar.”

“I’ve flown a collapsing bridge back onto its pillars,” she said. “Articles called me ‘mystery woman aids star’s hometown.’ You show up, pull three people from a bus, and the headline is ‘Noah Vale on Scene of Chaos.’”

“It’s not my fault,” Noah said, reflexively.

“I didn’t say it was. I’m just letting you know—which I think you already know—you’re screwing up the algorithm.”

He watched the stagehands coil cables. “People think Night Audit is a brand extension, a role I play.”

“Isn’t he?” Solace asked, studying him.

“I don’t get paid for him,” Noah said.

“That’s not what I asked.”

Noah didn’t answer.

Because when he was nine, he’d memorized lines to make his parents stop arguing. When he was fifteen, he’d cried on cue to make casting directors like him. When he was twenty-three, he’d become Noah Vale, whose name sounded like a sigh and whose jawline was focus-grouped.

And then the lab flood, the current, the gift. The first time he slipped through a locked door to pull a stranger from smoke, his body reacted like he’d hit his mark perfectly. Applause in his veins.

He’d never learned who he was when he wasn’t performing. Night Audit was supposed to be the answer. Only now the world had merged the roles. His secret identity was under contract.

“I tried,” he said to Solace softly, “to keep it separate. Mask, late nights, no press. But every clip, every blurry photo—they compare it to my work. ‘Method acting.’ ‘Immersive research.’ The studio loves it. They’re storyboarding a spinoff where my character moonlights as a vigilante—”

“That sounds derivative,” Solace muttered.

“I pitched something smaller. Anonymous volunteer. Guy in the background. They said my brand doesn’t do background.”

Solace watched him, something like pity in her eyes. “You could disappear,” she said. “Heroes do it all the time. Fake your death. Space, dimension portal, Kansas.”

“Can’t,” Noah said. “I have a season three pickup.”

She snorted. “You know, some of us chose masks because people wouldn’t listen to us otherwise. They only trust the emblem. You’ve got the opposite problem. They’ll follow your face into traffic.”

“I know.” He rubbed his eyes. “Sometimes I think if I went on a talk show and confessed—‘I’m Night Audit, I’ve been pulling people out of burning buildings between scenes’—they’d clap and ask if it was hard to do my own stunts.”

“Probably,” Solace said. “You’re very convincing.”

Later that night, a storm ripped over the east levee. Sirens, floodlights, screaming. Noah changed in the back of his town car while his driver pretended not to see. He phased through concrete, tasted live wires in the rain, carried kids and dogs and one terrified mayor up from the rising water.

When the sun came up, the trending topics were:

1. #NoahValeHeroic – candid shots of him, soaked, soot-streaked, mask askew, interpreted as guerilla marketing.
2. “Vale of Shadows” Season Three teaser: “This time, the hero steps off the set.”
3. Think pieces about “the blurring of fiction and reality in the age of prestige television.”

The official city emergency account posted: “Thank you to all first responders and volunteers!”

Reply with the most engagement: a fan edit of Noah in character, intercut with footage of Night Audit hauling sandbags, set to emotional pop.

Miri called. “We’re up fourteen points with Gen Z.”

“I dislocated both shoulders,” Noah said, lying on his hotel floor, ice packs balanced precariously.

“All in on this grounded hero narrative,” she chirped. “Sponsors want to partner with your ‘real-life activism.’ We can spin this into a foundation. Disaster relief, mental health, the whole thing. Noah Vale Cares.”

“What if,” he asked carefully, “Noah Vale took a break? Less exposure. Let Night—let someone else handle the crisis.”

Silence. Paper rustling. The sound of money being counted.

“We can’t let up now,” she said. “You’re not just an actor anymore. You’re a symbol. People need you.”

“They need help,” he said. “They don’t need me.”

“They think they do,” Miri replied. “That’s how belief works.”

She hung up before he could answer.

Three weeks later, a villain calling himself Auteur dosed the financial district with a gas that made everyone speak their deepest truths in florid monologues. Chaos, obviously. Noah had a mask with filters, but the stuff seeped through the seams.

On a rooftop, wrestling with Auteur over a device that looked disturbingly like an award statue, Noah inhaled.

Auteur grinned. “Action.”

Words ripped out of Noah, raw and unstoppable.

“I don’t know who I am if no one is watching,” he shouted. “I keep saving people hoping one day they’ll see me when I’m not on a billboard.”

The fight stopped. Auteur blinked. The cameras he’d set up drank it in.

“Oh,” Auteur said softly. “That’s good.”

Later, of course, edited clips played on every screen: Noah Vale in a mask, confessing emptiness. Talk shows debated his “performance art.” Essays heralded him as a genius satirist of celebrity culture. One critic called it “the bravest scripted moment of his career.”

Night Audit trended as a character.

Noah shut off his TV. The city hummed outside, alive and oblivious.

He went to the window, set his mask down on the sill.

The thing nobody told you about being a symbol is that you dissolve.

On some nights now, he doesn’t put the mask on. He walks among them as Noah Vale, ball cap low, hoodie up, helping quietly when accidents happen. People either scream his name or assume he’s doing immersive prep. They rarely say thank you. They say: “This is going to be amazing press.”

On other nights, he goes all in as Night Audit, no wisecracks, no glimpses of the famous jawline, slipping in and out like a draft. Those are the nights that feel most like breathing.

Both selves are famous, but only one is real. And it’s not the one on the cereal box.

Still, when the alarms wail, when bridges shake or sirens merge into a single desperate note, they look up, scanning the sky.

They don’t chant “Night Audit.”

They chant “Noah.”

And he goes.

samples.prompt: Everyone who dies is reincarnated as soon as history has completely forgotten about them. A secret centuries-old group has been keeping an list of hundreds of thousands of mass murderers, evil dictators, etc. to keep them from coming back. One day, someone loses the list.
samples.output:
The ledger vanished on a Tuesday.

There was no storm, no break-in, no Hollywood crack of thunder to make sense of it. One moment the Archive was as it had been for nearly five centuries—breathing in silence, its stone lungs full of dust and cold fluorescent light—and the next, the shelf was empty where it mattered.

Caleb noticed at 08:14, because noticing was his job. He came in with coffee and the disinterested trudging gait of a man whose faith had eroded into habit years before, turned the triple keys, submitted to the retinal scan, keyed the duress code he’d never had to use.

The room greeted him.

Row upon row of black ring binders, labeled in white ink. Some names written in the racing hand of frightened monks, some in the neat copperplate of Victorians, others in fading typewriter font, the most recent in stark laser print. He walked their aisles like a parishioner, sipping bitter coffee, letting the hum of the dehumidifiers settle into his bones.

He reached the end of row forty-two.

The gap struck him the way an optical illusion snaps into focus: there, and then impossible not to see. A span of shelf where the dust made a neat rectangle, the faint ghost of weight impressed into the metal. The binder that should have been there was gone.

He checked the adjoining shelves, because it had to be misfiled, because things did not simply vanish. Not from here. Not from them.

He checked the security feed: empty corridor, closed door, the flat stare of the camera. No one.

His throat tightened. He opened the drawer beneath the shelf, the one no one but the Keeper was supposed to touch. Inside, embossed into a silver plaque: MASTER INDEX.

He slid it out. Inside, a carefully handwritten list, updated through centuries.

He ran his finger down the page to where the opening on the shelf should correspond.

“Conflated ledger,” it read. “High Atrocity Tier. 267,104 Names.”

He read it again.

It was the list.

The list.

The binder that was no longer on the shelf had contained, in tight black type, line after line of the worst humanity had managed to produce: genocidaires, torturers, warlords, architects of famines, quiet bureaucrats of gas chambers. Names culled from every corner of recorded history and its footnotes, taken from diaries, court records, encrypted dispatches, hacked drives, oral histories. Names saved, repeated, whispered, never allowed to fall fully into silence.

Everyone who dies is reincarnated as soon as history has completely forgotten about them.

This was the law. Not divine, not negotiable, simply observed and confirmed more times than any of them could count. First by frightened peasants who seemed to recognize too easily the gleam in a neighbor’s eye. Then by patient scholars comparing fastidious birth records with the dates memorials were toppled and erased. Then by their predecessors, who discovered, horrified, that when a man’s name was scrubbed from the last archive, a child was born somewhere that carried his pattern like a stain.

There were exceptions, complexities, arguments about identity and probability and whether the universe could make mistakes. But the rule held enough that the Order of Oblivion had been formed in 1531 in a monastery already growing damp with its own secrets. They had taken as their charge the maintenance of the world’s memory of monsters.

Don’t let them be forgotten, and they cannot return.

They learned soon that forgetting wasn’t simple. People wanted to forget. Governments wanted to forget their founding massacres; families wanted to forget their cruel patriarchs. Time did the steady erasure that tyrants only dreamed of.

So the Order wrote names down. They carved some into stone, etched some into copper. As the centuries turned, they migrated to paper, microfilm, solid-state drives. Always redundancies, always encryption, and then above all of it, the ledger: the master list.

It had never been outside their custody. It had outlived empires, survived fires, wars, inquisitions. Men had died for it. A woman in Warsaw had swallowed a sheet of it, name by name, and gone smiling to her hanging rather than let it be taken.

Now it was gone between Caleb’s commute and his first sip of coffee.

He hit the panic button, and somewhere deep in the building, an old bell rang in a frequency that made bones feel hollow.

The Keeper arrived within minutes, gray hair loose, cardigan on inside out. Eliza had been Keeper for thirty-six years, and there was nothing in her manner that suggested she believed in melodrama. She looked at the gap. She looked at the security monitor. She looked at Caleb.

“Walk me through.”

He did, step by step. She asked no comforting questions, only precise ones.

“Any anomalies yesterday?”

“No, ma’am.”

“In the system?”

“Nothing flagged. I’ll pull logs.”

“You already know the logs will be clean.”

He did. That was the horror.

By noon the inner council had assembled in the conference den that pretended not to exist. Oak paneled walls, old portraits, the air thick with the smell of paper and a ghost of incense.

“We always considered this scenario,” said Moritz, the archivist from Vienna, fingers pressed together as if in prayer. “We have protocols.”

“We considered partial breach,” Eliza said. “Not the entire ledger. Not that volume.”

“It’s impossible,” someone else muttered.

“Apparently not,” said Caleb, before he could stop himself.

Faces turned in his direction, some irritated, some grateful he’d voiced it. He felt very small and very young.

“We have backups,” Moritz persisted, reaching for reassurance. “Encrypted across multiple nodes.”

“Shadow copies,” Eliza said. “Fragments. We designed them specifically so that no one piece could resurrect the whole. It will take weeks to reconstruct.”

“We don’t have weeks,” said a woman at the end of the table who had not spoken yet. Noor. Fieldwork, intelligence, the Order’s sharp edge. “Let us assume worst case. The ledger is gone beyond recall—or in hostile hands. I want us to say it aloud. What happens?”

Silence folded down over them.

Caleb, whose job normally never extended past controlled climate and metadata, answered, because he had been keeping the graphs. “We’re already at thresholds,” he said. “LBEs are spiking.”

LBEs: Low-Band Echoes. The Order’s euphemism for the early signs. Kids with a too-familiar charisma and contempt for consequence. Teenagers devising efficient cruelties no one had taught them.

They had learned to recognize patterns: the reincarnated did not come back as carbon copies, but as chords. The same notes of hunger or certainty, recomposed in new flesh. You could see them in statistics before you saw them in headlines.

“We’ve kept them below emergence by keeping names alive,” Caleb said. “If we lose that ledger, we’re losing… two hundred and sixty-seven thousand, one hundred and four of the worst.”

“And not just the famous ones,” Noor said quietly. “The obscure policemen who enjoyed their work too much. The surgeons. The ones who never got trials. We’re the only ones who ever said their names out loud.”

“The universe doesn’t care if their evil was famous,” Moritz said. “Only if they are remembered.”

“So what happens without the ledger?” Noor asked.

Eliza ran a hand over her face. “What has always happened,” she said. “They return. Not all at once; it doesn’t work like a dam breaking. But the waiting room empties faster. Old patterns find new vessels. The century gets darker.”

Caleb swallowed. “And if someone took it intentionally?”

“Then someone knows the rule,” Eliza said. “And intends to burn the safeguards.”

The Order had enemies, of course. There were cults that worshipped atrocity as purity. Regimes that resented anyone keeping inconvenient archives. Conspiracy theorists who had begun, dangerously, to get too close to the truth of why some names never died.

But knowledge of the core law—the link between forgetting and return—was their most guarded secret. Closed oral transmission, encrypted in anecdotes and parables. The ledger never left the vault.

“Unless,” Caleb said slowly, “it wasn’t taken.”

All eyes again. He almost wished he could pull the words back, but it was too late.

“Explain,” Eliza said.

“What if the ledger did what the names do? Once we forgot part of our own history of keeping it. If no one alive remembers the moment it was first made whole. If one of us, somewhere along the line, misplaced some record, some story… how do we know the ledger itself isn’t eligible? If forgetting triggers return…”

“An object cannot reincarnate,” Moritz snapped.

“Neither can a list,” Caleb said. “But its absence can act like their absence. Maybe we crossed a threshold of forgetting about our own vigilance. Got complacent. Treated Tuesday like just another day. The system answered.”

Eliza did not dismiss him. That was worse.

“What matters now,” Noor cut in, “is containment. We cannot rely on metaphysics. We need operational steps.”

“Go,” Eliza said.

“We do three things,” Noor said. “One: reconstruct from shards. Two: identify who knew enough to target us. Three: flood the world with remembrance.”

Moritz blinked. “Flood—?”

“Make documentaries. Leak archives. Name names in podcasts, articles, posts. Not just the famous dictators; the minor monsters too. If the law is that they return when history has completely forgotten them, we weaponize history. We make remembering contagious.”

“That risks exposing us,” Moritz said.

“Us or them,” Noor said. “Pick.”

Eliza nodded slowly. “We seed memory,” she said. “We have always hoarded it. Now we disseminate. Open the valves. Carefully, but we do it.”

“And if the ledger is in hostile hands?” Caleb asked.

“Then someone thinks they can choose who comes back,” Noor said. “Resurrect their champions by erasing others. That’s our fourth problem.”

“There is a fifth,” Eliza said.

They waited.

“We must not let ourselves hate the children,” she said softly. “Because that is what they will be. If the returns accelerate. They will not arrive with medals or mustaches. They will be born wailing and small and possible. If we forget that, we become another ledger the universe will misplace.”

Caleb thought of a baby somewhere, born as the ledger disappeared. Tiny hand flexing, some old cruelty cooling in new eyes. He wondered if that child was already on someone’s list, or if that was the problem: no one, anywhere, would bother to remember them until it was too late.

“So,” Eliza said, and in her voice there was both centuries and Tuesday weariness. “We act. Noor, start your operation. Moritz, the reconstruction. Caleb, you’re with me. We’re going to walk the aisles and say the names we still have, out loud. Every one. Slowly. Clearly.”

“Will that be enough?” Caleb asked.

“It has to be for today,” she said. “And tomorrow we’ll have to remember even harder.”

As they filed out, the hum of the Archive deepened, like something waking. On the empty shelf, the rectangle of undisturbed dust waited, an outline around absence, a door where nothing yet stepped through.

samples.prompt: The most powerful civilization in the universe does not have CGI - and cower in fear when an unsuspecting scout finds a human satellite laden with pop culture hits.
samples.output:
When the satellite first appeared in their outer sentry nets, the Kethorian Hegemony mistook it for debris.

It was small—shockingly so. No radiation lances, no probed dimensions, no quantum encryption halo. Just a metal husk coasting on a decayed trajectory around a pale, unclaimed star the Kethorians cataloged as irrelevant. The ensign on duty flagged it as a navigational hazard, filed the appropriate form, and would have forgotten it if not for the malfunction.

The moment they tried to tractor it in, every visualization node on the listening post went white.

“EMP?” asked Commander Sesh, rows of bioluminescent eyes narrowing.

“Negative,” said the technologist. “We are operational. The object started… transmitting.”

“Visualize,” Sesh ordered.

The central chamber dimmed to void-black, and then the walls bloomed to life, as they always did when the Hegemony’s bio-projectors painted a scene. The Kethorians never made “images” as humans understood them; they shaped coherent, multi-sensory fields—scent, color, taste of photons, soft gravitational shifts—that overlapped to form an experience directly in the nervous system. It was elegant, efficient, perfect.

The intrusion that erupted into their nervous nets was none of those things.

A black field appeared, then a sudden, blaring fanfare.

Golden shapes wheeled across the dark. Letters. Crude, rigid. A circle behind them.

“Translated glyphs,” murmured the linguist. “It spells—”

The sound slammed into them: orchestral, bombastic, shamelessly grand. Something in the composition screamed: This matters. This is important. Pay attention.

Sesh flinched. “Shut off the aural layer.”

“I can’t,” the technologist gasped. “It’s… encoded. It’s forcing sensory priority protocols.”

On the walls, glowing letters resolved:

PARAMOUNT PICTURES.

Then the picture shifted. Colors flattened, perspective warped into an approximation of depth using tricks that hurt to parse. A man in a tight shirt barked orders on a “bridge” that was clearly not in space, surrounded by panels of blinking lights that didn’t control anything at all.

“What… is this?” Sesh whispered.

“Simulation?” one suggested.

“No,” said another. “Look—seams in the backdrop, inconsistent lighting. They are aware of the falsehood. They display it anyway.”

Phaser beams shot across the “screen” as the crew lurched in choreography. Planets hung implausibly close; alien species appeared as the same basic form, altered with mere ridges and pigments.

The Kethorians watched the entire episode in silence, too stunned to speak.

When it ended, the satellite queued another.

“Multiple files,” the technologist whispered, horrified. “Thousands. Audio-visual content. Unencrypted. Broadcast in all directions.”

“Shut it down,” Sesh said.

“I’m trying. It’s incredibly primitive, Commander. There’s no hard lock. But it’s layered with—wait. Another’s starting.”

A yellow title card. A roaring lion in a decorative frame.

The lion opened its mouth and the sound hit them: a challenge, a declaration. They recoiled a fraction. And then:

STAR WARS.

The room filled with a starfield. A tiny vessel crawled across their perception, chased by an impossibly large wedge of a ship. The illusion of size came not from any spacetime distortion, but from lines and shadows. It shouldn’t have worked.

It worked.

Turbolasers flashed. The Kethorians felt their internal organs tense.

“This is… a war record?” Sesh guessed. “Their warships are crude. Chemical combustion, thermal weapons. Yet they depict conflict on astronomical scales with such confidence.”

“They’re lying to themselves,” the linguist murmured. “Showing power they do not have.”

“That’s not the fear-source,” said Sesh. “We’ve seen propaganda. Monitor response metrics.”

There was a soft chime as the station’s empathy field reported. “Neural resonance at seventy-one percent,” the technologist said. “They are syncing us to their narrative arcs without neural stitching. With faked visuals.”

The film continued. Laser swords. Death spheres. Faster-than-light leaps visualized as star-stretches. The physics mangled. The aesthetics extravagant. The Kethorians, as a people, had long treated visual falsification as a taboo. Once, early in their ascent, they’d discovered that if you could make a mind see something that wasn’t there, irrevocably, you could make it believe anything. One brush with civilization-wide psychosis had burned that lesson into their culture.

So they banned what they called Discrete Imagery: fixed-perspective illusions, standalone false frames. No paintings. No films. No CGI. Their sensory technology was always truth-indexed: what you saw was what was there. Simulations were tactile, annotated, devoutly honest.

Humans, apparently, had never agreed to this restraint.

“Commander,” the linguist whispered when the trench run began, when a wildly implausible shot destroyed an empire. “This species has industrialized constrained falsehood for emotional effect. Look at the patterns. Look at the timing. They understand the deep rhythms. And they deploy them like… like weapons.”

The shot landed; the station shook with the score’s climax. The Kethorians’ hearts raced in forced synchrony.

“Turn it off,” Sesh said. “Now.”

The file cut. Silence.

No one moved.

“Report,” Sesh ordered finally.

The technologist swallowed. “The device’s architecture is centuries old. Crude radio beacons, simple storage. But the content…”

He pulled up metadata. “A ‘cultural archive.’ Open to the cosmos. No encryption, no disclaimers. It assumes any recipient will decode its signals and see. They want to be seen.”

“Or they want us to see what they can imagine,” the linguist added. “They celebrate speculation. Worlds they cannot reach, powers they do not hold, beings they have not met. And yet they render them visible, detailed, emotionally coherent. With… with nothing but layered light.”

“That practice is prohibited for a reason,” whispered an elder advisor. Her throat-frills flushed warning purple. “You remember the Old Madness.”

They all did. Before the Hegemony, the Kethorians had unleashed sensory engines that crafted perfect illusions. People starved while feasting on fictional banquets, rushed into storms believing them to be gardens, killed each other over choreographed dreams. It took a planetary blackout and a generation of shame to crawl back.

“This species,” the elder said, “has taken that same abyss and built a culture around it. They fill their sky with fantasies.”

The technologist cycled rapidly through thumbnails: superheroes hurling cities, monsters leveling coasts, tiny teams of misfits saving galaxies that bore no resemblance to reality.

“And they are not broken,” he murmured. “They survived it.”

“Or they are broken differently,” the linguist said. “Look at the escalation. Early files show simple illusions, shaky, endearing. Later ones: near-seamless falsity. They name it ‘computer-generated imagery.’ Machines that paint perfect lies.”

“Perfect?” Sesh’s voice was brittle.

“Near enough. They simulate fluids, flesh, stars, impossible architectures. They invite their young to watch this from infancy. To love fabricated faces. To weep over code and composites.”

The elder’s frills dimmed to a sickly gray. “We cannot compete with a species that bonds to illusions.”

A silence, heavy as collapsed mass.

“They are pre-FTL,” Sesh tried. “Their technology is centuries behind ours.”

“And yet,” the linguist said, “their dreams outrun ours. We refused to picture what was not-here. They refused to stop. They train every mind on their world to crave impossibility. They canonicalize it in sagas. They file-share their hallucinations between continents as casually as nutrient data. They make films about defeating gods, annihilating fleets, reshaping reality with a finger-snap—and then they go back to their factories and ask, ‘How close can we get?’”

“You’re describing ambition,” Sesh snapped. “Ambition without safeguard. That’s not power. That’s instability.”

“But instability that survived,” the elder countered softly. “Imagine what happens when a species who regards physics as a suggestion achieves what we have. Imagine minds honed for generations to empathize with fictional beings. To inhabit simulations without losing self. To tolerate contradiction: knowing something is false and surrendering to it anyway. Do you know what that is, Commander?”

The word that followed did not translate easily. The system rendered it as: “Immunity to the terror of abstraction.”

The Kethorians remained the most powerful civilization in known space because everyone else trembled before the pure weight of the real. FTL required confronting spacetime as it was, not as it was wished to be. Dimension-folding demanded a psyche that did not shatter at non-Euclidean intuitions. The Kethorians had carved themselves sterile and disciplined to bear it.

But these humans? They had, for centuries, practiced playing in unreality.

“Commander,” the technologist said, very quietly, “what if exposing them to our true capacities will not break them? What if it will delight them? What if they see the folds between stars and say, ‘We’ve rendered this before. Show us the behind-the-scenes.’”

A clip flickered unbidden on a secondary node—behind-the-scenes footage of actors standing before green curtains, laughing, as invisible worlds were promised around them. Humans watching humans pretending to stand in imaginary places, trusting that machines would paint those places later.

The elder recoiled. “Corrupt,” she hissed. “They reveal the falsity and still the illusion holds value.”

“Commander,” whispered the linguist, “they are not ensnared by their illusions. They collaborate with them. They know the trick. They love the trick. They get better at the trick.”

Outside, the satellite tumbled on, uncaring.

Sesh felt, for the first time in a century of service, the cold press of fear not at a weapon, not at a fleet—but at a possibility.

A young, fragile species that broadcast its fantasies to the void as greetings, that taught its children to find meaning in characters that never lived, that could cry over a generated image and then go build the next one.

What happens when such a species gains tools that can remake actual stars?

“Seal this system,” Sesh said at last. His voice, normally resonant, came out low. “No beacons, no contact, no hints we were here. We quarantine it.”

“Until when?” the elder asked.

“Until they hit FTL on their own,” Sesh answered.

The chamber flared in alarmed color.

“We cannot let them roam,” someone protested.

“We cannot stop them,” Sesh said. “Not if they are as fluent with unreality as we are with truth. We show them our weapons and they will already have seen better ones in their ‘movies.’ We reveal our forms and they will say we look like something from Season Three. They are inoculated against awe. We are not.”

He looked at the frozen frame of a caped figure hovering over a cityscape, cape billowing in physically impossible wind.

“We are the most powerful civilization in the universe,” Sesh said. “And we are terrified of their toys.”

On the station’s edge, the satellite’s transmission cycled to another file, beaming bravely into the dark: a cartoon of a mouse whistling on a steamboat, the birth-cry of corporate fantasy.

The Kethorians shuttered their senses and turned away, not from disgust, but from a deep, quaking understanding:

They had chosen a universe that must always match what it is.

Humans had spent their brief existence training to thrive in universes that didn’t.

samples.prompt: Death had always wondered if it were possible, but today confirms it. On his daily list of harvests was a single name: God.
samples.output:
Death had always wondered if it were possible, but today confirms it. On his daily list of harvests was a single name: God.

There was, firstly, the handwriting.

The list wrote itself every midnight in a curling plume of pale blue ink, across parchment that did not exist in any sensible way. It simply unfolded in his hand as if he had always been holding it. The script, orderly and inevitable, had remained consistent since the first cell divided in the first lukewarm sea. Death did not write it. Death only read.

He read because that was what there was to do. And he harvested because that was what followed.

Except, tonight, the list was one word.

No tyrant. No infant. No saint. No soldier. Just:

God.

Death waited for the punchline. Something in the ink to shimmer, rearrange. Perhaps a smudge: Good? A glitch: Dog? Once, ages ago, a minor archangel had tampered with the parchment as a joke, slipping in his own name to test whether Death could be startled. Death had ignored it until the ink corrected itself, embarrassed, back into the span of nine hundred and six assorted souls scheduled for that second.

But this did not correct.

The word sat there, unornamented, perfectly spelled. A statement, not a question.

Death turned it over—figuratively, because there was only the one side, and literally turning it had never changed a word—and stared longer than strictly necessary. Around him, the Gray Between remained unhelpfully unchanged: a horizonless expanse with the suggestion of distant waves, the quiet hum of every ticking second layered on every other. It was his office and his road, his silence and the throat-clearing before every ending.

“This is not standard,” he said aloud.

Nothing answered. Nothing usually did.

He had wondered, of course. Not idly—Death did very little idly—but as one might probe a loose tooth with the tongue. Was there an end to what did not end? Was there a harvest waiting even for the one who’d lit the first suns?

The thought had seemed almost impious. He found that funny, in its way. Impious toward whom? His role was older than the oldest scripture, but younger than whatever had declared, Let there be. He’d reasoned it out a thousand thousand times: if he were necessary for all that lived, then whatever authored all that lived had authored him, too. If there was a designer, Death was part of the design.

But designs ran down. Systems decayed. Entropy was just his less personable cousin.

He studied the name again.

God.

It did not specify which one. Death, if pressed, would have said there had only ever been one, refracted through cultures like white light through stained glass. Names were not a problem for him; he knew whom the ink meant.

There were rules. He did not make them. He did not break them. They simply were, the way gravity simply is in places with mass. They had the texture of axioms: when the name appears, you go; when you go, you arrive; when you arrive, you reap.

“What happens,” he mused, “if I don’t?”

No response; no correction. The ink sat like a held breath.

He felt something he had not felt since the first time he’d stood at the bedside of a dying star: reluctance.

It was such a gentle thing, that star. It had taken millennia to exhaust itself. When he had laid his hand on its fading core, it had gone with a sigh of relief, collapsing into a whisper of heavier elements destined for later worlds, later lives. That had been his first inkling that his task was not cruelty. It was, if anything, housekeeping.

Was this that, then? Cosmic housekeeping?

He folded the parchment, though folding did nothing to it, and stepped.

The Gray Between unraveled. The place he arrived in was not a throne room, not a garden, not the abstract everywhere of omnipresence. It was a bench.

A wooden bench beneath an old tree whose species did not strictly exist. Its leaves were all shapes at once—fig, olive, bodhi, yew—and they did not rustle so much as converse. Beyond the tree lay a meadow where no two blades of grass agreed on a shade of green, and far off was a suggestion of mountains and sea and sky braided into a single horizon.

A man sat on the bench.

He was old, and he was young. His face rearranged itself whenever Death looked away: lined like riverbeds, smooth as newborn palms, dark, pale, tawny, all and neither. He wore no crown. His clothes were simple: a shirt, sleeves rolled; loose pants; bare feet in the grass. He was picking splinters from his thumb, frowning as if this surprised him.

On the air lay a familiarity. Death had known him without ever seeing him. The way one knows gravity. The way a word knows its meaning.

“Sit,” the man said.

Death did not consent easily. He lacked knees; he had to remember to have them. Now he remembered, and the bench accepted him as if he weighed more than galaxies.

“Is it a mistake?” Death asked.

“No.” The man examined the bead of blood on his thumb with fascinated sorrow. “Beautiful, isn’t it?”

Death followed his gaze. The droplet trembled, bright and impossibly red. So much meaning in such a small dot.

“I don’t bleed,” Death said.

“I know.” The man wiped the blood on his pants. “You will not have to.”

There was a pause. Meaningful, because everything here was.

“Your name is on my list,” Death said.

“I put it there,” the man replied.

“You do not write the list.”

“Don’t I?”

Death hesitated. That was new. “The list writes itself. It always has.”

“I wrote ‘always’ too,” He said, shrugging lightly. “It was ambitious.”

The leaves above them laughed, or perhaps it was wind. Death felt the shape of something like irritation.

“This is not a time for riddles,” he said. “If your name is there, I am bound to act.”

“I know,” God said.

His voice did something unexpected then. It cracked. Just barely. As though weight pressed on syllables that could no longer bear being infinitely steady.

Death watched Him. “Why?”

God leaned back, watching the kaleidoscope sky.

“Do you know how many prayers I have heard?” He asked.

“Yes,” Death said automatically.

“No,” God corrected gently. “You know the number. You do not know the weight.”

Silence fell, full and plush.

“I spoke a world,” God said. “Then others. I permitted choice; I permitted consequence. I watched love ferment into cruelty and cruelty into repentance. I watched suns form and die and form and die until the pattern became a hymn. It is beautiful. It is unbearable.”

Death said nothing.

“I set you there,” God continued. “At the edge of every ending. You are my mercy where they can’t see my face. My law where they see only chaos. You have been faithful.”

“Faith,” Death said slowly, “is not a term I apply to myself.”

“I do,” God said. “You never refused, never wavered, never spitefully stayed your hand. Even when they cursed you. Even when they made you a monster.”

“That was…irrelevant,” Death said.

“Duty,” God translated. “Faith in the function I gave you.”

Death lowered his gaze. He had never needed praise. Hearing it unsettled him more than any curse.

“Why put your name down?” Death asked again. “Eternity does not exhaust itself.”

“It does,” God said. “On both ends.”

He tipped His head toward the horizon, where all beginnings lay stacked like books.

“I have been all-powerful for a very long time,” He said. “Long enough to learn that omnipotence is not immunity. I am bound by what I chose to be. By promises. By justice. By the physics I liked too much to break. By their belief in me. By my belief in them.”

He sighed.

“To be God is to never be done. Unless,” He looked at Death now, and His eyes were ancient, “I choose to be done.”

Death felt an unease like a ripple through the Gray Between.

“If you end,” Death said, “who sustains what remains? Who writes the list?”

“You overestimate how much I micromanage,” God said dryly. “They think I am in every raindrop. Sometimes the clouds just happen. I have delegated more than you’d suspect.”

“It will all fall apart,” Death insisted, not sure why he cared.

“Yes,” God said softly. “But it was always going to. Heat death, thin dust. A lovely fade-out. I designed an end, remember? Every system with a beginning is honest enough to carry its own ending inside it.”

“Then what is this?” Death demanded, parchment crinkling in his hand. “An acceleration? An abdication?”

“A courtesy,” God said. “To myself. To you.”

Death stared at Him. The word offended and moved him at once.

“A courtesy,” he echoed.

“You wondered,” God said. “If there was anything beyond your task. If there would come a moment you were not needed. If even I might cross your threshold. I heard that wondering. It was a kind of prayer, though you would never call it that.”

“I do not pray,” Death said.

“And yet,” God said, with a small smile. “Here we are.”

Death looked at the list. At the single word.

“If I reap you,” he said, “do I become you?”

God laughed. It startled the leaves, shook bright fruit into being that vanished before they could fall.

“Do you want to?” He asked.

The question stretched.

Death searched himself. He found no hunger for worship, no desire for omniscience. Only a weary curiosity and a strange, small ache he could not name.

“No,” Death said.

“Good,” God answered. “One of me is plenty. Was plenty.”

“Then what happens?” Death whispered.

“What always happens,” God said. “You touch. I go where they all go, whatever that truly is. Perhaps oblivion. Perhaps something I could not see from my vantage point. I am tired of not being surprised.”

“And after?” Death pressed. “Who tends the list?”

God’s gaze softened with something like pride.

“Look down,” He said.

Death obeyed.

Below the line that bore the word God, ink unfurled anew, writing across what had been blank:

All That Remains.

Death watched the words fix, dry.

“It seems,” God said, “I delegate one last thing.”

“You make me God,” Death said, more accusation than awe.

“I free you from me,” God replied. “And bind you to no one. That line does not say ‘Creator’ or ‘Judge’ or ‘King.’ It says what it means. You will tend what remains. End what must end. Begin, if you dare, what might begin. Or don’t. For the first time, you will be what I never was: unbound.”

Death’s emptiness rang. Unbound.

“I am not suited to creating,” Death said.

“Neither was I, at first,” God murmured. “You learn. Or you leave the canvas blank.”

He stood.

Up close, He looked more human than anything. A little stooped. Shadows under His eyes. His bare feet were dirty.

“I am afraid,” God admitted.

The words shook the air.

“You?” Death said, genuinely startled.

“Of course,” God said. “Knowing everything doesn’t mean feeling nothing.”

“Do you wish to rescind your name?” Death asked, a formality he had never spoken before.

God smiled. “No. I wish you would take my hand.”

Death had taken uncountable hands. Tiny, trembling, clawed, calloused. He had never taken one that shook the architecture of reality.

Yet his fingers closed around God’s as easily as around any mortal’s. The skin was warm. The pulse fluttered.

“You can still refuse,” God said quietly. “I wrote free will for them. I can permit a taste of it for you.”

Death looked into His face. Found no compulsion there. Only invitation, and exhaustion, and hope.

Free will. The option not to obey.

It hit him like light.

He could let God remain, eternally watching, eternally burdened. He could step back. Say, Keep going. I will keep doing my part.

And in a million million years, they would all arrive here anyway, in heatless dark, and say, Why?

Death tightened his grip.

“No,” he said. “We are done.”

He felt the surprise ripple through God, sharp and bright, followed by something like gratitude so vast it bent the sky.

“Thank you,” God whispered.

Once, only once, Death broke protocol.

“You’re welcome,” he said.

He lifted his other hand, the one that had closed the eyes of every creature that ever was, and laid it gently against God’s chest.

All at once, there was a sound like every prayer unspooling at once into silence. The sky inverted. The tree shed all its leaves in a single, shining breath; the meadow browned and burst into seeds; the mountains and seas braided tighter, tighter, until they were a single point of brilliant, unbearable white in Death’s palm.

Then it went out.

No fanfare. No choir. Just absence, settling.

Death stood alone in a place that was no longer the bench, no longer the Gray Between, no longer anything designed by anyone but the person who now found himself with the option to design.

In his hand, the parchment trembled. New ink bled.

He looked.

There was no list.

There was only a blank page, and at its top, in his own unfamiliar handwriting, a single question:

What now?

Death, for the first time, did not know.

He considered the nothing stretched around him, rich as soil.

Slowly, almost shyly, he imagined a light.

It appeared.

He watched it for a long moment.

Then, not as duty, not as decree, but as choice, Death smiled, and decided to see what might live.

samples.prompt: "Centuries ago, when we granted you the mean to flee the Milky Way, we also warned you of the horror we are running from. And your kind didn't listen. You fought, and you failed, just as we had aeon before, and now all that left of Mankind is the ragtag band of refugees in front of me. Why?"
samples.output:
“Why?”

The word hangs in the stale air between us, drifting through the low murmur of the docking bay. Outside the fractured viewport, the swollen red eye of the gas giant churns silently, scattering rust-colored light across the battered hulls moored to this forgotten station. The ships look like survivors themselves—scorched plating, slashed insignias, jury-rigged modules pulsing with unstable power. A hundred human faces stare back at me, gaunt and sunken, holding an expression I have not seen on your kind in ten thousand years.

Humility.

I stand—or rather, I manifest—before you in a shape you can accept. A tall figure of pale light, neither male nor female, with features carved in calm regret. You recognize what I am: not a god, not a demon, but one of the ones who came before. My people named themselves in a tongue older than your sun’s birth, but your histories only ever called us “the Precursors.”

“Why?” I repeat, quieter. “We told you.”

No one answers. You are soldiers, pilots, engineers—those who outlived your worlds. You’ve seen continents unmake themselves in one long night. You’ve watched defensive grids melt like wax. You’ve listened to command channels dissolve into screaming and static. So you know, at least in the rawest sense, what we ran from.

But you do not understand why we warned you the way we did.

“We did not withhold details to be cruel,” I say. “You must believe that, if you believe nothing else.”

A woman steps forward, her uniform scorched and threadbare, rank torn away, leaving only the ghost of an admiral’s insignia. Her hair is white, not from age. “You came to us three hundred years ago,” she says, voice rough. “You shattered our orbital defenses like they were paper. You walked through our atmosphere without a ship. You could’ve commanded us. Instead, you advised. You gave us engines that could outrun our own sunrise. You laid out slingshot trajectories out of the galaxy. And then—just a warning. ‘Do not fight what is coming. Flee.’ No context. No proof. Just… fear. Yours.”

I incline my head. “Yes.”

“So why?” she demands. “Why not show us? Why not explain what it is? Why not help us fight it?”

A bitter laugh rolls through the listening crowd. They have heard this argument on burned-out decks, in sealed bunkers, in drifting arkships with half their life support gone. It is an old, old accusation.

“Because,” I say, “no one ever believes until it is too late.”

A murmur. Anger, disbelief. Humans hate being spoken to in riddles. You have always preferred an enemy you can put in a targeting solution.

“You’re very proud,” I continue. “As we were. You find meaning in defiance. As we did. When we first faced it, we had empires that made your brightest wonders look like toys. We wove gravity like cloth. We conversed in magnetospheres. We turned dead moons into living archives, star coronas into engines. We had mapped the dark filaments between galaxies. We had seen the first light of the universe caught in the jaws of black holes.”

I pause. The memory aches. “We thought there was nothing left that could frighten us.”

“The first systems went silent in patterns too delicate to see as anything but noise. Then came derelicts: planets scoured smooth, like their biospheres had sublimated. Our listening arrays reported missing: not destroyed—missing. Equations broke. Everywhere it touched, the fundamental constants wavered in the two hundredth decimal place. We caught its shadow in probability distributions. We never observed it in any conventional sense, never parleyed, never traded blows. It was not a fleet. It was not a god. It was not a predator in any way your myths would understand.”

I look up, past the hull, past the thin flexing of the station’s shields, to the distant scatter of stars.

“It is a convergence of failure states in the structure of reality itself. A self-propagating correction. Where complexity arises beyond a certain threshold, where conscious minds pile atop conscious minds and press at the boundaries of the possible, the continuity fractures. It finds you. Not because it hates you. Because you exist in a configuration the universe resolves by erasing.”

A young man in the back scoffs. “That sounds like theology.”

“That is you trying to force it into a story,” I reply. “We did the same. We named it a god, a demon, a law, a plague. None of the names changed what it did. It unmade us. We fought back with weapons that flensed time in localized regions. We seeded counter-histories. We quarantined half a spiral arm behind a wall of tangled causality. We won, once, for six thousand years.”

I let that hang; the staggering length means nothing to you now.

“And then the wall failed.”

I gesture toward your few remaining ships. “When we came to you, we had already lost. We had fled to the galactic halo, burned half our remaining strength carving narrow exit vectors between flows of dark matter. The Milky Way was already compromised. The infection—call it that, if you must—had sunk deep. We looked at you and saw the same reflex we had: you would fight. You would waste yourselves for the poetry of resistance. So we said: Do not fight. Flee.”

“And you didn’t tell us what we were running from,” the admiral says. “You expected us to trust a ghost and abandon everything we’d built. No name, no shape, no evidence. Just your fear.”

“Yes,” I say softly. “We did.”

“Then you failed us,” someone snarls.

“Yes,” I say again.

Silence. The honesty disarms them more than any excuse would.

“We thought,” I continue, “that if we showed you more, you would try to solve it. That is your genius, and your doom. You would examine it, probe it, weaponize scraped fragments of its pattern. You would dream of outsmarting the cosmic kill-switch. In that effort, you would accelerate its engagement with you. We have seen that happen before—on worlds older than your star, with species far more cautious than you.”

I look from face to face.

“But we also underestimated your pride. Your myth of the unconquerable human spirit. Your hunger to stand and say, ‘Not us. We’ll break the cycle.’”

Outside, the gas giant’s storms pulse, a slow heartbeat.

“When we left you the drives that could cross the great dark between galaxies, we gave you your only real chance at survival. Departure, ahead of schedule. Slip into the intergalactic night where complexity thins, where the correction passes you by. You could have gone quietly, centuries ago, a diaspora into the void. You could have survived as wandering embers between the great islands of light.”

“You call that survival?” the admiral says. There is real fury now. “Abandon our worlds, our art, our oceans, our cities, on the word of strangers? To spend eternity as vagrants between galaxies, hiding from something we’ve never seen? That is not living.”

“And how is this?” I ask gently, sweeping my arm at the ragged crowd, the half-dead station, the graveyard of ships. “Is this living?”

No one answers.

“That is why,” I say. “That is your answer. You did not listen because the warning denied you your favorite story: that courage plus ingenuity equals victory. Leaving without a fight felt like cowardice. You chose a glorious extinction war over a quiet, uncertain exile. You did exactly what we did, eons before, for the exact same reasons.”

I step closer to the admiral. She does not flinch.

“We come to you now, not as judges. We are far beyond judgment. We are fugitive echoes. We preserved what we could, of ourselves, in these projection forms and memory vaults drifting the dark. Most of us have already fallen out of phase, decohered into whispers. I am here because, despite everything, some of us remembered you.”

A flicker of surprise crosses her face. “Remembered us?”

“You are not the first younger race we warned,” I say. “You are the last that tried to fight alongside us instead of against us. In our decline, that stubbornness impressed us. Irritated us. Fascinated us.”

I allow a faint smile. “We wanted you to live. Not because you were special. Because you were… unfinished. Our story ended in recursion and surrender. Yours was still trying to rewrite the script.”

I gesture again to the viewport, where the thin scatter of distant galaxies glimmers. “The window has not entirely closed. You cannot save the Milky Way. It is written into the failure field now; its high-density networks of life and thought are already tagged. But small clusters—like you—can still slip free, if you go now, and if you stop pretending you can win.”

A murmur: hope, this time, thin and worn.

“The horror is not a beast to slay,” I say. “It is a clause embedded in reality. We never found a weapon to kill it. The only successes we recorded were acts of evasion, dilution—letting go of density, dispersing into the quiet. You call that cowardice; I call it adaptation. You ask ‘why’ you are reduced to refugees? Because you chose to stand your ground on a battlefield where ground itself is the enemy.”

The admiral’s hands curl into fists. “And what would you have us be? Drifters in the void. Fugitives, forever looking over our shoulders?”

“Yes,” I say. “If you want your children’s children to have stars of their own one day in another universe of their making, then yes. Live small. Live scattered. Live long enough to learn what we could not. There may come a mind, human or otherwise, that understands the flaw beneath the flaw, the line of code we missed at the foundation of the real. But that mind will not exist if you insist on dying poetically in front of a force that does not even notice your bravery.”

I let the last words fall.

Outside, one of your ships breaks formation and burns its aging engines, rising from the station like an ember. It turns, nose toward the thick black between the galaxies, where no constellations wait. A long silence follows.

Finally, the admiral speaks, almost to herself. “We fought because that was the only story we knew how to live.”

I nod. “Then write a new one.”

She looks up at me, eyes bright with something sharp and painful. “Will you help us this time?”

For the first time in a very long time, I hesitate.

“We are diminished,” I say. “We are pieces, not a people. Our strength is gone. Our knowledge is… scarred. But we can guide your paths into the dark. Teach you how to thin your presence, mask your signatures, live below the detection threshold. It will feel like regression. It will feel like fear. You must do it anyway.”

“And if we find a way to end it?” she asks.

A strange warmth stirs in me. Hope, or the ghost of it.

“Then,” I say, “remember that we warned you to flee—and forgive us for not believing you when you choose to stand.”

samples.prompt: 2 WW2 Pilots develop rivalry after multiple dogfights. Finally one of them dies.
samples.output:
The first time Kessler saw the red-nosed Spitfire, he thought it was a mistake.

The British pilot came head-on out of the sun, closing fast, too fast. Kessler flicked his Bf 109 into a climbing turn, expecting the Englishman to overshoot or break. Instead, the Spitfire knifed past at mere meters, wingtips flashing. A white-gloved hand lifted from the cockpit canopy in something between a wave and a salute.

Then the Spitfire rolled, came around on his tail, and the sky turned to tracers.

Kessler’s curses were swallowed by the roar of his engine. He yanked the stick, feeling the 109 shudder as it bled altitude. The Brit stayed with him for a full, terrifying spiral before breaking away, as if bored. The red nose dipped once, in acknowledgment.

Kessler landed that afternoon flushed with anger.

“He played with me,” he told his mechanic, lighting a cigarette with hands that still trembled. “Like a cat.”

“Next time you shoot him down,” the mechanic said.

Kessler ground the cigarette out. “Next time,” he agreed.

The second time, a month later, Kessler recognized him at once. There could not be two Spitfires with a nose painted so bright a red it seemed to bleed into the blue sky.

They met over the French coast, weaving through a chaos of contrails and spinning shadows. Kessler had just sent one RAF fighter smoking into the Channel when the red nose cut across his vision. A burst stitched silver just ahead of his propeller. Kessler rolled and dove, snapped back up, and found the Spitfire crossing his path.

He fired.

The Brit jerked aside, caught a few rounds along the wing root. Not enough. The Spitfire shimmied, recovered, looped right over him. They circled, two wasps locked in a private war no one else in that crowded, screaming sky seemed to notice.

It ended with them facing each other at distance, guns empty.

For a breath, both planes flew straight and level, closing. Kessler saw him clearly then: goggles, narrow jaw, the tilt of a head that somehow read as amused even from fifty meters away. The red-nosed Spitfire waggled its wings.

Kessler, before he knew why he did it, waggled back.

He had dreams about that Spitfire.

On the British side of the Channel, Flight Lieutenant Daniel Cole was earning a reputation.

“He’s got a painted nose like a circus wagon,” one of the new boys muttered.

Cole, sprawled in a chair with his boots on a crate, smirked. “Helps Jerry remember me,” he said.

“Helps them aim at you,” his squadron leader said dryly. “You fancy yourself invincible, Cole?”

Cole ran a thumbnail along the chipped edge of his mug. The memory of the grey 109 came to him: the precise, economical movements, the coolness. The German hadn’t panicked.

“He’s still up there,” Cole said softly.

“Who?” asked one of the others.

“Jerry,” Cole said. “My Jerry.”

They laughed, but it never left him. The sky didn’t feel like faceless enemies anymore. Somewhere above, between vapor trails and bursts of black flak, was the German with the steady hands and the wary eyes. He found him again over Dieppe, over Cherbourg, half-glimpsed shapes crossing at impossible speeds.

Twice Cole got the angle and missed by inches; twice Kessler came down on his six only for Cole to slip away, heart pounding, feeling the breath of death on his neck.

Once, during a rare quiet hour, Cole wrote in his logbook: “Red nose vs. grey 109. Met again. Still alive. He’s good.” After a moment, he added, “Next time.”

On Kessler’s side, there were similar notes, never shared: “Red nose Spitfire. Again. Pilot is skilled, reckless. Plays by his own rules.” He did not add how each encounter left him feeling strangely…alive.

By 1943, the war had grown heavier, dirtier. They flew escort, interception, defense. The stakes rose with each mission. There were fewer jokes in the mess, fewer familiar faces at the morning briefings.

Cole lost a friend over Caen, watching helplessly as fire hollowed out a cockpit. Kessler’s younger wingman, barely nineteen, simply did not return from a mission near Amiens. Both men learned that grief in wartime is compact, dangerously portable. You carry it in a pocket and pretend not to feel the weight.

Their rivalry sharpened.

Over Fécamp, Cole finally got the jump. The 109 shimmered below him, angled just wrong, offering a brief golden opportunity. Cole rolled in, firing a two-second burst.

Rounds chewed across the German’s wing and tail. For an instant, Cole thought he had him. Then the 109 snapped into a vicious split-S, hurtling toward the sea. Cole followed, pushing his Spitfire to the edge of its strength. The altimeter unwound madly.

At the last second, the 109 pulled up, brushing the whitecaps. Cole’s Spitfire shuddered, compressibility pinning his controls. The ocean surged up, gray and merciless.

In that instant, he believed he’d lost. Then the stick loosened; he leveled out, so low salt spray ghosted across his canopy. Heart roaring in his ears, he climbed. The German was gone.

“He nearly killed me,” Cole said later, sitting on the wing while a mechanic checked for stress fractures. “Dove like the devil himself was pulling him by the nose.”

“And did you nearly kill him?” the mechanic asked.

Cole thought of the bullet trails splintering aluminum. “Yes,” he said.

In a hangar across the Channel, Kessler stared at the jagged holes in his wing. “He aims better now,” he told his mechanic.

“The red one? You should finish him,” the man said.

Kessler didn’t answer. He only touched the torn metal as if it were a bruise on his own skin.

The last time they met, the war had turned.

Summer 1944. The Allied invasion had torn open the continent. Kessler’s squadron was tired, outnumbered, flying on fuel that tasted of desperation. Cole, now more weathered, more careful, led tense sorties deeper into France, his red nose as much a target as a banner.

They found each other over the retreating German column northeast of Falaise.

“Bandits, ten o’clock high,” came the call. Cole squinted, saw Messerschmitts diving in. Tracers stitched up from the loaded road below. He signaled his section and broke toward the attackers.

In the turning melee that followed, the world collapsed to noise and motion. A Spitfire blew apart ahead of Cole, pieces tumbling like burning leaves. He swore, rolled, and there—there—was the grey 109.

“Red Leader, you’ve got one on your nose,” his wingman called.

“I see him,” Cole replied.

He saw more than that. He saw the angle of the bank, the telltale twitch before a climb. His German.

Cole pitched up, turned into him, guns already chattering. The 109 swerved, but Cole had anticipated it. Rounds grazed the fuselage. The Messerschmitt jerked away, climbing. Cole followed.

They rose together into a thin, pale sky, leaving behind the boiling chaos. Up here, it was almost quiet. Each pilot knew the other’s rhythm now, each reading the minute hesitations that mirrored his own.

Kessler felt the Spitfire lock onto his tail and flung his aircraft into a barrel roll. Cole stayed with him. They spiraled, losing speed, edging toward a stall. At the top of the climb, both snapped over.

For a heartbeat, they flew parallel, canopies almost level.

Kessler turned his head. Through the glass, he saw Cole clearly: older now, fatigue carved into his face, eyes narrowed but still bright. Cole stared back at him. A thousand feet below, the war raged. Up here, there were only two men who had tried to kill each other more times than they could count and somehow hadn’t.

Cole saw the German’s mouth move, forming some word he’d never hear.

Then Kessler broke away, sudden and sharp, a maneuver that left his 109 momentarily exposed.

Cole reacted on instinct. Thumb. Trigger.

The burst was perfect.

He saw the tracers walk from the base of the Messerschmitt’s tail up through the fuselage, striking the engine cowling. Black smoke erupted. The 109 lurched.

Cole felt the triumph rise—and die just as quickly as the 109 did not explode, did not spin wildly like so many others he’d seen. Instead, it sagged, wounded, and began a controlled, shallow dive.

Kessler fought the bucking machine. Oil sprayed across his windscreen. Fire licked at the edges of his vision. He knew at once the engine was finished. He also knew he had altitude, some control, and perhaps a chance to put down in a field—if fate was kind, if Allied ground fire was blind for one blessed moment.

Behind him, the red-nosed Spitfire slid into position, perfectly placed to deliver the killing shot.

Cole’s finger hovered over the trigger.

“One more pass, Red Leader, he’s smoking,” came his wingman’s voice.

Cole watched the stricken 109. No evasive jink now, no clever roll. Just a wounded bird gliding down over fields scarred by craters and smoke. Through the smeared canopy, he thought he saw Kessler glance back once.

Cole eased his hand away from the trigger.

“He’s done,” he said. “Leave him.”

He throttled back slightly, watching. The Messerschmitt disappeared behind a thin row of trees. A faint smear of dust and debris rose. No fireball. No towering smoke.

“Think he bought it?” his wingman asked.

“Maybe,” Cole said. His chest felt strangely tight. “Maybe not.”

Orders crackled in his ears, dragging him back. He banked away and rejoined the others, the red nose cutting through the sky.

On the ground, Kessler never felt the impact. The failing engine seized at too low an altitude. The 109 clipped a copse of oaks, cartwheeled, and came apart in a scatter of metal and dirt. What little remained burned quickly.

Cole heard the confirmation two days later. An intelligence officer, flipping through reconnaissance photos, tapped a black-and-white image.

“Red Leader, you remember that 109 you flamed near Falaise?”

Cole looked. There in the picture, among the wreckage of a field, lay twisted wings bearing the faint, familiar markings.

“Pilot KIA,” the officer said. “Nice work.”

Cole stared at the photograph. The words came out flat.

“Yeah,” he said. “Nice work.”

That night, he sat alone outside the dispersal hut, the red nose of his Spitfire dull in the fading light. He lit a cigarette, then another, without really smoking them. Above, the sky stretched wide and indifferent.

He’d spent years trying to kill that German, and the German trying to kill him. When it finally ended, there was no cheer in it. Only an absence, a gap where something fierce and terrible and almost sacred had been.

Cole tipped his head back and searched the empty sky, as if expecting to see a grey shape rolling out of the sun, a white-gloved hand lifting in salute.

Nothing.

In the morning, the war went on.

samples.prompt: Guardian Demon (Details inside)
samples.output:
I didn’t know my guardian angel had horns until the night I died.

It happened on a Tuesday, which felt rude. Tuesdays were meant for emails and lukewarm coffee, not for car accidents. One minute I was driving home, squinting through a sleet-streaked windshield while a talk radio host yelled about housing prices; the next, there were headlights where no headlights should be, the shriek of tires, an impossible slow-motion tumble.

Then silence.

No tunnel of light. No comforting choir. Just the slow awareness of not being in my car anymore and not feeling my body in the familiar detailed way—just a vague, ghostly outline of limbs I was fairly sure were mine.

“Hey,” a voice said, very close. “Easy. Don’t freak out.”

I opened my eyes—had I closed them?—and saw him.

He leaned against the shattered guardrail as if it were a bar counter, arms folded, ankle crossed over the other. The highway lamps painted him in sodium orange. He looked…wrong, the way a sharp note sounds wrong in a familiar song. His suit was black and perfectly cut, his tie loosened, his shirt collar open. Curved horns, ash-black with veins of ember red, swept back from his temples like polished obsidian. A scaled tail twitched lazily behind him. Two cut lines glowed faintly along his jaw, like cracks in cooled lava.

“Breathe,” he said. “Or, you know, pretend. It helps.”

I sucked in a breath and only then realized my chest wasn’t moving. The world around us was frozen: my car crumpled against the median, flakes of glass suspended mid-air, the other driver’s face twisted, unmoving. Sleet hung like glitter in front of the headlights.

“I’m dead,” I said.

“Yep.” He pushed off the rail. “Well. Mostly. We’re in the grace period. Paperwork window.”

“Paperwork.” I stared at him. “You’re a demon.”

He clutched his chest, feigning offense. “I am your GP.”

“General practitioner?”

“Guardian Presence,” he said. “But ‘guardian demon’ is what people tend to land on if they ever see me, so sure, let’s skip to the part where you’re horrified.”

“I thought those were angels,” I said weakly. “You know. Wings, halos, white robes, soft lighting.”

“Marketing,” he said. “Sit.”

There was nowhere to sit, so I sat on the air. To my surprise, it held.

He joined me, unconcerned about gravity. “Angels exist. They get the press. They handle big miracles, wars, plagues, that sort of thing. But you? You got assigned to my division at birth.”

“Demon Division,” I said.

“That’s not the official name,” he said. “But yes.”

“I don’t understand,” I said. “Why would a demon guard me? Your whole brand is…souls, torment, eternal screaming. Fire.”

“You’re stereotyping,” he said mildly. “And technically, I’m here for quality assurance.”

I stared.

He sighed. “Look. It used to be simple. Heaven, Hell, scales, scrolls, the whole theater production. But eons of bureaucracy happened. Turns out if you want people to have meaningful free will, you can’t just rely on vague conscience and intermittent lightning bolts. You need oversight. So each soul gets an assigned presence who: nudges, documents, and intervenes if upper management gets jumpy.”

“Upper management,” I repeated.

He gave me a look. “You think the Almighty reads every file? There are departments, Ethan. And sub-departments. Review boards. Appeals. So I’m your supervisor. Call me Corin.”

I swallowed. “Are you here to drag me to Hell?”

“Gods, no,” he said. “I’ve spent thirty-four of your years keeping you alive. I do not intend to hand you off to those clowns if I can help it.”

“Keeping me alive,” I echoed. “Wait, what do you mean?”

With a snap of his fingers, the night peeled open like a curtain. Scenes flared around us in translucent layers: my childhood bed; a playground; a stormy highway; a bottle of pills on a bathroom sink.

“Age five,” he said, pointing. A version of me reached up toward a pot of boiling water. A wooden spoon slipped. In the vision, the pot teetered.

“I nudged your dog to bark,” Corin said. “You startled, stepped back. Third-degree burns avoided. You cried anyway. You were dramatic.”

Another snap.

“Age seventeen. You and your friends, stolen vodka, that bridge. I whispered ‘jump’ as a joke. You thought it yourself, twice. Then I showed you an image of your mother getting the phone call. You stayed on the rail.”

“I thought that was just…conscience.”

“Sometimes it is,” he said. “Sometimes it’s me.”

The visions kept coming. Small adjustments, intangible shoves.

“You were always one of my high-maintenance cases,” Corin said cheerfully. “A lot of…potential.”

“For what?” I asked.

“For everything,” he said. “Which is why we’re having this conversation before anyone clocks your file as ‘available inventory.’”

I bristled. “Inventory?”

He studied me. His eyes, I noticed, were not the cartoon red I would have expected. They were dark, tired, threaded with a sardonic warmth. “Listen carefully. The system is…crowded. Heaven delegates. Hell recruits. The living generate enough noise to keep us all very busy. Souls like yours—the ones that never pinned down to one path, never fully sold themselves in any direction—are attractive. Malleable. We call you ‘balance cases.’”

“That sounds ominous.”

“It is,” he said. “Because both sides will argue they have the better claim.”

I looked down at the highway, at the halo of smashed glass where my chest had met the steering wheel. “So what now? A trial? A scale with my heart on it?”

“Too theatrical,” Corin said. “Also messy. No. Now I offer you a deal.”

I narrowed my eyes. “I’m supposed to never accept deals from demons.”

He flashed a quick, sharp grin. “Good instinct. Keep that. But this is less ‘sell your soul’ and more ‘administrative extension.’ I can contest your death.”

“You can what?”

“I can file for a Guardian Override,” he said. “Claim the incident as premature, argue that your arc is incomplete, push you back into the timeline. Paperwork, like I said. But it comes with conditions.”

My heartbeat, ghostly or not, stuttered. “I can go back? I thought once you’re dead, that’s it.”

He lifted one shoulder. “It’s meant to be rare. But you’re borderline. Car hit you quicker than your story anticipated. I can fix it. However—”

“There it is,” I muttered. “The however.”

“However,” he continued, “Overrides are expensive. Not in money.” He flicked a finger. “In authority. I’d be putting my name on you in ink, not pencil. That means: if I send you back, I’m not just your guardian. I’m your claimant.”

“That sounds a lot like ownership,” I said.

“It’s sponsorship,” Corin said. “Think: you’re on my team. It grants me leverage to shield you from other claims, upstairs and downstairs. But I’ll be honest—it draws attention. You’d be a human walking with an official demon sigil on your soul.”

“That’s supposed to be reassuring?”

“That’s me trying not to sugarcoat this,” he said. “You want a gentle harp intro, you should’ve swerved ten seconds earlier.”

“Why would you do this?” I asked. “Why care? You said you’ve spent years keeping me alive, but that’s your job.”

He hesitated.

The silence stretched, thick with frozen sleet and the faint hum of unmoving engines.

“Because,” he said finally, “we’re not what you were told. I’m a demon because I work in enforcement, in consequence, in shadows. I watch people want terrible things. I watch them choose. Most are predictable. You weren’t.”

“In what way?” My voice came out softer.

“You wanted to be good, but you never trusted goodness to be real,” he said. “You held yourself just outside. You didn’t lie much, but you rarely risked telling the whole truth either. You stopped your friend from driving drunk, but never told him why you cared so much. You donated, quietly, but never believed it mattered. Half-measures. Not evil. Not naive. Just…stalled.”

That stung because it was true.

“I thought that was a failure,” I said.

“It’s incomplete,” he said. “And I hate incomplete stories. Also—and this will never leave this suspended highway—it’s impressive you stayed as kind as you did without any proof it counted. That kind of stubborn decency? We don’t get a lot of that. I’d like to see what you do if you knew the game was real.”

“And in return,” I said, “I get to live.”

“In return,” Corin said, “you get one more run. You remember this. You remember me. Most people don’t. That’s part of the override: awareness. You’ll see me, sometimes. Hear me. You’ll know when I nudge you. But that also means if you veer hard into cruelty knowing I’m real, there won’t be excuses left.”

“Are you warning me?” I asked.

“Yes,” he said. “And I’m telling you something else: I am on your side. Not ‘humanity’s.’ Yours. I picked you. If anyone else comes knocking—wings or horns—you send them to me.”

The idea of walking through life with a demon as my…advocate was absurd. Terrifying. Weirdly comforting.

“What if I say no?” I asked.

“Then we let the system do its thing,” Corin said softly. “You move on. Review, placement. Maybe quiet. Maybe not. I won’t lie: it’s not torture for most people. That’s propaganda in both directions. But it is final. No more coffee. No more trying. No more chance to fix the things you wish you’d fixed.”

Images surged up, unbidden: my sister’s face the last time I’d bailed on her call; my half-finished apology email sitting in drafts; the old man in 4B I meant to help with his groceries and never did; the stupid fight with Dad about politics that had calcified into silence.

“Can I help people?” I asked. “If I go back. For real, not just as a concept. Change anything?”

“Yes,” Corin said. “Not everything. You’re still just you. But you’ll have clarity. And I’ll have your back. I can’t shove you through doors, but I can point. Loudly.”

“You’re not going to collect my soul, someday?”

“Oh, I fully intend to collect your soul,” he said. “I intend to have the satisfaction, at your next death, of presenting a file so annoyingly redeemed neither side knows what to do with you. Maybe we retire you. Maybe we let you judge us.”

“That’s allowed?”

He smirked. “Not officially. The best changes never are.”

I looked at my broken body below: the angle of my neck, the bloom of red on the airbag. A ribbon of smoke curled from the crumpled hood. Time waited, patient and merciless.

“Will it hurt?” I asked.

“Very much, for a bit,” he said. “Then less. Then you’ll forget how sharp it was. Humans are gifted that way.”

“And you’ll really be there?” I said. “Not just when I’m about to do something stupid?”

“Especially then,” he said. “But also when you’re about to do something brave and try to call it stupid.”

I exhaled.

“Okay,” I said. “Do it. Override. Claim me.”

He studied me as if memorizing my choice. Then he nodded, satisfied.

“Done,” he said.

He reached out. His hand was warm where it closed around mine, heat like a hearth, not a bonfire. The horns, the tail, the cracks of ember light—they should have terrified me. Instead, the last emotion that hit me before the world snapped back into motion was an odd, fierce sense of being…looked after.

Then gravity slammed back.

Glass fell. Metal shrieked. My lungs ignited. Sirens howled from far away.

Through the pain, through the blur, I saw him—just a flicker in the shattered side mirror. Leaning where he’d been, arms folded, watching.

“Easy,” Corin’s voice murmured in my head. “Breathe. We’ve got work to do.”

samples.prompt: A monster adapts to living with its human family.
samples.output:
The first week, he broke three chairs, six plates, and my brother’s arm.

We all decided that was an improvement.

Before that, he’d broken people we didn’t talk about, and doorways, and the sound of the night. He’d been a story before he was a houseguest: the Blackthing in the Wood, the Maw in the Marsh, the Something They’d Never Explain. Then Dad brought him home in the back of the truck, too big to fit under the tarp, his horns scraping sparks off the rusted metal frame.

“His name’s Harl,” Dad said, as if that made it better. As if a name could soften ten feet of bone and bristle, all teeth and charcoal hide.

Mom stared into the truck like she was searching for the man she’d married. “You brought it here.”

“Him,” Dad said. “He saved my life.”

My brother Evan, nine and fearless in the wrong ways, grinned through the bandage on his nose. “Cool.”

I was sixteen and terrified in the way that keeps your mouth shut. I stood on the porch, knuckles white on the railing, and watched the monster unfold itself from the truck bed.

He moved wrong for something that size—too careful. The boards didn’t crack under his weight, they complained. He had hands, five long crooked fingers on each, tipped with obsidian claws that could slice a car in half. He used them to grip the truck’s side and lower himself as gingerly as a man exiting a sedan.

He stank of wet earth and iron. One gleaming eye was milky, the other a coin-bright yellow that flicked from Dad to Mom to me.

“Harl,” Dad said, “this is my family.”

The monster considered us, nostrils flaring. His voice, when it came, was the sound of boulders adjusting in a landslide, but he tried to soften it.

“I will not eat them,” he said.

Mom exhaled. “It talks,” she whispered.

“It saved me,” Dad repeated, quiet. “Storm caught me in the ravine. I’d be gone if he hadn’t dug me out.”

Harl’s ears—or the bone ridges that passed for them—twitched. “We are… neighbors now,” he said. It sounded like a guess.

That first week, he tried to sit at the table.

“I should sit,” he insisted, folding his huge frame through our too-small back door with the tentative focus of someone defusing a bomb. His horns gouged the doorframe; chips of paint fluttered down like snow.

“We can get a bench,” Dad said. “A reinforced bench. Or—uh—you can sit on the floor, buddy. Whatever’s comfortable.”

Harl lowered himself onto the kitchen floor. The house shuddered.

The table still came up to his chest. He had to hunch to peer at the plates, one of which he shattered with a single misplaced claw. Everyone flinched at the crack, the shards jumping.

“Sorry,” Harl said immediately, and the word came out thick, dragged over unfamiliar vowels.

“It’s just a plate,” Mom lied. She liked those plates. Wedding gift. But she found another one, placed it carefully closer to him.

He watched her cook. His head followed every movement of knife, pan, steam, like a cat tracking a fly. When she set a pan of roast chicken on the table, his pupils slitted into fine threads.

I expected him to fall on it. To unhinge his jaws and swallow everything, and maybe a sibling for dessert.

Instead, he waited.

“Can I…” His tongue fumbled over the word. “Eat?”

“Yes,” Dad said. “Yes, Harl. Go ahead.”

He pinched a drumstick between thumb and forefinger. The leg vanished into his mouth. He chewed, very slowly. The sound was still wrong. Too many teeth. But he chewed, and swallowed, and exhaled through his nose like he was remembering how air worked.

“Good?” Evan asked.

Harl nodded, took another piece. My brother, showing off, grabbed one at the same time. Claw and small human hand collided, grease slicking his fingers. Harl froze.

“If I cut you,” he said, every muscle turned to stone, “I will eat myself as apology.”

Evan laughed. “Dude, what? I’m fine.”

I dropped my fork. “You will what?”

“That is… what is done.” Harl looked at Dad, seeking confirmation that this was the custom here, too. “To prevent… arguments.”
