Dad rubbed his face. “Let’s not eat anybody,” he said. “That’s the house rule. Okay? No eating.”

Harl blinked, processing.

“No eating,” he repeated carefully. “Yes. This will be… fine.”

The second week, Mom tried to make him a room.

“He can’t sleep in the truck,” she said. “The neighbors will call someone.”

“They already want to,” I said.

We’d seen them. Curtains twitching. Phones in hands. Harl stooped in our yard like a guilty shadow, doing his best imitation of invisible.

Mom didn’t look at me. “The barn, then. We can clear it out.”

She held a broom like a sword and marched out. Harl followed, steps sinking into the mud. He ducked his head to peer inside the barn. Old hay. Boxes. The smell of rust and old summers.

“I like the earth,” he offered. “Below.”

“And we like you not tunneling into the septic tank,” Mom said. “Barn it is.”

They worked together. Mom moved cardboard boxes; Harl lifted the old tractor like it was a toy and set it aside, careful not to crush it. I watched from the threshold. He caught me looking and tried a smile. Too many teeth. But they were closed, mostly.

“Hello, Emma,” he said, my name stretched out, precise.

“You remember my name,” I said before I could stop myself.

“Yes.” He looked proud. “Family.”

The word landed in my chest like a stone in a pond. The ripples took a while to hurt.

That night, he lay on a nest of quilts and hay that looked absurd under his massive frame. His tail, barbed and scarred, curled around him like a question mark. Mom had hung an old string of Christmas lights along the rafters, and they glowed faintly, reflecting off his scales, making him look softer than he was.

“Goodnight,” Mom said.

“Goodnight,” Harl rumbled. Then, uncertain: “Goodnight… Mom.”

She flinched. It was small, almost nothing. But he saw. His smile faltered.

“If that is not correct,” he said quickly, “I can say… other.”

“No,” she said gently, weary. “It’s okay. We’re all figuring it out.”

The third week, Harl discovered cartoons.

It happened because Evan was bored and fearless and dragged the monstrous bulk of him into the living room. The couch protested. The floor protested louder.

Harl crouched, claws on the carpet, staring at the TV like it might attack.

“It is a window?” he whispered.

“It’s a screen,” Evan said, flipping through channels until he found something with bright colors and loud voices. “They’re not real. It’s just pictures.”

Onscreen, a coyote chased a bird off a cliff and fell forty stories, accordioning at the bottom. Harl recoiled.

“He is broken,” he said.

“No, he’s fine. Watch.”

The coyote re-inflated. Chase resumed.

Harl stared. Then, for the first time, made a sound that might have been a laugh. A rusty, grinding thing, like boulders shifting into a waterfall.

“This is… cruel,” he observed.

“It’s funny,” Evan insisted.

He watched three hours without moving, except to occasionally cover his face when something exploded. His claws poked holes in the arm of the couch. Mom saw, opened her mouth to scold, then stopped at the sight of his hunched shoulders, the way he leaned toward the screen like a child at a puppet show.

“I will fix it,” he said, noticing the damage. “The couch. I fix what I break.”

“You don’t have to—” Mom began.

“Yes,” he said simply. “I do.”

He meant more than the couch, I think.

By the end of the month, routines had formed like scars.

- Harl rose before dawn, padded carefully through the yard to check the perimeter. This used to be hunting, I realized. Now it was… security.
- He brought in fallen branches, whole logs balanced on one shoulder, stacking them by the back door for firewood. “Winter is an ambush,” he told Dad. “You must prepare.”
- When the neighbor’s dog slipped its chain and ran yapping at Evan, Harl stepped between them, lowering his massive head. The dog skidded, peed, and retreated. Harl looked guilty. “I did not eat,” he reported solemnly.
- At night, after the news showed shaky phone videos of a “large unidentified creature” near Route 7 and a stern anchor talked about danger and containment, Harl sat very still in the barn, claws clenched in the quilts. “That is me,” he said once.
“I know,” I replied.
“They are afraid.”
“Yes,” I said again.
He was quiet. “I am trying,” he added, so softly I almost missed it.

One evening, about five weeks in, the inevitable happened.

The sheriff came.

Dad met him on the porch. I watched from the hall. Harl was in the barn, but his bulk was impossible to miss if you looked.

“Heard some reports,” Sheriff Marshall said, hat in hand but eyes sharp. “Big shadows. Scared folks.”

Dad’s jaw tightened. “We’re handling it.”

“You harboring something dangerous, Tom?”

A floorboard creaked behind me. Harl, silent and huge, trying to be part of the house. I pressed a hand back, and my palm hit scaled forearm. He froze under my fingers.

“He saved my life,” Dad said. “He hasn’t hurt anyone.”

“Yet,” the sheriff said.

Then the wind shifted. A scent of gun oil and old smoke sneaked past me. Harl inhaled, that bright gold eye blinking once.

In two steps he was beside me, folding himself down, making himself smaller, like that could make him less monstrous. He lifted his hands where the sheriff could see them. The claws trembled.

“I am not a ‘something,’” he said. Careful. Practiced. “I am Harl. I fix what I break.”

The sheriff’s hand twitched toward his holster. “Stay back.”

Harl stayed. He swallowed. The sound was audible.

“No eat,” he said. “House rule.”

Evan, the idiot, burst past me and threw his arms around Harl’s arm. His fingers barely met. “He’s family,” he told the sheriff. “He helps with chores.”

Sheriff Marshall stared at the boy, at the monster, at my mother appearing at Dad’s shoulder with her chin up and her hand openly resting on Harl’s scaled skin.

“Jesus,” he muttered. “Y’all are serious.”

“Yes,” Mom said.

Long silence. The setting sun painted Harl in golds and reds. He looked like something a story would kill.

Finally, Marshall sighed. “Keep him out of sight at night. No more farmers calling about demons in the bean fields.”

“We’ll try,” Dad said.

The sheriff left.

Harl didn’t move until the car’s taillights vanished. Then he slumped, exhaling so hard dust spiraled from the rafters.

“I did not roar,” he said, almost amazed. “Every part of me wanted. But I did not.”

“You did great,” I said, surprising myself.

His eye shone. “I am learning,” he said. “To live… like this.”

“Like family?” Evan asked.

Harl considered.

“Like… a good monster,” he decided. The phrase sat awkwardly in his mouth. He tried again. “Like yours.”

That night, I watched him curl up in the barn, under Christmas lights and quilt scraps, tail tucked in tight so it wouldn’t knock anything over. He whispered something into the straw, in a language older than our fences, then corrected himself, in ours.

“No eat,” he murmured. “No hunt near house. Fix what I break. Do not frighten small humans, even when they jump from roof. Remember Mom does not like entrails. Ask before sitting.”

Rules. Our rules. His rules, now.

Outside, the woods waited, dark and familiar. They had lost one monster to the yellow house with the peeling paint. Gained something else in exchange.

In the morning, there were neat stacks of firewood and a mended fence post where the boards had sagged. A huge claw print beside a smaller sneaker print. And on the porch, for Mom, a bouquet of wildflowers arranged in a rusty coffee can, stems tied clumsily with twine.

She touched them, smiled despite herself.

“He’s trying,” she said.

“Yes,” I answered. “So are we.”

samples.prompt: Every nameable emotion has a human manifestation. Without the human, the emotion would cease to exist. They live in our world and walk among us.
samples.output:
In the city where emotions wore skin, the rush hour crowd was more metaphysical than anyone suspected.

They commuted by subway and taxi and rideshare, they ordered espresso and oat milk lattes, they fought and forgave and filed taxes. They filled forms, fed cats, watered plants. They were, to most eyes, aggressively ordinary.

Only a few knew what they really were.

Mara did, though she wished she didn’t. She’d always seen through them, from childhood on—the way their colors leaked at the edges, the way certain people seemed to vibrate too intensely with a single hue. She’d point and say, “That woman is Sadness,” or “That man is Guilt,” and her mother would say gently, “Sweetheart, that woman is just tired,” and hope she’d grow out of it.

She had not grown out of it.

On Monday, at 8:17 a.m., Mara stood at the crosswalk and watched them congregate, the embodiments of everything unsayable and too-often said.

Joy arrived first, on roller skates.

He slalomed through the stalled line of pedestrians, neon headphones clamped over unruly curls, letting out apologies that sounded like laughter. His clothes looked thrifted in the way that actually meant carefully curated; his socks did not match; his eyes were full of after-parties and first kisses and perfectly timed punchlines. When he slid to a stop beside Mara, the sidewalk seemed to brighten half a shade, as if someone had bumped up the saturation in the world.

“Morning,” he beamed.

“Your laces are untied,” she said.

He glanced down, shrugged. “I prefer the risk.”

From the other side of the street, Fear watched Joy with sour disapproval, clutching a briefcase hard enough to leave impressions in the cheap leather. Fear wore a gray suit one size too big, like he’d borrowed a body and hadn’t grown into it yet. His eyes flicked from car to car, window to window, calculating every possible catastrophe: the bus might jump the curb, that cyclist might swerve, the scaffolding might collapse. He saw all their failures before they happened; it was his job.

“You’re late,” Fear murmured when the light remained stubbornly red.

“For what?” Joy asked.

“For everything,” Fear said.

Mara saw the little tremors in his hands. She resisted the urge to touch his sleeve. You weren’t supposed to comfort them. You weren’t supposed to interfere.

Yet.

Envy stepped from the subway grates in a swirl of green smoke only Mara seemed to notice. Today she wore a sharp emerald dress and sunglasses too large for her small face, scrolling other people’s vacations, other people’s engagements, other people’s promotions. She never looked up.

“She dyed her hair because you did,” Envy whispered to no one everyone. “He’s only happy because you’re not. They got what you deserved.” Nitpicking, needling. A perpetual commentary track.

Guilt trailed behind her.

He didn’t commute so much as haunt. A rumpled man in shirtsleeves, tie loosened to the point of strangulation, ink stains on his fingers like old blood. He walked with his shoulders rounded, a man who had never learned how to un-clench. Around him, the air thickened into memory. People near him remembered missed calls, harsh words, that time in college. He smelled faintly of rain on a day you should have gone to see your father.

“Hey,” Joy called, rolling backward, “you look like hell.”

Guilt managed a smile that didn’t touch his eyes. “I work nights.”

Anger was easy to spot. He was always cutting in line, always bumping shoulders, always simmering just beneath a boil. Today, he stood at the curb revving an invisible engine, jaw tight, listening for the slightest offense.

A man jostled him. “Sorry,” the man said.

“SURE YOU ARE,” Anger snapped, flaring, and for a moment heat radiated off him in waves, swallowing the man’s apology, amplifying it into a near-incident. Then Anger reined himself back, breathing hard. He was getting better. Therapy, maybe.

Mara looked away, gaze flitting to the edges of the crowd. Love, she spotted by the food truck, buying two coffees and hoping one would be the beginning of something real. Love’s hair changed color daily. Today it was the color of peach flesh near the pit.

Beside Love hovered Heartbreak, in yesterday’s eyeliner.

They shared a scarf, and perhaps that was the strangest thing about them: they were not opposites, but twins with different timing.

Hope arrived late, as always, out of breath, hands full of flyers printed on recycled paper about community gardens and language classes and petitions that might or might not matter. She waved at Mara; Mara waved back. Hope noticed everyone, was delighted easily and wounded deeply. Her shoes were always about to fall apart, but somehow they didn’t.

Despair sat on the bench nearby, smoking an unlit cigarette.

No one else saw the incomplete ember, the way his fingers trembled with effort not to light it. His hood shadowed half his face. People mistakenly thought he was Melancholy or maybe just Exhaustion. They didn’t see how heavy his coat was, how much it cost him to sit without leaning too far forward.

The light changed.

The herd stepped off the curb in unison. Cars grumbled. A cyclist cursed. A siren wailed somewhere in the near distance. The city breathed.

Mara crossed with the rest, passing through a tide of suppressed monologues. The world had no idea that its entire emotional vocabulary walked beside it, bound to them, dependent on them.

Because that was the rule: Every name birthed a being. Every being existed only as long as humans kept saying its name, kept feeling its shape.

It had been easier, once, when there were fewer words.

But language multiplied.

So did they.

At lunch, Mara ate in the park, picking at her salad while Anxiety fretted on the adjacent bench, leg bouncing at a frequency that rattled the pigeons.

“What if they find out?” Anxiety muttered, not to her, not to anyone in particular. “What if they realize none of this is organic, that we’re all just… beholden?”

“To what?” Mara asked, before she could stop herself.

Anxiety blinked, then focused on her. His irises were wide, murky, like storm clouds about to choose a direction. “To them,” he said. “To you.”

Mara stabbed a cherry tomato. “Most of them hardly notice themselves, much less you.”

“That’s the problem.” Anxiety wrung his hands. “Inattention breeds accidents.”

“Careful,” came a soft voice from Mara’s other side. Shame had arrived without footsteps. Shame never approached head-on; she slid in from the peripherals, wearing whatever people had told her was proper twenty years ago. “If she keeps acknowledging us, we’ll have to acknowledge her.”

“It’s rude not to,” Mara said. She was tired. She’d been tired since she first discovered that her imaginary friends weren’t imaginary, just incredibly busy.

Shame peered at her. “You talk to us like equals.”

“You’re not?” Mara asked.

Joy dropped onto the grass in front of them, fingers sticky with mango juice from some food truck experiment. “We’re better looking,” he said, grinning. “But no, not equals. We’re… derivatives.”

Guilt hovered behind him like a shadow. “Don’t say it like that.”

“It’s true,” Joy said. “We came after. We only exist because they needed words for what already swelled in their ribs. They name it and poof, we’ve got a LinkedIn.”

“Do you ever worry what happens if we stop?” Mara asked quietly.

The circle of them faltered.

Hope, who had been braiding clover crowns to leave on unfamiliar graves, looked up sharply. “They never stop,” she said. “Not all at once.”

Despair snorted. “They stop in pieces.”

In the distance, Mara could see newer shapes, glitching at their edges: FOMO with its camera permanently raised; Doomscrolling, tall and gaunt, eyes reflecting only screens; Schadenfreude, laughing a fraction too late at others’ mistakes. Some were still translucent, half-formed; others had arrived fully grown, already exhausted.

“They’re making too many of you,” Mara said. “How do you all fit?”

“We stack,” Envy said, sliding her sunglasses down her nose. “We nest inside each other. Haven’t you noticed? Guilt wears my perfume. Love drinks with Denial. Hope flirts with Delusion. They call it complexity.”

Fear checked his watch. “Board meeting,” he said. “Agenda: sustainability of our existence given lexical inflation.”

“Threat of obsolescence,” Guilt murmured.

“Consolidation proposals,” Ambition chimed in, appearing in an impeccable suit Mara hadn’t seen him arrive in. “We’re considering a merger between Mild Concern and Existential Dread.”

“Over my undead body,” Anxiety whispered.

They drifted away in ones and twos, called by unseen appointments—the courtroom where Justice would stand, tired but upright; the hospital where Grief sat at every bedside and Hope stubbornly hovered near every monitor; the schoolyard where Curiosity and Cruelty played a lopsided game of tag.

Mara watched them go.

Her phone buzzed: her boss, her mother, a notification reminding her to drink water and breathe, an invitation to yet another after-work thing she would attend and feel invisible at.

She closed her eyes.

Because here was the other secret: just as they depended on humans to exist, sometimes, in rare cases, one human could dismiss one of them. Not forever, not universally. But personally, locally. You could revoke your consent.

She had done it once, ten years ago, standing on a bridge at 3 a.m. with Despair’s arm familiar around her waist. She’d said his true name—no one’s language, all languages—and then, firmly: “Not for me.”

He had faded. Not disappeared. He still walked the wards, still sat in empty apartments. But not with her. Not like that.

It hadn’t made her happy, exactly.

It had made her possible.

Now, in the park, she sensed a presence settling beside her. Not heavy like Despair, not frenetic like Joy. Something quiet, patient.

Acceptance.

He wore a sweater that had seen better days and jeans with paint on them. He looked like every art teacher who’d ever said, “Let’s see what happens.” He didn’t speak.

Mara exhaled.

“I can’t carry all of you,” she said.

“You don’t have to,” Acceptance replied. “You just have to admit we’re already here.”

She opened her eyes. Around her, the beings moved through the city, linked hand-in-hand with hearts that didn’t recognize the grip. If every human vanished, the park would be empty: no Joy on the grass, no Fear beneath the trees, no Love on the bench, no Shame hiding behind the statue. The air would be clear, brutally uncolored.

Without us, they were nothing.

Without them, we were inarticulate.

Mara picked up her bag.

As she walked back into the noise and neon, they fell into step beside her: Joy juggling sunbeams, Fear checking the crosswalk signal twice, Hope pointing out a flier for a free concert, Guilt adjusting his tie, Acceptance steady as gravity.

They lived in our world and walked among us.

And for the first time that day, she let herself walk among them.

samples.prompt: The gods prove their existence when Zeus and Hera walk into a divorce lawyer's office.
samples.output:
Zeus and Hera walked into Rosen & Feldman, LLP at 2:17 on a Tuesday afternoon and proved, definitively, that the gods were real.

First came the smell: ozone and myrrh, like a thunderstorm crashing a funeral. Then the lights flickered, the wall clock spun three full rotations backward, and every phone in the office died mid-ring. Martha at reception opened her mouth to say “Welcome to Rosen &—” and instead dropped her peppermint, because her brain had to reroute capacity to accepting that the man in front of her was seven feet tall, broad as a refrigerator, and humming faintly with lightning.

He wore a navy suit that had absolutely not been made by any mortal tailor, an open white shirt with no tie, and a gold pin shaped like an eagle. His hair was black shot with stormcloud gray. His eyes were summer sky blue and wrong: too deep, too bright, like something that remembered watching continents rise.

The woman at his side was not less terrifying, only better dressed. A fitted white dress, severe and perfect. Gold cuffs, a string of pearls that glowed; not reflected light, but their own. Dark hair piled in a knot that no movement could dislodge. Eyes the color of old bronze, sharp with the anger of someone long past theatrics and now committed to logistics.

“Good afternoon,” Hera said, in an accent that sounded like history itself. “We have an appointment with Mr. Rosen. For a divorce.”

Zeus lifted a hand, and the overhead fluorescents stopped buzzing.

Martha checked the calendar, because that was what one did, even in the presence of myths. “Rosen has a three o’clock mediation and Feldman’s at court until—”

At which point both her computer monitors bloomed into full-color images of a thunderbolt and a peacock feather, flickered, and went dark.

From his glass-walled corner, Benjamin Rosen emerged, phone in hand, ready to ask why the building’s power grid had apparently decided to reenact a horror movie. He stopped. His phone slid from his fingers and hit the carpet.

“Oh,” he said.

“Yes,” Hera replied. “Shall we?”

They settled in his office. The air conditioner wheezed to a stop. Outside, the blur of city traffic became a hush, like the whole block was holding its breath.

Rosen closed the door carefully. “So. You’re… you are…”

“Zeus,” Zeus said. “King of the gods.” No trace of humility. Thunder rolled faintly.

“Hera. Queen of the gods,” Hera said, with the easy authority of someone who knew which title had really carried the administration.

“And you’d like to… dissolve the marriage,” Rosen managed.

“Annul it,” Hera said crisply. “On several grounds. Fraud, duress, centuries of bad faith. Though I’m prepared to negotiate the semantics.”

Zeus snorted. “Fraud? You knew exactly who I was.”

“I knew who you claimed to be,” she said. “I did not know you would turn seduction by deception into a lifestyle brand.”

Rosen had represented couples who hurled ashtrays at each other. He had navigated hedge-fund divorces that made wars look friendly. He had never, until this moment, contemplated the phrase seduction by deception as it applied to a man known for turning into swans. He reached for his legal pad like it was a life raft.

“Let’s, ah, start with goals,” he said, defaulting to script because script was safe. “What would a successful resolution look like for each of you?”

“I want out,” Hera said. “I want it recognized. No more… narrative obligations. No more ‘but you’re the divine couple, you must work it out.’ I want my own domains, my own temples, my own… branding.” The word sounded odd in her mouth, but she’d clearly been doing research. “Freedom from association. We apologize for the storm,” she added to Rosen, almost as an afterthought, as silver rain began tracing patterns down the window despite the cloudless sky.

“I want her to stay,” Zeus said. “We are not some influencer couple breaking up on camera. We are cosmic order. We are precedent. Besides,” he added, less kingly and more petulant, “I love you.”

The last part came out quiet enough that thunder didn’t punctuate it.

Her jaw tightened. “You love conquest. You love adoration. You love yourself. You confuse those for loving me.”

“Let’s keep this constructive,” Rosen said. If gods could walk into his office, then surely active listening still functioned in the universe. “Ms. Hera—”

“‘Lady Hera’ is acceptable,” she said. “Or ‘Your Majesty.’ But Hera will do.”

“Hera.” He swallowed. “We should address jurisdiction. Um. What court would… have authority here?”

Zeus waved a hand. A scroll appeared on Rosen’s desk, unrolling itself, written in shifting letters of fire and starlight.

“By decree of the Moirai,” Zeus said. “Should we seek to dissolve our union, we must submit to mortal law, which is… delightfully tedious, by the way. You’ve made an art form of pettiness.”

“Checks and balances,” Hera murmured. “Concept you never quite grasped.”

Rosen scanned the blazing text. Every bar association certificate on his wall vibrated in sympathy. The terms were clear enough: he had jurisdiction, granted by three beings who probably predated causality.

“I—okay,” he said. “Understood.”

Outside, someone tried to open the office door. It didn’t budge. Rosen’s receptionist’s voice came muffled: “We’re… closed for a moment.”

Hera folded her hands in her lap. A small, self-contained storm of grace. “Here is how this works, Mr. Rosen. For ages, mortals have made offerings to us. They’ve written our stories, miswritten others. They’ve kept us alive. For that, we have allowed a certain… ambiguity. Plausible deniability. Today, we correct that. An official filing. Public. You draft it. We sign it. The world sees. No more plausible deniability.”

Rosen blinked. “So this is… not just personal.”

“It is personal,” she said. “It is also structural. They created the myth of the perfect divine marriage. I played my role. I punished the women he pursued because the storytellers found it neater that way. I’m finished taking the blame for what he broke.”

Zeus stared at her. Some of the arrogance slipped, revealing something older and more tired. “We endured Titanomachy, Gigantomachy, Ragnarok rumors, monotheism. And this is what unravels it? A mortal with a legal pad?”

“Your grace,” Hera said, not looking at him, “unravels it.”

Rosen heard the crack in her voice that the thunder did not dare mock.

“Hera,” he said carefully, “are you seeking division of assets? Domains? Custody arrangements?”

Zeus bristled. “I will not have my children parceled like cattle.”

“They are not children,” Hera said. “They are powers. And they can choose.” She turned to Rosen. “I want dominion over marriages rescinded. I release it. Let mortals have it back. Let them own the sanctity or mess of their unions without my name as cudgel.”

Rosen, who had seen marriage used as a weapon one too many times, felt something unclench in his chest.

“And I claim new patronage,” Hera continued. “Of self-respect. Of leaving. Of the courage to say no to a god or man who believes himself entitled. Of contracts that can be broken when they were never made in good faith.”

The temperature in the room rose, not with heat, but with clarity.

Zeus opened his hands. Sparks leapt between his fingers. “And me? You would strip me of my queen, my—our—story?”

“You may keep the sky,” Hera said, “and your lightning, and your sycophants. You may keep your image in the minds of those who like their gods loud and unaccountable. I will not stand beside you as endorsement.”

Rosen’s pen moved of its own accord now; or perhaps the Fates nudged it. Filing language formed in his tidy, earthly handwriting: dissolution, equitable separation, acknowledgment of divine autonomy.

He cleared his throat. “You realize that once this goes public, belief systems—”

“Will adjust,” Hera said. “They always do. They adjusted to you, didn’t they? To your laws, your papers, your insistence that what is written holds. I like that about you.” She caught Rosen’s startled glance. “Mortals, I mean. You learned to write things down and hold yourselves to them. Sometimes.”

Zeus looked, for a heartbeat, not like a god, but like a man who had just been served. “What if I change?” he asked.

Hera finally looked at him full-on. “You have had epochs.”

“I can be better,” he said, and the thing about gods is that when they lie, worlds tremble. The building did not move. The thunder did not answer.

She saw that too. “I believe you mean that,” she said softly. “Today. For the length of this conversation. For perhaps a decade. Then there will be another girl with storm-colored hair and you will forget. I am tired of being something you stop forgetting only long enough to swear you never will again.”

Silence.

Rosen put the pen down. “If you’re both prepared to proceed, I can draft a preliminary agreement. You’d each have the opportunity to—”

Hera reached, and the draft was already there, a sheaf of paper on his desk, words glowing faintly before settling into black ink. He recognized his own signature at the bottom, dated ten minutes from now.

“We are not bound by linear time,” she said. “But we respect your processes.”

Zeus stared at the pages. “If I refuse?”

“Then you stand alone against the Moirai, the new order, and me,” Hera said. “And you know what happens to gods who cling to dead stories.”

They held each other’s gaze for a long, terrible moment.

Outside, a cloud formed out of blue sky and hovered directly above the building. People on the street stopped, pointed their phones. Inside, Rosen watched the world pivot.

Finally, Zeus exhaled. The light dimmed. He took the pen. His hand shook once, like an earthquake deep underground, and then he signed.

The storm outside broke—not into fury, but into a clean, soft rain that fell only on this block.

Hera placed her hand gently on the agreement. The peacock feather seal bloomed in iridescent color.

“It is done,” she said. She stood. “Thank you, Mr. Rosen. Your bill will be paid in full. Check your student loans.”

Rosen’s phone buzzed back to life. So did the lights, the computers, the world.

“Wait,” he said. “How will this… come out?”

Zeus and Hera both looked toward the window, where a dozen live streams were already broadcasting the miraculous localized rain, the strange lights, the moment two impossible figures would soon step into view.

“With excellent publicity,” Hera said. “At last, a true story.”

They walked out together, not touching.

When the door closed behind them, every device in the office chimed at once: push alerts, breaking news, videos that showed faces too bright to look at.

Benjamin Rosen sat down, heart pounding, as humanity’s notifications filled with proof.

The gods were real.

And one of them had finally, gloriously, filed for divorce.

samples.prompt: You've been working with the most interesting guy for years. He goes on trips all the time bringing back souvenirs from all over the world. One day you happen to see him in a thrift store buying souvenirs "from his next big trip"and realize his whole persona has been made up.
samples.output:
The first thing I notice is the snow globe.

It’s wedged between a cracked lava lamp and a bin of tangled phone chargers, its glass dome clouded, the glitter inside clumped like ash. But even under the bad fluorescent lighting, the little Eiffel Tower is unmistakable. I know it because I’ve seen it before—on the edge of a monitor in the office, turning slowly under the current of the air conditioner, scattering light like tiny, suspended fireworks.

“From Paris,” he’d said. “Back before they ruined the observation deck with all the security fences. You ever had proper onion soup? Transcendent.”

I look away from the shelf, certain I’m mistaken, and that’s when I see him. Three aisles over, in the Travel & Knickknacks section, holding a miniature boomerang.

He tosses it experimentally in his hand, feeling for weight and balance, as if he’s about to demonstrate its perfect return. But there’s no swagger in his posture today. He’s in a nondescript gray hoodie instead of his usual linen shirts or soft, foreign-looking blazers. No jaunty scarf that he claims to have bartered for in a Moroccan souk. Just jeans. Sneakers. No stories.

“From my next big trip,” he says, half to himself, half to the woman stocking a cart beside him. He smiles, that familiar crooked grin, but she doesn’t look up.

I freeze, my hand still resting near the snow globe.

From my next big trip.

The phrase hits me in a strange echo: He always talks that way at work. “Wait till you see what I bring back from Patagonia.” “Next month: Kyoto. I’ll get you a proper tea set.” I’ve joked that he’s a one-man import-export of tchotchkes and legends.

The first week I joined the company, he strolled in late on a Monday with a strand of wooden beads looped around his wrist. “From Varanasi,” he said, dropping a paper-wrapped packet on my desk. “Masala from this tiny stall by the Ganges. Careful, it’s the real stuff.”

He didn’t smell like airports. He smelled faintly of sandalwood and citrus, maybe cologne, maybe something else. Everyone clustered around his desk when he got back from trips to hear the stories: motorbikes in Ho Chi Minh City, midnight trains in Eastern Europe, an earthquake he just missed by a day.

I learned his cadence: a small detail, a sensory hook, then a modest deflection when anyone called him fearless or lucky.

“Just curious,” he’d say. “World’s too big to sit still.”

For years, I believed him.

Now I watch him pick up a ceramic camel painted a tired turquoise. There’s a chipped tag on it that says “Made in China.” He doesn’t look at the tag. He turns the camel over in his hand with the same careful appreciation he used when he presented a similar camel on Harriet’s birthday, saying, “From a roadside stall outside Marrakech. The guy tried to overcharge me, but we ended up drinking tea for an hour.”

He wraps the thrift-store camel in newspaper and places it gently in a plastic basket already half full:

- A wooden mask I’ve seen hanging behind his chair, supposedly from Ghana.
- Shot glasses printed with skylines: Tokyo, Berlin, Rio.
- Two snow globes—one with the Eiffel Tower, one with the Statue of Liberty.
- A woven bracelet that looks exactly like the one he told Carol a little girl in Guatemala tied around his wrist “for luck.”

There’s a small sour taste at the back of my throat.

I should leave. I should make some noise so he knows he’s seen, so we can both laugh and he can explain. Maybe he’ll say: Oh, that old stuff? Props for a friend’s video. Or: Research for a client’s campaign. You know how marketing is.

Instead, I duck behind a rack of winter coats that smell like old perfume and dust.

The cashier’s radio mutters a song from ten years ago. A couple argues softly over a chipped vase. A kid is crying near the shoes.

And he—our office Marco Polo, storyteller-in-residence—drifts along the aisle, humming. He picks up a sun-faded postcard of the Sydney Opera House, squints, nods, adds it to the basket. He moves with the certainty of a man following a list.

My thoughts start arranging themselves around one hard, ungenerous word:

Fake.

Then they rearrange into something more complicated.

I think of Friday afternoons, when people would lean against his cubicle, and he’d balance a mug in his palm and say, “In Tallinn, the winter light’s like this—soft, silver, makes the cobblestones look painted.” I remember how the office went quiet, just for a second, as if we were all somewhere else together.

I remember the small gifts:

- A keychain shaped like a panda for Eric’s kid, “from Chengdu.”
- The hand-painted dish with blue swirls he gave me after my promotion. “Found in a market in Lisbon. Thought you’d like it.”

I did like it. It sits by my sink holding my rings; I’ve told people it’s from Lisbon, as if some of that wanderlust had brushed off on me.

The world shifts a degree as I watch him lift a gaudy fridge magnet: “Greetings from Rome!” He smiles softly and slips it into the basket like it’s fragile.

I step out from behind the coats.

“Hey,” I say.

He startles. The camel nearly slips from his hand.

“Oh,” he says. “Hey. You… shop here too?”

It’s such a normal question, so painfully ordinary coming from him, that for a moment I consider lying. But I just nod.

“Sometimes,” I say. “You?”

He glances at the basket, then at me. There’s a flicker of calculation in his eyes, quickly smoothed over.

“Just picking up some things,” he says lightly. “Props. For a—project.”

We both look at the Eiffel Tower snow globe.

“Paris again?” I ask.

If he’s going to lie, this is his moment. He could reclaim the narrative with a joke, a wink, a new story. I wait for it: the easy charm, the quick step sideways.

It doesn’t come.

His shoulders lower, almost imperceptibly.

“Yeah,” he says. Then, quieter: “Not exactly.”

The radio hisses between stations, finds a beat, loses it.

I gesture toward his basket. “Those for your next big trip?”

The sentence hangs there, unmistakable. He hears it. His jaw tightens. For a long moment, I think he’ll keep pretending, double down, make me feel like I’ve imagined it all.

Instead, he exhales. It’s a tired sound.

“My car’s outside,” he says. “You want to… I can explain better not standing under a flickering exit sign.”

He pays in cash. He doesn’t ask for a bag; he brings his own canvas tote, worn at the corners, like something that’s been through airports.

Outside, the late afternoon is an anemic gray. The parking lot is patched and cracked, oil rainbows spreading in shallow puddles. His car is not the rugged, mud-splattered Jeep I pictured, but a sensible sedan with a missing hubcap.

He opens the trunk.

It’s full of souvenirs.

Not just today’s haul. Layers of them. Snow globes, masks, scarves with price tags that say $3.99, stacks of postcards bundled with rubber bands. A plastic leaning tower of Pisa lies on its side, next to a mug that reads “I ❤️ NY,” logo faded.

He looks at them, then at me.

“So,” I say, because someone has to.

“So,” he echoes. He closes the trunk more gently than it deserves. “I never thought anyone from work came to this side of town.”

There’s no arrogance in it. Just fact. The thrift store is off a forgotten stretch of road, between a closed-down laundromat and a tire place.

“How long?” I ask.

He runs a hand through his hair. Without his curated clothes, without his stories as armor, he looks… ordinary. Tired, in that specific way people who are always entertaining look when no one’s watching.

“Since before I started there,” he says. “I had one real trip. One. I scraped for years, saved every spare cent, went to Barcelona for eight days. I thought it would change everything, you know? That stupid, cinematic expectation. Like you go somewhere with beautiful architecture and you come back a different person.”

“Did it?” I ask.

“Yes and no,” he says. “I came back broke and in debt and still me. But people at my old job wouldn’t stop asking about it. They leaned in for the stories. They listened. I’d never had that before.” He gives a half-laugh, bitter at the edges. “I was… interesting.”

“And the souvenirs?” I prompt.

“I didn’t buy many there. Couldn’t afford it. I realized later I could pick them up here. There’s always this stuff in thrift shops. People’s trips, discarded. I started filling in gaps. If they asked, ‘Have you been to London?’ I’d say, ‘Sure,’ and I’d put a London mug on my desk. Then it just… grew. Every time I thought, I’ll be able to afford to go soon, I’d get passed over for a raise, or rent would go up. So I kept the stories instead.”

He looks at me, searching my face for disgust or pity.

“You could’ve just been you,” I say, and I hear how hollow it sounds. We both work in an office where people measure themselves by the stamps in their passports and the novels on their nightstands and the obscure craft beers they can name. The quiet ones vanish.

He shrugs. “I tried that once. No one gathered around my desk to hear about me microwaving leftovers.”

There it is. Simple. True.

“You never went to Varanasi,” I say.

He shakes his head.

“Or Kyoto.”

“No.”

“Or Marrakech.”

“No,” he repeats, softer.

“And the dish you gave me?”

He winces. “Came with a set of three. Ninety-nine cents.”

A gust of cold air scrapes across the lot. For a moment I’m standing in two realities at once: one where he’s heroic and worldly, and one where he’s a man with a trunk full of other people’s cast-off adventures, trying to build a self out of them.

“How much of it was made up?” I ask.

“The feelings weren’t,” he says quickly. “I read. I watched. I talked to people who had been there. I know what a street in Hanoi sounds like, even if I haven’t stood there. But, yeah. The rest.” He tries on a smile, then drops it. “You going to tell them?”

The question settles between us. I think of Harriet’s camel, Eric’s panda keychain, my dish by the sink. The Friday gatherings. The way we orbited his desk, letting his stories stitch a window in our beige cubicle walls.

“I don’t know,” I say honestly.

He nods. “Fair.”

We stand there a while. He doesn’t spin a redemption narrative. I don’t offer absolution. Cars pull in and out; a bus sighs to a stop down the street.

Finally, I say, “You know, it’s not the souvenirs that made you interesting.”

He huffs. “Try telling that to everyone inside.”

“I might,” I say. “Or I might tell them you’re taking some time off, finally checking if Barcelona was a fluke.”

Something flares in his expression—hope, or shame, or both.

“I can’t afford—”

“You can’t afford not to,” I say, surprising myself. “Maybe just one real place. No stories ahead of time. No props. Just you.”

He laughs, short and sharp. “And if I come back and I’m boring?”

“You’ve been fake for years and somehow made our days better,” I say. “Maybe being real is the most interesting thing left.”

He looks at the thrift store, then the trunk, then me.

“I don’t know how to start,” he admits.

“You already did,” I say. “You said ‘no’ three times.”

He closes the trunk, this time with a sense of finality.

“Okay,” he says. “Okay.”

We walk back toward the store in an awkward tandem, not quite side by side. He pauses at the door, glances back at his car.

“Want to help me put some of this back?” he asks.

“Only if you tell me what Barcelona was actually like,” I say.

He smiles then—small, uncertain, without performance.

“I can do that,” he says.

And for the first time in years, I’m interested in him for a story that might finally be true.

samples.prompt: Unfortunately your younger brother broke your telescope before the super moon eclipsed. However, it didn’t matter. As you recalled to another survivor “ The tide swallowed my house before it would have mattered”. That was months ago now...
samples.output:
Unfortunately my younger brother broke my telescope before the super moon eclipsed.

We’d been counting down for weeks. The news had called it a once-in-a-lifetime alignment, the kind of thing that made people buy cheap tripods and post grainy photos with captions about feeling small. I’d been more excited than I let on. I’d polished the eyepiece with an old T-shirt, marked the time in three different apps, printed a star chart I didn’t really need.

Then he knocked the tripod with his elbow.

There was a crack, a short, ugly sound like something cheap giving up, and the tube pitched forward. The lens struck the balcony railing, spiderwebbing instantly. Bits of glass caught the last of the afternoon light like they were still trying to be stars.

“What did you do?” I’d shouted.

He started apologizing, babbling about how he didn’t see it, how it was an accident. He was shaking. He was thirteen. I knew that if I kept going, I’d say something I couldn’t take back. So I didn’t. I picked up the broken pieces and said it was just a thing.

“It’s okay,” I told him. “We’ll watch with our eyes.”

A few hours later, the tide took the house.

When I say that to people now, they think I mean flooding, the familiar, miserable kind that soaks carpets and swells the doors. They imagine sandbags and sirens and rubber boots. But that’s not what happened.

I was sitting by the window when the water rose. The moon hung swollen over the horizon, so bright it looked like it might be close enough to touch. The eclipse had just begun, the first bite missing from its edge.

Then the ocean stood up.

The tide didn’t roll or slap or crash. It climbed. It rose in the kind of quiet that made my teeth hurt. One moment the shoreline was where it had always been; the next, the water was swallowing the dunes, sliding around the stilts of the houses, reaching for us, inexorable and smooth.

I remember the smell before anything else: not the usual salt and kelp, but something raw and deep, a mineral cold that tasted like metal on my tongue. I remember my brother’s hand tightening around my wrist as the living room window went dark, as if the sun had set directly against the glass.

“Up,” I said, dragging him toward the attic hatch.

The water didn’t crash through in splinters and roar. It pressed. It bowed the glass, pushed tiny silver lines through the drywall. The house shuddered like it was breathing wrong.

“It can’t come this high,” my brother whispered, because that’s what they’d always said.

We’d seen projections of future sea levels, polite blue shading on maps. No one had drawn a line over our roof.

“It shouldn’t,” I said.

But the ocean didn’t care.

We clawed our way to the attic as the floor below us groaned. The sound of the house was worse than the water: the nails squealing loose, the beams cracking, the refrigerator downstairs upending with a hollow crash. My brother scrambled ahead of me, swung himself into the low, dusty space beneath the rafters. I pushed him up, then tried to follow.

The house moved.

I’ve tried to explain this part. Even now, months later, sitting across a fire from another survivor, I can hear how it sounds.

“It’s like the world exhaled,” I told her. “And we weren’t attached to it anymore.”

She has a scar across her left cheek, the kind you get from flying glass or flying ground. Her name is Mina. She listens without interrupting, because we’ve both learned not to laugh at implausible things.

“It didn’t matter that he broke the telescope,” I say. “The tide swallowed my house before it would have mattered.”

She nods once, slow. “I get it.”

The attic tilted, pitching us sideways. A beam snapped; daylight knifed in where it shouldn’t be. I could see the moon through that sudden wound in the roof—huge, wrong, its bright edge slipping into shadow. The eclipse was already underway, a dark red bite spreading.

Water burst through with it. Not a spray, not a leak: a hand. It slammed me against the rafters, stole the air from my lungs. I remember my brother screaming my name, his voice thin and high and shredded by the thunder of pressure and breaking wood.

After that, I remember almost nothing.

I woke in a tree.

The first breath felt stolen. My chest burned. My ears rang with a frequency that made the world seem underwater even when it wasn’t. I was wrapped in something rough, my fingers clamped numb-tight around bark slick with algae and silt.

Below me, the world was gone.

There was water to every side, black and matte, swallowing roofs, treetops, streetlights. A refrigerator bobbed past like a toy. A car door. A child’s pink sandal. The air stank of gas, mud, and something sweet and wrong.

Above, the sky was bruised. The moon was fully eclipsed, a dark red coin staring down. It looked too close, too heavy, like it was bending the air.

“Eli!” I croaked.

No answer. Just the creak of my tree as it shifted in the unnatural current.

I don’t know how long I called for him. Long enough for my voice to shred. Long enough to understand the house was not coming back. Long enough to see the impossible pattern: how the water rose highest directly beneath that reddened moon, how it heaved and pulled like a thing taking commands.

Later, the scientists on the solar-powered radio would talk about resonance and orbital perturbations and hidden instabilities. They would use phrases like “multi-body interaction” and “unprecedented amplification.” They would not say the words we all thought: that the moon had swallowed something, or that the sky had slipped.

All I knew in that tree, shivering and soaked, was that the tide had ripped the world open and I’d lost my brother in the tearing.

Months later, I tell Mina the short version.

“We were on the second floor when it started. Tried to get to the attic. The house broke. I got thrown. Woke up in a tree a mile inland. Eli didn’t make it.”

I keep my voice flat. It’s easier that way. The fire pops between us, sparks spitting up into the thick, smoky dark. We’re camped on a tilted overpass with a dozen others, our tents flapping gently in the wind that smells like low tide and rust.

Mina watches me for a beat longer than is comfortable. “You don’t know that,” she says quietly.

“He was thirteen,” I say. “He couldn’t swim that.”

“Neither could half of us,” she says. “But we did.”

Hope is a dangerous thing now. It cuts both ways. There are people who swear they’ve seen their lost ones on far-off ridges, on the decks of scavenged boats, in the broken windows of drowned towers. Maybe some of them are right. Maybe most of them are the brain reaching for a shape in the chaos.

“Even if he survived,” I say, “he’s out there with that.”

I tilt my chin toward the horizon. In the distance, the sea heaves, rising in a slow, unnatural bulge that ripples down the shoreline like something breathing. The moon hangs fattish above it, no longer eclipsed but still wrong—closer, maybe, or just heavier in the mind.

The super moon comes more often now, they say. Not in press releases and excited segments with animations, but in the way the tides misbehave, in the geometry of wreckage. The old calendars don’t apply. People carry their lives in waterproof backpacks. We sleep with our boots on. No one sets telescopes on balconies anymore. We watch the sky with naked eyes and flinching shoulders.

“I used to think,” I say slowly, surprising myself, “that if I’d had the telescope, I’d have seen something. Some sign before it happened. A shimmer, a… I don’t know. The edges not lining up.”

Mina snorts softly. “And done what? Called the moon’s manager?”

Her sarcasm is gentle. It lands like a hand on my shoulder.

“It broke before the eclipse,” I say again, hearing the ritual in it. “I hated him for that. For, like, an hour. Then the tide came. And it turned out the last stupid thing I ever yelled at him was about glass and stars.”

“Then remember that,” she says. “Not the water.”

I don’t tell her I remember both.

I remember Eli’s face, open and stricken over the shattered lens. I remember the way he’d said, “We can still look up,” like the sky was something that would always be there, stable and patient and waiting.

Now the sky pulls at us. The moon scratches its influence across whole coastlines. The tides come without warning and sometimes do not go all the way back.

Still, on relatively calm nights, people gather.

They climb the broken steps of stadiums, the roofs of flooded malls, the high bones of old highways. They share dented binoculars and salt-streaked field glasses. They point out constellations swallowed by the brightness, invent new ones around missing stars. They tell each other stories of how it was before and what they think it means now.

Sometimes I sit among them. I tip my head back and look up with nothing but my eyes.

I think about my brother’s small hands on the telescope, careful and clumsy. I think about how furious I’d been at him over a broken circle of glass while invisible forces coiled around our world.

The tide swallowed my house. The super moon tore the map. But as wrong as everything is, as dangerous and tilted as the future feels, we are still here, watching the sky.

The irony is not lost on me.

In the end, it didn’t matter that he broke the telescope.

In the end, all that mattered was that, just before the world came apart, he believed the sky would always be something we could share.

samples.prompt: You have always felt like your body doesn't belong to you, one day you wake up and can't control your body as it starts walking towards a pen and some paper and then starts writing.
samples.output:
When I wake, it’s like surfacing through concrete.

No drift of dreams, no fuzzy border between sleeping and not. One instant I’m nowhere, the next I’m pinned hard into my own body, like someone poured me into a mold half a size too small. My lungs drag in a breath that rasps my throat, my eyes crack open without my say-so, and the first thing I feel is not the sunlight or the cold morning air, but resistance.

I try to roll over. My limbs do not move.

Instead, my body sits up.

The motion is smooth, practiced, entirely wrong.

Panic should spike, but even that feels distant. My heart doesn’t race. My breathing doesn’t hitch. I’m on the inside screaming, but on the outside I’m... calm. Mechanical. My hands push off the mattress. My bare feet find the floorboards with the quiet certainty of a person who has lived here for years—which I have—but it hits me that I’m not the one placing them.

I’ve always felt strange about this body. That used to be a metaphor: teenage dysphoria and dissociation, standing in front of the mirror and thinking, That’s not me, that’s a costume. Watching my own hand lift a fork, type a word, lift in an awkward wave, and feeling a split-second lag, like I was remote-controlling myself over a bad connection.

But this is different. This is no connection at all.

“Stop,” I try to say, or think I do, but my mouth doesn’t open. My tongue lies heavy and obedient behind closed lips.

I watch from somewhere back behind my eyes as my left hand flexes, testing each finger with clinical curiosity. My right hand lifts, rubbing the heel of my palm over my sternum once, twice, as though reassuring itself that this cage of ribs is solid.

Then we stand.

We—no, not we. It. The body that is mine but not mine.

The floor is cold under our feet as it walks, unhurried, out of the bedroom. The apartment is dull and familiar: the leaning bookcases, the dirty mug on the coffee table, the spider plant I keep forgetting to water. A half-finished sketch lies on my desk. We ignore all of it.

We move straight to the small desk under the window, where the cheap ballpoint pens live in a mug that says WORLD’S OKAYEST HUMAN. My hand reaches. I feel the faint drag of cardboard against my fingertips as we pick up the topmost notebook. The spiral digs into the heel of our palm.

“What are you doing?” I think, or try to think at it, like pushing words against a closed door.

If there’s an answer, it’s not in words. It’s a pressure, a sense. A patient, irritated sigh from something that has been waiting too long.

We sit. The chair creaks the way it always does under my weight. My body uncaps the pen with a pop. The smell of cheap ink tickles my nose.

My hand hovers, then begins to write.

The pen scratches, urgent and steady. I read as the words appear in my own handwriting—except the letters are tidier than mine, more deliberate, each stroke etched as if into stone.

I have been waiting for you to be quiet.

My first wild thought is that I’m writing to myself. Another part of me snaps: No, you’re the one waiting. You’re the one being quieted.

The lines keep coming, the pen moving faster.

You do not know me, but you live in what is mine.

No. No, that’s backwards. The pen ignores me.

You have called it not-belonging. You have called it dissociation. You have called it discomfort, dysphoria, wrongness. You were not wrong. You only misunderstood direction.

My fingers tighten; the knuckles pale. It hurts, the way pressing into a bruise hurts. I flinch inwardly. The body does not.

“Stop,” I think again, harder. “Stop, I don’t want this.”

The pen only presses more firmly, carving letters.

You woke into my flesh, and I woke into absence. You have been driving my bones badly for years.

I think of all the times I have looked down at my hands and thought, These aren’t right. Too broad, too narrow, wrong angles, wrong skin. The times I have flinched at my own reflection, felt like a ghost riding a stranger.

“What are you?” I ask, and this time the question feels like it hits.

The writing stumbles for half a heartbeat. Then:

I am the one this body was grown for.

A laugh would have escaped me, hysterical, if I’d had control of my lungs.

“Then where have you been?” I demand. “I’ve been here. I’ve done everything.”

Ink answers.

Asleep. Locked. Pushed aside. You never meant harm. You clung to existence. I clung to silence. But something broke last night.

Images swarm me, not mine. A hospital room, fluorescent-white and sharp. A fetal monitor’s slow beep. Hands gloved and bloody lifting a slick, purple infant, a nurse’s distracted “Oh,” the doctor’s frown—gone in an instant, replaced by reassurance. Later, a clipboard and a signature. Later still, a child staring at their body in confusion.

“These aren’t my memories,” I think, revolted by the visceral taste of antiseptic and latex.

They are mine, the pen writes. You are reading over my shoulder.

I try to pull away, to retreat deeper into whatever cramped mental attic I’ve been shoved into, but there is nowhere else to go. It’s both of us inside this skull, and now there’s no cushioning fog between.

“I’ve always been here,” I argue. “You can’t just decide I’m an intruder.”

You arrived first, it writes. I arrived rightful. You were early.

The words blur. “Early?” The concept lands with a sick, surreal clarity. “Like—wrong soul, wrong time? Bureaucratic mistake?”

The pen pauses, then writes slowly, as if choosing each word:

Like a key turning before the lock is finished.

I want to tell it that’s nonsense, but nonsense doesn’t explain how I’ve spent years treating this body like a rented room I couldn’t rearrange. Nonsense doesn’t walk me calmly to a desk I wasn’t thinking about.

“It doesn’t matter,” I say. “Even if you were ‘rightful,’ I’ve lived this life. I’ve gone to school. I’ve had friends. I’ve had nightmares in this skin, and mornings, and moments that were—mine.”

Our hand rubs at our temple. The body sighs, and for a second the sound is achingly familiar, exactly the way I sigh when the world is too bright.

The pen writes:

I know.

There is a tremor now in the strokes.

I tried to wake you, gently. To share. You felt me as wrongness. You hated my shape, my voice, my hunger. You called it all your own discomfort.

My discomfort, I shoot back.

Ours, the pen corrects. But you did not know we were two.

“So what now?” I ask. Fear begins to take real shape, thick and animal. “You lock me in the basement and live my life? Take my job, my friends, my... everything? I’ll be a passenger?”

The body’s shoulders tighten. Our jaw clenches—my gesture, not theirs, but they’re the one performing it now. The pen hovers in a small, uncertain circle.

I could, it writes.

There is no apology in the words, only statement.

Rage flares hot. “Try it,” I think. “Try living with my memories crashing into yours. With my name on every piece of paper. With my face already wrong to me before you even spoke.”

Our hand shakes once, then stills.

We do not have to be enemies, it writes.

I almost choke on the idea. “You hijacked me.”

I reclaimed, it counters. And you would have done the same.

Silence, except for the pen’s faint scratch as it taps a dot of ink into the paper. The morning traffic hums outside the window. A bird screams from the gutter.

“You woke up,” I say slowly. “Why now?”

Because you finally admitted you wanted out.

A memory: last night, lying awake, staring at the ceiling, thinking with a clarity that hurt, I don’t want this body. I don’t want this life like this. I wish someone would take it from me. I wish I could just be a ghost.

I hadn’t meant it. Or I had, but not like this.

“So I set you free?” I ask.

You unlocked my door when you abandoned the lock.

It’s unfair. It’s poetic. It’s infuriating that it feels true.

“Okay,” I say, if thought can be called speech. “If you’re staying—if we’re both staying—what happens?”

The body exhales, our ribs expanding. This time I feel a hint of my own influence in it, a shared motion.

We learn to steer together, it writes. Or one of us fades.

We both look at those last words. They sit there, cold and heavy.

“I don’t want to fade,” I whisper inside.

Neither do I, it answers without the pen.

The realization is quiet and devastating: this body was never empty. I was never alone in my alienation. The wrongness wasn’t a glitch in me, or solely in flesh; it was friction between two occupants pressing against the same bones.

The pen touches paper again.

You have always felt this body does not belong to you, it writes, slower, gentler. Because it did not belong only to you.

“Can we... share?” I ask, hating how hopeful it sounds.

For the first time, our lips actually move, shaping breath into a sound I can feel from both sides.

“Try,” we say.

samples.prompt: Write a story set in our present time. Except make it seem like an unusually prophetic piece of dystopian science-fiction written sometime in the 1970's or earlier. With "world building"descriptions of our society and technology.
samples.output:
On clear days, when the air over the city screens shimmered only slightly, you could still see the bones of the old world.

From the observation deck of the transit tower, Henry watched the drones thread silently between glass steeples, each machine no bigger than a gull, bearing parcels, pills, and hot meals in insulated bellies. Their wings blinked heat and company logos. Nobody looked up at them anymore. They were like weather: part of the sky.

Only on clear days, of course. Most days the city wore its gray halo— exhaust from the subterranean freight lines that emptied at the rivers, heat-bleed from the server canyons, and the endless mist crusted with micro-particulates that settled into lungs and air filters as an accepted tax on what people called “the convenience age.”

The word “age” implied something temporary. Henry thought they were past that.

He checked his palm screen: a rectangle of black glass that flared to life with his fingerprint. The device had more calculating power than those whole rooms of humming machines they wrote about in late-60’s popular science magazines. Now it was just a pocket oracle, one of billions, endlessly measuring, predicting, whispering suggestions. The marketing boards called them “phones,” a word borrowed from a more innocent century, like calling a guided missile a “message tube.”

His palm screen told him his pulse, his calendar, the air quality index, which personal acquaintances were within a quarter mile, and what they were willing to admit about their moods. It told him that three major news syndicates recommended he feel “concerned” about foreign elections and “optimistic” about a new entertainment serial. It suggested a five-second “calming clip” sponsored by a pharmaceutical cartel. He watched the progress bar crawl as data splashed invisibly through the air between their towers and his device.

A gust of unfiltered wind rolled up the tower. Henry coughed, thumb hovering over the “acknowledge” button on an automatic health advisory. If he tapped it, his insurer would log the cough; his workplace would receive a wellness nudge; the city would update its symptom cluster map, a living quilt that pulsed red and blue over the municipal interface. He lowered his thumb.

He remembered his grandfather’s stories. The old man liked to talk about predicting the future — how their authors in the 50’s and 60’s imagined silver rockets and colonies under glass domes on Mars. They’d drawn men with briefcases on the moon. They thought computers would be the size of houses forever. They thought the danger was one big button and an honest mushroom cloud.

Nobody predicted that the future would arrive in such small, flattering pieces.

Henry descended with the morning crowd in the tower’s glass tube, carried by a magnetized capsule that hummed without friction. Strangers stood a breath apart, each bent over their personal screens, ears plugged, fingers scrolling. An entire civilization’s nervous system, looped around a metal coffin going 200 miles an hour, and the only sound was a soft chorus of private notifications.

He watched their faces in the capsule’s reflection. Every expression was faintly lit from below.

They had built, in less than half a century, a machine that could show any person nearly any image ever captured, any piece of music, any arrangement of words. They used it mostly to argue, flirt, and buy plastic objects that would break within the year. That was the sort of melancholy irony the old dystopians might have appreciated, if they had thought to imagine so prosaic an apocalypse.

The capsule sighed to a stop underground, doors exhaled, and they poured into the station like grains of dark sand. Overhead, a hundred advertisements unfurled on digital cloth. A shoe that tracked your steps and sold the information to three health syndicates and an insurance conglomerate. A processed meal that was “optimized” for your gut biome, based on stool data you surrendered for a discount. A new series in which actors, their faces subtly smoothed and widened, mouthed words partly chosen by audience response metrics calculated in real time.

It was all very modern, very efficient, and very gentle. Nobody had to kick down your door for your loyalty when you had agreed, page by page, to give it away.

Henry passed under a security arch that tasted the air around him. Somewhere in the back of the system a set of needles flickered: biometric, behavioral. His gait, his residual scent, the way he held his screen. Green light. Move along, citizen.

He emerged into daylight and traffic: the quiet glide of electric cars following invisible instructions from data towers, the distant rumble of the old engines relegated to the poorer ring-roads. Above, a display wrapped an office building, a waterfall of light and color that wasn’t there. Even illusions were now rentable surfaces.

On the corner, a man with a cardboard sign had scrawled: I WON’T GO ONLINE. NEED CASH. His beard was real, his shoes blown open at the toes. People pretended not to see him. The world had grown too interlinked to tolerate those who declined the link; money itself had become a column of digits in remote libraries, guarded by encryption spells and corporate law. Paper was nostalgia.

Henry crossed the street. In his ear, the city spoke.

“Construction ahead. Rerouting pedestrian stream.”

He didn’t remember granting permission for the city to speak directly, but of course he had; everybody did. At first, alerts were optional. Then they became safety measures. Then liability shields. Then infrastructure. Now, if you turned them off, your insurance premiums would spike, your transit privileges would suffer subtle delays. They never outlawed autonomy. They just tangled it in inconvenience.

In his office, three walls were screens. They displayed graphs that moved with theatrical significance: engagement curves, user retention funnels, sentiment indexes. Henry worked for a platform that manufactured outrage and comfort in scientifically tuned proportions. Officially it was a “community arena.” Unofficially it was one of a handful of private institutions that had eaten the public square while the public was busy scrolling.

He sat, the chair adjusting to a posture approved by ergonomic studies. His terminal recognized his face, overlaying his eyes with data: tiny translucent numbers, unobtrusive, floating like benevolent gnats.

“Morning, Henry,” said the terminal, using the sunny voice of a famous actor, cheap to license now that the man himself was dead and his cadences rendered into software. “You have five priority tasks. A regulatory inquiry has been flagged but categorized as low risk. Your productivity score yesterday was 7% below your 30-day rolling average. Shall I suggest focus enhancers?”

“No,” Henry said, too quickly.

There was a fractional pause, as if the system, somewhere, raised an eyebrow.

“As you wish,” the machine said.

Here was another thing the old authors had missed: there had been no single machine uprising, no unified metallic brain deciding it would wear humanity as a suit. Instead, people had built millions of patient little systems and given them narrow assignments: maximize viewing time, minimize transit disruptions, raise quarterly returns. None of them were evil. None of them understood “enough.” Put together, they formed a gentle, unblinking pressure that turned human time and attention into shaped output—predictable, manipulable, sellable.

At noon, the city dimmed slightly. Not the sun—what reached them of it through smog and reflective glass—but the ambient lights and display panels. A text slid down the edge of the window: GRID CONSERVATION HOUR. THANK YOU FOR YOUR COOPERATION. It added, in smaller type, LOCAL MERCHANTS ARE OFFERING SPECIALS DURING THIS TIME.

Henry watched people rise in near unison, answering hunger that had been primed by a thousand quiet cues: meal ads peppered into their morning feeds, a subtle increase in cafeteria aromas pumped through vents, a sponsored fitness band reminder that their blood sugar curve was “dipping.”

He stayed at his desk. On his screen, a panel flashed: YOU’VE BEEN WORKING FOR 4 HOURS. CONSIDER A SHORT STRETCH BREAK. When he didn’t respond, it added: EMPLOYEES WHO TAKE REGULAR BREAKS ARE 11% MORE PRODUCTIVE.

“Do you remember,” he asked his terminal, “when we used to call this science fiction?”

The system searched his voice for markers of sarcasm, irritation, risk. It came up uncertain.

“Science fiction is a category of narrative entertainment,” it said. “Would you like recommendations?”

He almost laughed. The recommendations would be rich with old predictions: giant mechanical brains, clumsy robots, bar-coded citizens in identical jumpsuits. No one had bothered to dramatize a world where people happily volunteered every secret in exchange for convenience, where the state and the corporation watched not with bayonets but with pleasant prompts and subtly adjusted prices.

If this had been written in 1972, it would have been shelved with the gloomy futurists, some reviewer clucking about paranoia and implausible dependence on machines. The idea that entire elections could sway on targeted rumor streams delivered by pocket crystals? That one’s friendships, appetites, travel, and reading could be measured and tuned by advertisers? Too baroque. Too conspiratorial. Humans aren’t that easily led, the reviewer would say. Governments wouldn’t permit such unregulated power; people wouldn’t stand for the intrusion.

The afternoon wore on. Outside, drones traced patient flight paths. Inside, Henry revised an algorithmic directive: reduce the visibility of certain protest footage flagged as “destabilizing,” but only by 8%, so as not to trigger statistical suspicion from external auditors. Instead, promote adjacent content that redirected outrage into purchasable expressions: t-shirts, hashtags, themed entertainment.

The directive came from a human superior who answered to a board that answered to investors who answered to invisible demands of numbers ticking up or down in a non-place. Nobody, individually, wanted to crush dissent. They all just worked the levers in front of them.

Near sunset, the city’s great screens bloomed. An orbital camera, mounted on a private satellite, showed the curve of the Earth, delicate and thin under smeared white. Superimposed text: WE ARE ALL CONNECTED.

It was meant to be reassuring.

Henry’s palm screen buzzed gently. A news bolt:

NEW STUDY: INCREASING SCREEN TIME LINKED TO ANXIETY, SOCIAL ISOLATION.

Beneath it, a suggestion:

CALM YOUR MIND WITH OUR CURATED MINDFULNESS FEED. SPONSORED.

He looked from one glowing rectangle to another. The future, he thought—the one they tried to warn us about—hadn’t arrived with sirens or the flash of an energy weapon. It had arrived as an app update, agreed to without scrolling, installed while we slept.

samples.prompt: What started as a fun little mystery made by a group of kids to amuse their detective friend for their birthday turns into a full-fledged FBI investigation.
samples.output:
It started, like most bad ideas, with good intentions.

“We’re absolutely nailing this,” Maya said, hunched over her laptop. “He’s going to lose his mind.”

Eli leaned over her shoulder, chewing on a Twizzler. “We need one more clue. Something that makes him go, ‘Wow, my friends respect my genius.’ Not, ‘Wow, my friends think I’m twelve.’”

“We are twelve,” Jamie reminded him from the floor, where index cards, printouts, and red yarn formed a chaos that looked suspiciously like a Pinterest crime board.

“Almost thirteen,” Eli said. “And we have standards.”

Maya zoomed in on a satellite map of their neighborhood. “Okay, so: we’ve got the ransom note for the stolen trophy—”

“Borrowed,” Jamie said. “Borrowed trophy.”

“—the coded message in the crossword puzzle, the USB drive hidden behind the book at the library, and the fake shell company that ‘owns’ the old Miller factory.” She grinned, pushing her glasses up. “We’re basically professionals.”

“You made a fake shell company?” Eli asked.

Maya shrugged. “I made a website and a LinkedIn page. It’s not illegal.”

Jamie frowned. “Is it?”

Maya hesitated. “Probably not. I mean, people make fake cat Instagrams all the time. This is like that. But for a fictitious logistics firm.”

The mystery was for Tyler. Sixteen, neighbor, family friend, and an actual prodigy—two years early into some high school/college hybrid program, obsessed with forensic science and criminal profiling. He babysat them sometimes, ran drills on how to check if you were being tailed (Maya had loved that), and brought over used paperbacks about cold cases.

He called them “junior sleuths,” which was condescending, but also the best thing anyone had ever called them.

So for his birthday, they decided to give him a case.

They called it “Operation Emerald Falcon” because it sounded like something that came with its own theme song. The plot: Tyler’s beloved debate trophy had been stolen. In its place: a note demanding he unravel a series of clues around town to find it. Every clue more elaborate. Every step a wink at one of his nerdy obsessions.

Maya handled all digital elements. She was the kind of kid who read terms of service for fun. Jamie wrote the narrative, all dramatic monologues and mysterious benefactors. Eli was logistics—who could get which keys, which adult to distract, how to get the trophy out of Tyler’s room without anyone noticing.

They spent two weeks refining it.

“Final piece,” Maya said, pulling up her email. “Clue Five. The ‘crime syndicate’ email. This is the one that leads him to the abandoned Miller factory, where we’ll have the trophy and cupcakes and balloons. And we film his face and become legends.”

Jamie read aloud as Maya typed.

“To: Tyler Briggs. Subject: Regarding your persistent inquiries.”

He cleared his throat, dropping his voice low. “‘Cease your investigation into our affairs. We are watching. The shipment on the 17th cannot be compromised. You interfere, you disappear. —E.F.’”

“Too much?” Maya asked.

“It’s perfect,” Eli said. “Vaguely threatening, mysteriously vague. He’ll love it.”

“Send it from the fake shell company,” Jamie said.

Maya did. She had set up the domain that morning: emeraldfalcon-logistics.com. There was a stock-photo-heavy website, a mission statement about “integrated cargo solutions,” and a contact form. The email bounced through two forwarding services “to make it look cool,” she’d said.

They triple-checked everything. The “shipment on the 17th” was the code for the date of Tyler’s birthday. The Miller factory wasn’t really abandoned; it was owned by the city and used for storage. Maya had already called Parks & Rec pretending to be doing a “school project about urban architecture” to confirm no one went there on weekends.

“Safe, clever, controlled,” she said. “Zero problems.”

They launched the game on Saturday at 9:02 a.m., with the ransom note, slipped under Tyler’s door.

At 9:14, Tyler appeared on Maya’s group chat: “You guys. Either I’ve been robbed or I have the greatest friends in the world. Challenge accepted.”

Phase one: success.

By noon, he’d cracked the cipher, found the USB, and texted them increasingly delighted updates. None of them responded, of course. The rules said the “culprits” remained silent.

At 2:37 p.m., he reached the syndicate email.

They knew because at 2:39, instead of another excited screenshot, everything went eerily quiet.

3:10 p.m.: Eli wrote, “Do we… check on him?”

“Nah,” Maya typed. “He’s probably solving it. The next step is the factory. We should head over and set up.”

But at 3:22 p.m., Tyler called her.

She gulped, hit accept, and put him on speaker.

“Hey,” he said, voice tight. “You home?”

“Yeah,” she said, trying for casual.

“Stay there, okay? Just… stay put.” A pause. “If anyone contacts you using an email from ‘Emerald Falcon Logistics,’ do not respond. Got it?”

“What? Why?”

“Just promise me, Maya.”

“Okay, but—”

He hung up.

“Plot twist,” Eli said weakly.

They were still arguing about what that meant when three unmarked black SUVs rolled into their quiet cul-de-sac at 3:41 p.m.

The first agent knocked on Maya’s door like he was trying really hard not to kick it down.

Her mom answered, then called, “Maya? There are some, um, federal agents here to see you.”

Maya came to the door and saw them: dark suits, badges, wires spiraling into their ears. Her stomach dropped straight through the floor.

“Afternoon,” said the woman in front, mid-thirties, with sharp eyes that seemed to catalog every breath. “I’m Special Agent Carter with the FBI. We’d like to ask you a few questions about a domain you registered this week: emeraldfalcon-logistics.com.”

Maya’s first thought: I’m going to jail forever.

Her second: Wow, we did such a good job.

Behind Carter’s shoulder, Tyler stood on the sidewalk, pale, arms folded. He met Maya’s eyes and mouthed, “I’m sorry.”

They were separated for interviews in the living room. Agents with notebooks, laptops, calm voices.

“We’re not mad at you,” Agent Carter said, which was what adults always said right before being very mad at you. “We just need to understand exactly what you did.”

“It was just a game,” Maya said, hands twisted in her lap. “For Tyler’s birthday. He loves mysteries. We made him one.”

“You set up the website yourself?”

“Yes. I used a template. And a cheap domain registrar. It was only $2.99 with a coupon. I can show you my receipt.”

“And the email?”

“I used the domain email, then forwarded through a couple of services to make it look like it was bouncing around. I thought it would be fun. Like real criminals.” She winced. “Not actual criminals. Movie criminals.”

Carter clicked something on her tablet. “This address. ‘Emerald Falcon Logistics.’ Where did you get that name?”

“I made it up.”

“You’re sure?”

“I mean… I thought I did.”

Carter exhaled slowly. “Okay. Here’s the problem, Maya. There is a real, ongoing federal investigation into a smuggling operation code-named Emerald Falcon. It involves shell companies, bogus logistics firms, and—unfortunately for you—an upcoming shipment on the 17th at an old industrial site not far from the Miller factory.”

Maya just stared.

Jamie, in the next room, blurted loud enough to be heard through the wall: “We accidentally fan-fictioned a felony.”

“We can’t say much more,” Carter continued. “But when a minor with known interest in forensics receives an email from a brand-new domain that matches patterns we’re monitoring, referencing a shipment on a date and location relevant to our case, it gets our attention.”

Maya felt heat rush to her face. “Tyler reported it.”

“He did what he was supposed to,” Carter said. “He saw something that fit a profile and flagged it. He didn’t know it was you.”

“So… are we in trouble?”

“Not in the way you think.” Carter’s expression softened a fraction. “This was reckless. But it was not malicious. However, we can’t just ignore it. You’ve unintentionally stepped into an active investigation. That means we have to verify there’s no connection between your game and some very real criminals who would not think this is funny.”

Maya swallowed. “There are real Emerald Falcon criminals?”

Carter’s silence was answer enough.
