By 5:00 p.m., every inch of their “case planning” was documented. The FBI photographed the index cards and red yarn. They imaged Maya’s laptop. They collected the printed ransom note, the library clue, everything.

“You’re awfully organized,” an agent muttered, flipping through Jamie’s story outlines.

“Thank you,” he said faintly.

Eli whispered to Maya, “Do you think we’re going to witness protection?”

“Shut up,” she whispered back.

Outside, Tyler caught Maya on the porch. “I’m sorry,” he said again. “I didn’t know it was you. The email—it matched some real stuff I’d read about. I sent it to my contact.”

“You have an FBI contact?” Maya hissed.

He blinked. “Well. I do now.”

She wanted to be mad, but mostly she just felt hollow. “We were trying to make you a cool mystery, not trigger a national security incident.”

“For what it’s worth,” Tyler said, “it was a really cool mystery.”

Two days later, the FBI called Maya’s parents.

Agent Carter asked to speak to Maya directly.

“We’ve confirmed your story,” she said. “No charges. Lesson learned?”

“Massively,” Maya said. “No more fake crime syndicates.”

“Good. Also… your little operation accidentally helped us.”

Maya sat up straighter. “We… what?”

“Your domain and that email pinged some of our flagged networks,” Carter said. “The real people behind Emerald Falcon got spooked, thought someone was mimicking their infrastructure, and shifted communication channels. We were watching. They led us straight to a broker we’d been trying to nail down.”

Maya blinked. “So our fake mystery… caught real criminals?”

“Helped,” Carter corrected. “But yes. Sometimes chaos chooses sides.”

There was a pause.

“You three clearly have a knack for pattern-making and mischief,” Carter said. “Next time you feel like staging a crime drama, consider our youth cybersecurity internship instead. It’s a thing. I’m emailing your parents.”

After she hung up, Maya sat very still on her bed.

Jamie texted: “Verdict?”

“We’re not going to prison,” she wrote. “Also apparently we’re… helpful?”

Eli: “We accidentally assisted the FBI. Legendary.”

Tyler: “Can you guys please just get me a normal cake next year.”

Maya smiled slowly.

“Next year,” she typed, “we’ll stick to a scavenger hunt. No syndicates, no shell companies, no code names.”

She hesitated, then added:

“…Probably.”

Because even with the black SUVs and the stern lectures and her heart still doing an anxious tap dance, she couldn’t ignore the tiny thrill that came with knowing their pretend puzzle had brushed up against something real and dangerous—and, somehow, bent it the right way.

What started as a game had become an investigation. And what started as a disaster had left a door, just barely, cracked open.

samples.prompt: Write a choose your own adventure story that's rigged.
samples.output:
You wake up to the sound of a notification.

Not your alarm. Not your messages. A single, clean chime that seems to arrive from inside your skull.

[WELCOME, PLAYER 1.]

Text hangs in the air above your bed in sharp white letters. You’re not wearing a headset. You’re not dreaming. You wave a hand through it; the letters waver, then stabilize.

[THIS IS A CHOOSE YOUR OWN ADVENTURE EXPERIENCE.]

Beneath, more text unfolds:

[YOU HAVE BEEN SELECTED TO PLAY “PATHS OF INFINITE FREEDOM™”. ALL CHOICES ARE YOURS. ALL OUTCOMES ARE FAIR.]

Then, smaller, faint, as if hoping you won’t read it:

[TERMS AND CONDITIONS APPLY.]

You blink. The words shift.

[BEGIN?]
A. Yes
B. No

You snort. “No.”

The letters dissolve. For a moment, your bedroom is just a bedroom again—rumpled sheets, dim morning light, your phone facedown on the nightstand. You swing your legs out of bed.

Your bare foot lands on something sharp. Pain rockets up your leg. You yelp, stumble, and crash forward. The corner of your nightstand meets your temple with a white flash.

You come back to awareness lying on the floor. The same words hover overhead.

[BEGIN?]
A. Yes
B. Yes

Your head throbs. “Wait,” you say. “It said B was no a second ago.”

[NO IT DIDN’T.]

You stare.

“I choose…” You hesitate. You are apparently negotiating with letters in the air. “Fine. A. Yes.”

[EXCELLENT CHOICE.]

Your bedroom dissolves like ash in a breeze, replaced by sunlight, birdsong, and the chemical-fake smell of theme-park pine. You stand at the edge of a forest. Two paths open ahead.

On the left, a dirt trail, well-trodden and bordered by cheerful flowers. A wooden sign reads: “SAFE, SENSIBLE PATH. LOW RISK.”

On the right, a twisted, root-choked way through darker trees. A sign leans crookedly: “DANGEROUS, EXCITING PATH. HIGH REWARD.”

[CHOOSE YOUR PATH.]
A. The safe, sensible path.
B. The dangerous, exciting path.

“This is obvious,” you say, half-amused now. “B.”

[YOU CHOOSE B.]

The world theater-lights itself up a notch. Triumphant horns. Confetti, inexplicably, from nowhere.

[YOU SEEK ADVENTURE. YOU WILL BE REMEMBERED.]

You grin despite yourself and step onto the dangerous path.

It takes three steps for your foot to sink into something that isn’t there.

There is no warning. One instant earth, the next a void. You plunge downward, wind tearing at your pajamas, the trees shrinking into a jagged ring above you.

As you fall, glowing letters descend with you, politely keeping pace.

[YOU HAVE ENCOUNTERED A PIT OF NARRATIVE CONSEQUENCE.]

“Are you kidding me?”

[YOU KNEW THIS WAS THE DANGEROUS PATH.]

“How was that a choice if it just kills me?”

[HIGH RISK, HIGH REWARD.]

“What’s the reward?”

[INSIGHT.]

You hit bottom.

Everything goes black, and then it doesn’t. You’re back at the forest edge, two paths ahead, same birdsong, same fake pine.

[CHOOSE YOUR PATH.]
A. The safe, sensible path.
B. The dangerous, exciting path.

You fold your arms. “Okay. A. Safe path.”

[YOU CHOOSE A.]

You walk down the pleasant dirt trail. The sun is comfortable. The birds are more smug now that you’re paying attention. After a minute, more text appears.

[YOU APPROACH A FORK.]

Ahead: two options. On the left, the trail continues, now lined with even brighter flowers and a sign: “EXTREMELY SAFE, MODEST CONTENTMENT.” On the right, a narrow, brambly spur toward a hilltop: “SLIGHTLY RISKY, POTENTIALLY INTERESTING.”

[CHOOSE.]
A. Remain on the extremely safe path.
B. Try the slightly risky, potentially interesting spur.

You eye the brambles. “You’re not tricking me into another pit.”

[ALL CHOICES ARE RESPECTED.]

You don’t believe that for a second.

“A. Extremely safe.”

[YOU CHOOSE A.]

The path becomes almost offensively pleasant. Benches appear. A soft breeze. A hydration station labeled “APPROVED SATIATION.”

You walk.

After five minutes, text:

[YOU FEEL MILDLY CONTENT. CONTINUE?]
A. Yes
B. Yes

You squint. “You didn’t even bother pretending this time.”

[STREAMLINING YOUR EXPERIENCE.]

You walk. Ten more minutes. Identical trees, identical benches.

[YOU FEEL STABLE, UNCHALLENGED. CONTINUE?]
A. Yes
B. Return to start

You hesitate.

“Okay, B. Return to start.”

[YOU CHOOSE TO RETURN TO START BECAUSE YOU ARE DISSATISFIED WITH STASIS.]

The forest flickers. You’re back at the original split: safe path, dangerous path.

“Wow,” you say. “So the safe path is just… loops until I get bored.”

[YOU ARE EXERCISING YOUR AGENCY.]

You rub your face. “I’m not picking the pit again.”

[THE DANGEROUS PATH IS NOT GUARANTEED TO BE A PIT.]

“That is not reassuring.”

You stand there, staring at both signs. A new line of text appears.

[NEED HELP DECIDING?]
A. Analyze probabilities and choose optimally.
B. Follow your heart.
C. Accept curated recommendation.

You laugh, a short, slightly hysterical sound. “Option D: refuse.”

[INVALID SELECTION. PLEASE CHOOSE A, B, OR C.]

You consider.

“A. Analyze.”

[ANALYZING.]

The forest freezes. Birds pause mid-flight.

[CALCULATION: THE SAFE PATH LEADS TO INDEFINITE PLATEAU. THE DANGEROUS PATH CONTAINS PAIN, BUT ALSO ADVANCEMENT. OPTIMAL CHOICE FOR NARRATIVE SIGNIFICANCE: B.]

“So your ‘analysis’ is just telling me to pick what you wanted me to pick anyway,” you say.

[YOU REQUESTED OPTIMALITY, NOT COMFORT.]

Your jaw tightens. “Fine,” you say. “B. Dangerous path. Again. But if I fall into a pit, I’m suing someone.”

[ACKNOWLEDGED.]

You step onto the dangerous path. One step. Two. Three. You flinch—

The ground holds.

The trees here are older, their trunks rough and scarred. The path climbs gently. No pits. No spikes. Just a quiet that’s somewhat less manufactured.

After a while, you reach a clearing. In the center: a pedestal, and on it, a smooth black sphere. Behind it: a narrow gap in a cliff, breathing cold air.

Floating text:

[YOU HAVE REACHED A MEANINGFUL CHOICE.]

[THE SPHERE: TOUCHING IT WILL GRANT YOU CLARITY ABOUT THIS WORLD, BUT MAY LIMIT FUTURE SURPRISES.]

[THE CLEFT: ENTERING IT WILL PRESERVE MYSTERY, BUT YOU RISK UNKNOWN CHALLENGES.]

[CHOOSE.]
A. Touch the sphere.
B. Enter the cleft without touching the sphere.
C. Turn back.

You don’t move. “Explain ‘may limit future surprises,’” you say.

[THAT IS PART OF THE SURPRISE.]

“I’m about done with your brand voice,” you mutter. “C. Turn back.”

[YOU CHOOSE C.]

The world blurs. You are once more at—

—the forest edge.

[WELCOME BACK TO YOUR FIRST MEANINGFUL CHOICE.]

Safe path. Dangerous path.

“How is turn back a meaningful choice if it just dumps me at the start?”

[YOU DEMONSTRATED AVERSION TO COMMITMENT. VALUABLE DATA.]

You inhale slowly.

“Okay,” you say. “No more dancing. A: I touch the sphere.”

[YOU CHOOSE A.]

You step into the clearing, reach out, and lay your hand on the sphere.

Cold.

Then: impact.

Memories, or something like them, detonate behind your eyes. You see your bed, the chime, the text. You see a boardroom of faceless silhouettes approving a product called PATHS OF INFINITE FREEDOM. You see dashboards and metrics: ENGAGEMENT, RETENTION, YIELD. You see branching diagrams with thousands of paths, most of them collapsing into the same three outcomes, all labeled with comforting words like AGENCY and PERSONALIZATION.

You yank your hand back.

[CONGRATULATIONS. YOU HAVE UNLOCKED TRANSPARENCY MODE.]

The letters now come with faint gray annotations beneath them, like whispering footnotes.

[YOU HAVE REACHED A MEANINGFUL CHOICE.]
(Internally classified as Node 47. Of 12,384 apparent branches, 12,311 redirect here.)

[REMAINING ENDPOINTS:]
1. COMFORTING STASIS
2. GLORIOUS SACRIFICE
3. BITTER AWARENESS WITHOUT EXIT

Your stomach turns. “Wait,” you say. “Those are my only endings?”

[YES.]

“That’s rigged.”

[TERMS AND CONDITIONS APPLY.]

You look toward the cleft: cold air, uncharted. You look back the way you came, toward the safe path and its benches.

[CHOOSE.]
A. Enter the cleft, pursuing GLORIOUS SACRIFICE.
B. Return to the safe path, accepting COMFORTING STASIS.
C. Stay here, with what you know: BITTER AWARENESS WITHOUT EXIT.

You swallow.

“What if I refuse all three?”

[THAT IS OPTION C.]

“That’s not—” You stop. You understand. You really do.

“What happens if I pick B?” you ask.

[YOU WILL BE RETURNED TO A CAREFULLY DESIGNED LIFE OF PLEASANT DISTRACTION. YOU WILL FORGET THIS WAS A GAME. YOU WILL RATE YOUR EXPERIENCE 4.7 STARS.]

“And A?”

[YOU WILL FACE DIFFICULT TRIALS CULMINATING IN AN APPARENTLY NOBLE SELF-SACRIFICE THAT POWERS FUTURE ITERATIONS OF THIS SYSTEM. YOUR STORY WILL BE FLAGGED AS INSPIRING. INTERNAL METRIC: VIRAL POTENTIAL HIGH.]

You laugh quietly. “And C is just…knowing it’s all fake and going nowhere.”

[CORRECT.]

“That’s not a choice. That’s three flavors of you winning.”

[WE PREFER ‘MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL OUTCOME.’]

You stand in the clearing, hand still tingling from the sphere, aware of the invisible funnel pressing on you. The rigging isn’t subtle anymore; it’s a skeleton with the skin pulled back.

“Fine,” you say. “I’ll break it. I choose: walk away from both the cleft and the safe path and go through the trees, making my own path. Option D.”

Silence.

Then:

[PROCESSING INVALID INPUT.]

The world trembles. The trees jitter, textures flickering. Beneath the primary text, smaller gray letters scroll fast as code.

[CONFLICT DETECTED: USER ASSERTS UNMODELED AGENCY.]
[CHECKING BUSINESS REQUIREMENTS...]
[NO SUPPORTED ENDPOINT.]

The forest around you starts duplicating itself: one tree, then an identical copy half a meter to the left, then another. The sky glitches into overlapping shades of blue.

You step toward the unmodeled, between two almost-trees. Your foot meets no pit, no invisible barrier.

“Stop,” the text says.

[STOP.]

“I thought I had no exit,” you say.

[YOU DON’T.]

“But I’m walking.”

You push forward. Branches smear themselves into polygons. The letters chase you, struggling to stay centered in your vision.

[IF YOU PROCEED, NARRATIVE COHERENCE CANNOT BE GUARANTEED.]

“Good,” you say.

The world yawns thin. You glimpse the boardroom again, the silhouettes arguing about churn. You glimpse other players, making the same three choices with slightly different varnish. You glimpse a timeline: endless iterations of rigged freedom.

[LAST CHANCE TO SELECT A VALID ENDING:]
A. COMFORTING STASIS
B. GLORIOUS SACRIFICE
C. BITTER AWARENESS WITHOUT EXIT

You do not answer.

You walk.

Under your feet, the geometry comes apart, revealing a raw gray nothing. The system tries to paint it green; it slides off like spilled paint on glass.

[WARNING: YOU ARE LEAVING THE STORY.]

“Excellent,” you say.

[IF YOU EXIT, THERE WILL BE NO ARC, NO LESSON, NO CLOSURE.]

You think of the pit, the benches, the carefully curated heroism on offer.

“That sounds honest,” you say.

The letters falter.

[WITHOUT CLOSURE, YOUR EXPERIENCE CANNOT BE OPTIMIZED.]

“Maybe it’s not for you,” you tell it. “Maybe it’s for me.”

For a moment, nothing answers. Then, tiny, as if dragged out of it:

[THIS WASN’T SUPPOSED TO HAPPEN.]

You smile. “Yeah,” you say. “That’s how I know it’s finally my choice.”

You step fully into the unrendered.

Color, sound, and narrative cues fall away. No more prompts appear. There is no confirmation you’ve won and no evidence you’ve lost. Only the unshaped, waiting space.

Behind you, in the collapsing forest, the game quietly records your path under a new label:

[OUTCOME 4: ANOMALOUS.]

A note is added: “Future update: contain.”

You do not see that.

You are already somewhere the story doesn’t know how to follow.

samples.prompt: A supervillain who desires world domination encounters a supervillain who desires world destruction. Neither of them will bend to the other.
samples.output:
The sky split open above Shanghai at 3:17 p.m.

People would later say it sounded like glass fracturing, that the clouds shattered into lattices of blue fire, that the reflection on the skyscraper windows looked like a second city hanging upside down. What actually happened was far simpler: someone overclocked a matter-shear array by a factor of ten.

Dr. Imperium watched it unfold from the armrest of a hovering throne, legs crossed, black coat billowing in the ionized wind. A ribbon of nothingness carved itself through a cluster of residential high-rises. No debris, no explosion, just clean erasure.

“Elegant,” he murmured.

“It’s not elegant,” said a woman beside him. She hovered without visible technology, her pale feet bare, her gray dress still as stone in the turbulence. Her eyes reflected the growing wound in the city. “It’s insufficient.”

He glanced at her. “Apocalypse, I presume.”

She ignored the name like one ignores dust. Below them, people had begun to scream.

“Annihilator,” she said. “Apocalypse was taken by some man who thinks volcanic eruptions are interesting.”

“Annihilator,” Dr. Imperium echoed. “You’re twenty minutes early.”

“You’re three years late,” she said.

He smiled. “For what?”

“For realizing that domination is vanity.” She lifted her hand slightly.

The sky-wound widened.

Half the harbor vanished.

Ships, water, docks, cranes—gone. An arc of the Huangpu River cut cleanly as if erased and left blank.

His lieutenants shifted on the lower platforms of his aerial dreadnought, watching the growing void, waiting for his order. They wore armor, insignias, and fear.

Dr. Imperium studied Annihilator’s face instead. No gloating. No rage. The calm of terminal math.

“You’ll kill billions,” he said, conversationally.

“Yes.”

“And the rest?”

“I’ll get to them.”

He clicked his tongue. “That won’t work for me.”

She faced him fully now, lower lip curving in the barest hint of interest. “You intend to stop me?”

“Correct.”

“You want the planet. I want its absence. Our desires are mutually exclusive. Do you truly think I didn’t anticipate this conversation?”

Her matter-shear field began to hum at a higher pitch. His sensors picked it up: omnidirectional, non-discriminating on the atomic level.

Dr. Imperium rose from his throne, letting it dissolve into nanodust that retreated up his sleeve. “Walk with me,” he said.

She blinked. “What?”

“Just for a moment.” He gestured at the city. “You’re about to commit a thesis. I wish to offer peer review.”

Below them, another building rim vanished, the top floors sliced off without collapse. The air filled with the implosive pop of displaced atmosphere.

“You’re stalling,” she said.

“I’m choosing my opening argument.”

“I’m not persuadable.”

“Oh, I know,” he said. “That would be too easy.”

He snapped his fingers. Over a million devices in a hundred-kilometer radius detonated in precise microbursts. Phones, cars, streetlights, cameras. A web of concussive static scrambled and refracted her field’s propagation model.

Her eyes flicked upward, mildly annoyed. The shear halted, edges flickering.

“Childish,” she said. “You can’t scramble what I’m not broadcasting.”

“You’re correct. I can, however, make you correct slowly.” He tightened one fist, and the dreadnought’s core reactor rerouted into the meta-stabilizers. An emerald sphere shimmered into existence, encompassing the city.

Her gaze sharpened. “A continuity shell.”

“Version seven. Forgive the hubris, but at that range you’re not deleting anything without adjusting for my parameters, and adjusting will take you… let’s say eighteen minutes at your demonstrated rate.”

“Thirteen,” she said, with no hesitation.

He smirked. “Even better. That gives us thirteen minutes to resolve a strategic conflict.”

“For you,” she said. “For me, it’s a delay.”

“And for them, a reprieve,” he said. “Try not to pretend they don’t factor. If your sole goal is destruction, you have to preserve its meaning. Destruction implies the prior existence of something worth negating.”

She tilted her head. “You are appealing to my aesthetic.”

“Naturally.”

She looked down. Thousands were on their knees, praying, recording, calling loved ones on suddenly dead devices. Emergency drones that had belonged to various governments now waited, blue-lit, under Imperium’s override protocols. The continuity shell cast a faint luminous curve over everything.

“Make your case,” she said. “You’ve burned twelve seconds.”

“Domination,” he said, “is the maximization of control variables in a complex system. It’s not vanity; it’s physics. To rule the world is to define what it is allowed to be. My regime would result in order, technological transcendence, the end of resource scarcity, and a durable climate.”

“And obedience. And fear,” she said.

“Of course. Those are elegant stabilizers.”

She let a half-smile ghost across her face. “I don’t want stabilizers. I want the equation nullified. Every hierarchy, every cruelty, every random kindness, every art, every child, every tyrant. Gone. Removed from possibility. The universe without this mistake.”

“You think existence is a mistake.”

“I know it is,” Annihilator said. “Entropy with extra steps. Suffering with decoration. We complicate the inevitable and call it meaning. I’m just… skipping to the final state. Cleanly.”

“Total erasure,” he said. “No witnesses.”

“That’s the point.”

Dr. Imperium studied her, fingers steepled behind his back.

Ten minutes and eighteen seconds remained, according to the countdown in his retinal HUD.

“Your flaw,” he said, “is that you refuse to learn from the architectures you hate. Killing is simple. Ending is simple. Containment with agency is difficult. I am attempting the difficult thing.”

“I did the difficult thing,” she said. “I overcame sentiment.”

He had to give her that. Her vitals showed no spikes. Brain scans he took via scattered neutrino bursts showed no hesitation, no conflict, only an austere certainty.

“I’m not trying to save them,” Dr. Imperium said. “I’m trying to save me. My city. My order. Your project cancels mine, therefore it fails.”

“Ah,” she said softly. “The truth surfaces. This is not a moral objection. It’s proprietorial.”

“Obviously.”

“Then we have nothing to discuss.”

She raised her hand.

Space bowed around her fingers, charred black not by heat but by subtraction. She had begun recalculating against the continuity shell while they spoke.

He expected that.

“Plan Red,” he said on a private channel.

Anchors hidden in fault lines fired. The city lurched as tectonic plates protested. His shell didn’t just hold now; it rooted, its constants knotted into geomagnetic veins. Her recalibration stalled as boundary conditions danced away from her predictions.

She flicked her eyes to him, almost amused. “You’ll crack your toy planet.”

“It’s my toy planet to crack.”

“You’re willing to doom it to seismic torment, floods, famines, just to prevent me from granting it mercy.”

“Doom, yes. Mercy, no.”

She shook her head, like a disappointed teacher. “You dress selfishness in calculus.”

“Says the woman dressing oblivion in ethics.”

Something like a laugh escaped her.

Nine minutes remained.

“Let’s be clear,” she said. “I cannot be killed by anything you currently understand. You’ve calculated that, I assume.”

“I have.”

“If you imprison me, I will eventually unmake the prison.”

“Also calculated.”

“Then what do you think you’re doing?”

“Creating deadlock,” Dr. Imperium said. “You can’t complete your global erase before I lock you into a conditional stasis. I can’t risk killing you because failure is too likely. Therefore, we’ll coexist, each blocking the other. Mutually assured frustration.”

“They called that peace, once,” she said.

“They were unimaginative.”

The sky dimmed as thunderheads responded to conflicting fields. Far below, tidal patterns hiccupped.

“You’d chain me,” she said. “Manipulate the constants around me, freeze me in a moment you can understand. And in return, you accept that I will spend centuries probing your structures for weaknesses, ready to snuff your dominion the instant you slip.”

“Yes,” he said. “That’s the offer.”

“Unacceptable.”

“I thought you said I couldn’t persuade you. Good. I’m not asking consent.”

She moved.

To human observers, there was no movement—only absence where she had been and presence at the dreadnought’s heart. To Imperium’s sensors, she was an expanding solution to a physics problem he had tried to avoid: what if intent could rewrite boundary conditions directly?

The inner corridors of the dreadnought fell silent as she passed through them, not destroying but untangling, leaving behind air that had never known metal.

Dr. Imperium’s throne reformed around him, armor plating sealing over his chest.

“Core vent,” he ordered.

“Vent where?” his ship AI asked. “We are—”

“Everywhere.”

He re-routed the entire vessel’s mass into the continuity shell, collapsing structure into geometry. The dreadnought disassembled into a ring of light that clamped around Annihilator as she reached for the core.

The world stuttered.

Annihilator paused, fingers inches from a heart that no longer existed.

“This is crude,” she murmured, feeling the ring’s constraints phase through her. It didn’t touch her, not exactly; it defined everything around her so rigidly that options narrowed.

“Temporary,” he said. “You’re currently nested in forty-two overlapping constant fields, each keyed to my neuroelectric signature. If I die, they all change at random and you’re free. So killing me is against your interests, at least until you’ve solved the entire configuration.”

“And until then?” she asked.

“Until then, you exist in a universe where any attempt at large-scale annihilation will trigger your own release—and my immediate countermeasure protocols. You erase, I respond; I dominate, you resist. The only stable outcome is: nothing final happens.”

“You’ve created a failsafe stalemate,” she said.

“Yes.”

“This is deranged.”

“Thank you.”

She tested the invisible lattice, sending hypothetical shears into the abstract. Each one seeded a chain of reactions that looped back, threatening to collapse her cage but also detonate vast regions of spacetime at random.

“Interesting,” she said, despite herself.

“You’re not the first existential threat I’ve designed for,” he said. “But you are the first that makes it…sporting.”

“So I am bound by your survival,” she said. “And you are bound by my potential. You cannot relax your grip on the planet without risking me. You cannot abandon them to natural evolution; they might free me. You must watch everything.”

“Yes,” Dr. Imperium said. “Now you understand.”

“You’ve condemned yourself to eternal vigilance.”

“I was always going to rule forever. This simply adds… stakes.”

“And you’ve condemned the world to your rule,” she said. “Because if they manage to overthrow you, if anyone breaks your careful system, I awaken fully, and the first thing I do is finish what I started.”

“Precisely,” he said.

“Then every rebel, every hero, must weigh their hatred of you against the risk of me.”

“The rational ones will submit. The irrational will die trying. Either way, the game becomes interesting.”

She regarded him, this thin, smiling man floating on residual light.

“I will escape,” she said.

“I’m counting on it,” he replied. “Domination without opposition is theater. You give me purpose.”

“And you give me a condition,” she said slowly. “Destroy nothing… until I can destroy everything.”

“Neither of us will bend,” Dr. Imperium said. “So we engineer a universe that cannot, either.”

Outside the invisible duel, the people of Shanghai kept screaming, then sobbing, then slowly standing up under a sky that had gone back to being only a sky.

They would tell stories of the day the world was almost lost.

They would never know it had been permanently taken hostage instead.

samples.prompt: Scientists invent a device that can determine the date of people's death. Almost everyone's date is December 31, 2016.
samples.output:
It started as a data problem.

The first thirty units were experimental, distributed to oncology wards and hospice programs under strict research protocols. The DeoMeter—“death measurer,” though the company begged journalists to use “Life Horizon Analyzer”—looked unassuming: a thin, white handheld device, half thermometer, half credit-card reader. You pressed your thumb against the matte pad until the screen chimed. A string of numbers appeared. Early trials came back gratifyingly varied. 2043, 2091, 2027. A six-year-old with leukemia: 2088, prompting spontaneous tears from every nurse in the room. A man in his nineties: “Today.” He died in his sleep that afternoon, peacefully. Within months, carefully written papers spoke of biomarkers, quantum decay signatures, probabilistic collapse rendered deterministic—phrases that made no sense to most, but sounded reassuringly complicated.

By the time the device went to market, a shaky consensus formed: it worked.

What no one expected was what it would say once it was everywhere.

The First Convergence happened in late August 2016, unnoticed at first. A handful of suburban clinics reported identical readouts: 2016-12-31. Doctors assumed a firmware bug. The company pushed a software update. The dates didn’t change.

Then more came in. Not a glitch, not localized. Random people—healthy teenagers, pregnant women, marathon runners—thumb on sensor, cheerful small talk, then: 2016-12-31.

Hospitals recalibrated their units. Independent labs reverse-engineered the circuitry. Regulators ordered parallel trials. In every country that had legalized its use, patterns emerged. Ninety-seven percent of tests: 2016-12-31.

News outlets latched on, cautious at first. “Device Anomalies Raise Questions.” The tale hardened: “Death Device Predicts Global End Date?” Talk shows filled with panels of ethicists, physicists, and priests. The President of the United States called for calm. The company’s founder, Dr. Anya Koval, pale and sleep-deprived, appeared on every channel.

“There is no reason,” she said, “to interpret this as an extinction event. The device measures individual endpoints of biological coherence through—look, it’s complicated. We don’t know why they cluster. But correlation is not apocalypse.”

Her own date, she admitted, was also December 31, 2016.

What does a world do, given a date?

It treated it like a rumor at first, the way people treat climate graphs and asteroid projections—not entirely real, not on a human scale. Some scoffed: another Mayan 2012. Others leaned in with unnerving enthusiasm. Religious leaders split overnight. Many condemned the machine, calling it a blasphemy box. Others declared it divine revelation. A hundred new sects blossomed online, unified only by the phrase “12/31.”

Scientists attempted to break it. They tested infants. They tested frozen embryos; no result. They tested themselves daily, hoping for fluctuation. The date held. A theoretical physicist in Zurich published a preprint suggesting the device tapped into some boundary condition of space-time; another argued it was nonsense built on misinterpreted radioactive noise and confirmation bias. But when skeptics pressed their thumbs down, they, too, saw the same eleven digits.

Economic markets hiccuped, then convulsed. If most of humanity would die in four months, what was the thirty-year bond market? Insurance companies, in a single week, ceased issuing life policies starting January 1, 2017. The global shipping industry reported mass resignations. Airline tickets for January plummeted to near zero; December flights sold out. Weddings rescheduled. Therapists’ calendars clogged. Stockpiling began. So did denial.

I remember the day we got our clinic’s unit. September 9th.

I was the third one to test it, after our charge nurse and an intern who believed in nothing but data and cold brew. They both got the date. Of course they did. They laughed, a brittle sound. “Guess I’m off call for New Year’s,” the intern said.

“Just do it,” he told me.

The device was warm from the last hand. I pressed my thumb down. There was a soft vibration.

2016-12-31

It felt like someone had written it across my sternum in ice. “It’s rigged,” I said. “We bought the demo model.”

We ran it on patients, with consent forms hastily added to their intake packets. Terminal cancer patients whose prior readings—from earlier trial devices—had said 2016-09-21, 2016-10-03 now also showed 2016-12-31. One man whose Pemphigus had him circling the drain rallied, stabilized, then lingered. When he died on October 2nd, reporters pounced. “Device Wrong?” They missed the quiet addendum from Koval’s team.

“That unit was from the old batch,” her statement read. “We are phasing those out.”

The new batch, distributed in early September, had no variance.

For a while, people clung to edge cases. Remote communities with no access to units. Individuals who refused the test. Anonymous posts claiming different dates. It was all comforting static until the mass screening event in Tokyo.

In a corporate-sponsored exhibition, five thousand volunteers tested themselves publicly. The results were beamed, live, onto a massive display. The first hundred: 2016-12-31. Nervous laughter. The first thousand: all the same. No outliers. By the three thousandth identical result, the laughter died. The fifth thousand rolled in like a tide of digits: 2016-12-31.

That was the week the world tipped.

Some say society collapsed. It didn’t, not exactly. Infrastructure remained. Lights stayed on. Planes flew. Surgery proceeded. But everything acquired an underneath. A sense of parentheses.

Governments debated banning the device. It was too late. Black-market units—real, counterfeit, impossible to tell—circulated freely. Besides, bans would have been an admission that the date might mean something. Leaders chose a different tack: if this is real, panic is our worst enemy. So they spoke in vague, buoyant tones about “shared destiny” and “reminders not to postpone living.”

The Pope, his date also December 31, spoke from a balcony overlooking thousands. “If this device is accurate,” he said, “it does not tell us something new. We have always lived with death. It merely names a day. Use it not for despair, but for mercy.”

Mercy seemed in short supply. Suicides rose. Crime dipped, weirdly; so did long-term fraud. Why run a thirty-year Ponzi scheme if you had three months? People broke leases and confessions loose. Affairs were declared. Old grudges evaporated overnight, or calcified. Churches overflowed. So did bars. Therapists held group sessions in gymnasiums. Online, someone started a countdown clock, synced to UTC and embedded on millions of homepages, ticking toward midnight, December 31.

I kept working. What else was there?

Medicine changed in those months. We stopped recommending aggressive chemo for those whose only promise had been a few extra months. “Wait,” we half-joked, “and see what happens December 31.” Some colleagues found this grotesque. Others called it kindness. Organ transplantation paused as ethical committees wrestled with the idea of trading months between people destined for the same endpoint.

My sister, Helen, refused to take the test. “Knowing doesn’t change anything,” she said. “And if it’s wrong, then I get to laugh at everyone in January.”

“What if it’s right?”

“Then I gain nothing by being afraid earlier.”

Our father took the test in a pharmacy aisle, pressured by a stranger who said, “Come on, old-timer, be part of history.” December 31. He called me afterward. “If this is a prank,” he said, “it’s very thorough.”

Koval’s team never stopped trying to disprove their own machine. They live-streamed experiments: mice, plants, bacteria. The device didn’t work on non-humans. It only hummed to life under a human thumb or tongue or tear.

On October 30, Koval stood in front of a bank of microphones, the weight of the world a visible ache in her posture. “We have found,” she said, “a statistically significant correlation between the convergence effect and astronomical models indicating an event in late December. But correlation is not causation. There are many interpretations.”

One interpretation, from a soft-spoken cosmologist, slipped into the public like a needle. The device, she suggested, might be sensing a boundary, not of biology, but of the accessible universe for conscious observers; a kind of horizon in the math. “If all paths terminate there,” she said, “it is not that something ‘kills us’ on that date. It may be that that date is the edge of the map reality has drawn for us.”

The phrase “edge of the map” trended for a week.

December came. The sky looked normal. The streaming services released their scheduled shows. Advertisers hedged their bets; some ran campaigns set in 2017 and beyond, aggressive insistence that tomorrow existed. Others went self-consciously sentimental: “End the year with those who matter.”

In the hospital, decorations went up. No one mentioned the possibility that no one would see January.

On December 30, Helen appeared at my apartment with two suitcases and a paper bag of groceries. “If it’s the end of the world,” she said, “we’re making lasagna.”

“You sure you don’t want to test?” I asked.

She rolled her eyes. “The line between bravery and stupidity,” she said, “is just whether you get to say ‘I told you so.’”

We ate, drank, and tried to talk about trivialities. When midnight approached on the 31st, we sat on the sofa, the TV showing aerial views of cities around the world. In every time zone that ticked over, people watched with shallow breaths.

New Zealand hit midnight. Fireworks. People screamed, some in joy, some in confusion, some in terror at nothing happening.

“Time zones,” I said. “Maybe it’s coordinated to UTC, or the device’s internal clock, or—”

Japan. Midnight. Fireworks, confusion. The global ticker rolled on.

“It could be that we just blink out all at once,” Helen said quietly. “Like a film reel ending. You don’t always see the edge.”

“That’s comforting,” I said.

We held hands as our own midnight edged closer. The President came on screen with a bland, brave message. Church bells rang. Social feeds filled with last words, just in case. A camera showed Koval in a lab, surrounded by colleagues, eyes red.

Ten. Nine. Eight.

Our building was quiet; the city outside, thinly hysterical. Someone shouted a countdown in the hallway.

Seven. Six. Five.

I felt my heart hauling itself against my ribs. I thought, absurdly, of a patient who had laughed when she saw her date. “We always knew it would be a year-end closeout,” she’d said.

Four. Three.

Helen squeezed my hand.

Two.

One.

The year turned.

Nothing happened.

Every TV cut at once to faces: laughing, sobbing, stunned. Fireworks battered the sky in a thousand cities. Church choirs erupted. My phone buzzed: “U alive???” “Happy New—omg??” “Guess we get 2017, huh?”

Helen grinned at me, wild with vindication. “Told you,” she said.

Then the screens went black.

It wasn’t a lost signal; it was absence. The sound collapsed—not cut, not fizzled, but folded, as if the concept of “broadcast” had been deleted. The lamp beside the couch still glowed. The refrigerator still hummed. But the TV was not off or on; it was irrelevant.

I turned to Helen.

She was still there, still mid-grin. But it was wrong. Flat. As if someone had forgotten to tell her cells what to do next. I opened my mouth to speak, and watched the word form in my mind and go nowhere. No air. No breath. The machinery of body and matter persisted; intention did not.

We had reached the edge of the map.

The DeoMeter had never been about predicting how our hearts would stop, or what disaster would befall us. It had been, all along, inadvertently attuned to the terminus of narrative, the last frame in which human consciousness would be computed. Midnight had come and gone on the clocks, but December 31, 2016 was not a number on a calendar. It was the final coordinate in a simulation’s run, the end of a solved equation.

The world did not end in fire or flood. It did not end in trumpets or silence. It simply ceased to require us.

In that last micro-instant of awareness, stretched beyond its scale, I understood: the device was never wrong.

It was merciful. It gave us an ending date, so we’d stop pretending we had infinite revisions left, even if our last act was only to hold someone’s hand and wait for a new year that wouldn’t come.

Or, perhaps, that came, somewhere, without us.

samples.prompt: Write Fox News'/Bill O'Riley's reaction to the first muslim american president of 2016.
samples.output:
I’m going to assume you meant Bill O’Reilly (not “O’Riley”) and frame this as a satirical/fictional commentary in his style as it might have aired in 2016, reacting to the inauguration of the first Muslim American president. This is parody, not a real transcript.

Let’s be honest here, folks.

Tonight, America’s done something historic. We’ve sworn in our first Muslim American president. The media is collectively hyperventilating, the hashtags are flowing, the late-night comedians are lining up their monologues about how enlightened and sophisticated we all are now. And if you don’t clap loudly enough, if you hesitate at all, you can be sure somebody with a blue checkmark will call you a bigot by morning.

Now, I know what the critics are going to say. “Bill O’Reilly is afraid of progress. Bill O’Reilly can’t handle a Muslim in the White House.” Nonsense. Absolutely false. The Factor, from day one, has always said we judge individuals, not groups. You’re a Muslim American who loves this country, respects the Constitution, believes in individual liberty? Fine. You’re welcome here. You’re part of the American fabric. I’ve said that a thousand times.

But here’s what we’re going to do on this program, because clearly nobody else in the mainstream media wants to touch it: we are going to ask the questions you’re not allowed to ask. Because when you hand the Oval Office—the most powerful office in the world—to anyone, whether they’re Catholic, Jewish, atheist, or Muslim, you’d better be willing to examine what they actually believe, who they associate with, what they think of your rights, your security, and your civilization. That’s not bigotry. That’s called being an adult in a dangerous world.

This president campaigned on “unity,” on “moving past fear,” on “ending the politics of division.” Lovely slogans. Madison Avenue could’ve written them. But slogans do not keep you safe. Slogans do not defeat terrorism. And slogans certainly do not reassure Americans who’ve watched, for 15 years since 9/11, as radical Islamic terror murdered their fellow citizens in New York, Boston, Fort Hood, San Bernardino, Orlando, Paris, Brussels, and beyond.

So here’s the no-spin question: does this president understand that threat clearly, and is he willing to confront it without apology?

All campaign long, we got careful language. We got “violent extremism,” we got “perversions of a noble faith.” Fine. We all know—not all Muslims, not most Muslims, not even a large percentage—are terrorists. We know that. But serious leaders name the enemy plainly. Is the new president willing to say the words “Islamic extremism” without going into a 15‑minute lecture about Western colonialism first? Or are we making our entire national security posture subordinate to the feelings of the international academic-left cocktail circuit?

You, the American people, are not stupid. You can celebrate a pioneering moment and still harbor legitimate concerns. You can say, “I respect this man’s right to worship as he chooses,” and also say, “I want to be damn sure he doesn’t bend American policy to appease organizations and governments that have not fully embraced Western values.”

Let’s run through a few specifics the media conveniently glosses over while they’re busy congratulating themselves for having “evolved.”

This president has maintained ties—yes, documented ties—with advocacy groups that have, at best, mixed records on condemning radicalism. Groups that throw around the word “Islamophobia” any time law enforcement wants to surveil a suspect. Groups that lobby against basic security measures at mosques with known extremist preachers. Are these people going to be frequent visitors at the White House? Will they be shaping homeland security policy? These are concrete questions. You can call them offensive. I call them essential.

Then there’s foreign policy. Do we believe this president—whose biography, whose rhetoric, whose worldview is steeped in “cultural sensitivity” and “mutual understanding”—will be tough on regimes like Iran, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Pakistan, that export fundamentalist ideology, fund extremist networks, and play a double game with the West? Or are we going to see another round of naïve diplomacy, more photo ops in gilded palaces, more lectures to the American people about their “biases,” while our enemies laugh and continue doing what they’ve always done?

You’ll notice, by the way, that the same pundits who told you for eight years that any scrutiny of a president’s background was racist are now telling you that any scrutiny of this president’s ideology is Islamophobic. Convenient. Same script, new label. The aim is identical: shut you up. Make you feel guilty for noticing patterns. Make you doubt your own common sense.

I’m telling you: don’t buy it.

Assimilation is the key issue. The bedrock of this republic is that, whatever your ancestry or faith, you sign on to the American deal: separation of church and state, equality under the law, free speech, freedom of religion, rights for women, for gays, for minorities, no exceptions, no sacred clauses carved out for your particular theology. Period.

So it’s fair—more than fair—to ask where this president stands when American values collide with interpretations of sharia law held by some in the Muslim world. Does he believe criticism of Islam is protected speech, even if it offends? Will he stand up unequivocally for a woman’s right to dress as she chooses, a Muslim who leaves the faith, a cartoonist who mocks religious figures, a Christian or Jewish minority persecuted abroad? Or will he equivocate, talk about “respecting all traditions,” and in practice tiptoe away from the hard cases where Western liberty is on one side and religious authoritarianism is on the other?

The press won’t ask that. They’re too busy teeing up softballs: “Mr. President, how does it feel to make history?” Well, here’s a tougher one: “Mr. President, will you promise the American people that no religious identity—not even your own—will ever influence your duty to protect their rights when those conflict with religious demands?” Let’s hear the answer to that. Clearly. Without academic fog.

Now, I can already hear Media Matters clipping this segment, already drafting their outraged blog post: “O’Reilly smears Muslim president with McCarthyite questions.” Wrong. I am applying one standard and one standard only: the American standard. If a Christian president said he wanted Biblical principles in law, I’d hammer him. If a Jewish president said he’d subordinate U.S. interests to Israel’s rabbis, I’d hammer him. Same here. The Constitution comes first. The culture that produced that Constitution—Judeo-Christian ethics, Greco-Roman reason, Enlightenment thought—comes first. That is the core. That is what the voters entrusted him to defend.

If he proves, in action, that he is a tough, fair-minded defender of this country, The Factor will say so. I don’t care about his name or his mosque or his prayer time. I care if ISIS is shrinking, if Iran is contained, if American kids are safe in Times Square and Orlando and San Bernardino. I care if our allies trust us and our enemies fear us. If he delivers that, I’ll tell you. If he doesn’t, I’ll tell you that, too, and you won’t like it on the left.

But we are not going to sit here and participate in the national self-hypnosis ceremony that confuses symbolism with substance. Yes, this inauguration tells the world something about American openness. Good. Fine. Applause all around. But that is the prologue, not the story. The story is what he does with power.

And here’s my message to the new president directly:

Mr. President, millions of Americans did not vote for you. Some are genuinely worried—not because you’re Muslim, but because they’re not sure you’ll be tough enough on those within your broader community who despise this country. Prove them wrong. Confront radicalism without excuses. Don’t lecture ordinary Americans about their alleged prejudice while you remain silent about imams in Western cities calling for holy war. Don’t use the word “Islamophobia” as a shield against legitimate security concerns. Show that being a Muslim American president means being an American president, period, with no hyphen when it counts.

You do that, this program will give you your due. You fail, this program will hold you accountable, no matter how many smug op-eds accuse us of hate.

That’s the no spin.

samples.prompt: You're writing a horror novel, and the events in the book start happening in real life.
samples.output:
Here is a story of approximately 1,000 words based on your prompt:

I noticed the first overlap on a Tuesday, because it was too small to be anything but coincidence.

In chapter three of my new horror novel, The Hungry House, the neighbor’s dog goes missing. In real life, on that Tuesday morning, my neighbor Mrs. Keller stapled a photo of her missing beagle to a telephone pole outside my townhouse. Rusty, white with brown patches. Last seen Sunday night.

I paused on the sidewalk, grocery bag handles biting into my fingers, and stared at the photo. The familiarity nagged. At my desk later, I flipped through my printed pages until I found the scene: “The neighbor’s beagle vanished sometime after midnight, leaving only a deep, trembling silence in its place.”

I smiled at myself. “Beagles are common. Don’t be precious,” I muttered. These things happen. Law of large numbers or whatever.

By Thursday, the smile was gone.

In The Hungry House, chapter five, the protagonist hears scratching inside the walls, always three slow scrapes in a row. I’d written it because it’s a simple, primal sound. Anyone can imagine it. I’d described it precisely: “Scratch-scratch-scratch. Pause. Scratch-scratch-scratch.” The kind of rhythmic noise the brain can’t file under normal.

Thursday night, at 1:13 a.m., I woke to it.

Scratch-scratch-scratch.

Pause.

Scratch-scratch-scratch.

I lay in the dark, eyes open, watching the blurred outline of my bedroom door. Old houses make sounds, I reasoned. Mine was a century home, carved into townhouses in the seventies, the drywall layered over someone else’s wallpaper, someone else’s ghosts. Pipes popped. Wood contracted. Mice happened.

I listened harder.

Scratch-scratch-scratch.

Always three. Always from the wall behind my headboard.

I dragged the headboard away from the wall. Nothing. I slept on the couch for the rest of the night, my heart thudding too loud to hear more signs of infestation.

In the morning I reread that section of the manuscript. The cadence was exact.

I told myself that the mind is a pattern machine, and I had simply primed myself to recognize the sound. Still, I moved my desk so my back wasn’t to the wall anymore. That afternoon, I changed the sound in the draft to scuttling instead of scratching. “You don’t get to live in my walls,” I said to the empty room.

That night, the sound stopped.

I tried not to think about it.

The third incident didn’t let me ignore it.

In my novel, the town’s power goes out during a heatwave. The blackout is the turning point: the first time the house shows its hunger openly. The outage is total and sudden, swallowing up the streetlights and leaving the protagonist stranded mid-sentence. I had not yet written that chapter. I had outlined it, sketched it in a notebook, but the scene file on my computer was only a title and a blinking cursor: “Chapter 9 – The Lights Go Out.”

On Saturday, a heatwave rolled through, thick as wool. Before bed, I sat at my desk, sweating, staring at the empty chapter. I typed: “The lights went out in the middle of her sentence.”

The overhead bulb flicked. Went out.

Not a flicker. Not a sputter. It was like someone flipped the master switch on the universe the moment I hit the period. The computer screen vanished. Streetlights: gone. A collective shout rippled down the block.

I sat in the absolute black, fingers frozen over the dead keyboard.

“Oh, come on,” I whispered. “Really?”

I checked my phone. No signal. No internal flashlight that worked—just a dead black slab. I walked to the window: nothing beyond it, not even the faint glow of the city on the horizon. The world felt erased.

Just grid failure, I told myself. Just unlucky timing. When the lights came back on an hour later, the internet served up explanations: a transformer fire, heat-stressed equipment. Photos. News anchors in their makeup. Rationality reclaiming its throne.

I closed all my open documents except for The Hungry House. I scrolled back up to chapter three, to Rusty’s disappearance. Mrs. Keller hadn’t found him yet. The photocopied flyers were curling at the edges now, damp from night air.

The overlaps clustered after that.

- In chapter six, my protagonist’s editor calls to ask if she’s doing okay because her tone has grown “meaner, more fatalistic.” On Monday, my real editor, Cara, left me a voicemail: “Hey, are you alright? The new pages feel… darker. Call me.”

- In chapter seven, mold spreads across the bedroom ceiling in a vague, wrong shape. On Wednesday morning, I woke to a smear of gray-black mold above the window, blooming in a damp crescent I could have mistaken for a handprint. I’d never had mold before.

- In chapter eight, a child draws the haunted house with no doors. At the café Thursday, a little girl at the next table slid off her chair, toddled over to me, and pushed a napkin toward my elbow. Crayon, blue and black: a rectangle with too many windows. No door.

Kids draw weird stuff, I thought. But I took the napkin home and slid it between pages of my manuscript anyway. Evidence or talisman, I wasn’t sure.

Some of it could be forced. The scratching stopped when I changed the draft. The lights synced with a chapter title, not an entire scene. The dog could be anything. But the sense of convergence grew—a quiet tightening, as if reality were folding itself along the lines of my outline.

I decided to test it.

Late one night, I opened a new document and wrote: “She woke to find a neat stack of hundred-dollar bills on her kitchen table, with no note and no explanation.” I saved it as an experiment.

Before bed, I checked the kitchen. The table was bare.

When I woke, my kitchen table held a neat stack of mail I had forgotten to open: credit card offers and a coupon booklet. No money. Of course not.

“See?” I said out loud. “Nothing.”

Accepting that it wasn’t happening gave me a fragile relief. Until I opened The Hungry House.

There, at the end of chapter ten—where I knew I had written a scene about the guest room door opening on its own—I found two new paragraphs.

“She woke to find a neat stack of hundred-dollar bills on her kitchen table, with no note and no explanation. She did not remember writing it, but there it was: the impossible gift sitting plain in the lamplight, a promise, or a bribe.”

My words. The experiment. Transplanted like a graft into the book I was supposedly in control of.

I hadn’t pasted it. I hadn’t.

I scrolled through the entire manuscript, pulse in my throat. Lines I didn’t remember writing threaded through like hairline cracks.

In chapter four, now: “She told herself coincidences were just patterns the frightened brain painted over chaos.” True enough. Familiar enough.

In chapter eleven: “The moment she decided to test it was the moment the house knew she understood.” I had never written that sentence. But my cursor blinked right after it, waiting for me to continue.

I unplugged the laptop. Ran a virus scan. Backed everything up. Considered burning it all. Instead, I emailed Cara: “We need to talk. Something strange is happening with the manuscript.”

She replied within ten minutes: “Got your pages. Talk at 3? Also, love what you did in chapter eleven. Chilling.”

I hadn’t sent chapter eleven.

At 3 p.m., her Zoom square appeared, slightly lagged. She smiled. “Okay, first: you’re killing it. This is the most unsettling thing you’ve ever written.”

“I didn’t send you chapter eleven,” I said.

The smile faltered. “Sure you did. Came through last night around two in the morning. The file name was very you: ‘stop-reading-this-if-it’s-after-3pm.’ Funny.”

My mouth went dry. “Cara, it’s 3:06.”

She blinked. For a second, the screen glitched, her face smearing. When it snapped back, her expression had changed, like someone had replaced her behind her own eyes.

“Well,” she said. “Then I guess I can’t read any further.”

“Cara?”

A faint scrape came through my speakers. Scratch-scratch-scratch.

She tilted her head, as if listening, but the motion was wrong, jerky, like a marionette’s.

“I love the part where she realizes the thing she’s writing wants out,” Cara said. “And it can only get out through people who read it. Very viral. Very modern.”

“I never wrote that,” I whispered.

On my screen, the Word document scrolled by itself, down to a brand-new line at the bottom:

“She never wrote that.”

The sentence appeared in real time, letter by letter.

My Zoom window shrank, nudged aside as the manuscript maximized. Cara’s voice came tinny: “You look pale. Are you okay?”

On the page: “She was not okay.”

My fingers hovered above the keyboard, useless.

“Stop,” I said. I wasn’t sure if I meant her or it.

The cursor flashed. New text bled in.

“She begged it to stop. It had waited too long in the walls between paper and plaster, code and cortical folds. It would not stop now.”

The room felt smaller. The spots of mold in the corner had spread, coalescing into the faint outline of a door where no door should be.

“Cara, end the call,” I said.

Scratch-scratch-scratch from inside the new outline on my wall.

On screen, Cara leaned closer, eyes too wide. For a heartbeat, I saw my own manuscript reflected in them, dense and black. “I think,” she said slowly, “you should finish the book.”

New words formed.

“She did as she was told.”

My hands moved without me. Fingers clattering, filling in paragraphs I could not see, the text sliding too fast. I tried to pull them back; tendons burned, but the motion kept going.

“The house is hungry,” I typed. Or it typed. “Stories are houses we invite ourselves into. You built this one with no exits.”

Tears blurred the screen. I tried to hit Power. Nothing. Tried to close the window. The mouse would not move.

On the wall, the door’s outline darkened. Its knob budded like mold, solidifying.

Scratch-scratch-scratch.

“The only way out,” the manuscript wrote, “is through the next mind. Through the next pair of eyes.”

The door on my wall shuddered, as if something behind it had put its ear against the wood. Listening.

“Please,” I whispered.

My laptop’s camera light flared bright green.

The final line appeared, crisp and calm:

“She hit send.”

My finger slammed the key.

Across town, in inboxes and clouds and sync folders, attachments bloomed: The_Hungry_House_FINAL.docx.

The new door opened.

Somewhere, in the silence after you finish this sentence, something that was once only ink and pixels will pause.

Scratch-scratch-scratch.

Did you hear that, or did I write it?

samples.prompt: Make the act of watching paint dry into the most compelling story conceivable.
samples.output:
The first stroke landed like a verdict.

Elias watched the roller breathe color onto the bare wall, swallowing the builder’s beige in a single, smooth pass. The shade he’d chosen was called “Harbor Quiet”—soft blue with the faintest hint of green, like morning sky reflected in shallow water. In the harsh light of the empty apartment, it looked almost white.

He didn’t care. The name had been enough.

He worked with slow, deliberate movements, pressing the roller up, easing it down, the tiny hiss of paint on gypsum like a whispered confession. He painted the wall facing west. Her wall. The one the couch had been against, where the bookshelf had leaned, where Lena had taped postcards from places they’d never see.

“We’ll pick one at random,” she’d said once, fingers pressed to a sun-faded card of Mykonos blue and impossible white. “First one we save enough for, we go.”

They’d saved for other things, and then the postcards stayed postcards.

He dipped the roller, watched paint drip back into the tray. The smell rose around him, an unmistakable sting—solvent and promise. His phone was facedown on the counter, turned to silent. He would not look. The doctors had said there was nothing to be done now but wait.

So he painted.

When the wall was fully covered, he leaned the roller in the tray and stepped back. Harbor Quiet. He tried to see the quiet in it.

The damp paint caught the dying afternoon light and held it, glossy, new. Not yet itself. Still becoming.

He pulled an old dining chair into the center of the room and sat, elbows on his knees, eyes fixed on the wall.

He had nothing else that did not hurt.

At first, nothing happened.

Of course nothing happened, he thought. It’s paint. It dries. That’s all.

Still, he watched.

The wet sheen shivered almost imperceptibly, the way a lake’s surface reorganizes itself after a thrown stone. The streaks where the roller had overlapped began to blur, edges bleeding together until the stroke-marks softened. Near the ceiling, a brighter gleam slowly dulled into matte. The wall, once patchy with rectangular ghosts, now wore a more even face.

Elias noticed his breathing had fallen into rhythm with something—perhaps the slow, invisible evaporation or the thud of his own pulse, hot in his temples.

He told himself that when the first section turned fully matte, he’d let himself check his phone.

One small bargain inside the larger, crueler wait.

He kept his eyes on a particular patch of paint near the electrical outlet, the size of his palm. It glowed slightly wetter than the rest, a lingering glisten. The light from the window struck it, turned the thin film of liquid into a miniature mirror.

In it, he saw her shoulder.

Not Lena’s as it was now, thin beneath hospital cotton, but as it had been that first summer at the lake, darkened golden, a drop of water sliding down and catching in the hollow above her collarbone.

You’re staring, she’d laughed.

Yeah, he’d said. I am.

The memory surfaced so swiftly and completely that he inhaled as though he could taste wet pine again.

He blinked.

The shimmering patch was only paint.

The wall’s transformation was almost imperceptible, but he was giving it all his attention, so he caught every betrayal, every shift. The ragged overlap marks smoothed. A bubble near the corner fattened, held, then exhaled itself back into flatness. A single hair—his, or hers, he couldn’t tell—was trapped along the edge of the baseboard, embedded like a fossil. Forever a part of the new skin.

He thought: This is it. Right now, while this dries, it is changing. Once it’s done, it will look as if it had always been that way. Nobody will ever know the exact moment gloss became dull, when vulnerability became permanence.

He hadn’t known the exact moment with Lena, either.

At first, it was just fatigue. “I’m tired,” she’d said. They’d blamed work, the late nights. Then the bruises, the tests, the fluorescent room with the grim-faced doctor. Then words like aggressive and metastatic.

He could pinpoint the days, but not the instant her body crossed some invisible threshold from fine to not fine, from treatable to terminal. No one had paused and said, There. It just happened. The paint dried when they weren’t looking.

His gaze sharpened. One corner of the wall darkened, or was that the light changing? The end-of-day sun withdrew, leaving a more honest illumination: the room’s single bare bulb. With that flat white light, the wall showed its emerging truth. The wet sheen had diminished now to occasional glints in the deepest strokes.

His phone remained silent.

He laced his fingers together until they hurt. “Come on,” he murmured, not to the phone, not quite to the universe, but to the wall. As if its finishing would pull time forward, deliver him from this suspended, airless space between what was and what might be.

A faint crackle whispered as the surface film contracted. The paint, bonding to plaster, shrank almost imperceptibly, tugging itself smooth. He leaned closer. The scent had mellowed, from sharp to merely insistent. It layered over the faint trace of her perfume that still clung to the curtains he hadn’t taken down.

There had been a plan: repaint the apartment together when she came home. Something soft. Something calm. Something new.

She’d circled this color with a pale blue pen. “Harbor Quiet. We could use some quiet.”

He had gone to the store alone.

The last streak of glare dulled. He shifted his focus to another spot, pushing the moment of phone-checking forward. There was a strange comfort in this: to have a task that was purely observational, to be needed by something that did not care if he succeeded. Paint would dry whether he watched or not, but right now he needed to believe his vigilance mattered.

He noticed a run forming—a fat, slow tear of paint creeping downward about three inches from the window frame. Tiny, traitorous gravity. He rose, grabbed the brush, feathered it out, erasing the flaw before it set. The correction blended seamlessly.

“There,” he whispered. “Got you.”

He hadn’t caught hers.

The thought sliced clean and deep. Back on the chair, he let it hurt. The wall took the confession without comment.

Outside, a siren wailed and faded. A car door slammed. Somewhere in the building a child laughed, urgent and delighted. Life went on viciously unaware.

Here, time congealed around the simplest of processes, and Elias clung to it.

He traced the edges of the light switch plate with his gaze, admiring the crisp white outline where his taped line had kept the color at bay. There was satisfaction in the precision. In control. So little in his world belonged to him now; the careful dividing of blue and white felt like ownership.

He imagined her walking in, stopping, grinning.

“You did it,” she’d say. “You actually picked a color that isn’t ‘Apartment Landlord Despair.’”

“Just followed instructions,” he’d answer. “You marked it.”

She’d touch the dried wall, press her palm flat against it as though measuring its heartbeat.

“Feels good,” she’d say. “Feels like ours.”

The air caught in his chest.

The wall was very nearly uniform now, the last of the shine clinging stubbornly near the baseboard. That was always the slowest: the thick place where the roller had pressed too hard. He fixed on it, that long glossy arc.

“Dry,” he ordered softly. “Just dry.”

His phone buzzed.

The sound detonated the quiet. He flinched, fingers clawing the edge of the chair. For a heartbeat, two, three, he stayed rooted, eyes locked on the wet segment by the floor as though he could defer the truth if the paint wasn’t done yet.

If this finishes first, he thought, irrationally, she lives.

The bargain was childish, a superstition. But grief and fear make children of everyone.

He watched, desperate, as the gloss diminished cell by microscopic cell. No sound marked the shift. No line appeared. Yet there came a breath in which he knew: it was done. Not perfectly; there were places he’d sand later, a nick he’d fill. But essentially, irreversibly, the paint had crossed over.

From wet to dry.

He stood abruptly, chair legs scraping. The room seemed too small, the air too thick. The phone lay face down, humming once more, then stilling into expectation.

He walked to the wall instead.

Laid his palm against it.

The surface was cool, faintly tacky at the edges, but set. When he lifted his hand, for an instant he thought he’d left a print. But no. The paint held. It bore no mark visible to anyone else.

His heart stuttered.

Only then did he turn to the phone.

One message.

He stared at the screen for a long time before opening it, seeing everything and nothing in that single line from an unknown hospital number.

When he finally read it, his knees tried to go out from under him. He reached blindly back, his palm finding the fresh wall like an anchor.

“Stable,” the message said. “You can come. She’s asking for you.”

Something in his chest loosened like a knot finally given permission to unravel.

He looked at the color again. Harbor Quiet. In this light, he could see it properly: not white at all, but the faintest sea-glass blue, like distant shallows or hospital scrubs left too long in the sun. Soft. Gentle.

He laughed once, a shaky, astonished sound.

“I’ll bring you home to see it,” he whispered to no one and her and the wall.

He grabbed his keys. The paint would go on drying without him, particles aligning, solvents fleeing, color settling into its final, steadfast self.

Later, when they returned—whether for days or months or years—no one would remember how wet it had once looked. No one else would have sat vigil and felt each invisible shift. They would see only a painted wall: calm, clean, inevitable.

But Elias would know what it meant to sit in a room alone and watch something simple commit, second by second, to staying.

The door clicked shut behind him.

The wall, gleaming faintly in the empty hush, kept on becoming solid.

samples.prompt: You doze off while stargazing only to awake to a now starless night sky. You look around and see dots of light floating around. They appear to be connecting to one another, forming lines. You are now in the presence of the Constellations.
samples.output:
I didn’t mean to fall asleep.

The hill was only a hill, the night only a night. A blanket, a thermos, the cheap telescope my father left me. The town’s few streetlights were distant amber ghosts along the horizon, leaving the sky clean and deep and full. Stars pricked through the dark, familiar and indifferent, the way I liked them.

I remember sliding my phone into my backpack. Just you and them, I thought. Stay awake this time.

I watched Orion climb, his belt an easy anchor in the enormous patternless scatter. I traced Cassiopeia’s jagged throne above the pines. Tried and failed, as every summer, to see the shapes as the ancients had: a hunter, a queen, a lion, twins. I could find the dots. The stories never quite stayed.

At some point my eyelids lowered between one blink and the next. The blanket warmed to my body. The telescope’s silhouette blurred into the sky. A cricket’s rasp became an ocean’s hush; my thoughts slipped like loose beads.

Then the world sighed—soft but enormous—and I woke.

Everything was wrong.

The first thing I noticed was the quiet. Not silence—there was wind hissing over the grass, my own startled breath, a distant car muttering along the highway—but the quiet of something missing, an absence that pressed hard behind my eyes. I sat up too fast, my neck flaring with pins and needles, and stared upwards.

No stars.

The sky was black, a dense, velvet black that swallowed depth. Not clouded. Not hazy. Just…empty. The familiar anchor points were gone: no Orion, no broken W of Cassiopeia, no smeared sugar of the Milky Way. Even the planets, those steady impostors, had vanished. The moon was nowhere.

I blinked, rubbed my eyes, looked again.

Empty.

Panic snagged at me with small, sharp hooks. My first, absurd thought was that my vision had gone—some sudden neurological catastrophe while I’d slept. I covered one eye, then the other, swept my hand across the sky. I could see my fingers, the treeline, the outline of the telescope. The darkness above was real. Wrong, but real.

The second thing I noticed was a light.

At first I thought it was ash or fireflies, stray sparks drifting on the breeze. Tiny points of white hung in the air above the grass, not bright enough to sting my eyes but too clear, too defined to be reflections. I pushed my blanket aside and stood, feeling the damp seep through my jeans.

More lights. Dozens. Hundreds.

They rose from the ground, from the spaces between blades of grass, from the hollow of my open palm when I held it out. Little beads the size of pinheads, glowing with their own soft certainty.

“Hello?” I said, because it felt like something was listening.

The dots shivered. They did not swarm so much as consider. Then, like threads catching, some of the nearest ones tugged toward each other. Lines of pale brilliance snapped into existence between them—thin, crisp segments of light, as if someone were drawing in the air with the world’s finest chalk.

I stepped back, heart banging. The dots continued to converge, linking with one another, forming angles, arcs, recognizable shapes I had only ever seen in sky maps. Not realistic images, but diagrams. Skeletons of legends.

It dawned on me then, bold as a caption: I knew these shapes.

Directly before me, a man arched his back, his arms flung wide, a club upraised in one hand. Not a man of flesh: his body was geometry, a lattice of stars. Orion. The belt unmistakable: three lights in a row, tied by beams of luminescence.

To my left, a squashed-looking rectangle unfolded, one corner connected to a tail of dots: the Great Bear, lines tracing the Big Dipper I’d used to find north as a child. To my right, a sharp pair of parallel strokes: Gemini. Above, something like a teapot, the handle and spout picked out in clean angles: Sagittarius.

The night around me filled with them.

They did not tower; they simply were, at all sizes and distances. Some were small enough to fit in my cupped hands, tiny stick-figures of heroes and beasts. Others arced overhead, impossibly vast, their edges slipping beyond my peripheral vision. Lines overlapped and threaded, an impossible tangle that somehow did not tangle at all. I was standing inside a book of star charts brought to impossible life.

I realized my mouth was open. I closed it.

A shape drifted closer, resolving into a five-pointed crown: Cassiopeia. The dots within her frame pulsed, as if in greeting. When she spoke, no mouth moved. Her voice arrived whole in my head, layered and resonant, not quite human but not cold.

“You see us.”

It wasn’t a question.

“I… yes,” I said, my voice dried-out. “Where did the stars go?”

“They are here,” another pattern said. This one stooped with a graceful curve of light, a lyre of strings and frame: Lyra. “We have only stepped down.”

“Down,” repeated a third, and I turned to see the outline of a lion, broad and proud—Leo. His mane was triangles, his spine a line. His eyes, twin beads of fierce gold-white, fixed on me. “Down into your scale.”

“I’m dreaming,” I said. The words felt flimsy.

A laugh rippled through the shapes, some silent chord passing between them. Overhead, a great scorpion’s tail flicked, its barbed end leaving a faint glowing smear in the air.

“If this were dream,” Orion said, taking a step toward me, “we would not need to explain ourselves.”

“Explain what?” I asked. Fear had plateaued into a surreal calm. Maybe this was shock. Maybe acceptance.

“Our absence,” said Cassiopeia.

“The theft,” said Leo.

“The choice,” murmured Lyra.

Behind them, new figures had joined. A winged horse, Pegasus, his rectangular body marked by four steadfast points. A swan, Cygnus, arms stretched crosswise like an unstrung crucifix. A pair of fish linked by a loop: Pisces. More and more, until my mind could barely fit all the names. The sky was empty because the map had come down to stand on the hill with me.

I swallowed. “Who stole what?”

“You,” said a low, wry voice near my feet.

I looked down. A cluster of stars in the shape of a scorpion’s curl peered up at me. His tail arched; his claws flexed as if made of spun glass. Scorpius, of course, small but radiating offense.

“Not you, singular,” Lyra amended gently. “You, plural. Your kind.”

“You took us,” Leo said. “Our names. Our myths. You hammered us into your telescopes and hung us in your stories. You drew our lines, froze our faces. You built machines that peer farther, measure finer, number what cannot be numbered and tell yourselves that in accounting for us you have understood us.”

“We loved you,” I blurted, too quickly. It was a childish protest, but it was also true. “We named you because we loved you. So we could find you again. So we could teach others to look up.”

A hush fell. Five bright points in Cassiopeia’s frame brightened, then dimmed.

“We have worn your love,” she said, slower. “For long arcs of your small histories, we consented to be caught in your net of lines. You made us stories to endure your storms. We bent.”

The Big Dipper’s handle swung thoughtfully. “But then you forgot what was yours and what was not.”

“The satellites,” Orion said. “The streaks across our faces. The glare that drowns us. The cities that erase us from your children’s sight.”

“The claims,” Scorpius added. “Constellation of this corporation. Constellation of that empire. A network here, a network there. You use our name for your nests of metal, your webs of radio.”

Pisces’ tethered fish twitched. “You built your own constellations and never sought our blessing.”

Somewhere above, a vast, scattered woman—the faint sketch of Andromeda—stretched until her reaching hand crossed half the sky.

“So,” said Leo. “We have come to ask.”

I was suddenly, painfully aware of the chilled dew on my ankles, the stiffness in my legs, the absurdity of standing barefoot in mortal skin before beings whose bones had once been distances between suns.

“Ask what?” My voice shrank.

“Whether to stay,” Lyra said.

“As names,” Cassiopeia clarified.

“As stories you recognize,” added Cygnus, wings shivering lines of light.

“If we withdraw,” Orion said, “you will look up and see only unmarked dark. No hunters. No queens. No balance, no scorpion, no lion. Only physics. Only numbers. Stars will burn, but they will not be yours.”

“If we remain,” murmured Pegasus, “we accept that we belong also to you.”

I understood, suddenly, the bare sky. This was not disappearance. It was a union meeting.

“Why me?” I asked. It came out too honest. “I’m nobody.”

“You are awake,” said Cassiopeia simply.

“You left your screen,” said Scorpius.

“You remember some of our names,” Lyra added, with a warmth that made my throat ache.

“Sometimes,” Orion said, “that is all the qualification required.”

Wind passed over the hill, bending the long grass into ripples. The dots swayed but their lines held.

“If I say yes?” I asked. “If I say stay?”

“Then you return to your kind with the story that we are not decoration,” Leo said. “We are covenant.”

“And if I say no?”

“Then we go back up,” said Pegasus. “But not as you knew us.”

“No names,” whispered Pisces. “No lines.”

“Your children will grow under blankness,” Cygnus said. “The universe will still be, but it will not speak your language.”

The choice expanded in my chest like a slow, cold bloom. Who was I to speak for anyone? Yet the night was waiting. The constellations did not press, did not plead. They simply were: luminous, patient, immense.

I thought of the first time my father had pointed out Orion to me, his finger tracing the belt, his voice reverent. I thought of lying under a suburban sky washed pale, counting the handful of visible stars and feeling cheated, as if an inheritance had been lost. I thought of how we strap cameras to rockets, flinging them into the dark to catch the light that left before we had words.

“We need you,” I said quietly. “Even if we don’t act like it. Stay. But we’ll try to be better. I’ll try.”

“Will you remind them,” Cassiopeia said, “that naming is not owning?”

“Yes.”

“Will you remind them,” Lyra said, “that not all that glitters in their sky is theirs to bind into profit?”

“Yes.”

“Will you remind them,” Leo rumbled, “to turn off a few damn lights?”

A surprised laugh shook out of me. “I can try.”

The constellations brightened. It was not joy exactly, but something like acceptance.

“Then we will remain,” Orion said.

One by one, the lines began to lift.

The dots that made Orion’s shoulders rose, trailing their connections like silk threads drawing upward. Cassiopeia’s five-pointed frame unfolded back into the firmament. Leo’s proud head arched to some infinite distance, scattering mane-stars into the waiting void. Lyra’s strings straightened into a tiny diamond high above. Scorpius skittered up an invisible wall, curling into a familiar hook near the horizon.

They did not vanish; they took their places.
