Light returned to the sky—not all at once, but in blossoms. First the bright, bold points, then the fainter embers. The Milky Way spilled itself, grain by grain, across the renewed black. Lines faded, but the memory of them lingered, etched sharper than any chart in my mind.

As the last of the close-floating dots rose, Cassiopeia’s shape paused, one star lingering just above my head.

“Do not fall asleep again,” her voice brushed against my thoughts, almost fond. “Next time, bring others.”

Then she slipped into the sky, completing her W among the countless restored lights.

I stood alone on the hill, the night now full and familiar and altered forever. The world below slept, unaware that its stories had nearly gone on strike.

I lay back down on the damp blanket, eyes wide open, tracing the constellations by their agreed-upon lines, feeling for the first time that they might be tracing me back.

samples.prompt: A werewolf considers biting a dying person to keep them alive.
samples.output:
The smell of iron was everywhere.

It clung to the hospital curtains, rode the humming fluorescent lights, embedded itself in the pale blue of the bedsheets. Machines whispered flatly; soft green numbers counted meaningless seconds. Beside the bed, a nurse adjusted a drip with gloved hands, eyes tired and kind and utterly mortal.

Luca watched from the far corner, half-shadowed by a plastic ficus and a privacy curtain that didn’t quite close. He kept his spine straight, hands loose at his sides so he would not claw the vinyl flooring.

“Family only, hon,” the nurse said, not unkindly.

“I’m his brother,” Luca replied. The lie had been easier a year ago, when the resemblance hadn’t yet faded so much. Now, with his skin a little too pale between full moons, his irises ringed faintly gold, and the way his stillness looked like held breath instead of calm, it was more of a performance.

The nurse studied him, then the man in the bed. “He’s heavily sedated. He might not wake up again.” Her tone gentled even further. “If you need anything…”

“Thank you,” Luca said. She left, and the door clicked shut.

Silence settled, punctuated by the soft hiss and beep, beep, beep.

Aaron’s chest rose and fell shallowly under the thin blanket. Tubes and taped lines adorned his arms like macabre jewelry. His lips were cracked. Without the beard he’d worn for a decade, his face looked startled and young, as if he’d just woken up on the wrong train.

A thin plastic bracelet dug into his wrist. Aaron Cole. 42. Terminal glioblastoma. Palliative care.

A month ago, Aaron had been walking—shuffling, really—through the park when Luca caught his scent on the wind: cedar soap, printer ink, and the sharp metal tang that meant tumors multiplying where soft brain should be. Luca had followed, silent on the path, watching the man lower himself to a bench with the weariness of someone twice his age.

“Rough day?” Luca had asked, because sometimes he forgot that other people did not track each other’s pulses by sound.

Aaron had laughed once, harsh and honest. “I’ve had better,” he’d said, rubbing his temple. “You ever feel like there’s something eating you from the inside out?”

Luca had almost said: Yes. Every twenty-eight days. Instead, he’d shrugged. “You look like you could use a beer.”

It had gone from there. Idle park conversations. Shared cigarettes, despite Luca never lighting his. Games of chess where Aaron’s hands shook over the pieces. Truth told in helpless increments: scan results, percentages, words like “aggressive” and “inoperable.” Luca’s own truths offered in edited fragments: insomnia, family issues, a vague genetic condition that “complicated” transfusions. He never thought friendships he made would last long. Being what he was made attachments cruel. But he liked Aaron. Liked his bitter jokes. Liked how he talked about his daughter, Ellie, like she hung the moon.

“She’s fourteen,” Aaron had said once, soft with awe and frustration. “She thinks I’m immortal and stupid at the same time.”

“You’re definitely one of those,” Luca had said.

Now the machines whispered and Aaron looked small. Ellie had been here earlier, curled in the plastic visitor’s chair, cheeks wet, fingers knotted in his gown. She’d left when the nurse insisted she rest, led away by an aunt who smelled like exhausted anger.

Luca had stayed.

“Hey,” Luca murmured, stepping closer. “It’s me.”

No response.

He took in the slow, laboring breaths. The faint bluish tinge at the fingernails. The smell of cells surrendering. The tumor’s scent was different now—overripe, almost sweet. The wolf inside him did not recoil. The wolf was pragmatic. Meat was meat, sickness or not. Life and death were points on a circle.

By your nature, you are the cure, his maker had told him once, running a claw lightly over his arm. And the disease, she’d added later, when he’d begged them to change his mother and they’d refused.

He could end this. He could save him.

Not save, he corrected himself. Change the terms. Trade time for blood and fur and hunger. Trade one disease for another.

He imagined it: his teeth sliding into the crook of Aaron’s elbow, where the dull human needle already pierced. The hot burst of blood, the body’s startle. The virus in Luca’s saliva—a legacy older than words—rushing through, tearing through the cancer cells as easily as the healthy ones, rewriting, remaking. The monitors spiking wildly, then leveling as the body rebuilt.

He’d seen it. The viral curse was greedy, clever. It cleaned as it conquered. The bitten rarely died of their prior wounds, so long as there was enough of them left to knit from. Limbs regrew. Organs scarred over shiny and new. Brain tissue, though—brain was tricky. Still, he’d seen a woman with a bullet lodged near her spine rise two days after the bite, golden-eyed and furious.

Could it scrub away a tumor? Probably. Maybe. The uncertainty seethed like acid.

“Don’t be a coward,” he whispered to himself. “Decide.”

He had rules. They all did. Biting was for defense, for threat, for the rare, carefully chosen recruit. Never for sentiment. Never for loneliness. Never for one mortal man in a hospital bed.

“You shouldn’t even be here.”

Luca flinched; the voice came from inside, from a memory of his maker’s gravelly disapproval. She’d walked away from a hundred pleading eyes. “We’re not angels. We are not a cure.”

But he could. Right now, he could.

“If I wake up furry, I’m suing,” a rasp muttered.

Luca looked down. Aaron’s eyes were slitted open, unfocused, but trying. A ghost of his usual grin tugged at one corner of his mouth.

“You don’t have a case,” Luca said reflexively. “You signed like twelve waivers.”

Aaron’s gaze slid blearily around, then settled on him. “Hey,” he exhaled. “How long was I out?”

“About an hour.”

“How bad?”

Luca hesitated. “They think… tonight or tomorrow.”

Aaron closed his eyes briefly. One tear escaped, tracking down the sharp plane of his cheek. “Figures. Ellie?”

“With your sister,” Luca said. “She’ll be back in the morning.”

“If I’m still… yeah.” He swallowed. “You look like hell, by the way. You sleep?”

“On odd days,” Luca said. “Sometimes.”

“Idiot.” Aaron wheezed a laugh that turned into a cough. The monitors fussed until his breathing steadied.

Silence stretched. Luca could taste every molecule of it.

“I need to tell you something,” Luca said.

“Gonna… profess your undying love?” Aaron whispered.

“Undying’s one word for it,” Luca said. His mouth was dry. He stepped closer, so the overhead light etched hollows beneath his eyes.

“Aaron. What if there was a way… not to die. Not now. To keep going. But it would mean… a different life. A hard one. Dangerous. You’d have to leave Ellie, at least for a while. Not forever, but—”

“Stop.” Aaron’s fingers twitched weakly toward him, and Luca took his hand, surprised at its lightness. “Spare me the... fantasy clinical trial pitch. I Googled everything. I know when they start saying ‘miracle.’ It’s what they say before they let you go.”

“It’s not that,” Luca said. His voice came out rougher. “It’s not… human medicine. It’s me.”

Something like clarity flickered in Aaron’s gaze. “You’re scaring me a little, man.”

“I’m not… exactly what you think I am,” Luca forced out. “I’m the reason I don’t drink with you. The reason I only meet at night. The reason I always know when the nurses are coming down the hall.” He inhaled, let his eyes slip gold for a heartbeat.

Aaron’s breath caught. “Contacts,” he tried.

Luca let his teeth lengthen, just enough for Aaron to see the sharpness. Hurt flared in his gums. He pulled his lip back, a small, terrible smile.

Aaron stared. The monitors ticked on.

“No,” Aaron whispered.

“Yes.”

“That real?” His voice shook. “God. So, what, like—”

“Like stories,” Luca said. “Like monsters. Like a virus that doesn’t care what you were before.”

Aaron closed his eyes. “And you’re offering me that.”

“I’m considering it.”

“Why?”

Because I don’t want you to die. Because watching you fade feels like that first winter after I turned, when everything I knew slipped away and walking back home meant smelling my own grave.

Instead he said, “Because you’re not done. Because Ellie needs you. Because it would kill her.”

“That’s not fair,” Aaron whispered. “To use her like that.”

“No,” Luca agreed.

Aaron’s hand squeezed his, surprisingly firm. “What’s the catch?”

Luca swallowed. “Hunger that owns you. Things you’ll have to do or spend every waking second stopping yourself from doing. People you’ll hurt, even trying not to. Sunlight becomes your enemy, the moon your boss. You outlive everyone, unless you bite them too, and that’s its own curse. You’d have to disappear so they don’t notice you stop aging. You’d probably miss her whole high school. College. You see her again when she’s grown, with kids who smell like half you and half someone else, and she’s looking for her father’s face and finds yours unchanged.”

He heard the bitterness in his own words.

“Sounds… lonely,” Aaron murmured.

“It is.”

“Does it hurt?”

“The change? Yes. Living with it?” Luca exhaled. “Sometimes less than this.”

Aaron’s gaze flicked to the bag hanging from the IV pole. “You really think it’d fix this?” he asked. “The… thing in my head.”

“I think so. Probably. I don’t know,” Luca said. “We don’t have a lot of data.”

Aaron actually smiled at that. “You nerd.”

“I’m serious. I don’t want to lie to you.”

“Too late,” Aaron said gently. “You lied by not telling me sooner.”

That landed. Luca looked away. “I didn’t think we’d… that I’d care this much.”

“Oh, man,” Aaron sighed. “That sucks.”

They let the machines talk for a while.

“I’m scared,” Aaron admitted finally, voice small. “Not of… afterward. Of leaving her alone. Her mom’s gone. It’s just me.” His lips trembled. “What kind of father lets a monster bite him and vanish?”

Luca flinched as if struck.

“She’d hate me,” Aaron went on. “Or worse, she’d follow. She’d spend her life looking for ghosts.”

“You’d be alive,” Luca said. “You could watch over her from a distance. Send money. Anonymous scholarships. Be a shadow.”

“She needs a dad, not a shadow,” Aaron said. His eyelids drooped.

“You’d have centuries,” Luca insisted, desperate. “We find ways. We have rules. We don’t have to be—”

“You said you’re a monster,” Aaron cut in softly. “You believe that?”

“Yes.” The word hurt.

“And you want to make me one to ease your conscience.”

Luca opened his mouth, closed it. The wolf stirred uneasily.

“That’s not all of it,” he managed.

“No,” Aaron agreed. “But it’s in there.”

They watched each other.

“Can you promise I won’t hurt her?” Aaron asked.

“No.”

“Can you promise I won’t wake up starving and kill someone on reflex?”

“No.”

“Can you promise she’ll forgive me?” he whispered.

Luca shook his head.

“Then I think you know the answer.”

Anger flared hot, feral. “So you’ll just die,” Luca snapped. “You’ll leave her.”

“She’ll survive,” Aaron said. “People do. Kids do. They break, then mend strange, but they go on. That’s what being human is.”

“You don’t have to be human,” Luca said. “You could be—”

“You,” Aaron said. There was no malice. Just tired comprehension. “You didn’t choose, did you?”

Luca looked at the bedrail. The memory rose, unwelcome: an alley, too much blood, a woman’s cool hand on his cheek. You can go now, she’d said. Or you can come with me.

“No,” he said. “I didn’t choose.”

Aaron exhaled. “Then let me.”

The words settled between them like a verdict.

Luca’s fingers tightened around Aaron’s. He could feel the weak, frantic flutter of his pulse. He could stop it. He could send his own wild beast racing through this failing body.

“You might hate me tomorrow,” Luca whispered. “If I don’t.”

“I won’t be here to hate you,” Aaron said. “That’s the point.”

“That’s not comforting.”

“It’s honest.” A pause. “Hey. Look at me.”

Luca did.

“Promise you’ll check on her. On Ellie,” Aaron said. “From your creepy shadows. Make sure she doesn’t… fall off the map.”

“That’s a lot to ask of a monster,” Luca said, trying to smile.

“I’ve seen you set your coffee down to pick up a worm off the sidewalk,” Aaron said. “You’re the softest monster I’ve ever met. Promise.”

Luca’s throat burned. “I promise.”

“Good.” Aaron’s eyes closed. “Then let me go.”

The wolf prowled, restless, offended. It wanted to bite, to claim, to expand its pack. To defy the whispered finality of this room.

Luca leaned down. For a moment, his open mouth hovered above the curve of Aaron’s wrist, where the skin was thin and the veins blue. His teeth tingled.

One bite. One second of madness. And everything would change.

Aaron’s breath rattled. “Luca?”

“I’m here,” Luca said.

“Don’t,” Aaron murmured.

The decision landed, heavy and sharp. Luca pulled back.

He pressed his lips, human-dull, against Aaron’s knuckles instead. “Okay.”

Later, when the monitors screamed and then fell into a monotone that tore the world in half, Luca was already standing in the corner again, eyes dry and burning, hands empty.

The nurse rushed in. People moved around the bed, voices urgent, then resigned. Time did what it always did: it went on.

No one noticed the man in the corner slip out. No one smelled the wild on him, or the sorrow.

On the sidewalk outside, under a thin slice of moon, Luca tipped his head back and let his eyes burn gold in the dark. Somewhere across the city, a girl who smelled like Aaron’s laughter was crying into a borrowed pillow. Somewhere within his chest, the wolf paced and paced and did not understand mercy, or consent, or promises.

“You could have saved him,” it snarled.

“No,” Luca said softly, to himself, to the night. “I could have kept him breathing.”

He started walking toward the street where Ellie lived.

He was a monster. He would be her shadow.

Some choices, he thought, weren’t given. Others, you had to live with. Forever.

samples.prompt: With a quivering hand you finally utter "That's it, I'll kill everyone...."
samples.output:
With a quivering hand you finally utter, “That’s it, I’ll kill everyone…”

Silence holds the room like a fist. The words drop between you and your reflection, and the bathroom mirror, spotted with old toothpaste flecks and faint scratches, returns your gaze without flinching. You look deranged. Not movie-deranged, not theatrically monstrous. Just… frayed. Like someone who ran out of road a long time ago but kept driving on shards of glass because there was nowhere else to go.

You stare into your own eyes long enough to see the tremor in them, too. You don’t sound like you. You don’t feel like you. But the words slip out again, softer, testing their weight.

“I’ll kill everyone.”

Your throat tightens, and suddenly it’s harder to breathe. This is what monsters say, isn’t it? The ones that were wronged, humiliated, crushed. The ones the world laughs at until the screaming starts. You meant it when you said it. You want to mean it now.

Behind the bathroom door, the apartment hums with the tiny sounds of an indifferent world: the ticking of the cheap clock on the wall, the muffled traffic six floors below, someone laughing in the hall. That laugh flares something inside your chest, hot and feral.

They laughed at you today.

You’d walked into that meeting prepared. Slides, printouts, three nights of lost sleep hanging under your eyes like bruises. You knew the numbers. You knew where the leaks were, how to fix them. They’d asked for initiative; you’d brought them a map. And Peterson, with his lazy smirk and his expensive tie and his inherited position, had leaned back, glanced at your work for nine seconds, then picked one line—one line—and said, “This is why we leave strategy to people who understand the big picture.”

The room had laughed. Of course it had. A small laugh, a polite laugh, but it was laughter all the same.

Thirty minutes later your project was reassigned.

Three hours later the promotion list went out.

Your name wasn’t on it.

Ha ha.

It’s never just one thing. It’s all of them. It’s the way your mother’s voice still lives in your skull, sharp and disappointed. The way your father’s silence swallowed every apology you tried to give him. The way teachers said “almost” about you, so often that “almost” feels sewn into your skin. Almost smart enough. Almost leadership material. Almost stable.

Almost a person.

And today, when you came home early with the polite corporate knife still lodged between your shoulders, you walked in on what should have destroyed you instantly—but instead did something stranger.

Your partner on the couch, your best friend leaning over them, their mouths pressed together.

They didn’t see you at first.

You froze, grocery bag slipping from your hand, tomatoes bouncing across the floor. Then they jerked apart, faces crumpling into shock, then guilt, then concern. That concern was the worst part. Like you were something fragile that needed carefully worded explanations.

“I’m so sorry,” your partner said.

“It just happened,” your best friend said.

“Please, listen,” they both said.

You didn’t shout. You didn’t cry. You watched your heart step out of your chest, look back at you, and shrug. And then everything inside went cold and very, very clear.

Now, in the harsh bathroom light, your cheeks are dry. No tears. None left to give.

You lean close to the mirror and study your lips as they shape the words again. “I’ll kill everyone.”

They taste bitter and childish. They make you want to laugh at yourself. You imagine yourself standing on a desk at work, shouting it. Storming into your partner’s parents’ house, shouting it. Scribbling it in blood-red letters on the walls.

I’ll kill everyone.

Everyone who made you small.

Everyone who looked at you like you were a temporary inconvenience.

Everyone who trained you so well to swallow it all until it curdled into this.

Your hand moves without you deciding, reaching under the sink. Past the bleach, the rusted shaving blades, the half-used bottle of drain cleaner. You find the black case wedged behind the plumbing. You’d forgotten it was here. Or you told yourself you had.

You unzip it. The pistol lies inside, wrapped in a discolored towel. Old weight. Clean metal. A mistake you made years ago after a break-in two floors down. You went to a gun range twice and then hid the thing away. You never sold it. You never got rid of it.

You hear his voice then. Not Peterson’s. Not your father’s. The instructor at the range. Calm, rehearsed.

“Most people who buy a gun for protection never actually imagine using it. They imagine a version of themselves who will.”

You thought that version of you was braver. You didn’t realize it might just be more broken.

Your fingers close around the grip. Perfect fit. Your thumb grazes the safety. All it would take is learning one more habit. One more role.

You stand. The light flickers. You think: If I walk out there with this, if I knock on doors, if I wait in parking garages, it all changes. There is a before and an after.

You picture headlines. Coworkers’ names. Your partner’s face, your best friend’s face. Peterson’s stupid tie crumpled, red blooming across white.

And something unexpected shivers through you: boredom.

You blink at your reflection. “Seriously?” you whisper.

You see it all played out like a cheap series finale. Sirens, grainy photos of you in better lighting, coworkers saying, “I had no idea.” Your name trending for forty-eight hours. Think pieces. People arguing about mental health, about gun laws, about toxic workplaces, without knowing your favorite song, or how you tried to be kind, or how careful you were with everyone else’s feelings.

You imagine holding the gun up, the recoil, screams. You imagine the moment when the rage is supposed to climax into catharsis.

But you don’t feel catharsis in the fantasy. You feel… tired. Tired and cliché.

“That’s it,” you say again, softer now. “I’ll kill everyone.”

You listen closely to yourself this time. You hear the crack in it. You hear the emptiness.

You think of the word “everyone.”

Peterson, sure. Your partner. Your best friend. The supervisor who let your ideas be plagiarized. The stranger who knocked your coffee out of your hand last week and didn’t apologize. Your mother. Your father. Yourself.

Because it wouldn’t stop at “them.” Once you cross the line, you’re one of the people you hate. You’d be the worst of them. The final proof that they were right about you. Too emotional. Too unstable. Too much.

Everyone would look back and edit the story to make sense of it.

Of course they snapped.

You picture your mother saying into a camera, “We tried to get them help.” Your father staring at the ground. Your coworkers remembering when you were quiet in the break room. Your partner insisting there were signs.

The narrative writes itself. You become a lesson, not a person.

The gun feels heavier.

Very slowly, you set it on the edge of the sink.

Killing everyone is easy in your mouth. It tastes powerful when you’re drowning. But power built out of annihilation is just another trap. It ends with you in a cage or a coffin, your rage neatly filed in someone else’s chapter about statistics.

The mirror doesn’t blink. You wish it would look away.

“I don’t want this,” you say, and your voice cracks on want.

You don’t want to forgive them, either. You don’t want to turn the other cheek, or write a gratitude list, or whatever nonsense lives in pastel self-help books. You want the world to feel the pain it put into you. You want them scared.

A thought comes, unwelcome and honest: What if “everyone” doesn’t mean them?

What if it means:

Everyone who gets to choose your value.

Everyone whose voice is louder in your head than your own.

Everyone you’ve let sit behind your eyes and puppet your worth.

Peterson doesn’t live here, but you replay his words. Your mother doesn’t live here, but you hear her criticism when you fold your laundry. Your father’s silence, your partner’s apology, your friend’s stammer—those echoes crowd your skull. They are your “everyone” long before they’re bodies.

Killing them wouldn’t silence that crowd. It would feed it.

But killing their place in you—killing your obedience to them—might.

You pick up the gun again, this time like it’s evidence, not solution. You unload it with clumsy fingers, rounds clinking against porcelain. You don’t fully trust yourself yet, so you move quickly. Gun in one hand, phone in the other.

You google the nearest police station. You google “gun buyback near me.” You don’t know exactly what you’ll do, only that the gun does not stay here tonight.

“That’s it,” you whisper, voice steadier. “I’ll kill everyone.”

And now you know who.

The everyones just became:

- The voice that says you are almost enough.
- The habit of swallowing words until they rot.
- The reflex that accepts humiliation as normal.
- The quiet agreements that let people use you without consequence.

You look at yourself—red eyes, clenched jaw, shoulders squared with something that is not righteousness yet, but closer to choice.

“I’ll kill everyone that thinks they own me,” you say. “In here.”

You tap your temple.

It isn’t redemption. It isn’t forgiveness. It’s not even particularly noble. It’s survival, raw and inelegant. It will take time. You will fail at it, relapse into the old scripts. You will think of Peterson, your partner, your friend, and feel surges of hatred that make your palms itch.

But you step out of the bathroom without the gun in your waistband. That, today, is the line you choose not to cross.

In the living room, your partner and your friend sit with their guilt, rehearsed explanations curling on their tongues. They look up when you emerge. They see something new in your face and mistake it for the wrong thing.

“Can we talk?” your partner asks.

“Yes,” you say. “But not the way you think.”

Your hand no longer trembles.

“First,” you continue, “you’re both going to leave.”

Shock. Protests. You hold up a hand, and to your own surprise, they fall silent.

You’re not merciful. You’re not monstrous. You’re something else.

You’re the person who almost broke bad, who almost became a headline.

Almost.

And that “almost,” for once, is what saves everyone.

samples.prompt: The so-called heroes are dead and you, the dark goddess, rule the world. And now all those who fought against you are begging for your forgiveness. Not because they hope to avoid your wrath, but because you turned out be a just ruler and they genuinely regret having opposed you.
samples.output:
I receive their apologies in a ruined cathedral whose god never answered prayers.

Once, this place was alabaster and gold, the vaulted ceiling arched like open wings, stained glass throwing holy colors over sharpened steel. They called it sanctified. They carved my name into their sermons as the ultimate blasphemy. Now, ivy threads through shattered windows, red light seeps in from a sun lowered on its axis, and the mosaics have fallen like flaking scabs from the walls. The air smells of damp stone and cooling wax. It is quieter than it has any right to be, considering the line that spirals from the cracked steps back to the plaza, from the plaza along the avenue, and on and on, disappearing into the distance like some contrite serpent.

They have come to beg.

Not for their lives. It is too late for that fear to move them, and they know I do not slaughter for sport. Not for their lands; those they forfeited when they marched under stolen banners and sang hymns about casting me down. No, they have come with words trembling on their tongues, with guilt like lead in their throats.

They have finally realized I was right.

A former paladin kneels first. I know his name, though he does not expect me to. Sir Aldren of the White Flame, the one who swore, voice shaking with boyish fervor, to plunge his sword into my heart at the final battle. He did not reach me; his arm broke under the recoil of my power, his sword melted into slag when it met my shadow. He lived. I let him. That bothered him more than death ever could have.

Now his armor is scuffed and ill-fitted, missing its sigils. He has gone soft in the months since the war, sleeping through nights not shattered by screams. His hair has more gray. He presses his forehead to the cold floor before my throne of carved obsidian and bone.

“Dark Lady,” he says, the old insult stripped from his tone. “I was wrong.”

A pleasant thing, to hear aloud.

“About what?” I ask, though I know. Though I remember him calling me demon and tyrant, his words ringing off the stone while priests anointed his brow. Though I remember him charging into my ranks, believing dying would be a final argument. Though I remember his eyes when my magic washed over his army, not killing, but stripping away hunger and plague, mending broken limbs, dissolving the whips from slavers’ hands like rot eaten from within.

He swallows. “We believed… I believed you would burn the world. We were told you fed on souls, that you’d enthrone yourself on corpses. We fought for the old order, because we were told it was holy. But since your reign…”

He falters. I wait. Time is mine; I can be generous with it.

“You have ended the famines,” he says at last. “You broke the chains. You tore down the tithe-houses and opened the granaries. The noble lords… they cannot gut villages for sport anymore. The priests cannot sell absolution to the highest bidder. The roads are safe. The healers you sent cured my sister’s child of the wasting. No one turned them away because they were poor. You brought night to their power, and it was… it was mercy.”

His voice cracks on that last word.

Behind him, there is only silence. Thousands of ears listening.

“I was wrong,” he repeats. “I came to ask your forgiveness. Not to live. Just… to be less wrong than I have been.”

I could remind him of the villages my acolytes burned in my name before I took full control, the chaos of prophecy drawing broken minds. I corrected them later, but the scars remain. I could remind him I razed three cities that refused to abandon their altars built on human bones. I could say: Your world is better, yes, but I am not gentle. You opposed me because you were told a story that fit your fear. That story needed blood. You gave it freely.

Instead, I regard him. I see the boy he was, the cracked-voiced man he became, the weary penitent now.

“Stand,” I say.

He flinches as if struck.

“I— Your Majesty, I—”

“Stand,” I repeat, and he obeys, joints stiff, gaze fixed somewhere at my throat, unable yet to meet my eyes.

“You are sorry for believing lies,” I say. “But you are more sorry for the harm you’ve realized you caused. You regret the orphans left in your crusade’s wake, the fields salted on your march, the peasants strung up as my supposed sympathizers. You regret that you mistook cruelty for holiness because it wore the right colors.”

His hands shake.

“Yes,” he whispers.

“I forgive you,” I say.

The word is simple. It is thunder in the hush.

His shoulders jerk. Tears drag down his face, hot and helpless. He bows again, deeper, but this time not in worship of an idol and not in terror. This bow is older than their hollow religion; it is the bow of one human to something vaster and, confoundingly, kinder than they were promised.

“Live well,” I tell him. “If you would serve penance, spend the rest of your days using your strength to protect those you once harmed in idea, if not in deed. Teach them that righteousness and cruelty are not the same.”

“I will,” he says.

He steps aside, stumbling. The line shifts; the next supplicant approaches.

A priestess. Her vestments are threadbare, the gold thread picked out, melted down by my decree to fund public aqueducts and hospitals. Once, she spoke sermons about me as an apocalypse in flesh. Now, her hair is uncovered, her shaved crown growing in awkward stubble.

“Lady of Night,” she murmurs, kneeling. She does not call me goddess. That would be too easy for her. Old habits die hard.

“You orchestrated the witch hunts,” I say, before she can speak. “You blessed the spears that killed children who dreamed in strange colors.”

She flinches. “Yes.”

“And now?” I ask.

“I see that the children you called blessed starved outside our sealed temples,” she replies, voice tight. “And the ‘witch spawn’ you hunted are the ones you elevated. Your scholars, your engineers, your healers. You took the broken and made them your chosen. You gave them libraries. You gave them power. If we had not feared them—if I had not feared them—this world might have been healed sooner.”

Her confession is bitter. The crowd outside presses closer, listening through the open doors.

“I am sorry,” she says. “Not because I fear punishment. You already stripped us of our altars, and you did worse to those who would not relent. I am sorry because I see it now: my faith wore beauty and spoke of light, but it required darkness like mine to survive. And when you came in honest darkness, you brought better light than we ever did.”

I lean back.

“It is a strange thing, is it not,” I say, “that they called me dark for telling the truth about my nature, while they wore white and lied about theirs.”

She lets out a shaky laugh. “Yes.”

“Stand,” I tell her as well.

She does, unsteady as a newborn deer.

“You taught lies,” I say. “You will spend the rest of your life unteaching them. You will go to the villages that still curse my name when storms roll in, and you will say: we were wrong; she is not what we told you. You will feed the hungry with the hands that once collected coin. You will tend the sick with the hands that held the knife. That is your absolution.”

Tears spill over, but she nods. “I will.”

“I forgive you,” I say.

Her shoulders sag with something like relief and something like grief. She steps away.

Forgiveness is not weakness. They believed it was. They believed mercy was sentimental, a crack in the armor. They did not understand that forgiveness is a form of power: the power to define what the wrong was, the power to extract from remorse a debt repaid in service rather than blood.

Understand this: I did not spare all of them. Some I shattered, loudly and publicly. There are tyrants carved into stone along the northern road, their immortalized screams warning anyone who would resurrect their ways. There are battlefields salted with the bones of men who would not lay down their blades even when offered a better world.

Justice is not the absence of cruelty. Justice is the presence of consequences proportionate to the harm done, and a path to atonement if one is willing to walk it barefoot.

A young woman approaches now, not a paladin, not a priest. She is thin and pale, her hands roughened by work. She wears no insignia.

“I opposed you,” she says, without prompting. “I threw stones at your soldiers when they passed. I hid the men who hunted your mages. I spat when your banners went up.”

“Why?” I ask.

“They burned my cousin by mistake,” she says. “She had the spark, but she never hurt anyone. Some warlock used your name. They said it was in your honor. I didn’t know you had ordered it stopped. All I saw was fire.”

Ah. The rot of my own making, from before I consolidated, before every fanatic understood my law. Not all wounds in this new world were dealt by the old.

“And now?” I ask.

“Now I have food,” she says simply. “I have a roof. Your people rebuilt our well. My brother is learning letters. The magistrate listened when I said my foreman hit us. He is gone now. They said it was by your decree.”

“It was,” I say.

She nods. “I came to say I’m sorry for hating you when you were the first one who ever cared if I lived.”

There is no theater here, no trembling piety. Just a girl who has lost enough to know gratitude costs less than bitterness.

“You owed me no faith without evidence,” I say. “Your hate was misdirected, but understandable.”

“Do you forgive me?” she asks.

I find myself smiling, faint, a small fracture in the carved obsidian of my composure.

“Yes,” I say, and mean it gently. “Go. Live. Grow old. Teach your brother not to worship me, but to judge me by what I do. If I ever fail him, tell him to shout.”

“I will,” she says, and almost grins.

They keep coming. Generals whose campaigns I crushed. Scholars who wrote treatises damning me as chaos incarnate, now citing my legal codes as the foundation of a rational era. Common folk who resisted the conscription of my builders, then walked on the roads those conscripts laid and felt shame.

I forgive most of them.

Some, I do not.

When the architect of the old slave-markets is dragged in chains before me, trying to wrap remorse around himself like a cloak, I strip his words bare and weigh them against the tally of suffering he engineered.

“No,” I tell him. “You are sorry you lost. Not that you did wrong. There is no place for you in my world.”

He does not leave that cathedral.

Justice demands lines.

But mercy demands I see the difference between ignorance and malice, between zeal misled and cruelty enjoyed.

They called me dark because I did not flinch from those lines. Because I do not pretend all are redeemable. Because my love for this world is not soft; it is edged, willing to cut away rot so that the living may grow.

So they kneel, and rise, and go back into a world remade by the goddess they once tried to kill. They plant trees along roads where gallows once stood. They craft laws with the hands that once signed edicts of conquest. They tell their children a new story: that the monster they feared held the mirror up and made them see monsters in themselves.

I could demand worship. Some give it freely. But what I want is this: a world that no longer needs a dark goddess to be just.

Until that day, I sit among broken saints and humbled heroes, listening to their apologies, forgiving where it will build something stronger than vengeance ever could.

After all, they were wrong about me.

I am not their villain.

I am their consequence.

samples.prompt: During a routine check-up, it's revealed that you heal your wounds faster than ordinary people. Due to that, you are taken to a secret facility for "testing". You learn that you will be confined there for the "betterment of humankind". After years of experiments you become immortal.
samples.output:
The first time the doctor went quiet, I thought it was because of the numbers.

He had my chart in his hand and a faint groove forming between his brows. The clinic smelled like antiseptic and bubblegum fluoride, the background buzz of printers and quiet conversation humming in the hall. I swung my legs from the exam table, paper crinkling beneath me. A strip of gauze wrap circled my left forearm.

“So,” I said, because silence made me feel like a specimen already. “Is my cholesterol finally going to kill me?”

Dr. Hayes didn’t laugh. That was the second sign.

“Can I see your arm?” he asked.

I held it out. He unwound the bandage. He stilled.

What had been a deep, jagged cut from a week ago—twelve stitches, lots of blood, lecture from Mom about “responsible knife handling”—was a thin pink line. Not scabbed. Healed. I’d seen it three days ago: still ugly, those black ant-leg stitches grimly holding it together. Now it looked like a six-month-old scar.

He pressed gently along the line. No flinch, no tenderness. He checked my chart again, lips moving over dates.

“When did you get this injury?” he asked.

“Last Thursday.”

“That would make it… today’s Monday.” He nodded once, but it was wrong, an absent, unsettled motion. He left without a word.

Third sign.

Two men came in. Not nurses. Suits, thin smiles. They brought a laminated badge that said SPECIAL CONSULTANT: FEDERAL HEALTH REVIEW. They brought calm voices and gentle questions about my “unique healing.” They brought a softly worded suggestion that I go with them “for some additional tests,” because my “condition” could be “invaluable.”

My mother’s mouth was a hard line. “Is my daughter sick?”

“Not at all,” one man said. “Quite the opposite. We believe she might be very important to the future of medicine. We’d like to run some diagnostics. She’ll be well taken care of.”

He slid a folder across the table. Clinical letterhead. Signatures. Stamps. It all looked so official; it all looked like permission.

I remember my mother’s hand tightening around mine. I remember her looking at me, not them.

“You’ll be okay?” she whispered.

I was sixteen. I thought this was what it meant to be special.

“Yeah,” I said.

That was the last time I saw her as a mortal.

—

The facility never had a name, only numerals. Building 36. Wing B. Lab 4.

The first week was tests: blood draws, MRIs, biopsy samples. I watched my skin re-knit around the needle before the nurse could tape gauze down. They whispered. They called others in to watch. They said words like “accelerated mitosis” and “error-free replication” and “unprecedented stability.”

“Your cells don’t age normally,” Dr. Lang said.

He was tall with tired eyes and coffee stains on his cuff. He spoke like he was always half-in a different conversation, one happening in numbers and molecules. “You heal without scarring, no telomere shortening, no senescence signals. It’s… extraordinary.”

“Will I get to go home soon?” I asked.

He opened his mouth, shut it. “We’re still evaluating.”

Days turned into months. “Evaluating” became “essential work.” Essential work became routine procedures. Routine procedures became scheduled injuries.

A controlled burn on my forearm.

A surgical incision on my thigh.

A broken finger, carefully induced.

Each time, they recorded the baseline, then watched, cameras on, while the swelling dulled in hours, the flesh closed overnight, the bone fused in a day. Something inside me rose to meet the damage like a wave swallowing a stone.

“This is for the betterment of humankind,” one of the directors told me when I refused the needle one morning, clamping my arm to my chest.

“I didn’t agree to this,” I said.

She smiled, precise and pitying. “The consent forms were signed, dear. You’re a minor. Your mother understood how important this is.”

I remembered my mother’s shaking yes, the pressure, the forms already half-filled by official hands. I wondered if she could withdraw it. I wondered if they’d let her.

They took away my phone. Then calls. Then the window in my room.

“We can’t risk contamination,” they said. “You’re a national resource.”

They said it like a compliment.

—

Time in captivity doesn’t pass like outside. Days are ruled by other people’s schedules: blood at six, scan at nine, incision at noon, observation at three. They tested more aggressively as my body kept refusing to break the way they expected.

Higher voltages. Deeper cuts. Cellular toxins.

There were nights I lay in the dark and waited for pain to crest and stay, thinking, This one, this one I won’t bounce back from. But always, a coolness, like water running through my veins, like something ancient and sure, swept the damage away.

“You’re adapting,” Lang murmured once, more to himself than to me. “You’re not just healing. You’re… correcting. Improving. There’s no sign of cumulative damage.”

“Is that supposed to be good news?” I asked.

“For humanity,” he said. Then, a beat later: “And for you.”

“For me this is a prison.”

He flinched. “It’s necessary.”

“Necessary for who?”

He didn’t answer.

—

The first time they killed me, it was “an unfortunate complication.”

At least, that’s how it was written in the after-action report I wasn’t supposed to see.

It was an induced trauma protocol. Anesthetized, they said, but the IV line burned going in and then my heart… stopped.

I knew because I felt it: a sudden wrongness, a vertigo, and then—nothing. No light, no dark, not even the idea of time. It wasn’t peaceful. It wasn’t anything.

Then I gasped awake.

The room came back like a slammed door. Dazzling white. Masked faces looming. A shrill alarm flattening into silence as the monitors leapt back to life.

“Jesus,” someone whispered.

My chest heaved. I clutched at the spot where they’d cut. Smooth, unbroken skin.

“How long,” I croaked.

Lang’s voice was rough. “Six minutes.”

They had ultrasound images. Video. My cells swarming over necrotic tissue, dissolving it, replacing it. My heart restarting itself without defibrillation.

“It seems,” the director said later, fingers steepled, eyes bright like a predator’s, “that we’ve underestimated your potential.”

I understood, in that sterile fluorescent moment, that they were never going to let me leave.

—

Years sanded my anger into something sharper, more patient. I stopped arguing. I cooperated. I smiled. They relaxed.

By year five, I had died seven more times. Each more brutal, more deliberate. They needed to know where the line was. It turned out there wasn’t one.

A bullet through the brain. Back in thirty seconds.

Full exsanguination. Back in two minutes.

Multi-organ failure induced by cascading toxins. Back, every time.

My body learned. The recovery grew faster, smoother. The wave inside me became an ocean, rising instantly to swallow any insult. I watched through the glass of Lab 4 as my own samples defied entropy in petri dishes, dividing clean, DNA coils unfraying like they’d made a pact with eternity.

They called me Subject Aion in their notes. “Aion” as in endless.

Lang still called me by my name when we were alone. Small rebellions.

“Does it hurt?” he asked once, not clipboard-Lang, but human-Lang.

“Yes,” I said. “Every time.”

“I’m sorry,” he whispered.

“Then let me go.”

He looked at the security camera in the corner. “I can’t.”

—

Immortality doesn’t arrive with a trumpet. There’s no single switch flipped. It’s a series of adjustments, of lines crossed and not found again.

The fine wrinkles I used to see near my eyes in the facility bathroom’s harsh light faded instead of deepened. My hair stayed the same length unless cut, the ends never splitting. I never bruised unless they forced it; when they did, colors bloomed and vanished in hours.

Pathogens they introduced—viruses that should have leveled me—died like sparks in the rain.

“This isn’t just slowed aging,” Lang said, sounding half-mad with awe. “This is controlled stasis. Immortal in practical terms.”

“Practical,” I repeated. “To you.”

He winced. “Do you know what this could mean? For cancer. For degenerative diseases. For—”

“For more people like me in cages?”

He didn’t answer. Silence was his most honest response.

They let slip fragments of the outside world. Pandemics stalled by a breakthrough that came from my blood. An experimental treatment reducing organ rejection. Politicians speaking of a “biological safeguard” without saying my name.

“Your sacrifice is saving millions,” the director told me.

“My sacrifice was never mine to give,” I said.

She folded her hands. “History won’t remember it that way.”

“But you will,” I said. “And I’m not going anywhere.”

For the first time, I saw something like unease in her eyes.

—

I stopped aging at twenty-four.

I knew because they taped polaroids to the wall over years of evaluations. Same face. Same eyes. Time outside stacked up in headlines I wasn’t meant to see but did—in Lang’s guilty tablet left unlocked, in the hurried whispers of techs.

New presidents. New disasters. New wars.

In all of them, my body’s data ran under the surface, the invisible backbone of miracle cures. They called it Project Dawn in public. They said, “A gift from science.” They never said, “Stolen from a girl.”

A century after I signed that form—because yes, I counted, each tick mark scratched in concrete—I stood in front of a mirror and saw the same reflection. My captors had gray hair now. Some had retired, some died. Lang’s hands shook when he adjusted my IVs.

“You’ve outlived all your consent,” I told him one day.

He laughed, a broken sound. “We’re close to replicating the effect. Think about it—a world without death from disease, from injury. You’ll be the mother of a new humanity.”

“I never wanted to be a mother,” I said.

He met my gaze. “What do you want?”

The question hung between us like a test.

“I want a choice,” I said. “I want out.”

He closed his eyes. When he opened them again, something was decided. On the camera feed, a red light blinked. He stepped between it and me.

“Run,” he said.

I almost didn’t. The habit of staying is strong when movement has always meant a new kind of pain. But the door was open. The corridor was empty. The alarm hadn’t sounded yet.

I ran.

—

If this were a different story, the escape would be the end. Freedom, sunset, roll credits.

But immortality means endings are liars.

I made it past the first locked door, and the second. Lang had codes for both. A siren finally wailed as I reached the perimeter—floodlights blooming, boots pounding behind me. Bullets cracked through the night. One took me in the spine.

I fell. Felt nothing below my chest. Saw the stars overhead, cold and indifferent.

Then my fingers twitched. Vertebrae knit. Lead slid from knitting tissue. I stood up before the guards reached me.

They saw. They knew.

I ran again.

They couldn’t kill what kept standing back up, not fast enough. I took a bullet to the heart and got back up. A baton to the skull and got back up. It slowed me but didn’t stop me. The world beyond the fence smelled like wet asphalt and exhaust and freedom.

I didn’t stop running for miles.

—

Now, I write this in a room with a window.

I’ve watched the sun rise in different cities. I’ve seen people whose lives were lengthened by treatments that hum in resonance with my blood. I’ve held the hand of a child who survived a car crash that should’ve killed her, her tiny body stitching itself together with something that once belonged only to me.

They’re looking for me, of course. I am intellectual property incarnate. A walking lab result. The immortal runaway.

Sometimes I think about going back, not in chains but in fire, tearing down every lock, every camera. Sometimes I think about walking into a public square, tearing my skin open and showing the world how fast it closes, forcing the truth into the daylight where no one can spin it.

Mostly, I think about time.

I used to count days; now I count lifetimes. Empires brick themselves up and crack. Languages shift. The people who signed my forms are dust. The people who benefited don’t know my name.

They say this is for the betterment of humankind.

Humankind is getting better at not dying. I’m getting better at not forgiving.

Immortality is not glory or light. It’s accumulation. Of memory. Of rage. Of obligation.

I cannot die. They made sure of that.

What they forgot is that I can wait.

samples.prompt: Backwards time travel is a reality, however forward time travel is not. Therefore when you go back you must relive everything again.
samples.output:
The first thing they tell you, before you sign, is that you will forget.

This comforts some people. It didn’t comfort me.

“You won’t know you’ve done this,” the counselor said, her voice level, rehearsed. “No one does. Subjectively, you live life once. Objectively, you have done this before. Are doing this again. Will choose to do it again. You won’t remember this room.”

I stared at the slim chrome band on the table between us. Backwards travel interface, Version 6.2. They used to call it a time machine. Now that the novelty had worn off, it was an “interface.” The only direction possible: back.

“Why do I believe you?” I asked.

“Because the math works,” she said. “Because the audits work. Because we can track temporal recursions in the neutrino background. Because there is an anomalous consistency in decision clusters among Recurrent Individuals. You decided to be here before. You will decide again. Statistically speaking.”

“And I’ll forget.”

She folded her hands. “That’s the condition of the loop. No forward travel. No skipping. You go back to your starting year, your earliest stable cognitive state, and you live forward again. Every second. No fast-forward, no branching out of sequence. Local continuity must be preserved.”

“So no killing Hitler?” I asked.

“Only if you were in 1930s Germany the first time,” she said. “Were you?”

“No.”

“Then you won’t be.”

The rules were simple and horrific:

- You can go back as far as your earliest coherent memories.
- You retain all knowledge only until the jump completes.
- The universe—whatever that really means—does not allow paradox by changing your remembered past.
- You can only go backwards; there is no mechanism to jump ahead of your own experience.

Backwards travel exists; free will is questionable.

The counselor watched me. “You scheduled this consult,” she reminded me. “You said you’d already done it. That you could feel it.”

I had. On bad nights, I woke with a disorienting certainty that my life was a rerun. Déjà vu wasn’t flutters at corners; it was entire days that felt like reading a script I’d once misplaced. I knew answers in meetings before questions finished. I reached for words that were already waiting. Tiny timings: the phone rings, and I think, It’s Mom, and it is, more often than chance. Patterns in the noise.

Most people shrug it off. A few of us feel it like a splinter in the mind. Those few end up in this office.

“If I’ve done this before,” I asked, “why isn’t my life… better?”

“It is,” she said. “You’re alive, for one. Your chart shows avoidance of several high-risk events you were statistically likely to attend. Not by much—a missed flight, a changed commute—but enough. People think looping makes them geniuses or millionaires. What it reliably makes them is cautious.”

“And unhappy,” I said.

“Yes,” she said calmly. “Awareness without memory tends toward unease.”

I picked up the chrome band. It was light, warmer than the room. “Remind me of the constraint.”

“You may select any point from your earliest stable memory to last week. We advise childhood, for maximum potential impact. But wherever you land, you must live every moment again until this one. No skipping. No editing. You cannot jump back here; you cannot jump forward. This present line ceases to be primary. And you will not remember that you jumped.”

“Except somehow I did,” I said.

She smiled, thinly. “Leaky loops. Intuition. Call it what you like.”

“What if I don’t do it?” I asked.

She glanced at the file. “You will. You made this appointment six times.”

That startled me. “Six?”

“Separate timelines,” she said. “Separate loops. We detect recurrences in your signature. Each time, you come closer to a decision. Today’s pattern suggests you’re at ninety-two percent probability of activation.”

“Six loops and I still haven’t fixed everything,” I said. “That’s pathetic.”

“It’s human,” she said. “Your constraints travel with you: your temperament, your fears, your loves. You can nudge. But you are still you.”

I considered that. People fantasize about going back with knowledge intact, placing perfect bets, dodging heartbreak, delivering witty comebacks. But knowledge doesn’t stay. Only the grooves it carved in you.

I tried to be honest with myself. What did I actually want?

My father’s laugh again, before the coughing. A kinder break-up with Lena. Eating fewer late-night burgers, not because of vanity but because of the quiet terror of that faint ache in my chest. Maybe studying something that didn’t trap me in a cubicle vibrating under fluorescent lights. Tiny edits along the same rails.

“Suppose,” I said slowly, “I pick age eight. I go back. No memory. Just… déjà vu. But that déjà vu nudges me to drag Dad to a doctor sooner. He lives two extra years. I don’t ghost Lena; I say the hard things earlier. I exercise. So what? From this perspective, none of that happens, because I don’t come back here, right?”

“From this perspective,” she said, “this line terminates when you jump. From the new perspective, it is all that ever happens. There is no clean bird’s-eye view. Only local, continuous experience. This is fundamental: you never stand outside your own timeline.”

“That’s bleak,” I said.

“That’s physics,” she replied.

“And what about him?” I asked. “The me that doesn’t jump. The eight loops that didn’t happen.”

She hesitated only briefly. “We do not create new universes. We re-index an existing personal trajectory. ‘Other yous’ are not hanging in the void, abandoned. There is one you, experienced in non-linear order by… something. Call it a soul, if you like. Call it a measure on the wavefunction.”

I laughed. “You’re not supposed to say soul.”

“I’m off script,” she admitted. “I see a lot of you. Recurrents. You always come in around this age. Early forties, calculations of regret saturating. You think: if only I’d… So here we are. The offer: go back, unknowingly, and trust that the shape of your regret will be shallower next time.”

“Is it?” I asked.

She slid a different folder across. No name, just a code. Inside: redacted case summaries. Lives lived three, five, eleven loops. Patterns trending toward stability. Healthier marriages. Different careers. Easier deaths.

“You recall none of it,” she said. “But it’s you. Each loop is a chance to converge on a life you can unconsciously choose better.”

“That sounds like domestication,” I muttered.

“Or growth,” she countered.

I turned the band in my fingers. If I put it on and confirm, I’ll blink and be eight, chasing my brother down the cracked sidewalk, the summer air syrup-thick, knowing for no good reason I shouldn’t let him run into the street. I’ll yank him back, heart pounding with a déjà vu of screeching brakes that never occur. I’ll feel proud, or shaken, without knowing I just shaved a tragedy off my stack of potential lives.

Is that so bad?

The cruelty isn’t in the chance; it’s in the exile of memory. I want both: the wisdom and the saved time. But forward travel doesn’t exist. No skipping ahead to see if it worked, no zooming through the dull stretches. If I jump, I earn every day again. The school assemblies. The breakouts. The hour-long staff calls. The waiting rooms. The nights I lie awake wondering why I feel like I’ve forgotten something enormous.

“You’re sure it’s not addiction?” I asked. “That I didn’t already go back a thousand times chasing a perfect life?”

“If you had,” she said, “you wouldn’t be here. You’d be elsewhere, having learned. Convergence is real. People stop coming in, one loop or ten. They just… live.”

The idea pierced me: that an absence of this gnawing might be the only proof that I’d done it enough.

“Last question,” I said. “From your perspective, are we… looping right now? Have you given this speech to me before?”

Her eyes flicked, almost amused. “Statistically? Many times.”

“And you don’t remember either.”

“No,” she said. “I only walk one line, same as you.”

The band on my palm hummed faintly as it synced, reading whatever makes me me. My earliest lasting memory: spilling orange juice on my mother’s new dress at four, her sharp inhale, my first raw understanding of shame. I could start there. So small, so early.

“Will it hurt?” I asked, for no good reason.

“You won’t remember if it does,” she said softly. “All you will know is waking up into a life you feel strangely more prepared for.”

Relive everything. The whole slog. Back through all the mistakes, each surprise dulled by a ghost of recognition. There is something monstrous about choosing that. There is something monstrous about refusing it and suspecting you already chose it, and squandered your extra chances.

I slid the band onto my wrist. It tightened with a click like a closing handcuff.

“Confirm?” she asked.

And here is the puzzle that’s been with me for as long as I can remember: I have always known, secretly, that I had already said yes.

“Yes,” I said.

The room dissolved before the word finished. Not spectacularly; no swirling colors or thunder. Just an odd, sideways slipping, like realizing a word you’ve said your whole life has no meaning.

Then sunlight. Orange juice. My mother’s dress. My small hand tipping the glass.

Careful, something whispered inside me.

This time, I catch it.

samples.prompt: You wake up greeted by a blue screen hovering in front of your eyes. “You have slept in your own bed. 100% HP and MP recovered, all negative mental and physical status effects have been recovered. You have received the Well Rested bonus, -90% fatigue accumulation for the next 8 hours. ”
samples.output:
I wake up to the Windows error screen.

That’s my first thought—blue, glowing, hovering where the ceiling should be—but then the words come into focus.

“You have slept in your own bed. 100% HP and MP recovered, all negative mental and physical status effects have been recovered. You have received the Well Rested bonus, -90% fatigue accumulation for the next 8 hours.”

I blink. The text doesn’t go away.

“Okay,” I whisper, my voice dry. “That’s new.”

The blue screen hangs there in the air with the determined clarity of something that either obeys no laws or has never heard of gravity. My room is still my room: beige walls, crooked poster, laundry chair, the lingering smell of yesterday’s coffee. Nothing is pixelated. This isn’t a dream, at least not the obvious kind. I raise a hand and wave it through the glowing rectangle.

My fingers pass through it. The text does not waver.

“Close,” I say, because that’s what you do to pop-ups.

The box gives an obedient little ding and dissolves into faint motes of light.

A small chime sounds in my head. Not in my ears. In my skull.

New Buff: Well Rested. -90% fatigue accumulation for 8:00:00.

Eight hours appear in the top-right of my vision in a tiny, translucent font, ticking down with digital precision.

I sit up much too quickly, expecting dizziness, the usual headrush. Nothing. No sluggishness, no sand in my joints, no vague sense of existential rot. Just clarity.

I feel…good.

I haven’t felt automatically good in years.

I swing my legs out of bed. The wooden floor is cold, but in a crisp, informational way, not the usual hateful shock. I stand up. No crack of knee. My back doesn’t complain. I stretch my arms wide; muscles move like they’ve been oiled. I roll my neck, and instead of the gritty crunch, there’s a smooth, painless arc.

I laugh, a single uncertain breath.

“Status,” I say, half-joking.

Another blue panel snaps into existence.

Name: Alex Reed
Level: 5
Class: Civilian (Unassigned)
HP: 100/100
MP: 40/40
Strength: 8
Dexterity: 9
Vitality: 10
Intelligence: 12
Wisdom: 11
Charisma: 9
Luck: 5

Conditions:
- Well Rested (+90% fatigue resistance, 8:00:00 remaining)
- Passive: Mild Anxiety (suppressed)

Quest Log: Empty.

I read it twice. It reads back, unchanged.

I poke one of the lines. My finger meets no resistance, but the text ripples and a smaller tooltip unfolds from the word “Mild Anxiety.”

“Mild Anxiety: A persistent mental status effect acquired over time. Increases background worry, reduces confidence in decisions. Currently suppressed by Well Rested.”

“…Huh.”

I close the panel with an instinctive flick. It vanishes.

Okay. Either I’ve finally broken in a very well-organized way, or reality has patched itself overnight.

I pull on jeans and a T-shirt, half expecting a “+1 Modest Outfit” message. Nothing. My reflection in the mirror looks ordinary—messy hair, faint shadows under the eyes—but the shadows are lighter. The familiar knot in my stomach is absent. The silence inside my head is so unlike the usual low-grade hum of dread that it’s unnerving.

In the kitchen, I open the fridge to the usual suspects: half jar of marinara, three eggs, questionably old spinach. A new blue box flickers at the edge of my vision.

Skill Check: Cooking (Novice). Suggested Recipe: Omelette (Success Chance: 82%).

I swallow a startled laugh.

“Do it,” I tell it.

A translucent step-by-step guide overlays my field of view, with tiny indicators: heat pan now, whisk eggs harder, flip in three, two, one—perfect. The omelette comes out fluffy, golden, like something from a diner commercial.

I sit down, take a bite, and close my eyes.

A warm little notification appears.

HP fully maintained.
Minor Mood Increase: +5% for 00:30:00

I eat slowly, waiting for the other shoe to drop, for glitching textures or a voice booming “Tutorial Complete.” The clock ticks. The world stays solid.

Phone: 32 unread emails. I brace for the usual cortisol spike; instead, a small tooltip blooms beside the screen.

New Quest Available: Clear the Inbox.
Difficulty: Easy.
Reward: +50 XP, Reduced Cognitive Clutter (Minor).

I huff. “You’re kidding.”

Another line appears under it.

Optional Objective: Do not spiral.

The fact that whatever this is knows me well enough to phrase it that way is concerning.

I don’t accept the quest. Or maybe I do; another corner of my vision quietly logs it as “Active.”

The Well Rested timer ticks down: 7:43:12.

I leave for work. Outside, a faint mini-map traces the street layout in the bottom-left of my vision, labeling the bus stop, the coffee shop, the shortcut alley I always forget about. Potential interaction points glow in soft blue: crossing signal, “Walk” sign, an abandoned flyer tacked to a pole flagged as “Notice Board (Inactive).”

When I step onto the sidewalk, another message blinks.

Hidden Trait Discovered: Overthinking.
Effect: +10% to analysis; -5% to action speed.
Would you like to begin mitigating this trait? Y/N

My throat tightens. There it is, spelled out. Not a character flaw, but a debuff.

“Yes,” I say.

New Long-Term Quest: Act Without Rumination.
Progress: 0%
Reward: Trait Upgrade: Thoughtful (Balanced).

I don’t know whether to be grateful or insulted.

At the bus stop, people scroll their phones, oblivious. No one else flinches at invisible text. Car horns, the hum of the city, the morning haze already heating up. I study faces, looking for the glassy, unfocused stare of someone clicking invisible menus. Nothing.

“Hey, Alex,” Mariah says, stepping up beside me. She’s in her usual blazer-and-sneakers combo, curls pinned back. She looks real. Solid.

A subtle translucent bar appears over her head.

Mariah Torres
Level: 12
Class: Analyst
Disposition: Friendly

I startle.

“You okay?” she asks.

“I—did you just see that?”

“See what?”

Right. Just me, then.

“Uh, nothing. Didn’t sleep great.” The lie leaves my mouth automatically, habitual.

My peripheral vision flashes red.

System Notice: LIE detected.
Charisma Check: Failed.
Relationship Impact: -1 (Minor Distrust).

I choke. “Wait, no, I…did sleep great. Weird dream, that’s all.” I correct myself, words scrambling.

The notification shifts to soft green.

Correction Noted.
Relationship Impact: +1 (Appreciated Honesty).

Mariah eyes me. “You look better than usual, actually,” she says. “Like you’re not three ghosts in a hoodie.”

I laugh, genuine. “Thanks. I think.”

On the bus, I experiment. “Inventory,” I murmur under my breath.

A grid appears. It’s unimpressive:
- Phone (Worn, Reliable)
- Wallet (Low Funds)
- Keys (Slightly Jangly)
- Headphones (Common)
- Confidence (Fragmented, but Present) [Bound]

The last one stops me.

I tap “Confidence.”

“Confidence: A self-belief resource affected by successes, failures, feedback. Currently damaged but regenerating slowly. Growth Rate increased by: Well Rested.”

I sit back, headphones dangling forgotten. All the swirling intangible parts of me, quantified, itemized, but…not condemned. Just described. Modifiable.

At work, my monitor boots up, and another box appears.

New Environment Discovered: Open Plan Office (Mildly Hostile to Focus).
Ambient Noise: +10% Stress over Time (Mitigated by Well Rested).

My inbox quest updates as I start answering emails.

Quest Progress: 35%… 60%… 100%.
Quest Complete: Clear the Inbox.
Rewards: +50 XP, +1 to Organization (Minor), Reduced Cognitive Clutter (Minor).

A faint warmth spreads through my chest. It feels…good. A pat on the back I never give myself. Gamified competency.

I float through tasks that usually feel like trudging through wet cement. Spreadsheets balance on the first try. Jargon-laden emails translate themselves in my mind, as if a mental “Tool Tip” has appeared over every acronym.

Co-workers drift over. Small talk, requests, one minor crisis involving a mislabeled file. My vision periodically flags social cues.

Insight: Your coworker is not angry; they are anxious.
Suggested Response: Clarify, reassure briefly.

I follow it. It works. Micro green notifications: “+1 Rapport,” “Situation De-escalated.”

Sometime after lunch, a new notification slides into view, tinted gold instead of blue.

Main Quest Unlocked: Choose a Class.
You have continued as Civilian (Unassigned) for 25 years.
Based on observed tendencies, recommended options:
- Scholar
- Support
- Trickster
- Builder
- ??? (Locked)
Choose now? Y/N

My cursor, invisible but surely there, hovers over the question.

I’m in the break room, fluorescent lights humming. The coffee is burnt. Someone’s left crumbs on the counter. Life is ordinary. And yet.

If this is a psychotic break, it’s a very polite one. It has patch notes.

“What happens if I don’t choose?” I whisper.

A smaller line appears.

Continuing as Civilian (Unassigned) will limit your growth but maintain current lifestyle safety. Are you satisfied?

That feels unfair.

“I don’t…know,” I admit.

Honesty Registered.
Wisdom +1 (Temporary).

I snort.

I back out. Not yet.

By four p.m., the Well Rested timer dips under an hour. I feel it as a layer of fuzz at the edge of my focus. The glow of green notifications slows. Tasks take slightly more effort. The knot in my stomach taps at the door, testing the lock.

Mild Anxiety: Emerging from Suppression.

I watch that line appear like weather rolling in.

But I also see a new passive effect.

New Passive: Awareness (Rank 1).
You can now view and name your own status effects. Duration: Permanent.

On the bus home, I open my Status again. The numbers are small, modest. Level 5. Luck 5. Nothing legendary. But now they’re visible. Not accusations, not destiny—just data.

“Mild Anxiety,” I tap. A new option flickers.

Begin Side Quest: Seek Help.
Objectives:
- Research therapy options.
- Book one appointment.
- Attend.
Rewards:
- Reduced Anxiety Debuff.
- XP.
- Access to New Coping Skills (Skill Tree Unlocked).

My chest tightens, but it’s a different feeling than before. Fear, yes, but framed. A quest with steps, not a vague fog.

“Accept,” I whisper.

Quest Accepted.

When I step through my front door that evening, I feel a subtle shift, like passing a checkpoint.

“You have returned home,” a familiar blue box says softly. “Safe Zone entered.”

I exhale. The apartment smells faintly of this morning’s coffee and something hopeful.

No instant full restore this time, but I don’t need it. Not yet.

I drop my bag. Sit on the edge of the bed. Stare at my hands.

“If you’re going to stick around,” I say to the invisible interface, “then you’re going to help. Not just make it look like a game and leave me grinding.”

No text appears.

Then, quietly:

Tutorial Complete.
Free Mode Enabled.
Remember: Quests are suggestions. You still choose.

I lie back.

Tomorrow, maybe I’ll pick a class. Maybe I’ll book that appointment. Maybe I’ll start the inbox before it metastasizes. Maybe I’ll take the longer way home, see what’s down the alley the mini-map keeps tagging as “Hidden Path.”

Above me, in the corner of my vision, a tiny message glows.

New Buff Available upon Sleep: Well Rested.

For the first time in a long time, the idea of waking up again feels less like resetting an alarm and more like saving a game.

I close my eyes, not to escape, but to rest.

It’s not much.

In game terms, though, it’s everything.

samples.prompt: Create an original monster. Make its own rules as to how it works, and how it has to be destroyed. Explain all of this when people run into it for the first time ever and how they deal with it.
samples.output:
The first time anyone saw the Lanterner, they thought it was a search party.

It came over the ridge at dusk—tall shapes, thin as scaffolding, moving in a slow, careful line. The storm had taken most of the town’s power, and a girl was missing in the woods. So when the lights appeared—soft, pale lantern-glow swaying above dark silhouettes—people on the porch of the makeshift command center stood up with relieved shouts.

“Good,” Sheriff Dalca muttered, lowering his radio. “Search and Rescue finally made it.”

The Lanterner adjusted.

Until that moment, it had only guessed at how they spoke, how they stood, how they trusted light. It had watched them from the treeline: firelight, flashlights, screens. It learned quickly. It added the lanterns for them.

The figures crossed the gravel, six of them, each bearing a round, glass-bright light where a head might be. No faces, just a sunken glow. Limbs too long, joints too loose. Their shadows fell wrong, stretching toward the light instead of away.

“Evening!” Deputy Rios called, stepping out. “You folks from the ranger station?”

The front figure turned.

Up close, nothing about it was right. Its lantern was not a lantern, but an orb of congealed, trembling light, like bioluminescence trapped under skin. Its “arms” were bundled dark threads, thousands of them, twisting together into the suggestion of limbs. They whispered softly against each other, like hair in a slow current.

Rios slowed. “Sheriff…” she murmured.

The nearest orb flared, just a little.

Rios blinked.

Her pupils vanished.

Her scream never made it out. Her jaw hung slack, strings of spit bright in the lantern-glow. Then she folded like a dropped coat, and there was no sound but the click of her teeth on impact.

Rule one: Looking directly into the Lanterner’s light strips you of yourself. The body lives. The mind is taken. The Lanterner doesn’t devour flesh. It harvests awareness.

“What the—Rios!” Dalca lunged forward, but the second lantern turned toward him. He saw, just before diving behind the patrol truck, the coiling interior of the orb: swollen, translucent sacs, hundreds of tiny mouths, all open in unison, teeth like pins. The light formed their tongues.

The missing girl stepped out from behind the tall shapes.

She was barefoot, soaked, unscathed. Her eyes were two coins of milk. She smiled. “They’re here to help us,” she said in a voice that sounded like an old tape, replayed over itself, flattened. “Let them look at you. It only hurts first.”

Her words were wrong, but they contained pieces of real things the Lanterner had heard in the woods, rearranged like a child’s collage: help, here, only hurts first.

Dalca fired a warning shot. The bullet tore through the leading figure’s torso, unraveling dark threads. No blood, no bone. The shape staggered, but did not fall. The orb-head swung toward the muzzle flare.

The shot’s light was enough. The Lanterner tasted that, too.

Rule two: The Lanterner is not one creature, but a colony of filament-bodies animated by stolen cognition. The lanterns are its sensory organs and its mouth. It can extend itself along any sufficient source of light, riding illumination like a bridge. It prefers forms that make sense to its prey.

The people saw six. There was only ever one.

The orbs brightened, feeding off porch bulbs, vehicle headlights, the pale flicker from the command center’s open laptop screens. Every artificial light vibrated, subtly syncing with that queasy pulse.

The girl, her mind scraped empty, tilted her head. “You’re making it strong,” she said.

Power went out entirely then, as the grid failed. For a second, the world snapped into honest dark. The orbs dimmed like startled eyes.

Rule three: It cannot exist where there is no light at all. In pure darkness, its filaments lose coherence and slacken into inert threads, incapable of binding a stolen mind or holding form. It fears the places it cannot see and cannot be.

“Kill the lights!” Dalca yelled, realizing.

Someone inside the building heard him and panicked. Instead of hitting the main breaker, they grabbed a lantern and ran outside.

The Lanterner rejoiced.

Light spilled onto the gravel, and its filaments surged forward, invisible in the brightness, weaving themselves up that beam. In one sliding instant, one of the dark shapes dissolved and re-formed around the newcomer: the bobbing lantern refilled with crawling white.

This is how things spread, Dalca thought numbly. Through the parts of ourselves we trust.

The rules weren’t clear yet, only glimpsed in the edges: light makes it strong, darkness makes it falter. But there was something else—they’d shot it, and the threads hadn’t bled. Bullets meant nothing. Firearms created muzzle flash. Dangerous.

The girl, puppet-mouthed, raised her arm and pointed at Dalca’s hiding place. Her joints moved wrong, a beat off, like something remote-controlled through a bad signal. “We see you,” she said. “We can be you.”

Rule four: Once the Lanterner has stripped enough minds, it learns nuance. It remixes voices, reconstructs familiar faces in the glow. It does not shapeshift flesh but arranges light and threads to approximate what you expect to see. It becomes your missing wife, your dead friend, your colleague from the ranger station, always with those too-bright eyes. It uses recognition as bait.

They found this out ten seconds later, when “Rios” climbed back to her feet.

Her body straightened as if pulled up on wires. Her eyes opened, colorless. She holstered her pistol with smooth efficiency and turned toward the others.

“Sheriff, stand down,” she called. Her tone was perfect. “They’re with the Feds. You’ll spook them.”

The sheriff’s knuckles went white around the shotgun.

“That’s not her,” muttered a volunteer behind him.

“How do you know?” another asked, voice shaking.

Rios’ lip twitched. The Lanterner didn’t quite have microexpressions yet.

Dalca gambled. He stepped out, keeping his gaze low, not meeting any glowing orbs. The lanterns made the gravel glitter, made the volunteers’ faces look waxy.

“If you’re with the Feds,” he said carefully, “turn off your lights.”

All six orbs brightened at once, too synchronized, then dimmed, an imitation of compliance. But not off. They couldn’t go off.

“Good enough?” Rios asked.

Her question came one second too late. After the dimming. After a human would have spoken.

“No,” Dalca said. “It isn’t.”

He fired—not at the orbs, but at the last unbroken visible light he could see: the runaway lantern in the hands of the possessed rescuer. Glass shattered. Oil splashed. The brief flare of fire gave the Lanterner a surge, but then the flame snuffed in the wet gravel and everything plunged into a sudden, unnatural black.

The world held its breath.

The lantern-orbs guttered like candles in a downpour.

For the first time, they saw it as it really was. Only dim outlines, only for a heartbeat: a mass of tangled filament like seaweed pulled from a tar pit, writhing in confusion, groping along surfaces, trying to find a beam, a glint, anything to reconstitute itself.

Rule five: It is only “real” while expressed in light. Without it, the Lanterner is blind code without a screen, a script without a voice. It remembers, but cannot act.

Someone screamed and turned on their phone.

The tiny rectangle of light snapped the Lanterner back into clarity around that person’s hand. Threads shot up their arm like veins drawn in ink. The glow swallowed their eyes; their scream cut off with a wet choke. The phone hit the ground, shining.

“Power off!” Dalca roared. “Everything! No screens, no flashlights, no nothing! Close your eyes if something glows!”

They listened because they were terrified.

A few phones winked out. One didn’t. When its owner looked up, there were two orb-faces inches from his own. A white bloom swallowed him whole.

Rule six: It moves through attention. Light you do not look at is only potential. When you look into its lantern, you grant it access—your focus is the open door. Glancing might not damn you. Staring will. Its harvest is not random; it wants engaged minds.

They scrambled inside the command center, dragging Rios’ body, the girl’s body, anyone fallen but breathing. Dalca slammed the heavy storm shutters, cutting off the reflected glow from outside.

Inside, emergency lights bathed them in red. The sheriff cursed, lunged for the control panel, and punched at the override. The red went out.

Someone sobbed in the black.

“All right,” he said. “Listen to me. That thing rides light. It eats…whatever makes you you when you look at it. We don’t shoot it. We starve it.”

“How?” a man whispered.

Dalca swallowed. His voice found something steady. “We keep it in the dark. We wait till morning.”
