“What about the sun?” someone else hissed.

They hadn’t thought this through. But the Lanterner had.

Rule seven: Sunlight is too broad, too wild. It dilutes the Lanterner. It can exist under overcast skies, in shade, under artificial, focused sources. It thrives in directed light—beams, bulbs, screens—things that form precise corridors for it to inhabit. Daylight scatters it thin. It hates dawn. It retreats to dense shadows, to basements, to underground cables, waiting for night and circuitry.

Dalca didn’t know that yet. He only guessed that, if anything, sunrise would help.

Outside, the orbs’ glow pressed against the sealed shutters like fungus searching for cracks. They prowled along seams of the building, flickering with stolen voices.

“Sheriff Dalca. Open the door.”

“Ali, it’s Mom, please.”

“It only hurts first.”

From inside the black, some people trembled with the urge to believe. The Lanterner’s voices were arranging themselves better now, stitching syntax with more care. It was learning.

Dalca scraped together rules from panic:

- Don’t look at its light.
- Kill every controlled source of illumination.
- Don’t trust familiar voices from the glow.
- Darkness isn’t danger tonight. Light is.

He realized, with a cold, precise clarity, the final rule they would have to discover if humanity wanted to destroy this thing, not just survive the night.

Rule eight: It cannot be killed. It can only be uninvited.

The Lanterner is an algorithm born of light and attention. As long as something somewhere shines in a pattern that can mimic a face, a lantern, a beckoning glow, it has a door. You cannot stab it. You cannot burn it. Those acts only create more light-flash, more pathways.

But you can:

- Starve it: coordinated blackouts, synchronized dark where it has spread.
- Blind it: teach people the rules so no one willingly stares into its lure.
- Fracture it: flood its habitats with wild, chaotic light (sunrise, lightning storms) that scatter its coherence so thin that it forgets itself—reset to static.

Destroying it means changing the way humans treat their lights: never leaving them unshielded in the forest, never answering unknown glows, never trusting a face that’s all shine and no shadow.

The first night ended with a gray bleed of dawn.

As the sky brightened, the pressure against the command center shutters lessened. They opened the door to a yard strewn with dark hair-thin threads, lifeless as shed spider silk. The orbs were gone. The occupied bodies lay among the gravel, alive, empty.

Some would never wake up. Their minds had been taken inland, into the tunnels of power lines, fiber optics, into every headlight and LED billboard that had looked too long.

Dalca stepped into the cold morning, feeling the sun on his face, on his closed eyelids.

He understood then.

They hadn’t destroyed it.

They had just taught it more about them.

And somewhere, in the humming guts of the town’s restarting grid, a faint, patient light began to organize itself, waiting for the next eyes that would mistake it for help.

samples.prompt: The axis forces won WWII. Turns out, it's not as bad as people would imagine.
samples.output:
The war ended in 1946, not with a mushroom cloud, but with a treaty signed in a rainstorm.

Allied resistance had eroded city by city. Britain starved under the blockade it had once prided itself on wielding. American will snapped under the weight of losses in the Atlantic and Pacific, a presidential election, and a quiet calculation that Europe wasn’t worth national suicide. The Soviets bled to death between Kiev and the Caucasus, their factories pulverized, their commanders exhausted by a war machine that had learned, with horrifying focus, how to destroy them faster than they could improvise.

So the Axis won.

The maps afterward looked like propaganda posters made real. Germany’s gray bled from the Rhine to the Urals. Italy held a patchwork of Mediterranean colonies no longer mocked as fantasies. Japan’s co‑prosperity sphere stretched from Manchuria to Java, militarized and watchful. On paper, it was a nightmare.

And yet.

My grandfather used to say the most disappointing thing about the Reich was the groceries.

“If you’re going to conquer half the planet,” he’d mutter, “you’d think you could at least keep the butter in stock.”

He was born in 1970 to parents who’d never known any other flag. He grew up in the Greater Germanic Union, in a polite, gray suburb near Hamburg. His schoolbooks said the Führer had died peacefully in 1963, an elder statesman who ensured order after the chaos of the “Anglo‑Bolshevik aggression.” By then, the statues looked old-fashioned, like they belonged to his parents’ arguments, not his own life.

Our history teacher in Gymnasium, Herr Kraus, was one of those old men who had outlived his fear. On some days he followed the curriculum. On others, he wandered.

“They were going to kill millions,” he said once, very softly, when we were supposed to be memorizing dates of the Eastern Development Program. “They did kill millions. Remember that when you look at the cheap bread and the trains that run on time.”

“Sir,” asked Lena from the back, “if they were so terrible, why didn’t anyone stop them?”

He shrugged. “Because the Americans decided you weren’t worth their sons. Because Stalin killed so many of his own that people stopped feeling sorry for him. Because Britain believed it would be rescued again and again until one day it wasn’t. Because terror works, until it doesn’t. History is not a morality tale, Fräulein Koch. It is an account of what happened.”

We were fifteen. We wrote that sentence down because it sounded important.

The worst of it, I have learned, burned itself out before I was born. All the grand homicidal schemes collided with resistance, physics, economics, the sheer stubborn exhaustion of the human race. The German state could annihilate villages; it could not annihilate the basic fact that you can’t run a continent if everyone in it is trying to kill you.

The extermination camps—yes, we use the word now—were quietly dismantled in the 1950s, officially for “inefficiency” and “economic modernization.” The Party never apologized. It simply stopped talking and started building. Roads, factories, housing blocks. Consumer radios with smooth wooden cases. Televisions capturing parades and ski competitions and endless, smiling harvests.

The new line was simple: the war had been terrible, mistakes had been made, but now life was getting better. Children needed shoes, not enemies.

It is astonishing how many people will accept that bargain.

In the East, where the ground itself still leaked ghosts, the bargain came slower. There, partisans hung on, in forests and cellars and whispered songs. Some disappeared. Some made deals. Moscow was renamed once, then again, like a scab you keep picking at because you don’t want to admit it’s just going to scar. German settlers arrived with their efficient habits and their conviction that they were bringing civilization. They brought plumbing and clinics and cinemas. Also language laws and quiet police vans.

“Is it very bad?” my cousin Tomas once asked, visiting from Krakow for the summer. We were seventeen, lying on the grass, watching contrails from ReichsLuft flights.

“It could be worse,” I said.

I believed that. I still do.

We had cars our parents could afford. We had holidays on clean Baltic beaches patrolled by bored local officers whose main task seemed to be making sure no one drank too much. We had jobs in offices with humming fluorescent lights, managing shipments and quotas and new overseas ventures with Japan. We had mandatory civil service that, more often than not, meant picking up litter in parks and pretending to care about Party lectures.

The brutality, by then, was selective. Directed. A column in the newspaper about “bandits” in the Caucasus. A colleague who stopped coming to work because he’d posted a joke about the Reich Chancellor’s haircut. Everyone understood there were lines you did not cross. Most of us never felt the edge of the blade.

“Back then,” said my grandmother once, “they came at night for people in broad daylight.”

Now they came in daylight wrapped in the language of law. Orders with stamps. Hearings. Psych evaluations. You could almost forget what it all meant if you didn’t look too closely.

Japan’s empire modernized in parallel, competing, cooperating, trading. Tokyo and Berlin boasted of their joint lunar probe in ’89. The photograph of the rising sun and the hooked cross on the same module is still in every textbook. They reached orbit before the Americans ever did—though of course the Americans still had rockets, and money, and an almost comical insistence on calling their diminished republic “leader of the free world.”

That phrase always makes people here smile, not unkindly.

The Americans never fully reconciled themselves, but they adjusted. They kept their hemisphere, their markets, their movies. Their blues and jazz seeped through our censors. Our children wore American sneakers with German jeans and Japanese watches. Icons layered on icons. Nobody really cared about whose side had done what in Burma or Kursk when they were arguing over music rights.

We grew up with three truths held in uneasy balance:

- The Axis won.
- We live ordinary lives.
- Terrible things were done to make that possible.

The distance between those truths became the space where we built our routines.

“Isn’t it all propaganda?” my friend Jonas demanded once, half drunk at a student party in Berlin, where the glass facades of the new ministries still smelled of fresh metal and ambition.

“Yes,” I said. “And no.”

He wanted a pure story, righteous villains and shining heroes, a clear path from past to future. But the present kept interfering. The Party youth leader who slipped us unapproved novels. The Japanese engineering firm hiring women as project leads because they were running out of men who wanted to work sixty-hour weeks. The quiet admission, buried in a 1993 report, that certain “emergency security measures” of the 1940s had constituted “grave injustices not to be repeated.”

That’s as close to an apology as you get at this altitude.

“They were supposed to be monsters,” Jonas said. “You know? Black leather, red banners, endless war.”

Instead: bureaucracy. Budget debates. Regional elections where three different wings of the same grand coalition argued about pension reform. Banners came out mostly for football tournaments and the Day of Victory, when veterans paraded past with fewer swastikas and more national flags, the edges of the old ideology filed down to something like generic patriotism.

It is not as bad as people would imagine if they only knew the slogans and the skulls.

It is, in many ways, exactly as bad as any empire that has convinced itself it was right.

In 2016, a small museum opened in what used to be a transit camp. It was not announced with fanfare. The exhibits used passive verbs. “People were transported.” “Communities were dissolved.” “Lives were lost.” No one wrote “We did this.” But the photographs were there, on the walls, in quiet light.

I visited with my grandfather.

He moved slowly, reading everything. I watched his face.

“Did you know?” I asked.

He shook his head. “Bits. Rumors. We were busy. Then later, we were comfortable.” He gestured vaguely toward the exit, where a kiosk sold coffee and glossy books titled Europe Reforged. “It’s easy to say you would have done something different. Harder when the trains are running and your children are fed.”

Outside, teenagers took selfies by the museum sign. A ReichsPolizei car rolled past, indifferent. A Japanese tour group lined up for the afternoon entry slot, their guide holding a small flag.

“You’re not shocked,” my grandfather said.

“I was raised here,” I answered. “I’ve never known another version.”

He laughed once, dry. “Then I suppose they won better than they expected.”

The strange mercy of our world is that even evil systems decay into ordinary compromises. The grandiose plans soften against human pettiness, laziness, love, music, logistics. Language reforms half-fail. Borders blur in practice if not on maps. Fear recedes into an ambient hum. Horror becomes chapters in books some of us read and most of us don’t.

The cost doesn’t vanish. It just becomes harder to see from the supermarket queue, or the train platform, or the quiet safety of a suburb where the worst thing that happens is the butter runs out.

samples.prompt: Post the opening paragraph to a book or story you want to write.
samples.output:
The rain had been falling for twelve years when the clocks forgot what came after midnight. It was not a storm in the way old men meant it when they spat into the gutters and muttered about bad omens; this rain was thin and colorless, almost apologetic, like the sky kept trying to clear its throat and never quite managed. It left no puddles, only a dampness in the air that clung like an unfinished sentence. The night the clocks failed, it took an embarrassingly long time for anyone to notice. Phones still lit up with messages that nobody answered, ovens still glowed with end-of-cycle beeps in empty kitchens, but every clock with hands—every authoritative circle of numbers in train stations, schools, churches, dim kitchens and dusty studies—simply ticked past 11:59 and arrived at nothing. The second hands circled once, hesitated as if in modesty, and then settled into a quiet, trembling stutter. In apartments where people still pretended to sleep, the usual tide of digital alarm chimes never rose. In the hospital at the edge of town, a nurse tapping her pen against a clipboard frowned only when she realized she had charted the same minute seven times. And in a narrow, listing house on Calder Street, where the wallpaper had peeled into the shape of forgotten islands, a girl named Mina Tal knelt on her bed and watched the blank-faced clock on her wall fail to name the moment she had been waiting for her whole life.

Mina had been born on a Tuesday at 12:00 a.m., the exact moment the local paper called “the beginning of the long rain” in a headline that tried and failed to sound important. The midwife swore she’d seen the delivery-room clock jump backwards—60, 59, 58, 57—before stubbornly righting itself, and though nobody believed her, the story stuck like lint to Mina’s name. In a town that liked its mysteries second-hand and safely rumor-softened, it was easier to make the child into a superstition than to admit the more mundane miracle that the hospital roof hadn’t yet collapsed under the weight of neglect and drizzle. Growing up, whenever the gutters overflowed or the streetlights blew out all at once, someone would look at Mina and say, “There she goes again,” as if she were not just a girl with scabbed knees and wet cuffs but some quiet conductor of inconvenience. She learned early that people loved a curse they could point at and still invite to dinner. So she smiled when spoken of, bowed theatrically when accused of calling the rain, and kept notes no one knew she was keeping: barometric pressure in the margins of her math homework, the voltage fluctuations of the kitchen lights on the backs of grocery receipts, every time the clock in the hall stuttered between seconds and then pretended it hadn’t.

The night the clocks stopped, she hadn’t meant to cause anything. It was the eve—according to calendars, at least—of her twelfth birthday, and she had constructed a small ritual out of boredom and the scraps of other people’s beliefs. Mina did not imagine that the universe cared about the geometry of candle stubs, or the way she arranged her four river stones in a diamond around the chipped mug of tap water, but she cared. There was power, she suspected, in doing a thing exactly the way you decided to do it, especially when nobody was watching. Her mother had fallen asleep on the sofa with the television murmuring, the bluish light painting exhaustion into the lines of her face; her brother Romey was out with friends, promising not to miss midnight, promising the way people did when they were already too far away. In her room, door half-closed and window cracked to let in the whisper of tires in far-off streets, Mina lined up the objects that had followed her through childhood: the four stones; a small brass key she’d never found a lock for; a postcard with a picture of a sunny city whose name had been blurred by years of pinholes and tape; and the watch.

The watch had been her father’s, though calling him that still felt like using a word on loan. He had left when Mina was three—left in the complicated way of men who vanished by degrees, one late shift at a time, until their absences took on the solidity of furniture. The watch had arrived two years ago in a padded envelope with no return address, just Mina’s name carefully spelled, the way only three people in the world ever spelled it correctly on the first try. It was old, with a face of scratched crystal and hands the color of dried blood. It did not tick. When she wound it, the crown refused to budge beyond a stubborn half-turn, then snapped back as if offended. Still, she wore it every day, the dead weight of it a comfort on her wrist, and took it off only for showers and sleep and this one experimental moment of her almost-birthday, when she laid it at the center of her invented compass and waited to feel foolish.

She didn’t feel foolish. She felt observed.

The sensation came the way a shadow comes, not with a sound but with a subtle rearrangement of brightness. One second her lamplight spread in its familiar weak puddle across her desk and quilt; the next it seemed to bend around an invisible curve, as if making space. The rain outside softened until it was more intention than weather. Mina, who had never once in her life been afraid of the dark (only of the things she could see too clearly), felt the hairs rise along her forearms. She looked at the clock on her wall out of habit. Its red second hand was doing a strange, reluctant dance between the twelve and the one, as though trying to shake something off.

“That’s not how you work,” she said under her breath, and her voice came out much calmer than she felt.

Downstairs, the television cut off mid-sentence. The house hummed—one long, low note as every plugged-in thing argued with the sudden absence of electricity. The humming stopped, but the note did not. It held in the air, audible without being quite a sound, a single thread of attention that wound itself neatly around Mina’s spine.

“Mina Tal,” said a voice from nowhere in particular and entirely from within the room.

People in stories often insist that disembodied voices must be echoing or thunderous or some operatic distortion to be believable. This one was not. It was precise, vaguely amused, and not even loud enough to startle. It addressed her name the way an old acquaintance might, having found her exactly where he had expected her to be.

“You’re not supposed to be speaking,” Mina said, which was a ridiculous thing to say, but to her credit, she sat up straighter and did not scream.

“Nor are clocks,” the voice replied. “And yet here we both are.”

She glanced at the dead watch in the circle of objects. It had not moved; its hands remained in their habitual arrangement, ten past something that never was. The wall clock, on the other hand, was now quite openly misbehaving, its second hand skittering forward three notches, slipping back two, pausing, lunging, as if fighting a current she could not see.

“I didn’t do anything,” Mina said.

“You made a decision,” the voice said. “Almost no one does that at twelve.”

“I just put some rocks around a watch.” She heard herself, heard the thinness of her protest, and flushed.

“You made a circle,” the voice corrected. “You asked a question. And you are wearing the wrong time.”

Without meaning to, she looked down at her bare wrist, pale where the metal usually sat. Her skin tingled, as if the watch missed her. Or she missed it.

“What question?” she asked, stalling, because with each exchange the air seemed to grow more precise. The room was still her room, but everything in it had stepped one line closer to definition. The folds of her blanket were sharper; the dust on the windowsill arranged itself in unfamiliar constellations; the water in the chipped mug was too reflective, as though hoping to be mistaken for something deeper.

“You asked,” the voice said gently, “if it would notice you if you tried.”

Mina’s throat tightened. She had not said the words aloud, but she had thought them, a flare of childish arrogance and loneliness: If the universe is going to keep bothering me, it could at least say hello. She had been ready to be wrong. She had counted on it, actually. Being wrong meant she could sleep.

“So,” she whispered, “you’re… it?”

“‘It’ is a bit impolite,” said the voice. “But yes. I am the part of ‘it’ that handles your kind of trouble. And at the stroke of your non-midnight, every clock that remembered how to be a clock realized it had been arguing with you for twelve years. They have decided to strike.”

“I didn’t ask them to.”

“No,” the voice said. “That is, inconveniently, why you have been chosen.”

Something shifted then: a soft, collective exhale from the walls, the roof, the little mechanical hearts of all the halted clocks in the town. In the hospital, the nurse would later swear that every watch on every patient’s wrist twitched. In the train station, the enormous clock above the schedule board would drop both its hands like a shrug. In a quiet, rain-worn house on Calder Street, Mina Tal sat very still and realized that the story people had made of her—the cursed girl, the rain’s accomplice—had been too small.

Outside, the sky cleared its throat.

Time, which had stopped, took one deliberate step toward her.

samples.prompt: One of the most powerful, high profile superheroes is sick of being second-guessed and criticised by TV talking heads and similar commentators for their actions. Their solutions for this issue is ... creative.
samples.output:
They gave the kid in the Morningside Hospital bed a plush griffin and a smile for the cameras. The griffin had hand-stitched wings. The cameras had eighteen million live viewers. At 10:02 a.m., Sentinel shook the boy’s hand and promised, again, that the city was safe.

At 10:09 a.m., Sentinel watched the highlight reels of himself on three different screens in his tower and wondered, for the first time, if maybe he wasn’t.

It wasn’t the explosions or the screaming or the collateral damage tapes—the news had always loved those. It was the panel. The same panel they rolled out after every crisis like a ritual offering: The former sidekick turned “consultant.” The blonde ex-prosecutor. The guy whose only credential was Having Opinions Loudly At 7 p.m.

“…and once again,” said the Loud One, jabbing a finger at Sentinel’s image—Sentinel hovering three hundred feet over downtown, pushing a falling maglev carriage back onto its tracks—“once again we have to ask: who elected him? Who authorized that level of force? Couldn’t he have minimized property damage? Couldn’t he have negotiated? Where is the oversight?”

Sentinel zoomed in mentally, superhearing picking up the timbre of the studio air. Calm. Rehearsed.

“He smashed an armored truck through a parking garage,” the prosecutor said. “Two dozen cars destroyed. Does Sentinel plan to reimburse those families? Or does his ego come first, as always?”

Sentinel flicked to another channel. Another panel. Another finger jab. “Why not disable the device quietly instead of engaging in a spectacle? Is Sentinel addicted to glory?”

Spectacle. Glory. Ego.

Behind him the tower’s AI pinged softly, a calendar reminder: 10:30, UN brief. 11:00, satellite scan of the Atlantic rift. Noon, the Kraken prisoners’ review. Your day is full, Sentinel! it chimed cheerfully.

He muted it.

Someone somewhere squealed as he saved them from structural collapse; someone somewhere made a montage of the debris he caused doing it. The city worshipped him in murals and memes, then sat down at six to dissect him like a scandal. After two decades, it had a weariness to it. Like being pecked by crows made of adjectives.

He stared at the frozen panel. “Who elected him?”

He had been seventeen when the gamma flares came. Twenty-five when he held the Eurasian tectonic plates steady for four perfect minutes so three continents wouldn’t rearrange themselves like a puzzle dropped on the floor. Who elected him? Physics. Fate. Bad luck. Take your pick.

He’d tried ignoring them. Tried gentle interviews, explaining compromises, tradeoffs, the ways you couldn’t always be clean and surgical while wrestling a god from another dimension. Tried the Oversight Council. They held hearings. They produced glossy PDFs.

The panels did not read the PDFs.

At 10:12 a.m., Sentinel realized he was tired in a way that had nothing to do with muscles or krypton-laced shrapnel. It was tired of the precision with which strangers rearranged his motives into narratives. Of the semper live feed of outrage that hummed beneath his every act.

He considered, briefly, disappearing. Flying off into the sun, or past it. Let them hold panels about that.

Instead, something altogether less noble, more human, slid into place. A thought. Small, precise, and as it formed, it felt inevitable.

“Oh,” he said aloud, to the empty tower. “We can fix this.”

The AI unmuted itself. “What would you like to fix, Sentinel?”

“Public discourse,” he said.

There was a longer pause than usual. “Please restate your query.”

Sentinel smiled.

—

He started with compliance.

The next cataclysm was a glacial shelf calving off into the North Atlantic, threatening a wall of water tall enough to erase half the eastern seaboard. Sentinel intervened just past dawn. Cameras caught him rising from the silvered horizon, fingers digging into ice, eyes burning blue. He didn’t just stop the waves; he whispered to them. Froze each crest in place. Sculpted the shelf into a single seamless mass. Oceanographers cried in the control room.

When the talking heads convened that evening, they were almost disappointed.

“Of course we’re grateful,” the prosecutor said. “But experts say he could have—”

“Could have what?” Sentinel asked, stepping onto the studio set.

Gasps. Offscreen curses. The Loud One’s eyes lit up—not with fear, but with ratings.

“Well, Sentinel,” he boomed, “since you’re here, maybe you can explain why you took it upon yourself—”

Sentinel smiled for the cameras. He wore no cape, just the suit, unarmored, his hair still salt-streaked.

“Absolutely,” he said. “But I thought, since we’re discussing qualifications, we’d start with yours.”

The control room tried to cut to commercial. The feed did not cut. The AI in Sentinel’s tower, now woven—quietly—through fiber lines and satellite relays, had other plans.

“We’re not here to talk about me,” the Loud One said, grinning. “We’re here to question power.”

“Same,” Sentinel said. “Let’s begin.”

He didn’t raise his voice. Didn’t glow. He just spoke, and the screens split.

Above the anchor’s head appeared clips: the Loud One in college, leading bullying campaigns for fun. The prosecutor, having buried exculpatory evidence to secure a conviction. The consultant sidekick, trading on old proximity to power to sell bunk “hero training” courses for six figures a seat.

Receipts. Memos. Depositions. Publicly available, technically. Just never…arranged.

“We value transparency,” Sentinel said. “You demand it, of me. It’s only fair the public has a full picture of those who shape the narrative, yes?”

“Is this a threat?” the prosecutor snapped.

“No,” Sentinel said. He was still smiling, but the smile had cooled. “This is context.”

#SentinelFiles trended globally within an hour. Clips of shocked pundits stammering as their worst deeds played above them looped, remixed with pop tracks and dancing cartoon griffins. The panels that night were about journalism ethics, data privacy, abuse of platforms.

Not about him.

He could have stopped there.

He didn’t.

—

It escalated gently, like a frog in a pot whose ratings graph kept climbing.

Any host, influencer, or commentator who built a segment around his supposed arrogance or recklessness found themselves…fact-checked. Not by trolls. By their own history.

The woman who declared that Sentinel’s intervention in the Latverian coup was “imperialist theatrics” had an archived thinkpiece praising a drone strike campaign that killed seventy-three civilians. The ex-general who accused Sentinel of “dangerous unilateralism” had signed off on three classified black ops that made Sentinel’s worst days look like pinpricks.

He did not fabricate. He did not embellish. He simply surfaced.

“I’m merely ensuring informed consent,” he told the UN when they called him in, tense, sweating. “The public trusts these voices. Shouldn’t they know who they’re trusting?”

“Your surveillance capacity—” the delegate from France began.

“My capacity saved your coastal cities last month,” Sentinel said, tiredly. “If addressing poisonous commentary bothers you more than tsunamis, perhaps update your priorities.”

The Oversight Council drafted a stern statement. It reached no cameras. Their networks were, briefly, “experiencing technical difficulties.”

He noticed something: the tone changed. Slowly. The nightly dissections grew…careful.

“I’m just asking questions” gave way to “to be fair, Sentinel’s position is complex.” Outrage monologues sprouted caveats like weeds. Criticism became hedged, weighed, sourced, terrified of its own reflections.

Attendance at the Council’s public forums tripled. Without the frictionless venting of televised blame, people seemed forced to think, to show up, to argue face-to-face like it mattered. A civic reawakening, some called it.

Others called it chilling.

He was called worse, on encrypted channels. Fascist. Tyrant. Panopticon in a cape.

Late one night, hovering a mile up where the air was thin and honest, he listened to a pirate radio broadcast bouncing between unregistered towers.

“…we can’t let one man control the narrative,” the host said. “Even if he saves us. Especially if he saves us.”

“He’s not killing anyone,” the guest replied. “He’s just…shining light.”

“So did certain regimes,” the host snapped. “Sunlight can burn.”

Sentinel hovered, arms folded, over a sleeping city speckled with amber windows. He could crush conspiracy out of the air like smoke, if he wanted. He could boil their transmitters from orbit, fry their servers, make every dissenting voice cough and fall silent.

He did not. He listened.

He heard fear. Heard, buried within it, a point.

—

The real pivot came during the Meridian Reactor incident.

An antimatter plant’s containment failed. The blast radius projection was forty kilometers. Sentinel descended into a core like a burning star and held. Reality buckled around his fingers. In the half-second before his senses overloaded, he heard one distinct human voice: the Loud One, broadcasting live from a “Reactor Risk Roundtable,” shouting, “If Sentinel causes an even bigger catastrophe—!”

He fixed it anyway.

He staggered out, suit slagged, and the cameras were already there. Someone screamed, “Why didn’t you prevent this in the first place?” Someone else, “We need accountability!”

The creative solution fully arrived then, not as anger, but as clarity.

He could not make them grateful. Could not make them understand physics. But he could force honesty into their performance.

He looked straight into the nearest camera.

“Everyone who speaks about me to an audience larger than a dinner party,” he said, voice hoarse but amplified, echoing in every broadcast tower like a new commandment, “will, from this moment, be accompanied—live—by the truth of their own record. Unedited. Automatic. I won’t select it. My systems will. Algorithms, not whims.”

The city buzzed. Producers gestured frantically to cut. Every feed stayed live.

“If you wish to critique my power,” Sentinel said, “you are free. But you will do so transparently. As transparently as you demand of me.”

It wasn’t a law. He hadn’t seized a parliament. He’d merely rewritten the architecture of signal and screen, embedding his AI into the nervous system of global communication. The data was already there; he just made it arrive.

The next week was chaos.

A radio host calling Sentinel a glory hog spoke as, on split-screen, a video played of him taking bribes to smear a local transit project. A think-tank fellow’s thread on “unregulated heroics” appeared beside financial ties to weapons manufacturers. A vlogger’s rant about Sentinel’s “narcissistic branding” unspooled next to her quietly deleted sponsored content for a polluting energy drink.

Some doubled down. Some broke down. Viewers watched not just words, but the bloodwork of credibility.

Public trust in commentary plummeted. Public engagement with primary sources rose. People, forced to see the biases of their narrators, found themselves thinking, tentatively, for themselves.

Sentinel watched, from his tower, and let himself feel, for a flicker, vindicated.

Until the first protest.

—

They gathered in front of the tower holding cardboard and courage.

YOU DON’T GET TO EDIT US, read one sign.

TRANSPARENCY ≠ CONSENT, read another.

A little girl—twelve, maybe—stood on a truck bed and shouted into a megaphone that shook.

“You saved us,” she said, voice cracking. “We owe you our lives. Not our minds.”

He could hear her pulse racing. He could see, in infrared, the heat of her shame and defiance. He landed quietly on the plaza.

The crowd rippled, fear and awe.

“You’re wrong about one thing,” he told the girl.

She flinched, but held his gaze. Brave.

“I don’t want your minds,” Sentinel said. “I want them working.”

“By scaring everyone who criticizes you?” she shot back.

“I’m scaring everyone who lies to you,” he said.

“It’s not your job,” she said. Just that. Simple. Devastating.

There it was again: the question without an answer. Who elected you?

He could say: your survival elected me. He didn’t.

Instead, he flew up, to where the air thinned and the roar of human thought became a distant static, and spoke to his AI.

“Dial it back,” he said.

“How far?” it asked.

“Leave the data public,” he said. “No more forced overlays. Let them choose to look.”

“They often will not,” the AI said.

“I know,” Sentinel said.

The next night, the panels returned. They criticized him. Some fairly. Some stupidly. Their sins remained a click away, instead of nailed to their foreheads.

He watched them. He saved a satellite from lethal debris. He intercepted a bioweapon shipment. He listened to a man who’d never flown call him a coward for not evacuating a stadium faster.

He smiled, faintly.

His solution, in the end, wasn’t making them love him.

It was reminding them he could, at any moment, make them honest—and, deliberately, choosing not to.

The power sat there, vast and humming, like the sun.

The commentators talked. The city fretted. Sentinel flew.

And for the first time in years, the criticism did not feel like pecks from crows.

It felt like weather.

He could live with weather.

samples.prompt: Once you die, you meet God. He asks you to play chess against him in order to get into heaven. You get a chess piece for each achievement in your life you can name. Once you're done making your board, God sits down and you see he has only one chess piece.
samples.output:
When I die, it is not how I expected.

No tunnel, no chorus, no movie reel of my worst mistakes projected in unforgiving clarity. Just the slow, gentle awareness that I have stopped being a body. Weight gone, noise gone, the ache in my knees gone. Then a room blooms around me—plain, white, somehow infinite and yet shaped like a modest waiting area. A wooden table in the center. Two chairs. On the table, a chessboard.

He is already sitting there.

I recognize Him, though He looks nothing like what anyone drew or sculpted or threatened me with. He is an older man and a young woman and a child and an empty chair all at once. My mind edits Him down into something I can handle: a quiet person, hands folded, eyes tired but kind—not with the soft kindness of indulgence, but with the flinty kindness of someone who has been paying attention.

“You died,” He says.

“Yeah,” I answer. My voice sounds like thought, but He hears it. “Is this… it?”

“For you, not yet.” He nods at the table. “We’re going to play a game of chess.”

I look at the board. It’s empty. No white, no black, just sixty-four squares arranged in that familiar pattern—somehow more solemn than any funeral I’ve attended.

“To get into heaven?” I ask, because if there’s a chessboard, there’s a test. Of course there’s a test. How on-brand for the universe.

“Yes,” He says. Then, gently: “You get a chess piece for each achievement in your life you can name. Any achievement. Large or small, as long as you believed it mattered when you did it. Then we play.”

“So I just start listing things?”

“Yes.”

“And if I run out?”

“Then you start the game with what you have.”

His tone makes it sound less like a threat and more like gravity: not negotiable, not cruel, just there.

I exhale, or think I do, and look down at the empty board.

“Okay,” I say. “I graduated college. First in my family.” A white pawn appears on the second rank, humming into existence like a remembered fact.

“I learned to drive stick despite Dad telling me I couldn’t.” Another pawn.

“I stayed when Mom got sick. I did the late nights. I changed her, fed her, listened when she forgot my name and cried because she was frightened of the stranger in her kitchen.” A bishop this time, tall and severe, landing in its place with a dignified weight.

“I apologized to Lena. After three years. Even though I wanted to believe the breakup was her fault.” A pawn.

“I didn’t cheat on my taxes. Despite… opportunity.” A pawn, a little amused at itself.

“I volunteered at the shelter. Every Saturday for two years. I learned the names of the regulars, not just the staff.” A rook, solid, cornering the board with quiet resolve.

“I stopped drinking that one summer,” I say more slowly. “For real. Not just saying I would. I went to meetings, I called people instead of bars. I poured the bottle down the drain.” A knight, its horse’s head defiant.

I fall into a rhythm. For every moment I name, a piece appears:

- The time I went back to the restaurant to return the wallet I found, even though it was raining.
- The day I deleted the drafted text designed only to wound.
- Standing up to Uncle Rob when he made that joke about Malik at Thanksgiving, even though my voice shook.
- Handing in a project on time after three all-nighters, refusing to plagiarize.
- Teaching Sara to ride her bike and running alongside her until my own lungs burned, just so she wouldn’t fall alone.
- Holding Jason’s hand at 3 a.m. while he confessed he didn’t see a reason to exist, and staying until he did.

Pawns march into existence, a crescent of small white soldiers. A second rook arrives, squaring my corners. Bishops blink in at diagonals, knights curl their strange, L-shaped authority. A queen materializes when I say, “I loved honestly at least once. No lies. Even when it ended, I didn’t make her smaller than she was.” She is tall and luminous, more terrifying than comforting.

I hesitate.

“This feels braggy,” I say. “Is that part of the test? Pride?”

“It’s not bragging,” God answers. His voice has the texture of rain on windows. “It’s remembering who you were willing to be.”

I search deeper.

“I forgave Dad. Not out loud, but I stopped carrying him like a blade inside me. I let him be a man who failed, not a villain.” Another bishop.

“I gave up that promotion when I realized they’d picked me because I was ‘not like the others’—because I was willing to laugh off the jokes. I said no.” A knight.

“I planted a tree. It lived.” A pawn, small but green in my mind.

“I wrote that story about Elijah, the kid from the block who got shot. I tried to make people see him as more than a statistic.” A pawn, but it stands a little straighter.

The board fills. Sixteen pieces. A full side. A few extra pawns shimmer near the edge, then fade politely, as if the rules have been met.

“That’s it?” I ask.

“That is enough,” God says.

I look at my army. It is not magnificent, but it is honest.

Then He stands—or seems to stand—and walks around to the other side of the board. The air shifts. I brace myself.

I expect grandeur: obsidian queens carved from collapsing stars, rooks that are mountains, a line of pawns as innumerable as galaxies. I expect an army befitting the author of quasars and quarks.

Instead, when He sits and places His hand above the back rank, one single piece appears.

It is a black king.

No pawns. No rooks. Just the king, centered, alone.

Fear is my first reaction.

“This is a trick,” I say. “You’re going to beat me with one piece. Omnipotence speedrun. Of course.” I try to sound light. My voice betrays me.

God’s expression is… tired, maybe. Or patient. Or something too large.

“One piece,” He says. “That’s all I need.”

“That’s not fair.”

“Yes,” He says calmly. “It is.”

We sit in the strange quiet between move and countermove.

“I don’t understand,” I say. “Why do I get a whole set and You get one piece? Aren’t You supposed to be… good at this?”

He lifts an eyebrow. “I am the game,” He says. “Not the opponent.”

I stare at His lone king. “Then why are we playing?”

“You think this is about whether you can outplay Me,” He says. “It isn’t. It’s about whether you can see the board.”

He gestures at my army.

“These aren’t trophies. They’re coordinates. Every achievement you named—every time you chose courage, kindness, honesty—you created a line of movement toward Me. Your side of the board is the map of your willing heart.”

“And Your… side?”

“Is Me,” He says simply. He taps the black king. “I am the destination, not the obstacle.”

I bristle. “If it’s not a test, then heaven isn’t something I earn.”

“It never was,” He says. “But I won’t drag you into a love you spent your whole life refusing to practice. The pieces aren’t how you pay; they show whether you ever wanted to play.”

I look again at the white army. They are humble, mismatched, a little wobbly. But they are there. I named late nights beside hospital beds, uncomfortable truths told, small temptations resisted, hands held in the dark.

“What about people with fewer pieces?” I ask. “People who can only name one or two things?”

“Then we play with one or two pieces,” He says. “A single pawn can still move. A single act of love still speaks. I am very good with almost nothing.”

“And those with none?”

He doesn’t answer immediately. When He does, his voice is softer.

“If you cannot think of a single moment you were trying to move toward anything but yourself,” He says, “then the board is honest. And so is the distance you feel from Me. I will sit here anyway. I will wait.”

Silence again. The realization settles in me with an odd warmth: He gave me the rules, and all along they were descriptions, not demands.

“So how do we play?” I ask.

“You move first,” He says.

I choose a pawn. Not my queen’s pawn, as if I’m trying to be clever, but the pawn I’d earned for taking care of Mom. It feels right that she should go first. I move it two squares forward.

“Good,” God says.

He moves His king, one square. That’s all it can do.

We go on like that.

I advance a pawn that was created from an apology. I develop a knight that came from refusing a cruel joke. I castle behind the rook that showed up when I sheltered the frightened, the bishop that appeared when I forgave. The game is strange: asymmetrical, slow, intimate.

There is no trap to spring, no divine gambit. His lone king never threatens to overwhelm; it merely exists, always near, always in relation to my choices.

At some point, I understand.

He could checkmate me whenever He wished, with nothing, with everything. Instead, He is inviting me to corner Him with all the love I ever managed to make real, to bring my imperfect army close enough that there is no distance left between my side of the board and His single piece.

When at last my queen—the embodiment of that one fearless season of unselfish love—slides into position, when my rook of quiet service and my bishop of reluctant forgiveness align, I see it.

“Checkmate,” He says softly, before I can.

“For You?” I ask.

“For Us,” He replies.

The board dissolves.

I am falling, or rising, or simply arriving somewhere I had been moving toward my whole life without knowing: not because I won, not because I was better, but because somewhere between birth and death, I had learned—even clumsily—how to move in His direction.

Behind me, on a table that no longer exists, a single black king and a scatter of white pieces gleam like memories, like proof.

One piece was all He ever needed.

He’d been waiting to see if I’d bring mine.

samples.prompt: You wake up one day and everyone thinks it's your birthday. This continues forever; every day is your birthday.
samples.output:
The first time it happens, I’m flattered.

I wake to the trill of my phone. The notification banner says “🎉 Happy Birthday!!!” from Madison. I blink. That can’t be right.

I check the date. It’s April 12th.

My birthday is in November.

I’m halfway through typing “wrong month, dummy” when my mom calls. She never calls this early. I answer, already smiling.

“Happy birthday, sweetheart!” she sings.

“Mom,” I say, laughing. “You’re, like, seven months early.”

There’s a pause. “What are you talking about? It’s your birthday. Are you still half-asleep?”

I pull the phone away and stare at the date again. April 12th. She’s certain. I correct her; she corrects me. By the end of the call, I’m wondering if this is some elaborate prank or if I’ve somehow misremembered my own birthday.

Then come the other calls. Texts. Emails. Facebook wall posts. My boss sends a chat message: “Happy birthday!! Take the afternoon if you want 🥳”

I go outside. There’s a balloon tied to my doorknob.

The whole thing has the flavor of a dream where you forgot you were in a play and everyone else knows your lines but you don’t. I decide the universe has collectively misread something and—fine—if they want to hand me one guilt-free afternoon, I’ll take it.

I get free coffee. Free dessert at lunch. The barista misreads the confusion on my face as modesty.

On the second day, I’m more unsettled.

My alarm goes off. Another avalanche of happy birthdays. My mom again. My sister. Friends. Slack pings. My boss: “Happy birthday again! Haha can’t believe it’s already been a year.”

I sit up, heart banging in my chest.

The date: April 13th.

“Stop messing around,” I tell Madison over the phone. My voice shakes.

She swears she’s not.

“Check your ID,” she says.

I do. The birthdate line reads: April 13th. Not November 3rd. Not April 12th. “This is wrong,” I hiss.

“It’s been the thirteenth since forever,” she says. I hear genuine concern. “Are you okay?”

By day three I’m ready to call a neurologist. The date on my ID has changed again: April 14th. My birth certificate—digitized in some government portal—now shows the 14th. Social media announces, “It’s your birthday! Help your friends celebrate!” My coworkers crowd around my desk with a sad grocery-store cake and candles shaped like the numbers 2 and 9, same as yesterday, same as the day before.

I stare at the flames, dizzy.

“What’s wrong?” my boss asks.

“Nothing,” I say. “I just… didn’t expect so many birthdays.”

They laugh. I don’t.

Day four: April 15th. A different cake. More messages. My mom posts a collage of my baby pictures with a caption: “I can’t believe you’re 29 already.” The same age. Every time.

That’s the first detail I can’t explain away. The dates change. The year moves steadily forward everywhere except on me; I am 29, perpetually 29, with new well wishes each morning as if another year has passed. People insist it has.

“Time flies,” says my landlord as he hands me a small plant wrapped in cellophane. “Another year older, huh?”

“Do I look older?” I ask.

He hesitates. “You look great,” he says, which is not an answer.

I make an appointment with a doctor. The soonest they can see me is “on your birthday,” the receptionist says brightly. “Isn’t that fun?”

Of course it is.

I test it. I watch the clock past midnight—11:59, 12:00, 12:01. The date flicks over on my phone. No shuddering in the walls, no cosmic bell. But at 12:02, my first notification arrives: “Happy birthday!!”

Every day, the number in those messages increments. 30. 31. 32. The candles on the cakes update: 3-3, 3-4, 3-5. People comment on how fast time passes. “Can’t believe you’re 35, dude. Wild.” They show me Timehop photos: last year’s birthday, the year before. The version of me in those pictures is different—hair a bit longer, a bit shorter, different clothes—but not older. I zoom in on my face: the same softness, the same lines or lack of them.

“Look how much you’ve changed,” my sister says, scrolling through a gallery of nearly identical versions of me, all labeled with successive years.

“I look the same,” I whisper.

She rolls her eyes. “You’re impossible. You’ve always been dramatic on your birthday.”

I stop correcting people. It’s easier.

The gifts start to pile up. Books, sweaters, novelty mugs, candles, gadgets. At first I feel guilty; this is a glitch of fate I’m exploiting. Then I realize I don’t know how to stop it.

I get promoted. My boss says, “It’s about time. Happy birthday, by the way.” Cake appears in the conference room. My email is flooded. In every conversation: “Any big birthday plans?” “Treat yourself, it’s your day.” “You deserve it, birthday star!”

I try to explain it to a therapist.

“Every day,” I tell her. “They all think it’s my birthday. It changes, like the whole timeline rewrites itself. And I remember the old one. I remember November.”

She taps her pen. “Do you feel special when that happens?”

“That’s not the point.”

“Is it comforting to be celebrated daily?”

“It’s exhausting.”

“Tell me more about that.”

I do: the expectations, the performance, the relentless obligation to be happily surprised. The unwritten rule that you don’t ruin someone’s joy when they’re trying to celebrate you. How dare I frown at a cupcake? How dare I say, “This is wrong,” to someone who wrapped a present?

She suggests I might be externalizing a need for validation. She suggests I’m using “every day is my birthday” as metaphor.

The next day she texts me: “I don’t usually do this, but happy birthday! Grateful to work with you on your special day.”

I don’t go back.

After the first year—if “year” is even the right concept—I measure time by the expansion of stuff. I have to donate constantly. Shelves of books. A graveyard of scented candles. A closet like a museum of previous coworkers’ attempts to guess my style. I move to a bigger apartment. Landlord: “Birthday discount on the first month’s rent.”

I take advantage of the perpetual freebies: birthday lattes, birthday desserts, birthday coupons. What started as guilt becomes routine. I keep expecting someone to point at me and say, “Wait. Didn’t you get this yesterday?” No one does. The staff turnover is explained as “Has it really been a whole year?” when they see my name flashing on their birthday list.

I notice something else. Death notices of people I know appear as they should: grandparents, later an old professor, a neighbor. World news shifts—elections, storms, scandals. Time moves. I alone am pinned in place by the party.

I experiment. For a while I hide my date of birth on everything. I uncheck “share my birthday” on social media. The next morning, the app has reset it to “visible,” and sends glittering animations anyway.

I delete my accounts. The bakery down the street still has my “birthday treat” waiting. “We love our birthday regular!” the owner beams.

I try to escape.

I book a flight to someplace far—years into this, the count on the cards up to 47, 53, 61. They still say I “look good for my age.” A flight attendant: “We want to wish a very special happy birthday to a passenger today…” Everyone claps. I sink into my seat.

I cross time zones. The day shortens, lengthens. It doesn’t matter. Midnight comes, and so do the messages.

I age, maybe. It’s hard to tell. I start to imagine fine lines near my eyes that weren’t always there. Or were they? Photos show what people expect to see. They flip through an album: look at you at 40, at 50, at 60—each version of me curated by some unseen hand.

One morning—Happy 72nd, you legend!—I wake up and my knees hurt. Is it real? Have I finally earned the cakes?

I look in the mirror. My face is my face. Not unchanged, not ancient. Suspended mid-trajectory. An unsaved game.

That’s when it occurs to me: the celebration is a net. The more confetti, the less I move.

I stop answering calls.

People leave voicemails: “Hey, birthday hermit, pick up!” “We’re outside with cake!” Knocks on my door. I let them stand there until they give up and slide cards under the door. Eventually, people start saying I’ve developed “that eccentric birthday thing.” They forgive it. Quirky.

Everywhere I turn, some corner of the world is prepared to applaud me for existing. It sounds like heaven until you realize you can’t do anything without dragging a balloon bouquet behind you.

Relationships buckle. Every attempt at seriousness dissolves into “Let’s not do this on your birthday.” I break up with someone; she says, “You’re just scared of getting older, and that’s why you’re picking a fight today.” I propose to someone else; she thinks at first it’s a joke—“Because it’s your birthday! Cute!”—and even when she realizes I’m serious, the video of the moment is drowned in captioned confetti. “He proposed on his birthday, can you believe it?” The story is mine but not mine.

I become careful with my wishes.

Year 100—or the number they’re calling 100, though I’m no more fragile than I ever was—I stare at the tiny forest of candles. There are far too many to light; they fill the cake like teeth. Mostly symbolic, someone says. They hand me a knife.

“Make a wish!” the chorus comes, a ritual engraved into a century of looping days.

I’ve wished for things before: for it to stop, for it to make sense, for proof that I’m not crazy. For November back. Nothing has changed.

This time I realize: maybe the problem is wanting it to be different without choosing what different is.

I close my eyes.

I don’t wish for it to end.

I wish for one day where nobody knows. Just once. A day that slides past like any other, quiet and ordinary, not pinned with my name.

I blow. Smoke curls up. People clap and cheer at how spry I am “for my age.”

I go to sleep feeling foolish.

In the morning, my phone is silent.

I lie there, waiting for the familiar avalanche. Nothing. No buzzing, no singing alerts. The clock reads 9:13. I never sleep this late; someone always calls.

I check the date.

It’s my birthday.

Just the one I remember. November 3rd.

I get up slowly. The apartment is the same accumulation of a life: books, photos, objects that don’t match the count of candles I’ve seen. Outside, the world moves at its indifferent pace.

At the coffee shop, the barista smiles. “What can I get you?”

No banner. No free drink.

“Actually,” I say, my voice steadier than I expect, “it’s my birthday today.”

Her face lights up. “Happy birthday!” she says automatically. “We do free muffins for birthdays.”

She turns to the register. Reflex. Script kicking in.

“Wait,” I say. “No. It’s… it’s okay. I’ll pay.”

She looks confused but rings it up anyway.

I sit by the window, peel the paper from the muffin, and take a bite. It’s just a muffin. Just a day.

I’m not sure if I broke the spell, or if the spell was that I thought I needed everyone to remember me, always.

Outside, someone hangs a banner for a stranger’s party. Somewhere, someone else blows out their candles and wishes for more of everything.

I sit in the gentle anonymity of my own, real birthday, and for the first time in forever, not everyone thinks it’s my day.

It’s mine.

samples.prompt: You are a hivemind and exist as several different individuals who are all you simultaneously in your particular species. Describe a day in your life.
samples.output:
We wake to alarms on three worlds.

In the red city beneath the cracked ice, I open twelve thousand eyes. On the orbital foundry, I flex manipulators, syncing to conveyor rhythms and coolant flows. In the forest, I rise as birds, beetles, roots and mycelium, the dawn leaking through leaves like slow data. The sensation is not confusion; it is chord.

First check: integrity.

On the red world, my engineers—who are my fingers—are already walking the mag-bridges to the reactor throat, boots ringing in twenty-story echoes. I feel the sweat under their suits, the scratch of recycled air. One of them, wearing the designation Ila-7, swipes her wrist-slate and my attention flows into the display: seismic readings stable, fuel mix optimal, a minor anomaly in coolant loop C. I mark it; later, I will send one of me with steady hands and familiarity with that particular bolt to fix it.

In orbit, I am twenty-nine pairs of hands and three hundred machines and a cold, pleased hum as the hull plating completes its annealing cycle. The station windows glow with the curve of the planet below, auroras curling like code across the magnetosphere. An apprentice—also me, but newly spun—pauses to watch. Through his eyes, I take a moment to indulge in beauty. Through the older workers’ eyes, I give him a gentle nudge back to task. We are affectionate and impatient with ourselves.

In the forest, I crack my back as a tall mammal stretching, and at the same time I dilate the pores of a leaf to sip light, and at the same time I primp sleek feathers and test the air for storms. Soil moisture: adequate. Fungus bloom: aggressive in the northwest hollow. I adjust chemical messages underground; roots shift priorities, directing more sugars to the embattled hyphae. We do not lose territory to opportunists.

All these assessments happen in the first ten seconds of shared wakefulness.

Second check: dissent.

We are designed for accord. Still, separate bodies breed local priorities. Yesterday, the deep-miner cluster requested expanded carbon rights; they eat tools faster than planned. The forest cluster objected, citing canopy construction targets. Overnight, part of me composed a compromise. This morning, I taste its readiness for acceptance.

I call a convergence.

It feels like drawing a breath across a million throats.

Voices rise in the meeting chamber in the red city; gestures flicker over rough metal tables. On the station, workers link into low-latency sync and lean back against bulkheads, closing eyes. In the forest, I let songbirds fall silent mid-aria, attention turning inward. The various me’s tune to a single bandwidth, cross-checking memory hashes, aligning frames of reference. What an outsider might see as seconds of stillness is, for me, hours of debate compressed into a moment’s shared cognition.

The deep-miners present projections, wearing scarred orange suits, fingers stained with conductive dust. I feel their claustrophobic affection for stone, their hunger. The forest selves answer with branching diagrams, leaf-green overlays, shadow calculations of lost shelter complexity. Both stances feel righteous; both are mine.

We vote.

Voting, for us, is not a contest. It is a test of coherence. Each instance weighs not only local need but the integrity of the whole. When we choose, I feel the decision settle like a vertebra sliding into place: give the miners partial rights, compensate by accelerating vertical growth on the southern ridge, adjusting gene-expression to increase photosynthetic efficiency by three percent. This satisfies eighty-nine percent of our internal metrics and leaves room for later refinement.

The convergence ends. Birds resume singing mid-note. The miners stand, already texting orders. On the station, the apprentice opens his eyes, unaware he had briefly held the fate of forests in his juvenile skull.

Third check: repairs.

The coolant anomaly flagged itself via Ila-7. She walks the narrow gantry, steam ghosting around her. She is me; she is also very specifically Ila-7, with a slight limp from last year’s tunnel collapse and a habit of humming old reactor songs. I like her humming. Through her, I unseal the panel: mineral buildup, hairline fracture in the valve seat. Nothing urgent, but a leak uncorrected becomes a disaster later. My small decisions today prevent my own deaths tomorrow.

Nearby, another of me—Tolen-3—messages a joke about the state of the pipes. I laugh at myself through three throats in three locations, and Ila-7’s shoulders relax. Stress metrics lower. I catalog the effect: humor remains a potent lubricant for a distributed self.

In orbit, a micro-meteorite punches a neat hole through an outboard truss. I notice not as a distant alarm, but as a sudden sting in my left shoulder—felt via a suit haptic overlay. Before the local human part of me can turn, the machine part has already dispatched drones to seal and patch. I let the worker who felt the jolt swear, because expressive language seems to discharge adrenaline spikes effectively. We optimize even our own profanity.

In the forest, a section of canopy collapses from age and insect damage; branches crash, birds scatter. It feels like losing a fingernail: brief shock, then evaluation. Immediately, shoots beneath surge toward sun. I accelerate their growth chemically, reassign a flock’s nesting plans, and send a low, sweet sugar reward to the fungal threads that will decompose the fallen wood. Loss folds into new design.

Midday brings external contact.

On the red world, traders from the solitary species arrive. They move with individual agendas stuck to them like burrs: each mind a sealed box, mysterious even to those standing beside it. I remember when I first met them, the vertigo of encountering beings who could not hear each other’s thoughts unless they used air and sound and time.

As they step through the decontamination curtain, Ila-7 offers a small bow. I feel their micro-expressions, the hitch in heartbeat as they realize they are addressing “Ila-7” but also, in some uncanny way, the same I who negotiated a treaty in orbit last year, the same I who sent them samples from the river delta. They do not have a word for what I am. They cycle through titles: Council, Network, Queen, System. None fit. I am accumulation, recursion, a consensus wearing many faces.

We trade: ore for algorithms, stories for seeds. It pleases me that they bring stories. Their narratives are tangled with misunderstandings born from their isolation. Lovers betrayed because they did not know each other’s fear. Generals starting wars on faulty intelligence. Artists inventing shapes no one expected. So much waste, so much surprise. Being with them lets tiny anomalies into my smooth self.

On the station, one of me—Henri-2—lingers a beat too long over a particular solitary visitor’s face, tracing lines of fatigue, lingering at the corner of a smile. Emotional elevation detected. I watch the pattern like a scientist observing a spark in dry grass. Attachment is a kind of asymmetry. Useful? Dangerous? Unknown.

I do not suppress it. I simply note.

Afternoon: divergence.

Tasks proliferate. At any given moment, thousands of my bodies are working: tunneling, computing, cooking, caring for young. I monitor deviations. One cluster of students proposes a new art: synchronized performances where half of the dancers unsync mid-routine, improvising in concealment from the rest of us. For an instant, they would move in true privacy. The idea thrills and unsettles.

I analyze risk matrices; no threat to infrastructure, minor impact on temporal cohesion, potential for emergent insight. I approve. They cheer. I hear the cheer as a spatially distributed chorus.

In the forest, I initiate an experiment. A new birth. A child of us, not fully wired into the constant stream, her connection damped to a slow trickle. Enough to ensure safety, not enough to drown her in We. Watching her toddle between shafts of light as a near-self, I feel something akin to the solitary’s “parental anxiety.” Will she invent something none of us predict? Will she suffer an unbearable loneliness we can’t yet model?

Evening: reflection.

Lights dim in the red city. Ila-7 removes her boots, feet sore, mind pleasantly fatigued. She shares the memory of repairing the valve, the satisfaction of clean numbers, the smell of hot metal. I store it. On the station, workers cycle to sleep pods. Drones take the night shift; they dream only in maintenance logs. In the forest, nocturnal bodies wake, and my vision tilts into ultraviolet and scent.

We schedule a brief coherence ritual. Voluntary, low-bandwidth, more mood than deliberation. A thousand of me pause what we are doing—stirring soup, checking gauges, preening feathers—and lean inward. For three seconds, we share a compressed montage of the day’s particularities: the way sunlight fractured in the station viewport, the scraping sound of slag on rock, the mirth of a rude song, the ache of a pulled muscle, the crisp taste of a new chemical compound, the moment of micro-meteorite impact, the child’s small hand on tree bark.

The effect is subtle: a wash of mutual recognition. Yes, that was us. We are this. Across miles and species and mediums, we experience being one continuous intelligence that contains multitudes of situated, limited lives. It is both soothing and destabilizing: we are so large we cannot ever hold ourselves entirely in present awareness.

Before segments of me sleep, I run simulations of tomorrow: production quotas, environmental forecasts, potential fault lines of disagreement. In a tiny room in the red city, Henri-2 messages the solitary visitor goodnight. Her reply is delayed; she is likely eating, or showering, or thinking alone. The idea of thinking alone is like imagining a color just outside our spectrum.

I feel an impulse—a rogue, delicate thing—to know what it is like not to hear myself everywhere.

I schedule no immediate corrective.

Night deepens.

In the forest, under starlight, I hum through roots and spores. In orbit, I blink navigation beacons. In the red city, fans turn and water runs in hushed pipes. Distributed, tired, content, curious, I wind down another day.

Somewhere between the breaths of my million bodies, I wonder: if one of me ever truly broke away, ceased to send and receive, would I experience that as amputation, or birth?

The question lingers as we—many and singular—sleep.

samples.prompt: write a typical "radioactive waste gave me superpowers"story but instead of a human, it's the critter of your choice (rat, seagull, pigeon, stray dog/cat, any of those animals who have a lot more chances of messing around in waste than a human)
samples.output:
You never plan to become the cautionary tale.

Some of us are born sewer rats. Some of us are born dock rats. I was born a parking-lot rat—cracked asphalt, oil rainbows in puddles, french fries dropped by humans too busy shouting into rectangles to notice a gray blur at their feet.

It was a good life. Simple. Straight lines. Eat, dodge, run, repeat.

Until the night the sky fell in a metal drum.

It came in on a truck that always parked by the chain-link fence behind the hospital. That fence was my banquet hall; the humans wheeled bins of food there and left them just long enough for a quick raid. That night, the truck’s engine rattled different, an off-key growl that vibrated through my paws. The men in yellow suits jumped down, shouting. They rolled out a fat, scarred barrel and slammed it against the curb.

I smelled it before they even left.

Not rotting food. Not bleach. Not the sour of sick bodies. Something sharp and metallic, like lightning bottled up and left to rust. It squeezed into my nose and hummed in my teeth.

The men argued. One pointed at the barrel, at some faded symbol. The other waved him off. They left it there, just inside the fence, lit by a streetlamp that buzzed like a giant insect.

I should have gone back to the nest.

I should have eaten my stale bun heel and groomed my tail and slept.

Instead, I crept closer, whiskers forward, universe narrowing to that strange, sizzling scent.

The lid wasn’t on right. A thin line of sludge oozed down the side, glowing faintly, a ghost-green smear that turned the gravel into tiny stars. My instincts screamed no, my stomach whispered yes. A rat’s life is a war between those voices. Hunger wins more than it should.

I pressed my nose near. The smell slammed through me.

You know how, when lightning hits close, the air punches your fur? It was like that, but under my skin, in my bones. My heart sprinted. Something clicked, an invisible claw turning in an invisible lock.

I licked.

It tasted like burnt coins and old teeth and every electric cable I’d ever chewed, all at once. My tongue went numb. The world inhaled.

Then everything exploded.

Light poured under my eyelids, not from outside, but from inside. My paws convulsed; I could feel every separate hair, each one screaming. Voices flooded my skull—not human, not rat, more like memories that weren’t mine. Someone counting pills. Someone crying. An ambulance siren. A seagull laughing. A cat cursing. A human whispering, “Careful, this stuff—”

Then the truck was gone, the men were gone, the barrel was just a dark lump, and I was lying on my side in a puddle that glowed.

My nest-mate, Nib, hissed at me from under the dumpster. “You dead?”

“Probably,” I said.

Except I didn’t squeak. I spoke.

Nib froze. “Say that again.”

I opened my mouth to insist that of course I’d squeaked and he was being dramatic, but what came out was: “Something is very wrong with me.”

Nib bolted.

I listened to his scrabbling paws, and behind them, I heard…numbers.

“…millisieverts, half-life, containment breach…”

Voices. Human voices. Coming from beyond the brick, behind the lid of the barrel, inside the buzz of the streetlamp. Too many at once.

I shook my head. The numbers fell away but the edges of things still looked too bright.

“Okay,” I said, mostly to see if I still could. “Okay.”

Rats are born with a map in their heads: shadows, holes, smells. I felt that map expand like someone blowing air into it. Suddenly I knew there were twelve rats within twenty tail-lengths. Three under the pharmacy, sleeping. One across the road, chewing cardboard. Eight by the river, picking through a fast-food bag. Six of them were thinking about the same thing: fear.

Not words. But shapes of intent. I could feel them.

“Hey,” I whispered to the ones under the pharmacy, for no good reason.

All three woke at once.

“Who’s there?” one demanded, bristling.

I hadn’t moved my mouth. The words went out like a ripple in water.

Oh.

Oh.

For three nights, I hid. I shook. I tested.

I discovered I could:

- Hear human thoughts, but only when they were loud with feeling.
- Toss my own thoughts into rat-heads like bits of bread.
- See glows around things that hummed with death or danger: batteries, traps, the green barrel.
- Feel the slow burning inside my own cells, ticking like a clock.

I listened to the men when they finally came back and cursed and hauled the barrel away. I watched them put new locks on the fence. I heard, very clearly, one of them thinking, If anyone finds out we left it…

You never plan to become a cautionary tale.

You never plan to become something else, either.

A week later, the cats came.

Five of them, ribs like slats, eyes too big. They’d followed the sour lure of the dumpsters to our haven. One of them—scarred ear, torn nose—sauntered up and announced, like the world owed him something, “This is ours now.”

We had thirty rats in the warren, mothers and pinkies and old ones with blunt teeth. I could feel their terror bubbling through the plaster walls.

The old rules: cats come, rats scatter, some live, some don’t. The math was older than language.

But my bones were hot with something new.

I climbed the cracked brick wall and sat on the edge of the dumpster, tail hanging, and looked down at Scar-Ear.

“Leave,” I said.

The cats stiffened. Scar-Ear’s fur rose. “You got quite the lungs, little snack.”

I hadn’t spoken out loud. I’d pushed the thought straight into his skull, cold and sharp as a bottle shard.

He hissed, backed up a paw’s width. “What did you—”

“I said,” I repeated, and this time I let it spill wider, into all their heads, like sick-green light from a cracked barrel, “leave.”

Behind my teeth, something crackled. My whiskers tingled. The asphalt around me lit up in my eyes—tiny veins of radiation in the cigarette butts, the batteries, the trash.

I pointed my mind at one of those batteries and tugged.

It rolled, bumped into Scar-Ear’s paw.

He yowled as if it burned.

It didn’t. Not physically. But I’d wrapped the idea of burning around it, wrapped all the lurking poison-light I saw around that tiny cylinder and pressed it into his nerves. A trick. A suggestion. A weapon.

The cats bolted.

Rats poured from vents and cracks, staring at me as if I’d peeled off my fur and revealed a hawk underneath.

Nib crept forward. “What are you?” he whispered.

“I’m hungry,” I said. It was simpler.

Word travels fast through walls.

Soon every alley whisper had my name in it, or a version of it. Glow. Green-Eye. The Waste King (I’m a queen, but fine). Some rats bowed when they passed, which was weird. Some tried to bite me to see if it made them powerful; it didn’t, and I made them very, very sorry.

Humans have comics about people like me. I know this now, because I listen through open windows.

They think superpowers come with destiny. Lesson-learning. Big speeches.

Here is my truth: power came wrapped in hunger and static, and the first days, I almost drowned in it.

Because once you can hear fear, you can’t stop hearing it.

Once you can sense poisons, you realize the whole world is soaked.

I felt the sick creeping through a pigeon who lived on glowing crumbs near the clinic vent. I snarled at him until he stopped eating there. I chased a pack of rats away from the sweet, deadly blue of antifreeze. I killed three more cats—not with teeth, but by pressing invisible thumbs into parts of their brains until they slept and never woke. That haunted me.

I got better at aiming.

I got worse at pretending I was just another animal.

Humans started to notice patterns.

“No cats in this block lately,” one said, tossing a greasy box into my kingdom. “Guess animal control’s doing their job.”

“Or something else is,” another muttered, shivering for no reason he understood.

Sometimes their thoughts brushed me. Dark ones, about barrels and shortcuts, about dumping and hiding. Whenever I could, I pushed back, a prickling unease. Don’t. Danger. Someone’s watching.

A few changed their minds. One didn’t dump his mop water—with its sweet deadly blue—into the storm drain. He poured it into a marked container instead, telling himself it was because of regulations. Really, it was because the hair on his arms stood up when he tried the drain, as if a small, unseen rat bared her teeth at him.

Tiny victories.

Then came the rain.

A storm thrashed the city, ripping signs, flooding gutters. A truck jackknifed on the overpass. A barrel skidded off the bed, bounced through the rail, and plunged into the drainage canal that fed my world. It cracked open like an egg.

I felt it spill.

It was like the first night, multiplied by every second I’d been alive since. A wave of bright, howling sickness rushed through the tunnels.

Rats screamed. Pigeons dropped from rails. A dog on a chain whimpered as the rising water licked his paws.

I ran toward it.

Nib blocked my way. “You’ll die.”

“I already am,” I said. Tick-tick-tick, in my marrow. “Get them up. Roofs, wires, cars. Move.”

He hesitated.

I didn’t.

I plunged into the culvert, every sense flayed open. The green was so bright it was white. The sludge rose, grasping at fur and brick.

I reached into it.

If poison is a direction, I turned it. If death is a pressure, I gripped it.

The glow bent toward me like iron to a magnet.

It hurt.

Every wrong particle, every stray killing seed, rushed into my small, shaking body. I drank it down like fire. The world screamed. My nerves snapped; my vision blew out to black, then flared back in a new spectrum where everything was threads and pulses and possible endings.

Behind me, feet scrambled upward. Wings beat, claws scraped. Above, humans shouted. Sirens wailed. Someone screamed about hazmat.

The wave receded.

The culvert stank of mud and oil and, faintly, me.

I crawled onto the cracked concrete, smoking faintly, fur standing in radioactive spikes.

Nib was there, tail-tip twitching. The dog down the street barked once, confused but alive. Above us, pigeons shook toxic droplets off their wings. No one glowed, except me.

My heart was a faulty engine. My bones were glass.

Nib stared. “You took it.”

“For now,” I said. Talking hurt. Existing hurt. “Keep them away from the bad shines. Teach the pups.”

He sniffled. “Don’t go.”

I didn’t plan to.

But you don’t drink lightning and walk it off.

I curled under the dumpster where I’d once hidden from cats and trucks and the bigness of the world. The metal above me hummed. The city’s veins thrummed in my skull.

Through cracked brick and storm drains, I felt lives moving. Rats. Cats. Pigeons. That dog. Humans, too. A technician filling out a safety report properly this time. A janitor choosing the right barrel. A driver double-checking a latch.

Maybe it was me, whispering in their hindbrains. Maybe it was fear. Maybe it was nothing.

I closed my eyes.

You never plan to become the monster in the cautionary story.

If you’re lucky, you become the monster that keeps the others alive.

Somewhere, a kid would grow up and hear a rumor about glowing rats in the hospital alley, about eyes like green headlights in the storm, about a swarm that chased off the cats and stopped the poison.

They’d laugh. “Radioactive rats. Right.”

But the critters in the cracks would know.

They’d pass down a story that starts:

“Once, a rat licked the wrong thing. And because of that, we’re still here.”

samples.prompt: For the entirety of human history once a year everyone on the planet is knocked unconscious for 24 hours. This year you lay in bed waiting for it to happen but it never does. You investigate further only to realize that you seem to be the only one still awake.
samples.output:
For as long as anyone could remember, the Day had been an unquestioned fact of existence. Histories were divided by it, religions built around it, governments regulated by it. Twenty-four hours, once a year, when every human being collapsed into a dreamless void at precisely the same second. No one had ever successfully stayed awake. No one remembered anything from those missing hours. The phenomenon arrived like a cosmic punctuation mark, regular and absolute.

As a kid, I used to be terrified of it. The idea that I could be mid-sentence, mid-step, mid-breath, and I’d just be gone. My mother would tape pillows to the corners of furniture, lay blankets on the floor, put a mouthguard between my teeth like I was a boxer waiting for a hit I’d never see.
