When I was eight, I asked her, “What if I don’t wake up?”

“You always will,” she said. “We always do.”

She said it with the calm devotion of someone who’d seen it happen thirty times already. And she was right. Everyone always woke up.

The Day synchronized humanity in a way nothing else did. Flights were grounded, surgeries rescheduled, reactors set to automatic protocols. The world’s infrastructure pulsed in a yearly ritual of preparation: backup systems, shutdown sequences, checklists refined over centuries. There were no wars launched on the Day. No laws passed, no votes taken. It was the one calendar entry no one argued with.

This year, the countdown clocks had been everywhere, as usual. News anchors reminding people not to drive within ten minutes of the Moment. Influencers posting “See you on the other side” videos. Governments beaming out reassuring statements that all critical systems were secure. Nothing new. Just the familiar nervous humor people used to talk about hurricanes and eclipses.

I lay in bed like I always did, face lit by my phone, watching the seconds bleed away.

00:00:08.

00:00:07.

I’d tried to resist in the past, of course. Everyone had. There were experiments with stimulants and alarms, EEGs and blink-rate monitors. People chained themselves upright, stuck their hands in ice water, poured energy drinks down their throats. It never mattered. Consciousness cut out at zero like someone flicking a cosmic switch.

00:00:03.

I took one slow breath and waited for the familiar swallowing of the world.

00:00:02.

My heart thumped, steady.

00:00:01.

My phone vibrated softly on my chest as it hit zero and triggered the “See you tomorrow” reminder app I’d forgotten to delete.

00:00:00.

Nothing happened.

I blinked.

The digital confetti animation cheerfully cascaded down my screen. A popup: “Goodnight, Earth!”

I stared at it, waiting for the icepick sensation at the back of my skull, the effortless plunge into nowhere.

Still nothing.

I sat up. The room was too normal. The streetlight outside painted the same yellow stripe on my wall. My clock ticked. The radiator hissed once. I could hear my upstairs neighbor’s TV murmuring.

Maybe the timing was off. It had never been off.

Ten seconds. Thirty. A minute.

I swung my legs out of bed. Stood. I felt…awake. Not just awake. Hyper-aware. Every sound peeled away from the background noise, distinct: the low hum of my fridge, the barely audible buzz of the ceiling light.

I stepped to the window and looked down at the street.

There should’ve been bodies. Sometimes people miscalculated and dropped where they were, slumped on park benches or folded against their steering wheels. There should’ve been a few stragglers caught mid-errand, curled up on doorsteps. But the street was empty. Cars parked neatly, shop gates rolled down. Everyone home, prepared.

It looked like midnight in a small, well-behaved town.

I grabbed my hoodie, slipped on my shoes, and left my apartment door hanging open.

The hallway smelled faintly of old paint and laundry detergent. The fluorescent light flickered. I knocked on Mrs. Cho’s door across the hall. No answer. I knocked harder.

“Mrs. Cho? The Moment passed.”

Silence.

I tried her handle. Unlocked. I hesitated—then pushed it open.

She was in her armchair by the window, cardigan buttoned to her throat, hands folded around a mug that had tipped and spilled onto the rug. Eyes closed. Breathing slow, even. Completely gone.

“Hey,” I said softly. Not wanting to startle her if this was some terrible mistake. I touched her shoulder.

No response.

Okay.

I moved down the stairwell. Third floor: Hernandez family. Their door was ajar. Hall light on. Inside, both parents and their toddler lay on the couch like discarded puppets, heads lolling, the TV frozen mid-ad on a streaming service. Little Maya’s fist still clenched around a stuffed rabbit's ear.

“Hey,” I tried again, louder. “Guys?”

Nothing.

My pulse beat in my temples. A thick, animal dread rose in my chest, trying to convince me I was dreaming. This was just some weird strain of anxiety reconfiguring itself into a nightmare.

I slapped my own face. Hard. Pain blossomed. I didn’t wake up, because I wasn’t asleep.

I ran outside.

The sky was clear, dotted with sharp winter stars. The whole city sounded wrong. No sirens. No distant rumble of traffic. Just a soft mechanical hum from things that didn’t need people to run.

I walked into the middle of the intersection by my building and turned in a slow circle. Streetlights blinked on and off in their programmed cycles. A traffic light changed obediently from red to green. No cars moved.

An Uber with its hazard lights on sat diagonally across a bus lane, driver slumped over the wheel. The app on his phone glowed faintly, navigation arrow stubbornly pointing him forward.

I approached and tugged at his door. Unlocked. I shook his shoulder. “Hey. Wake up. Something’s wrong.”

Nothing.

Their pulses were all the same: strong, slow, as if in some synchronized hibernation. Bodies laid out on couches, in beds, on floors where they’d sat cross-legged to “wait for it.”

For a shaky second, I found myself wondering if I was the one who was wrong. If maybe I’d died. Or lost my mind. Or slipped somehow between the gears of whatever mechanism ran this yearly blackout.

I pulled my phone out. No bars, which wasn’t unusual on the Day; networks often went into low-activity mode, automated routing and all that. But WiFi should still be working.

I joined a random open network from a nearby cafe. My notifications had frozen at “See you tomorrow.” No new messages. No social media posts. Just the digital silence of a planet mid-hold-breath.

I went behind the counter of the cafe. The barista lay on the floor, apron on, milk steaming pitcher tipped over.

Their security feed still recorded: 23:59:57, 23:59:58—

Then static. Not black. A wash of gray noise, like old TV snow.

I scrubbed forward through the timeline. For the first time I’d ever seen in footage from the Moment, the static didn’t resolve. It just continued. No images. No room. No me standing there.

I looked up slowly.

“I’m not on the cameras,” I said aloud, just to hear the words.

At home, I pulled up all the public feeds I could. Traffic cams, street corners, building lobbies. They cut out at the Moment into the same analog snow. Every one of them. The world had gone not dark, but… unwatched.

I grabbed my bike and rode.

I saw no one awake. Hundreds—then thousands—of sleeping forms, every window I checked revealing the same slack faces, peaceful in enforced oblivion. The whole city like a stage after the play is over, actors fallen exactly where they’d been told.

The farther I rode, the more the unreality thickened into something oppressive. By the time I got to the river, my breaths were sharp in my throat.

I stopped on the pedestrian bridge and answered, finally, the question that had been pacing at the edge of my mind:

Why me?

I’d never been special. Not a scientist on the Day research teams, not a religious leader, not even one of those cranks who thought the blackout was an alien harvest. I was a nobody with a mediocre job and an overdue electricity bill.

“Hello?” I shouted into the still air. It startled birds from a lamppost. “If this is a test, or a glitch, or whatever— I notice it. Okay? You got me. Very funny. Turn it back on.”

Only the river replied, lapping at its banks.

I waited for fear to mutate into panic. Instead, something stranger happened.

A thin thread of exhilaration slid under my ribs.

For the first time in the history of my species, someone was awake when no one else was. The world, for one day, belonged entirely to me.

The thought was monstrous. It also felt honest.

I checked my watch. We were fifteen minutes past the Moment. If the pattern held, there were twenty-three hours and forty-five minutes left of this… exception.

“Okay,” I whispered. “Okay.”

First: rule out danger.

I biked to the nearest hospital. People sprawled on gurneys in hallways. Nurses slumped in chairs mid-chart. ICU monitors beeped steadily; the patients on ventilators were unconscious just like everyone else, no different from any other time. Automatic systems doing their work. The hospital backup generators hummed; their pre-Day configuration had accounted for this. No alarms screamed. No apocalyptic failures.

Things were working. Without us.

I walked among rows of sleeping bodies, my shoes squeaking on linoleum. I felt like an intruder in a sacred place.

At the nurse’s station, computers displayed frozen login screens. I found one with an open research article about the neurophysiology of the Day. Brainwave studies, decades of them. Every result the same: at zero, a global, instantaneous shift into a perfectly uniform state beyond all known sleep stages.

There had been no variation.

Until now.

I saw an icon for a live EEG feed. On impulse, I stuck electrodes to my own scalp, hands shaking a little, and started the recording. Jagged waves traced across the screen. Awake. Normal.

I printed the graph, just in case, though I didn’t know who I’d show it to.

Outside, the silence followed me like a thought I couldn’t shake.

If no one remembers the Day, what happens during it?

No one knew. Theories filled textbooks and sermons.

-A cosmic failsafe to prevent technological runaway.
-A scheduled maintenance window for reality.
-A side-effect of the universe adjusting its constants.
-Interference by some higher-order intelligence.

All unprovable. All equally absurd.

What if, I thought, pedaling aimlessly down the center of a major avenue, it’s not about them at all?

What if it’s about whoever doesn’t sleep?

The idea lodged in my mind with horrible neatness.

Previously, that number had always been zero.

This time, it was one.

I stopped again, abruptly, in front of a department store. Mannequins in the window wore spring fashion under cold fluorescent light. The automatic doors parted obediently for me.

If some… operator… inspector… caretaker… had been doing whatever they do in those blank twenty-four hours since the first fish hauled itself onto land, they’d never had to account for an observer inside the system.

Until now.

“Is that it?” I asked the empty cosmetics section. “Did you miss a spot?”

I listened, absurdly, for an answer. A voice from the ceiling. A message on a screen. A glitch.

Nothing.

I walked through the aisles, touching things just to prove I could, to feel the resistant textures of plastic wrap and glass. I pocketed a chocolate bar without paying and laughed once, a sharp sound in my own ears, half hysterical.

“If this is an experiment,” I said to no one, “you picked the wrong subject.”

But that wasn’t true, was it?

You never pick the obvious ones if you’re trying to see what happens.

I stepped back out onto the street.

The stars overhead were the same as before, but they felt closer. Too bright. Like eyes.

“Fine,” I said. “You want to know what I do with it?”

I had twenty-three hours left in a world paused mid-breath.

I was going to find out what happened during the Day.

If something watched us, maybe it would notice I was missing from whatever process usually ran. Maybe it already had. Maybe I had already drawn its attention the moment I failed to fall.

I felt suddenly, acutely seen.

You always will, my mother had said. We always do.

I looked at the endless rows of sleeping windows, the motionless lights, the empty streets.

“Not this year,” I whispered.

And I started walking toward the places no one was ever allowed to see.

samples.prompt: There is an ancient Hittite saying "What problem that isn't dealt with will come back.". The sea people as the ancient Bronze Age people have called them are back and are advancing to the Eastern Mediterranean, where they collapsed civilizations 3000 years ago.
samples.output:
There is an ancient Hittite saying: “What problem that isn’t dealt with will come back.” For three millennia, the saying lay quiet in footnotes, carved in stone no one living could read. Then the signals started.

At first they were misfiled as glitches.

A dark bloom appeared on satellite imagery, far out in the eastern Mediterranean: a ragged smear of interference, a region where sensor arrays read nothing at all. Not cloud, not storm, not dust. A blocked-out square of sea as if the world’s rendering engine had failed. A weather technician in Ankara flagged it. A naval analyst in Haifa marked it as “instrument anomaly.” A bored grad student in Rome put it on a conspiracy subreddit and forgot about it.

Then fishermen from Cyprus, Lebanon, and southern Turkey, men who knew every line of color on the water, began radioing in reports that went into the “maritime folklore” folder.

There were lights on the horizon where no ship should be.

Not white and red and green, not the clean geometry of container vessels and cruise ships, but fires. Torches. A low, shimmering band of orange that rose and fell, vanished and reappeared. One captain swore he saw oars catching that torchlight, a rippling forest of them. His recording showed only blackness and static.

The problem, in other words, had returned. And once again, no one dealt with it.

When the first coastal town was attacked, most of the world missed it. It was a fishing harbor on the southern Turkish coast, population eight hundred, the kind of place that made no headlines when it existed and no headlines when it stopped.

The story trickled out as a gas explosion, a boat fire, a mishandled diesel tank. Satellite images showed charred foundations, a web of scorched streets. No survivors appeared in nearby cities. No obituaries. Just a name disappearing.

In a basement office in Hattusa—resurrected as an archaeological park and research hub—a young epigrapher named Leyla read the wire story, frowned, and went back to the clay tablet under the magnifying lamp.

The inscription was late Hittite, from the final years before the Empire’s collapse: a report to the king. She had been deadened by reports: grain tallies, troop rosters, tax lists. But this one was different. It mentioned ships with beaked prows, men with feathered crowns, a union of peoples from many coasts. It mentioned burning ports. It mentioned the phrase that had become the department in-joke: “The problem that is not faced will return.”

They had all chuckled about it: how, yes, unpaid debt and unsolved wars and rising temperatures all “come back.” The Hittites had discovered truism. High-fived across three thousand years.

But here, in the faint wedge-shaped scratches, after the line about burning ports, the scribe had added something more specific.

“It is written,” Leyla murmured, her fingertip hovering over the signs, “that those driven into the sea will be birthed from the sea.”

She checked the sign-values again. No mistake.

She opened a search on her laptop. Fishing harbor. Explosion. No survivors. Satellite blackout. The hairs along her arms rose, a very old, animal sense of pattern.

Her email to her supervisor was tentative, careful. It included scans of the tablet, translations, links to the satellite anomaly. Her supervisor thanked her and forwarded it to a historian in Munich with a note full of hedges. The historian skimmed it between flights. Interesting. He’d get to it.

He didn’t.

The second attack was impossible to ignore.

At 02:17, local time, a coastal monitoring station near Latakia recorded hundreds of returns on radar, all low to the water, all without transponders. Drones scrambled; their feeds cut out the moment they dipped under a certain altitude. A medical ship anchored offshore sent a brief, confused distress call: “Multiple contacts—unidentified—no lights—oars?” Then static.

Satellite infrared showed the shoreline erupting into orange. Amateur footage spread within hours: a forest of narrow, high-prowed silhouettes emerging from a blank strip of sea, torches burning along their rails. Men standing shoulder to shoulder, their heads crested as if with stone or feathers. They made no engine sounds. They spoke no language to the cameras. They moved forward like tide.

People said it was AI-generated. People said it was a marketing stunt. People said a lot of things, all of which fluttered apart when the same shapes appeared a week later off Haifa, then Port Said, then Limassol.

Only one camera, a handheld forgotten on record, caught the attackers up close.

They were not quite human.

The footage was muddy but the forms were wrong in small, undeniable ways. Limbs too long for their torsos. Eyes reflecting torchlight like an animal’s, white and flat. Cloth and leather armor that glimmered wet though no rain fell, though fire cooked their skin. Some wore bronze that hadn’t seen air in three thousand years, green with a patina that should have flaked away. All of them charged with a sound like breaking surf, and where their bare feet struck stone, the stone darkened as if soaked.

The clip went viral. Every channel that aired it reported unexplained technical issues. The official line was mass psychosis, deepfake, propaganda. The official line frayed.

In Hattusa, Leyla’s supervisor finally called.

“I sent your note to Munich,” he said. “They’ve convened a small…working group. They want you on a call.”

On the screen appeared faces from London, Berlin, Tel Aviv, Athens. Historians, linguists, one retired admiral, one grim seismic researcher whose inclusion made no sense to Leyla. The Munich historian shared a slide: the line from the late tablet.

Those driven into the sea will be birthed from the sea.

“We dismissed it as metaphor,” he said. “A warning that enemies, if merely displaced, will return. But:”

He pulled up side-by-side images. Reliefs from Medinet Habu, Ramses III’s battle scenes: long ships, feather-helmed warriors. And next to them, stills from the harbor attacks. The resemblance was obscene.

“History theorizes,” he went on, “that the Sea Peoples were a confederation of displaced groups. Economic collapse, climate stress, migration, piracy. No unifying ethnos, no singular origin.

“We also theorize,” he said, “that our ancestors feared more than ships.”

The seismic researcher took over. In soft, accented English, she explained: for months, something had been moving under the eastern Mediterranean. Not a tectonic plate shift, not a known submarine. A low, looping signal. A presence.

“There is a cold upwelling,” she said. “Not water temperature. Something else. Instruments call it an error. It is spreading toward the Levantine coast.”

“You’re saying,” the retired admiral interrupted, “that three-thousand-year-old raiders have crawled out of the water. That’s your scientific assessment.”

The seismic researcher looked at Leyla’s tablet scan. “I am saying something was put into the sea and not dealt with.”

Silence held.

“We are not equipped,” the admiral said finally. “Not mentally, not doctrinally. Every time we’ve seen them on satellite, no signal gets back out. We can’t lock missiles on what our sensors can’t see.”

“Stories saw them,” Leyla said quietly.

Several heads turned.

“In the collapse texts,” she said, “they’re not just raiders. They’re carriers. They drag with them famine, fire, the unmaking of order. The scribes write as if the sea itself has people now. Or…something that wears people.”

“You’re suggesting demonic agency?” a British classicist scoffed.

“I’m suggesting,” Leyla said, “that if every civilization on these coasts carved the same shapes into their walls as warning, and we are seeing those shapes now, maybe we should stop correcting them.”

The admiral broke in. “Folklore later. Tactics now. What do they want?”

The question hung useless. The Sea Peoples of the late Bronze Age had wanted land, plunder, survival. These ones—if they were the same, if they were descendants, revenants, possessed—gave no demands. They did not broadcast, negotiate, boast. They arrived, burned, took bodies and metal, and returned to the black smear on the map.

Within weeks, coastal populations fled inland. European officials floated evacuation plans for Cyprus. Shipping lanes shuddered closed. The global economy flexed and popped.

In one emergency session, a politician declared: “We face a problem of security, nothing more. These are terrorists with mythological branding.” They ordered drone swarms, saturation bombing of the silent patch of sea.

The drones vanished. The bombs fell. Satellite feeds broke into white, then gray. When the data recovered, the sea was calm, unmarked. The black smear had widened.

Leyla spent nights reading the old tablets, fingers tracing the baked clay as if she could feel the fingernails of the ancient scribe.

“You knew,” she whispered. “You knew they weren’t gone.”

One fragment, previously dismissed as scribal error, now struck her like a shout: “We smothered them in salt and bronze and stone. We pushed them back into the mother of storms. But nothing that is only pushed away is ended. We have left a knife in the dark waters for our sons.”

Not dealt with. Pushed away. Left to fester, to change.

A coordinated plan emerged almost despite the disbelief.

- Abandon vulnerable shorelines.
- Fortify key port cities with medieval simplicity: walls, fire, watchtowers not reliant on electronics.
- Deploy navies not to attack the anomaly but to encircle it, observe it with human eyes, signal with light and flag.
- Dig, translate, listen.

Modern missiles had failed. Perhaps the Bronze Age had left behind more useful weapons: ways of binding, denying landings, cutting supply and story. The past, scrambled and occult, might be an arsenal.

An uneasy coalition formed: admirals and priests, climate scientists and cuneiform scholars. They met in rooms lit with redundant analog bulbs, maps papered, cellphones in lockers. They reread the myths of Baal’s battles, Poseidon’s rages, Yahweh parting seas, Hittite storm-gods dragging monsters from waves. Not as comforting fiction. As case studies.

“What if,” Leyla said to them, “what we called ‘Sea Peoples’ were never the prime mover? What if they were the first infected? And every collapse that followed that didn’t root out the infection left an echo in the deep?”

“And what if we don’t root it out now?” the admiral asked.

She thought of the Hittite saying, Basic as gravity: What problem that isn’t dealt with will come back.

“Then,” she said, “three thousand years from now, whatever’s left of us will be clay under someone else’s fingers. And they’ll read our last words and wonder why we thought we had so much time.”

Outside, beyond the reach of cameras, the dark fleet waited on the horizon of a nervous world. The waves moved with their ancient, indifferent rhythm. In the deep, something that had once been men, or used men, turned its attention to the shore that owed it an ending.

This time, perhaps, someone would face it. Or the saying would carve itself again, in a new dead language, for another age that thought its dangers were new.

samples.prompt: "Stop."Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. "That isn't a human."The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply. Sam was right; this clearly wasn't a human. I couldn't tell you how I knew it- I just knew.
samples.output:
“Stop.”

Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong.

“That isn’t a human.”

The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply.

Sam was right; this clearly wasn’t a human. I couldn’t tell you how I knew it—I just knew.

The thing standing under the flickering parking lot light wore our father’s jacket. Same frayed cuffs, same missing button near the collar. But the shoulders sat wrong, lifted and stiff like a hanger still ran through them. Dad never stood that straight. And he never, ever stopped mid-step when we shouted at him. He’d turn too fast and bump something. He was clumsy. This thing was not.

It pivoted toward us with a single, deliberate motion, like it had been placed on a rotating platform. The light hummed and buzzed overhead, casting its face half in shadow. The part I could see was perfect: the mole by the left temple, the faint silver scar along the jawline from that time with the chainsaw and the stubborn maple limb. Perfect, and completely wrong.

Its eyes took a second to find us, like they had to remember where pupils should point. They landed on Sam first. The skin at the corners of its mouth creased into an approximation of a smile.

“Sam,” it said. Our father’s voice. Only the timing was a fraction off, syllables landing with metronome precision. “You’re late.”

I felt Sam’s hand close around my forearm. He squeezed once; I heard the tremor in his breath, but his voice came out steady.

“Don’t come closer,” he said.

The thing blinked slowly. Each closing of the eyelids was just a hair too long, as if it had to run a diagnostic before opening them again. When it opened them, its gaze slid to me. Recognition lit up, too bright, too sudden.

“Eli,” it said. “You look tired.”

I swallowed. Of all the things it could have said, it chose something small, something father-soft, and that made my stomach twist. It was learning.

The night air smelled like wet asphalt and exhaust. Somewhere, a semi roared by on the highway. A stray shopping cart rolled a few inches in the breeze, squeaking.

Our real father was home, asleep, a county away. I had texted him a few hours ago to say we’d be back late. He’d sent a thumbs up emoji. He hated emojis. That had been the first wrong thing.

The second was when Mom had called, except Mom was three years dead, and the voicemail that came through was an old one, cheery and alive, timestamp all wrong, sound warped like it was being played underwater.

We had traced the number to this parking lot like idiots. Like protagonists in stories who don’t know they’re in a horror film. But we did know. That was the worst part. We came anyway.

“Why are we late?” the thing asked conversationally, as if picking up thread it had dropped. “The car broke down? Highway jam? You could have called.” It shifted the jacket cuff, revealing our father’s wristwatch, the one buried with Mom, the one we hadn’t seen since the funeral.

Sam’s fingers dug into my arm. I heard him breathe the single word: “Shit.”

“Don’t talk,” he hissed, so quietly only I could hear. “It’s rifting.”

Rifting. The word had weight. We’d grown up with stories, told in half-whispers over cheap coffee in the kitchen when they thought we were asleep. There are seams in the world, our father had said once, his eyes unfocused. Things that slip through. Things that borrow. Things that listen too well and learn too fast. Mom had humored him, called it his poet’s paranoia. But Mom had been the one who insisted on iron nails in the window frames and salt lines at the door.

“Sir,” Sam said, louder now, addressing it like a cop. “You’re in the wrong place.”

“We asked you to come,” the thing said, confusion passing across its face in a glitch. Its eyebrows wrinkled, then smoothed too quickly. “You picked up. You were good boys.”

Its hand twitched at its side. Not in impatience; in rehearsal. Fingers stretching, curling, stretching again, like they were remembering what hands did.

I realized then how I knew.

Humans are noisy. Even in stillness, we are full of small movements—shifts of weight, breaths, ticks, flinches, the blink-blink-blink. This thing wore stillness like a costume that didn’t quite fit. Each move was isolated: lift arm, turn head, speak. No bleed, no overlapping gestures. Everything it did named itself.

Dad’s voice came again. “I missed you,” it said.

My gut twisted. “Sam,” I whispered. “It has his voice.”

“It has his everything,” Sam said. “It shouldn’t.”

“You came,” the thing went on. “She said you would. That you still listen when she calls.”

There it was. The third wrong thing.

“Don’t say her,” Sam snapped.

He let go of my arm. His shoulders squared. I recognized this posture; it was the same one he’d had when he stepped between me and the dog that went rabid on Tucker Lane. That same reckless protective tilt.

“What do you want?” he asked the thing.

The parking lot suddenly felt too open, an empty stage, surrounded by hushed black woods. The big-box store behind us was closed, all windows dark. The yellow lines on the asphalt glowed weakly.

“What do I want,” the thing repeated, like tasting it. “I want to come home.”

It smiled again, wider this time, and I noticed a smear—an inexactness at the molars, like the details got fuzzy at the edges, like someone had copied a high-resolution image and compressed it too many times.

“Home is waiting,” it said. “He is alone. You leave him. I can fix that. We can be together. Like before.”

Like before.

Mom humming in the kitchen. Dad reading on the couch. Sam throwing popcorn at my head during late-night movies. Before the hospital, before the machines, before the long, quiet drive home with one less seatbelt clicked.

“Eli,” it said. My name in that familiar cadence, that gentle drop at the end. “I can give her back. Just say yes.”

My teeth chattered once, not from cold. The seams in the world, Dad had said. Things that slip through. Things that bargain.

“Don’t answer,” Sam said sharply. “It’s baiting.”

Its head turned to him; this time, the motion stuttered in the middle, like a buffering video.

“Samuel,” it said. “You believe. You always did.”

Its eyes seemed darker now, the brown sliding toward a depth that had nothing to do with color. “You wanted one more day. One more word. I can make that true. You just have to invite me in. Bring me to him. Open the door.”

Behind my fear, anger sparked.

“You called from her number,” I said. “You faked her voice.”

Its lips quivered, then settled. “I used what I had.”

There it was. An admission.

“You’re not very good at this,” Sam said.

The thing tilted its head. “At what?”

“Pretending you care.”

Silence pooled between us.

The wind picked up, cold and sharp, sending a rattle through the cart corral. Somewhere in the dark, something metallic clanged.

“You came,” it said again, less certain.

“We came to see what was knocking,” Sam replied. “That’s all.”

A flash passed across its face—too many emotions at once, overlapping in a way no human muscles could manage. A grotesque slideshow: hurt, anger, curiosity, hunger. It settled on something like a pout.

“You should be careful,” it said. “There are worse things than me.” The words carried power, like it was quoting something older. “They don’t ask.”

“And you do?” I asked. I didn’t recognize my own voice; it sounded smaller, younger.

“I am trying,” it said simply.

For a moment, that was the most terrifying thing of all: the idea that this was its attempt at kindness.

Sam reached into his jacket pocket, slow and deliberate. When he pulled his hand out, I saw the small canvas pouch. The one Dad kept in the junk drawer. Salt and rusted iron nails. Precautions masquerading as superstition.

The thing’s eyes dropped to it instantly. Its nostrils flared, like it was smelling a fire.

“You can’t keep him alone forever,” it said softly. “You will leave, and he will be afraid. I would not let him be afraid.”

“You don’t get him,” Sam said. “You don’t get us.”

He tore the pouch open with his teeth, spit a piece of thread. The salt sparkled under the harsh yellow light.

“You step back,” he said. “Or I send you back.”

The thing didn’t move.

“Last chance,” Sam said.

“You need me,” it said. But doubt had crept in, fraying the edges of its borrowed voice.

“No,” I said, and surprised myself with the certainty. “We miss them. That’s not the same.”

Sam flung the salt. It soared in an uneven cloud, glinting, catching the light in a brief constellation before dusting over the asphalt in a broken line between us and it.

The reaction was instantaneous.

The air warped, lines of the parking lot bending, the light flickering wild. The thing jerked back as if struck. Its hand shot up, fingers spidered, clawing at its own face. The skin around its eyes bubbled, not bleeding but smearing, features sliding out of alignment. Its borrowed clothes fluttered as if on a mannequin dropped from a height.

“You shouldn’t have done that,” it hissed, voice now layered: Dad’s, Mom’s, my own, Sam’s, strangers’. “You shouldn’t—”

It hit the invisible line of salt and stopped dead, body contorting against nothing. For a moment it stretched, tall and thin, every atom protesting. Then it snapped back like a rubber band let go.

It laughed once, a glitching burst.

“There are seams in the world,” it said. “He was right.”

Then it went out.

Not vanished with a pop or a puff of smoke. It unspooled. One second, it was there, half-melted and twitching. The next, the shape lost coherence, like someone had turned down the resolution until it was only a blur, then only a shadow, then nothing at all but a faint impression of our father’s cologne in the air.

The parking lot lights steadied. The world shrugged back into its familiar shape.

I realized I’d been holding my breath. I let it out in a shudder.

Sam knelt, fingers trembling, and pushed the scattered salt into a cleaner line with the edge of his shoe, as if shoring up a wall.

“Are we safe?” I asked.

“For tonight,” he said. His voice sounded older than our father’s.

We stood there in the humming quiet.

“You think it’ll try again?” I asked.

“Yes,” Sam said. “Or something like it.”

A beat.

“He really was right,” I said. “About the seams.”

“Yeah,” Sam said. “He was.”

“What do we tell him?”

Sam’s jaw flexed. He looked down at the line of salt, then back up at the dark, empty lot.

“We tell him to keep the nails in the windows,” he said. “We tell him we’re coming home.”

“And the rest?” I asked.

Sam looked at me, eyes steady, voice soft but sure—the way he spoke when something was truly wrong.

“We don’t invite anything in,” he said. “No matter whose face it wears.”

We walked back to the car. Behind us, the salt line lay bright and thin, a seam we had drawn ourselves. A boundary. A promise.

In the rearview mirror, as we pulled away, I thought I saw our father standing under the light, raising a hand to wave.

I didn’t let Sam look back to check.

samples.prompt: You decide to try out a new cafe. You get your latte and sit outside. A few minutes later, a hooded stranger sits down across from you. Startled, you look up, only to find your own face staring back at you.
samples.output:
The first thing I notice is the chip in the rim of the mug.

It’s a small, crescent-shaped bite missing from the ceramic, right where your lower lip wants to rest. It bothers me more than it should, and I pivot the mug so the flaw faces the street instead of my mouth. The latte art is half a heart, half a fern; the foam smells faintly of burnt sugar. I watch it tremble when a bus sighs past.

The new café is trying very hard. Matte black exterior, brass fixtures, white tile, potted plants that have not yet had time to wilt. It was raining earlier; now the afternoon is cool and gray, the sun a vague intention behind clouds. I choose a table outside more out of habit than desire. I like corners, sightlines, exits.

I’m alone. That’s the point.

My phone offers me distractions: three group chats, a news alert about something awful far away, a message from my sister I don’t feel like opening yet. I put it face down and look at the street instead. People pass: a woman dragging a reluctant beagle, a cyclist with a milk crate zip-tied to his back, a couple arguing in stage whispers. The mundane hum of other lives calms me.

“Is this seat taken?”

I flinch. I didn’t hear anyone approach. I look up.

They are already sitting.

Hood up, gray sweatshirt, hands folded loosely on the table. Not intrusive, not looming, just there. For a tiny, irritated second, I think: Of all the empty tables.

And then I see their face.

My own face.

The world does a quiet, decisive tilt.

Every photograph I’ve tried to avoid having taken, every involuntary glimpse in the mirror, every video call where I catch myself in the corner—suddenly all of that is sitting three feet away, focused, alive, real. The same straight nose I once broke on a basketball hoop trying to dunk in eighth grade. The same faint scar on the chin from falling off my bike. The same eyebrows, constantly on the verge of looking skeptical. The same birthmark like a thumbprint smudge at the edge of the left jaw.

My first thought is: This is a prank. Some viral stunt—hidden cameras, deepfake silicone, a carefully curated set of my Instagram photos. But I’ve locked my accounts. I’ve been careful. I want to say, “What are you doing?” and I do, but my voice comes out smaller than I intend.

They smile. It’s my smile, too.

“Relax,” they say. My voice, unbroken by self-consciousness, the way I always imagine it might sound if I weren’t the one hearing it.

I scoot my chair back. The metal legs screech against the pavement, an ugly sound, very real. A man at the next table glances over, then away. No one seems alarmed. No one is pointing, or whispering, or raising their phone to record.

“I’m calling the police,” I say, because it’s what people say in movies when something impossible happens.

“With what?” they ask mildly, tilting their head toward my silent phone. “And what will you tell them?”

My hand hovers over the phone. I imagine dialing. Imagine: Hello, yes, there is someone here wearing my face. They ordered a confrontation with extra uncanny.

“Who are you?” I manage.

They pull down their hood.

There’s no seam. No mask edge. The hair is my hair when I don’t tame it: unruly, ambiguous, one bad decision away from a mullet. The eyes are mine, but held steady in a way I avoid in mirrors. An attentive stillness. I hate how composed they look.

“I’m you,” they say. “Don’t worry, this isn’t like, cosmic identity theft. Think… call it an intervention.”

“An intervention for what?”

They glance at my latte, at the chip I turned away, at my phone face down like a sulking child. “For you. Obviously.”

A stupid heat rises in my chest. “If this is a joke, it’s not funny.”

“If this were a joke,” they say, “I’d have picked a better location.” They scan the café façade. “They’re overroasting the beans. You can smell the bitterness from here.”

“This place has good reviews,” I say automatically. Defensive, on behalf of strangers.

“You read thirty-three reviews,” they reply. “Cross-referenced star ratings, filtered out anything under four, spent twelve minutes deciding if you could handle trying somewhere new. Congratulations. You did it.” They spread my hands in a little ta-da.

The heat turns to cold.

“How do you know that?”

“I’m you,” they say again, like it’s the simplest answer. “I know how long it took you to walk past the door yesterday and not go in. I know you tried to fix your hair in the reflection and then didn’t because you didn’t want to see your whole face. I know about the draft email. Subject line: ‘I think I’m done.’ Still unsent.”

I can’t breathe for a second. The café’s ambient playlist warbles through a cover of something I loved in high school, now slowed down and somber. It feels like a mockery.

“Okay,” I say, fighting for a rational foothold. “Let’s say you are me. From when? From the future?”

They chuckle. “No. Not from any respectable timeline, anyway. Think of me as… the version you keep not letting yourself be.”

“Like, what, my potential?” I cringe at the word as soon as it leaves my mouth.

“Your unabridged edition,” they say. “The ‘if you stopped editing yourself down to fit in other people’s margins’ version. The ‘if you didn’t ghost your own wants’ version. The one who goes into the café on the first pass.”

I almost laugh out of sheer discomfort. “If you’re that version, why are you wearing a hoodie?”

They glance down at the sweatshirt. “Fair. Symbolism overshot. Look, I didn't pick the aesthetics. I’m just here.”

“Here to do what? Lecture me over coffee?” I ask. Sarcasm, my favorite thin armor.

“Here to offer you a choice,” they say, and the words land with surprising weight.

“Choice about what?”

“About being done with… this.” They gesture not just at me, but at the table, the café, the nervous system currently trying to exit my body via my fingertips. “The half-life. The way you orbit your own plans without landing. You came to a new place today. That was step one.”

“I just wanted coffee.”

“You wanted to see if you could be different without announcing it,” they correct. “Tiny rebellion, plausible deniability.”

I hate that they’re right. I hate, more, the swift accuracy, as though my inner monologue has been fed through a better editor.

“If you’re me, then you also know you sound insufferable,” I say.

“Oh, absolutely,” they agree easily. “I am fully aware I am the exact tone of inner voice you mute with podcasts. But here we are.”

A car door slams. A siren murmurs somewhere blocks away. The air presses damp and cool around us. The foam in my cup has collapsed into a dull beige skin.

“What’s the choice?” I ask.

They lean in slightly. I realize with a small shock that their eyes are kinder than I ever allow mine to appear in my own memory. Same dark rim to the iris, but less restless.

“Carry on,” they say. “Or come with me.”

I wait for a punchline. None comes.

“Carry on how?”

“As you are. You know the script. You’ll finish this latte, decide it was fine but too bitter. You won’t come back, because something about it will feel like a failed experiment. You’ll go home, open your laptop, click the same three sites, hover over the draft email to your boss that says you’re taking a break. You’ll save it. You’ll text nobody about what you really want because you don’t want to be seen wanting it. You’ll sleep badly. Repeat.”

“And if I ‘come with you’?” I ask. My voice is light, but inside I’m leaning forward.

“We walk,” they say. “Right now. We don’t pay. We forget the social choreography for a minute. We just leave. You ask your boss for the time off and hit send before you talk yourself out of it. You call your sister back. You confess. You tell her you’re scared you’re becoming a ghost in your own life.

“And then,” they continue, eyes holding mine, “we do the thing you keep thinking about at 2 a.m.—the training program, the move, the trip, the book, the song, the whatever—the thing that keeps surviving all your so-called pragmatism.”

“That’s… vague,” I say.

“So is your fear,” they counter.

I glance at the café window. My reflection looks back: me-in-here, me-out-there, and, three feet away, me-in-possibility. My heart punches unevenly at my ribs.

“Why now?” I ask. “Why here?”

“Because you finally did one small thing differently without asking permission,” they say. “Turns out that’s all the invitation I needed.”

Silence pools between us. A bee investigates the sugar packets and loses interest. A drop of leftover rain falls from the awning, darkening the table between our hands.

“How do I know you’re real?” I ask.

“You don’t,” they say. “You’re good at requiring certainty as an excuse for staying still. I’m not offering certainty. I’m offering momentum.”

I want to argue. I want to dig my heels into the cracked pavement of the known. I want to say I have responsibilities, even though most of them feel like costumes I agreed to wear in a play I don’t remember auditioning for.

Instead, I hear myself ask, “If I say no?”

They nod. “Then I finish your latte so it doesn’t go to waste, and you never see me again. Doesn’t mean you’re doomed. It just means you keep needing bigger and stranger signs before you trust yourself. That gets… exhausting.”

“And if I say yes?”

They smile, and it looks like me the way I have sometimes glimpsed myself when I’m talking about something I love and forgot to be self-conscious.

“If you say yes,” they say, standing smoothly, “you pick up your phone, you send the email, you make the call, and you walk away from this table without putting your whole life on trial for it. You treat it like choosing a new café: small, reversible, except it isn’t. Not really.”

My hands are sweating. My legs feel hollow. I think of all the ways this could be a psychotic break, a stress dream, an elaborate metaphor I will later flatten into an anecdote: Once, I saw myself and she told me to get my act together.

“You’re sure this isn’t… death?” I ask, trying to grin.

“Oh,” they say softly, “staying is death. You already know that.”

The clouds thin; a wedge of sunlight slides across the street, catching dust and exhaust and the fine grain of the wooden tables.

I look at my phone. The screen wakes to my touch, reflecting us both. One of me looks terrified. The other looks patient.

I open the draft email.

I delete “I think” and “maybe” and “if it’s okay” and everything that makes my own life sound like an imposition.

I hit send before I can swallow it back.

My thumb trembles. The world does not end.

I pick up my phone. I stand.

The hooded stranger—my stranger, my self—grins.

“There you are,” they say.

We leave the chipped mug cooling on the table and step into the street.

samples.prompt: You're a Bounty Hunter, and a bad one. Somehow, you still manage to make ends meet.
samples.output:
I’m not the kind of bounty hunter who walks into a saloon and makes the piano stop. I walk in and the piano player nods because I owe him ten dollars. The barkeep glances up to see if I’ve got it this time. I don’t. But I smile like I might.

I’m a professional disappointment with a badge-shaped tan line.

People think bounty hunters are either legendary killers, or mysterious loners with dark pasts and cool hats. I have a hat. It used to be cool. Now it looks like it’s seen three wars and lost all of them. There’s a hole in the brim where a man stabbed it, trying to stab my head. That was one of my better days. He missed.

I got into this business because the posters made it look simple. Render subject. Collect reward. It’s the “render subject” part that keeps getting away from me. These people run, or shoot, or lie in creative ways. I can’t run fast, I shoot crooked, and I’m a lousy liar. I survive on a different talent:

I am very hard to get rid of.

Take Sid “Blue Boots” Calder. Wanted for stagecoach robbery. Poster said $200 alive, $100 dead. I preferred alive because I had this notion of being a principled man. I tracked him for three days by following reports of his boots. Not tracks—complaints. A woman in Harrow said, “He had the ugliest blue boots I ever saw.” That was enough.

I finally cornered him behind a livery stable. Well, I tried to corner him. He had a gun. I had a hangover. He aimed. I tripped on a rake, the rake handle flew up, clipped his chin, he fired, missed, stumbled back over a bucket, and knocked himself out cold on a hitching post.

I stood there, ears ringing, holding nothing, having done nothing, and looking at a wanted criminal unconscious in front of me. The stable boy peeked out and said, “Was that on purpose?”

“Yes,” I said.

I dragged Sid two miles in the wrong direction before realizing town was the other way. By the time I got him to the sheriff, I’d torn my coat, lost my canteen, and developed a limp. The sheriff looked at Sid, whistled low, and said, “He’s worth two hundred. Good work.”

“Yessir,” I said, trying to look like a man who’d done it on purpose.

“Thought Blue Boots shot you back in Carson,” he added.

“He tried,” I replied. That part, at least, was true.

I walked out with two hundred dollars and a reputation I hadn’t earned.

That’s how it usually goes. My career is a trail of accidents and misunderstandings tied together with bad decisions and small acts of mercy I can’t afford.

Another job: Milly Rae Cortez. Wanted for fraud, forgery, and persuading three different mayors to marry her in three different territories—all three marriages overlapping. Poster said: $400, alive only. Picture showed a woman with eyes that suggested she’d beat you at cards and make you like it.

I found her in a church, of all places, arranging flowers like she’d been born pious. I sat in the back pew, hat in my hands, wrestling myself.

I could draw on her. She was unarmed, far as I could see. It’d be easy. Clean. For once.

But instead of a gun, I took off my hat and said, “Ma’am, you’re Milly Rae Cortez.”

She turned, met my eyes, and there was a flash of something sharp. Then she smiled.

“And you’re late,” she said.

“Late?”

“Two others came before you. One’s missing two teeth. The other’s missing his nerve. Which are you?”

I’m the third thing, I thought. I’m the one who really needs this money.

“You walked in with your gun unbuckled,” she continued. “Sat in the back like a man hoping someone else arrives first. You’re kind, or tired, or both. You don’t belong in this line of work.”

“Ma’am, I’m afraid I do,” I said. “I owe money to everyone who can spell ‘invoice.’”

She laughed. “So what now?”

I was supposed to stand, draw, and tell her to come along quiet. What I did was sit there and say, “Why three mayors?”

“Because one wouldn’t have been enough,” she said, unashamed. “Because the world pays men in advance and women on delivery. Because I could.”

I didn’t cuff her. Instead, we walked out together, like we’d just had a nice confession. The sheriff in that town was fresh and by-the-book. I told him I’d arrested Milly at the train station. Milly sweet-talked him, signed three statements, and turned over some stolen bonds. The territory dropped half the charges. Her bounty shrank to $150.

I walked out with my cut: forty sad dollars, after fees. Milly walked out with her freedom on a technicality. On the way out of town, she slipped a folded note into my pocket.

“You’re bad at this,” she murmured. “Don’t die at it.”

The note had an address and a reminder: You ever need a favor, ask for Milly.

Sometimes the people I bring in send me work. Honest work, even. A shopkeeper I saved from a stray bullet pays me to guard his shipments twice a month. “Cheaper than hiring a real firm,” he says. I take no offense. He’s right, and his wife gives me stew.

There’s a drunk ex-lawman named Porter I once tackled while aiming at the wrong man. My clumsy tackle knocked his gun aside; the bullet he meant for a gambler hit a post instead of a lung. Now Porter slips me information. When he’s sober enough, he circles faces on wanted sheets for me.

“That one’s mean,” he’ll say. “That one’s stupid. That one will surrender if you tell him his mama’s disappointed.”

He’s never wrong about the mamas.

I make ends meet on partial bounties, flukes, and side arrangements.

Sometimes I get there late and the mark is already dead. Sometimes a better hunter beats me to it. Once I arrived to find my quarry running full sprint at me, screaming, chased by an even worse hunter who’d lit half a barn on fire. My target crashed into me, knocked himself silly, and I claimed I’d intercepted him. The bondsman didn’t ask too many questions. Nobody wanted to mention the barn.

I’m not proud of all of it. There was Jory Kane—a mean-eyed boy wanted for knifing a miner. When I cornered him in a culvert, he was shaking, younger than his poster, bleeding from a wound he’d gotten while running.

“I didn’t mean to kill him,” he sobbed. “He grabbed me. I just swung.”

I believed him. I also needed rent.

I brought him in anyway.

He looked at me like I was his last hope as they locked him up. In that look I saw exactly what I am: a man who won’t quite lie to himself, but who sins by compromise.

I used most of his bounty to pay a lawyer to argue imperfect self-defense. Jory got ten years instead of the rope. The bondsman called me soft to my face. The lawyer never learned my name. I spent the next month eating bad beans.

The thing is, this job whittles you. The good hunters turn to stone or legend. The bad ones turn to bones under shallow dirt. Me? I’m that stubborn splinter that never quite comes out.

I manage my miracles in pieces:

- I remember names, so some folks feed me.
- I don’t shoot first, so sometimes people surrender.
- I talk too much, which sometimes keeps me alive.
- I inspire just enough pity that barkeeps extend credit.

And, occasionally, the universe tips my way: a horse throws a man into my lap, a storm chases a fugitive into the only barn I’m sleeping in, a loaded dice set falls out of a cheater’s pocket right when I need proof.

People call that luck. It isn’t. It’s what you get when you’re too stubborn to quit and just receptive enough to use every tiny mercy like a lever.

I know I’m not carved for legend. My coat’s too thin, my eyes too tired. My gun is slightly bent from when a horse stepped on it. Real hunters oil their weapons like lovers; I talk to mine like an ex.

But I keep a wall in my head with all the posters I’ve touched, all the faces I’ve dragged, convinced, or accidentally concussed into custody. Some deserved worse than they got. Some deserved better. A couple I helped slip the noose by filing the wrong paperwork very correctly.

At night, lying in cheap rooms that smell of dust and faded prayers, I count how many more jobs I need before I can walk into a town as nobody special. No hat. No pistol. No debts.

It’s always just a few more than I have.

Until then, I am what I am: a bad bounty hunter who, by misfires, favors, and sheer refusal to go away, still manages to make ends meet.

And in a country this unforgiving, sometimes barely is the most honest kind of success.

samples.prompt: You're watching a horror movie with only one other man in the theater. To your annoyance he begins to yell things at the characters on screen. Surprisingly, they listen.
samples.output:
He starts early.

“Don’t go in there,” he says, almost conversationally, as the blonde on the screen edges toward the basement door.

I grit my teeth. There are only two of us in the theater—late show on a Tuesday, barely advertised indie horror, squeaky seats, the faint smell of ancient popcorn oil—and I have to be stuck with the guy who thinks he’s part of the movie.

The woman on screen pauses, hand on the knob.

“Seriously,” he says, louder. “Just call the cops.”

To my surprise, she lets go of the knob and backs away.

On screen, the music stumbles, then stops. Not fades. Stops. The low drone just cuts out like a cable pulled from a speaker.

The blonde fumbles for her phone. No dramatic sigh about no service. She dials 911.

I blink.

“Cute,” I mutter. Some meta gimmick. Fine. This is what I get for liking weird horror.

The dispatcher’s voice is flat, real. Too real. The blonde stammers about noises, about the neighbor’s house, about how something is wrong.

Beside me, the man chuckles. He sounds pleased.

The cops arrive on screen. They sweep the house that should have been the scene of the first big kill: the basement, the creaking stairs, the washing machine that was supposed to kick on suddenly. They find nothing. No bodies. No monster. No masked guy.

The blonde is confused. I’m confused. The man next to me sighs theatrically.

“Okay, fine,” he says, pitching his voice toward the ceiling speakers. “Check the crawlspace.”

On screen, an officer frowns, as if he’s just remembered something.

“Crawlspace,” he tells his partner.

They find a trapdoor behind the water heater, new-looking boards nailed over old. One crowbar pry later, the first corpse is visible, pale and limp in the flashlight beam.

The theater sound system shrieks with a violin sting so sudden I flinch. The blonde screams. The officers call for backup.

I turn to look at the man.

He’s maybe mid-thirties, jeans and a denim jacket, hair too long to be tidy, too short to be deliberately messy. He has a soda he hasn’t touched. No popcorn. His eyes are on the screen, bright, attentive.

“Are you… how are you doing that?” I whisper.

He ignores me. On the screen, the shot widens to show something moving deeper in the crawlspace. A shape, wrong angles, long fingers.

“Don’t zoom,” he says. “Stay wide. WIDE SHOT. Back up.”

The camera, obediently, pulls back instead of creeping closer. The shape is still there, but smaller, less distinct. The officers don’t crawl in. They just see enough and start shouting orders, calling for more units.

The shape presses against the mesh vent from inside, pale flesh bulging between rusted slits, then slips back into shadow.

The man laughs. “That’s better,” he says. “You’re welcome, guys.”

It’s no longer clever. It’s wrong. There’s no latency, no editing trick. His words and their actions are too tightly linked. This is live, or it’s something beyond that.

“Say something else,” I murmur, uneasy.

On screen, the blonde starts to cry to an officer about her missing brother, who was supposed to be home hours ago.

The man shifts, annoyed. “Stop talking to the cop. Go home. Lock your doors. Call your brother’s friends, not the cop who’s obviously going to die.”

The blonde stares at the officer, swallows, then mutters, “I—I’m sorry. I need to get home,” and bolts. The cop tries to follow; she shakes her head, backing away. “I need to make sure my doors are locked.”

The music, which had picked back up, falters like it’s stumbling over its own cue.

My arms break out in goosebumps.

“Hey,” I say, louder. “Seriously. What are you doing?”

He finally glances at me. His eyes are gray. Tired. “Someone has to help them,” he says.

“They’re fictional,” I say.

He looks genuinely offended. “So are you, if we go up a level.”

I laugh, because I don’t know how to respond to that. It comes out thin.

On the screen, our Final Girl—if that’s who she is—drives home instead of wandering into the woods like the trailer had promised. The scene we saw in the trailer where the hooded figure appears in her headlights never happens. Her drive is quiet, the roads empty. She keeps checking her mirrors, but nothing is there.

“Good,” the man says. “Stay paranoid. Don’t stop at the creepy gas station—”

She passes the gas station without slowing.

“—and don’t pick up hitchhikers.”

Up ahead, a figure by the road lifts a thumb. She speeds up.

I stare at him. “Is this a prank movie? Are you an actor?”

He ignores me again. “Alright, director, let’s see what you do with agency,” he mutters toward the projection booth.

At home, she walks through a dim entryway, keys jangling. She reaches for the light switch.

“Lights on,” he says.

She flips them. Every bulb comes up blazing. No mood lighting. No shadowy corners. Just an ordinary, slightly messy house.

“Kitchen knife,” he says. “Big one. Keep it on you. Call your brother’s best friend, the one who lies badly. Put him on speaker.”

She does. She actually does. She pulls a long chef’s knife from the block, sets her phone to speaker, calls a kid named Ryan who immediately sounds guilty.

I feel like I’m going to crawl out of my own skin.

I stand and walk down the aisle until I can see the empty rows, the red exit sign’s dim glow, the projector beam hanging like dust-filled sunlight. Nobody else. No camera crew waiting to shout “Gotcha!” at me.

I go up the short ramp toward the exit door, push it open a crack. The hallway outside is dark, almost black. The lobby neon doesn’t reach here. It’s a thick, strange darkness, like there’s no building beyond the door at all.

A low, wet sound bubbles from that darkness.

I shut the door fast and go back to my seat.

“Smart,” the man says without looking at me. “Stay in your theater.”

Something cold crawls from my spine to the back of my tongue.

On screen, Ryan admits through sobs that they’d been at the neighbor’s house, that there was a dare, that something came out of the basement. The man next to me leans forward.

“Put him on video,” he says. “Show us the room you’re in, Ryan.”

Ryan, sniffling, flips to video and aims his phone at his surroundings: an unfamiliar living room with flowered wallpaper, a big clock, and behind the couch—

“Left,” the man says.

The camera swings left. There’s a dark smear on the wall. And lower, parallel gouges in the baseboard, each about as long as a hand.

The soundtrack hums with a low note like a plucked nerve.

“Get out of there,” the man snaps. “Ryan, front door, now. Take the bat by the umbrella stand. Don’t argue.”

Ryan startles, as if hearing him, and the image jostles. He runs. He grabs a bat I hadn’t even noticed. The camera lunges toward the door.

The door opens onto not a porch, not a street, but a black, depthless void that looks exactly like the hallway beyond the theater exit.

“No,” the man says sharply. “Close it. Back door. Back door. Real world only.”

Ryan slams the front door. He’s sobbing now, shaking, pants too loud on the phone mic. He runs to the kitchen. This door, when he opens it, shows a normal night street, yellow sodium lights, wet asphalt.

“There you go,” the man murmurs. “Out. Good boy.”

Ryan stumbles out, bat in hand, the phone view wobbling. Behind him, the smear on the wall bulges outward, like something pressing its face against paint.

I sink down slowly.

“What is that?” I ask.

The man shrugs one shoulder. “Hungry. Bored. It likes stories with rules. You make good rules, you keep people alive. You make bad rules, it eats everyone. Don’t worry, you’re not in that one.”

He says it like it’s supposed to comfort me.

On screen, the cops from earlier report in. One of their body cams glitches, freezing on a frame of the crawlspace creature’s hand reaching toward the lens. The footage jumps. The creature is gone. So is the officer whose camera we’re seeing through.

“Flashlights on the floor,” the man instructs. “Guns up, backs to each other. No splitting up. Call it in as a Code Whatever, I don’t care. You need more people.”

They obey. Instead of peeling off alone like horror cops always do, they clump together, voices tight, breathing loud. The camera doesn’t wander. It stays at human height. Every time they look like they might do something stupid, the man steers them with a word.

It should be funny. It’s not. It feels like we’re on a narrow bridge over a bottomless pit, and he’s the only one who knows where the planks are missing.

“Why can you talk to them?” I ask.

“I watched this once already,” he says. “Didn’t go well. Got… interactive on the replay.”

“That’s not how movies work.”

He smiles faintly. “Doesn’t mean it’s not how this one works.”

On the screen, the creature finally commits to an entrance: it slithers halfway out of a vent, all limbs and joints in the wrong order, skin like wet plaster, teeth like rebar. The cops scream. One aims; the gun doesn’t fire.

“Tap the side,” the man says. “Rack it. Aim for the joints. Knees, elbows.”

The officer slaps the gun, racks it, shoots. The creature’s elbow shatters, spraying gray-brown chunks. It howls with a sound that rattles the theater’s seats.

“Again,” the man says, calm. “Don’t run. Cripple it.”

They do. It thrashes, dragging itself forward, leaving a trail like wet clay.

“Fire,” the man says. “Lighter. Gasoline. Kitchen. Contain perimeter. No hero shots.”

They listen.

The creature burns. It burns too long, too loud, like something that exists in more places than the basement. The screen whites out with the glare.

For a moment, the theater goes completely silent. No music. No credits. The projector hums steadily, but there’s nothing on the screen.

The man takes a slow breath. “Okay,” he says softly. “You’re alright.”

The image snaps back: daylight, paramedics, cops, the blonde in a blanket on her porch, her brother alive, Ryan alive, everyone attached to oxygen and trauma but intact. No one smiles. They don’t need to. They’re breathing.

The end credits roll in simple white text over black.

I’m shaking.

“So,” I say. “You… edited the plot.”

“I enforced common sense,” he says. “The plot didn’t like it.”

“The plot?”

He nods toward the screen. Names scroll in silence. No score. “It wants things. Tension, sacrifice, escalation. It bends things. People, doors, distances. You felt it at the exit, right?”

I think of that thick darkness beyond the door, and the sound inside it.

“Why doesn’t it bend you?”

“It tries,” he says. “But I’m… noisy. Harder to write over.”

He stands up for the first time. Up close, there’s something off about his outline, like the grain of the projector light stutters around him.

He drains his soda. It was empty the whole time.

“You helped them,” I say. The credits are nearly done. My voice sounds very small. “You can do that for other movies? Other people?”

He smiles without humor. “Not my movie.”

The last name on the credits fades. The screen stays black.

I wait for the house lights to come up.

They don’t.

Instead, white letters fade in, crisp and new, over the black screen:

FEATURING

THE AUDIENCE

I exhale a shaky laugh. “Very meta,” I say. “Okay.”

My phone screen won’t turn on.

The man glances up at our names as they begin to appear.

I see my first initial, my last name, sliding up the screen.

“Don’t,” he says quietly, and for the first time he sounds afraid. “Don’t stand up. Don’t go for the exits. Don’t call out. Just sit. Breathe. Let the scene change without helping it.”

“But—”

“Shh.”

The theater is too dark. The red exit signs are dimming, color draining from them like blood from a face.

On the screen, in the reflected glow, I see the two of us: grainy night-vision, seated in row F, center. One man watching the camera. The other—me—turning, about to notice.

“Don’t look at it,” he says.

I stare straight ahead, heart pounding.

Somewhere high above us, something drags its long fingers across the ceiling tiles.

He raises his voice, sharp now, aimed at the speakers, at whatever is watching through them.

“Cut,” he says. “Scene’s over. Roll to black. This one walks.”

For a beat, nothing happens.

Then the screen does go fully black. The dragging stops.

The house lights come up.

The exit signs are normal red. My phone unlocks to the time: 12:03 a.m.

I whip my head toward him.

The seat beside me is empty. No soda. No jacket indentation. Just cracked pleather.

On the screen, in the last fading ghost of projected white, three new words hang a fraction too long before disappearing:

FOR NOW.

samples.prompt: Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes. But with your help, we changed that.
samples.output:
Every sixty seconds in Africa, a minute used to pass.

That was the way the joke went, at first—shared online with a smirk, a shrugging dismissal dressed up as cleverness. People liked it because it threw up its hands at the vastness of the continent and the scale of its problems. It pretended to be about time, when really it was about distance. Their distance from us. Our distance from them.

But then something small and strange happened.

Every sixty seconds in Africa, a minute passed—and we watched.

We watched the girl in northern Ghana who walked forty minutes one way to reach a borehole that spat out rust-colored water. We watched the boy in rural Malawi whose school had three walls and one textbook for thirty-seven students. We watched the nurse in a clinic in northern Kenya who sterilized instruments over a charcoal stove and whispered apologies when she had to turn mothers away because the vaccines were gone and so was the power.

We saw these things not because they were new, but because, this time, we did not look away.

The joke collapsed under the weight of watching.

You were there, remember? When the first message went out. It did not sound grand; it did not say: “We will remake the story of a continent.” It said, simply:

“What if every 60 seconds, something better happened instead?”

It was a comment under a video, an offhand thought turned invitation. But you answered.

You answered with coins shaken loose from digital wallets, with code typed late into the night, with stubborn emails to indifferent bureaucrats, with lesson plans, with patent waivers, with solar panels carried on calloused shoulders. You answered by refusing to believe minutes had to mean nothing more than time sliding by.

In the first year, not much seemed different.

But that’s the thing about minutes. They behave themselves at first, lining up, pretending each one is just like the last. Only later do you see how they conspired.

There was a village in Senegal that can tell you the exact minute things began to change.

It came at 3:14 in the afternoon, on a day sewn together by heat. The solar array—funded by a hundred and three strangers who would never set foot there—shuddered to life. A single bulb flickered on inside a low cement building that had once been a storehouse. Children pressed against the doorway, eyes enlarged by the shock of electric light in daytime.

The bulb did not cure malaria. It did not plant crops. It did not fix roads. But it changed the math of the next minute.

Light meant a refrigerator could run. A refrigerator meant vaccines that did not die before they arrived. Vaccines meant fewer funerals on cloudless mornings. Fewer funerals meant girls stayed in school longer because their families were not pushed so hard against the edge of survival. Girls in school meant fewer child marriages, more delayed pregnancies, more income, more ideas.

Sixty seconds of humming electricity reordered years.

You remember the logistics pilot project in Uganda. It sounded like science fiction, and to some, it sounded like a distraction. Drones flying vaccines to hilltop clinics. Blood bags crossing valleys by air instead of being trapped in the rusted bellies of broken trucks. The skeptics said: “Cute, but symbolic.”

Symbolic is what we call a thing before we see the data.

One drone. Two clinics. Three months.

Then the quiet, unglamorous arithmetic began to arrive: maternal deaths down, emergency response times slashed, cold-chain integrity up. Minutes that used to be fatal delays became narrow but sufficient spaces where a life could be pulled back from the brink.

Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passed. But now, your help had slipped a scalpel into that sentence and carved a different outcome into its flesh.

In the markets of Lagos and Dakar and Nairobi, coders and designers and stubborn dreamers took those minutes and stretched them. They didn’t ask for permission to be brilliant; they built payments platforms that made microloans real and honest; they made telemedicine apps that took a doctor’s voice into desert villages; they taught farmers to read the sky through satellite data instead of rumor.

You did not bring them brilliance; they already had that.

What you brought, mostly, was the refusal to tell a smaller story.

You insisted their ideas were worth backing. You leveraged your privilege until it groaned under the weight of petitions and partnerships. You demanded that climate funds flow not just to conferences but to community forests and coastal mangroves and women’s cooperatives building clean cookstoves that flickered blue instead of coughing black.

Every minute, another stove lit. Another lung spared. Another tree left standing, stitching its roots deeper into the soil.

We used to talk about Africa as though it were a wound or a warning. You helped replace that language with something more accurate and less patronizing: a partner, a plurality, a place where the future was being prototyped at terrifying speed because it had to be.

Do you remember when we changed how we give?

At first, it was disaster to disaster. A flood here, a famine there. You opened your wallet when a headline was sharp enough. Then someone asked a better question:

“What if our help is not a spotlight, but an infrastructure?”

That’s when you committed not just money, but duration.

A ten-year pledge instead of a ten-day burst. You funded data scientists in Accra. You funded teacher training in Lusaka. You funded legal aid in Addis Ababa so that miners could say no, communities could say no, so that “development” stopped meaning extraction by another name.

And because you did that, small courts in small towns began to say: “The river stays. The forest stays. The children stay in school.”

It did not make a meme. But it made a minute.

Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passed; now, within that minute, a girl read a chapter instead of hauling water. A boy powered up a tablet in a lit classroom instead of squinting by kerosene. A midwife checked a vital sign on a charged device. A field received a text message telling the farmer when to plant. A community health worker opened a cold refrigerator and found, reliably, what she needed.

You did not do this alone. Of course not.

Africans led. Governments, NGOs, stubborn elders, furious youth, grandmothers with salt in their hair and iron in their voices—they led. You listened, then lent your leverage to make it harder for the world to say no. You refused to be placated by charity that spent more on its logo than on its lives.

And crucially, you stopped thinking of “Africa” as the punchline to a lazy joke about time.

Because once you truly see sixty seconds as the container of a beating heart, a decision, a chance, you cannot go back to smirking.

So here we are.

Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute no longer merely passes.

In those same sixty seconds now:

- A new business is registered by a woman who once sold oranges by the roadside and now runs a cooperative.
- A sensor in a dryland farm pings a cloud server, helping a family survive another erratic season.
- A student in Kigali submits code to an open-source project that will be used on three continents.
- A patient in a township receives a reminder to take her HIV medication, and she does, and she lives.
- A mangrove seedling takes root, quiet and defiant, holding back the sea a little longer.

These changes are not magic. They are not evenly spread. There is still hunger, misrule, violence, theft dressed up as policy. There are still places where minutes are squandered or stolen.

But because of what you chose to do—because you treated that joke as an indictment instead of entertainment—there are also places where minutes have been armed with possibility.

You measure the success not only in metrics but in absences:

The cholera outbreak that never happens because the water is clean.
The famine that does not fully form because the grain store is full.
The child marriage that is quietly cancelled because the school fees are covered.
The dangerous crossing that is never attempted because there is something worth staying for.

There will be new crises. There always are.

But we have, together, committed a small and radical act: we have stopped treating African time as disposable.

You bent your sixty seconds toward connection instead of contempt. And in ways both ordinary and profound, the continent answered with innovation, resilience, and grace that was never yours to bestow, only to finally notice.

Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute still passes.

The difference now is simple, and it is everything:

We have decided those minutes matter. And with your help, they are no longer empty.

samples.prompt: WP about any subject you want with a sudden twist that ends with the words 'they are finally free'
samples.output:
When the Lightkeeper vanished, most assumed the sea had taken him.

Children in Harrowport dared one another to scramble up the black rocks and peer at the glass eye of the lighthouse, long since dark. They told stories of the old man who had tended its flame for sixty years, until one night the beacon blinked three times and never came back. Some said the light itself had stepped down in the shape of a man and walked away with him. Others preferred simpler ghosts: a white figure on the cliffs, a lantern swinging, a call no one could answer.

It was easy to invent things about the lighthouse. No one went there anymore.

No one but Mara.

Mara had grown up beneath its beam. As a child, she’d fallen asleep to the slow sweep of light through her bedroom window, a celestial metronome pacing her dreams. She’d sat on her front steps, counting: there, then gone, then there again. In its rhythm she’d learned that some things in life were steadfast, predictable. Her father drank, her mother left, her teachers cycled in and out, but the lamp above the sea kept its patient watch.

Until the night it didn’t.

Years later, after she’d left Harrowport for a city of glass towers and halogen glare, Mara came back to settle her father’s debts and clean out the house he’d finally abandoned, this time by dying. The town was as she’d left it: paint scabbed from the clapboard houses, gulls screaming like they were owed something, the sea wearing away at everything that dared stand still.

But the lighthouse—its emptiness troubled her.

The people at the dock shrugged.

“Coast Guard put in a GPS buoy and some automated thing down the line,” said one, hauling in a rope. “Old man was a relic. Don’t need him now.”

“No one replaced him?” she’d asked.

“Why would they?” he’d said. “Isn’t any romance left in standing in the wind all night, waiting for someone to crash.”

That night, sleep came thin and light. The house felt wrong. Every creak was unfamiliar, every shadow suspect, as if the structure resented being reduced to papers and collectibles. Around midnight, her chest tight, she stepped outside.

The cliffs were a darker line against the stars. The lighthouse silhouette stood empty, a smudge of deeper black, its glass eye opaque.

She should have felt closure, she thought. A chapter ending, the past folded away. But instead she felt…attuned. As if some thread tugged at her sternum.

Before she could stop herself, she was walking.

She took the path she’d sworn off at sixteen, the narrow one along the cliff edge, stones slick with old spray. The sea was restless, scales of moonlight flashing across black waves. The lighthouse rose larger, each step revealing more of its flaking white paint, its rusted railing. The door at the base hung open, its padlock snapped, one hinge defeated.

Mara hesitated on the threshold.

The smell hit her first: salt, stale lamp oil, dust, something metallic underneath like old coins or blood. The spiral staircase wound upward into darkness.

She climbed.

Her phone’s flashlight skated over the walls, catching carved initials and dates. She added nothing. The steps groaned, but held. Her breath echoed.

Near the top, she heard it: a sound of glass shifting, a sigh of—what? Wind? She stepped into the lantern room.

The great Fresnel lens rose before her, a many-faceted crystal organism. Even without light, it seemed to gather the pale moon into its segments, bending and holding it. It dominated the room, cold and grand, dust riming its brass.

Mara approached. The room felt charged, as if a thunderstorm hung somewhere just beyond the horizon of sense.

Her phone flickered.

Went dark.

The only light was the moonglow trapped in glass.

She reached out, intending only to touch the metal frame, to anchor herself.

Her fingers brushed the lens.

The world inverted.

It was as if she’d been plunged into a depthless pool without water or temperature. Her body dropped away. She was awareness and nothing else, pressed against something enormous and multifaceted. Colors she didn’t have names for cascaded; she felt the curvature of the earth like a slow breathing under her.

“Steady,” a voice said, somewhere inside the rushing light.

She tried to jerk back. She had no muscles. Nothing obeyed.

“You’re fine,” the voice said. “You’re only touching. It’s worse if you fall in.”
