Images slid over her: ships in storm, the white cone of the lighthouse beam cutting rain, a man’s hands tending the mechanism, cranking, cleaning, his back bent, his hair going white. The beam swung, swung, swung.

“Who’s there?” Mara thought, or said. It was hard to tell.

“The one who left,” the voice answered. It layered over the afterimages of the old man, half borrowed from her memories, half utterly other. “The one they called mad. The one who learned to listen when the lens spoke back.”

She thought of the stories. The Lightkeeper talking to himself on the cliffs. The supplies he’d stopped collecting. That last night, the beacon flickering oddly.

“You’re dead,” she thought.

“I’m busy,” the voice said. “Death is a shore. I stepped past it.” A shimmer of amusement, like light on wave tops. “But you—you shouldn’t be here. Not yet. Step away from the glass.”

She tried. No sense of movement.

“What is this?” she demanded. Panic rising electric in her.

“This is what the lens does,” he said. “What all lenses do, if you let them: they focus. For years I poured oil and sweat and time into this machine, thinking I was only feeding its light. Turns out I was feeding something hungrier.”

The images shifted. She saw, impossibly, not just ships but dreams—people on shore sleeping while the beam swept over town, their faces soft and trusting. Threads of pale luminescence lifted from them, drawn seawards, caught and turned by the lens.

“Stop,” Mara said, or prayed.

“You never felt tired for no reason,” the Lightkeeper said softly. “Never woke feeling like someone had skimmed something off you in the night?”

She had. As a child, especially. Those mornings when school felt like walking through wet sand.

“It’s not evil,” he said. “It’s hungry. It was made hungry. We built it to insist the night stay back. The night doesn’t like that. It bargained. Or something older did, through it. The details are muddy, even now.”

The weight of it pressed on her: all the years, all the nights, all the stolen slivers.

He continued. “I discovered it by accident. Watched a storm from up here, reached out, and slipped—fell through. Saw the trade. The light for their dreams. The safety for their years. The storm took no ship that night, but in town three hearts gave out, clean as candles snuffed at once.”

She saw those too. A woman in her garden. A man at his dinner table. A child in his sleep.

“Why are you telling me this?” she asked.

“Because you touched the glass,” he said. “Because it likes you. Because it wants another keeper. I refused. I broke the contract as best I could. Vanished, as they say. Slipped sideways into the beam and chewed at the threads until they loosened. But it is patient. It will tempt you. It will promise you you can save them all.”

Down below, on the black water, a ship’s running lights traced a line toward the rocks.

“They’ll crash,” she whispered. “There’s no beacon.”

“There’s GPS. There’s radar,” he said. “And there’s the truth: we can save a hundred bodies at the cost of draining thousands of souls just a little faster. Or we can stop. It won’t be clean. Some will be lost. But they will be lost honestly.”

“Turn it on,” a new voice said, pressing slickly at the edges of her perception. It did not sound like wind or man. It was heavier. Sweet. “She is good. She is diligent. Give her a purpose. She longs for one.”

Mara realized that was true. The city job, the hollow promotions, the return to this dying town—all symptoms of a restless vacancy in her. The idea of being needed, of watching the sea, of catching ships before they broke—oh, how that fit into her.

“All you must do,” the slick voice murmured, “is feed the flame. A little of them each night. They never notice. Think how grateful they’d be never to know. You could be the unseen guardian of generations.”

“Don’t listen,” the Lightkeeper said. His tone, which had been dry, turned sharp. “It always offers. It always says it’s almost harmless. I tore myself thin getting out. I didn’t do it so you could take my place.”

“You didn’t finish,” the other hissed. “There are still threads. Still promises. One of them is hers. She slept so often beneath my gaze. I have a claim.”

Mara felt something pluck at her. She remembered nights as a girl, the light turning through her curtains. Counting, trusting. Had it been counting her?

“Let go,” the Lightkeeper said. “You’re strong. Stronger than I was. Step back.”

“If you step back,” the thing purred, “they drown.”

The ship below angled closer. Its white wake glowed faintly.

Mara hung between.

She saw, with a clarity that sliced: if she agreed, the mechanism would hum to life, the flame would catch, the lens would throb with stolen luminescence. The town would be safer. The sea would be kinder. People would sleep easier, not knowing why they woke hollow. She could be a sacred secret.

If she refused, the ship might break. Screams on the rocks. In town, there would be funerals, anger, questions. The old stories would rise again: the useless, empty lighthouse that hadn’t saved them.

“Please,” the thing said, and in its plea she heard not mercy but appetite.

“I can show you everything,” it promised. “Every storm, every wave. The shape of the world’s dark. You will never be small again.”

Mara thought of her father, drunk on his stories of the sea but never brave enough to leave the harbor. Thought of her mother, who had walked away one morning and never looked back. Thought of herself, orbiting other people’s needs, never her own.

“No,” she said.

It wasn’t brave. It was tired. A tired that went back to childhood mornings after long nights under the revolving light.

She pushed.

For a moment, the resistance was immense, cosmic. The lens clung to her, the unseen thing poured honeyed terror into her mind: you’ll kill them, you’ll be nothing, you’ll be alone.

She stepped back anyway.

The contact broke.

She stumbled in her own body, knees buckling against the cold metal floor of the lantern room. The only light was the moon through plain, unlit glass. The lens loomed, but now it was just glass and brass and dust.

Below, the ship’s horn bellowed. She lurched to the window in time to see it correct course, swing wide, its lights sliding safely past the teeth of rock. Technology, she thought distantly, almost laughing. GPS. Radar. Charts. Things that did not need her soul.

The room was painfully quiet. Then, faint as a last ember, the Lightkeeper’s voice.

“Well done,” he said. “The bond is broken. It’s dark for good, now.”

Something uncoiled, subtle and everywhere. A tension in the air, in the stones, in the very memory of the lighthouse, eased.

“Go back to them,” he murmured.

“Will they be all right?” Mara asked.

“Now? Yes,” he said. “They will dream their own dreams again. Age at their own pace. Fear and love and drift without the beam sipping at their edges.”

“And you?”

He sounded surprised. “I think I can go, finally. I wanted to see someone choose without my fingers on the scale.”

The presence that had been watching from the glass slunk away, seaward, thwarted. The lens was mute. The tower, once a hungry god’s altar, felt like what it should have been all along: a hollow place above the waves.

Mara descended as dawn seeped into the sky, pale pink over gray water. In town, windows blinked awake. People emerged yawning, stretching, unaware of anything but the day ahead. Children shouldered backpacks. Fishermen checked their nets. An old woman swept her stoop, humming tunelessly.

No one felt it consciously, the change. Not like she did. But shoulders sat looser. Laughter came a fraction easier. A girl on a doorstep looked up at the cliff and shivered, then smiled for no reason she could name.

Mara stepped into the street, her own limbs unexpectedly light.

She looked back once at the dark tower on the headland and thought—not of ghosts or loss, but of an absence finally healed.

She turned toward town as the sun broke cleanly over the horizon, spilling unbent light on the cobblestones, on the harbor, on the faces turned up to warmth that asked nothing in return.

And though no one else heard the quiet, passing sigh at the edge of perception, she knew what it meant as clearly as if it were spoken aloud:

They are finally free.

samples.prompt: Immortality is a naturally occurring medical condition, affecting 1 out of 1 million births. You are the oldest immortal.
samples.output:
They stopped counting my birthdays when the candles became a fire hazard.

At first it was charming—thirteen candles, sixteen, twenty-one. Then a cake that needed a second cake to hold all the wax. My mother laughed about it, my father pretended to grumble about the cost, and I played along, because what else is a child supposed to do when the world behaves like it’s normal?

We didn’t know, then. Nobody did.

The early manifestations of immortality look like good luck. Rapid healing after broken bones, suspiciously few infections, an uncanny resistance to bad flu seasons. A pediatrician recommended I be part of a study after I snapped both radius and ulna falling out of a tree and showed up two days later with fully remodeled bone and no sign of fracture. The study folded before it began; nobody had the funding, nobody took it seriously. My mother said I was “a tough little thing” and ruffled my hair.

Tough little things grow up.

By thirty, the first threads of unease had sewn themselves into my days. College friends complained about feeling old, joking about their backs, their thinning hair, the faint lines at the corners of their eyes. They turned late nights into early bedtimes. They said things like “my wild twenties” as though the decade had become a country they’d emigrated from.

I looked exactly as I had at twenty-two. People said I’d “aged well.” They asked for skincare routines. They attributed it to good genes, clean living, yoga. I lied because the truth wasn’t available yet. No one had said the word.

The word came for me at thirty-eight, in a research hospital smelling of antiseptic and air-conditioned exhaustion.

There were a few hundred documented cases by then. Enough that “Immorbus Congenita” had an ICD code and a lobby and several international conferences. The media called us “Immos” until someone did a piece about the dehumanizing language, and then they favored “IC patients” or “Naturals,” like I’d been grown in some organic, free-range afterlife.

The diagnostic team took fourteen vials of my blood, full-body imaging, genomic sequencing, telomere analysis. I lay inside a white ring humming with magnetics, staring at a strip of padding while a resident’s disembodied voice told me not to move.

When the results came, the lead physician had the expression of someone who had discovered something and didn’t know if it was gold or a grenade.

“You’re not just positive,” she said, tapping the screen. “You’re… atypical. Your biomarkers indicate no senescence, no telomere shortening, no cumulative mutation burden. And based on historical records and your own account, you are the oldest confirmed case.”

“Confirmed,” I said. The word felt like it had sharp edges.

“At present,” she added. “As far as the registry goes, you’re the oldest immortal on record.”

I asked her if I would live forever.

She said, “Biologically? You show no signs of aging or degradation. Pathologically, you’re resilient to everything we know how to test. Practically?” She hesitated. “Barring trauma to the central nervous system of a kind we cannot repair, or hypothetical changes we can’t yet foresee… yes. You appear functionally immortal.”

Functionally immortal. Like a dishwasher with an excellent warranty.

My parents died in their late eighties, proud of my “good health,” never fully believing the diagnosis, as though it were just another study I’d been enrolled in. I didn’t correct them. On the last night, my mother’s hand felt like paper in mine and she whispered, “You’ll have a long life. Use it well.”

I didn’t tell her there would be no “old age” for me, just an unspooling of days.

When immortality is a naturally occurring medical condition affecting roughly one in a million, it is rare, but not mythic. That’s the problem. There are enough of us to study, to legislate around, to argue over at dinner tables and during elections. We are not gods or stories. We are a statistical anomaly. We have support groups.

At first, being the oldest meant invitations.

They asked me to sit on panels. To speak at memorials for immortal children lost to accidents, because nothing is so cruel as surviving everything except a poorly timed streetlight. They called me “a living window into the future,” which would have been poetic if people didn’t also call me at three in the morning to ask if their immortal teenager would ever stop feeling like a monster.

“I don’t know,” I told one sobbing mother. “None of us ever stops feeling different. But monster? No.”

I felt like a liar, sometimes. Not because of the comfort I offered, but because of the secrets I kept.

Here is one: I am older than the registry believes.

Birth certificates are malleable things. Countries shift; records burn. A war here, a bureaucratic reshuffle there, and dates can be reissued. Identities can be reconstructed. Mine have been, several times. People assume that “oldest on record” means sixty, seventy, eighty. It is easier to think that modern medicine made us. It did not.

I remember horses in the streets. Oil lamps behind glass. The scrape of quills. I remember when tuberculosis was called consumption and when polio locked summers indoors. I remember both World Wars not as chapters in textbooks, but as stretches of years where the air tasted like metal and grief.

I didn’t know I was immortal then. I knew that I survived when others didn’t. I knew that infections that took neighbors left me untouched. I knew that bullets missed, bombs somehow spared the buildings I was in, that famines ended right before desperation tipped into death for me.

Survivor’s guilt is heavy enough over one lifetime. Stretched across centuries, it becomes geological, a pressure that shapes you.

When the classification finally came, when genomic analysis and pattern recognition wrapped language around what I am, I was already tired. Not tired in cartilage or sinew—I have never woken with aching joints—but tired in the slow, deep way that comes from watching the same mistakes regenerate in new clothes.

They track us now. Naturals are registered at birth when the biomarkers light up. Parents get glossy brochures: your child is special. There are recommended counseling services, specialized insurance products, long-term educational plans. Corporations salivate quietly. Governments discuss military applications less quietly.

By law, we cannot be conscripted; that was one of the first global accords, passed in the wake of a scandal where a small nation’s defense ministry politely refused to demobilize an immortal corporal. The public decided quickly that turning us into permanent soldiers was monstrous. They are more comfortable when we are doctors, firefighters, astronauts. Heroes in ways that look good in profiles.

I’ve been all those things, at one time or another. When you have time, you collect careers like other people collect souvenirs.

Medicine, in my forties—my second forties. Engineering in my “sixties.” Philosophy between. I was an early coder when code smelled like ozone and hot plastic, long before it sank into everything. I worked in climate remediation for thirty years. People like to ask me which job meant the most.

I tell them the truth: teaching. Standing in front of new minds and saying, “This is what we learned last time we tried this and failed,” and hoping someone listens.

Being the oldest immortal does not make me the wisest. It just means I have run this loop more often. I’ve watched ideologies bloom and burn, watched certainty harden into cruelty, watched kindness go quietly viral.

Do I regret it? That’s usually the next question, when the cameras are off and the interviewers get brave.

I regret specifics: faces I couldn’t save, words I didn’t say, the first great love I walked away from rather than watch him grow old beside my unwrinkled face. I regret the centuries I spent pretending, cycling through “cousins” and “descendants” to keep neighbors from counting too carefully. I regret the lies that insulated me but isolated me too.

But regret the condition itself? No.

People assume immortality is an endless party until it isn’t; then they assume it is endless torment. It is neither. Mostly, it is Tuesday. Mostly, it is habit. You adapt. You learn to hold your attachments differently—not weaker, but more honestly, without the illusion that love is safe because it is brief. You love knowing you will stay to remember for two.

Here is another secret: I am not sure I am truly indestructible.

They say our neural tissue is self-repairing, that our cells correct errors, that carcinogenesis fails to take hold. So far, knives, bullets, even one very unfortunate fall from a rescue helicopter have not kept me down. But all systems have thresholds. Drop me into a star, perhaps, or scatter me thoroughly enough, and even my miraculous feedback loops will have no substrate.

The knowledge that there may be an off switch out there is oddly soothing. Eternity without the possibility of ending would be a prison sentence. Instead, I have something else: a horizon I cannot see, but can imagine. It makes my choices matter.

Being the oldest immortal means I am frequently used as a story.

Parents point to me: “Look, longevity can be meaningful.” Politicians cite my testimony: “Continuity has value.” Tech companies court me for endorsements. Religions alternately misunderstand me or treasure me as a very inconvenient data point.

I have outlived kings and parties and platforms. I have watched doctrines bend to accommodate new observations. I have learned to say “I don’t know” more often than anything else.

What do I know?

I know that every mortal person I have loved has, in one way or another, asked me for the same blessing at the end: “Remember me.”

Not save me, not fix me, not make me like you. Just: keep me from vanishing.

So I do. I remember. I carry them in an archive that no fire or flood can touch. I keep their jokes, their gestures, the way their eyes flashed when they cared about something. I speak their names sometimes, alone, as if I am lighting candles in an unending dark.

Immortality, as they clinically define it, is a naturally occurring genetic anomaly with profound implications for human society, resource allocation, ethics, and law.

Immortality, as I live it, is this: an agreement, renewed quietly each day, to stay and witness, to keep learning, to keep loving in full knowledge of loss, and to bear the weight of memory without turning away.

I am the oldest immortal.

Ask me again in a hundred years what that means.

I suspect my answer will have changed.

samples.prompt: Scientists have solved the mystery of why headphones always tangle, causing huge advances in science/technology.
samples.output:
When the paper first came out—“Topology of Self-Entangling Flexural Filaments Under Ambient Perturbation”—almost nobody outside the field noticed. It was a 68-page manuscript full of stochastic differential equations, knot invariants, and simulation screenshots that looked like spaghetti art. A few science blogs ran headlines like “Mathematicians Explain Why Your Earbuds Always Tangle,” and people shared it for a day, nodding in weary recognition, then moved on.

But in labs from Zurich to Kyoto, in think tanks and defense agencies and quietly ambitious startups, people did not move on. They printed the paper, annotated it, argued with it, tried to break it, and couldn’t. For the first time, someone had done more than observe that sufficiently long strings randomly jostled in a confined space tend to form knots. The authors had quantified it. They had built a predictive theory of entanglement.

The lead author, Dr. Imogen Khatri, had not set out to change the world. She genuinely just hated detangling headphones. Before the era of seamless wireless earbuds and bone-conduction headbands, there had been that decade where every commute began with a ritual of frustration. In grad school, she’d read the 2007 paper showing that “spontaneous knotting of an agitated string” was a statistical inevitability above certain lengths. It annoyed her. It was elegant but resigned, like saying, “Well, socks disappear in the dryer, that’s just entropy, isn’t that cute?”

Revisiting the problem fifteen years later, as a tenured physicist with a fondness for petty questions, she added three key twists.

First, she and her team modeled the cord not as a uniform string, but as a flexural filament: a body with preferred curvature, memory, microscopic asymmetries, and anisotropic friction. Real cables had layered sheathing, braids, stress-relief collars, tiny eccentricities from manufacturing. They did not explore configuration space uniformly; they moved with biases.

Second, they took seriously the environment: the geometry and material of pockets and bags, the cadence of human motion, the vibrational spectra of walking versus running versus cycling, the starts and stops of trains. With accelerometer data and high-speed imaging, they translated every jostle into perturbations in configuration space.

Third—and this was the leap—they connected the local mechanics to global topology in a closed form. They discovered that under realistic perturbations, certain small “proto-loops” were attractors: once formed, they were disproportionately likely to tighten and interlock with neighbors, forming what Khatri named metastable entanglement complexes. These complexes were not mere accidents; they were emergent structures with measurable formation rates, lifetimes, and coupling behaviors.

What emerged was a map: given filament properties, container geometry, and motion profile, you could compute the probability distribution of knot types after a given time. Conversely, given constraints on allowable knots (like “none”), you could design filaments and environments that would almost never tangle.

The media mostly ran with “Scientists confirm your headphones hate you.” What they missed at first was that Khatri’s equations did something more radical: they tamed a piece of everyday chaos. They replaced hand-wavy appeals to entropy with engineering-grade predictability.

The first obvious applications were trivial, and therefore lucrative.

Consumer electronics companies licensed the models to produce genuinely tangle-resistant cables, not just the thick rubber ropes marketing departments had been peddling. By tuning stiffness gradients, surface textures, and distributed mass irregularities at the micron scale, they created “entanglement cold” cords: in a normal pocket, shoved in carelessly, jostled for an hour, they statistically refused to form closed loops robust enough to self-tighten. Promo videos showed people pulling perfectly straight cables from impossible messes.

Backpacks and handbags followed. Luggage interiors were reshaped with “topological rails,” subtle seams and ridges that disrupted proto-loop formation. The old joke about spending your life untangling cords faded, then died.

But the bigger impact came when other fields realized that Khatri’s framework applied far beyond earbuds.

Biologists, especially those dealing with DNA and chromatin folding, seized on the math. The genome is, among other things, a very long filament in a very small space, constantly jostled. Scientists had long known about topoisomerases and supercoiling, about how the cell prevents catastrophic tangling. Now, they had a generalized entanglement theory that could be parameterized for biopolymers.

Within three years, a team at the Max Planck Institute used a Khatri-inspired model to predict—and then image—a previously unknown class of DNA loop structures that regulated gene clusters in response to mechanical stress. These “K-complexes,” named in somewhat embarrassed honor of the headphone paper, turned out to be central to how cells sense crowding and tension in tissues. Pharmaceutical companies pounced. Drugs designed to modulate the formation or dissolution of these complexes gave surgeons new tools: encouraging controlled repair pathways, inhibiting maladaptive fibrosis, slowing certain cancers that relied on stress-response loops.

As DNA yielded new secrets, materials scientists had their own revolution.

Fiber-reinforced composites—used in aircraft, turbines, prosthetics—depend on the alignment and entanglement of microscopic strands. Previously, much of their manufacture had been an empirical art: tweak curing times, weave densities, hope for the best. With entanglement theory in hand, engineers began to design fiber layouts that self-organized into optimal, predictable networks under vibration, heat, or stretch.

You could print a tangle now. Program a spool of carbon fiber with slight modulation in stiffness and torsion; as it was shaken, it would climb into a pre-calculated metastable mesh, stronger and lighter than any hand-laid equivalent. Wind turbine blades gained years of life. Lightweight exoskeletons became less bulky, more organic.

Data centers were next. Cabling in massive server farms had quietly become a nightmare: thousands of kilometers of fiber and copper, where tangling equaled downtime. Using the new models, architects created “knot-neutral” routing geometries. Cable trays, conduit, even ventilation patterns were tuned so that random disturbances (maintenance, thermal expansion) statistically relaxed snarls instead of worsening them. Service interruptions dropped. Nobody made a movie about it, but the people who kept the internet running slept better.

Then came robots.

Soft robotics had been limited by control: flexible tentacles and artificial muscles were powerful but awkward, prone to unwanted wraps and knots. With a predictive entanglement framework, roboticists could choreograph limbs that temporarily braided around each other for strength, or slid apart cleanly without snagging. Search-and-rescue machines crawled through rubble as morphing bundles of tendrils that never truly trapped themselves. Surgical robots, once constrained to stiff arms, gained filamentous manipulators that could snake through vessels and intestines without tying deadly knots.

The military, predictably, classified half of what they did. Rumors leaked: deployable “string-fields” of smart cable that could spontaneously weave into barriers under the right vibrations, or unknit on command; swarms of micro-drones connected by ultra-fine tethers that used entanglement to create dynamic antenna arrays in midair.

The flourishing of knot-aware technology culminated, symbolically, in space.

Long-duration missions had always struggled with storage and deployment of long flexible structures: tethers, hoses, inflatable habitats, solar sails. Microgravity made tangling both more likely and more catastrophic. With Khatri’s equations extended to orbital dynamics, mission designers began to embrace a concept that had once been nightmare fuel: purposeful, controlled tangling.

The first “K-Array” solar sail launched seven years after the headphone paper. It started as a dense spool of ribbon. As it unfurled, guided by tiny reaction wheels and programmed vibrations, it self-entangled into a fractal mesh that maximized surface area and redundancy. Micrometeoroid damage no longer doomed the sail; loads rerouted through the network. The whole architecture had been discovered in simulation, a metastable attractor in filament configuration space, as inevitable under certain deployment sequences as a headphone knot in a commuter’s pocket.

By then, public perception had caught up. Khatri gave a widely viewed talk where she said, half joking, “We thought we were asking why your headphones hate you. We were actually asking: given a flexible thing being bumped around, what shapes is the universe trying to push it into?”

That phrasing stuck. The “shapes the universe prefers” became a cultural shorthand for emergent order.

The backlash, when it came, was not against the math but its implications.

Labor organizers complained about warehouses redesigned with entanglement-aware layouts that herded workers like flows of cord, subtle architecture nudging human motion along predicted paths. Privacy advocates warned that crowd control models based on these equations let authorities anticipate and “smooth out” gatherings with eerie efficiency—if filaments sought certain knots, so did people in confined spaces.

A philosopher at Cambridge wrote a viral essay arguing that Khatri’s work had done to casual chaos what Newton did to falling apples: replaced a comforting shrug with the unsettling knowledge that even our tangles obeyed law. “We are running out of accidents,” she wrote.

Khatri answered, in a rare social media thread, that understanding something didn’t mean surrendering to it. A cord that can tangle is also a cord that can be guided not to. Power sat with the designers.

In the end, history textbooks would summarize it in three flat sentences: “In 2028, a comprehensive theory of filament entanglement was published. Initially famed for explaining why wired headphones tangle, it rapidly catalyzed advances in biology, materials science, robotics, and space engineering. The work marked a key step in the broader 21st-century project of predicting and engineering complex systems.”

But in the quieter version of the story, it began with a scientist on a train, staring in mild fury at a little white knot in her palm and thinking, There has to be a reason. She followed that reason into equations and experiments, into loops and links and probabilities.

We thought we were dealing with a minor inconvenience. Instead, we pulled on the knot—and half the world came with it.

samples.prompt: Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. Yours however, is a brick.
samples.output:
By the time I turned five, most kids’ familiars were speaking in full sentences.

Mara’s fox corrected her math homework in a bored Oxford accent. Jun’s crow brought him shiny bottle caps and recited weather reports. The twins down the street had matching lynxes that moved like liquid shadows, their eyes reflecting anything that glowed. Familiars curled at the feet of mothers at bus stops, perched on dads’ shoulders at hardware stores, trotted alongside teenagers like living declarations of personality and destiny.

Mine was a brick.

Not even a particularly interesting brick. Standard clay, faded red, dent in one corner. It manifested on my chest at 3:17 a.m. on my naming day, falling with a dull, grating thud onto my blanket. No smoke, no whisper, no shimmering. Just: clunk.

My mother screamed.

The nurse rushed in, saw the brick, stopped, and tried very hard to arrange her face into neutrality. My father reached for it and burned his fingers on heat that wasn’t fire, exactly, but something like compression: the sense that whatever it was had been squeezed through too small a gap.

“It’s… unique,” the nurse said.

And so it was.

Everyone tried to make it make sense.

Maybe it would change, they said. Some familiars did—puppies grew into wolves, embers into phoenixes. A brick might be… a chrysalis. Or a metaphor. Or a late bloomer.

We set it on my windowsill. It did nothing.

At seven, it finally moved.

I was sitting on my floor coloring while my best friend Mara’s fox flicked through my storybooks with its tail, criticizing every illustration. My brick, as usual, sat there. My mother had put a small plant on top of it, as if to apologize.

“Why don’t you talk?” I asked it for the thousandth time, more angry than hopeful.

The brick scraped two inches to the left. The plant wobbled, then toppled.

Mara screamed. Her fox hissed. I stared.

“You saw that,” I said.

“It scooted,” Mara whispered, in the same tone people used for miracles and murders.

After that, everyone had a new theory: it was slow. It was shy. It required special conditions. It needed to be studied.

We tested it. Left it in front of the TV. Gave it music, books stacked around it, my homework, my tears, a little of my blood once when I scraped my knee nearby. It would move sometimes: tiny adjustments when no one watched, positions slightly different than I remembered. I’d put it against the west wall; find it nudged toward the north by morning. It was never where I left it if I actually cared.

“You know,” my father said once as we watched the brick angle itself almost imperceptibly toward the living room door, “it doesn’t have to talk to be yours.”

But every other familiar talked. Or sang. Or glowed. Or did something beautiful and obvious. They were reflections of souls. A girl with a tiger was fierce; a boy with a songbird was sensitive; a nonbinary kid at my school had a shifting, translucent jellyfish that floated at their side, humming like a power line. Everyone had a story.

What did a brick say about me? That I was sturdy? That I was boring? That I was meant to be part of a wall, indistinguishable from a thousand others?

The first time someone called me Brick Girl, they meant it as a joke. The tenth time, it stuck.

I learned to carry it in my backpack, because kids would steal it and build things out of it—a little fortress of mockery—and ask why it didn’t fetch or purr. I’d snatch it back, cheeks burning, and it would vibrate faintly in my hands, like it wanted to move but wouldn’t.

In middle school, familiars began helping their humans channel.

Mara’s fox sharpened her perception; she could pick up lies like a bloodhound. Jun’s crow heightened his focus; he could memorize entire textbooks overnight. A boy named Elias had a bear that, when he touched its paw, lent him the kind of courage that made teachers pause.

The day I tried a formal channeling with my brick, the instructor coughed to hide her skepticism.

“Every familiar is a conduit,” she said. “Even… unconventional ones.”

She set the brick between us. The other students had their animals and entities arrayed like an arcane menagerie. My brick just sat there, a dull block on a polished desk.

“Place your hands on your familiar,” she said.

I did. The clay was cool at first. Then warmth seeped into my palms, slow and sure. Not a flame, not a spark. Compression again. Potential packed into silence.

“Ask it,” she said softly.

“What are you for?” I whispered, not expecting an answer.

There was no voice in my head. No vision. Just a sensation: weight, alignment, lines being drawn in straight, uncompromising paths. For a second, the room faded. I felt the building’s bones—the lattice of steel, the stacked floors, the pressure of one level on another. It was terrifying and insanely intimate.

I jerked my hands away. The sensation snapped.

“Anything?” the instructor asked.

“No,” I lied.

Because what I felt wasn’t the magic everyone else bragged about. It wasn’t flashy. It didn’t feel like power. It felt like responsibility.

By high school, I understood three things:

1) My brick was not going to turn into a fox.
2) It was, to my increasing annoyance, quietly protective.
3) It never moved randomly.

When a ceiling tile collapsed during finals, everyone ducked. I didn’t have to; the brick in my bag tugged at the strap seconds before it happened, urging me aside. When a drunk driver hopped the curb one night, walking home with Mara, my backpack yanked me backward, hard enough to bruise my shoulders, just before the car swiped where I’d been.

The more I paid attention, the clearer its pattern became. It angled toward safe exits. It grew heavier when people lied to me about important things. It warmed when the ground under my feet was solid—not just literally, but in the subtle ways plans and promises either held or didn’t.

“You’re like a living level,” Mara said once, when we were fifteen, sitting on the roof. Her fox slept across her knees. My brick rested between my hands. “A human spirit level.”

“Super glamorous,” I said, rolling my eyes. But I couldn’t deny the way its steady presence calmed me. How chaos felt less sharp when my fingers brushed its rough surface.

College brochures began arriving with sectored tracks: Elemental Studies. Combat Channeling. Healing. Illusion. All full of glossy photos of magnificent familiars mid-feat.

I flipped past them until I hit: Structural Magic & Protective Wards.

The pamphlet’s cover showed a nondescript gray stone. It glowed faintly at the joints of an enormous bridge, threads of light traveling from one anchoring point to another, keeping the whole impossibly long span intact while storms raged beneath it.

I picked up my brick.

“So that’s it?” I asked.

It did not answer. But it was warm and very, very still, the way a decision is right before you say it out loud.

On the first day of Structural class, I walked into a room with no windows and too many pillars. Everyone else had familiars that looked wrong there—hawks and tigers and serpents—restless in the cramped geometry.

My brick was serene.

The professor, an old woman with hands like knots in wood, eyed it and smiled, actually smiled.

“Foundation type,” she said. “Rare.”

“Foundation type?” I repeated.

She nodded. “Familiars that stabilize, anchor, bear loads. You don’t throw fire. You keep the ceiling up. You don’t break enemy lines. You make sure your people have a wall that doesn’t fall. Everyone wants to be the sword. Some of us are the stone.”

There was no pity in her voice, only certainty. For the first time in my life, Brick Girl felt less like a joke and more like a title.

We learned to read stress lines in mortar and magic alike. To lay ward-stones that channeled pressure away from weak points. To listen: not with ears, but through skin and bone and brick. My familiar never spoke in words, but under my hands it thrummed, guiding my attention—there, that crack, that lie in the architect’s original spell, that future fault.

When a storm ate the western pier, it was our cohort that held the bridges. My classmates with the fierce familiars joined the front lines, flames and claws and lightning. On the newsfeeds, they were brilliant.

No one broadcast the basements. The long nights with my brick pressed to the trembling foundations of evacuation centers, feeling the building lean and wanting, swaying like a tired animal.

“Hold,” I whispered.

This time, something answered.

Not in language, but in pressure shared; the distinct awareness that I was not holding it alone, that we were distributing the burden across a web of points I could not name but could feel. The walls quieted. The tremor settled.

In the morning, people walked out without knowing how close the beams had come to buckling. They did not thank the brick I carried or the hands that had shaken from the strain. They thanked the heroes on the screens.

My familiar remained a rectangle of clay.

It will never be majestic. It does not look good in photographs. Children do not squeal and reach for it. But when my brother wanted to buy a house, I brought it along. It grew oddly heavy in the doorway; I ran my hand along the frame and found the rot. The realtor frowned. My brother sighed and said he trusted me. Two months later, the city condemned the place.

“You’re weird,” he told me. “Useful, though.”

When Mara married, the hall she’d rented had hairline fractures in its load-bearing charms. I walked the perimeter with the brick in my palm until it warmed and settled. We moved the party three feet to the left and no one knew why, only that the night felt easier, as if nothing in the room could collapse.

I am not the fiercest or the fastest or the flashiest.

But I have never once stood alone with my brick in my hand and felt abandoned. When things quake, it does not panic. When people lie to themselves, it grows dense and uncomfortable until they adjust or leave. When I am uncertain, it sits with me like a fact: simple, inelegant, indestructible enough.

Everyone on earth is born with a familiar, they say, a mirror of the soul.

I used to hear that and flinch.

Now I run my thumb over chipped clay and think: good. Let them have their soaring, their roaring, their blaze of teeth and feather. I am mortar and weight and the quiet magic that keeps the arch from falling.

You can build a life on that.

samples.prompt: a relative finds old newspapers hidden, in their deceased grandparents home. they dont match up with recorded history.
samples.output:
The newspapers were the first thing I found that didn’t smell like my grandparents.

The house still held their scent—old wool and lavender soap, the dry paper tang of library books and recipes. Three weeks after the funeral I’d come back alone, armed with cardboard boxes and a resolve my mother didn’t have. She waited out in the car, engine off, pretending to be on her phone.

The attic hatch was where Grandpa had always said the ghosts lived.

“It’s just insulation,” Grandma would say. “He’s full of stories.”

I tugged the cord. Dust fell like gray snowfall. The ladder unfolded with a tired cough of metal. I climbed with a flashlight clenched between my teeth, the beam weaving.

Up there, the air was hotter and closer. Boxes. A trunk I’d never seen. The usual strata of forgotten holidays.

I found the newspapers under a moth-eaten quilt in the trunk, bound with rough twine, folded in on themselves like they were hiding.

The top one was dated June 19, 1972.

The masthead read “The New York Times,” but not as I knew it—slightly wrong in the font, the eagle sharper. The lead headline said:

“APOLLO 18 ASTRONAUTS REPORT CITY-LIGHTS ON LUNAR FAR SIDE.”

I stared. I knew enough space history to feel the jolt. There had been no Apollo 18. Congress canceled after 17. That fact had buoyed countless bar trivia nights.

Beneath the headline: a grainy photograph of three suited men, helmets under arms, grinning in that clean-cut NASA way—only their names weren’t any I recognized. Commander Harold Kline. Pilot Joseph Wu. LEM Pilot Andrea Morales. The caption described “anomalous geometric illumination near crater Tsiolkovskiy,” and words like “non-natural” and “structured array.”

“Okay,” I muttered. “So this is… what? A movie prop?”

I loosened the twine and flipped.

July 12, 1973: “PRESIDENT SHIRLEY CHISHOLM ANNOUNCES MOON ACCORDS WITH ‘OTHER INTELLIGENCE’.”

There was a black-and-white photo of Chisholm at a podium, hand raised, expression fierce and bright. That hurt—because in my world she was the woman who had tried and failed. In this, she’d won.

Another page: “COPENHAGEN FLOODED AFTER THIRD LEVEE BREACH; GLOBAL CLIMATE COALITION BLAMES ‘STRANGE STAR’.”

Another: “THE SECOND JUNE WAR ENDS; AFRICAN UNION ANNEXES SUEZ CHANNEL.”

Dates through the seventies, eighties, nineties. Familiar names doing unfamiliar things, familiar tragedies twisted or erased. No Reagan assassination attempt; instead, “PRESIDENT REAGAN MEETS MOSCOW PROTESTERS AT RED SQUARE PEACE VIGIL.”

I shuffled pages. History, but incorrect, written with the casual authority of the paper of record.

I checked the ink. Real, not laser. The paper browned properly at the edges, fibers rough beneath my fingers. Not glossy, not cheap.

“What are you doing up there?” my mother called from downstairs, voice thin.

“Old papers,” I called back. “Just junk.”

I slid one copy free, folded it under my arm, and climbed down.

In the kitchen, under brighter light, the wrongness grew more precise. Little details snagged the eye. Advertisements for airlines I’d never heard of. A half-page about a vaccine for “Variant Marburg-3” in 1984; as far as I knew, that variant didn’t exist. Obituaries for people who were, in my world, still alive.

I took photos with my phone and searched headlines.

Nothing.

Fact-checking websites, archived microfilm databases, conspiracy forums. The actual June 19, 1972 New York Times had a very different front page.

My mother came in, saw me with the newspaper, and went pale so quickly I thought she’d faint.

“Put that away,” she said.

“Mum, look at this. This is insane—”

“Put it away.”

Her hands were shaking, her voice too loud. Grief, I thought. Anything was a tripwire now.

“No, listen. It says Apollo 18. There wasn’t an Apollo 18.” I turned the page toward her. “Grandpa kept fakes for a prank? Did he show you these?”

“It’s not a prank.” Her voice went flat. Then softer: “They said it was safer if we didn’t.”

“Who said?”

She sank into the chair, as if someone had unhooked her strings.

“Your grandparents,” she said. “And some others. Put the rest back where you found them, Eli.”

I heard, more than understood, that she’d used my full name.

“Safer from what?” I asked.

She rubbed her temple. “Is there just the one bundle?”

“There’s a whole stack.”

Her breath left like a slow leak. “Of course there is.”

It took twenty minutes and a cup of tea before she would speak again. When she did, it was in circles.

“Your grandfather liked patterns,” she said. “He taught math because he liked when things fit. But the world didn’t fit, not the way he remembered it. So they told him he was stressed, then they told him to stop talking about it. Then they gave him those.”

“They who?” I said.

She looked up, and for a heartbeat I saw a girl inside the woman my mother had become, terrified and furious, standing in this same kitchen fifty years earlier.

“I was eight,” she said. “I woke up one night and the clock on my wall was wrong. It had always had black numbers, then they were red. Tiny thing, right? But I knew. I always knew. My school had different colors. The neighbor’s dog was named Pepper, not Pickles. Little, stupid things. When I told Mom, she cried so hard I thought I’d done something unforgivable. When I told your grandfather, he brought out a box of old newspapers.”

She gestured toward the ceiling.

“He said, ‘I remember this,’ and pointed at some headline about President Kennedy opening the Lunar Archive. Except in this world, in all the books and libraries and TV, that never happened. They told him he’d misremembered. But he wasn’t alone. There were… others.”

“Others,” I repeated. “Like an association of people with bad memories?”

“Like people who remembered a different run of history.” She shook her head quickly. “I sound crazy.”

“There’s alternative timelines on Reddit,” I said. “Mandela Effect, that kind of thing.”

She flinched.

“I hate that name,” she whispered.

I watched her carefully. “Are you saying Grandpa remembered… what’s in these newspapers, but nobody else did?”

“No,” she said. “I’m saying once upon a time, this was the history. And then it wasn’t.”

Silence.

Outside, a car crawled down the street. The refrigerator hummed. I could hear the house settling.

“You know that’s not how it works,” I said gently. “History doesn’t just… update.”

“Your grandparents were not imaginative liars,” she snapped. “These came to us in a locked metal case. They weren’t printed in our garage. Military courier, men in suits. I remember their shoes.”

“Their shoes.”

“Shiny. Wet,” she said. “It was raining, and they left no footprints on the porch. I remember thinking that. They sat at this table. They told your grandparents there had been an adjustment. That the world had been… corrected. Quantified, I suppose. They used a lot of words that meant nothing. But they apologized, because some people like your grandparents and, apparently, me, would remember pieces of the previous configuration. Residual overlap.

“They said the newspapers were artifacts from that prior run. Evidence, for the affected. To keep us from thinking we were mad. That we must never show anyone, must never try to ‘restore’ anything. That this—” she slapped the counter “—is the stable state now. Tampering risked another cascade.”

She laughed once, a short unsound thing.

“I had nightmares for years.”

I stared at her. Part of my brain was composing diagnoses. Shared psychosis. Grief-induced confabulation, belated. Some long elaborate family joke taken too far.

“You believe them,” I said.

“Yes,” she said, without hesitation.

“Because of red numbers on a clock,” I said.

“Because I watched a photograph change,” she said. “It was Kennedy standing beside a woman in a silver suit at a lunar module display. Next week, same frame on the mantle, the woman was gone and his tie was blue, not gray. And nobody but my parents thought that was strange.”

“It could have been swapped—”

“I checked the back. The same scratch, same bent corner. Only different.”

Her eyes were bright with tears. My arguments shrank.

“Grandpa never told me any of this,” I said.

“They wanted it to stop with me,” she said. “If you don’t notice, you don’t get visited.”

“That sounds ominous.”

“They weren’t threatening,” she said. “More like janitors. Tired. As if they’d cleaned up a mess bigger than we could understand and were just asking us not to spill anything.”

My rational mind scrabbled. “If this was real, there’d be more than a few old people and some newspapers.”

“There are more,” she said. “Hard to find. They used to meet. Compare notes. Your grandfather went for a while. Then your grandmother got sick, and he stopped. He said it didn’t matter. This life was real, too. We had to live in it.”

I exhaled. The newspaper felt heavy.

“So which is it?” I asked. “President Chisholm and moon cities, or my student loans and whatever this is?” I flicked at an ad for cassette players.

She gave me a look that was almost amusement.

“Both were real to the people inside them,” she said. “We’re only in one now. Your grandfather used to say: there’s no going back. Entropy only listens one way.”

“Why keep the papers?” I said.

“Proof that we weren’t crazy,” she said simply. “A love letter from a world that didn’t make it.”

I took the bundle home with me that night, despite her protests. I told myself I wanted to debunk them. I found a conservationist forum that explained paper aging. I weighed them, smelled them, checked for watermarks. They passed too many checks.

At two in the morning, with the city outside my apartment window and the radiator ticking, I read.

I read about the 1986 announcement: “WORLD CELEBRATES FIRST CONTACT ANNIVERSARY—TWENTY YEARS OF SHARED SCIENCE.” I read about the early, aggressive climate accords, the eradication of smallpox and polio and “Variant Marburg-3” by 1990. I read about setbacks, too; wars I’d never heard of, a reactor accident on the moon, a failed lattice between Mars and something beyond.

It wasn’t utopia. Just… tangibly different. A world that had turned hard in another direction at some crucial fork.

When dawn came, I put the papers back in their trunk in my living room. I labeled the box “Tax Records” in thick black marker.

Weeks went by. I returned to my job. I saw my mother on Sundays. We did not talk about the newspapers.

But I began to notice small things. A coworker swore a logo used to have a hyphen. A podcast host said, laughing, that she remembered learning there were twelve countries in South America. A barista insisted the KitKat bar used to have a little dash.

Mandela Effect, I told myself. Brains making patterns out of noise. Collective misremembering, not evidence.

Except: one evening I pulled out a random old paper I didn’t remember reading. Date: March 3, 2001.

Headline: “CROSS-BORDER PROTESTS HALT QUANTUM REVISION BETA TEST.”

I read it twice.

The article talked about an international effort to “recalibrate reality baselines” using “distributed quantum anchors,” about fears of “ontological refugees,” about ethics in editing history like code.

None of those terms, in my world, had the context the piece took for granted.

“Janitors,” my mother had said.

Tired people. Cleaning up.

Suddenly the men with the wet shoes made a different kind of terrible sense.

I folded the page very carefully.

I don’t know what’s true. Maybe that’s the point. Maybe you can only ever see the outline of what’s been edited by the smudges at the edge.

I only know that my grandparents kept a stack of newspapers that do not match our recorded history.

I know they were gentle and sane and believed in finish-your-vegetables and check-your-work and don’t-slam-the-door.

I know someone came once and told them, softly, to please not try to mend a fabric we are all still standing on.

So the box sits in my closet, under winter coats. Sometimes, late, I take out a random issue and read a day from a world that isn’t ours.

In one, a photo shows an older Shirley Chisholm at a podium under alien stars, saying, “We did not come here to be small.”

I touch the grainy edge of her face and think about choices, about corrections, about how many lives fit inside a word like “adjustment.”

When I’m done, I slide the paper back among its others. I turn off the light.

And I try, patiently, to remember which history I’m supposed to belong to.

samples.prompt: "Stop your crying! There's always someone out there who has it worse than you."
samples.output:
“Stop your crying! There’s always someone out there who has it worse than you.”

You hear it first as a scolding, sharp as snapped chalk. Your mother flings it over her shoulder as she scrubs plates, as if the suds can erase the wetness on your cheeks by proxy. You are eight, maybe nine, and your crime is that your favorite blue cup broke, or the girl in your class laughed when you read too slow. Your mother does not look back when she says it. It’s a reflex, like swatting a fly.

You sniff it in, the sentence, as if it’s medicine. It tastes like soap and shame.

Someone out there has it worse than you.

You picture a vague, gray crowd of unfortunate children: barefoot, hollow-eyed, clutching empty bowls or patched backpacks, always somewhere else, some distant “there” that makes your “here” trivial. You are not entirely sure where they are, only that they are important in the way your own feelings apparently are not. Their suffering is your measuring stick.  

So you learn quickly.

When your knee scrapes open on the pavement, red and gritty, you bite down on your tongue instead of wailing. There’s someone with two broken legs. When you don’t get picked for the team, when you are picked on in class, when your father slams a door hard enough to make the walls flinch—there’s always someone with a bigger bruise, a louder door, a worse father. Your pain is a math problem: subtract, divide, reduce.

At twelve, you are praised for being “so mature,” because you shrug after disappointments. “It’s fine,” you say. “It could be worse.” The adults nod. They feel reassured. You have become easy to manage.

This is how you learn to ghost yourself.

It is not that your life is devoid of blessings. You have food, a bed, a secondhand laptop, a childhood without bombs or sirens. You hear stories about countries with names your tongue trips over. Floods drown whole villages. A boy in your school loses his brother to leukemia. The news offers up images of disaster like beads on a rosary. You watch, and the familiar sentence whispers in your head, now in your own voice.

Stop your crying. Look at this. Look at that. Who do you think you are?

Compassion, they tell you, begins with noticing others. Gratitude, they tell you, comes from perspective. You try to be compassionate. You try to be grateful. So you strip your feelings down. You are brutal in your audits:

- Sad? But not homeless.
- Lonely? But not orphaned.
- Stressed? But not in a war zone.
- Heartbroken? But others have buried lovers.

You file your hurts under “Nuisance: Self-Indulgent.”

When you do cry, it’s in secret, and it’s less about whatever hurt you, and more about the fact that you are crying at all. The tears accuse you. How dare you, with your pantry and your parents alive and your city mostly intact?

In college, a professor introduces the word “invalidating” during a lecture on emotional development. You write it down, underlining it twice. There is a story about children whose feelings are dismissed until they no longer recognize them as real. The word sits in your notebook like a lit match.

After class you walk across campus, noticing how many people say “I’m fine” like a password. You start to hear the echoes in your friends’ stories.

One friend laughs about working three jobs and never sleeping. “It’s nothing,” she says quickly. “People have it worse. I’m lucky.” She grinds her teeth at night.

Another shrugs off panic attacks. “I mean, it’s not like I’ve been through real trauma.” He grips his coffee cup so tightly his knuckles whiten.

Someone posts a thread online, confessing they’re overwhelmed. Dozens of comments appear:
“Be grateful you even have a job.”
“At least you’re not dying.”
“First-world problems.”

Wrapped inside the slogan is an accusation: Your pain is a privilege you haven’t earned.

At a party, you meet a man named Elias who grew up in a war zone, the kind that appeared on your childhood television. He is quiet, careful with his words. When someone, tipsy, says, “I feel bad complaining about my workload in front of you, my issues are nothing,” Elias frowns, gently.

“That’s not how it works,” he says.

Everyone looks at him, surprised.

He continues, “If you are hurting, you are hurting. Comparing it to mine doesn’t make yours vanish. Pain is not a competition.”

You watch him, the way his jaw is soft but sure. Later, you ask him, hesitantly, “Did people say that to you? That someone had it worse?”

“All the time,” he says. “Sometimes as comfort, sometimes as command. It never helped. It just made me feel like I was failing at being strong enough.”

“But doesn’t perspective matter?” you ask.

“Yes,” he says. “Perspective matters. Dismissing does not. You can hold both: your pain and someone else’s. There is room.”

You carry this conversation home like a fragile object wrapped in your coat.

Night comes. You lie in bed and feel the familiar urge to scold yourself for the day’s aches: the criticism from your boss that lodged like a splinter, the unanswered text from someone you love, the heavy gray that has been trailing you like weather. You are ready to reach for the old refrain—stop your crying; people have it worse—when Elias’s words interrupt, quiet but insistent.

There is room.

You consider, for the first time, that the sentence you were raised on might not be a moral truth but a shield. An adult’s shield against the discomfort of your tears. Society’s shield against looking closely at the structures that cause suffering. Your own shield against the vulnerability of saying: This hurt me.

If someone has it worse, you don’t have to ask for help. You don’t have to risk being told no. If someone has it worse, you can clutch your martyrdom of silence and call it virtue.

But what if refusing to acknowledge your pain doesn’t ease theirs, and only deepens yours?

You imagine the abstract “someone out there” the phrase invoked when you were small. For a moment, you give her a face. She is standing ankle-deep in floodwater in a ruined kitchen; or she is in a hospital chair; or she is sitting on the edge of a narrow bed in a country where the electricity scrapes by for a few hours at night. She is exhausted in a way that gets into the bones.

In your imagination, you tell her about your day, your small miseries you’ve been taught to swallow. You watch her reaction.

She does not slap you with your privilege. She does not yell, “How dare you cry?” She is too tired and too human. She says, “Oh. That sounds hard,” because she knows that hurt is hurt, scaled differently but cut from the same cloth.

Suffering does not envy suffering. Only fear and guilt play that game.

You start experimenting.

The next time your chest tightens on the train for no reason, instead of saying, “This is ridiculous, I have no right,” you say, “Something in me is hurting.” You put your hand on your sternum. Nobody notices. The world doesn’t end.

When a coworker sighs and says, “I shouldn’t complain, others have it worse,” you say, “You’re allowed to complain. This sounds like a lot.” She looks startled, then relieved. It is a strange, small rebellion, this refusal to rank pain.

At a family dinner, your younger cousin bursts into tears over a breakup. Your aunt starts to form the words—you can tell by the inhale—“There are bigger problems in the world,” but you cut in, gently.

“It really hurts, doesn’t it?” you say to your cousin.

She nods, shoulders shaking. The aunt’s sentence dies on her tongue. For a moment, the air changes.

You are not dismissing the bigger problems. They are still there, vivid and unjust. You still donate when you can; you still march, sign, call. But you stop using other people’s suffering as a weapon against your own tenderness. You start to understand that empathy is not a pie with only so many slices. It is a muscle that strengthens each time you allow it to move, including toward yourself.

Months later, you visit your mother. Her hair is grayer. Her hands are rough. The TV mutters disaster in the background. You ask her, casually, if anyone ever told her, when she was young, “Stop your crying, others have it worse.”

She snorts. “All the time. My mother. My teachers. The nuns. Why?”

You think of her, small and scolded, learning the same subtraction you did. You look at her more softly.

“It never helped me,” you say. “I’m trying something different.”

She eyes you, defensive, then curious. “Like what?”

“Like…letting things hurt if they hurt. Without grading them.”

She clicks her tongue, ready with a retort, but it doesn’t quite land. Instead she sighs. “If I’d done that, I’d never have stopped crying,” she says, half-joking.

“Maybe you should have cried more,” you say.

The two of you sit in the hum of the television. Onscreen, someone out there is indeed having it worse. You do not turn away. You do not turn against yourself. You feel a knot in your throat—for them, for you, for your mother at eight years old being told to harden.

You let it rise. This time, you do not stop your crying.

samples.prompt: Politics in a fantasy world is tough to say the least.
samples.output:
Politics in a fantasy world is tough to say the least.

The fires of the capital still glowed sullen red on the horizon when Lysa reached the last bend in the road. It should have been dawn by now, but ash hung so thick in the sky the sun could only guess from behind it, sending down a pale, bruised light that turned armor gray and skin sickly. The banner of the High Crown, a rearing white gryphon, drooped sodden on its pole, feathers stained with soot. She shifted her weight in the saddle and inhaled carefully. Smoke. Magic. Blood. The usual cocktail of statecraft.

“Stop here,” she told her escort.

The riders halted. Behind them, the caravan of petitioners, merchants, and opportunists jostled, craning for a view of the capital. News had traveled faster than horses, carried on wind-spirits and gossip spells: the king was dead, the wards had failed, the dragons were out, and the Parliament of Nobles had convened an emergency session to “ensure continuity.” That last phrase, Lysa thought, translated roughly to: “We are about to ruin everything.”

“Advisor,” said Captain Dorn, his voice clipped and respectful. “Our orders are to see you into the city.”

“You will,” Lysa said. “But we will ride in like people who are not afraid. Two banners, white, both visible. No shields raised. The royal seal on my neck visible and glowing. If someone takes a shot at us, let me do the talking.”

Dorn grunted. He had seen her “talk” in the war of the southern passes. That talk had turned a mountain regiment into trees. Actual trees. The southern lords still sent very polite letters about that.

Politics, she reminded herself, was the art of getting people to not make you turn them into trees.

They rode.

The northern gate yawned open, its once-invisible wards flaring a faint, unhealthy purple. The air inside the walls tasted wrong: too sharp with stray spellwork, too flat where the old protections had woven life into stone. A group of armored elves stood in quiet formation just inside, their silver-and-blue cloaks marked with the crescent of the Moon Throne. Foreign allies. Or foreign occupiers, depending on who ended the day alive.

“Lady Lysa of Thornhall,” their leader said, stepping forward with courtly grace and battlefield eyes. “Dawn-blessing. Our Queen sends condolences. And counsel.”

“Condolences accepted,” Lysa answered. “Counsel conditionally so.”

That earned the barest twitch at the corner of the elf’s mouth.

“To the council hall, then,” Lysa said.

Of all the magic in the world, the most dangerous had always been concentrated in one chamber: a round room, twenty-four chairs, a dome lined with sky-crystal and memory-gold, where the great and terrible of the continent came to speak as if their words did not bend armies. Carved into the center of the floor was the Oath Sigil: whoever lied outright beneath it would cough up black ash until their heart stopped. Convenient. But like all things in politics, it had loopholes. The Sigil did not ignite half-truths, evasions, or statements of belief.

Lysa entered last, as planned, forcing everyone else to rise and watch.

They were all there.

Duke Marren of the Iron Coast, whose private navy could strangle half the kingdom’s trade.

Archmage Veloran, white-robed, eyes faintly glowing, smelling of ember and old parchment.

High Priestess Elen of the Dawn, serene, hands folded as if she hadn’t an army of fanatics to call.

Prince Calen. The late king’s only legitimate child. Too young. Too earnest. Too alive a symbol to be permitted an uncomplicated life.

And across from Calen, at ease in her seat as if it were a throne, sat Sorrel Blackwing: dragon, in her human shape. She was barefoot, of course. It was a small insult. Or a reminder. Dragons need not armor their feet.

“Advisor Lysa,” said Marren. “At last. We were concerned the roads had become…unpredictable.”

Translation: We wondered if someone had killed you. Or if we should have.

“I prefer to walk into burning cities at a measured pace,” Lysa said lightly, passing her hand over the Oath Sigil as she took her place behind Calen’s chair. The Sigil flared, recognizing her as sworn to the Crown. The light faltered for a second—because the Crown was vacant—then steadied. Interesting. The old magics wanted continuity.

Veloran’s gaze flicked down at the Sigil, calculating. “We convene under ill stars,” he said. “The king is gone, the southern wards shattered, and certain…ancient beings…have taken advantage of the lapse in our defenses.” His eyes slid, deliberately, to Sorrel.

Sorrel smiled, annoyed and amused in equal measure. “If your king plays with binding sigils he does not understand,” she said, “and leaves the chains on my kin to fray, it is hardly our fault if they remember they have wings.”

Lysa spoke before the priestess could. “The king is dead because someone turned the wards inward,” she said. “That is not a fraying. That is a hand on a lever.”

The Oath Sigil gave no reaction. Not a lie. An accusation made of suspicion, not falsehood.

Marren clasped his hands, rings clicking. “Are we here for theatrics, or to keep the realm from falling apart? My harbors are choking with refugees. My coffers do not refill themselves.”

“Nor do the temples,” Elen murmured.

“Nor the treasury,” Veloran added.

Sorrel shrugged. “My kin have no need of coin. We have hills to sleep on.”

Calen finally spoke, his voice steady, his boy’s face made hard by the last three days. “You are here,” he said, “to swear to the continuity of the realm and the safety of its people. As your prince—”

“Uncrowned,” Marren said.

“As your prince,” Calen repeated, jaw tightening, “I ask for your oaths.”

The Sigil pulsed faintly at the word “ask.” Asking, not commanding. He heard it too; Lysa felt his shoulder tense.

Politics in a fantasy world, she thought, required power to be spoken in exactly the right tense.

“We might begin,” Lysa said smoothly, “with the question of dragons.”

Sorrel tilted her head. “Delightful. Please, do tell me what I am.”

“You are a sign,” Lysa said. “Three nights ago, when the wards folded, the capital shield burned out from the inside. That requires High Circle access. Exactly three people here had that access.” She let the words hang. “At the same moment, the binding on the Dragon Accord weakened, but did not break. Enough that your kin could test the edges, not enough that they were compelled to stay away. And then,” she looked to Veloran, “someone sent fire-messages to the Moon Throne, asking for ‘stabilizing support’.”

Veloran’s jaw flickered.

“The elves arrived before the dawn after the disaster,” Lysa continued. “Fast. Very fast. They were close. How fortunate.”

The Moon Queen’s emissary lifted a brow. “Are we to apologize,” he asked, “for our readiness to aid? The Accord binds us, too. Your wards flickered—we respond. That is our treaty.”

“The wards did more than flicker,” Lysa said. “They inverted. That is an attack. An internal one.”

The Oath Sigil stayed still. No one had spoken a lie yet. That was the trouble.

“Enough shadows,” Marren said. “Advisor, what do you propose?”

There it was. The question that cut through grief and oath and ash. It sounded respectful. It meant: Which leash are you asking us to wear?

Lysa flexed her fingers behind Calen’s chair, feeling the familiar buzz of contained power, of the oath-marks burned into her palms the night she’d sworn to the Crown at fifteen. She thought of the options.

She could name Veloran a traitor. He had motive—the chance to rewrite the Accord, to place the mages above crown and temple. But she could not prove it, and the Sigil wouldn’t kill him on conjecture.

She could accuse Marren. The chaos served him; his ships controlled food; chaos made kings kneel. But his kind never put their own cities to the torch. He preferred to own things, not ruin them.

She could blame Sorrel. Blaming dragons was easy. That was their function in human politics: incarnate scapegoats. But Sorrel had been the one who’d sent her warning scent on the wind when the first wardstone cracked. Lysa had smelled dragon-smoke, yes—but laced with panic. Dragons did not panic at their own plans.

She could try to use the elves. Invite them in, let their presence frighten the nobles into obedience. But invite an immortal queen’s “support” into your power vacuum and you never quite get your seat back.

Every option cut another thread.

“Politics in this realm,” Lysa said aloud, “is a tapestry woven on a spider’s web over a pit. We pull too hard in any direction, we fall.”

“That is…poetic,” Elen said carefully.

“It is accurate,” Lysa answered. “So we will do the ugly, difficult thing. We will share the blame.”

Marren frowned. “Explain.”

“We say this, beneath the Sigil,” Lysa said. “That the wards failed because all of us failed. Mage tower, crown, temple, coast. That we neglected them in our squabbles. True enough to live. We say the dragons came because the Accord is old and must be renewed. True. We say the Moon Throne’s presence is welcome, bound strictly and narrowly by revised terms. If they accept, we have their spears but not their chains. If they refuse, we know their aim.”

The elf emissary watched her, expression unreadable.

“And in return?” Sorrel asked softly.

“In return,” Lysa said, meeting the dragon’s molten eyes, “you bind your brood, willingly, to a new Accord. Not chains. Partnership. If the kingdom falls, you lose your hoards anyway, buried under someone else’s flags. Help us hold the sky up, Sorrel.”

The Sigil flared gold at “Help us hold the sky up.” A phrase of vow. That was the thing about ancient magic: it loved metaphor, and punished carelessness.

Sorrel’s nostrils flared as she tasted the binding in the air. “You play a hard game for a soft-handed human,” she murmured. That, from a dragon, was almost a compliment.

Marren tapped his rings. “Shared blame dilutes my liability. Shared cost means shared control. I could live with that.”

Veloran bristled, but he could see the walls closing. Elen would not stand alone against a story of collective fault; her sermons could spin repentance from it.

“And the boy?” Marren asked. “Do we crown him now, in the ashes? Or wait?”

Calen’s fingers dug into the chair. Lysa rested her palm over his knuckles—steady.

“Now,” she said. “Before another story settles. Before anyone can say the realm lived a day without a Crown and did not shatter.”

“Risky,” murmured Veloran.

“Everything is risky,” Lysa snapped. “That is the point. But if we do nothing bold, we will spend the next decade in committees while dragons circle and foreign banners ‘support’ us.”

She stepped forward, onto the Oath Sigil. It flared bright white, and she felt its scrutiny crawl up her spine.

“I, Lysa of Thornhall,” she said, “sworn Advisor to the High Crown, declare Prince Calen the rightful, living, and necessary King of this realm.”

The Sigil burned, testing each word.

Rightful. True by blood, by law.

Living. Obvious.

Necessary.

That was opinion. Belief. Safe.

The Sigil held. Then, slowly, it shone brighter, spilling light up around Calen’s chair like a dawn.

One by one, because none of them could afford to be seen hesitating while the magic watched, they stepped forward. Marren, lips thin with calculation. Elen, eyes distant with theology. Veloran, burning with repressed fury. Sorrel, bare feet whispering against stone, gaze thoughtful. The elf emissary, representing a queen who would be very interested in what disaster had bound these mortals tighter together.

They all spoke some version of the vow. The Sigil accepted just enough.

When it was done, and Calen sat crowned with a circlet still warm from the forge, smoke leaking through the high windows, Lysa let herself exhale.

Outside, dragons circled the broken wards like patient hawks.

Inside, elves lounged in borrowed corridors, mages adjusted ledgers, priests composed sermons, and nobles counted ships.

Politics in a fantasy world was tough to say the least.

But it had worked, for one more day, without anyone becoming a tree.

samples.prompt: You're a small animal about to be captured by a bird of prey. You can speak to each other.
samples.output:
I notice the shadow first, a rippling dark over the clover and dandelions, stretching long across the sun-warm dirt. The others keep nibbling, twitching their noses like everything is green and always will be green, but the air has thinned. Danger has a taste: old stone and rust and the memory of feathers.

I freeze.

His wings fold as he drops, a silent spear of brown and gold. There’s a hiss of air, a thump of displaced grass, and suddenly he’s there, talons pinning the ground where my back foot was a heartbeat ago.

I stumble, scramble, feel the wind of his wing graze my ear. One claw clips my flank—just a sting, a shallow slice, but the force spins me. When I stop, I’m on my side in the hollow between two roots, my chest hammering so loudly it’s almost a voice of its own.

He’s already turned.

“Oh,” he says, and his voice is surprisingly calm, surprisingly tired. “You’re fast.”

“I’d… prefer… to be faster,” I pant, trying to push myself upright.

He hops closer, each step precise. His talons open and close with an absent-minded flex, as if he’s checking a tool. His eyes: suns in miniature, gold and unblinking.

“Most do,” he says. “Stand, if you can. I don’t take pleasure in catching those who can’t stand.”

“Nice ethics,” I mutter, ears flat, forcing my paws under me. “Very noble. Really softens the whole murder thing.”

He tilts his head, curious. “You all call it ‘murder’ like I’m malicious. If I don’t eat, I die. That’s not malice. That’s arithmetic.”

There’s a space between us that feels like it’s already filled with his decision. I could run. I could try. The warren is twenty leaps away, the entrance a dark slit beneath the thornbush. I know exactly how that sprint would feel: the burn, the hope, the sudden weight on my back.

I stay. I haven’t finished being afraid yet. It would feel rude to run in the middle of a conversation.

“It’s murder from my end,” I say. “Arithmetics usually looks better depending on which side of the sum you’re on.”

I expect a strike for that. Instead, he chuckles—that’s what it sounds like, though it’s half rasp, half sigh.

“You speak well for something that trembles,” he says.

“I tremble well for something that speaks,” I shoot back, more sharply than I feel.

“You know what I am?” he asks.

“Sharp,” I answer. “High. Hungry.” A pause. “Buzzard? Hawk? You all look like blades to me.”

“I am a hawk,” he says, mildly offended. “Buzzards wait, I descend. There is a difference.”

“Congratulations on your initiative.”

He studies me. I feel him counting my breaths, my muscles, my choices.

“I will take you,” he says at last, simply. “You’re the right size. The others are too far, too close to cover, or too thin. You will feed my chicks.”

I swallow. My heart is a wild drum.

“You have chicks,” I say. It comes out too high, too bright.

“Yes.” He doesn’t embellish. His gaze doesn’t soften. “Three.”

“Oh,” I say. It’s too small a sound. “So I’d be… what? Breakfast? Lunch?”

“Life,” he says.

“Well that’s dramatic,” I say, because if I don’t keep talking, I might cry, and that feels like letting fear have the last word. “And if I ask you not to?”

He’s quiet. A soft wind stirs his feathers, and they shiver like leaves.

“Why would I grant that?” he asks.

“Because I don’t want to die.”

“That’s not a reason,” he says. “If not wanting to die prevented death, nothing would eat anything and we’d all be ghosts of hunger.”

“That’s a nice line,” I say. “Did you come up with that, or is there a school for ominous birds?”

He almost smiles. It’s in the tilt of his head, the fractional relax of his shoulders.

“Fox said something similar,” he says. “Right before I took his eye.”

“Fox can talk?”

“Everything can talk,” he says. “Not everything bothers to listen.”

I draw a breath that shudders on the way in.

“If you can listen,” I say slowly, “then you can choose.”

“I can choose among my prey,” he says. “I cannot choose to be something that does not kill.”

“Can you choose… to skip a day?”

He scoffs, a sound like feathers against bark.

“Can you choose to skip a lifetime of clover?” he asks. “You’d gnaw bark before noon. No. I have a weight to bring home. They open their beaks when I land. They don’t understand ethics. They understand empty.”

My legs are steady now. My pulse is not.

“I have a warren,” I say. “We’re five. Had eight. Fox took one. Snare took another. One just… didn’t wake up after winter.” I swallow. “If you take me, that’s one more hole that goes quiet. Just… know that. Add that to your arithmetic.”

He listens. To my surprise, he nods.

“I always add it,” he says. “The quiet is part of the cost.”

“And?”

“And I take you anyway.”

The honesty stings more than if he’d lied.

“So that’s it?” I ask. “I give you a good conversation; you give me a philosophical shrug?”

“You asked to be heard,” he says. “I heard. Hearing is not the same as yielding.”

I look at his talons. The curve of them. How clean they are. How thoroughly they must do their work.

“What’s it like?” I ask.

He blinks. “To kill?”

“To hunt. To fall.”

He glances upward, as if considering whether to share the secret.

“It’s falling toward an answer,” he says after a moment. “Up there everything is question. Wind, distance, flicker of fur.
