Then you fold yourself into the question and the ground rushes up and there’s a moment—just one—where all the angles align. If you meet it well, you live. If you misjudge, you starve. It is—” He stops, flexes his wings slightly. “It is a kind of grace.”

“Does grace ever trip?” I ask.

“Often,” he says. “I’ve seen my shadow scatter you like leaves and gone home with nothing. I hate those days.”

“I love those days,” I say.

“Yes,” he agrees. “That’s the trouble.”

We stand there, which is an odd thing to do with death between us. The others are gone, slipped into the earth at the first sweep of his shadow. Cowards, I think, then correct myself. Survivors.

“Tell me your name,” he says.

“Why?”

“So I can carry more than flesh,” he replies, as if it’s obvious. “Respect the taken.”

I think of lying; some grand name with history and thunder. But the world has been too honest today.

“Thistle,” I say.

“Thistle,” he repeats, testing it, as if it might prick his tongue. “I am Corren.”

“Corren,” I echo. It’s a sharp name. It fits.

“You could still run,” he says. “You’ve been thinking about it the whole time.”

“Would it help?”

“For me, yes,” he says. “I am built for pursuit. The chase would clear the weight in my wings. I would enjoy it.”

“Would it help me?”

He looks me over, calculating in a way beyond words.

“No,” he says. “Not enough.”

“Then no,” I say. “I’ll stay.”

There’s a hollow quiet after that. A cricket, confused by the pause in motion, starts up again.

“I’m afraid,” I admit.

“That does not shame you,” Corren says.

“I’m not asking for your blessing.”

“I’m giving it anyway,” he says. “I was afraid when the owls nested near my tree. Fear is not small; it is precise. It tells you that you love the time you’ve had.”

“That’s very poetic for someone about to bite my head off,” I say.

“I don’t bite,” he says, almost offended again. “I break and pierce. Biting is for foxes.”

“Apologies,” I say. My whiskers twitch. “You know, you’re not what I expected.”

“What did you expect?”

“A monster,” I say. “Something that enjoyed scaring us. Something that called us stupid for not having wings.”

He fluffs, not with pride, but irritation.

“What a waste of time,” he says. “Mocking food? Preposterous. Without you, I’m just a rag of feathers falling out of the sky.”

“I was hoping you’d say, ‘Without you, I’d starve, so I’ll let you go out of gratitude.’”

“That is not how gratitude works,” he says.

“I figured,” I say.

A cloud passes over the sun. The field cools.

“Thistle,” he says, and my name in his beak is unexpectedly gentle. “Do you wish anything before I take you?”

The question nearly undoes me. A hundred wishes crowd my throat: more sun, more clover, more nights pressed soft against the others in the warren listening to their breathing. A winter survived. A spring after that. A longer, slower ending.

“Tell them I ran,” I say. “If you catch another from my warren. Tell them I made it hard.”

“I told you running wouldn’t help,” he says.

“I know,” I say. “But tell them anyway.”

He considers, then inclines his head.

“I will,” he says.

“That’s it,” I say. “That’s my wish.”

“No last request for mercy?”

“If you were going to grant mercy,” I say, “you wouldn’t need me to beg for it.”

He nods once. There’s something like respect in it, though that might just be another of my hopeful illusions.

“Look up,” he says.

I do.

The sky is vast, a blue that goes on longer than any rabbit’s life. A lark is a distant flicker. A cloud edges past the sun, its rim bright as bone.

“It is not so bad,” he says. “As ceilings go.”

“I always liked tunnels more,” I say. “But this is nice.”

“You are ready?” he asks.

“No,” I say. “But I don’t think that matters.”

He pauses. For the first time, something like reluctance brushes across his features.

“Nor did I,” he says quietly. “When the first life I ever took kicked in my grip and stared at me as if I’d invented endings.”

“Well,” I say, and there’s a strange calm rising through the fear, a clear, narrow path of acceptance. “We both know better now.”

“Yes,” Corren says.

He moves.

It’s fast, clean. A rush of feathers, a sharp dark, the world folding.

His talons close, and for a heartbeat he is weight and warmth and the scent of sky. I feel the lift begin, the earth shrugging away beneath us.

“Thistle,” he says once, softly, like a promise.

I think of the warren, of telling stories about monsters above. I think of how wrong we were, and how right.

“I hope your chicks live,” I try to say, but I’m not sure if the words escape.

Above us, the sky waits, vast and indifferent, as a bird of prey carries a small animal upward, both of us exactly what we were made to be.

samples.prompt: You are not the hero, your job is to do the bad things in the shadows to help them succeed.
samples.output:
The first thing you learn in my line of work is that stories lie.

The bards and the scribes, they crave clean lines: light over here, darkness over there, a hero with a shining blade, a villain twisting his mustache in the gloom. People like that. It helps them sleep.

Me, I’m the reason anyone sleeps at all.

I work for the hero.

Not with. Not beside. For.

That distinction matters, because my job is to do what cannot exist in their story. The things that stain, that cling, that don’t scrub off with a tragic speech and a tearful apology. I stand five paces back and three strides to the left of greatness, and I make sure greatness happens on schedule.

You know how the tale goes: the hero arrives at the fortress just as the moon passes behind the clouds. The guards are oddly sparse; the gate is strangely unlatched; the villain’s lieutenant is just a little too drunk. The hero takes it as providence or destiny.

It’s not destiny.

It’s me.

The guard rotations that were quietly altered when I found the captain’s gambling debts and bought them up. The gate mechanism that “just happened” to fail because I paid a blacksmith double to use an inferior pin and keep his mouth shut forever. The lieutenant whose wine was watered down and replaced with stronger spirits in exact measures so he’d be at precisely the right stage of stupid at precisely the right hour. None of that is divine favor. It’s ledger work. It’s leverage. It’s breaking three fingers and leaving one intact so the man can still sign the confession I wrote for him.

The hero never asks why everything lines up. They call it faith. I call it logistics.

I’m not complaining. I chose this.

The world doesn’t permit heroes without monsters backing them. The trick is to pick your monster carefully.

I met mine—a golden-haired, clear-eyed prodigy with a sword that hummed when liars spoke—when he was still just a loud, angry boy standing on a box in the market, shouting about justice.

“Careful,” I told him, taking the apple he’d just dropped. “Justice gets people killed.”

He squinted at me, like I was the problem. “Injustice gets more.”

That was the moment I knew: left alone, he’d die young, all ideals and no instincts. And the world would keep rotting. He needed a shadow. So I stepped into one and stayed there.

My work falls into three categories.

First: prevention.

The tyrant’s informant who was getting too close to our sympathizers? His body washed up two towns downstream, throat cut in a way that suggested a jealous lover, not a political threat. I made sure his ledgers burned, his coded messages dissolved in lye. The hero never knew how close his mother came to being named an enemy of the state. He just knew that the tyrant’s spy network “showed cracks.” A sign, he decided, that their cause was blessed.

Second: correction.

Heroes make promises. In desperate villages, under gallows trees, to sobbing mothers. “I’ll come back with your sons.” “I’ll make sure he pays for what he did to you.” “I’ll protect this town.”

Half of those promises are impossible.

It’s my job to rearrange reality until they’re not.

The corrupt magistrate who humiliated a widow in open court? The hero promised her justice. The law offered none. So I followed the magistrate home over a week, mapped his patterns, found his secret visits to a brothel with a basement. During one of those visits, the basement door “jammed.” The candles “fell.” Flames climbed old wood like eager fingers. His body was found clutching the door, fingernails worn to pulp. Tragic accident, everyone said.

The widow heard. Word spreads. She believed the hero had made good on his promise, and she was right, in a way. The hero slept well that night. I did not.

But I can live without sleep. I cannot live in a world where men like that grin from the bench.

Third: containment.

Do you think the enemy doesn’t try to break the hero? They send temptations: gold, glimmering; secrets, whispered; prisoners, chained and sobbing, used as bargaining chips. They set up situations with no clean answers, blades that cut both ways.

My job is to make sure the blade always swings my way.

An envoy from the enemy once arrived under flag of truce, carrying a chest and a list of names, and a delicate little ultimatum: Turn back, or every name burns. Schools. Temples. Villages that had sheltered us.

I watched the hero read. I watched his jaw clench.

“We can’t let them suffer,” he said. “I’ll… I’ll go. Alone. Maybe I can parley.”

If he went, they’d kill him. If he didn’t, they’d slaughter innocents to break him later.

That’s a story you tell in ballads: the impossible choice, the noble sacrifice.

Here’s what actually happened.

The envoy didn’t leave camp.

He was found in the morning, throat torn out, horse gone, tracks scattered. Bandits, we said. Or wolves. Or fate. The chest and the list of names disappeared into my keeping. That night, enemy scouts we’d spotted circling the listed villages died with black fletching in their throats. The villages burned in no one’s song.

The hero called it a miracle when the threat never materialized. “Maybe they never meant it,” he said, hopeful.

He didn’t have to know I’d turned the dilemma into a corpse in a ditch. His conscience is a weapon; mine is armor. His must remain uncracked.

Sometimes people ask, the few who know what I am: why you? Why choose to be the stain?

I don’t bother saying that someone has to. That the work is there, whether I do it and aim it at something better, or leave it to men who enjoy cruelty for its own sake. All of that is true, but it sounds like justification.

This is the real answer: I am good at it.

I see angles. Pressure points. How one missing ledger can topple a baron, how one whispered rumor can redirect a mob, how one life ending at the right moment can save a hundred others who will never know they almost died. It’s math, of a sort. Grim arithmetic.

The hero is good at making people believe in tomorrow. I am good at making sure tomorrow isn’t worse.

Not everyone I hurt deserves it. Let’s not pretend. There’s the innkeeper who saw too much and wouldn’t take my gold to forget; the stableboy who tried to sell our location to the wrong men; the courier whose fear made his tongue slippery. I try to choose the lesser evils. Sometimes there isn’t one. When a secret must not leave the circle, I decide how wide the circle is.

I remember their faces. That’s the only rule I gave myself at the start: no forgetting. No letting it turn into numbers. I carry them like weights hung from a chain around my ribs. Some nights I think I will drown in them. Some mornings I wake and realize I haven’t thought about the magistrate in weeks, and that scares me more.

The hero suspects, in the way that people suspect the existence of rats: if there’s no grain missing, if the walls don’t rustle, if the streets are too clean, someone is doing work they’d rather not see.

Once, after a battle we won too neatly, he looked at me for a long time.

“I never asked,” he said.

“I know,” I replied.

“It’s easier if I don’t.”

“Yes.”

“Am I a coward for that?”

“No,” I said. “You’re the reason I bother.”

He nodded, slowly, and never brought it up again. That’s our covenant: he shines, I crawl; he inspires, I ensure. He carries the hopes of thousands; I carry the blame they’ll never know they owe someone.

One day, if we win—and we might, because I am relentless and he is impossible—we will build a quieter world. When that day comes, there will be no more need for what I do. That’s the theory.

In practice, there is always need. Peace just drives brutality indoors, wraps it in law and seal and harmless words. Someone will still be required to break rules that are too rigid, to stop evils sheltered by the very systems we fought so hard to create.

If I am very fortunate, that someone won’t be him.

I don’t want the hero to become me. The story needs one of us to stay clean, to prove that all this filth is in service of something that isn’t filth. If the day ever comes when he looks at a kneeling man and thinks of how efficiently a knife fits under the jaw, we’ve lost more than any war can tally.

So I will be the one who does the bad things in the shadows.

I will be the rumor, the harsh necessity, the ugly footnote omitted from the epic.

I’ll make sure gates are left unlatched and tyrants fall down long flights of stairs, that innocent promises aren’t broken even if it means my hands are. I’ll keep the story simple for them:

The hero came. The hero fought. The hero won.

Leave the rest to me.

samples.prompt: Retell the Book of Exodus using comic book superheros.
samples.output:
In the beginning, there was only the Company.

TitanTech sprawled over the world like a steel-and-glass pharaoh, its logo etched into every device, every drone, every screen. The Board sat unseen in a tower above the clouds while workers at ground level hunched over assembly lines and code farms, building wonders they’d never own. Security drones watched. Corporate enforcers patrolled. No unions. No questions. No escape.

Among the countless “associates” was a man named Moses Grant, badge #EX-0213. He was not from the inner circles of TitanTech. He had been adopted young by Miriam and Aaron Grant, low-level employees in a forgotten satellite facility. But fate, glitches, and an affirmative action initiative gone wrong once lifted him into the junior executive track. For a moment, he tasted the polished chrome of privilege. He saw the Boardroom. He saw the fear. He saw a stray spreadsheet: “Population Control Directive – Enhanced Enforcement for Unregistered Metas.”

He saw the order to capture or eliminate any child showing anomalous abilities in “affiliated communities.”

One line item had his district’s code.

The illusion shattered.

Moses bolted from the executive program, leaked what he could to underground forums, then vanished into the Neon Wastes beyond TitanTech’s jurisdiction. Headlines spun him as a traitor, a terrorist, a superhuman sympathizer. Out there in the toxic dusk, chased by drones, he nearly died.

That was when the Burning Server spoke.

It was an old, abandoned relay tower, miraculously powered, its cables glowing with phantom fire instead of electricity. It pulsed strange symbols into his retinal implants, rewriting permissions, rewriting him.

“Moses,” the voice said, layered with a thousand encrypted frequencies. “I am I AM— the Source. Not TitanTech. Not the Board. I am the code beneath all code. And I have seen my people enslaved.”

He tried to disconnect. He couldn’t.

“Send someone else,” he whispered, eyes blazing gold with data. “I’m just a guy who ran.”

“I have sent you,” the Source replied. “And you will not go alone.”

In the shadows of a ruined subway station, Moses met her: Miriam “Echo” Grant. His sister, grown into a full-fledged metahuman, able to manipulate sound and vibration— turn whispers into earthquakes, silence into sonic spears. Beside her stood Aaron “Spark” Grant, whose nervous system ran on raw electricity. They had been leading a small, secret network of metas and normies alike: the Children of Exodus.

“You’re late,” Echo said. “The Source told us you’d come.”

Spark smirked, fingers crackling blue. “What’s the plan, prophet?”

“The plan,” Moses said, feeling the Source flicker through his mind, “is to march into TitanTech HQ and tell the CEO to let everyone go.”

They stared.

“You got upgraded out there, huh?”

“Turns out the universe runs on better software than TitanTech’s.”

They went anyway.

TitanTech Tower was a black monolith stabbing the clouds. Inside, CEO Pharaoh Nox stood wrapped in nanofiber armor that shimmered like oil slicks, his scalp crowned with a platinum circlet that doubled as a neural control rig. Nox didn’t age; TitanTech’s life-extension protocols saw to that. His eyes were augmented, irisless and gleaming.

Moses and his siblings walked into Nox’s throne-boardroom under escort, hands raised but unconcerned. Security lined the walls, meta-suppressants primed.

Moses spoke, voice amplified by the Source.

“TitanTech will release its workers, annul its meta-capture directives, and remove its control implants. Effective now.”

The Board snickered. Nox did not. He looked Moses up and down.

“You were a promising candidate once,” Nox said. “You would trade the power of TitanTech for street filth and lab accidents that think they’re ‘heroes’?”

Moses’s eyes flashed. “These people aren’t your hardware.”

Nox smiled slowly. “I don’t negotiate with defective code.”

He flicked his fingers. Meta-suppressant fields roared to life. Echo stumbled; Spark’s fingers fizzled. Moses felt pressure slam into his nervous system— and then shatter.

The Source burned brighter.

“As proof,” Moses said, “we’ll show you your code is not the highest.”

He raised his hand. The holo-walls went black. Every screen in the building bled static, then rearranged into a single symbol: an all-seeing eye, fracturing.

“Cute,” Nox said. “A hack.”

“More,” the Source whispered.

So came the Plagues.

First Plague: TitanTech’s water systems, from hydration pods to eco-fountains, turned viscous and red, polymerized by an elegant bit of reprogrammed nanotech. Drinkable reserves became undrinkable sludge. Faucets spat scarlet gel. The media called it “The Blood Bug.” Nox called it a nuisance.

Second Plague: The Frogs. Bio-grown cleaning drones, shaped like sleek amphibians, had their safety protocols inverted. They multiplied, swarmed, invading luxury suites and executive spas. Glass broke under their synchronized leaps. Board members shrieked, fending off chirping cleaners with designer shoes.

Third: Glitch-Flies. TitanTech’s micro-surveillance bots went haywire, darkening the skies with pixelated metal wings, streaming unauthorized footage of Board meetings onto public feeds. Every secret: exposed.

Fourth: Livestock Crash. Autonomous delivery mechs and agri-drones malfunctioned, collapsing in heaps of smoking alloys. TitanTech’s food monopoly shuddered.

Fifth: Viral Boils. A nanovirus, targeted exclusively at TitanTech’s registered executive-level implants, caused painful AR hallucinations and neural spikes. Boardrooms filled with groaning elites clutching their temples while the common workers went untouched.

Each time, Moses came back to TitanTech Tower.

“Let them go.”

Each time, Nox hardened.

“My technomancers can replicate your tricks,” he snapped after the third, nodding toward his cyber-mages, code-wizards in brushed steel suits. And they could—partially. They would mimic the surface of the miracles, never touch their source. Quietly, some of them began to fear.

Sixth: Storm of Shards. The sky over TitanTech City blackened. Hail made of smartglass and metal rained down, guided to avoid the slums and strike only corporate infrastructure. Solar arrays shattered. Nox’s private garden dome crashed in a glittering storm.

Seventh: The Locusts. Swarms of recycling nanites recompiled into devouring clouds, eating through stockpiled goods, luxury towers, vault doors. They left only structures tagged as “essential residential.”

Eighth: Darkness. An engineered blackout. Three days, the power grid in TitanTech’s upper echelons went dead. No AR filters, no security drones, no artificial sunlight. Executives stumbled blind through their penthouses. Down below, in the forgotten stacks, LEDs glowed warm; Exodus safehouses hummed with power siphoned from the Source.

Nox was shaken. He called Moses in again, voice tight.

“Take your metas and leave. Go out into the wastes; see if the desert loves you. Just restore my systems.”

Moses lifted his hand. The Source pulsed. Lights flicked back to life. Hail ceased. Swarms disassembled.

As Moses turned to go, Nox’s neural rig flared crimson. Pride. Fear. A subroutine older than reason, written by a lifetime of unchecked power.

“No,” Nox snarled. “You go nowhere.”

He sent the Enforcer Corps. Armor gleaming, weapons humming with anti-meta rounds. In response, the Source whispered the Ninth Plague:

The Firstborn Program—TitanTech’s crown jewel AI, controlling weapons, satellites, lockdown protocols—began to unravel.

“Final warning,” Moses said, message broadcast citywide. “Mark your doors with the symbol of the Source. Step out of TitanTech’s contracts. Stand aside. What comes next is not for you.”

In the midnight hour, a silent wave of code tore through TitanTech’s networks. Systems bearing the seal of Nox’s personal authorization—his “firstborn”—crashed. Defense grids died. Personal vaults erased. The Enforcer Corps’ suits powered down mid-stride. Nox’s private fortress AI went still, screens flatlining.

For the first time, TitanTech Tower went quiet.

“Get out,” Nox hissed, trembling before Moses’s image on a flickering holoscreen. “All of you. Take your metas. Take your dissidents. Just go.”

So they went.

A torrent of workers, outcasts, failed experiments, and frontline metas poured from the industrial districts and data mines. Echo boomed directions with a voice that shook billboards from buildings. Spark strobed electricity into makeshift shields. Moses guided them, the Source ghosting routes across his vision.

But as the Exodus approached the city’s boundary—the Colossus Gate, a monumental shield-wall humming with lethal energy—Nox’s pride rebooted. He summoned the last of his functioning hardware: Titan-class mechs, crawling like steel kaiju, and a swarm of jury-rigged drones.

“Bring them back,” Nox whispered, eyes feral. “Or erase them from my world.”

The refugees saw the Gate ahead and death behind.

“You led us into a trap,” someone cried.

Moses stood at the edge of the kill-line, staring up at the shimmering barrier. The Source was quiet. For a heartbeat, fear gnawed him.

“Anytime now,” Spark muttered.

Moses raised his hands.

“Part,” he said.

The Colossus Gate flickered.

The Source roared.

Circuits reversed. Polarity inverted. The shield-wall’s energy didn’t shut down; it split. Power arced aside, drawing back in two massive curtains of blue fire, leaving between them a dry, crackling corridor through reinforced alloy.

“Move!” Echo shouted, her voice carrying miles.

The Exodus charged forward between walls of captive lightning.

Nox’s mechs thundered in pursuit, pilots certain the shield would swallow the fugitives. But as the last of the Exodus crossed, Moses turned back. The Source poured through him one last time.

The energy-walls snapped shut.

Titan-class mechs vaporized in a flash of light and molten metal. Drone swarms fell like locust husks. The ground shook. The Colossus Gate burned out, a dead scar on the horizon.

On the far side, in the open wasteland under an honest sky, silence settled.

“Now what?” someone asked.

Now: the journey.

Food ran low. The desert was wide and wired with hidden TitanTech outposts. People grumbled. Some wished to go back to the devil they knew.

The Source provided, in ways that looked like miracles and clever hacks: nutrient foam extruding from atmospheric processors Moses awakened; clean water drawn from poisoned ground by Spark’s reverse-ionization; Echo’s voice mapping safe paths through minefields and corporate traps. At a scorched mountain of abandoned satellites, Moses vanished into a blinding storm of light and code, returning changed— his eyes deeper, his powers more disciplined, carrying with him a new framework.

Laws. Not software locks, but principles.

“No more pharaohs,” Moses declared to the gathered heroes and civilians. “No more Boards above the clouds. Power serves the people, or it is no power worth keeping.”

Meta and human alike listened. Some cheered. Some frowned, already nursing ambitions.

Moses looked across the crowd of would-be heroes, hackers, and former wage slaves. Exodus was not an ending; it was an origin story.

Somewhere far away, in the dark core of a backup server no one had found, Nox’s protocols twitched.

The struggle for freedom had only just begun.

But for the first time, the people were not alone. They had each other. They had power. And they had learned that no empire, no matter how armored, could stand forever against a single burning truth:

Let my people go.

samples.prompt: you've been attending a weekly apocalyptic disaster survival preparation class for years. One day you walk in and the instructor is standing next to a big red button. He smiles as he cheerfully says "let's take a hands on lesson today class!"
samples.output:
By year three, the class had settled into a rhythm so familiar that I could have survived it in my sleep.

Every Tuesday, 7:00 p.m. sharp, Suite 2B of the Community Resource Annex: fluorescent lights humming, coffee burned to tar in the corner, a whiteboard half-stained with acronyms like PACE and SHTF and COG. We sat in our usual seats. We knew our usual jokes. We rolled our eyes in our usual ways when someone asked if Costco was an adequate bug-out hub. The world outside never quite ended, so we contented ourselves with rehearsing how it might.

Our instructor, of course, was the gravity that held us there.

He insisted we call him “Mack.” It was probably not his real name. Mack wore the same reinforced cargo pants every week, the same faded black polo with a discreet embroidered compass on the chest. He had the compact, coiled energy of someone who had long ago chosen a hill to die on and was patiently waiting for the paperwork. He loved laminated handouts, redundant systems, and cheerful worst-case scenarios.

“If there’s one thing you’ll remember when it all goes sideways,” he’d say, “it’s that you had time. Everyone gets more warning than they think. What you do with it is what matters.”

We learned to purify water six different ways. We rotated canned goods. We practiced fire drills, trauma drills, OPSEC protocols, and improvised sanitation. We cataloged skills: who could sew, who could code, who could splint a fractured wrist with two paint stirrers and a necktie. Once, he had us spend twenty minutes in absolute silence while the lights were off, just to “get acquainted with how loud your brain gets when the power goes.”

We scoffed, then obeyed, then came back next week.

On that particular Tuesday, traffic was light and the sky was offensively normal: pastel sunset bleeding over the strip mall’s cracked parking lot. I parked in my usual spot. Passed the usual door notice (“Apocalyptic Skills Workshop – Suite 2B”) printed in Comic Sans, because irony had a sense of humor.

I walked in three minutes early, expecting the familiar shuffle of backpacks and half-hearted chatter.

Instead, I saw the button.

It sat on a steel pedestal where the folding table usually held the sad coffee urn and off-brand powdered creamer. The button was the cartoon of a red button: glossy, fist-sized, encircled by a yellow-and-black hazard stripe. An LED panel above it blinked a calm, green “STANDBY.”

Next to it stood Mack, hands folded behind his back, grinning.

“Well, look at you, punctual,” he said. “Grab a seat. Today’s a special day.”

That sentence landed with a small, specific weight. I hesitated for half a beat, then slid into my usual chair in the second row. Around me, the others filtered in: Kara with her color-coded binder, Dan in camo shorts, Lydia in her emergency-room scrubs, Miguel still wearing his delivery uniform. These were my disaster people. We exchanged nods that said, Do you see this? without saying it.

When the clock clicked to 7:00, the door swung shut with a decisive snick I’d never heard before.

Not the easy clack of a cheap office door. A mechanical slide-and-lock.

Mack clapped his hands once, bright and sharp.

“Evening, class! Attendance is excellent. Hydration looks adequate. Situational awareness…” He tilted his head, eyes sweeping over us. “Marginal.”

Our nervous laughter came on cue.

He gestured grandly at the pedestal. “As you can see, we have a little visual aid today.”

Kara raised her hand, voice small. “What… is that?”

“This,” he said, patting the metal, “is our hands-on lesson. We’ve spent years talking about protocols, decision trees, supply chains, civilizational fragility. We’ve done simulations. Tabletop scenarios. But there’s always been a layer of… abstraction. You leaves these four walls, you get in your cars, and the urgency dilutes.”

He stepped around the pedestal, fingers resting lightly beside the button. He was still smiling. That was the detail that wouldn’t sit right. The smile was too bright, too pleased, like someone about to unveil a cake.

“So today,” he went on, “we’re going to close that gap.”

Miguel chuckled. “Is it, like, connected to the lights or something?”

“Something,” Mack said.

He tapped a remote. The blinds whirred down over the windows. The fluorescent lights dimmed. A projector hummed to life. On the whiteboard, instead of slides, a real-time map appeared. Air traffic. Power grids. Weather patterns. A digital heartbeat of a continent.

“Whoa,” Dan said.

“This is a live operational overview,” Mack said. “I’ve pared it down to essentials. Power distribution. Major communication nodes. Transportation corridors. You’ve all seen versions of this in my lectures. Tonight, we’re going to see your training in practice.”

He clicked another button. At the bottom corner of the projection, text appeared:

SIMULATION: 00:02:00

“Two minutes,” he said. “Questions?”

I raised my hand, throat suddenly dry. “Simulation of what, exactly?”

“Triggering a cascading systemic failure,” he said. “Grid overload. Data corruption. Targeted infrastructure disruption. You know, the usual suspects. You’ve all been very diligent. You have go-bags. Rally points. Redundancies. Contingencies. You’re as ready as any civilians are going to be.”

He placed his palm flat on the table next to the button.

“Tonight, one of you will start the collapse.”

The silence was full-bodied. It rose up, got into my ears, into my teeth.

Lydia said, cautiously, “You mean, we decide to start the drill? Like, we pick when?”

“No,” he said. “I mean one of you will press this button and initiate the scenario.” He lifted a hand before anyone could speak. “Relax. It’s contained. Isolated. We’re not barbarians.”

The map pulsed gently, as if listening.

Miguel tried to laugh it off. “So the first hands-on is who’s brave enough to hit the big red button?”

“Yes,” Mack said. “Except bravery is the wrong metric. This is not about courage; it’s about comprehension. You’ve spent years internalizing the idea that collapse is inevitable. That all systems fail. That preparedness is morality. But there’s a logical extension, isn’t there? If collapse is inevitable and delay increases casualties, what’s the moral position?”

He let the question hang, casual as a weather report.

Kara whispered, “That’s messed up.”

“Is it?” Mack asked gently. “You practice evacuating a burning building. You don’t start the fire, fair. But systems-level? You’ve all sat here nodding while I showed you ticking clocks. Missing redundancies. Single points of failure. You’ve come to feel special for seeing the cracks. The chosen few who will make it through. Tonight is an opportunity to interrogate that comfort.”

I heard my pulse in my ears. “Mack, is this a joke?”

He looked at me like I’d disappointed him, just a little. “I am many things,” he said. “A bore. A broken record. A man who owns too many water filters. But I am not a prankster.”

The countdown read 00:01:02.

He moved closer to the first row. “Here’s the structure. When the timer expires, I will randomly select one of you. That person will come up, place their hand on the button. I will ask a simple question: ‘Do you believe the collapse is inevitable in your lifetime?’ If they say no, we walk away. Lesson over. If they say yes, they press it. And we begin the simulation.”

“Simulation,” Dan repeated. “You keep saying that like we’re supposed to believe you.”

“You should believe me,” Mack said. “You’ve trusted me to terrify you accurately for years.”

On the screen, the map zoomed in and out, data flickering. Little icons glowed where major substations lived, where undersea cables touched land. Everything looked fragile once you knew what to look for.

“What happens… if they press it?” Lydia asked.

“You enact the protocol,” Mack said simply. “You go home if you can. You make calls if networks hold. You meet at your rally points if they don’t. You protect, you adapt, you share, you triage. The things you’ve planned instead of living unexamined lives.”

00:00:23.

My chair suddenly felt wrong beneath me, too flimsy.

“This is coercion,” Kara said, voice cracking.

“Oh no,” Mack said. “No one is forced. You all have agency. You can lie when I ask. You can refuse to participate. You can tackle me, I suppose.” He spread his arms. “Though that would be an interesting ethical footnote, wouldn’t it? Violence to preserve the continuation of business as usual.”

00:00:10.

The room shrank around the pedestal, around that stupid gleaming red dome.

“We should leave,” Miguel said, standing. The door handle clanked uselessly. He pulled harder. Nothing.

“Safety protocol,” Mack said mildly. “No interruptions during the exercise.”

The countdown ticked:

3
2
1

The clock went dark. The room exhaled with it.

Mack reached into his pocket, pulled out a small metal tin, and shook a mint into his hand. He crunched it between his teeth.

“Random selection,” he said conversationally. He pointed the remote at the projector. Our names, every one of us, appeared in a column. The cursor blinked at the top, then scrolled down in a blur, up again, jittering with coded whimsy before finally stuttering to a halt.

It landed on my name.

My stomach dropped through the cheap carpet, through the foundation, into the cooling mantle of the earth.

“Ah,” he said, almost warmly. “Good. You take notes. Come on up.”

Everyone turned to look at me as if I’d been called on for the pop quiz we all knew was coming but hoped wouldn’t. Their faces were pale, expectant, guilty, relieved it wasn’t them.

My legs carried me forward without my consent. Each step scraped.

Up close, the button was even more absurd. Some part of me still expected a confetti cannon, an air horn. April Fool’s in November.

I stopped an arm’s length away.

“Mack,” I said quietly, “tell me this is a drill.”

“It’s a hands-on lesson,” he said. “Same as advertised.”

His eyes were clear. No wildness, no hint of malicious glee. Just calm conviction, like when he taught us how long tap water would remain potable.

He nodded at the button. “Hand on it, please.”

I set my palm on the cool red curve. It had a little give to it, like an unripe tomato.

He raised his voice, addressing the class. “Remember, consent is the core of any moral framework. So we’ll ask the question.”

Then, back to me:

“Do you believe the collapse is inevitable in your lifetime?”

The answers crowded my throat. The ones I’d been nodding along with for years. The floods. The fires. The brittle supply chains. The graphs he’d shown us until they stopped being shocking and started being background radiation.

“Yes,” I almost said.

And heard, behind it, the tidy satisfaction of being proven right.

I swallowed it.

“I believe,” I said slowly, “that preparing for collapse is necessary. I do not believe making it happen is our job.”

He watched me, weighing each word.

“That wasn’t the question,” he said.

“I’m not pressing it,” I said.

Silence folded over us. My hand stayed on the button. Every muscle in my arm shook.

Mack’s smile thinned. For the first time that night, he looked… tired.

“You’d rather wait,” he said. “Let it grind down the long way. More suffering, more noise, more plausible deniability.”

“I’d rather fix things,” I snapped, surprising myself. “Or fail trying. But I am not signing my name on it.”

Something like disappointment flickered across his face. Then—unexpectedly—satisfaction.

He clicked the remote.

The map projection dissolved. The blinds crept back up. The locks on the door thunked open.

The button under my palm went dead, just a plastic toy.

“Lesson concluded,” Mack announced.

The room erupted. Shouts. Swears. Demands. Lydia called him insane. Miguel threatened to report him. Kara was crying, binder clutched to her chest like a shield.

“You lied to us,” she said.

“No,” he answered. “I placed you in proximity to what you talk about. You did the rest.”

He looked at me, really looked.

“People come to these classes for comfort,” he said, softer. “The comfort of believing they’re smarter than the herd. The comfort of inevitability. It’s a story that absolves. Today’s exercise was to show you that crossing from prediction to initiation is a choice. One you’re capable of not making.”

He picked up the button, light as a paperweight now, and slipped it into a case.

“Next week,” he said, as if nothing extraordinary had happened, “we’ll cover rainwater harvesting systems in urban environments.”

Nobody moved.

He shouldered his bag and walked toward the door, pausing beside me.

“You did well,” he murmured. “The world ends often enough on its own.”

The door closed behind him, leaving us in the bright, ordinary room, blinking at one another, suddenly aware that all our practiced endings had never really accounted for our own fingers hovering above the start.

samples.prompt: As I was nearing the end, I had no recollection as to how I got started in the first place.
samples.output:
As I was nearing the end, I had no recollection as to how I got started in the first place.

It should have bothered me more than it did.

The idea of an origin, a cause, an initial decision—these things used to matter. They were the ways I defended myself against the accusation that my life was just drifting. I could say: no, look, here is the first domino, and here is the path that followed. But by the time I found myself in that room—white walls, no windows, a low hum I couldn't locate—I had nothing. Just a dull awareness that I had been at this for a very long time and that I was almost, finally, done.

A man sat across from me. He was familiar the way a dream is familiar; I recognized his posture, the line of his jaw, but his face shifted whenever I tried to hold it still.

"Do you know why you're here?" he asked.

I almost laughed. The standard question, and I had the incorrect answer.

"I'm finishing something," I said.

He tilted his head. "What are you finishing?"

I opened my mouth and found nothing. Not even air, for a moment. An animal tightness gripped my throat. I looked down at my hands: callused, faint ink stains on the sides of my fingers, a pale ring of skin where a band had once sat. There were scars, too, a narrow ladder on my forearm, a crescent at the base of my thumb. I recognized them, yet I could not say where they came from.

"I was working," I tried. "On… a project."

"Which project?"

"The project," I said, and that felt right, like a puzzle piece dropping into place. "The one that runs through everything."

He watched me as if my answer confirmed something. "Go on."

I closed my eyes and let the hum in the room carry me backward. It wasn't memory so much as inference: I followed the evidence of the person I appeared to be. Ink stains suggested pages. Scars suggested accidents. The pale ring finger suggested a missing presence, which suggested grief, which suggested a search. It all pointed toward a narrative I must have been telling myself for years.

"I've been trying to understand," I said slowly. "To map it all. To get it down right before—"

Before what? Before this.

"You've been writing the Record," he said, as if filling in the blank for me. "Cataloging your life."

"My life," I repeated. "Yes."

That sounded grandiose, but I felt the weight of it. Endless pages, cramped handwriting that loosened over time, margins filled with corrections. I could almost see stacks of notebooks, dog-eared and swollen with use. I saw myself hunched over a desk, some indistinct light at my back, pursuing a feeling that if I could just get it all organized—if I could just trace the line from the first decision to the last consequence—then something would click into place and the ache under my ribs would finally dissolve.

"But I don't remember starting," I said. "I only remember continuing."

"What do you remember?" he asked.

"Middle," I said. The word came without thinking. "I remember the middle."

I remembered being already in motion: standing in a small kitchen late at night, reading pages aloud as if testing whether the sentences could hold the weight I was putting on them. I remembered arguments—sharp, bright, unnecessary—in another room, another life, about what it meant to spend so much time circling myself. I remembered promising that I was doing this for us. That if I could understand the pattern, I could stop repeating the same mistakes.

"Did you?" the man asked, almost gently. "Stop repeating them?"

I considered lying, but there was no point now.

"No," I said. "I just documented them more thoroughly."

He smiled. It was not unkind.

"It is common," he said. "To mistake annotation for change."

"Who are you?" I asked.

"For your purposes," he said, "I'm an index."

The hum shifted, or I imagined it did, resolving into the flutter of turning pages. I looked past him and saw, or thought I saw, rows of shelves receding into the white, filled with volumes that had no markings on their spines.

"Is this all mine?" I asked.

"Some of it," he answered. "Enough."

I stood, unsteady, drawn to the nearest shelf. My hand closed on a book at random. It had no title, just a worn cover soft beneath my fingers. When I opened it, I saw my handwriting. The first sentence: At some point I decided that nothing in my life would go unexamined, so that I might never again be ambushed by myself.

"At some point," I whispered. Not a date. Not a scene. Just a vague pivot, like a curtain drawn between Before and After.

"You never wrote down the beginning," the man said. "You thought you remembered it clearly enough. You assumed you could always go back."

I turned pages. There were fragments, entries titled as if they were episodes of a show: The Night I Didn't Answer the Phone, The Lunch I Pretended Not to Mind, The Time I Told Myself It Wasn't My Fault. Oddly precise, obsessive. But no origin story. No first spark that turned a moment of pain or confusion into a lifelong project of recording.

"So I lost it," I said.

"It decayed, as unvisited things do."

I laughed, short and harsh. "All this effort to hold on, and I let the beginning rot."

"You held on to the work," he said. "Not the reason."

"Is there a difference?"

"There is all the difference."

His answer irritated me more than it probably should have so late in the process.

"Does it matter?" I demanded. "I'm at the end now. I did what I did. I filled the pages. Does it change anything if I can't recall what pushed me to pick up the pen in the first place?"

He regarded me for a long moment.

"To you," he said finally, "it matters."

I wanted to say it didn't. I wanted to claim a lofty detachment, to argue that the story I constructed along the way was all that counted, that the origin was a triviality, a forgotten prologue. But beneath the layers of practiced self-analysis, another voice—the one I had been writing toward without admitting it—whispered that he was right.

The first wound shapes the scar, even if you forget the cut.

"Can I read it?" I asked. "The beginning. Wherever it is."

He gestured toward the shelves. "If you can find it."

I moved along the aisle, pulling books at random. Each opened to some moment I recognized or almost-recognized: the angle of a hospital room at dawn, the smell of burned coffee in an apartment I no longer could locate on a map, the scratch of a stranger's pen signing a form that determined the next five years of my life. But every volume started in media res.

The effect was disorienting, like the world kept popping into existence mid-breath.

"It isn't here," I said.

"You're looking for a single page," he said. "It wasn't one."

"Then what was it?"

He folded his hands. "A series of small refusals."

I stared at him, waiting.

"You refused," he continued, "to let certain things pass unmarked. The first time you woke from a nightmare and wrote down every detail instead of pushing it away. The first time you replayed a conversation until the words felt like code. The first time you saw someone you loved walking away and told yourself that if you'd analyzed it better, you could have stopped it."

I saw, suddenly, a cheap lined notebook on a bedside table. Blue ink bleeding through thin paper. The word Remember underlined three times. No context. No explanation. Just a command issued from the wounded to the future.

"You were very young," he said. "You thought that attention was the same as control."

"And it wasn't."

"It kept you company," he said. "It did not save you, but it gave you a task. It made sense of random pain by suggesting it was data."

"I turned my life into a case study," I murmured.

"You turned yourself into both subject and researcher."

"And now?"

"Now the study concludes."

I looked down at the book still open in my hands. The later entries had grown sparse. Days condensed into lines, lines into half-phrases. Tried again. Didn't work. Called. No answer. Let it go this time (did I?). There were more questions than observations. The ink was shakier.

"I thought," I said, "that at the end I would have a thesis."

"You do," he said. "It just isn't the one you expected."

"What is it?"

He rose, and for the first time I noticed how tired he looked, as if he had been sitting across from people like me for longer than anyone could measure.

"You devoted yourself to remembering so that you wouldn't feel erased," he said. "But in doing so, you let the present blur into a series of footnotes. You misplaced the simplicity of the first decision. Nearing the end, all you could see was the machinery you built to protect yourself, not the person you were before it."

"That's not a thesis," I said. "That's an indictment."

He shook his head. "It's an observation. The thesis is yours to write."

"What if I don't have time?" I asked.

"Then be brief."

I thought of all the pages, the circling, the diagrams of cause and effect. I thought of the early insistence—Remember—and the later fatigue. I thought of the origin I had reconstructed from absence: a young version of me, believing that if nothing slipped past me, nothing would be lost.

I set the book back on the shelf. My hands didn't shake anymore.

"All right," I said. "Here it is."

I didn't write it down; there was no need.

I began because I was afraid.

I continued because I was afraid to stop.

I am ending because, at last, I'm more curious than afraid.

The man—index, guide, whatever he was—studied me. The hum in the room softened, or my hearing dimmed.

"Acceptable," he said. "Concise."

"Do I get the beginning back now?" I asked.

"You never truly lost it," he said. "You only stopped recognizing it for what it was."

The shelves, the books, the room—all of it started to fade, not dramatically, but like fog when the sun finally commits. For a moment, I panicked, reflexively reaching for something to hold onto, some detail to capture, to archive.

Then I stopped.

Some things, I realized, don't need to be written to be real.

As I was nearing the end, I had no recollection as to how I got started in the first place.

But I had, at least, stopped mistaking my notes for my life. And that, however late, was a better ending than I had expected.

samples.prompt: A Goth in ancient Bulgaria on the eve of battle and another Goth in modern day getting ready to play Vampire: The Masquerade, suddenly and inexplicably exchange places in history.
samples.output:
On the eve of battle, the sky above the Danube was the color of old iron. Thorismund pulled the leather strap tight on his bracer and spat in the dust. Around him the camp murmured: men sharpening sax blades on river stones, horses snorting, a low thrum of voices in Gothic, Latin, and crude Greek. Fires smoked, carrying the stink of mutton and sweat.

He told himself he was ready.

The Romans would cross at dawn, they said. Or they would creep in the dark. Or they would not come at all, playing for time while their emperor begged new barbarian allies from the east. Everyone had a story; none of the stories changed the fact that Thorismund’s spear was old, his shield was cracked, and his father’s ghost had not visited him in a dream.

He held his shield up, squinting at its face. The paint was mostly gone, only a pale, fang-like crescent remaining. It had once been a wolf’s head. “Good enough,” he muttered.

A gust of wind picked up, harsh and cold. For a moment the air seemed to hum in his ears, like a thousand distant voices whispering in a foreign tongue. The torch beside him flared blue. The smell of the river vanished, replaced by something burnt and chemical, thick and sweet.

He blinked.

The camp was gone.

He stood instead in a small, square room with white walls and no smoke hole, lit as bright as midday by a box on the ceiling that hummed. The earth underfoot had become something smooth and hard, gray like stone but too perfect, as if poured flat by a god with no patience for gravel. Fabrics in violent colors spilled over a bed. On a table lay a stack of thin, colorful slabs, one showing a pale-faced woman with eyes like a cat, framed by words in Latin letters he could puzzle out but not believe.

VAMPIRE: THE MASQUERADE.

Thorismund’s spear clattered from his hand.

The only other soul in the room was himself.

Not himself.

The other man had Thorismund’s face, though cleaner, without the weathering of rain and wind, and his hair was black, shorn on the sides, long on top and slicked back. He wore strange black garments that clung to his body without the lacing of leather or the hang of wool. He stared at Thorismund with the same stunned horror.

“What the actual—” the stranger began, and then he vanished.

No, not vanished. But in that instant, a pressure popped in Thorismund’s ears, the air twisted, his stomach lurched, and the world snapped back into place with a slap of cold night over the Danube.

Adrian choked on woodsmoke.

One second he was in his bedroom in Plovdiv, eyeliner uneven, clipping on his ankh necklace, half-laughing about how late he already was for session. The next second he was standing in mud in the middle of a medieval LARP that smelled way too real.

He coughed, eyes watering. The darkness around him was angry firelight and looming shapes. Men in leather and mail turned to stare. Someone shouted something sharp and harsh that sounded like the reconstructed Gothic podcasts he listened to while coding.

Adrian recognized one word: “Thorismund?”

Gothic. They’re speaking Gothic. All of them.

He had read The Gothic War. He’d played through three chronicle arcs about Roman frontiers. He wore black boots with eight metal buckles and had opinions on 80s post-punk. The word “Goth” for him meant Siouxsie Sioux and Bauhaus and the comfort of dim clubs, not… these men, actual Goths, historical Goths, staring at him as if he’d grown a second head.

A big, bearded warrior clapped him on the back so hard he stumbled. “Brother, you look pale as death. Finally listening to the augurs, eh?” He spoke in Gothic, clear, fast. It landed in Adrian’s ears with the uncanny half-comprehension of language he’d only ever read.

Adrian swallowed. “I…” Somehow, his tongue found the shapes. “I am… unwell.”

The man laughed. “Afraid of the Romans? They bleed like us. Prayer, wine, and a sharp spear, that’s all we need.”

Behind him, the river gleamed, wide and black. The banners snapped in the wind—wolves, ravens, simple crosses. Above, the iron sky.

Adrian’s heart hammered. This is impossible.

He looked down at himself. Not a mesh shirt and faux-leather pants. A wool tunic, worn; rough trousers; heavy boots crusted with mud. A spear in his hand, a shield on his arm. His body felt denser, stronger, cords of muscle under his skin that he definitely had not earned at the gym.

He had become someone else. Or been slotted into him.

“Thorismund,” the man said, more softly now. “Night before battle is bad for the mind. Come, sit. Share wine. Think of the gold we’ll take.”

Thorismund. Okay. Okay, think.

Adrian had always joked that if vampires were real, he’d be first in line. This was not that. This was… some glitch in history, some cosmic LARP with live steel. For a dizzy second he wondered if his gaming group had gone so extra they’d spiked his drink and airlifted him into some reenactment camp on the Danube. But the fear in his gut felt realer than any nightclub.

He forced a breath. If this was real, freaking out in English—or Bulgarian, or bad student Gothic—would get him killed faster than any Roman pilum.

He took the wineskin. It was sour and thick, but it steadied him.

Across time, in the bright room, Thorismund had discovered a mirror.

The glass showed him: same broad nose, same heavy jaw, same scar at his eyebrow. But the hair… what heathen barber had pared it so? And what were these strange black robes that clung like a serpent’s skin?

He prodded the lamp on the desk. It was cold, but its light did not falter. He slammed the door open and stepped into a narrow corridor paved in the same unnaturally smooth stone. The air smelled of cleaning herbs he did not know.

Downstairs, voices: a woman’s, then a man’s, trading words in Bulgarian.

“Adrian, are you leaving or are you brooding at your posters again?” the woman called.

Thorismund stiffened. Adrian. The name felt like something he should answer to.

He descended into a larger room where a woman stood, holding a glass cup. She was thirty, maybe, with Adrian’s eyes. A man watched a flickering box full of moving figures on the wall.

“Adrian?” the woman said. “Wow. You committed to the look.” Her gaze took in his startled stare, his too-straight posture. “You okay?”

Thorismund searched for familiar words. The language was strange but close to his own tongue in some places. He reached for what had slipped into his mind when the world changed, as if the other man’s memories had been sprinkled through his skull.

“I am… late to game,” he said, in halting Bulgarian.

She rolled her eyes. “Of course. Say hi to the guys from me.”

Outside, the world assaulted him. Stone roads with glowing lines. Wagons with no horses, roaring past. Buildings of impossible height. Lights like captured stars. People staring down at little slabs of glowing glass in their hands. Music thumping from somewhere, tinny and thin.

Thorismund’s legs wanted to buckle. He gripped the railing and somehow, impossibly, knew where he was going, as if Adrian’s habits tugged on his sinews. Left at the corner. Wait for the light. Across to the tram.

On the ride, he clung to the rail and watched the city flash by. In the reflections on the tram window he saw his own shadowed eyes and, layered faintly over them, the pale, lined face of Adrian’s mother. He felt a pull in his chest that was not his own.

When he reached the cafe—the one Adrian loved because it pretended at being a crypt with its arched ceilings and candles in wine bottles—he saw them. The others. All in black, with silver jewelry and dyed hair, smoking, laughing. On their table lay dice, character sheets, and a thick rulebook with the same title he’d seen in the room.

“Dude,” said a tall one with blue hair. “You look intense. You bring the angst tonight or what?”

Thorismund looked at the book: Vampire: The Masquerade. The pale fiend on the cover bared its fangs. A cold amusement crept through him.

“I know something of vampires,” he said slowly, sitting. “Let us play.”

Back by the Danube, Adrian sat by the fire and listened to men speak of their families: of children left in wooden farmhouses, of brothers killed by Huns, of Roman lies. He caught names that he recognized only from scholarship: Fritigern, Valens, Hadrianople. Dates lined up in his mind and his mouth went dry.

“Oh, shit,” he whispered in English.

“What?” his companion asked.

“Nothing,” Adrian said in Gothic. The words came easier now, as if the body knew them. “Just… thinking of blood.”

He realized something with slow horror and slow wonder: he knew how tomorrow ended—for the Romans. A slaughter. An emperor dead. The Goths, for once, not crushed.

He also knew nothing of how to survive a 4th century battle.

“What if we waited?” he said suddenly, surprising himself. “What if we drew them to the marsh? Set fire in the grass? Make them choke.”

The older warrior squinted at him. “You have ideas now?”

“I have…” Adrian inhaled. “Visions.”

Superstition rustled through the camp as the idea spread: Thorismund’s dream of fire and marsh, of Roman cavalry bogged down. And why not? A small adjustment. A different slope. A trap.

Far in the future, Thorismund rolled Adrian’s dice.

He listened as they spoke of clans with dead-white faces and ancient grudges. Of eternal night, of predation cloaked under a veil called the Masquerade. Children playing at horror, he thought, yet their words touched truths his people also knew: masks worn for survival; names changed at the border; deals with powers that offered safety at a price.

The Storyteller described a prince of the city. Thorismund remembered chieftains bowing to emperors, kings bowing to no one, treaties made and broken. “And what does this prince demand?” he asked, his eyes narrow.

“Obedience,” the Storyteller said. “Secrecy. Feeding with discretion.”

Thorismund smiled, slow and sharp.

“My character refuses,” he said.

The table laughed. Of course Adrian would play edgy.

In another century, Adrian walked into the dawn as the battle smoke lifted.

The Romans had broken. The field was a tapestry of shields and corpses, tangled horses, spears snapped like twigs. He was alive. His borrowed arms were slick with blood that had not existed for him the day before.

The men shouted Thorismund’s name as if he had been clever, as if his suggestion to shift the line had mattered. Maybe it had. Maybe history was more fragile than he’d thought.

Night fell again and no lightning came to take him home.

He stared at the constellations he knew by different names.

In Plovdiv, under softer stars dimmed by city haze, Thorismund left the cafe alone.

He walked through a world that had forgotten his people, except as a borrowed adjective for a fashion of pale faces and dark clothes. He passed a shop where a song played in English about being undead, eternal. He understood almost none of the words, but the beat struck something in his breast.

On a wall someone had painted a graffiti wolf’s head in white.

He touched the fading plaster with his fingertips.

“Perhaps,” he murmured in thickened Bulgarian, “this is also a battle.”

Somewhere between them—between spear and character sheet, between real blood and imagined fangs—the universe had folded, trading one Goth for another.

Neither screamed anymore.

Both, in their own centuries, straightened their shoulders, bared their teeth, and stepped forward into the dark.

samples.prompt: You are a chess grandmaster. You aren't particularly good at chess, but you can read minds, allowing you to know your opponents strategy, as well as the best way to counter it. Your next opponent does the same thing.
samples.output:
By the time I sit down at the board, the theater is already full.

They haven’t come for my chess. No one ever does. They’ve come for the story: the grandmaster who can’t calculate three moves ahead without blundering a rook, the fraud with a rating inflated beyond his natural talent by a quiet, invisible edge. They haven’t come for my opponent’s chess either. They’ve come because, for the first time, my edge is gone.

He’s already seated, waiting. Viktor Petrov. To the world: enigmatic genius, undefeated this season. To me: a clean, cold mirror.

He looks up as I pull out my chair. His eyes are pale and amused.

(So this is him. He looks scared.)

I try not to flinch. I’m not scared, exactly. Not yet. But anxiety tastes like tin along the back of my teeth.

He offers his hand. I take it.

“You finally made it,” he says.

“What took you so long?” I ask.

(It’s true. Why did it take me so long to find someone like me?)

We sit. The board between us is the same wooden battlefield I’ve crossed a thousand times. The pieces are arranged in the standard opening position. They look harmless. They never are.

The arbiters fuss around with pens and clocks. Cameras blink their red eyes. The commentators in the glass booth to the side look thrilled. They think it’s a clash of titans.

“What are the odds,” Viktor murmurs, “that two anomalies end up here?”

“Not odds,” I say. “Inevitable.” And it is. If you are cursed with an advantage, destiny is just a corridor funneling you toward the one person who nullifies it.

(Very dramatic, he thinks. He really believes this.)

He picks up a pawn in his mind before he picks it up in reality.

He’s going to play 1.e4.

(I’m going to play 1.d4.) he hears.

He pauses, surprised, and for a moment, I feel the old rush. I’ve been in so many minds. They are soft, clumsy places. They leak intention. They do not expect their thoughts to have teeth.

He considers 1.d4.

(If he plays 1.d4, I’ll respond with Nf6, then c5, go into some weird Benoni structure he doesn’t know. He’s not actually good at chess.)

“What if I am?” I say before I can stop myself.

A chuckle ripples through him, but his face stays composed. He looks at the arbiter, at the camera, back at me.

“You know,” he says quietly, “we should not talk aloud.”

He puts his hand over the king’s pawn.

He thinks, sharply: 1.e4.

(I know he thinks I’ll do that. So I shouldn’t. But he knows I know—)

The move clock ticks.

For most people, opening theory is a map: memorized lines, forks of possibility. For me, it’s been a script I read from their minds. I never had to learn the moves; I just had to see the shape of their plans and walk around them. But Viktor’s thoughts are not a passive broadcast. They’re focused, directed. They push back.

He changes his mind.

1.d4.

I blink.

He smiles, just a tiny shift at the corner of his mouth.

“Your move,” he says.

He has thrown himself off his own preference to avoid what he thinks my counter will be. Which I saw. Which he saw me see. The first move has already turned into a hall of mirrors.

I move 1...Nf6, the flexible response I thought of when I believed he’d play 1.d4 for real. I do it partly out of stubbornness, partly because any deviation now is just another layer of overthinking and I can’t afford to drown in that yet.

He raises an eyebrow.

(He’s trying to pretend he’s relaxed. He’s not. He’s improvising.)

He plays 2.c4.

I answer 2...e6. Nimzo-Indian territory, more or less. Or Queen’s Indian. Something I actually studied, once, out of guilt.

He leans back, fingers steepled.

(If I play Nc3, he wants Bb4. He knows I know that. If I play Nf3, he can go b6, Ba6, equalize comfortably. But he’s weak in strategic endgames. No, he’ll steer away.)

I rub my forehead, annoyed. “You’re loud,” I mutter.

“So are you,” he replies. “I’ve never had echo before. It’s… distracting.”

He plays 3.Nf3.

We now both know, with equal clarity, that he chose the line to avoid my prep, to go somewhere “solid.” We also know that I know that. And that he knows I know that. It’s like trying to walk a straight line in a room full of mirrors, every step doubled and second-guessed.

I answer 3...b6. Queen’s Indian.

The position on the board is sane. The positions in our minds are not.

The noise builds quickly.

(He’s going to fianchetto. No, he thinks I think that, so maybe g3 is too obvious. But obvious might be good because he’ll overreact—)

(He’s going to overcomplicate. He has to; it’s his crutch. He doesn’t trust raw calculation. If I simplify, he’ll be uncomfortable.)

I don’t hear his words so much as his intentions, structured in the abstract language of plans: pressure on c5, knight maneuvers, kingside safety. Overlapping them are his meta-thoughts about what I am perceiving.

We are not thinking about good chess moves as much as we are thinking about what each other thinks about good chess moves.

He plays 4.g3. Straightforward fianchetto.

He does the obvious thing.

I hesitate.

(He’s surprised I did the obvious thing, Viktor thinks. He expected I’d dodge. He doesn’t trust simplicity. Remember that.)

I play 4...Bb7. Also obvious. Also theory. Something like relief flickers across his face and vanishes; there is comfort in conventional moves, even when your minds are locked in an arms race.

The game unfolds, and with every move, the psychic interference intensifies.

I reach for a pawn.

(If he pushes that, he hangs his queenside later. He doesn’t see it.)

I freeze. Now I see it. If I push that pawn, fifteen moves later, after natural development, my a-pawn becomes weak. Without Viktor’s silent contempt, I would never have noticed.

I change moves.

He smirks.

“You’re welcome,” he says softly, under the murmur of the crowd.

It hits me then: he’s improving my play. I’m improving his. Every calculation error, every blind spot, is instantly flagged and patched by the other’s scorn, fear, hope. We are, against our wills, collaborating on a perfect game.

(He thinks I’ll miss the exchange sac on c3 if he builds up slowly.)

I won’t, because he just told me.

(I think he’ll overlook the g-file pressure if he castles short.)

I won’t, because he can hear that I would have.

We bleed each other’s weaknesses dry. The messiness that gives human games character is stripped away. Variations unfold not as guesses but as shared inevitabilities, weeded of blunders.

By move fifteen, there are no cheap tactics left. Just a balanced, razor-edge position, quiet and deadly.

The commentators must be gushing about “deep preparation” and “profound understanding.” If only they knew.

We hit a critical moment. The center is tense. He can trade on d5 and steer toward a symmetrical structure that’s slightly better for White, or he can launch a kingside expansion that is sound only if I respond passively.

He considers 16.cxd5.

(If I take, he gets a half-open file, simple play. Dry. He thinks I’ll hate that. He’s right.)

He considers 16.f4.

(If he plays that, I can consider Nxe4 in some lines. He sees that. He also sees I see that. That line is poisoned.)

We spiral.

If he takes, I equalize. If he pushes, it’s sharp, but we instantly see each other’s refutations. Every aggressive idea is met, pre-birth, by perfect defense.

The clock ticks. For the first time, we are low on time not because the positions are complex, but because our thoughts are.

“This is stupid,” I say, not entirely under my breath.

“Agreed,” he replies.

He plays 16.cxd5. The sober choice.

I recapture 16...exd5 without drama.

The position flattens. We’ve chosen the path that is boring, equal, bloodless. Not because we wanted to, but because every other path, once shared between us, became unsound. Our joint omniscience pruned excitement.

“You know,” he thinks—so strongly I almost hear it as words—“if we both keep doing this, it can only end one way.”

“Yeah,” I think back. “A draw.”

“That’s one way.”

“And the other?”

He glances at the pieces, then at me.

“We could make a mistake.”

I almost laugh aloud. “We can’t,” I whisper. “You won’t let me. I won’t let you.”

We keep playing.

The endgame creeps closer: queens off, rooks exchanged, bishops symmetrical, pawns mirrored, kings centrally poised like old men on a walk. Every imbalance that might have grown into something deadly is identified and neutralized the moment someone dreams of exploiting it.

When he considers a minority attack, I see his plan and structure my pawns to meet it. When I toy with triangulating my king to outflank his, he adjusts without me having to prove the idea over the board. We’re editing each other’s games in real time, forcing perfection.

Move thirty. Move forty.

The audience shifts, restless. The commentators start using the phrase “high-level technical draw.”

No one says “unavoidable.”

We reach a textbook drawn rook-and-pawn ending. Opposite corners, opposition, all the diagrams from all the manuals.

He looks at me over the king he is about to move.

“This isn’t chess anymore,” he says, softly.

“No,” I say. “It’s just… confirmation.”

(He wonders if I ever won a game solely on my own.)

(He wonders if he ever did.)

He plays the final precise move that seals the draw. I respond with the only move that doesn’t lose. It’s elegant, sterile.

He offers his hand. “Draw?”

I look at the board. At the inevitable line we both see unspooling to stalemate, to mutual futility.

I hear his unspoken fear: If I agree, I admit that without the fog of ignorance, without human error, chess between us is dead. Perfect play, perfect knowledge, perfect mutual prediction—nothing left but equilibrium.

I also hear my own: Without advantage, what am I?

“Draw,” I say.

We shake. The audience applauds, a little disappointed. They wanted fireworks, a brilliancy. They don’t understand they’ve just watched something far rarer: two men with too much knowledge quietly killing the possibility of beauty.

As we stand, Viktor leans close.

“Next time,” he murmurs, “no reading. Just us.”

“You first,” I say.

He smiles, because we both know we’re lying. We can’t not hear each other. That’s the curse.

As I walk away from the board, I realize the cruelest thing about reading minds: it gave me every move but stole from me the only thing that made the game worth playing—the uncertainty, the risk, the chance to be wrong and brilliant anyway.

samples.prompt: Google starts an online dating service.
samples.output:
It was only a matter of time before Google decided it knew who you should love.

They called it GMatch: “Connection, clarified.” The launch video dropped during a dull tech conference keynote. Sundar stood in front of a gradient screen and said, with rehearsed humility, “We believe we can help people find meaningful relationships by leveraging what we do best: understanding information.”

Information. Not data. Never data.

I signed up three weeks after launch, on a Tuesday night, drunk on boxed wine and professional disappointment. I’d searched, that afternoon, for “symptoms of burnout” and “what if I never achieve anything,” and by 7 p.m. my entire Google ecosystem pulsed with quiet concern: short guided meditations on YouTube, calendar nudges to “reconnect with old friends,” and a smiling email banner inviting me to “find someone who gets you.”

And didn’t that sound nice.

GMatch auto-filled most of my profile. “We’ve pre-populated your interests based on your activity across Google products. You can edit or remove these at any time.” It was breathtakingly fast. Favorite films: the ones I’d rewatched on YouTube. Books: scraped from my search history and e-book purchases. Food: derived from Maps reviews. Politics: inferred from the articles I spent the longest hovering over. It even suggested my attachment style, which seemed rude.

“You prefer partners who are emotionally communicative but respect your autonomy,” the interface read. “(Confidence: 87%.)”

“How?” I muttered.

A tooltip popped up: “This is estimated based on your language patterns in Gmail, Docs, and Chat over the past five years.” It offered a link to “Learn more,” which I did not click.

The final step: consent.

“We use signals from across Google services to recommend highly compatible matches. This may include: Search activity, YouTube watch history, Maps timeline, Calendar events, Photos metadata, Gmail semantic analysis (excluding sensitive categories), and more.”

There was a toggle for “Use sensitive categories (sexual orientation, religion, health, etc.) to improve matches.” It was off by default. I stared at it for a full minute. Then, with the shameful decisiveness of someone who has read too much behavioral economics, I flipped it on.

Immediately: “Great! This will help us find better matches for you.”

The first match appeared before I finished the sign-up.

Her name was Ami. Thirty-one. A software engineer ten miles away. GMatch offered a brief, unnerving summary:

“You and Ami share:
- 93% overlap in core values
- 88% alignment on long-term goals
- 91% media compatibility
You are highly likely to enjoy the same podcasts but will politely disagree about two of them. (We’ll let you discover which.)”

What stood out most: under “How we matched you,” a tiny link.

I clicked.

“You and Ami:
- Searched for the exact same obscure error message three times.
- Favorited the same ramen place in Maps.
- Watched three identical YouTube videos within 24 hours of each other in 2021.
- Wrote unsent emails (Gmail drafts) about feeling inadequate in similar language patterns.
We think you’ll understand each other.”

I felt my stomach flip. The unsent drafts. They were reading the drafts.

A message appeared, composed for me, cursor blinking at the end:

“Hey Ami, GMatch says we’ve both rage-searched the same bug. Want to talk about it?”

I deleted it. I retyped: “Hi Ami. Apparently we share a remarkable number of oddly specific neuroses. Coffee?”

I hovered. Sent.

She replied in forty seconds.

“Finally,” she wrote. “Someone else who’s seen ‘segmentation fault (core dumped)’ as a lifestyle.”

We met three days later.

GMatch prompted: “We’ve suggested a meeting spot convenient for both of you.” It offered three cafes, ranked. I recognized one as the ramen place. “You rated this 5 stars on Maps. Ami has uploaded multiple happy Photos here. High potential for positive association.”

I picked it.

On the way, Maps gave me a subtle banner: “Running 6 minutes late? Let Ami know.” I wasn’t late, but when the light turned red longer than expected, the banner flashed again. I declined, a little irritated.

Ami was sitting near the window, exactly as her profile picture suggested she would: hair half up, glasses smudged, laptop open, stickered with past lives. She looked up with an expression I recognized instantly: amused skepticism.

“So,” she said. “Did you read the breakdown?”

“Of our compatibility? Yeah.”

“They showed you the drafts thing?”

I winced. “Yeah.”

She laughed. “Good. If they hadn’t, I was going to.”

We talked. A lot. It was easy in that suspicious way that felt like walking onto a stage and discovering the lines were already written for both of you. When I mentioned a podcast, she already listened to it. When she referenced a meme, I’d liked it six months earlier. Jokes landed. Silences didn’t hurt.

Halfway through, my phone buzzed with a quiet notification from GMatch: “How’s it going with Ami?” There were buttons: “Great,” “Okay,” “Not great,” “Haven’t met.” I turned my phone face down.

“Did you get the feedback ping?” she asked.

“Yes. I’m ignoring it.”

“Good. I installed an extension that auto-answers ‘Great’ whenever they ask,” she said. “Freaks them out.”

“How would you know if it freaks them out?”

She grinned. “I don’t. But I like imagining some machine frantically recalibrating.”

Two hours in, she said, “It feels… scripted, doesn’t it?”

I exhaled. “Yeah. Like we’re two really compatible datasets.”

“Is that bad?”

“I don’t know.”

We saw each other again. And again. GMatch kept up a polite presence in the background. “Many couples enjoy a second date within 3-5 days…” “Here’s a list of conversation starters based on your mutual interests…” “We’ve noticed you both listen to music associated with nostalgia late at night. Consider sharing playlists.”

We mocked it. But we did share playlists.

Three months in, GMatch sent a push: “Relationships like yours have a 79% probability of long-term success. See how you compare.” At the bottom, a satisfaction slider. I slid it to the far right because I was, annoyingly, happy.

Then one evening, while we were on the couch watching some video essay we’d both had independently recommended, Ami’s phone lit up. She frowned.

“New feature,” she said slowly. “‘Predictive Conflict Warnings.’”

I leaned over.

“To support healthy communication, GMatch will proactively flag moments where your digital patterns suggest elevated risk of conflict. Only you can see this.”

Below that: a specific prediction. “In the next week, probability of tension related to career insecurity: 63%.”

I laughed, until I saw her not laughing.

“What?” I asked.

“I got… the same topic,” she said. “But with 71%.”

We looked at each other.

“That’s creepy,” I said finally.

“It’s also not wrong,” she murmured.

She’d been restless. I’d noticed. I’d been spiraling, too. GMatch had noticed first.

For a few days, its warning hung between us like a third person, smug and invisible. Every time we brushed against work talk, I saw her glance at her phone, as if the probability might tick upward in real time. I tried not to be careful, which meant I was careful about being careful, which meant I was weird. By Friday we’d managed to prove GMatch right in a slow-motion argument about nothing.

After she left that night, my phone pinged.

“Looks like that didn’t go well. Here are some resources to help navigate difficult conversations.”

Underneath: targeted suggestions based on search history, messages, and, presumably, the tone of our texts. It had clipped one of my unsent messages to her—“I’m scared I’m not enough for you”—and turned it into a bullet point labeled “Expressing vulnerability.”

Something in me snapped.

The next day I went nuclear on my settings. Turned off the sensitive categories. Disconnected YouTube history. Disabled “relationship insights.” Every toggle I could find, flipped.

“We’re sorry to see you go,” the interface said, as if I’d quit a gym I never visited. “Note: This may impact match quality.”

Ami messaged: “Did you just de-link from GMatch? I got a notification: ‘One or more signals are temporarily unavailable for this relationship.’”

I stared at the screen. “You got notified?”

“Yeah,” she replied. “It said, ‘Your partner has changed data sharing settings. This might reduce personalization.’”

I called her.

“Okay,” I said without hello. “This is messed up.”

“It’s absolutely messed up,” she agreed. “They framed you turning off surveillance as you withdrawing from me.”

“Exactly.”

She was quiet for a moment. “Do you want to leave it? Use it less?”

“I want us,” I said, surprising myself, “without the commentary.”

“I installed GMatch because I didn’t trust my own judgment,” she admitted. “Feels like… offloading sense-making, you know? But I don’t want it gamifying whether we stay together.”

I laughed. “They gave us a probability score.”

“Yeah, and I keep thinking, if we’re at 79%, what if I behave differently to push it to 85? That’s not love. That’s A/B testing my personality.”
