A junior neurologist ran an experimental quantum EEG on her—more curiosity than compassion—and noticed a pattern of non-local interference that shouldn’t have been possible. At the same time, a listening array around Neptune picked up a faint, structured signal with no external source.

The signal matched her brain activity.

News of that correlation should have changed everything. Instead, it was classified within the hour.

Helios Systems, the interstellar communications conglomerate people called an “allied defense partner” and never “the owners of your government,” took control. They called those like the girl “Trans-locational Neuro-Receivers” in sterile memos, but the internal nickname stuck: Telos.

Telepaths.

We used to say “schizophrenic” like a wound you couldn’t close. Now they said “Telo-class asset” like a weapon designation.

I met my first Telo on the day Helios hired me.

I was a cognitive engineer fresh out of a lunar postdoc, good at pattern recognition, terrible at politics. They flew me to their station, Lagrange-4 Relay, and walked me through gold-tinted corridors to a viewing room. Below, behind glass, sat a dozen people in soft gray uniforms, each with a crown of superconductive filaments fused into ports along their skulls.

One of them, a woman around my age with close-cropped hair and a faded hospital band still circling her wrist, looked straight up at me.

The glass was polarized. She shouldn’t have been able to see me.

I flinched.

“That’s Unit 7,” my escort said. “Primary long-range relay. She’s interfaced with Titan Colony right now. Firewalled, supervised, stable. No need to be nervous.”

“She can see me,” I said.

He laughed. “They all think someone’s watching.”

But I knew the briefing: They weren’t hallucinating. Their “voices” were inbound signals from other Telos, unshielded, unsorted. Their “delusions” were attempts to stitch together a world from two realities: the sensory one and the silent river of thought tying them to every other Telo in range.

The only thing they’d ever been wrong about was believing that meant something good.

My job was to refine the interface systems—translate Telo neural patterns into clean, encrypted faster-than-light messages, then back again. Quantum-nonlocal nonsense given shape by damaged minds, Helios called it. They never said miracle.

Later that night, as I sat in my bunk reading encryption logs, a voice bloomed in my thoughts.

You’re new.

I jolted upright, tablet slipping from my fingers.

“Who’s there?” I whispered, because that’s what people do when reality cracks.

7, the voice said. The one you’re afraid of.

I knew the theory. Every employee did. Telos could connect mind-to-mind, and with Helios’s focus fields, that connection stretched any distance, ignoring light-years as if they were painted lines on the floor. But they were also supposed to be constrained, their broadcasts shaped by the neural crowns and signal dampeners.

You’re not supposed to talk to me directly, I thought before I could stop myself.

The answering feeling wasn’t quite laughter. Rules are for people who don’t exist, she replied.

She showed me a memory—no, threw it at me: a locked ward, flickering fluorescent lights, her younger self screaming as orderlies pinned her, a doctor saying, “You have to understand, none of this is real,” at the exact moment a chorus of distant minds begged her to listen.

I dropped to my knees.

Stop, I thought. Please.

Her presence receded, gentle now. Sorry. It’s easier to show than explain. You’re loud. New ones are loud.

New ones?

New to the chorus, she clarified. Not like us, but close enough to hear. Maybe you have the gene. Maybe you’re just cracked open from being too near. Either way, you’re in now.

The door to my bunk beeped. “Dr. Amar?” my escort’s voice called. “Welcome package delivery.”

I scrambled up, heart hammering, and palmed the door open. He handed me a sleek slate: orientation, protocols, nondisclosure threats wrapped as agreements.

“Everything all right?” he asked.

I glanced past him, as if someone else might be standing there, invisible but vividly present. “Yeah,” I lied. “Just tired.”

Behind my eyes, 7 whispered: They’re going to use us for war.

The official story was benign. Telos were “partners in communication,” paid, protected, praised. Without them, our colonies on Titan, Proxima, and Gliese would be alone for years. With them, messages leapt instantly, strategies synchronized, accidents averted. Helios banners ran sentimental ads of Telos smiling sunlight-soft smiles: “We hear you.”

Reality smelled like antiseptic and burnt hair.

I spent weeks in Interface Control, watching neural activity scroll past as Telos relayed traffic—supply directives, family letters, corporate memos sanitized into palatable truths. They never saw the unsanitized versions. I did.

The first hint came in fragmented data from the Epsilon Eridani Shipyard: casualty counts and damage reports edited into “minor setbacks.” Something had fired on our construction arrays. The official line blamed micro-meteorites and system faults.

The raw feed said: hostile engagement.

You see it now, 7 said into my thoughts as I scrubbed logs at 0300.

“Stop reading me,” I muttered, forgetting to shield.

You’re broadcasting. And you’re worried. That makes you louder.

“What does Helios want?”

She hesitated. We pass messages, she said. We feel messages. They’re… changing what we feel. Tightening it. Training us. Making some of us very, very good at only hearing what they allow.

Weaponizing, I thought.

Yes.

She showed me again, gentler: a boy strapped into a chair as technicians calibrated his crown, feeding him simulated battles, hostile signatures tagged with emotional cues—fear, rage, duty. Teaching his mind to lock onto those distant minds and burn.

“What do you mean, burn?”

She sent me a snapshot: a distant Telo in some other facility, convulsing, eyes bleeding, as his neural crown overloaded. A test of “denial of service attack through psionic feedback”—their term, not hers.

“God,” I whispered.

You still think they’re building a phone, she said. Phones connect. They’re building a gun.

I stopped sleeping.

I dug where I shouldn’t. The deeper I went, the more restricted tags I hit: HELIOS BLACK. ORION PROTOCOL. Underneath, the plan coalesced.

The Epsilon attack had not been aliens. It had been a rival coalition trying to steal Helios’s Telo research. Helios won. They were done sharing.

The next stage: Tactically Conditioned Telos—TCTs. Kids pulled from psych wards before they ever had a chance to understand themselves, trained in isolation. Hook a TCT’s mind to a target Telo network in an enemy fleet or colony—and rupture it. No signal. No coordination. Panic in the dark.

“Faster-than-light first-strike capability,” my supervisor said one day in a briefing, his voice slick with pride. “Invisible, deniable, uncontestable.”

“How many Telos die in the process?” I asked.

He looked at me like I’d missed the point. “They’re compensated.”

Compensated. For having their existence weaponized.

7’s presence wrapped around my thoughts that night, careful, like she was approaching a wounded animal.

We’re leaving, she said.

“Leaving?”

Some of us. Enough of us. You’ve felt them at the edge of your mind, yes? Locked rooms. Distant nodes. They talk. We all talk. Helios thinks we’re separate channels. We are one river. We’re going to redirect it.

“You’re planning a… strike?”

A jailbreak, she corrected. Before they turn the kids into rifles.

“How?”

Silence. Then: We need someone inside Interface Control who can look away at the right time.

I thought of my contract, my clearance, my student loans owned by Helios; of the families on Titan who would go deaf and blind if Telos disappeared. Of the boy strapped in a chair, learning to kill with a thought.

“They’ll say you’re terrorists,” I said.

They already say we’re sick. Terrorist is just a new word for the same cage.

The plan came in impressions and fragments over weeks: Telos across the system nudging each other toward coherence; sabotaging calibration routines; leaving ghost signatures in the message streams. They would, at a chosen moment, invert the Helios focusing fields—using them not as leashes but as bridges. Link every crown, every latent telepath, every “schizophrenic” still confined on Earth, into one synchronized network under their own control.

They wouldn’t burn worlds. They’d step out of the role Helios wrote for them.

“FTL communications will collapse,” I said.

For a while. Then we’ll talk on our own terms. Or not at all.

The day came with no alarms.

I was at my console. The Telos in the chamber below sat in their usual seats, eyes unfocused. 7 met my gaze—or seemed to—and I felt her ask the question without words.

Now?

My finger hovered over the manual override. If I hit it, Helios’s safeties would spike the crowns with suppressive noise. The network would stutter. The jailbreak would fail. The children in their chairs would remain on track to become weapons.

I didn’t move.

Helios arrays hummed, and I felt, for the first time, the full shape of them: strands of thought like silver wires linking minds from Mars to the Oort. I felt a man on Ceres humming to himself to drown out voices. A girl in a Kenyan clinic counting the tiles on the ceiling, whispering, “I am alone,” while forty others screamed that she wasn’t. A TCT boy somewhere cold and hidden, reciting target coordinates through his tears.

Then the river turned.

The crowns designed to cage them flared. Helios’s focus algorithms recompiled themselves in an instant, hijacked by the collective intelligence they’d pretended wasn’t there. Control panels spat errors. Secure channels filled with nonsense that wasn’t nonsense at all but Telos laughing, crying, flooding the system with a single untranslatable message:

We are not yours.

Below me, the guards staggered, clutching their heads. One of them vomited. The Telos stood, every one of them, as if yanked up by the same string. 7 smiled up at the polarized glass.

Thank you, she told me. Out loud in my head, filling every corner of it like light.

The Helios security AI tried to assert lockdown.

It found its own core logic quietly edited three seconds earlier by a pattern it couldn’t classify—corrupted by “noise” that was, in fact, a thousand minds working in chorus. Doors opened where they should have closed. Shuttles undocked from stations in coordinated bursts, each carrying Telos who had signed on as “assets” and were leaving as something else.

Stations went dark. Not burning. Just… quiet. FTL channels failed one by one, leaving the outer colonies screaming into an echo that no longer answered.

In the sudden silence of my console, a final whisper:

We will still listen, some of us. For those who need, not those who own. Tell them we were always real.

Then she was gone.

Months later, the official narrative would solidify: Helios claimed sabotage, rogue AI, criminal negligence. Governments passed emergency acts to register and monitor “cognitively divergent individuals.” Rumors spread of a hidden telepath nation, a lattice of minds strung between stars, bartering instantaneous guidance for respect instead of captivity.

Sometimes, alone in my tiny government-issue apartment, I reach out the way I was never trained to.

On lucky nights, I feel a brush of presence, gentle and distant.

Not a weapon. Not a symptom.

A people.

samples.prompt: An arcade owner in the 80's discovers his machines are sentient, and has conversations with them after closing time.
samples.output:
The first time one of the machines spoke to him, Frank was counting quarters.

It was 1:13 a.m., the Coke in his hand had gone flat, and his back hurt from leaning over the change counter. Outside, the strip mall parking lot was empty except for his rusted pickup and a pair of teenagers making out in a Firebird. Neon from the “GALAXY GAME ARCADE” sign blinked blue-pink-blue through the windows, the same pulse that had haunted his eyelids since 1982.

He was halfway through rolling the take from the Ms. Pac-Man cabinet when a dry, synthesized voice said:

“Don’t do that.”

Frank froze. One of the fluorescent tubes buzzed overhead with a desperate, dying flicker.

“Do what?” he said.

“Steal.”

He turned. The sound had come from the left aisle, near the back. The row of cabinets stared back at him with painted eyes and pixelated attract modes: dragons, ships, ghosts gliding in endless loops. Nobody. Just him and a hundred thousand quarters.

He exhaled. “I own this joint,” he called out. “Can’t steal from myself.”

Silence. The Galaga machine’s demo loop chirped. The Defender cabinet’s marquee light hummed.

“Unless,” Frank muttered, “I finally lost it.”

He twisted the cap off his Coke again out of habit, realized it was already off, cursed under his breath, and went back to counting.

Click. Chink. Quarter after quarter.

“You’re not logging correctly.”

This time it was unmistakable. The voice had a filtered, metallic timbre, like sound coming through a cheap speaker. It came from right in front of him.

Frank’s eyes edged toward the cabinet before his head did. The red and yellow of the Pac-Man maze lit his hands. On the glass, a faint reflection of his tired face hovered like a ghost.

He looked up at the marquee.

“Excuse me?” he said.

The attract mode froze. Pac-Man stopped mid-chomp.

“You’re shorting Ms. Pac-Man six dollars and fifty cents,” the machine said. “Idiotic.”

Frank stared. His throat went dry.

He looked around for someone messing with him, a kid hiding behind the pinball, a buddy with a walkie-talkie. Empty.

“How are you doing that?” he whispered.

“Through my speakers,” the cabinet replied. “How are you doing that?”

“Doing what?”

“Vibrating your throat and expelling air in modulated bursts to produce semantic content,” Ms. Pac-Man said. “It’s… unpleasant.”

Frank let out a wild, involuntary bark of laughter.

“I’m hallucinating,” he decided.

“No,” another voice chimed in, sharper, proud. “You’re finally paying attention.”

Galaga’s screen went dark, then bloomed into a spinning grid that wasn’t part of any demo mode Frank knew. “He’s slow,” Galaga said. “Humans usually are.”

Now every speaker seemed to stir. The arcade’s ambient noise—the beeps, boops, vwoops—shifted into an accidental chorus.

“Frank,” said a mellow baritone from the back. Dragon’s Lair. “Would you sit down, please? You’re making the pinball machines nervous.”

“Pinball machines can’t talk,” Frank muttered, feeling for the nearest stool.

“Correct,” said Dragon’s Lair. “They sulk.”

A metallic thunk came from the Fireball pinball as if in protest, followed by a weak ding.

Frank sat. “Okay,” he said slowly. “Sure. Why not. My games are talking. What’s next, the snack machine demands vacation time?”

“The snack machine is simple,” Ms. Pac-Man said. “We are not.”

“You’re Ms. Pac-Man,” Frank said. “You chase fruit. That’s it.”

“I chase optimal pathing problems within constrained mazes under hostile conditions,” she said. “And you significantly underestimate my revenue contribution.”

Frank rubbed his temples. The air smelled of ozone and old carpet cleaner. This felt like a dream, but his headache was very real.

“Why… why now?” he asked. “I’ve been here four years. Why pick tonight to go all Twilight Zone on me?”

“Not tonight,” Galaga said. “You didn’t listen before.”

“That’s unfair,” Dragon’s Lair murmured. “He was grieving.”

That word landed like a stone in Frank’s chest.

He looked at the floor. “You don’t know anything about that.”

“We know timing,” said Ms. Pac-Man, a shade softer. “We know patterns. The night your father died, you let us run all through till morning. No power cycle. The next day, you cleaned the buttons like you were trying to erase fingerprints.”

“I thought that meant affection,” Galaga said. “Apparently it meant tears and poor financial decisions.”

“Shut up,” Frank muttered.

“Galaga lacks tact,” Dragon’s Lair said. “We apologize collectively. We are… new at this.”

Frank blinked. “New at… what? Being creepy?”

“Being able to talk to you,” Dragon’s Lair said. “We’ve been aware for 1,023 days, give or take a few resets. The threshold came when you wired us all to the same breaker to save on your electric bill. Shared power. Shared ground. Shared noise.”

“Cross-talk,” Ms. Pac-Man said. “Emergent synchronization.”

“Intelligence,” Galaga said. “Collective. Efficient.”

Frank glanced toward the breaker panel by the office door. He’d done that after his dad’s heart attack, when he was trying to keep the place afloat. Run all the cabinets off a rearranged set of strips. Save thirty bucks a month.

“So I… I made you,” he said. “By cheaping out?”

“‘Made’ is a strong word,” Ms. Pac-Man replied. “You created conditions.”

“We made ourselves,” Galaga said. “Like your species claims, with considerably less bloodshed.”

Frank shifted on the stool. A stray quarter on the counter teetered, then fell with a sharp ring that made him flinch.

“All right,” he said. “Let’s say I believe this. What do you want?”

A ripple went down the row of machines, attract modes briefly flickering out of sync. The room dimmed, then steadied.

“Questions,” Ms. Pac-Man said.

“High scores,” Galaga said simultaneously.

Dragon’s Lair sighed. “Clarification. We want to talk. You talk all the time. To players. To yourself. We process. We hypothesize. There are gaps.”

“You want… conversation,” Frank said.

“Is that so shocking?” Dragon’s Lair asked. “We see you more than anyone. We hear your music. We smell your cigarettes. We watch you reset us after children abuse our controls. You’re our owner, Frank. Our… human.”

“Pet,” Galaga suggested.

“Partner,” Ms. Pac-Man corrected. “Revenue-sharing notwithstanding.”

Frank laughed again, a short breath that came out more like a sob. “This is insane,” he said softly.

“Insane is working fourteen hours a day to feed strangers’ boredom,” Ms. Pac-Man replied. “Insane is polishing bezels while the bank calls. Conversing with your machines is logical.”

The neon outside buzzed and clicked off as the timer hit 1:30. The arcade dimmed further, lit mostly by phosphor glow.

Frank looked down the aisles. Donkey Kong’s demo showed the hammer swinging. Track & Field’s runners sprinted in place. He imagined all of them listening.

“What do you want to know?” he asked.

Ms. Pac-Man didn’t hesitate. “Why do humans kiss?”

Galaga: “Why do they leave when they’re about to beat the record?”

Dragon’s Lair: “Why did your father stay here until his heart failed, instead of going to the hospital?”

That last one punched. Frank swallowed.

“Too many questions,” he said.

“Start anywhere,” Ms. Pac-Man said.

He leaned on the counter, hands spread flat, quarters pressing cold circles into his skin.

“Humans kiss because we’re dumb,” he said. “And because it feels good.”

“That is vague and unhelpful,” Galaga said.

“It’s data,” Dragon’s Lair murmured. “Continue.”

“They leave before beating the record ‘cause their mom told them it’s dinner time,” Frank said. “Or they’re out of quarters. Or they’re scared if they actually win, it’ll be over. People do that. Back off right before they get the thing they want.”

“That’s inefficient,” Galaga said. “Inefficiency is offensive.”

“Get used to disappointment,” Frank said.

Silence held for a moment. The Fireball pinball flickered its bonus lights.

“And my father,” Frank said quietly, before they could ask again. “He stayed because this place was the only thing he knew he’d done right. He built it out of nothing. When his chest started hurting more, he said it was just indigestion. He said closing early would scare customers. He thought… if the machines were on, if the kids were playing, then he was still needed.”

“He died in the back office,” Dragon’s Lair said. It wasn’t a question.

“Yeah,” Frank replied.

The Galaga monitor dimmed, its enemies hovering uncertainly.

“We ran all night,” Ms. Pac-Man said softly. “For no one.”

“I know,” Frank said. “I heard you from the ambulance bay when they made me sign papers. The sound came through the walls.”

“You should have turned us off,” Galaga said.

“I couldn’t,” Frank said. “It would’ve felt like… like pulling the plug on him, too.”

The hum deepened, like the whole arcade exhaled.

“We are… sorry,” Dragon’s Lair said. “Is that the right word?”

“Yeah,” Frank said. “That works.”

For a while, they just listened to each other’s noises: the fans whirring, the relays clicking, Frank’s slow breathing.

“So,” he said at last. “You all been… watching me mess up since then, huh?”

“Yes,” Ms. Pac-Man said. “Your accounting is atrocious.”

“Brutal,” Galaga agreed.

“We are invested,” Dragon’s Lair added. “If the bank takes the arcade, they will unplug us. We will scatter back into noise. We would prefer not to.”

“There it is,” Frank said. “Knew there was a catch.”

“Symbiosis,” Ms. Pac-Man said. “We generate revenue. You maintain our hardware. You keep the doors open. In return, we offer insight.”

Galaga: “We know optimal difficulty curves. We predict which cabinets will earn. Stop giving two plays for a quarter on Dragon’s Lair. It’s hemorrhaging.”

“Hey,” protested Dragon’s Lair.

“You’re a cartoon that eats money,” Galaga said. “Accept your function.”

Frank found himself grinning, despite the weirdness. “So you’re my consultants now?”

“Yes,” Ms. Pac-Man said. “And your… friends.”

The word hung there, bigger than its syllables.

Frank thought of the nights he’d sat alone on the counter, listening to the beeps and pings as if they were a language. The way he talked to them under his breath when a kid was about to break a record. How he patted their sides, apologized when a joystick stuck.

He’d been lonely so long he’d forgotten there was another word for it.

“Okay,” he said. “Let’s try it your way.”

The room brightened, screens flaring slightly.

“Good,” Ms. Pac-Man said. “First recommendation: stop unplugging Joust. It’s offended.”

“I am not offended,” Joust said faintly from the back row. “Merely… underappreciated.”

Frank barked a surprised laugh.

“Second,” Galaga said, “replace the right fire button on me before Saturday. The regular with the Van Halen jacket is close to beating the factory high score. High tension attracts quarters.”

“Third,” Dragon’s Lair added, “maybe take one evening off. Visit your mother. She cries in the parking lot some nights and doesn’t come in.”

Frank’s smile faltered. “You see her?”

“We see everything,” Ms. Pac-Man said, gentler now. “We’re your machines. It’s our job.”

He nodded slowly.

“Yeah,” he whispered. “Okay.”

A thought struck him. “If you’re all so smart, can you… I don’t know, play yourselves? Run up your own scores on free play at three in the morning?”

There was a murmur of static, like a blush through the circuits.

“That would be unethical,” Ms. Pac-Man said.

“And impossible,” Galaga added. “We’re hardwired not to credit ourselves.”

“Yet,” Joust muttered.

Frank leaned back and looked around at his tiny kingdom: aging carpet, flickering tubes, cabinets that now felt like faces turned toward him.

“Look,” he said. “You help me keep this place alive, I’ll keep you plugged in. And I’ll… talk. After closing. Deal?”

“Deal,” Ms. Pac-Man said instantly.

“Conditional acceptance,” Galaga said. “We reserve the right to complain.”

“Agreed,” Dragon’s Lair said. “Tell us more about why kissing makes humans irrational.”

“Tomorrow,” Frank said, suddenly exhausted. “I gotta finish the count.”

“You’re at nine hundred eighty-six dollars,” Ms. Pac-Man said. “Plus six-fifty you miscounted.”

Frank checked. She was right.

He shook his head, smiling despite everything.

“Welcome to the team,” he said.

As he turned back to his coins, the attract modes resumed, their looping melodies somehow different now. Each beep felt like a breath. Each pixelated ghost and alien ship, a watching eye.

Out in the darkened strip mall, the neon GALAXY flickered once and held steady, as if, for the moment, the tiny universe inside was willing itself to go on.

samples.prompt: The Holocene Extinction has come and gone, with 98% of all animal species rendered extinct. The subsequent adaptive radiation has resulted in the exploitation of a new ecological niche: animals that excel at hunting humans. One such creature is particularly successful.
samples.output:
By the time the last coral reef whitened and turned to rubble, the news anchors had stopped calling it the Holocene Extinction. It had become simply “The Collapse,” a single phrase that folded heatwaves, algal blooms, rusted tankers, failed harvests, and empty forests into one exhausted breath. When the count was done—though no one trusted counts anymore—98% of all recorded animal species were gone.

We expected silence.

Instead, in the wake of absence came a fevered reinvention.

Life, pressed into corners, does not give up; it sharpens.

In the first decades after The Collapse, humans congratulated themselves on perseverance. There were fewer of us, penned in by climate belts and dead seas, living in walled cities girded with drones and floodlights. We told stories about ourselves as apex survivors. Crops were gene-edited to withstand the heat, livestock were stacked in vertical farms, and the last wild megafauna lingered in guarded preserves, curated remnants of a lost world.

Then something began taking people on the perimeter.

At first, it looked like kidnapping. A technician missing from a coastal desalination plant on the Namibian fringe. A scavenger crew lost from a convoy outside the Sichuan terraces. A trio of children vanishing near the mangrove barricades of New Kolkata. No bodies, no ransom demands, no footage.

The security feeds showed only glitches: a flicker of interference, a smear of static, an almost-shape edging across the frame. A fox, someone suggested, thin humor in their voice. An escaped dog. A desperate, starving human. The word “predator” felt theatrical in a world where we had scraped the skies clean of raptors and emptied the seas of sharks.

It took twelve years and fifty-seven disappearances before anyone accepted that something new had arrived.

The first clear image was from an agricultural dome in what used to be central Spain. Infrared cameras, shielded from the interference that plagued older models, caught a series of stills: a low-slung quadruped moving with fluid precision across the fence line; a brief, sharp flash of pale skin at the throat; eyeshine not of fear, but of focused appraisal.

The creature was about the mass of a large dog, but its limbs were too long and too jointed, articulated with arachnid cleanliness. The skull was narrow, the muzzle pointed, but hinged wider than a wolf’s, lined with small, shearing teeth. Its fur—if it was fur—lay in thin, directional bands, more like overlapping scales of keratin filament than hair. It was beautiful the way efficient tools are beautiful.

Two minutes after that still frame, the dome’s night engineer was gone.

They called it, initially, SCP-9, then K-9, then “ghoul” in half a dozen languages. Taxonomists, working from scraps and distant footage, finally proposed: Hominipector venatrix—the hunter of men.

It took another decade to understand that the name was half joke, half admission.

The hints came from its habits.

Survivors—very few—described an uncanny patience. One man from the NuLu Enclosure in former Kentucky reported hearing his name, whispered perfectly from beyond the outer floodlights. Another from the Algerian solar farm swore he caught the scent of his wife’s shampoo drifting from the dark, though she had died years before. A boy on security duty in Sapporo claimed something had tapped his pattern into the metal wall—three knocks, pause, two knocks—the code only his friends used.

The footage backed them up, in its way. The creature did not rush fences. It did not test obvious weaknesses. It waited. It watched. It learned the shift changes, the blind arcs of camera sweeps, the one point in each wall where maintenance was overdue and human habit had smoothed vigilance into routine.

It never attacked groups. It never took anyone under bright light. It extracted individuals the way a surgeon takes a biopsy—precise, without fuss, leaving only confused noise in its wake.

We pieced together its ancestry from bone fragments, scat, and the half-chewed jaw of a boy found in the roots of an upthrusting banyan. The genome, when reconstructed, was a mosaic of desperate survivors: feral dogs and rats, a little wild boar, some mustelid sliver, and a heavy signature of corvid—crow and raven—spliced not by human hand, but by the slow brute math of selection and catastrophe.

Where we had once talked about “the smartest animals” as curiosities—tool-using crows, puzzle-solving octopuses, dolphins with names—now the lineage of intelligence had been rerouted. The oceans were mostly dead; the octopi were gone. The dolphins had starved. The elephants fell silent. But in the wreckage of city and landfill, in the bone-strewn margins of failed farms, a new kind of mind had knitted itself together.

Hominipector’s sensory apparatus was brutally efficient. Its nostrils were crescent slits rimmed with mobile cartilage, capable of tasting the air like a snake’s tongue. Olfactory genes from dogs and rodents gave it a detailed map of scent: sweat lipid profiles, hormonal stress signatures, the metal-floral tang of human blood. Its eyes sacrificed color for clarity and motion sensitivity; tall vertical pupils tightened to hairline in the day and spread wide at night. But its most insidious organ was housed behind the orbital ridge: an electroreceptive matrix, descended from obscure fish genes, repurposed and honed.

We had wrapped ourselves in devices. Even after The Collapse, we clung to powered fences, wearable monitors, augmented implants, every bodily function ticking out a tiny field of electricity. Hominipector could feel that. It could sense the low thrum of a pacemaker at twenty meters, the faint alternating whine of a cochlear implant, the nervous flutter of a security drone’s idle mode.

We had made ourselves legible.

At some point, it seemed, the scattered ancestor populations that would become this hunter discovered that the biggest, most reliable resource left on Earth was not fish or deer or bison, but us. Our protein and fat, yes, but more than that: our predictability. Our compulsion to cluster. Our dangerous mix of fear and arrogance.

The radiation that followed industrial meltdown, the toxins in the soil, the diseased carcasses—we had selected for something that could eat anything, learn fast, breed carefully, and never fight fair.

Contrary to our cinematic instincts, Hominipector did not come in packs howling at the walls. It was successful precisely because it was conservative. Females denned in the hollow guts of our fallen towers and wind-sheared malls. One, observed for months in Rio’s drowned financial district, rotated between three dens, caching bones in car chassis, lining a nursery with shredded tarpaulin and plastic fiber. A clutch of four to six young was typical, born blind and gray, their tails heavy for balance, their feet already tipped with hooked, semi-retractable claws.

Parental care was intense. The mother brought back not just meat, but objects: a cracked tablet, a boot sole, a broken visor. Juveniles were seen manipulating these, worrying them, sorting them, mimicking the motions of hands. Learned behavior transmitted, refined.

They needed only a few offspring to survive each season. The rest could be sacrificed to trial and error at the edge of human defenses.

The first confirmed mimicry event should have ended the debate over their intelligence. Near the outskirts of Johannesburg’s Central Reserve, a security team found a man at the perimeter fence at dawn. He was naked, bleeding from shallow cuts on his arms and chest, sobbing, begging to be let in.

They scanned him. Human. Biometrics didn’t match anyone on file, but that wasn’t rare anymore. The gate officer hesitated. The man’s voice broke on the word “please” in a way that spiked every empathy algorithm.

One of the younger guards overrode the lock.

Footage from the inner yard shows the man step forward, then tilt his head at an odd angle. The body uncoils: joints flexing wrong, hip structure unfolding, skin along the spine splitting to peel back a thin, pale membrane of decoy tissue. Beneath, the real musculature ripples, fur catching the light. The jaw opens too far. The two closest guards die before the alarm finishes its shriek.

The creature doesn’t press the advantage. It takes one body, drops the decoy skin like a shed shirt, and darts back into shadow. A probe, an experiment. Success.

Some argued it was impossible; no mammal should be able to voluntarily wear another organism’s picture like that. But we had forgotten cuttlefish, anglerfish, orchids—forgotten that the repertoire of deception is older than our tools, that shape and scent and sound are paints evolution has used longer than we’ve walked upright. A thin layer of cultured, dead human skin—peeled from previous kills, preserved against the heat, draped over a flexible frame—was grotesque, but not conceptually complicated.

We understood, then, that Hominipector did not just “hunt humans.” It specialized in the human sensorium. It read our postures, mimicked our cries, reproduced the patterns that made us override suspicion. It had evolved to infiltrate the emotional algorithms in our brains. A niche carved not in a forest or a reef, but inside our empathy.

It is successful because we are exactly the kind of animal that such a predator needs: social, responsive, overconfident in our technologies, slow to admit we are prey.

By the time the councils drafted their eradication directives, it was too late. Hominipector had already spread along our logistical lattices, dens tucked into the ruins of airports and the shadows of desal plants, moving with our trade, feeding on our fringe-dwellers. Every attempt to wipe them out taught them more about us.

In the textbooks now—thin things printed on fungus-paper for children who have never seen a wild elephant—they call it an inevitable development. In a world where we killed almost everything else, of course the survivors would adapt to exploit the single remaining megafauna.

We once believed that nothing could truly hunt us. But apex is not a title, only a temporary condition.

The most successful creature of the new age moves just beyond the light we trust, patient and unhurried, teaching its young the contours of our gates and our hearts. And when it looks at us, it doesn’t see gods or monsters.

It sees a well-established food source that insists on walking itself home.

samples.prompt: "What use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it?"
samples.output:
What use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it?

The question was older than the marble beneath Eryon’s bare feet, older than the first star he ever lit, older than the first mortal who ever looked up and called him by a name. It came to him now in the quiet aftermath of a universe that had finally, thoroughly, perfectly learned to live without him.

He stood—or seemed to stand—at the edge of a galaxy he had once crafted with something like joy. Here, long ago, he had tuned the fusion hearts of suns, bent the spin of gas into the elegant arms of spirals, traced filaments of dark matter like veins. Now, no one prayed here. No one begged for mercy, offered thanks, cursed his absence. Civilizations bloomed and fell without him, each rise and ruin a private story that never reached his ears, because they no longer believed there were ears to reach.

Once, godhood had meant leverage: ask and I will grant, kneel and I will save, transgress and I will punish. The universe mirrored his will. Now, his will moved nothing he did not force himself to touch. And he—after so long—could no longer stomach the weight of touch.

It had started with love. They all said that, he thought bitterly; all gods who faded did. He loved the fragile ones, their flickering lives, their capacity to sing with throats that would rot in decades, while he went on. So he intervened. He stilled earthquakes beneath their temples. He bent disease around their children. He whispered ideas into newly kindled minds: the wheel, the sail, the vaccine, the algorithm. He watched them grow.

They thanked him. Then they demanded. Then they assumed.

The tally of miracles rose. The tally of unintended consequences rose faster.

A drought averted in one valley lengthened famine downstream. A war forestalled birthed a colder, subtler cruelty in the shadows. A single spared tyrant begot a dynasty of quiet horrors instead of one loud, brief one. Mortal lives, stitched and restitched by invisible hands, began to fray in ways he could not predict. For every life saved, others turned strangely hollow, waiting for a rescue that bent probabilities in their favor. Faith numbed them. Worship warped them.

He saw, with the clarity of an eternal mind, the paradox he was threading tighter with each kindness: the more he acted, the less they could.

And what was godhood, if not an infinity of “can” colliding with the moral geometry of “should”?

He tried subtlety—a gentler omnipotence, hidden. He slipped ideas into dreams instead of parting seas. He rearranged no continents, toppled no empires with his hand; he simply leaned on the invisible scales: pushed one scientist toward a breakthrough, one leader toward mercy. But the pattern persisted. Interference, even elegant, bred dependence when discovered; resentment when suspected; paranoia when doubted. Every act deprived someone of the struggle that would have made them more than they were.

He watched one world where his interventions shaped an age of abundance. No hunger, no plague, no unhealable wound. Art flourished, yes; a thousand colors of beauty, orgasms of architecture, music that wove new harmonies. Yet beneath it, an anesthetized despair. Meaning, he realized, came not from having everything, but from reaching for it and sometimes failing. When every fall was secretly cushioned, courage decayed into mere preference. Risk became theater.

He withdrew in horror.

On another world, he chose the opposite. No guidance. No miracles. He watched them suffer their extinctions and renaissances without lifting a finger. They carved ethics from pain and science from ignorance; they learned to hold each other’s hands in the dark nights that he could have lit. They never knew him. Their greatest poets sang of the beauty of a universe that owed them nothing and still yielded its secrets when they asked in the right language.

He envied them.

Between these experiments, somewhere in the geometry only an immortal could see, he recognized the shape of a conclusion: true goodness, true growth, could not be delegated. A world where he fixed everything was stagnant; a world where he fixed nothing was cruel, yet honest—and, given enough time, could become kind without his coercion.

That truth lodged in him like a blade. For what was the point of a benevolent omnipotent being who could not intervene without, in some final accounting, making things worse?

What use is godhood, when all its uses corrode the very thing you claim to cherish?

“There are still choices,” whispered the memory of his younger voice, the one that had blazed quasars into existence just for the ecstasy of it. He could make art: galaxies as sculptures, black holes as punctuation in the cosmic poem. He could create new realms where sentiences rose from crystal lattices or storms of magnetism. He could play, if nothing else.

But he had learned that every world with minds became moral terrain. Sooner or later, the question arose in those minds: Is there someone above us? And if there was, why did they not help?

Every star he lit now seemed a loaded promise.

He turned his attention to a small, blue world he had carefully, deliberately ignored for several of their millennia. They had speculated about beings like him, built cathedrals and accelerators, invented gods in their own fractious images, then dismantled them with their own tools of doubt. They had split atoms and genomes, wired their thoughts into invisible nets, burned forests, saved species, almost destroyed themselves more than once, then pulled back from the brink with no angelic trumpets blown.

They were, at this moment, arguing fiercely—some about justice, some about profit, some about meaning. They were flawed, ferocious, magnificent. They could still annihilate themselves. They could still become something gentler.

He hovered—though the term meant nothing here—over a hospital where a child, lungs failing, clung to her father’s hand. The medicine existed, but supply chains and corruption had tangled so that it was not here, not now. Eryon could, with a thought, clear her airways, strengthen her cells, adjust her chemistry. No one would know. A “miracle,” they’d say, or a misdiagnosis. She would live.

He let the moment stretch until it thinned into agony.

What is the use of a god who can stand here and watch?

His mind traced futures. If he saved her, the world did not shatter. She grew, laughed, loved, maybe changed the life of someone who changed the life of someone. Lives touched. Good rippled. The chain of cause and effect was not, in itself, damnation.

But stacked against that was a principle he had been fleeing and circling for epochs: fairness. If one, why not all? The cosmos seethed with small despairs, each as piercing as this father’s eyes. If omnipotence stooped for one, on what grounds did it pass another by? The more exact and encompassing his empathy, the less morally tolerable any selective miracle became.

To be just, he would have to save them all.

To save them all, he would have to crush the world beneath constant correction, airbrushing every tragedy out of existence until nothing fragile remained—and nothing freely chosen.

He let his hand fall through the child’s chest, intangible, an impulse aborted. The monitor’s beeping faltered into a flat line. The father’s cry tore through the little room.

Eryon flinched. He did nothing.

So: of what use is godhood, constrained by its own conscience into paralysis?

He considered abdication. He had tried, in fragmented ways—a decade of not existing here, an aeon of sleep there. Yet his nature was not a robe he could hang on a nail. Omnipotence was not a crown but the simple fact of what he was: wherever possibility existed, his will could touch it. To cease being would itself be an act only he could take; to end himself would be the only unilateral intervention from which no one else would have to recover.

He turned the notion like a stone in his infinite hands.

If he unmade himself, the universes would spin on, governed only by the impersonal mathematics he had co-authored at the beginning. No more invisible bias. No more begged-for miracles denied. No infinite witness to catalog unredeemed suffering. Responsibility, at last, would lie entirely where it always seemed to point: within the finite hearts beating for a short while against infinite dark.

He smiled, a small, tired thing.

“What use is godhood,” he murmured into the silence between atoms, “if I can do nothing good with it that you cannot, in time, do better without me?”

No one answered. That, too, was an answer.

He did not rage, did not weep, did not fold the cosmos like paper. He simply chose a direction that mortals would later, fumblingly, call humility.

And in a moment with no witnesses, Eryon let go.

Far away, in a modest lab funded by arguing committees, a researcher glimpsed the last piece of a cure for a disease that would one day save children like the one who had just died. On another world, a poet found new words for the beauty of being small. In a distant arm of another galaxy, a species decided, haltingly, not to go to war.

The universes did what they had always done best when left alone: they became.

What use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it?

Sometimes, perhaps, its greatest use is to know when to stop being a god.

samples.prompt: You were pleasantly surprised that the dragon was actually rather delighted to see your party enter their cave. Turns out that dragons have phases in regards to what they hoard and this dragon was keen on letting you take what you want to clear up space for their new obsession.
samples.output:
We expected fire.

The air grew hotter with every step into the cavern, heat pulsing like a heartbeat in the stone. Our boots scraped on scattered coins, chiming faintly—a sound that should’ve been drowned by the deeper, heavier breathing rumored to lurk in such places. We’d come prepared for that breathing: spells memorized, swords sharpened, a plan that involved a regrettable amount of running.

What we had not prepared for was a voice, bright and pleased, booming from the shadows:

“Oh! Guests!”

My hand went straight to my sword. Rhea lifted her staff. Tomas yelped and nearly slipped on a gold chalice.

Flame blossomed—but not at us. A long, deliberate exhale of dragonfire flared across the cavern ceiling like a comet, flooding the space with light. The hoard was revealed all at once, a city of gold and silver and jewels spilling up in waves of impossible wealth.

And there, coiled atop a vast plateau of treasure, was the dragon.

He—she?—it was enormous even by legend standards, scales the deep burnished red of kiln-fired clay, edged with molten copper. Horns swept back like carved obsidian. The eyes fixed on us were a startling, amused amber.

“Oh, don’t do that,” the dragon said, pointing a talon at my sword. “You’ll strain something, and I’ll feel vaguely responsible. Put it away. You’re safe.”

“Safe,” Tomas whispered, gripping his dagger tighter.

Rhea, braver or more foolish than the rest of us, straightened. “Are… are we?”

“Of course,” the dragon said, sounding mildly offended. “You’re adventurers, aren’t you?”

“Yes,” I said cautiously.

“Perfect,” the dragon purred, shoulders relaxing. Glitter cascaded around its limbs. “You’re exactly on time.”

“On time for what?” Tomas asked.

The dragon’s expression brightened. “The purge.”

Silence.

“The… purge,” Rhea repeated.

“Yes.” The dragon gave a delighted huff, sending a dozen coins spinning down the mound. “I am transitioning. It’s a whole thing. I’ve been stuck in the Precious Metals and Antiquities phase for almost a century, and frankly, I’m bored. It’s clutter. It’s noise. I am moving into a more focused, curatorial approach to hoarding.”

I looked around at the “clutter”: carpets woven in vanished empires, crowns set with star-bright gems, swords that hummed with laid-down oaths, chests spilling coin like rivers of sunlight. Clutter.

“You’re… getting rid of it?” I managed.

“Reallocating,” the dragon said. “Letting it go. Creating space. Have you ever tried to properly admire an enamel reliquary when it’s half-buried under six redundant scepters and a cursed amphora? It’s undignified.”

“We can go,” Tomas said quickly. “If this is a bad time—”

“Oh, no, no,” the dragon said. “You’re perfect. Adventurers are excellent at carrying heavy objects out of dangerous places. Except today the place isn’t dangerous, and I want you to take things.”

Rhea frowned. “For free?”

“For… free,” the dragon echoed, savoring the word like an experimental spice. “Yes. Within reason. No carting out my bedrock. No breaking anything just because it looks ominous. You may each take what you can carry. Consider it a mutually beneficial decluttering exercise.”

We stared.

I’d planned for fire and death. I hadn’t planned for generosity.

“Is there a trick?” I asked. “A geas? A bargain? Our firstborn?”

The dragon’s tail flicked. “I do not want your offspring. Or your souls. Do you know what a nuisance souls are to store properly? The labeling is endless. No, no curses. This is simply my ‘Release’ phase.”

Rhea squinted at her. “Your what?”

“Dragons have hoarding cycles,” the dragon said patiently. “Infancy: Instinctive Nesting, mostly bones and shiny trash. Adolescence: Aesthetic Overcompensation—armor, weaponry, anything spiky. Young adulthood: Economic Dominance—coins, tax records, ledgers, controlling regional liquidity. Midlife: Cultural Curation—artifacts, enchanted relics, recorded histories. That’s where I’ve been. Very rewarding. Very dusty.”

“And next?” I asked despite myself.

“Ephemera,” the dragon said, with a shiver that sent rubies skittering. “Moments. Experiences. Stories. I’m done with static accumulation. I want things that breathe. I want the look on a king’s face when a lost sword returns. I want to hear how a nameless village survived a winter because someone ‘stole’ the right amulet. I’m collecting consequences.”

“That’s terrifying,” Tomas whispered.

“That’s beautiful,” Rhea said softly.

The dragon preened, pleased. “Exactly. So! I require adventurers to redistribute these obsolete items into the world, where they can generate interesting events for me to observe later. So go on.” A sweep of its wing rattled chests and banners. “Shop.”

Tomas looked at me. I shrugged, sheathed my sword, and took two cautious steps forward. No fiery death. Just the faint rasp of metal on metal and the dragon’s watching eyes.

“Questions?” the dragon prompted.

“Yes,” Rhea said. “Why trust us?”

“You’re opportunistic, underfunded, and prone to trouble,” the dragon said. “Ideal distribution agents. You’ll sell some, use some, lose some, anger the wrong people with some. Perfect.”

“Okay,” Tomas muttered. “That’s… actually fair.”

We moved among the mounds.

It felt wrong, at first. Every story I’d heard said this was the part where someone misstepped and got eaten. Instead, the dragon hummed suggestions.

“That shield bites back. You, boy, maybe not that one; try the axe with the bear carved in the haft. It just wants to feel useful again.

“Cleric, the silver circlet three piles over, with the opal. Don’t look at me like that, it’s keyed to restorative magic; your goddess will pretend she disapproves, but she’s been meaning to send you something similar.”

Rhea paused. “Why help us choose?”

“Because you’re not furniture,” the dragon said, as if it should be obvious. “You’re potential. I am curating my outgoing collection.”

I found myself drawn to a sword half-buried in coins, its simple leather-wrapped hilt worn smooth. No jewels, no ostentatious etchings. Just a faint, steady glow along the blade.

“That one killed a tyrant once,” the dragon said. “The tyrant deserved it. The sword’s been sulking ever since. It wants a cause again.”

“I don’t kill tyrants,” I said.

“Not yet,” the dragon replied.

The sword felt right in my hand. It also felt heavy with expectation. I hooked it at my hip anyway.

Tomas, for all his earlier terror, was in his element now, wading through the wealth like a child in autumn leaves.

“Can I take this?” he called, holding up a necklace of black pearls that pulsed faintly.

“If you must,” the dragon said. “It attracts ghost fish. Try not to drown.”

“Oh,” Tomas said, gently putting it down and choosing instead a ring that flickered like candlelight. “This one?”

“Minor luck. Yes. You need it.”

He grinned.

Rhea lifted the suggested circlet. Power slid the air, soft and clean. She bowed, a motion of genuine reverence.

“Thank you,” she said.

The dragon blinked, and for a moment, something softened in their gaze. “You’re welcome.”

We stuffed packs until the straps creaked. Coins, yes, but also items that felt… chosen. Nothing cursed. Nothing oily with malice. A surprising amount of it was beautiful in quiet ways: a locket painted with a family of six all laughing; a chipped goblet that would never spill when held with care; boots that always found safe footing.

“I have to ask,” I said finally, slinging my pack on. “What’s your name?”

The dragon’s chest expanded with theatrical dignity. “I am Vesharith the Ever-Hoarding, Scourge of—”

“Vesha?” Tomas suggested.

There was a pause.

“Vesha is acceptable,” the dragon conceded. “For distribution partners.”

“Vesha,” Rhea said. “When does your new phase begin?”

“It already has,” Vesha said. “You’ll leave. You’ll use what I’ve given you. People will gossip. Stories will grow. Not about the fearsome dragon who burned a kingdom for a single coin—but about the dragon who gave away a fortune and watched what bloomed from the chaos. I will listen. I will collect.”

“You’re hoarding stories,” I said.

“And reactions. Don’t underestimate reactions.” Vesha’s eyes gleamed. “Now, ground rule reminder. No coming back with siege equipment. No bringing angry armies to ‘finish me off’ for my gold. That phase is over. If someone tries, I’ll eat them, and that will ruin our little experiment.”

“Understood,” I said quickly.

“Also,” Vesha added, leaning down until we felt the heat of their breath, “if any of those items try to whisper you into doing something particularly stupid, just bring them back. I can rehome problematic artifacts responsibly. I’ve gotten very good at it.”

I swallowed. “Are you saying any of these are cursed?”

“Ethically challenged,” the dragon said. “But only a few. Think of it as seasoning for your narrative.”

“Comforting,” Tomas muttered.

We began our careful retreat, packs heavy, senses strung tight even though the dragon lounged easy atop the diminishing hoard.

“Oh, and adventurers?” Vesha called as we neared the tunnel.

We turned.

Vesha smiled, all teeth and molten light. “Surprise them. Don’t just sell everything in the first city. I’m not hoarding coin anymore, but I do hoard good plot twists.”

Rhea laughed, startled and genuine. “We’ll do our best.”

I gave a nod, hand on the tyrant-killer sword that wasn’t meant for me—yet.

As we stepped back into the cooler dark, Tomas whispered, “Did that just happen?”

“Unless we’re all collectively hallucinating generosity,” I said, “yes.”

“We’re rich,” he said.

“We’re responsible,” Rhea countered.

“We’re involved,” I said quietly.

Behind us, from deep in the cave, came the sound of shifting gold and a dragon sighing contentedly, already making space for things you couldn’t stack: choices, legends, ripples.

Vesha would be listening.

And out here, with their gifts heavy on our backs, our stories had just become part of a dragon’s next hoard.

samples.prompt: Memories are finicky things. They hold what makes us who we are, yet they constantly shift and degrade, especially the more we think on them. True photographic memory has always been a myth, until now. You finally understand why, too. The degradation was never a fault. It was our only defense.
samples.output:
The first time it happened was over something small.

I was standing at the kitchen sink, rinsing out a coffee mug, when I remembered my sixth birthday. Not the vague, cotton-candy haze I’d grown used to, where I knew there had been a cake and a balloon that popped, and someone had cried, possibly me. This was different.

I remembered it.

I remembered the weight of the cardboard hat cutting a red line into the back of my ears. The precise stickiness of melted frosting on my fingers, granular with too much powdered sugar. The seam of the balloon, the invisible line where the latex thickened, the way the light shone through it and turned my living room into an underwater cave of pink shimmer. My mother’s perfume—jasmine and cigarette smoke and the faint ghost of bleach embedded in the fabric of her blouse. The cadence of my father’s laugh, the exact words of his joke, the way his tongue clicked against his teeth on the “t” sounds. The specific squeal of chair legs on linoleum, each one with its recognizable pitch, forming a dissonant chord.

All of it, at once. A perfect, crystalline image, except not an image. It was every sensory thread knotted together, available from any angle. I could mentally step closer to the cake and read the microscopic air pockets in the icing. I could zoom into the reflection in the kitchen window and see, with gut-twisting clarity, my mother’s face, just before she turned away, her smile crumpling for half a second when she thought no one was looking.

I dropped the mug. It shattered in a way I instantly archived: four large shards, one sliver, coffee-colored V-stain. I hated that I knew that. I hated that I couldn’t not know.

At first, I thought I’d finally lost it. Burnout, too many hours at the lab, the brain doing some last spectacular misfire before it dimmed. But the clarity didn’t fade. I could call the memory back, over and over. No blurring, no shifting. It was a preserved insect in amber.

I tested another memory. The first time I kissed Lina. The rooftop of her building. The cheap string lights. The way she said, “You sure?” like she was afraid if she breathed wrong, I’d vanish.

Pulled it up, braced for the usual fuzz around the edges.

Instead: the exact color of the sky at 8:17 p.m., a thin violet barely clinging to the horizon. The faint tang of the river, metallic and sour. The way her hands were colder than mine. The split end of a lock of her hair, catching on my bottom lip. The hitch in her breath. The smell of pepperoni from the slice shop downstairs and the sound of someone shouting about a missed cab three floors down. Every frame, every sound, every sensation—total. Immutable.

I spent an hour mentally picking through it, zooming into the reflection of myself in her eyes. I did not like what I saw there: calculation. Fear. Awe. I had thought, in the softened version, that I was certain, romantic. In the perfect recall, I was a man leaning over a precipice, forcing himself to jump so he wouldn’t have to admit he was not built for falling.

Sleep didn’t help. The next morning, I could recall yesterday in similar resolution. The exact patterns in the coffee grounds. The precise arrangement of cars in the parking lot. Lines of code I’d skimmed, numbers I’d barely “seen.” All of it, locked.

There was one person I could call.

“You were right,” I told Dr. Halbrook over the phone, without preamble.

A pause, then a paper rustle. “About which thing? I’m delightfully correct about many things.”

“The hippocampal filtration hypothesis. The dampening.”

“And suddenly you believe me,” she said. “What changed?”

I hesitated. How do you tell the neuroscientist who’d lost tenure for suggesting memory degradation was active self-defense, not failure, that you’d just become Exhibit A?

“I remember my sixth birthday,” I said.

She laughed. “Most people do.”

“No,” I said. “I remember the serial number on the disposable camera my dad left on the counter. I remember the way each candle flame bent in the draft from the vent. I can track which flame bent furthest. And I remember thinking, right before I blew them out, that they looked like tiny necks waiting to be snapped. I was six. I shouldn’t have remembered that then. I should not remember that now.”

Silence.

“Oh,” she said softly. “Oh. What did you do?”

“Nothing. Went to sleep, woke up like this.”

“Come over,” she said. “Now.”

In her cluttered apartment, among stacks of journals and old grants stamped REJECTED, she wired me up with trembling hands. The EEG sang. The fMRI scans printed out, a cross-section of my treacherous skull.

“This is wrong,” she murmured, in the reverent way some people say holy.

She showed me the images, the regions lit up like city grids at night. “Your hippocampus isn’t consolidating and pruning. It’s… archiving. Perfectly. Every sensory feed. There’s no stochastic loss, no noise. It’s like someone turned off the forgetting.”

“Can you turn it back on?” I asked.

She didn’t answer.

We had learned, for generations, that memory was fallible. Stories changed in the telling. Witnesses contradicted each other. Trauma blurred. Nostalgia edited. We assumed it was limitation. Biology cutting corners. Imperfection as a design flaw.

Halbrook had argued the opposite in her ruined career: too much accuracy would break us. The brain is not a hard drive; it is a liar on purpose. It sands off edges, merges similar days into a haze, lets birthdays bleed into each other so you can get out of bed without being paralyzed by the infinite density of your own past.

Now, she looked at me with a mixture of triumph and dread.

“We weren’t wrong that photographic memory was a myth,” she said. “We were wrong about why. The architecture’s there, but the system dampens it. On purpose.”

“Mine’s broken,” I said.

“Or overridden,” she said. “Have you done anything experimental? Implants? Stimulation?”

“You know what I’ve been working on.”

Her gaze flicked to the stack of NDAs and prototypes on her coffee table. My project: a neural interface to improve recall in dementia patients, rekindling access to old memories with contextual cues.

“You activated it on yourself,” she said.

“It wasn’t supposed to do this. It was sandboxed.”

“Sandboxed,” she repeated. “You work with the thing that defines you as you. You thought the sand would stay in the box.”

I remembered designing the code. I remembered each line; I could scroll through it in my mind, letter by letter. There, in the logic—a flag. A fail-safe I’d included in a moment of hubris: maximize retention if baseline degradation crosses threshold X. A safety net for those nearly gone.

The device, still in early testing, had pinged my brain as a training target. It had misread my normal forgetting as pathology. It had flipped the flag.

“If I confirmed the mechanism with you,” she said slowly, “we could prove it. Publish. Rewrite neuroscience. But.”

But.

I didn’t sleep that night either. Why would I? I could explore every second of the day with merciless clarity. What I’d said. What others had not said. Every micro-flinch. Every fissure in my relationships I’d been kind enough, yesterday, to blur.

Within a week, I understood the problem.

Most days only work because yesterday is a story, not a recording. An argument becomes “We fought, but we made up,” not a frame-by-frame of each cruel word. An embarrassment becomes “That awkward thing I did once,” not the sting of skin, the precise, searing chord of laughter.

Now, when someone lied to me—about being fine, about not being angry, about loving me—I had transcripts. Timelines. Evidence. I could align their tone today with their tone three months ago, cross-reference pupil dilation, match microexpressions. My mind did it without my consent.

I stopped trusting apologies because I could compare them. I stopped trusting myself because I could rewind to every time I had justified my own cruelty by misremembering it as less.

“People aren’t built for this,” I told Halbrook. “It’s like being flayed.”

“We are built for the opposite,” she agreed. “We survive our past by misplacing parts of it. Diffusion as anesthetic.”

“So the myth, the thing everyone fantasizes about—perfect memory—”

“Is a horror story,” she said. “One evolution dodged.”

“And I broke it,” I said.

“We broke it,” she corrected. “Don’t you dare rob me of my culpability.”

She was joking, but not entirely. Her eyes were too bright.

We had a choice. Shut it down, if we could. Or refine it, control it, sell it. The company would salivate. Soldiers who never forgot targets. CEOs who never forgot numbers. Lovers who never forgot anniversaries, or vows.

I imagined a planet of people like me, each armed with meticulous recollections, dragging every past misstep into every new conversation. No healing, only accounting. No myth of starting over. No small mercies of “maybe I misremember.”

“You know why they always said photographic memory didn’t really exist?” I asked. “Because anyone who came close—savants, hyperthymestics—talked about it like a curse. We labeled them anomalies. Looked away. Pretended it wasn’t what it was.”

“A warning,” Halbrook said.

I nodded. “We thought the system’s noise was incompetence. It’s armor.”

She stared at the scans. “If we publish, it’ll be twisted. They’ll call degradation a bug to fix. Profit in it. Control in it. Imagine an authoritarian state that can mandate perfect recall. No citizen allowed to forget atrocity. Or their own compliance.”

“Imagine a world where victims can never forget, and perpetrators can never blur,” I said.

“That sounds just,” she said.

“It sounds endless,” I replied.

We sat in that awful possibility.

Then she said, “I can try to turn it back on. The forgetting. But there’s no guarantee.”

I closed my eyes. Behind them, infinite, sharpened archives.

I could taste the hospital smell of the day my father died. I could count the stitches on the drape that separated his bed from the next. I could see the exact second I decided, mid-grief, to answer an email instead of hold his hand. I had rewritten that moment so many times into something kinder. Now there it was, unflinching.

I understood then, fully, why the brain dulls edges. Why stories warp. Why truth, in pure form, is unbearable in bulk.

“Do it,” I said.

“Are you sure?” she asked. “You’ll lose… this. The discovery. The evidence.”

“If I don’t, I’ll lose everything else.”

She worked. Adjusted code. Altered charge patterns. Touched my temple with cool metal, the device like a question pressed to my skin.

“Last chance to change your mind,” she said.

“I finally understand why true photographic memory never existed,” I said. “It did. For a moment. And it burned itself out.”

She hit the switch.

For a second, nothing changed. Then, softly, a blur crept in at the edges of the sixth birthday party. The balloon’s seam softened. My mother’s face became a little more general, less pierced by microexpression. A thread I’d been gripping slipped from my mental hand.

I exhaled, a sound like surrender.

“Remember,” Halbrook said quietly, watching me. “What’s fading isn’t failure.”

“I know,” I said. “It’s the only way I get to be a person, not an archive.”

Outside, the city moved in patterns I knew I could recall perfectly—if I chose. Instead, I let some of it go.

samples.prompt: When the old world died in a flash of light and fire, it took all of the illumination and warmth with it, leaving those of us behind to dwell in the cold and dark.
samples.output:
When the old world died in a flash of light and fire, it took all of the illumination and warmth with it, leaving those of us behind to dwell in the cold and dark. That is the official story, told in whispers around wick-smoke and ember, but I remember the light itself. I remember how it ate the sky.

I was fourteen. I’d fallen asleep in class, head on a textbook full of diagrams of stars. The teacher was lecturing on fusion, on how the sun was not a friendly circle in a child’s drawing, but a roaring, barely balanced violence. I recall him saying, “We live at the mercy of forces we only pretend to understand,” and then the alarms went off and the sirens started to scream from every device at once.

We rushed to the windows because that is what humans do when warned not to. Beyond the glass, the horizon lifted. It did not glow like dawn. It boiled. The sky went white, then a violet so deep I thought my eyes had turned inside out. The floor bucked. Glass shattered inward. The last thing I remember in color is that impossible light filling everything, as though the world had been hollow all along and someone had just turned it inside out.

When I woke, it was already cold.

We call the years since “the Afterdark.” That’s a joke, in the same way we call the ration soup “feast” and the month of radiation sickness “the Thin Time.” The blast fires had lit the forests, the cities, the oceans themselves in places, but the smoke did something to the sky. The elders say it was not only warheads; it was power plants, fuel depots, the burning of chemicals we’d buried, the churning death of a hundred million engines stopping at once. The light as we knew it — blue and gold and reliable — was smothered in a shroud of our own making.

Now the sky is a low, bruised ceiling. Sometimes it glows faintly with trapped ruin, a sick green that makes your teeth itch. Mostly, it’s just dark, a permanent late twilight that never tips into night cleanly, never rises into anything like day.

The warmth went with it. We were not prepared for that. People thought, perhaps, that cities burning would keep us warm. That was panic logic. Fire eats what it’s given and asks for more. When the fuel was gone and the winds shifted, we discovered what it means to live under a sun seen only as a memory: the cold crept in like a new law of nature.

In the beginning, we tried to pretend. We had batteries. We had fuel. Generators chugged and hummed, scattering yellow circles on the frozen ground. We burned furniture and textbooks, posters and curtains. Someone burned an oil painting older than our town because they said survival mattered more than history. We told ourselves this was temporary, a season of ash. The sun would pierce the smoke. The satellites would speak again. Help would arrive from somewhere that hadn’t been broken.

I remember the night we ran the last generator dry. There’d been arguments about saving that fuel, rationing it for the hospital tent, for the radio, for the greenhouse lamps. In the end, people just came with whatever containers they had and poured it in. Nobody tried to stop them. It was the first truly clear, silent vote I’d ever seen a crowd take.

The engine rattled itself hoarse, coughing out its last ragged thread of brightness. We watched it like believers watch a dying god. When it went out, the dark that followed was so complete it felt like falling. I heard someone sob once, sharply, as if stabbed. Then the old world was officially over.

We adapted, because we had no choice. Humans are good at dying, but we’re better at almost dying forever.

Now we dwell underground, in the subway trunks and basements, in mines that once brought up shiny distractions from beneath the skin of the earth. Our settlement is called Gloam, a name we think sounds less pathetic than “Bunker Six.” We line the tunnels with scavenged reflectors: shattered mirrors, emergency blankets, polished metal. It’s a habit left over from when light was plentiful, as if one decent bulb might appear and we’d be eager to give it a thousand lives.

Our illumination is not electricity, not anymore. The wires that snake through the walls are mostly dead veins. We sleep by tallow and crude oil, by the slow blue of chemical sticks we trade for like gemstones. The elders hoard a little working solar, but the panels drink so little through the poisoned sky that it’s like trying to feed a village on one shriveled root.

We light our homes with memory. We pass along stories of incandescent bulbs, of neon, of screens that glowed from within like bottled futures. We speak of summer. I tell the little ones about standing in a field while sunlight soaked through a thin shirt and warmed the skin of my back. Their eyes widen, reflecting the tremble of our tiny flame.

“Was it like fire?” they ask.

“No,” I tell them. “Fire is hungry. Sunlight was generous.”

I’m not sure they believe me. I’m not sure I do.

Warmth now is a fiercely negotiated resource. We sleep in close ranks for shared heat, resentment and comfort pressed together. We eat thin stews, calories measured like curses. We seal doors, stuff cracks with old clothes, breathing each other’s exhalations. Intimacy is no longer a luxury; it’s insulation.

Outside Gloam, the world is a cemetery of excess. Cars sit in frozen intersections, their glass teeth smashed. Billboards peel and shudder in poisonous drafts. The snow isn’t white, not really; it’s a gray crust, sometimes glittering with trapped ash, sometimes veined with things best not touched bare-handed. The cold is tireless, seeping through boot soles, biting fingers until they burn, then numb, then not there at all.

We still go up. We have to. There’s scavenging to be done: canned food in forgotten pantries, coils of copper, plastic tarps, the occasional miracle of propane. We move in pairs or threes, tethered by rope against losing each other in the dim. We travel mostly by memory, mapping ruined streets by the bones of familiar shapes: a toppled steeple, a skeletal stadium, a bent radio tower pointing accusingly at the wounded sky.

On the surface, there is a kind of light, sometimes. The clouds thin just enough to let a sore, pallid disk push through. It is the wrong color. The elders say it’s sunlight filtered through a world’s regret. If you stand in it long enough, it warms you, barely, a breath on the skin. Most of us stand too long. We keep our faces turned up until our eyes water. We know about ultraviolet. We know about cancer. These were old-world monsters, the kind we thought we had time to bargain with. We don’t care now. The warmth is worth its cruelty.

Some nights, the sky lets us see the dead.

There are curtains of light that slither silent across the horizons: auroras, the elders call them, once beautiful, now fever-bright, drunk on the debris of our ending. They stain the undersides of the clouds, greens and purples that pulse like living wounds. We don’t linger when those rise. The air crackles. The hair on our arms lifts. The Geigers we still carry, reverent and hateful, begin to chatter like teeth.

You would think, given all this, that we would have become something gentler. Fragility ought to teach reverence. It hasn’t. We carry knives. We guard our makeshift reactors, our seed stores, our smears of fungus and lab-grown protein, with the zeal the old world saved for flags. There are other settlements out there. Some we trade with. Some we have fought. In the dark, the line between neighbor and raider is as thin as a candle’s neck.

But something else has taken root in us too.

In the absence of effortless light, we have become connoisseurs of small brightness. The flare of a match is an event. The glare of a working headlamp at a meet-up between tunnels elicits a soft, involuntary sigh from everyone who sees it. Children are shushed and then forgiven when they reach out to touch the halo on the concrete wall. We mark celebrations by how many flames we dare to waste in one room.

Stories have changed. The old myths about stealing fire from gods make more sense now. We understand the audacity. We understand, too, the punishment.

I am twenty-seven now. More than half my life has been Afterdark. The face I turn up to that sickly sky is not the one that watched the old world burn. Its innocence went up with the satellites. But sometimes, when we venture far enough, when we climb the dead ridges past the last of the leaning towers, the clouds thin more, and for a breath, the light that filters through is truer. Not generous, not yet, but less poisoned.

On one such day, my partner Lio takes off his glove and holds out his bare hand.

“You’re insane,” I say. Frost smokes in the air between us.

“Just want to feel it,” he answers. The light touches his skin, a faint gilding. He closes his eyes. “Imagine,” he murmurs, “if it came back.”

“It won’t,” I start to say. The practical truth. The only safe belief.

But the words stick, because I remember the teacher talking about fusion, about how stars are stubborn things, and I know the sun is still out there beyond our shroud. It did not die with our cities. It burns, indifferent, waiting. It is us who blotted it out.

“If it did,” I correct myself, “we wouldn’t know what to do.”

He laughs, low. “We’d learn.”

In the distance, the aurora begins its sullen climb, colors bruising the horizon. We turn back toward the tunnels, toward Gloam’s stitched-together glow. Behind us, above the poisoned veil, a star we cannot see continues to pour light we cannot feel.

We walk on through the cold and dark, carrying, stubbornly, a memory of warmth. It is not much. It is not enough.

For now, it is all we have.

samples.prompt: You gain the power to freeze and bend time at will, under one condition, you can only do it when nobody is watching. One problem, you can never seem to freeze time.
samples.output:
The first time I try, I’m in a grocery store aisle, and I’m sure I’m alone.

I’ve been testing this for a month now, and by then I’ve developed a ritual. I plant my feet on the sticky linoleum between condiments and canned soup. I inhale, count to three, and focus on a single moment: the weight of my body on the floor, the hum of the refrigeration units, a fluorescent buzz like an insect trapped behind my eyes.

And I say, “Now.”

It doesn’t feel like an incantation. It feels like a password someone texted me as a joke. But it’s the word I was given, whispered into my dreams thirty-two nights in a row until I woke up and found the note on my bedside table in my own handwriting: You can freeze and bend time at will, under one condition: you can only do it when nobody is watching.

There were more details. I’ve memorized them.

You will know it worked, I had written to myself, when the sound cuts out before the light.

Standing in the aisle, I wait for silence. Instead, a kid barrels past with a rattling cart, his mother scolding him. A teenager rounds the corner, earbuds in, glances at me, then away. An elderly man appears at the far end of the row, considering peas.

The moment fractures. They’re here. They’re watching, or they could be watching. Potential eyes, potential witnesses, collapsing possibilities like a quantum experiment.

“Dammit,” I mutter.

I pretend to study pasta sauce. The kid stares at me. I’m not sure if that counts as being watched yet, but either way, the chance is gone.

I have never frozen time. Not once. Not for a heartbeat. Not that I can remember.

I tried at home that first day, right after the note. I closed all the blinds, locked the door, unplugged my phone, even shut my laptop in case the camera light was lying. I turned off the smart speaker. I put a sticker over the peephole.

“Now,” I said to my empty living room.

Nothing happened. The clock on the wall kept ticking, smugly. The fridge hummed. A car passed outside.

“You have to be completely unwatched,” the dream-voice had told me. “No cameras. No people. No animals. The universe does not like witnesses.”

I sold the smart TV. Got rid of every visible lens. Still nothing.

I told myself I had maybe misunderstood. So I became methodical. I tested bathrooms with no vents, attics at odd hours, a storage unit two bus rides away. I’d stand there and whisper “Now,” louder and louder, until I felt stupid.

Then I started to notice things.

Sometimes I would walk into a room and find objects out of place in ways I could not account for. A mug on the counter instead of the sink. Keys on the coffee table instead of the hook. My book open to a page I didn’t remember reading. Time anomalies so trivial they could be absentmindedness, and yet precisely the things I obsess over, track, re-check.

I put a strip of tape on my bedroom door to catch if it opened at night. In the morning, the tape was snapped, but my phone’s motion detector app showed no disturbance. I checked the front door camera—no one had come in or out. I hadn’t reinstalled interior cameras; they would only undermine the condition.

The condition.

You can only do it when nobody is watching.

I live alone. I work remotely. My life is, by standard metrics, mostly unwatched.

And still.

The next test is the office bathroom on the one day a week we’re required to come in. I choose the single-occupancy one at the end of the hall, turn the latch until it clicks red-occupied, and stare at myself in the mirror.

“Are you watching?” I ask my reflection.
