This has become another paranoia: do I count as a witness to myself? The note hadn’t specified. The dream-voice had said, “The universe does not like witnesses,” and I am, unfortunately, quite present.

I back away from the mirror until I’m out of my own line of sight. I stand against the cool tile and look down.

“Now.”

The fan keeps spinning. A drop of water plinks from the faucet.

“Now!”

A fist hits the door. “You almost done?”

I jolt. “Yeah, sorry. Just a sec.”

I wash my hands and avoid my own eyes.

On the train home, I stand in the corner by the doors, head down, headphones in with nothing playing. I scan for cameras and count the people.

The condition loops in my head: when nobody is watching.

What bothers me isn’t that it’s difficult. It’s that it’s almost, constantly, nearly-but-not-quite possible. There is always one more possible gaze: a neighbor’s window, a hidden camera, a squirrel. The knowledge that any microsecond of power would collapse the instant some other consciousness glanced my way.

What bothers me more: why would I be given a power whose condition is almost impossible?

Unless it isn’t impossible. Unless it’s already happening.

After two months, the anomalies sharpen.

I miss a bus by a clean thirty seconds, but my phone alarm shows I should’ve had two minutes. An egg I crack into a pan is already cooked on one side. My coffee cools twice as fast as yesterday under identical circumstances. My search history contains terms I don’t remember typing: “temporal perception thresholds,” “quantum observer effect consciousness,” “self-surveillance paradox.”

I start keeping a log. Times I feel a faint pressure behind my eyes, a hollowing of sound, a thinning of the world’s texture.

Sometimes I get déjà vu with muscular intensity, like my bones remember having done this before, this exact awkward interaction with the barista, only smoother, as if I had rewound and tried again and yet all I recall is the failed take.

I begin to suspect a version of me I can’t see.

“What if we’ve been using it?” I ask the darkness of my bedroom ceiling at 3:17 a.m. “What if every time it works, I erase the part where I knew it worked?”

The note is still in my drawer. I read it again. The handwriting is undeniably mine, but slanting, rushed:

You will question if it’s real. That’s how you’ll know it is. Nobody can watch, including you. It only works when you forget to look.

That line wasn’t there when I first read it. I am sure. I am, almost, sure.

I do a new test: I set up a voice recorder on my kitchen counter and sit at the table. I stare at it.

“If I try while you’re recording, will that count as being watched?” I ask the silent device.

Probably.

So instead, I hit record, put my head down, and close my eyes. I slow my breathing. I wait for my mind to wander.

Time passes—subjectively. I think of nothing in particular: grocery lists, emails, a song half-stuck in my head. At some point, I remember the experiment and snap upright. I hit stop.

When I play it back, most is ambience: the fridge, a car, my breathing.

Then, at minute eleven, silence. Not the soft hiss of quiet, but a cut. A bald absence.

Seven seconds later, the world returns: the fridge hum, a chair creak. My inhale, sharp, right before I woke.

I don’t remember those seven seconds.

I replay the segment again and again until my scalp prickles.

The condition, I realize, is narrower than I thought. Nobody is watching includes me. It includes awareness itself. It’s not about eyes or cameras. It’s about attention.

I can only bend time when no one is paying attention, including the person doing it.

Which means I have likely been doing it in the margins of my own awareness: in daydreams, micro-blackouts, those slips between thoughts. Fixing small embarrassments, sidestepping accidents, snipping out the worst seconds and sewing reality back together, roughly enough that I suspect but cleanly enough that I cannot recall.

And every time, the me who chose to freeze, to rewind, to rearrange, dissolves into the seam. Only the edited version continues, blinking, with a vague sense that something is missing.

I test it further, carefully.

I light a candle, set it in front of me, and stare at the flame. I tell myself I will not try. I let my eyes blur until the candle is two flames, then one, then an orange smear. When my head nods forward, I jolt back—and the candle has burned down further than it should have for the time that passed on the clock. Wax pooled like spilled milk.

I have a headache like I’ve been concentrating for hours I don’t remember.

The power isn’t something I can trigger with intention; intention itself disqualifies it. It’s reflexive, a subconscious recoil against observed time, kicking in where I’m not looking. I have no access to the lever, only to the outcomes. I can never seem to freeze time because “I” am the part that is always watching, always narrating, always pinning moments down like insects.

The other part of me—the one that slips loose when I’m not there to see it—wields time like a muscle.

Now that I understand, it gets worse.

Because if the power works only unobserved, then trying to catch it is the same as preventing it. If I set up sensors, cameras, notes, I lace my life with witnesses, and the ability bleeds out. If I relax, if I forget, it resumes, but the me who could confirm it never survives the jump.

I stand in the grocery store again, between condiments and canned soup. The fluorescent lights buzz. A child laughs somewhere. No one is looking directly at me.

I feel the urge to try: to focus, to command, to finally seize that godlike stillness.

Instead, I close my eyes. I let the hum of the cooler blur. I let my thoughts drift, loosening my grip on the second hand’s crawl.

And for a breath, I feel it: an edge, a thin cold place where sound thins, where the air is thick as honey. I feel the possibility of stepping sideways, of rearranging the next thirty seconds like puzzle pieces.

My awareness flares at the feeling. “Oh,” I think. “There it is.”

And in that instant of noticing, it’s gone.

I open my eyes. A teenager passes, earbuds in. An elderly man reaches for peas. The world is seamless.

I can never seem to freeze time.

Which is another way of saying: I am the only thing stopping me. Or saving me.

Depending on what the other me would do, if I ever stopped watching long enough to let them.

samples.prompt: She held onto the night, for she feared what the day would bring.
samples.output:
She held onto the night, for she feared what the day would bring.

It had not always been this way. Once, morning had been a promise: the pale spill of light over the rooftops, the scent of coffee from the corner café, the first tram screeching down rusted tracks. Becka had loved that world—the small sounds and soft colors of people beginning. She had been among them: one more woman with a satchel and a tired smile, walking briskly toward the university’s sandstone arch, ready to talk about photosynthesis to half-awake freshmen.

Now she watched the same rooftops from the narrow balcony of her apartment, arms wrapped around herself, as though she could pin the night in place with the grip of her fingers.

Below, the city hummed. Neon sighed. Headlights slid along slick asphalt in slow procession. A bus hissed at a stop; an argument flared on the sidewalk, sharp words quickly swallowed by laughter. Somewhere someone dropped a bottle, glass exploding into a brief constellation on the street.

The night was imperfect and frayed. That was why she trusted it.

At night, the worst had already happened. Darkness announced itself with brutal honesty: This is the hour when you remember. This is where your fears come out. There were no surprises in it, only replays. She could move through that landscape like one walks through a familiar, wrecked house: careful of broken floorboards, sidestepping shattered frames. The shadows here were catalogued. The ache behind her ribs was known. The absence of a baby’s cry was a silence she could name.

Daylight was different. Daylight pretended.

She had learned that the day, with its brightness, was merciless.

It had been a day when the doctor had pressed his lips into a thin line and said, “I’m sorry, there’s no heartbeat.”

A day when the nurse said “These things happen” in the tone people reserved for weather and accidents you should have anticipated.

A day when the empty car seat waited by the door like an accusation.

Morning had brought those things. Morning had turned her body from promise into tomb.

So she held onto the night.

Inside, her phone buzzed again. She didn’t turn. It had buzzed at seven, at eight, at ten: her sister, her friend Mariana, her supervisor, an unknown number that was probably HR. Messages piled up like unopened bills. She knew what they would say. Checking in. Thinking of you. Just wondering if you’ll be back on Monday. Grief has a timetable in other people’s mouths.

Wind tugged a strand of hair loose. She realized her feet were cold—bare against the chill of the cheap concrete. She welcomed it. It proved her body could still register something that wasn’t inside her own head.

On the balcony rail, her mug waited with its cooling tea, untouched. Below, a taxi door slammed. A woman in a red coat emerged, laughing too loudly. Becka watched her sway toward the entrance of the building across the street. That unselfconscious laughter felt like a sound from another planet.

The sky above the city was not truly dark. Light bled upward from billboards and streetlamps, painting the low clouds the color of old bruises. In a few hours, that false glow would pale at the edges, then yield to the gradual wash of blue.

She had lived over a thousand mornings. It only took one to make them all suspect.

“Becka?” The voice from inside was soft.

She flinched, only slightly. Her sister, Leah, appeared in the open balcony doorway, wrapped in one of Becka’s cardigans. Leah had arrived a week ago, suitcase in hand, pretending she’d always meant to visit.

“You should sleep,” Leah said.

“I’m fine.”

“You’ve been out here for hours.”

“I don’t want to miss it,” Becka said.

“Miss what?”

She hesitated. The truth would sound too fragile, spoken out loud. “Just… being awake.”

Leah stepped closer, the cool night air lifting the ends of her hair. “You’re allowed to sleep, you know.”

Becka shook her head. “If I sleep, it’ll be morning sooner.”

“That’s how time works,” Leah said gently. “Even if you watch every second, it still passes.”

“But if I watch it,” Becka said, “it can’t surprise me.”

Leah’s face folded, just slightly. She’d been trying not to cry in front of Becka, as though grief were a load that could only be carried by one person at a time.

“There isn’t going to be another phone call,” Leah said. “No more bad news. There’s just… the next day.”

“The last day was enough,” Becka said. “It ruined all the others.”

Leah didn’t argue. She came to stand beside her, forearms resting on the railing. “I remember when you used to wake up at five to see the sunrise,” she said.

“Yeah,” Becka said. “I remember that woman. She died in a hospital bed with her child.”

Silence stretched between them. Down the street, a siren wailed, crescendoed, then faded. The ordinary emergencies of the city carried on.

“You could come back to Mom and Dad’s for a while,” Leah offered. “Just until… until you feel less…”

“Less what?” Becka asked, though her voice wasn’t sharp, only tired.

“Less like you have to stand guard against the sun,” Leah said.

Becka stared at the horizon. “I can’t go back there. Everyone knows. They’d say her name like it’s fragile. Or they wouldn’t say it at all. Either way…”

Leah nodded. “Okay. Then I’ll stay here until you get bored of me.”

“You have classes,” Becka reminded her.

“I can take them online.”

“You hate online.”

“I hate you out here alone more.”

Becka almost smiled. Almost.

A thin pale seam had begun forming at the edge of the sky, so faint you’d miss it if you blinked. She felt it the way some people felt storms: a pressure drop, a subtle rearrangement of the air.

“I’m not ready,” she whispered.

“For what?” Leah asked.

“For a day where she still doesn’t exist,” Becka said. “I wake up and remember all over again. Night doesn’t make me remember. Night lets me hold it. I can see her more clearly in the dark.”

She didn’t say: In the dark, I can still imagine the weight of her in my arms. In the dark, I can pretend she is sleeping in the next room.

Leah exhaled slowly. “What if,” she said, “today isn’t asking you to forget her? What if it’s only asking you one small thing. Like… open the curtains. Or drink the tea while it’s hot. Or answer one message. Not all of them. Just one.”

“It was the day that hurt me,” Becka said. “It brought the loss.”

“It also brought her,” Leah said quietly. “The day you found out you were pregnant. The day you heard her heartbeat. The day you bought that stupid yellow blanket because you said pink was a marketing conspiracy.”

Against her will, Becka saw it: the little sonogram print, the gummy blur that had been everything. The yellow blanket folded in the corner of the now-empty room. Mornings when she’d woken with a hand on her stomach, feeling a flutter and thinking, There you are.

“Don’t,” Becka said, flinching.

“Okay,” Leah said. “Okay.”

The seam of light brightened. The city’s neon dimmed in response, like embarrassed guests at a party realizing the host had fallen asleep. The shape of things grew sharper: window frames, antennas, the line of the distant hills beyond the urban sprawl.

Becka felt panic tighten her throat. The day was coming and she was still broken; nothing had been fixed in the night. She had watched and watched, and still the horizon glowed.

“I can’t do it,” she said. “I can’t watch it rise.”

“Then don’t,” Leah answered. “Come inside.”

But Becka’s feet wouldn’t move. Her fingers dug into the metal railing. The first bird called, a single note. Treachery, she thought. The world aligning itself to carry on.

“When the sun comes up,” she said slowly, “it’ll have been one week. Since.”

Leah’s hand found her arm, steady. “I know.”

“A week,” Becka repeated. “As if you can measure losing a person in units of time passed.”

“You measure it in breaths survived,” Leah said. “And you’ve survived a lot of them.”

The rim of the sun broke over the distant buildings, a thin, blinding sliver. She squinted against it, tears rising, hot. She wanted to hate it, this indifferent star, this relentless rotation.

Yet in the sudden gold, the city’s harsh edges softened. The glass caught light and burned. A window opposite them flared open; an old man leaned out to water his plants, same as he did every morning. A kid stepped onto a balcony three floors down, blinking, earphones in. A cyclist rattled by on the street, scarf trailing, late but still pedaling.

The day did not arrive like a verdict. It arrived like a continuation.

She had expected it to shout her loss to every surface. Instead, it did what it always had: threw itself on everything without choosing.

“It’s not fair,” she whispered.

“No,” Leah said. “It isn’t.”

“I feel like if I let it be morning, I’m saying it’s okay. That I’ll move on.”

Leah’s voice was steady. “You’re not saying it’s okay. You’re just saying you’re still here.”

The sun rose, unapologetic.

Becka’s hands loosened on the railing. Her knuckles, blood returning, burned. She did not forgive the day. But the warmth on her face was real.

“I’m still here,” she said, as if testing the words.

“Yeah,” Leah said. “You are.”

Behind them, the apartment was dim, the hallway strewn with takeout containers and untouched condolence flowers. Life, stalled.

Becka reached for her mug. The tea had gone cold. She swallowed anyway. It tasted faintly of bergamot and metal.

“I’ll answer one message,” she said.

Leah nodded, relief too large for such a small concession. “Okay.”

“And then I might go back to bed.”

“That’s allowed.”

“And then,” Becka said, looking out at the spreading light, “tonight I might come out here again.”

“I’ll come with you,” Leah said.

She held onto the night still, in her heart and in the raw places that winced from the brightness. But as the morning unfolded, thin and fragile, she found she could stand within it, too.

Not because she trusted what the day would bring.

But because, for now, it was enough that it had brought her another chance to breathe.

samples.prompt: Nobody expected the Paladin to become the evil ruler in the prophecy, and the Necromancer to become the chosen hero.
samples.output:
Nobody expected the Paladin to become the evil ruler in the prophecy, and the Necromancer to become the chosen hero. That was the part of the story the bards never sang correctly: the way expectation itself laid a curse upon the world.

In the days before the Sundering, when prophecies still glowed bright and unbroken on temple walls, the words were simple:

“In white shall rise the tyrant king,
In black shall walk the hope of spring.”

Priests and scholars laughed. White was purity, the color of the Dawn Orders; black was the mark of forbidden arts. If the gods meant to invert sense and reason, surely they would have said so outright. Besides, the young Paladin, Ser Aldren Vale, gleamed like the sun on new snow. He was every story carved into chapel stone: noble, handsome, immaculate in faith. And the necromancer—the only one the city knew by name—was Lysander Crowe, a gaunt, black-clad exile who spoke with the dead and refused to kneel to the High Temple.

It was easy to assume who would be hero and who would be villain. That was the first mistake.

I remember the morning Aldren took the Oath, because the bells wouldn’t stop ringing. The city poured into the steps of the Dawnspire, faces lifted, trusting. Aldren knelt before the Radiant Flame, white cloak pooling like spilled milk, sword crossed over his heart.

“I pledge my life to the Light,” he said, voice loud, flawless. “To order, to purity, to the will of the divine.”

The Flame burned higher, bright gold flaring toward white. Priests wept. They called it a sign. And I—then an acolyte, too naive to fear certainty—felt warmth settle on my skin and thought, Here is our savior.

I met Lysander three weeks later by mistake.

Necromancers weren’t allowed inside city walls, so he came as a whisper: a rumor caught in market tents, a name muttered with loathing. They said he raised armies of corpses. They said he drank souls. They said he’d been touched by the same darkness the prophecy warned of.

So of course I followed when I heard the guards mention him, as they marched out to “remind the heretic of his place.”

They found Lysander just beyond the northward stones, among the graves of those claimed by plague. Cloaked in worn black, hair tied back loosely, fingers stained with ink and earth, he knelt before a simple wooden marker.

“You were not invited,” he said when the captain raised her spear.

“You are forbidden,” the captain replied. “By decree of the Dawn Council.”

“I am asking,” Lysander said, so gently I almost missed it, “for fifteen more minutes to speak with a child’s ghost.”

The captain snorted. “The dead are gone. You insult them by pretending otherwise.”

“No,” Lysander said, eyes flicking up. Grey eyes; not glowing, not monstrous. Just tired. “You insult them by refusing to listen.”

She ordered him beaten. Nothing fatal. A lesson. Light does not murder, I had been taught; it corrects.

I remember the sound of the first blow, the crack of wood on bone. I remember the boy’s ghost standing beside Lysander’s shoulder—not some horror, just a transparent child, clutching a ragged stuffed hare, watching with wide eyes as his would-be advocate fell.

“Please,” the boy whispered. “Don’t hurt him. He’s helping me not be scared.”

I stared, throat tight. I could see the boy. None of the guards could.

Lysander did not raise a hand to defend himself. When it ended, he lay in dirt and dead leaves. The ghost knelt beside him, sobbing without sound. I did nothing.

That was the second mistake.

Aldren rose fast. Prophecy clung to him like perfume. Monsters fell beneath his blade; miracles bloomed in his footsteps. Crops revived with a touch. He spoke words of shining righteousness and people built statues before he’d reached his thirtieth year.

Yet with each victory, the Light grew harsher.

Laws appeared, etched in brilliant gold that seared to look upon: no contact with “impure” magics; no shelter to those who spoke with spirits; no mourning rites outside Temple sanction. Curfews. Purges. The Radiant Inquisition began as a rumor and solidified into men and women in white enameled armor, faces hidden, tasked with “preserving order from rot.”

The prophecy, the priests claimed, was being fulfilled: the Chosen of Light was purifying the world before the final darkness came.

I became a librarian in the Dawnspire, hidden among scrolls. That was how I first saw the unedited prophecy, the one carved into the foundation stone, beneath all the revisions.

“In white shall rise the tyrant king,
His justice cold, his mercy thin.
In black shall walk the hope of spring,
Who loves the lost and broken kin.
Trust not the sheen of burnished mail,
Nor words that blind with borrowed flame.
The heart that bends to hear the frail
Shall break the night and set aflame
The chains you worship as your law,
The lie you praise as holy awe.”

The later inscriptions had removed those lines.

I remember sitting there, the stone cold under my fingers, and feeling something in me break.

The next time I sought Lysander, I did so on purpose.

I found him at the edge of the Blightwood, kneeling among flowers that grew only where bones lay thick beneath. Ghosts clustered around him like pale fireflies: an old woman humming; a dog thumping an invisible tail; a warrior missing half his skull; the same little boy with the stuffed hare.

“You came from the city,” Lysander said quietly, without turning. “You smell of incense and guilt.”

“I’ve read the original prophecy,” I blurted.

“So have I,” he said. “It was screamed at me by a murdered oracle whose throat was cut to silence her correction.” He turned then, giving me a small smile that did not reach his eyes. “How long did it take your shining king to become what she warned against?”

“He’s not a king,” I said, from habit.

Lysander raised an eyebrow.

By then, Aldren’s word overruled the Council’s. “Temporary,” they said. “For the duration of crisis.” Crisis had become a permanent season. The Inquisition’s prisons were full. The poor starved more neatly, in tidier streets. Golden banners everywhere.

“He believes,” I said. “He thinks everything he does is right.”

“That is the poison,” Lysander replied. “The cruelest tyrant is the one who calls his cruelty devotion.”

“You’re the one in black,” I whispered. “The one in the prophecy.”

“I talk to the dead,” he said. “I mend what I can, speak for those your temples ignore. That does not make me chosen. It makes me unwilling to look away.”

But the Light did not tolerate unwillingness.

The Inquisition came for him as winter bled into spring, led by Aldren himself. By then, Aldren’s armor was no longer bright; it was white, whiter than any metal should be, humming with a high, constant note. The Radiant Flame had changed him. There was less man now, more conduit.

“Lysander Crowe,” Aldren announced at the graveyard’s edge. “By decree of the Holy Council, by the will of the Light, you are condemned for necromancy, sedition, and the corrupting of souls.”

Ghosts gathered behind Lysander: the boy, the old woman, warriors, mothers, nameless dead. They did not look corrupted. They looked like citizens no one had heard.

“I am doing what your Light will not,” Lysander said, rising slowly. “I am listening.”

“You chain them here,” Aldren said, hand on his sword. “You deny them rest.”

“I offer them choice,” Lysander shot back. “They stay because justice half-done still aches. Because your sword solved nothing for them.”

I was there, hanging back, my Dawnspire robes hidden beneath a simple cloak. I should have spoken sooner.

“Aldren,” I called.

His gaze found me. For a moment, there was recognition. We’d trained in the same courtyards once. He’d helped me up when I fell during combat drills, laughing, golden.

“Brother Tomas,” he said. “You should not be here.”

“The prophecy,” I said. My voice shook. “We read it wrong.”

“The prophecy is fulfilled in me,” he said. “In order. In purity.”

“It warned us about you,” I said. “It spoke of a tyrant in white who confuses chains for law.”

Silence. The Inquisitors shifted uneasily.

“The text you read,” Aldren said, slowly, “is corrupted. The Light chose me.”

“The Light,” Lysander murmured, “or those who profit from your certainty?”

Aldren drew his blade. The white edge burned.

“Stand aside, Tomas,” he said. “This creature traffics in death.”

Behind Lysander, the boy’s ghost tugged his sleeve. “He doesn’t listen,” the child whispered.

“I know,” Lysander said softly.

I stepped between them. My heart hammered, but my path felt clear for the first time.

“If you strike him down,” I said to Aldren, “you fulfill the wrong half of the prophecy.”

Aldren’s eyes shone with too much light. “If he is truly chosen, let the gods prove it.”

He lunged.

Lysander did not raise bone walls or shadow storms. He raised his hands and called, not to darkness, but to everyone Aldren had ever “saved.”

The graveyard flared.

Not with black, but with a pale, gentle radiance as hundreds of ghosts appeared. Men Aldren had executed without trial. Villages burned “for purity.” Children buried in plague pits when temple healers withheld aid from “unworthy” districts.

They stood between Lysander and the descending blade.

Aldren froze as his path filled with faces. Faces he remembered. Faces he’d been told were necessary losses.

“You did this to us,” a woman said.

“In the name of Light,” murmured a soldier.

“We were not rot,” whispered the child with the hare. “We were your people.”

The sword trembled. Aldren’s perfect certainty cracked, but he clung to it like a drowning man.

“Lies,” he rasped. “Illusions.”

“Truth,” Lysander said. “I could have bound them as weapons. I have not. I asked if they wished to speak. They said yes.”

The Radiant Flame’s power surged around Aldren, rejecting doubt, scorning humility. His armor flared blinding white, trying to burn the ghosts away.

But the prophecy had named him: tyrant king, mercy thin.

“Look at you,” Lysander said quietly. “Drowning in Light so bright you cannot see.”

There is a point where light, unshaded, ceases to illuminate and only blinds. Aldren had passed that long ago.

He roared and struck. The blade sliced through a dozen ghosts, harmless, then bit into earth at Lysander’s feet. The backlash of divine force rippled outward. It should have incinerated the graveyard.

Instead, it shattered Aldren’s armor.

We saw the Light leave him like breath on a cold day. He staggered, suddenly just a man again, horrified, gasping.

“What have I done?” he whispered.

Lysander stepped forward, still ringed by ghosts. His black cloak stirred in a wind that smelled of turned soil and rain.

“You believed you could outsource your conscience,” he said. “You let prophecy and priests decide for you who was worthy of compassion.”

“I wanted to save them,” Aldren said, choking.

“Then start by listening,” Lysander replied.

I spoke then, reading aloud the lines that had been cut, letting the words hang over broken armor and watching the Inquisitors lower their blades, eyes wide.

No heavenly trumpet blared. No god descended to crown a new champion. Instead, something subtler shifted: a recognition, a recalibration.

In the years afterward, the bards tried to make it neat. To say Aldren was possessed and Lysander flawless. That is another lie.

Aldren carried his guilt like a cross and worked, quietly, to mend what he had shattered. Some forgave him; some never did. That was their right.

Lysander was never comfortable with the word “hero.” He continued to walk the graveyards and gutters, speaking with the lost, challenging laws written in unyielding gold. Hope of spring, they called him, though he remained robed in black—a reminder that life grows richest from dark soil.

As for me, I keep the prophecy in its original form and read it to anyone who will listen.

The lesson was never about cloth colors or convenient monsters. It was this:

Beware the righteous who never doubt.

And never, ever trust a world that decides a man is damned before it hears him speak.

samples.prompt: A pill is invented which eliminates the need for sleep. It has one side effect.
samples.output:
The pill went to market under the name Lucidium, though nobody called it that for long. They called it Awake.

Awake was small, blue, and bitter if it lingered on the tongue. Its pitch was simple and obscene: one pill, each morning, and you would never need to sleep again. Not less sleep, not a “reduction in fatigue.” Eliminated. Your body would idle at night like a machine on standby, your mind as clear at 3:47 a.m. as it was at 10:15 a.m. No microsleeps, no cognitive decay, no hidden costs.

Well. One cost.

It was printed on the label, technically. “May intensify subjective experience of time.”

The CEO described it in interviews as “a mild alteration in temporal perception, easily adjusted to.” A rounding error.

For most people, the first week felt like a miracle that had finally arrived on time. Commuters watched the sunset, ate dinner, and then, instead of collapsing on the couch and dissolving into half-conscious scrolling, they had another full eight hours. Some learned piano. Some picked up second jobs. Parents spent nights building Lego skyscrapers with their kids, then left the house at dawn without the grit of exhaustion behind their eyes.

There were think pieces about the end of the night. Studies on how Awake users didn’t just function without sleep; their bodies quietly reallocated the “repair time” into continuous micro-maintenance throughout the day. No increase in cancer. No mysterious organ failure. The classic trade—time now, death sooner—failed to materialize. Life expectancy stayed the same. Just... 30% more waking hours to live inside it.

It took longer for the side effect to separate itself from the sales language.

For Lena, it began on what would have been Day 12, if she were still counting days by waking. She was in her kitchen, rinsing a mug. The ceramic slipped. The mug fell, hit the floor, and shattered. She watched a shard spin, the little flecks of coffee scatter. It took forever.

Not metaphorically. She had time to read the brand name on the inside curve of the mug as it rotated past her nose. She had time to see her own reflection in the arc of its motion. She had time to think: This is wrong.

The neurologist, a compact woman with brisk, rehearsed sympathy, explained it for her.

“Awake modifies the orexin system and several thalamocortical loops,” she said. “Objective chronology is intact. But your brain’s internal clock—your felt duration—stretches. It’s like running your consciousness at a higher frame rate. Ten minutes may feel like twelve. An hour may feel like ninety minutes. It’s non-linear and grows with continuous use.”

“How much does it grow?” Lena asked.

The neurologist hesitated. “It varies.”

The numbers emerged online, of course. They always do. Forums of early adopters mapped it out informally. On average, after a month on Awake, a calendar hour felt like about seventy-five minutes. After six months, an hour felt like two. The effect plateaued around the two-year mark, where each “day” felt like it contained roughly the subjective content of three.

“You’re making time,” the ads had boasted.

The truth was worse and better. You weren’t making time. You were stretching its fabric and living more densely inside it. To your body, you still had 24 hours between heartbeats one and two, ten years between thirty and forty. But inside your skull, you had more. More thoughts. More feelings. More waiting.

By the time the government hearings began, there were about sixty million registered users.

The companies argued that the side effect was a gift. “You effectively gain decades of conscious life,” one executive said, smiling in that careful, practiced way that suggested he’d rehearsed the phrase in a mirror. No physiological penalty. No sleep. And your mind, your precious you, just… got more of itself.

The opposition called it psychological torture in a blister pack.

They brought in testimony.

A logistics manager from Chicago: “At first it felt like a superpower. I’d get so much done. Then, about four months in, meetings got longer. Everything did. Waiting in line at the DMV felt like hours stacked inside hours. I’m not talking about boredom; I’m talking about density. Like I could think five different ways about how much I hated it before my number even changed.”

A hospice nurse: “Nights used to be a blur of alarms and soft steps. Awake stretched them. Sometimes I had to sit with a dying patient for what felt like days compressed into a single shift. I saw every tremor, every shallow breath, and I had time to imagine a thousand better deaths I couldn’t give them. I can’t unlive that.”

A programmer: “My hobbies turned into careers, and my career turned into a life sentence.”

The question no one could dodge came from a senator on the second afternoon of hearings. She was seventy, gray hair pulled back, Awake-branded capsule in a small plastic bag in front of her like evidence.

“How does it feel,” she asked the lead developer, “to know your invention makes prison longer? A ten-year sentence: same number of heartbeats, but twice or three times the felt duration. Is that not, effectively, cruel and unusual punishment?”

He replied, carefully, “Awake is voluntary.”

It was, and it wasn’t, of course. Employers began to prefer candidates who could work the “night shift” without fatigue. Countries with strained healthcare systems quietly encouraged adoption among staff. “Not mandatory,” they said. Just “incentivized.” A bonus here. A promotion track there.

Lena worked in emergency medicine. The pressure came couched in admiration.

“You’d be incredible with Awake,” her attending said. “No circadian crash at 4 a.m. Think of your patients.”

She thought of her patients. She thought of the patients who never arrived because they had fallen asleep on the steering wheel. She thought of the additional lives she could save with eight more usable hours.

She swallowed the pill the next morning.

When the side effect took hold, it wasn’t in a crisis, but in an ordinary moment. She was holding a baby in the pediatric ward, soothing him while his exhausted mother handled paperwork. The baby’s eyelids fluttered, heavy. The room smelled like disinfectant and milk. The clock on the wall ticked.

Each tick arrived like a separate event she could walk around and study. Between them she had time for entire chains of thought: about the baby’s chart, his mother’s shoes, the forgotten sandwich in the break-room fridge, the soft pulse in her own neck. Her mind stretched to fill the expanded space. She was fully present, acutely so; she saw beauty in the slope of his tiny ear, the trust in his small fist. She also saw the mother’s cracking composure in too much resolution to bear.

She gave Awake to the baby’s mother long before she ever admitted it to herself: the belief that if suffering had to exist, more time didn’t make it kinder. It magnified. A toothache that once ruined an evening now colonized what felt like days.

Support groups formed, both for those on Awake and those stubbornly off it. A cultural split emerged. The Sleepers kept their soft eight-hour vanishings, their dreams, their nightly annihilation. Awakies, as the media inevitably named them, looked at that and saw waste, an obscene burning of a third of a short life.

“You’re throwing away years,” an Awake influencer said in a viral clip, eyes bright at 3 a.m. “I’ll have lived 120 years in the time you live 80, even if we die the same day.”

“Maybe I don’t want a long movie,” one Sleeper replied in a stitched video. “Maybe I want a good one, with scene breaks.”

There were other side effects on paper—slight upticks in anxiety, in existential rumination—but the core remained: time had become uneven, stratified. There were people living thinly and people living thick.

The pill’s defenders leaned into the narrative of empowerment. “You can learn more. Love more. See more art, read more books, spend more time with your children, reinvent yourself five times over. The side effect is only problematic if you choose to fill that extra felt time with emptiness.”

But that assumed everyone could choose.

For a warehouse worker, nocturnal shifts stretched into subjective eternities under fluorescent light, with nothing changing but the pallet numbers. For a refugee stuck in bureaucratic limbo, each waiting-room hour bloomed into a labyrinth of fear. For a widower alone in an apartment, the nights no longer offered oblivion; grief poured unbroken from dusk to dawn to dusk again, no natural reset.

Crime changed. A five-minute beating was now, to an Awake victim, a slow, detailed horror. Torture without sleep deprivation protocols became more effective; no need to keep them awake, they were already cursed with endless wakefulness and elastic time. Human rights groups raised alarms. Legislators wrung their hands: ban the pill and strip millions of their “extra life”? Regulate time perception?

You couldn’t outlaw a subjective state.

Lena lasted ten months.

By then, each real-time hour felt like nearly two. Nights in the ER became epics: she saved more people. She knew she did. She had time to double-check doses, to notice subtle rashes. She could stand in a trauma bay and think through five treatment algorithms between one beep and the next.

She also had time to replay every mistake in high-definition slow motion.

One morning, after a particularly long night in which a boy bled out despite everything, she found herself in the hospital stairwell between the fourth and fifth floors. The fluorescent bulbs hummed. Her hand rested on the metal railing. Dust motes floated in a beam of grimy light.

She realized she had been standing there for what felt like hours.

She realized she had been thinking the same thought, looping: I cannot do this for another fifty years of this length.

On the official guidance site, “discontinuation” was addressed in a bright, reassuring font. You could stop Awake at any time. The need for sleep would return within days. The altered perception of time would recede gradually, like the afterimage of a bright light. Most users, they promised, normalized within six months.

“Normalize” was doing a lot of work.

You could not unknow that an hour could contain so much.

Lena tapered. On the first day without Awake, fatigue slammed into her like a withheld verdict. She fell asleep in the early evening and slept twelve hours. Her dreams were frantic, overfull. It was as if her mind was trying to cram itself back into the narrow bottle of ordinary time.

Months passed. Her sense of duration softened, but it never returned to what it had been. Minutes no longer stretched like elastic, but they did not snap back entirely. Waiting in traffic, she caught the old echo, the sense that she could unfold more thought into each red light if she leaned.

Society adapted, as it always does. Awake became normalized, then regulated, then optimized. Kids grew up never having slept, their baseline a rich, slow flood of consciousness squeezed into stable biology. The Sleepers became a cultural minority, sometimes envied, sometimes pitied, sometimes mocked.

And running quietly underneath it all was the thing no billboard phrased, no paper quite pinned down:

The pill did not make more time.

It only made you feel every second in its full, unblinking length.

For some, that was a miracle.

For others, it was the side effect.

samples.prompt: A schizophrenic person's experiences and/or how they live their life (Possible trigger?)
samples.output:
Mornings always began with the checklist.

Keys. Wallet. Phone. Meds.

Not “medication,” because that sounded like something clinical and distant, a word you might find printed on a clipboard. “Meds” was faster, smaller, less accusing. He tapped the orange pill bottle with his thumbnail, the rattle of tablets sharp in the quiet kitchen, and swallowed them with lukewarm tap water. He hated the way they stuck to his tongue for a second before sliding down—a tiny reminder that this day, like all days, came with conditions.

The apartment was too loud that morning. The neighbor’s TV upstairs, the pipes, traffic three stories below, and the low, restless murmur that lived somewhere just behind his ears. He checked the stove twice to make sure it was off, then once more because the third voice whispered, “You left it on, you know you did.” He touched each burner. Cold. He sniffed the air. No gas. He still took a picture with his phone as proof for later.

That was new: using his phone as an external memory. His therapist had suggested it. “It’s not about distrusting yourself,” she’d said. “It’s about giving the anxious part of you evidence.” Evidence: photo of stove, timestamped, unambiguous. When the whisper started up again at the bus stop, he could look, breathe, and say, “No, see, we checked.”

He locked the door. Jiggled the knob. Walked down one flight of stairs, went back, checked it again. The old woman at 3B opened her door, saw him testing the handle, and smiled politely like she didn’t see anything strange.

Small mercies.

Outside, the city pressed in: too many colors, too many reflections in windows, too many overlapping voices. Most of them were real. Most. He put his headphones on—no music, just the illusion of a barrier. People tended to leave you alone if you wore headphones. Also, if he started hearing anything else, anything that didn’t quite sync with people’s mouths moving or the rhythm of traffic, he could pretend he was just reacting to a song.

“Don’t go,” the soft voice said as he reached the bus stop.

It was the gentlest of them. It sounded like his mother, but he tried not to think of it that way.

“I have work,” he murmured, keeping his lips barely moving. He’d learned to layer his oddness under normal habits: mumbling like you’re on a call, glancing around like you’re just thinking. “We talked about this.”

“You’re tired,” it said. “You could rest. You could stay safe.”

The bus wheezed up to the curb. He stepped on. Clung to the pole. Work was not safe, exactly, but it was structure. Structure was what held the ground up.

He worked part-time at a small print shop. His boss knew he had “a condition,” but not the details; Human Resources had the details, sealed in a digital folder. Official words: schizophrenia, chronic, stable with treatment. The first time he’d seen it written in his chart, he’d felt oddly detached, like he was reading someone else’s story.

At the shop, the day unfolded in small, manageable steps. Load the paper. Check the proofs. Smile at customers. Check that the numbers match. The printer’s hum was comforting; it drowned out the murmur in his mind, turned inner voices into background static.

Between jobs, he scrolled his phone. In one mental health forum, a stranger wrote: “I am not my diagnosis.” He clicked “like.” Set the phone down. The third voice—this one harsher, male, impatient—snorted.

“Pretending doesn’t make it untrue,” it said. “You’re broken, and everyone sees it.”

He flinched, fingers tightening around a stack of flyers. He knew this voice well. The meds had dulled it, blurred its edges, but it had been with him since he was nineteen, since the night he’d stayed up for three days convinced the light patterns on the wall were a code from the government.

He reminded himself: a thought is just a thought. A voice is just a symptom. The therapist’s words again, rehearsed like catechism. Name it. Frame it. Do not negotiate with it.

“I’m working,” he thought, carefully, like he was speaking through glass. “You don’t get to talk to customers.”

He expected a retort, but the printer jammed at that moment and his focus snapped outward. Sometimes it felt like the world did him favors on purpose. He knew that was a dangerous line of thinking. Paranoia wore friendly masks, too.

A woman came in near closing, frazzled, clutching a thumb drive. “I’m so sorry, I know it’s late, but I need fifty copies of this for tomorrow morning—”

“No worries,” he said, and meant it. He liked tasks with clear beginnings and endings. The document was a flyer for a community mental health event: bold letters, calm colors, a list of resources. He stared at the word “schizophrenia” on the page, the way it sat quietly alongside “depression” and “anxiety,” unitalicized, unhysterical.

“Looks good,” he said, voice steady.

“Thank you,” she replied. “We need more people to see this stuff as… just part of health, you know?”

He nodded once too quickly. “Yeah. We do.”

On the bus ride home, the city was dimmer, softer around the edges. That’s when things were usually worse—when he was tired, the day’s energy used up on smiling, on cross-checking reality, on passing. He watched reflections in the dark window: his own face, the ghost of rows of seats behind him, a flicker of something else as the bus passed under a broken streetlamp.

He blinked, focusing on his reflection. Brown eyes. Frown line between them. Stubble he’d forgotten to shave. No one standing behind him. He turned his head and checked anyway. Just a man in a hoodie staring at his phone, a woman holding a sleeping child.

“Paranoid,” the harsh voice sneered. “Pitiful.”

“Overly cautious,” he corrected in his mind. “Don’t be dramatic.”

This, too, was practice: reframing. He’d learned that language mattered. If he called himself crazy, he’d spiral. If he called himself careful, he could sometimes stand up a little straighter.

He got off two stops early to walk. The night air was cool, and the movement helped. He counted his steps in fours, a private rhythm. At sixteen, he touched his keys. At thirty-two, he checked the pill bottle in his pocket for tonight’s dose. Small rituals, anchors. People called them odd; his therapist called them coping strategies. He preferred the second term. It sounded like a skill instead of a flaw.

At home, he reheated leftover pasta. The fork scraped against the plate. The sound made him wince.

“Microwave is bugged,” the soft voice said abruptly.

He froze. It had been months since that particular delusion. The microwave hummed innocently on the counter.

“No,” he said quietly. The word came out louder than he intended. “We’ve been through this. It’s a microwave.”

“They’re listening,” the harsh voice added. “They laugh when you take your meds.”

His chest tightened. He turned the fork over in his hand. The air in the kitchen thickened, edges warping.

He picked up his phone with fingers that shook only a little and opened the notes app. A list waited there:

- What is the evidence?
- Has this happened before? How did it end?
- Did anyone get hurt last time you ignored the voices?
- Call for help if needed.

He inhaled slow. Answered silently:

Evidence? None. The microwave is a box that heats food. Last time you believed it was bugged, you didn’t use it for a week and got sick from eating out. No one ever confronted you with recordings. Ignoring the voices before has not harmed you.

He tapped out a short message to his sister: “Hey. Rough night. Can you remind me the microwave is just a microwave?”

The reply came fast: “100% just a microwave. Pinky swear. Love you. Proud of you for checking.”

The tightness eased, not all at once, but enough.

He took his meds. He washed his plate. He checked the stove again, took another photo. He put his phone on the nightstand, screen down to cut the glow. The apartment was quiet now. The upstairs neighbor had turned off the TV. The pipes hummed softly.

“Did good today,” the soft voice said.

He hesitated. This voice was tricky because sometimes it was kind. Sometimes kindness could lead him somewhere dark. He’d learned not to trust praise too easily, even from inside his own skull.

“No commentary,” he whispered into the dim. “We’re going to sleep.”

For a moment, there was silence.

Then, in his own voice, unlayered, simple: “I’m trying.”

He lay on his back and stared at the ceiling. This was what people didn’t understand: it wasn’t a horror movie every second. It was maintenance. It was managing. It was learning which thoughts to believe, which to greet like eccentric neighbors and send politely on their way. It was side effects and appointments and forms and a thousand tiny acts of resistance against the idea that he was nothing but a diagnosis.

Tomorrow, he knew, would start again with the checklist.

Keys. Wallet. Phone. Meds.

He would get up anyway. And that, more than anything the voices could say, was the truth of how he lived.

samples.prompt: A door leads to a different location each time it is opened.
samples.output:
The first time it happened, Lena thought she was still dreaming.

She opened her apartment door, expecting the bitter hallway draft, the chipped linoleum, the neighbor’s bicycle half-disassembled against the wall. Instead, she stepped onto a beach made of glass.

It chimed under her bare feet, pieces of sea glass worn smooth and milky by invisible waves. The air tasted like oranges and salt. Towering above her was a sky so profoundly blue it tinged toward violet, with three pale moons stacked like coins during daylight. Lena blinked, heart pounding. Behind her, when she reached back, her hand found the cool brass knob of her own apartment door, standing unsupported in the sand like a prop on a stage. The wood was the same flaking white, the same dent at hip level where her moving dolly had slammed two summers ago.

Carefully, she stepped back inside. Her apartment smelled of coffee and dust and the leftover fear from last night’s insomnia. She closed the door.

Then she opened it again.

This time: a frozen field beneath a black sky. Stars in brutal focus. Wind like razor blades. She slammed the door.

Lena put both palms against the wood, her breath shallow. She waited. Opened it once more.

Sunlit stone, wide marble steps, a breeze carrying incense and something like roasted cinnamon. A city spread below the steps, all golden domes and white arches, red banners fluttering. People moved in the distance: tiny, colorful, purposeful. Somewhere a bell rang with a clear, effortless note.

Lena shut the door very slowly.

She checked her phone for the date. It was still Tuesday. She checked the kitchen clock. Still 6:42 a.m. Her morning mug of coffee was cooling on the counter. A ring of sunlight rested exactly where it had before. Nothing in her life had the decency to look different when everything had just come undone.

On the fourth opening, the door led to the stairwell again. Fourth-floor landing. Ugly gray paint. The bicycle. Lena laughed, half in relief, half in hysteria. “Okay,” she said aloud. “Okay. Stress dream.”

She took her keys, locked the door, walked down the real stairs, and went to work.

All day, the memory pressed against the back of her eyes: the glass beach, the frozen field, the golden city. She misfiled reports. She poured sugar into her coworker’s black coffee instead of her own. At lunch, while others talked about a new show, Lena’s hand flexed, remembering the knob, the grain of the wood, the feeling that the world had hinges she’d never noticed.

When she got home that evening, she stood in front of her door and hesitated.

This is stupid, she told herself. You’re exhausted. Open the door. It’ll be the hallway. It’ll be your dusty plant and the broken lamp and—

She opened it.

A forest. Light pooled green in the air. The smell was wet earth and sap, heavy and alive. Trees rose, pale and straight, bark spiraling, leaves translucent like veins. At eye level, tiny moth-like creatures with glass wings drifted, leaving trails of faint luminescence that folded and unfolded like soft handwriting.

“Oh,” Lena whispered.

She didn’t step through. She might get lost. She might not find her door again. She might stay and never have to answer another email.

A moth-thing landed on the frame, its wings catching her reflection in fractured pieces. It tilted its head at her.

“Sorry,” she said. “Wrong address.”

She closed the door.

The next morning, she opened it onto a subway platform she’d never seen, the signage in an alphabet like curls of smoke. The day after that, a storm-lashed cliff above an ocean that roared with voices instead of waves. Then a desert with two suns, the heat slamming into her like an accusation. Then a dim library whose shelves rose into darkness, ladders drifting of their own accord, pages turning themselves.

She began to keep a notebook by the door, jotting down each place:

Day 3 – purple sand, green water, empty horizon, no sound.

Day 4 – snowy city, silent cars gliding, no visible drivers, smell of metal.

Day 5 – hallway.

Day 6 – coral cave, water overhead like glass, enormous shapes moving beyond.

Every time, her own apartment waited behind her like a save point. She experimented. She counted to ten between openings—still different. Tried opening, closing quickly, opening again—always different, except for occasional returns to the real hallway, which felt stranger each time it appeared. The ordinary world thinned, like something seen through fogged glass.

She told no one. How could she?

It took nine days before she stepped all the way through.

The door opened to a hillside of tall silver grass under a lavender sky. Warm, mild wind. In the distance, slender towers rose, not vertical but gently varied like reeds in a pond. The air buzzed with a sound almost like flutes. Lena stepped forward, heart hammering. The grass brushed her bare ankles like cool hands.

She turned to check. The door stood there, alone, as always. On its other side, her apartment flickered in familiar beige. It felt like a memory already.

She wandered only a little: just beyond the crest of the hill, where she saw the towers were built around enormous trees that grew sideways, trunks braided with luminous vines. She caught a glimpse of people or not-quite-people gliding along bridges grown from the branches, their forms blurred by distance or by some softness woven into her perception. The world seemed to hum in one giant, comfortable chord.

She went back before she could talk herself into staying.

After that, not stepping through became harder.

Days and places blurred:
- A cavern where phosphorescent stalactites sang when she exhaled.
- A city of rain where people wore mirrors instead of faces.
- A small quiet field of dandelions beneath a normal blue sky, so painfully ordinary she cried.

The door never repeated a place exactly, though some felt like cousins: similar skies, related architecture, recurring scents. Sometimes the worlds looked dangerous: jagged lightning close enough to taste, shadows with too many joints. Those she shut on instinct, chest tight.

She tested limits. Left a mug halfway through; when she closed the door, the mug thudded to the floor of her apartment, wet with some thin blue liquid. She stuck a hand out once, felt gravity tilt sideways, her arm flesh and bone under rules that changed mid-skin. She snatched it back, tingling for hours.

Once, she opened onto a room that was almost her kitchen. The tiles were the wrong pattern, and the fridge was a shade too green, and all the magnets spelled words in a language she did not know but almost understood.

“Hello?” she called.

Her own voice answered, faint from another doorway. The door swung shut on its own. She did not sleep that night.

Weeks passed. The notebook filled. She went to work, came home, opened universes. Laundry piled. Plants died. Emails went unanswered. Her life curled around the door, orbit tight and inescapable.

The question, unspoken at first, took on words: Is this for me?

On a Tuesday that might have been three months in, she opened the door and found a bench in a park. Just an ordinary park, ordinary people: joggers, dog walkers, parents with strollers. Pigeons. Litter. A sky on the edge of rain. It could have been any city. It might have been hers.

A man sat on the bench, maybe her age, in a blue jacket. He looked up as if he’d been waiting. His eyes went straight to the frame she stood in.

“There you are,” he said.

Lena froze. “Do you… see this?”

“The door?” He nodded. “Of course.”

Behind her, her apartment waited. In front of her, an ordinary park and someone who seemed to know.

“How long?” she asked.

“Since I was twelve,” he said. “Yours?”

“Months,” she said. It sounded childish.

He smiled, not unkindly. “It doesn’t stop,” he said. “If that’s what you’re wondering.”

“Does it mean something?” Lena asked. “Is it broken? Am I?”

He shook his head. “It’s a door. It opens. That’s what it does.”

“Why different every time?”

“Would you really want the same place?” He tilted his head. “Or are you hoping for one that feels like enough?”

She thought of the silver grass hillside. The sideways trees. The glass beach. The almost-her kitchen. “Have you found one?” she asked.

“I’ve found many,” he said. “Stayed a while. Left. It remembers you can always leave.”

“Can it go away?” Lena asked quietly.

“If you ignore it long enough.” His gaze flicked to something over her shoulder. “Most people manage. They convince themselves it’s a phase. Or an illness. Or a metaphor.”

“And you?”

He spread his hands. “I keep opening.”

Lena swallowed. “Is that… good?”

“It’s honest,” he said. “It’s also lonely.”

They looked at each other. Pigeons shuffled. A child laughed too loudly. The air smelled like impending rain.

“What if one day the door opens and there’s nothing?” Lena asked.

He considered. “Then you close it,” he said. “And you learn to make where you are enough. Until it opens again.”

A drop of rain landed on her wrist. She glanced back. Her apartment looked dim, cramped. Familiar.

“Will I see you again?” she asked, turning back—but the bench was empty. The blue jacket gone. Just pigeons and damp wood.

Her heart lurched. She stepped out, onto the park path, looking around. No sign of him. The door, when she spun, was still there, standing free, her doorway cut into air.

“No fair,” she muttered.

She went back inside. Closed the door. Leaned her forehead against it. She listened. Nothing but her clock ticking, the fridge humming.

She could stop. Sell the apartment. Move. Surely the door would stay, nailed to this place like a problem for the next tenant.

But she knew, with the quiet certainty of gravity, that the door was hers, not the building’s.

The next morning, when she opened it, the smell hit first: coffee, toast, rain on pavement. The hallway outside her actual apartment. Her neighbor’s bicycle. The stairs.

She almost laughed, almost cried. She stepped out into the familiar hallway, closed the door behind her. It clicked. Solid.

On the way down, she passed Mrs. Alcala from 3B. “Morning, Lena,” the woman said.

“Morning.”

Outside, the city was the same smeared gray. Cars. Sirens. Gum on the sidewalk. Real, heavy, persistent.

All day at work, Lena felt an ache made of possibilities. Afterward, standing before her apartment door with groceries in one arm, she hesitated only a second.

Then she smiled, very slightly, at no one at all.

“Let’s see,” she whispered.

She opened the door.

Wind carrying the scent of pine and snow rushed past her, and distant, from somewhere over an unseen ridge, came the sound of voices singing in a language she didn’t yet know but wanted to.

Lena put the groceries down carefully.

This time, when she stepped through, she pulled the door closed behind her—not all the way, just until it almost latched, leaving the smallest crack, enough for a line of her world’s stale hallway light to fall across the new snow like a promise, or an escape route, or a hinge between choices that was—like the door—always, inexplicably, hers to open.

samples.prompt: That 6-year-old girl you demonically possessed turns sixteen today. It's been a good run and you want to move on to someone else, but she won't let you out.
samples.output:
When she turns sixteen, I buy her a cake.

I do not have hands, of course, so the candles are lit by Mrs. Harper, whose fingers tremble as if arthritis has arrived a decade early. The cake is pink and white and far too sweet. The frosting reads: HAPPY BIRTHDAY, LILA! with a heart where the dot above the exclamation point would be, as if the punctuation itself is in love with her.

She beams. She always beams.

“Make a wish,” her mother says.

I know what wish she’s making. She’s been rehearsing it in her head for a month. It’s not about the boy who sits next to her in chemistry, or about the college brochures hidden under her mattress, or the car she covets. It’s about me.

Don’t you dare.

She smiles slightly wider. Our secret smile. Then she blows out the candles.

Smoke curls upward; wax meets air. The kitchen lights flicker for half a heartbeat. Her mother flinches; her father glances up at the chandelier as if the wiring is at fault.

I feel her wish like a hook in my chest.

Stay.

It is not my favorite sensation.

Sixteen years ago, she was a small, damp thing, screaming in a crib that still smelled of paint and talcum powder. Her parents had prayed for protection against nightmares. They had meant well. They had said the wrong words.

I came through the crack.

At six, she barely understood what I was. That was the charm of it: the way her mind took sharp edges and softened them into imaginary friends. She named me Whisper. She knew I was more than that, even then, but children are stubbornly fond of naming monsters something gentle.

I was supposed to be a passing shadow: a tempest in her tiny life. A few years of coaxing her toward mischief, of savoring her fear like sugar on my tongue. Then I would slip away into another house, another frightened heart.

But Lila took to me with an intensity I had not anticipated.

When she woke screaming from night terrors, I coiled around her memories and drank the flavor of her fear. But I also murmured in her head, pushing away the worst images, turning the clawed hands into kittens, the teeth into clouds. It was selfish. A calm host is a more stable anchor. That’s what I told myself.

“Are you real?” she whispered once, huddled under unicorn sheets.

Real enough, I answered.

“Will you leave?”

Soon.

“Don’t,” she said, so quietly her lips barely moved.

I remember being amused. They all said that, in the beginning—children enamored with the idea of having a secret. But they grew up; they forgot, or believed they had. I always left before they could look too closely, before belief turned into armor.

Lila did not forget.

At eight, she stood up to Cody Marsh when he tried to take her lunch. She said, “Don’t touch my stuff,” with the weight of my presence behind her teeth. Cody stepped back, eyes wide, and never tried again.

At ten, she hid in the bathroom at school, panicked by a math test. I slid through her veins like cool water, focused her thoughts, gave her the answers. She aced it, of course. That night her father ruffled her hair and told her she was “too smart to worry so much.” She looked at the mirror above the sink and mouthed, Thank you.

I should have left then. I knew it. She was growing more adept at feeling me, at leaning on me, at expecting me. The line between host and parasite must remain blurred for this to work. Clarity is dangerous.

When she was eleven, her uncle cornered her in the garage after Thanksgiving dinner, whiskey on his breath, his hand heavy on her shoulder.

That was the first time I truly showed her what I could do.

He did not touch her again. In fact, he never came back at all, not after the “accident” on the highway three weeks later, when his car inexplicably veered into a ravine.

“You did that,” she whispered in bed, her eyes burning in the dark.

Yes.

“Thank you.”

The gratitude sat oddly in me. I am not in the business of gratitude. I am in the business of hunger and bargains and slow corrosion. But I did not correct her. It was pleasant, being thanked.

Twelve: she began to test her edges.

She stared down a teacher who belittled her in front of the class. She stole the answers to a quiz from a locked drawer without touching it. She watched a boy trip the quiet girl in the hallway and, without moving, watched him fall as if yanked backward, his nose cracking against the floor. She laughed then, a small delighted sound. Later, lying in the dark, she whispered, “Show me how,” and I did, against my better judgment.

Demons are not meant to mentor.

By fourteen, she no longer pretended I was an imaginary friend. She knew.

“What are you?” she asked.

You know what I am.

“A demon,” she said. “A parasite. A voice. A power.”

All correct.

“And you’ll leave someday.”

Yes.

“When?”

Soon.

She was silent for a long time. “What if I say you can’t?”

You don’t get to choose.

I felt her smile. It was new, that smile. Sharp in all the places my kind finds unnerving.

“We’ll see,” she said.

Possession is not a one-way tether. The host influences the invader in tiny, insidious ways. I am old, older than the bricks of Rome and the salt roads they walked on. I have worn emperors and beggars. I have slid, unnoticed, through popes and warlords and children whose names history never learned. None of them ever held me.

Until Lila.

Sixteen candles. Sixteen years of shared skin. I am tired.

I’m leaving tonight, I tell her as she picks at the frosting with a fork hours later, alone in her room.

She pauses mid-bite. “No, you’re not.”

I feel an odd chill. Hosts say many things. No one has said it like that.

It’s time. You’re grown. You don’t need me.

“I don’t remember asking what I need,” she says. She licks sugar from her thumb. “I’m not done.”

I press against the edges of her skull, the sutures of bone, the invisible membranes where I slip in and out. There is always a seam. Always.

The seam does not give.

Lila?

She sets down the plate. “You taught me to look. To push. To pull. Did you think I wasn’t paying attention?”

My kind do not feel nausea, but there is a lurching in me that mimics it.

What did you do?

“I watched you,” she says calmly. “Every time you left a fingerprint. Every little static shock that made Mom drop a glass. Every time a shadow moved wrong. I traced the pattern. You’re not the only one who can learn from a bond.”

I sharpen, forceful now. Release me.

“No.”

I reach for the crack between her heartbeats, the resonance where soul and something-other meet. It’s where I’ve always slipped through. It’s where I came in.

It is sealed.

“How—”

“I thought about what you are,” she says. “You’re a squatter with bad boundaries. You’re power without a body. You’ve been wearing me like a dress since I was six. But dresses get tailored.”

I slam against her, hard enough that her vision should blur. She doesn’t even flinch.

This is not how this works.

“It is now.” She shrugs. “You had sixteen years to go. You didn’t. That’s on you.”

I taste something unfamiliar: the edges of my own fear. It’s bitter.

Others will come. You can’t hold me forever. There are rules.

She laughs, delighted. “Oh, the rules. You mean the ones nobody ever teaches us because we’re supposed to be helpless? You break into a little girl’s head and think there are rules.”

There are cosmic balances. There are structures older than—

“Yes,” she interrupts. “And they bend. I watched you bend them. I just pushed further.”

I can feel it now, the architecture she’s built while I was indulging my arrogance. Wards made from our memories. Knots tied in the threads of her aura. Traps.

“You thought you were coasting,” she says. “You thought you were grooming. But you were training.”

Let me go, Lila.

“No,” she says again, and this time the word is a binding.

I struggle. I roar. Objects in her room shudder. The window rattles. The lamp flickers, flares, explodes.

Her mother calls from down the hall, “Lila? Everything OK?”

“It’s fine, Mom!” Lila says brightly, not taking her eyes off the cracked bulb. “Just dropped something.”

The door doesn’t open. It never does, not when it should.

I throw myself against the weave of her being. I try every exit I know: through breath, through blood, through dream.

She has closed them all.

You can’t keep me. I am a storm. I am famine. I am legion.

She moves to the mirror above her dresser, studies her reflection. Our reflection. Her dark hair, her steady eyes, the faint smirk that is entirely new.

“You’re a roommate,” she says. “And your name is Whisper. Remember?”

That was a joke.

“It’s a collar,” she counters softly.

This isn’t love, I say. It comes out almost a plea.

She tilts her head. “You murdered my uncle for me.”

You wanted him gone.

“You held me when I was alone.”

It was convenient.

“You gave me strength when I was small.”

You were a better anchor that way.

“And you stayed,” she says. “That’s the one thing you weren’t supposed to do. Do you know what loyalty looks like to someone like me?”

I do not answer.

“It looks rare,” she says. “It looks worth holding onto.”

I am not loyal.

“You are now,” she says, and I feel the bind pull tighter.

Outside, the last smear of sunset drains from the sky. In other houses, other rooms, other children shiver as shadows lengthen. I should be there. I should be free, sliding into a new vessel, renewing the ancient game.

Instead, I feel her hands—metaphorical but excruciatingly effective—close around my essence.

You’re making a mistake, I say. I will ruin you. I will corrode you from within.

“Maybe,” she says lightly. “Or maybe I’ll ruin you.”

That is not possible.

She smiles into the mirror, and I see myself trapped behind her eyes: an ember in an ocean.

“You showed me how to be feared,” she says. “Now we’re going to see how far we can go.”

We.

She turns off the ruined lamp, leaving us both in the dark.

I pull. I claw. I whisper the old names of doors that open for my kind.

None of them open.

“Happy birthday to me,” she murmurs.

And because there is nothing else to do, and because her will closes around me like a fist, I stay.

samples.prompt: You're a history major. Your final exam is to travel back in time and successfully pass as a normal, everyday citizen. It's not going well.
samples.output:
I arrived in 1372 with eyeliner on.

Not intentionally. The machine’s calibration hiccuped, the light went sideways, and I stumbled into a muddy alley with my tote bag half open, my phone in my hand, and thick black liner still smudged around my eyes like I’d been crying at a concert. Which, to the milling peasants outside the alley, apparently read as: “possessed.”

“Jesu!” someone gasped.

I reflexively said, “Hi.”

That did not help.

Professor Havel’s voice echoed in my memory: “Your grade is based on immersion. You must pass as a normal, everyday person for forty-eight consecutive hours. No one may suspect that you are out of place. If you are burned as a witch, you fail.”

He’d said that like a joke. Standing there, clutching my phone and wearing sneakers, it suddenly didn’t feel like one.

A woman made the sign of the cross at me—at my face, specifically, my eyeliner. I remembered too late: elaborate cosmetic use is suspicious for lower classes in this period. I was dressed in a rough wool kirtle Havel’s grad students had sewn, but the department hadn’t mentioned “don’t bring 21st-century raccoon eyes.”

“Bless you,” I tried. “Lovely…weather…we’re having.”

The sky was choked with smoke, something was definitely on fire, and it had just started to drizzle. This got me three more crosses and a kid pointing at my shoes.

“Where are your pattens?” he demanded.

My brain scrambled. Pattens—wooden overshoes. Right. I opened my mouth, and this is where I made my second mistake.

“I, uh, forgot them.”

Forgot them. Like I’d forgotten my keys. The boy’s face narrowed. The woman’s narrowed. Behind them, a man in a stained tunic eyed me like I might start levitating.

“I’m not a witch,” I said quickly.

Technically, that was my third mistake.

—

I ducked into the nearest doorway that didn’t smell entirely like dead goat and tried to reset. I had prepared for this. I had spent three years memorizing crop rotations, saints’ days, diet, price fluctuations in rye, and the correct way to address a reeve. I had spent one expensive, nauseating afternoon in the department’s olfactory simulator specifically to acclimate to “high-medieval urban environment,” which, unfairly, had been kinder than the real thing.

I checked my pocket. My “coins” were accurate replicas of English silver pennies—wrong kingdom, wrong year, wrong monarch, but they were at least metal discs. My phone was dead; time travel fried it. Fine. That was in the syllabus.

“Plan,” I whispered. “You are a normal person. You are so aggressively normal.”

I practiced my cover story: I was from a small village a few miles away. Visiting an aunt. I had papers from the department printed on convincingly old parchment, with someone’s best guess at fourteenth-century handwriting. I adjusted my headscarf to hide the eyeliner, took a breath, and stepped out into the street.

“Excuse me,” I said to a passing woman. “Where might I find…your…market?”

This was at least historically plausible. Markets existed. People asked directions.

She squinted at me. “You French?” she asked.

Oh, God. Accent. I had not practiced accent. The department’s “vernacular immersion” module had met at 8 a.m. I remembered hitting snooze.

“N-no,” I said, and because my brain is wired by standardized testing to always be more specific than necessary, I added, “I’m from up north.”

“Up north where?”

I could name six medieval counties and their taxable value per hide, but precisely zero of them surfaced. “Near the…uh…river,” I offered weakly.

She looked at me like I’d told her I was from “left.”

“Market’s that way,” she said finally, jerking her chin. “Mind your tongue, stranger.”

I shuffled off, heart pounding, trying to walk like my shoes weren’t made by Nike. Chickens scattered. People stared. I tried to smile less, then realized that now I was making intense eye contact with strangers and not smiling, which was almost worse.

At the market, I decided: Step one, purchase bread. Normal people buy bread.

I approached a stall. “Good day,” I said, in what I hoped was a humble yet confident tone. “One loaf, if you please.”

The baker eyed my headscarf, my shoes, my too-clean hands. “A farthing.”

I pulled out a coin and immediately realized a vital oversight: I did not know what a farthing looked like here. Havel had gone on and on about relative values, but he’d never said, “By the way, learn all actual coins by sight.”

I picked a small coin at random. The baker’s expression shifted from bored to suspicious.

“This is wrong,” he said. “Where’s this from?”

“From…home,” I said lamely.

“Your home has the king’s wrong face?”

I leaned in, squinting. Right. Monarch mismatch. “Oh! That one. Silly me.” I tried to take it back, fumbled, dropped my entire purse. Coins clattered all over the muddy ground, flashing wrong faces and unfamiliar symbols, a tiny, glittering cascade of anachronism.

A circle formed.

“Those are strange,” someone murmured.

“Foreign,” someone else said.

“Witch,” the first woman from the alley hissed, having evidently followed me, because of course she had.

“I’m an exchange student,” I almost said.

Instead, I blurted, “They’re…blessed! Pilgrim tokens.”

Not on the reading list, but it was all I had.

“A pilgrim with no pattens,” the kid said. He’d followed her, too. Excellent.

“Where’s your badge, then?” a man asked. “You been to Canterbury? To Rome? Show it.”

We had covered this in second-year Medieval Piety. I had written—God help me—an actual paper on pilgrimage badges.

“It…was stolen,” I said.

By now, I had successfully constructed the most suspicious person imaginable: a shoe-less, coin-dropping, eyeliner-smeared pilgrim with a stolen badge and a fake king. The baker narrowed his eyes.

“Serjeant!” someone shouted.

Panic flared. Getting arrested wasn’t technically “burned as a witch,” but the rubric had used the word “seamlessly,” and nothing about this was seamless.

I bolted.

Which was mistake four, because normal, everyday, guilty-of-nothing citizens generally do not sprint away from bread stalls shrieking “Sorry!” in modern English.

Behind me: yelling. I careened down an alley, nearly trampled a pig, and ducked into a church, because that felt right historically and also I am, at my core, a coward who believes in stone walls.

The dim, incense-heavy quiet hit me like a wall. It was cooler, and I nearly cried with relief. A few people knelt in prayer. A priest glanced up.

I knelt in the back pew and tried to become wallpaper.

“Okay,” I whispered to myself. “Regroup. People are weird here. You know this. That’s the whole point of your major. You’re prepared.”

I absolutely was not prepared.

I noticed, with a distant academic part of my brain, that the stained glass was simpler than later centuries, that the wood of the pew was rougher, that the smell was thick with tallow and humanity and no lemon-scented anything.

“Are you ill, child?” the priest asked, appearing at my elbow.

He was younger than I expected, with wary eyes.

“I’m…” I summoned everything I knew. A normal medieval woman, stressed, alone, in trouble. “I’m far from home,” I said, which was the most honest thing I had said all day. “I’ve lost my…my uncle. And my—” I almost said “papers.” Too bureaucratic. “—and my tokens.”

He studied me. “Your tongue is strange,” he said.

“I had a fever,” I tried. “It made my words…wrong.”

Fevers did that, right? Probably. There were case studies. Or maybe that was a novel.

He made the sign of the cross, murmured something in Latin. I latched onto that.

“Pater noster, qui es in caelis,” I whispered. I had memorized several prayers because they were testable content. For once, academia aligned with survival.

He relaxed the tiniest bit.

“You should stay,” he said. “For Vespers. For safety.” His gaze flicked toward the door, where two men with clubs had just appeared, scanning the congregation. “The serjeant is seeking a young woman with strange coins.”

“Unfortunate,” I said, then realized that was not the correct pastoral response. “I mean—God protect her.”

His mouth twitched. “Indeed.”

I stayed.

The hours dragged. I tried very hard to be normal. I copied others: kneel when they knelt, bow when they bowed, don’t sing too loudly. The priest watched me. Once, he whispered, “From where, truly?”

My academic brain tried to answer with latitude and longitude. I swallowed that.

“A village.” I named one I remembered correctly. He nodded.

“Ah,” he said. “Then your priest is old. Has he yet died?”

He was testing me. I thought of Havel’s lectures: “Names matter. People talk.”

“I have been away,” I said cautiously. “I know little news.”

Not wrong. Just eight hundred years of news.

After Vespers, the serjeant came in, spoke quietly with the priest. They both glanced at me. I practiced breathing like a person who was not one question away from collapsing the entire temporal protocol.
