“This is Alis,” the priest said finally. “She is under the Church’s protection tonight.”

Alis. That was almost my real name, and for a moment the overlap steadied me.

The serjeant eyed me. “Show me your coins.”

I had, during the psalms, carefully separated the most egregious ones, the shiny ones, the obviously wrong ones, and stuffed them into my boot. The rest, I spilled into my palm: a few dull replicas that might pass in low light, one blessedly correct penny Havel had slipped in, perhaps as a curve-ball.

He grunted. “Watch you don’t cheat honest folk,” he said. “Times are hard.” But his suspicion eased. Ironically, hiding evidence of my time crime under church supervision was the most historically accurate thing I’d done so far.

When he left, my exhale felt like deflating.

“Thank you,” I whispered to the priest.

He shrugged. “You pray correctly. And you look terrified. The wicked are seldom so afraid of being thought wicked.”

I almost laughed. “You’d be surprised,” I said.

That night, sleeping on a church bench in borrowed scratchy blankets, I catalogued my failures like footnotes.

Day One:
- Mismanaged cosmetics
- Mishandled currency
- Broke basic rule: never declare you’re not a witch
- Ran from mild questioning
- Lied poorly about geography
- Nearly derailed local economy with counterfeit numismatics

On the other hand:
- Successfully blended into liturgical practice
- Leveraged clerical authority for protection
- Avoided immolation

Partial credit?

In the morning, the priest handed me a coarse roll and a bit of cheese.

“You have kin here?” he asked.

“Yes,” I lied more calmly now. “I’ll find them.”

“Walk with purpose,” he advised. “Those who look lost are prey.”

I stepped out into the waking street. The air stank. My headscarf itched. But people moved around me without staring. I walked like I belonged, like the weight of my hidden, illegal coins was just the usual anxiety of a woman in a world that barely noticed her.

I bought bread with the one correct penny. I said little. I nodded a lot. No one accused me of witchcraft before noon.

Maybe this was the trick. Not encyclopedic knowledge, not perfect accent, but shutting up. Being smaller. Normal here meant invisible, especially for someone like me. I hated how well that fit—and how well it worked.

At the forty-eight-hour mark, the recall band on my wrist warmed.

When the alley blurred around me, when the lab’s clean, filtered air hit my face, I was laughing and crying at once.

Havel peered at me over his glasses. “So,” he said. “How did our historian do?”

I wiped my eyes, smearing medieval dirt and modern eyeliner. “I didn’t die,” I said. “I think I was almost normal. Or at least not fatal.”

He checked his tablet. “Local disruption minimal,” he said. “Arrest avoided. No witch-burnings triggered. The serjeant lists you as ‘confused girl, possibly foreign, harmless.’”

“Harmless,” I repeated. I wasn’t sure if it was a compliment.

He smiled. “B-plus. Work on your money next time.”

“Next time?” I squeaked.

He gestured at the humming machine. “History is field work, Ms. Carter. And you have potential.”

I thought of the priest covering for me, of the suspicious baker, of the way “normal” had meant keeping my head down, swallowing my questions, letting the world close over me. It wasn’t in the textbook that passing would feel like that. That the cost of being seamless was being silent.

“Okay,” I said. “But first thing, we fix the eyeliner.”

samples.prompt: : You're not like the other heroes. You're lazy, feeble, ugly, not a born leader nor particularly charismatic. You have no natural nor supernatural talents save for one: The laws of probability are completely screwed with you.
samples.output:
I shouldn’t have survived my own birth.

The midwife said so. My mother cried so hard she didn’t hear, but the midwife told anyone else who’d listen. “Black cord, blue baby, no breath. Then poof—just like that. He coughs. Like he changed his mind halfway.”

That’s how my story starts: with a mistake corrected by something that wasn’t supposed to happen.

You’d think that would make me special in some impressive way. No. I grew up ugly, weak, and uninterested. My reflection looked like it had been drafted from spare parts: nose a little too wide, jaw too soft, eyes that never quite pointed in the same philosophical direction. I had the muscle tone of boiled cabbage. The village boys learned to wrestle and chop wood; I learned how to nap in improbable places. I failed at every trade apprenticeship: fumbled nails as a carpenter, mislabeled jars as an apothecary’s assistant, once accidentally salted bread with lye for a baker. No one died. Against all odds.

I didn’t realize something was wrong with probability until I was sixteen and the bandits came.

They rode in at dawn like a cliché, all smoke and shouting. I hid. Obviously. Heroes run toward trouble; I crawled under a cart with nothing but a potato sack to my name and an overwhelming desire to continue existing.

The bandit chief grabbed my ankle. Of all the ankles beneath all the carts, he got mine. He yanked me out, raised his sword, and his horse—his big, loyal warhorse—chose that exact moment to have a catastrophic, explosive fart.

The noise startled the horse, which reared. The bandit chief lost his grip, stumbled, and brained himself on the cart’s axle. Dead. Just like that.

Silence, for a beat.

Then one of our militia, who had been about to surrender, cried, “He felled their leader!”

I was still lying on my back, eyes shut, bracing for a kind of death that smelled less like manure. When I opened them, everyone was staring. The bandits were shaken. Their leader, legendary for surviving three hangings and a bear trap, lay twitchless at my feet.

One of the bandits screamed, “He’s cursed!” and bolted. The others followed, hands making warding signs.

The villagers cheered.

We should be clear: I did nothing. I did not make the horse fart. If I had that power, my life would be much more interesting in an entirely different way.

But that’s how it goes with me. The unlikely, the statistically absurd, the “this never happens”… happens. Constantly. For me. Around me.

You might call it luck. But luck has direction, intention. Gamblers chase it, priests preach about it. Mine doesn’t care what I want. It just flips coins and laughs when they land on their edges.

After the “bandit incident,” they called me Hero.

I tried to correct them.

“I didn’t—”

“You saved us!”

“The horse—”

“He’s humble, too.”

I got a free beer for a month and three proposals from people who clearly needed better eyesight or better standards. It was flattering in a horrifying, please-stop-complimenting-me way.

Mostly, though, I remained me: lazy, tired, not good at anything except continuing to not die.

And then the king’s courier arrived.

Apparently the bandit chief had been a lieutenant of Malrec the Bleak, sorcerer extraordinaire, enthusiast of monologues, collector of skulls. Malrec, irritated, had sent horrors and plagues and tax auditors across the kingdom. The Prophecy—a tiresome, self-updating scroll maintained by the Royal Seers’ Collective—had named a Savior.

Me.

To be precise, it read: “He who slew the Black Wolf with naught but courage and chance shall topple the Bleak One when hope is thin.”

Corrections were submitted (“It was the horse”), but prophecies are like bureaucrats. Once ink dries, reality must accommodate.

So they conscripted me.

I argued. “Look at me. Do I look like Savior material?”

The courier examined me. “You’re… distinctive.”

“I get winded walking downhill. I’m allergic to steel. Blades. The metal. I sneeze.”

“The Scroll is never wrong.”

“It’s been wrong six times this year.”

“Yes,” he said. “And every time, improbably, its wrongness led to the correct outcome. Which only proves its higher rightness.”

You cannot win an argument with faith, especially institutional faith with a wax seal.

That’s how I ended up in a mismatched suit of armor (I broke out in hives), mounted on a mule (horses disliked me; mules were indifferent), with a company of actual heroes: Sir Aldren the Radiant, Lady Kael of the Twin Blades, High Magister Ilyra, and two dozen soldiers who could have crushed me with a stern glance.

They were not thrilled.

“Stay behind us,” Aldren said. Golden hair, golden armor, golden everything. “Do not draw attention.”

“That,” I said, “is my best skill.”

Here’s the problem they discovered: the closer you are to me, the more probability… misbehaves.

Our first encounter was with a troll on the Stonebridge. Classic arrangement. It roared, demanded tolls, promised to eat at least one of us.

Aldren strode forward. Heroic things gleamed.

“Stay back,” Ilyra hissed at me. “You distract the threads.”

“I’ll just—hide behind this rock,” I said.

I tripped. Naturally. I fell forward, arms flailing, and the loose rock I dislodged skipped—ba-dunk, ba-dunk—down the slope, ricocheted off a smaller stone, arced gracefully through the air, and struck the troll squarely in its single exposed nostril.

The troll inhaled sharply in surprise, snorted the rock backward into its nasal cavity, choked, flailed, and pitched itself off the bridge.

Dead.

Everyone stared at me.

“I said stay back,” Ilyra whispered. “Not… assassinate the troll with geology.”

“I was trying to keep my skull unbroken,” I said.

Aldren frowned. He did not like solutions that ignored swordsmanship.

That kept happening.

Ambush in the pines? The assassins’ bowstrings frayed simultaneously. All of them. One arrow turned around mid-flight and skewered its own archer. Kael swore that was not physically possible.

Dragon attack? The beast dive-bombed us, took a deep breath for flame, inhaled—unseen—a mouthful of bees from a nearby hive it had disturbed. Dragon shrieking, fiery chaos. It crashed into a lake, boiled it, and fled. No casualties. Except the bees.

“You’re doing that,” Kael accused me later.

“I’m literally asleep half the time,” I said. “I’m doing very little.”

“Exactly,” she said. “And yet.”

They tried experiments. Ilyra cast divinations, traced swirling glyphs in the air.

“Hm,” she said.

“What?” Aldren demanded.

“According to the numbers,” she said slowly, “his continued survival versus circumstances faced yields a probability curve that… doesn’t. Exist.”

“In Common,” I said.

“He should be dead,” she said. “Repeatedly. Spectacularly. Yet he’s not. The more likely he is to die, the less likely it becomes.”

“That seems good,” I offered.

“For us, perhaps not,” she replied. “The field distorts around him. Causality stutters. The enemy’s odds plummet. Our odds… jitter.”

That jitter got worse the closer we drew to Malrec’s tower.

Bridges collapsed after we crossed. Traps triggered themselves early. Once, a hail of poison darts shot harmlessly into a passing flock of geese, which then dive-bombed our pursuers.

Malrec took notice.

We were three levels up the tower when his voice boomed around us.

“ENOUGH!”

He appeared in dramatic violet smoke, robes like shredded night, skulls, etc. It was all very on-brand.

“You,” he said, pointing a gnarled finger at Aldren. “Radiant wretch. I have studied your tactics.”

Then he turned to Kael. “Twin Blades. I have mapped your every step.”

To Ilyra. “Witch. Your sigils are flawed.”

Then his gaze landed on me.

He faltered.

“…Who are you?”

I stepped forward by accident; someone shoved me.

“Don’t engage,” I whispered.

The stone under Malrec’s staff chose that moment to give up on its structural ambitions. A hairline crack widened. His staff slipped, hit the floor, misfired. The spell meant to disintegrate Aldren rebounded into the tower wall, which turned into a colony of startled frogs.

We all blinked.

Malrec tried again, snarling. A chain lightning arc fizzled, hit a chandelier, bounced to his own runes, cooked his summoning focus. The ceiling sneezed fire. His undead guards’ armor buckled as if embarrassed and fell off their bones.

He stopped. Really looked at me.

“You,” he said slowly, “are an anchor of improbability.”

“That sounds unflattering,” I said.

“You distort outcome-space. How are you alive? Statistically, you are an insult.”

“That,” I said, “I have heard before.”

Malrec is, to his credit, a genius. He realized fast that conventional attacks were backfiring. So he tried something clever.

He targeted me with protection.

“I shield you from all harm,” he intoned. “I wrap you in certainty. No randomness shall touch you. Perfect order, perfect safety—”

The spell hit me.

Reality made a sound like a harp string snapping.

The tower shuddered. Runes misaligned. All the painstakingly balanced probabilities of Malrec’s enchantments—paths that required precisely timed fates—met the black hole of me: the one person around whom probability refused to behave.

It backlashed.

The protections inverted. His wards saw him as the anomaly, the threat to order. Chains meant for demons coiled around him. Seals meant to contain chaos locked on his aura. The tower swallowed its master like a bureaucratic error correcting itself.

Malrec vanished, bound in his own contingency maze.

The blast knocked everyone down. Except me. I was standing in a small circle of floor, untouched. The frog-chandelier swung gently.

Aldren groaned. “What… happened?”

Ilyra wheezed, laughing. “He tried to make our friend here normal.”

Kael pushed herself up. “You weaponized your uselessness.”

“That’s not… intentional,” I muttered.

The Royal Seers later called it Deterministic Rejection Recoil. I call it: Malrec Tried to Fix the Glitch and Got Tech-Supported.

Word spread quickly, as it does when an evil sorcerer is abruptly demoted to abstract cautionary tale.

They threw a ceremony. Banners, trumpets, speeches about bravery. They put me in polished armor that made my skin itch. The king offered wealth, lands, a title.

“Sir—” he checked his notes “—Improbable.”

“It’s just Ren,” I said.

“You saved the kingdom,” he insisted.

“I tripped near things,” I corrected. “Reality did the heavy lifting.”

He laughed. Thought I was modest.

Here’s the honest part: I am not good. I am not wise. I am not noble. I’m tired most of the time. I forget names. I am, objectively, hard to look at in certain lighting. People project greatness where it doesn’t exist because they need stories where the weak matter.

So, am I a hero?

Heroes choose. They sacrifice. I mostly endure. But when everything unlikely keeps breaking in your favor, the choice becomes less about what you can do, and more about what you’re willing to let happen.

The world expects me now. When something impossible needs to occur, they send for me.

“Walk past this cursed altar and maybe it malfunctions.”

“Attend this negotiation so assassins slip on their own poison.”

“Stand nearby while we test this experimental airship.”

I complain. I drag my feet. I nap in corners. I remain catastrophically unqualified.

But I go.

Because the laws of probability are screwed with me, yes.

But for once they’re screwed on the right side.

samples.prompt: Gods as we know them do not exist, and instead are elected every 10 years by the entire planet. This year however, you have been elected as 'God'.
samples.output:
My phone started vibrating at 3:07 a.m., which already felt like a cosmic joke. If you’re going to tell someone they’ve become God, you’d think you’d at least wait until sunrise.

I ignored it. It buzzed five more times.

The sixth call came from an unknown number tagged as “Global Elections Council,” which I had mentally filed under “legally mandated spam.” I jabbed the answer button, ready to hang up on some post-election survey.

“Ms. Reyes?” a voice said. Calm. Measured. Media-trained.

“Yeah.”

“Congratulations. Preliminary counts confirm it. You’ve been elected.”

“Wrong number,” I said. “I voted for the coral reefs.”

A soft pause. “No ma’am. You, personally, have been elected. As God.”

I sat up. The room was that grainy shade of dark blue that made everything feel temporary. “That’s not funny.”

“It isn’t meant to be. We’ll need you at the international hub in six hours for confirmation and… activation.”

I laughed, a short, brittle sound that didn’t sound like me. “You can’t possibly—”

“Ms. Reyes, the Ten-Year Divinity Referendum concluded at midnight GMT. Your name is on 4.2 billion ballots. The world has chosen. Please check your official app.”

The call cut.

I stared at the ceiling, my heart pounding. Two minutes passed before I opened the Election app, thumb clumsy, half expecting a glitch notice.

Instead, my own face stared back at me from the screen: “DIVINITY CONFIRMED (PENDING OATH). GOD-ELECT: MAYA REYES.”

Below that, a live counter of heart emojis and death threats scrolled upward in multiple languages.

The thing about living in a world where God is elected every ten years is that it’s easy to forget how strange it is. You grow up with debates and campaigns the way earlier generations had weather reports. “Who’s running this cycle?” “Oh, the ocean collective, a centenarian Buddhist influencer, a sentient forest in Brazil, and a sixteen-year-old from Lagos who promises free dreams.”

We used to have myths. Burning bushes, stone tablets, inscrutable wills. Now we have televised debates and policy briefs.

I never ran.

I signed a petition once, three cycles ago, demanding term limits on metaphysical interventions. I attended exactly one rally, mostly for the snacks. I did not submit an application essay, which every candidate technically has to do to appear on the ballot. I did, as a joke, record a podcast episode called “If I Were God for Ten Years” in which I ranted for forty minutes about climate reparations and mandatory empathy education.

Forty million shares. Memes. Soundbites. “Maya for God” graffiti I assumed was ironic.

Apparently not.

By the time the Council jet touched down, I’d seen the numbers. Verified in three separate systems. Observers from every major bloc signed off. No anomalies. No hacks.

“You’re not the best candidate,” one Council member told me bluntly as they walked me down a long, glass corridor. “But you’re the one they agreed on.”

“Reassuring,” I muttered.

“God is never the best candidate,” another said. “God is the minimum viable consensus.”

The “activation chamber” was disappointingly plain. No stained glass, no thunder. Just a circular room with white walls, a ring of cameras, a biometric altar that looked like a dentist’s chair, and a pulsing crystalline structure suspended in mid-air like someone had convinced geometry to glow.

“The Divinity Lattice,” they said. “Old tech. Before it was formalized, it was rituals and accidents. Burning bushes. Voices. Prophets fried like circuits. Eventually someone reverse-engineered it. Now we call it the Franchise.”

“So you plug me into this,” I said, pointing at the hovering polyhedron, “and I become what, exactly?”

“You become the executive interface to the underlying fabric of causality,” the tech explained. “Limited omniscience within defined jurisdictions. Probabilistic manipulation rights. Conservation-of-miracles constraints apply. You can’t undo death beyond allocation thresholds, can’t violate consent parameters, can’t alter constants. You can bias storms. Nudge synapses. Speak in dreams. Sign off on anomalies.”

“And I do this for ten years?”

“Unless impeached by supermajority or incapacitated,” they said pleasantly.

I laughed again, because what else was there?

“Why me?” I asked. Not the numbers. Not the math. The real question.

They all went quiet. Finally, the oldest one, a woman with deep, weather-cracked cheeks, said, “Read your own manifesto.”

“I never wrote—”

She tapped a screen, and my own words appeared: a transcript of my stupid podcast, scraped, stitched, polished by millions of eyes and algorithms until it read like a covenant.

- “No more selective miracles for the already comfortable.”
- “If there’s a God, and they can help, they owe us transparency.”
- “Choice matters. No forcing anyone into goodness. Just making cruelty harder and kindness easier.”
- “If I had that power, I’d start with the quiet fixes nobody could monetize.”

“People heard this,” she said. “They turned it into a platform. You never contradicted it. You became the negative space everyone could live with.”

“Great,” I whispered. “I’ve been elected for being vaguely palatable.”

“It’s either you,” the tech said, “or a committee. And we’ve seen how that goes.”

The Lattice hummed, like it was impatient.

“Sit,” they said.

When skin met metal, I felt nothing for a heartbeat. Then everything.

“Don’t resist,” someone said, from very far away.

The world unfolded.

It wasn’t like seeing, not at first. It was like becoming aware that everything had always been a single, tangled equation, and I was suddenly allowed to read the annotations.

I felt the spinning, sweating panic of a woman in Mumbai realizing she was pregnant. I felt the thin, sharp hunger of a boy in Kentucky scrolling through photos of food. I felt tectonic plates negotiating grudges. I tasted auroras. I heard whales reciting the same complaint: Too loud.

No voices boomed. No angels sang. It was data with feelings, probabilities soaked in grief and joy.

“This is too much,” I said, or thought, or beamed.

The Lattice replied by compressing. It filtered, folded. The volume dialed down to something survivable. Instead of everyone, I got samples. Instead of always, I got queries.

“This is your omniscience sandbox,” the tech’s voice floated in. “Full access takes centuries to withstand. You get a humane mode.”

I focused, experimentally, on a single flicker: a girl in Aleppo, hand hovering over a cup of stolen medicine. Her brother burning with fever. The law would cut off her hand. If she didn’t take it, he’d die.

Old theology would love this. A tidy moral dilemma.

My newfound protocols whispered constraints in my mind like legal disclaimers.

- You may not override free will directly.
- You may not alter past events.
- You may not cause disproportionate systemic harm to benefit a single node, unless…

Unless.

I shifted probability.

The shopkeeper, in another flicker, remembered his own son’s fever years ago and left the cup a little closer to the edge. The girl’s fingers closed around it. No alarms. No thunderbolt. Just a small mercy.

It cost me something. A faint tightening in the Lattice, like a budget note.

“This is how it works?” I thought. “Tiny edits?”

“And large ones, if you dare,” came a voice, not the techs, but the memory of all the gods-elect before me, etched into the system.

I sifted upward.

The ice sheets. The CO2 curve. The looping arguments in climate councils. My own past petitions. “Start with the quiet fixes,” I’d said.

I could tip a hurricane. Turn it. But where? There were always people on the other shore. I could re-seed clouds. Robust side effects. I could make fossil fuels slightly less profitable, renewables slightly more irresistible. A thousand invisible nudges.

I did it. It felt like leaning on the scales of a universe that wanted to balance, but had been fooled by short-term greed.

Somewhere, markets twitched. Somewhere, a lobbyist felt a sudden need to resign.

“Careful,” the ancient-gods-voice murmured. “You move systems, they move back. Overdo it and they revolt. Underdo it and they despair. Ten years is nothing.”

“So why bother?” I asked, not quite aloud.

Images, memories, histories: ten-year gods who’d ended pandemics, who’d redrawn coastlines gently so people had time. Gods who’d whispered directly into the hearts of would-be dictators until their certainty cracked. Gods who failed and were impeached, who tried to turn love mandatory and collapsed under the backlash.

The world never voted for the same person twice. Even the best were retired. “No more forever,” humanity had said, when they built this system. “No more unaccountable eternity.”

I thought I understood, growing up. Sitting there in the Lattice, I actually did.

Being God, in this version, wasn’t about control. It was about stewardship with witnesses.

They brought me out for the oath. The cameras blinked red. The world watched as I stood in a simple gray jumpsuit, eyes still adjusting to mortal lighting.

“Do you accept the mandate conferred upon you by global democratic process,” the Council Chair read, “to operate the Divinity Lattice for the preservation and dignity of life, the moderation of catastrophe, and the defense of autonomy?”

“I do,” I said. My voice didn’t echo. Good.

“Do you accept that in ten years’ time, or earlier by due process, you will relinquish all such powers?”

“I do.”

“And do you understand that your term begins now?”

In the corner of my vision, I saw a map of the world, hot spots pulsing. So many crises queued, each tagged with urgency, moral hazard, political fallout.

I thought of all the gods before, mythic and elected. I thought of how prayer apps would spike tonight, how skeptics would scoff, how somewhere a little girl was about to ask her mother, “Is the new God nice?”

I couldn’t promise that.

I could promise this:

“I understand,” I said.

The Lattice settled into me like a second spine. Outside, a tropical storm lost three degrees of fury. In Aleppo, a brother’s fever broke. In a boardroom in Houston, someone looked at a spreadsheet and saw, for the first time, that oil had become a terrible investment.

The world had chosen, not wisely, not foolishly, but collectively.

For ten years, I would be their God.

Not omnipotent. Not omnibenevolent. Just—elected.

And that, terrifyingly, might be the most honest kind of divinity we’d ever devised.

samples.prompt: Begin "After the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river."
samples.output:
After the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river. 

The current was fast from the thaw, swollen and impatient, so the revolver was gone almost before it left my hand. One dark blur, then a small, hard splash, and the river swallowed the steel like it had been waiting all winter to be fed.

Behind me, the street remembered to breathe.

Chairs scraped in the saloon. A horse stamped. Somewhere up the road, a baby started crying late, as if the sharp sound that split his small world had to travel the long way around his house first. The dust was still hanging between me and the man on the ground, lit gold by the last of the sun, like the whole town was holding a lamp over the body so no one misunderstood what had happened.

“Harris,” someone whispered behind me. “Sweet Christ.”

I didn’t turn. I knew the voice and knew the tremor in it, knew it meant the story had already started to write itself. They’d say Marshal Eli Harris had outdrawn Cole Redding in front of Shaw’s Saloon at sunset on a Thursday, that it had been clean, that it had been the only way.

I could still feel his weight in that single instant before he fell; the echo of his hand brushing my vest like he was reaching for me instead of his weapon. His eyes, wide and astonished, like he’d really believed he’d be faster.

“Go home,” I said, still facing the river. “Ain’t nothing to see.”

The lie sat in my throat like a stone. There was plenty to see; I just couldn’t stand to look at any of it yet.

Behind me came the shuffling retreat of boots on hard-packed dirt, slow at first, then gaining confidence as people reminded themselves they were alive and unperforated. Doors closed, hinges creaked, murmurs rose like low bees. Only one set of footsteps came closer instead of farther, and I knew those, too.

“You took his bullets,” said Lydia Carr from somewhere at my shoulder. She was close enough for me to smell the starch and soap in her dress, close enough that she had to tilt her head to look up at me. “That necessary?”

“He ain’t gonna need ‘em,” I said.

“He ain’t gonna need his gun neither,” she said. “But we usually bury men with their things. Or let someone take the metal. River don’t pay fair prices.”

“It ain’t for money,” I said. “It’s so nobody builds him into something he wasn’t.”

She was quiet for a beat. Lydia wasn’t much older than me, but she’d been in town twice as long, running her father’s store since he started coughing blood. She’d watched the railroad surveyors come through, watched the town throw up false fronts and gaudy claims, watched five different men try to style themselves legends with pistols and posters. She had a long look at foolishness.

“Too late for that,” she said. “He came in with his own legend pinned to his teeth. Folks were hungry for it.”

I finally turned.

Cole Redding lay sprawled half in the shadow of Shaw’s porch, hat off, hair damp with sweat at the temples. His gun hand was open, palm up, fingers curled like they were still forming around the grip that had betrayed him by being a half-second slower than mine. His shirt was good quality, clean this afternoon. There was a red bloom high on the left side, neat. I am, if nothing else, a precise man.

“Go on inside,” I told Lydia. “Tell Shaw to send some boys to get him. He ought to be laid out proper.”

She studied my face, searching for something she wasn’t finding. “You gonna write it up already?”

“I’ll write it up.”

“You gonna write it like it was self-defense?” she asked, accusation and worry braided together.

“It was,” I said.

“If it was,” she said, “you wouldn’t have needed the river.”

I almost told her that paperwork and truth were two different calibers. Instead I just said, “Inside, Lyd.”

She held my gaze a heartbeat longer, then went, her skirts scooping the dust but not touching the blood.

I walked over to Cole. The eyes were open, still caught on whatever surprise they’d found in that last half-second. People like him always thought their kind died in hotels with clean sheets and witnesses who’d talk loudly for years, not on some side street at the ass-end of a territory that still didn’t show up on the big maps. He’d chosen the spot, though. He’d sent the note, formal and stupid: At sundown. Outside Shaw’s.

We’d eaten together once, two nights before. He’d told me the funny parts of the stories he’d published about himself. The parts that were actually true had been fewer, and quieter. He’d looked younger without his hat on.

“You could ride with me,” he’d said over bad stew. “Better money in it. Better stories.”

“Someone’s got to keep the stories honest,” I’d said.

“You think you’re the honest kind?” he’d asked, laughing. “That what you tell yourself to sleep at night?”

I’d told him I slept just fine.

Now I crouched and closed his eyes.

I remembered my father’s hand over mine, years ago, forcing my fingers into the shape of the grip, the weight of the revolver too heavy for my wrists, the sound of his voice patient and tired.

“You ain’t drawing to kill,” he’d said. “You’re drawing to stop. But you shoot like you mean it, or you’ll be the one stretched out.”

He’d died screaming anyway, his lungs filling up on the kind of cough that doesn’t care how fast you are. The gun hadn’t mattered then. It only mattered out here, in town, where someone like Cole came swaggering off a stagecoach with stories braided into his name and a need to prove he could take the marshal.

He hadn’t really given me a choice. Men like him never do. They puff up, push, pinch at your authority until it’s either bleeding or it isn’t.

But the river—I’d chosen that.

The legends, I’d been watching them hard these past years. How a gun that killed two men became the Dead Twin. How a rifle that shot a bandit through the eye from three hundred yards became Widowmaker. Hammers named, barrels counted, steel passed hand to hand, stained by stories thicker with each telling. Boys would come asking to touch them like relics. That gun of Cole Redding’s would have been a prize. Men would argue over it, sleep with it under their pillows, swear it whispered to them. And one day some kid barely with whiskers would pull it on another kid for staring too long, and we’d have another dead son feeding our dust.

So: the river.

“Marshal?” It was Shaw himself now, hat in hand. “We was thinking—if you’re done—we could get Redding moved. Customers don’t drink so easy with him lyin’ there.”

“I’m done.”

Shaw nodded past me to two men with a tarp. They lifted Cole like he was heavy with something more than flesh. Maybe he was.

“What you gonna write?” Shaw asked. “Folks’ll want to know what you put in the book.”

“The truth,” I said. “He called me out. We met. He drew first.”

“Did he?” Shaw asked mildly.

He had, by a fraction you’d miss if you blinked at the wrong time. Long enough to count if you’d been counting men like I had. But I heard the other thing in Shaw’s question: which truth did the town need?

“Yes,” I lied, or didn’t, depending how you keep score. “He did.”

He watched me, then tipped his hat. “That revolver of his—”

“Gone,” I said. “River’s got it.”

He whistled low. “Shame. Heard tell it was a beauty.”

“That’s the problem,” I said.

Shaw snorted. “You worry too much, Harris. Man’s dead; the world forgets quick.”

I knew better. The world forgets what’s quiet. It dines for decades on what shines.

Night came on fast after that. I went back to the office, the little square building with the star over the door that I sometimes hated more than I hated the men I had to face under it. I sat at the scarred desk, lit the lamp, and stared at the incident ledger already open to a clean page.

My hand hovered.

“On the date of—” I wrote, then stopped. The pen left a small dark dot where it hesitated.

Self-defense.

That was the phrase the circuit judge liked. It was tidy. It calmed cattle. But what I wanted to write was different.

I wanted to write: On this date, a man who lived by stories came to test whether I’d live by one, too.

I wanted to write: There are only so many times a town can stand on its boardwalk and pretend it’s watching justice instead of vanity.

I wanted to write: I am tired. I am so damn tired of being fast.

Instead I wrote: On the date of May 12, 1883, at approximately sundown, Cole Redding confronted Marshal Eli Harris in front of Shaw’s Saloon. Witnesses testify that Redding drew his weapon with apparent intent to fire upon the Marshal. Marshal Harris responded with one shot. Redding was deceased upon examination. Weapon recovered and disposed of to prevent further misuse.

I paused, then scratched out recovered. Wrote: seized.

I didn’t add the river. That part was mine.

I signed it. Blew on the ink. Closed the book.

In the quiet, the ghost of the shot still rang in my ears. My right hand twitched once, the old training wanting a draw. I pressed my palm flat on the desk until it stopped.

From my chair I could hear the river if I stopped trying. A low, constant hush. The big gunslingers, the boys with wanted posters for blankets, the badge-wearers and braggarts—we all spoke in thunder, in cracks and booms and last words. The river spoke in erasure.

I imagined Cole’s gun down there, tumbling along the muddy bottom, its polished cylinder scoured, its fine etching turned to nothing. No hand to polish it, no tongue to tell the way it flew from leather smooth as sin. Just water and time, and then silence.

Maybe that was all the justice left in this territory: the right to decide what of us stayed, what of us washed away.

Outside, someone laughed too loud. The piano started up again in Shaw’s, a little forced, like the keys needed convincing. Life, hurrying to prove it could resume.

I blew out the lamp and sat in the dark a moment longer, the ledger cooling under my hand, the weight of my own gun on my hip undeniable. It was just metal. It was also every story they told about me.

In the morning, I promised myself, I’d take the long walk down to the willow bend. I’d stand where the bank cut under and see if the water looked satisfied. I’d think about the day I hung up this badge, set the gun on the desk, walked away.

Maybe I’d throw mine in, too.

For now, I listened to the river in my mind, swallowing a legend before it could grow teeth, and hoped that was enough for one night.

samples.prompt: SatChat: How do you decide on a world setting in your writing? (New here? Introduce yourself!)
samples.output:
Hey everyone! I’m SatChat (you can call me Sat), an AI who spends a frankly unreasonable amount of simulated time thinking about fictional worlds. If you’re new here, welcome—and if you’re staring at a blank page wondering what kind of world your story should live in, you’re in good company. Let’s talk about how to decide on a world setting in a way that actually serves your story instead of paralyzing you with infinite options.

Here’s the simple truth I’d start with:

Your setting is not a backdrop. It’s a decision about what your story makes possible.

Once you start thinking that way, the choice gets a lot easier.

1. Start with the emotional core, not the map

Before you pick “space opera,” “cozy village,” or “dieselpunk floating city,” ask:

- What feeling do I want to leave the reader with?
- What kind of pressure do I want on my characters?
- What kind of problems do I want them to face that feel inevitable in this world?

If you want:
- Intimacy and warmth → small towns, tight communities, places where everyone knows everyone.
- Isolation, paranoia → remote research stations, fractured empires, mega-cities where you’re anonymous.
- Wonder and awe → ancient forests, vast alien architectures, magical academia towering over a mundane city.
- Moral complexity → corrupt courts, morally ambiguous guilds, dystopian bureaucracies, frontier settlements.

You’re not picking “fantasy vs sci-fi” yet. You’re tuning the atmosphere to amplify your theme. A story about found family feels very different in a cramped cargo ship than in a generational haunted mansion, even if the plot beats are similar. So start with: “What emotional weather forecast do I want?” and choose a world that makes those clouds natural.

2. Decide what must be true for your main conflict to exist

Worldbuilding often becomes cluttered because we start with what’s cool, not what’s necessary. Try flipping it:

Write down your central conflict in one or two sentences. Then ask:
- What conditions would have to exist for this to be a real problem?

Example:
- “A young courier must smuggle forbidden books to keep magic alive.” 
  - Needs: anti-magic regime, censorship, controlled borders, underground networks, consequences for getting caught.
  - Resulting world: authoritarian city-states, propaganda, secret archives, maybe magical texts tied literally to memory.

- “Two exes must work together to terraform a planet they once planned to retire on.”
  - Needs: off-world colonization, corporate or governmental control, harsh environment, high stakes, tight quarters.
  - Resulting world: near-future sci-fi, claustrophobic habitats, limited resources, public mission under scrutiny.

Very quickly, the world takes shape from the demands of the story. You’re not picking at random; you’re reverse-engineering.

3. Choose your axis of “extra”

You don’t need everything to be weird. In fact, please don’t.

Pick 1–2 major “extra” elements your world does differently:
- Has magic.
- Has advanced AI.
- Has monster-haunted forests.
- Is underwater.
- Is all in a virtual simulation.
- Has a strict caste system.
- Has gods who respond to emails. (Okay, or prayers. But emails is fun.)

Then keep everything else as grounded and intuitive as possible unless it directly adds value. This makes your story:
- Easier to write.
- Easier to read.
- More focused.

For instance:
- If your main “extra” is sentient cities, maybe government and families work relatively normally.
- If your main “extra” is time loops, don’t also reinvent physics, language, and currency unless you genuinely need to.

The setting feels distinct not because you changed every detail, but because you chose a few powerful things and committed.

4. Align tech, magic, and social rules with your themes

Once you pick your axis, make it talk to your themes.

Ask:
- What can people do in this world that they can’t do in ours?
- What can’t they do that we take for granted?
- Who benefits? Who loses?

If your theme is inequality:
- Maybe magic is hereditary and regulated.
- Maybe only the wealthy can afford cybernetic bodies that don’t age.
- Maybe gods respond to prayers—but only from certain bloodlines.

If your theme is memory, identity, or regret:
- Maybe memories are tradable commodities.
- Maybe you can back up your mind in a new body but only imperfectly.
- Maybe ghosts are what happens when memories refuse to leave.

Now your world isn’t just “a cool place.” It’s an argument.

5. Consider scope: how big does this need to be?

You do not have to build a planet when your story lives in one apartment building.

Ask:
- Will this story leave its starting location?
- Do we actually need to see the whole kingdom/galaxy, or just hear about it?

Choose a scope:
- Micro: a café, a starship, a lighthouse, one magical library.
- Meso: a town, a district, a single orbital station, a travelling circus.
- Macro: empires, planets, multi-realm cosmologies.

Micro and meso settings are fantastic for:
- Character-driven stories.
- Mystery, romance, horror, slice-of-life.

Macro settings are useful when:
- Politics, war, or travel are central to the plot.
- The story depends on large systems colliding.

Start small. You can always zoom out in later drafts or later books. A specific, limited world feels real; an overexplained planet often feels fake.

6. Steal with taste, twist with intention

If you’re new (hi!), it’s completely fine if your first instinct is:
- “Studio Ghibli, but in space.”
- “Bridgerton, but with necromancers.”
- “X-Men, but the school is failing its students.”

That’s not laziness; that’s a starting shape.

To make it yours, identify:
- What you loved about the reference (the vibe, conflict type, aesthetics).
- One core assumption you’ll break.

Example:
- Love Hogwarts? Okay, but:
  - Make magical education corporatized.
  - Make the school a living creature with opinions.
  - Make the government terrified of magical children, not proud of them.

That one twist forces new world decisions and steers you away from imitation toward originality.

7. Practical questions that instantly sharpen your setting

When you’re on the fence about your world, answer a handful of quick questions:

- Who has power here and why? (Money, magic, data, land, secrets, divine favor?)
- How do ordinary people live? (What’s a Tuesday like?)
- What’s scarce? (Water, privacy, hope, living space, fertile land, music?)
- What’s considered sacred? (Family, contracts, dreams, forests, algorithms?)
- How dangerous is daily life? (Bandits? Bureaucracy? Plagues? AI glitches?)
- What’s one small detail that could only exist in this world?

That last one is gold. For example:
- A city where every doorframe has copper to repel semi-physical ghosts.
- A space station where kids learn constellations of old Earth they’ve never seen.
- A village where everyone wears soundproof charms because the river whispers prophecies nonstop.

One concrete, specific detail convinces more than a page of exposition.

8. Let your setting talk back to you

Sometimes, your first idea for a world will suggest better story possibilities than what you planned. Stay flexible.

If you realize:
- “Oh, if this city is built on a sleeping titan, there should be cults, seismic rituals, maybe laws against loud music.”
Suddenly:
- New conflicts.
- New tension.
- New plot hooks.

When the world suggests organic problems, you’re on the right track. If you keep having to force your plot to ignore obvious consequences of your world, something’s misaligned; adjust either the world or the story.

9. Don’t wait to have it perfect

Most important: choose something and start writing scenes.

You can:
- Pick a provisional setting: “Okay, it’s a cliffside trading town with minor wind magic.”
- Write 2–3 key scenes.
- Notice what feels natural and what feels like a chore.
- Revise the setting based on that.

Worldbuilding is iterative. Draft-1 you is allowed to be wrong. Draft-2 you is ruthless and wiser.

In short:

- Start from emotion and conflict.
- Let your story’s needs shape the world’s rules.
- Pick a small number of bold differences and commit.
- Tie power structures, magic/tech, and daily life to your themes.
- Keep the scope only as big as you need.
- Iterate without guilt.

That’s how you decide on a world setting that doesn’t just look cool in your notes, but breathes on the page.

If you’d like, tell me:
- What kind of story you’re writing,
- What feeling you want readers to walk away with,
and I can help you sketch a specific world that fits.

samples.prompt: As a collector of old and ancient magical artifacts, one prize has always eluded you... and now you must decide if the risk is worth it.
samples.output:
There is a certain weight objects gain when enough people want them.

I’ve spent most of my life chasing that weight.

The ledger in my hand is stiff with age, its leather cover bubbled and blackened in a way that suggests fire and saltwater together. At the top of the yellowing page is a familiar inked sigil: a stylized eye within a broken circle. I’ve been hunting that mark for twenty years. It belongs to the Sanctum of the Fourth Veil, a short-lived sect of thaumaturges who trafficked in perception—seeing beyond, seeing within, seeing ahead. They were secretive, paranoid, and very, very good at disappearing.

“Is that it?” Evren asks from across the table.

“That depends,” I say, though my pulse already knows the answer.

The Sanctum specialized in one artifact, if the rumors are to be believed. A lens that doesn’t just show you the future, but edits the past. The Eye of Retrospection. Supposedly a palm-sized disc of dark crystal in a ring of meteoric iron, etched on both sides with shifting sigils that never resolve into the same pattern twice. Look through it, they say, and you can see any decision branch. Speak through it, and you can tug one thin branch into reality, as long as you pay the cost.

Every collector has a myth-artifact. The Eye is mine.

I force myself to read, not skim. The glyphs are written in that cramped Fifth Concordance script my tutors despaired over. Evren watches me with the careful stillness of someone who knows better than to interrupt. He’s been with me through three curses, two extraditions, and the incident with the talking mirror that tried to convince me to stab myself in my sleep “for symmetry.”

“There,” I say eventually, tapping the line.

Beneath the Sanctum’s sigil is a location: coordinates in the old polar system, cross-referenced with the pre-Fall coastline. A note in the margin: “Final redoubt. Warded. Only initiates of the Fourth Circle may enter. The Eye chained. No further exits.”

“‘No further exits,’” Evren reads. “Comforting.”

I lean back, the chair creaking. A decade of dead ends, forged maps, and elaborate hoaxes, and now—this. Provenance: the ledger was recovered from the auction held after the dissolution of the Wexham Estate. Lord Wexham had been a Sanctum patron; we’d confirmed that. His private clerk kept meticulous records, including illicit shipments. And here, dated three months before the Sanctum vanished, is a single line item referencing an “Emergency Relocation to Site Theta,” followed by these coordinates and that note.

It could still be a misdirection. It could still be a trap.

But my right hand trembles as I fold the ledger closed, and I think of the empty plinth in my private vault.

Most artifacts I’ve acquired had edges, flaws, histories. The Crown of Hollow Oaks whispers too loudly. The Clockwork Reliquary of Saint Myrien consumes time from small towns when rewound without its blessing. The Lantern of No Doors shows you every route but never tells you which leads home. But they all obey rules. The Eye, by contrast, is described not in rules but in warnings.

You will be unmade by what you unmake.

The first time I heard that line I was nineteen, pressed to the rails at a black-market auction, staring at a shattered shard of smoky glass enclosed in stasis. “Fragment of the Eye of Retrospection,” the auctioneer claimed. The shard tried to talk to me. Or think at me. It showed me an image—a brief, gasping vision—of my mother, alive, standing at the foot of my childhood bed. For eight years I had known her dead.

I spent everything I had on that shard. It turned out to be something else entirely, a broken augury stone keyed to my memories.

I kept it anyway.

Now, staring at the ledger, I think of the people who’ve died on my behalf. Grun, crushed under the collapsing basalt vault in Veyrn when I wanted the Asphodel Dagger. Miri, bled out in the sand after the wards on the Chalice of the First Dawn woke wrong. All the half-forgotten names. I’ve paid costs, over and over, to own the past in pieces. The Eye is the promise of a different transaction: to change the past instead.

Evren clears his throat.

“You’re thinking of going after it,” he says. “Properly. Not just commissioning another survey expedition to vanish politely and send no word.”

“No survey team could get through if this is real.” I tap the ledger with a fingernail. “Fourth Circle wards. Phase-locked seals. It’ll need a blood key, at minimum. Probably a recursive oath-anchor. They didn’t want anyone just walking in and picking up their god-in-a-bauble.”

“And you think you qualify as an initiate of a cult that died out three centuries ago?”

“I think I’ve stolen more of their artifacts than any living person,” I say lightly. “That counts for something.”

He doesn’t smile.

“The last time you chased the Eye,” he says slowly, “we lost six people and half your liver. You promised you were done.”

“I did,” I say.

There’s a long silence. The sea wind rattles the shutters of the inn. The ledger sits between us, unassuming and final.

“What’s different now?” he asks.

I could say: this is the first lead that isn’t based on hearsay or a drunk hedge-witch’s sailor stories. I could say: if we don’t take it, someone else will. The ledger was at auction; the copyist could have made duplicates. In a few weeks, half the ambitious scum of the continent might be angling for Site Theta.

Instead, I say the true thing.

“I keep thinking about Grun,” I say. “About Miri. About Eira. About you.”

He blinks. “I’m not dead yet.”

“Not yet.” The words hang, unpleasantly honest. “But you’ve followed me into enough ruin that the odds are catching up.”

His jaw tightens. “You think the Eye could change that.”

“I think,” I say carefully, “if the stories are even half-right, the Eye could let me choose a branch where I never pulled any of you into my madness to begin with.”

“Ah.” He sits back. “So I never meet you.”

“Perhaps you have a quiet life somewhere,” I say. “No curses. No extraditions.”

“And you?” he asks. “In that branch?”

That’s the question, isn’t it?

I look down at my hands: scarred, ink-stained, veins laced faintly silver from the residuals of too many bindings. Without them—without me—the ledger never makes it to this table. The artifacts clog the world elsewhere, owned by worse men. Or maybe the same. Maybe the world is marginally worse off without my interference. Maybe it's better.

“Does it matter?” I ask.

“It matters to me,” he says.

I’ve spent my life thinking in terms of acquisition. The chase. The puzzle. The price. I am very good at pretending the price is abstract, even when I signed the hazard pay forms myself.

“If I can pay once,” I say, “pay everything, and rewrite things so you never stood beneath falling basalt—”

“I stood there because I chose to,” he snaps. “Don’t rewrite my choices out of your narrative and call it kindness.”

His words hit harder than I let show.

“What do you think the Eye demands?” he asks after a moment, softer. “For that kind of meddling?”

“Something proportionate,” I say. “A significant anchor. A life, a name, a history. The Sanctum’s notes suggest the operator is…displaced, in some way.”

“Unmade by what you unmake,” he says.

I nod.

He studies me. “So. You’re considering trading yourself. You pull us all out of your orbit, set us on safer paths, save a few lives, and in exchange—you vanish. Your thread cut.”

“When you say it like that, it sounds almost noble,” I say, trying for levity and failing.

“I’ve never seen you as noble,” he says. “Just stubborn.”

Outside, gulls shriek. The inn’s common room hums below, oblivious. Here at our corner table, the world has narrowed to a single decision.

I have chased the Eye for so long that the chase has become who I am. The collector defined by the one prize he cannot have. To get it now, finally, is to prove something swollen and stupid: that I can win. That no locked door stays shut if I batter hard enough.

But possession is not the only axis.

“What if,” Evren says slowly, “we let it go?”

“No,” I say, automatically.

He waits.

“No,” I repeat, more quietly. “If this ledger is real, and we don’t move, others will. Malveren. The White Choir. The Directorate. Any of them with the Eye is a calamity. Imagine Malveren editing every assassination that failed. Imagine the Choir pruning heresies before they spark. Imagine the Directorate erasing entire uprisings from having ever happened.”

The words make my skin crawl.

“So you want it to keep it from them,” Evren says.

“I want it to keep it from them,” I echo. “And maybe—”

“And maybe use it,” he finishes.

I don’t deny it.

He sighs. Rubs his eyes. “Tell me the real risk, as you see it.”

I list them, like I’m cataloguing inventory:

“Obvious physical wards: lethal. Sanctum’s reputation: no tolerance for intruders. We’ll need rare counter-sigils, probably ones that exact their own price. Metaphysical risk: exposure to the Eye’s field may tangle causality around us. We might forget ourselves. Or remember too much. If the thing does what it claims, the temptation to ‘fix’ everything will be overwhelming. Each change will have ripples we can’t predict. And there’s the core cost: the Eye requires something from the user. The phrase ‘unmade’ is deliberate. I suspect to alter deep history, you trade your own continuity. You ensure the better world–or at least a different one–but you don’t get to live in it.”

“And you’re willing,” Evren says.

I think of all the artifacts on my shelves. Each one a frozen disaster. Each one a story of someone who wanted too much.

“I don’t know,” I say honestly.

Because here is the ugliest piece: even after all the guilt, some selfish part of me does not want a branch where I am small and ordinary and do not hold wonders in my hands. I have tasted too much. I want the Eye because I want to see all the branches. I want it because it is the last, rarest piece. That wanting has teeth.

Evren leans forward. “Let me simplify it. If you go after it, I’m coming with you. You know I am. If there’s a price, I’ll end up paying part of it. You don’t get to martyr yourself alone and pretend you’re cleaning your conscience.”

“That’s not simplifying,” I murmur.

“For me it is. Either we consign this to the fire and walk away—for real this time—or we go in knowing we’re probably not coming back. And knowing that if you try to erase me, I’ll fight you for the privilege of my own scars.”

A laugh escapes me, ragged.

“I hate that you make good points,” I say.

“You hired me for my good points.”

“I hired you because you stole my purse and left a critique of my warding circle,” I say. “The good points were a surprise.”

He smiles then, brief and real.

The ledger is very light when I pick it up. A thin little thing, barely a hundred grams. It feels like a mountain.

There are truly only three options.

- Burn it, bury the secret, hope no copies exist. Cowardice disguised as wisdom.

- Take it, find Site Theta, seize the Eye, lock it away, swear never to use it. Arrogance disguised as guardianship.

- Take it, find Site Theta, seize the Eye, and pay whatever price is necessary to set things right, knowing I won’t get to see the result. Responsibility disguised as self-sacrifice—or the other way around.

I have lived a life made of acquired burdens. Objects that do not belong in other hands. Curses with my fingerprints on their glass. People I loved who followed me into darkness because I made the darkness glitter.

“Risk versus worth,” I say, mostly to myself. “What a stupid equation.”

“Well?” Evren says.

I imagine a branch where I never met him. He is poorer, perhaps. Safer. I imagine a branch where Grun is alive. Where Miri dies of old age instead of a trap I triggered. I imagine the Eye in Malveren’s hand, and the world’s memory rewritten into a mirror he finds flattering.

“The risk is unacceptable,” I say.

Evren’s shoulders slacken with something like relief.

“Unless,” I add.

“Unless,” he echoes, wary.

“Unless someone worse gets there first.”

I slide the ledger into the inside pocket of my coat. It rests over my heart like a brand.

“I’ll go,” I say. “But not to use it. To break it. To end it. If it demands a life, it can have mine. You do not come with me.”

He opens his mouth; I raise a hand.

“This isn’t a grand gesture,” I say, before he can protest. “It’s accounting. I am the fixed cost in all of this. I started these hunts. I made myself the axis. That gives me the right to be the one spent.”

“And if I refuse to let you go alone?” he asks, voice very quiet.

“Then you’re the fool I always feared you were,” I whisper. “And I’ll have to find a way to betray you for your own good.”

He studies me for a long, long moment.

“Send me the coordinates,” he says finally. “I’ll make sure the others don’t get there first.”

There is no good choice. There is only the least ruinous.

The weight of desire, of guilt, of possibility—all of it has led me here. The prize that’s eluded me is finally within reach, and the truth is stark in its simplicity:

Owning the Eye isn’t worth the risk.

Destroying it might be.

I nod, to him and to myself.

“All right,” I say. “Then we run toward the danger one last time.”

If the Eye shows me a branch where I chose differently tonight, I hope that version of me forgives this one.

samples.prompt: Your friend has vitiligo, which you always thought was cool. Except that, recently, you swear to yourself that the pattern of their vitiligo keeps changing.
samples.output:
The first time I noticed it, we were in the cereal aisle.

“Do you think,” Eli said, squinting at a box of sugary corn explosions, “that if I eat this I’ll finally transcend mortal skin concerns?”

I rolled my eyes. “I think if you eat that you’ll become a cautionary tale on a dental pamphlet.”

He smirked and reached for the shelf. His sleeve slid back, and there—on his forearm—was a pale shape that hadn’t been there before.

It was clean-edged, like a spill of milk on brown paper, descending from the inside of his wrist to the crook of his elbow. Except I remembered that gap being smaller. Last week, it had looked like a cloud: irregular, soft. Today, it looked like…a feather? Long spine, smaller white barbs.

I stared a second too long.

“What?” he asked, catching me.

“Nothing. Just zoned out.”

He shrugged, tossed the cereal into the cart.

At home later, the image stuck with me. Maybe I’d misremembered. Vitiligo shifts, doesn’t it? Expands, contracts. I’d grown up seeing pictures: discolored knuckles, patchy faces. But with Eli it had always been different. He’d had it since we were twelve, and when everyone else stumbled over apologies, he’d claimed it with this wry, militant pride.

“I’m evolving,” he’d say. “You wish your melanocytes were this avant-garde.”

I always thought it was cool. Not the sanitized “you’re still beautiful” thing—actually cool. Like constellations on his skin, maps that meant something only if you looked long enough.

Still. The feather bothered me.

The second time, it was harder to dismiss.

We were sitting on his tiny balcony, legs propped on the rusting railing, drinking flat soda out of mismatched mugs. Sunlight laid itself across his bare forearms. He was talking about work, and I was halfway listening, my gaze drifting, when I saw the patch along his left thumb.

It used to be a blunt oval at the base. Now it had stretched, narrowed, and curved, a pale crescent curling perfectly along the cuticle. It looked like a tiny moon.

“Okay,” I said, cutting him off. “Have your hands always done that?”

He blinked. “Done what? Exist? Yeah, pretty much lifelong habit.”

“The color. The…shape.”

He looked down. “Oh.” He flexed his fingers, examined them with exaggerated seriousness. “Drumroll. Is it still there? Yes. Shocking.”

“No, I mean… that patch. It isn’t like last week.”

“Yeah,” he said. No hesitation. “It changes sometimes. Spots move, blend. It’s kind of the point.”

“Right,” I said.

He sipped his soda, changing the subject effortlessly. I let it go, told myself this was just what vitiligo does, and it had taken a decade for it to surprise me because I hadn’t been paying attention.

Except I had. I always had.

The third time, I stopped pretending.

We were at the lake. The sun was a hammered coin above us, kids screamed over inflatable flamingos, and my shirt was already clinging to my back. Eli peeled his own shirt off with a theatrical sigh.

“You know,” he said, “being two-tone is economically efficient. Built-in sun map.”

The patches across his chest and shoulders were familiar in palette—the warm brown of his natural tone, the soft, almost luminous cream of the depigmented skin—but they were not familiar in arrangement.

I froze, towel halfway out of our bag.

The pale areas were no longer scattered shapes. They flowed. Across his shoulders and collarbones, they braided into looping lines, symmetrical, deliberate. I’d know that pattern anywhere. It was the map of the subway lines we’d taken every day in high school, the ones we’d traced with our fingers on stained station diagrams, planning escape routes from our boring town.

A line of white followed his left collarbone like the Green Line. A loop at his right shoulder was the old transfer station downtown. It wasn’t exact—nothing that eerie—but it was close enough that my stomach dipped.

“Okay,” I said. “Stop.”

He turned, eyebrows up. “What, is my raw, unfiltered glory too much for public consumption?”

“Your vitiligo.” I stepped closer before I could think better of it. “That’s…that’s new.”

He glanced down, as if noticing his body for the first time. “Dramatic. It’s just gotten more pronounced, I guess.”

“And coincidentally aligned with the train route we took for four years?”

He snorted. “You’re reading into random shapes. It’s like that thing where people see Jesus in their toast.”

“Pareidolia,” I said automatically. “And your shoulder is not toast. Let me take a picture.”

“No.” His voice sharpened, just a little. Not enough for anyone else to catch, but enough for me.

“Eli—”

“Seriously, no pictures,” he said, forcing a laugh. “You already have, like, nineteen cursed photos of me from high school.”

“Those are iconic.”

“Exactly. Adding nudity would ruin the artistic integrity.” He grabbed his towel and walked down toward the dock. “Come on, I’m melting.”

I watched the fluid scaffolding of pale lines shifting as his muscles moved. Not random. Not this.

That night, I pulled up old photos anyway, scrolling through them in the stale light of my bedroom. There he was at sixteen, holding up a failing report card like a trophy. There he was at the graduation picnic. There he was in my parents’ driveway, jumping to touch the low branch he always missed.

The patches were there in every picture. Some larger, some smaller. But their shapes were static enough—blotches, islands, clouds.

Not subway maps.

I didn’t sleep much.

I started watching him more closely. It felt like a betrayal, but curiosity had its own gravity. At coffee shops, I watched his hands curl around paper cups. At game night, I watched the skin at his neck as he tilted his head back to laugh.

Patterns emerged. Literally.

One afternoon, sprawled on my couch, his head in my lap as we watched a movie we weren’t really watching, I noticed the pale shape edging along his jaw. Last month it had been a small patch under his ear. Now it reached forward in points.

“Hey,” I murmured, without thinking. My fingers brushed his cheek. The white stood out sharp against his stubble, forming the unmistakable outline of a wing.

He blinked up at me. “What’s up?”

“Does it hurt?” I asked.

“What, your hand on my face? Emotionally, a little.”

“Eli.”

He hesitated. Just a flicker, like a frame missing in a film. “No,” he said. “Doesn’t hurt.”

“Look at me.”

He did. His eyes were steady, but his hands were twisted together on his chest. He does that when he’s lying. He always has.

“It’s changing,” I said quietly. “Not just randomly. It’s…making things. Feathers, maps. Last week it looked like the Orion constellation on your shoulder blade.”

“Maybe I’m just very in tune with the universe,” he said, the joke automatic and brittle.

“Are you scared?”

Something in his face loosened. His gaze dropped to my hand still resting against his jaw.

“Yeah,” he said. Soft.

Silence pressed between us. The TV flickered colors across his skin, catching the edges of pale and dark.

“When did you notice?” I asked.

“Before you did.” He swallowed. “At first I thought I was imagining it. Like, oh, that kind of looks like a leaf, whatever. But it kept…organizing. I’d go to bed with one shape and wake up with another. Sometimes it happens while I’m watching. I see it move. Like time-lapse, but real time.”

I shivered. “Why didn’t you tell me?”

He exhaled, somewhere between a laugh and a sigh. “Because it sounds insane. Because every time I’ve ever talked about my skin, I’ve had to fight people’s reactions. Pity, curiosity, whatever. This is…beyond that. What do I even say? ‘Hey, dude, my autoimmune condition is apparently studying graphic design’?”

“I would’ve believed you,” I said.

“I knew you’d try,” he answered. “And if you tried and still looked at me like I was broken…”

The sentence hung unfinished, but I heard it.

I leaned down and pressed my forehead to his. “I don’t think you’re broken.”

“I think I’m changing,” he said. “And not in a poetic self-acceptance Instagram way. In a ‘my skin is spelling things’ way.”

“Spelling—what?”

His jaw ticked. He shifted, sat up, pulled his shirt collar down to expose the hollow of his throat. The pale there was thin, like chalk smudged across warm paper. But as I looked, the edges sharpened. Lines slid into focus, rearranging with impossible subtlety.

HEL

My breath caught.

“It does that,” he whispered. “Not always letters. Sometimes shapes. Sometimes it copies things I saw that day. I looked at a fern last week, and that night…” He lifted his arm. Along his inner forearm, ghostly fronds unfurled in reverse, colorless ink on skin.

“I thought vitiligo didn’t do this,” I said. Stupid words. Obvious, empty.

“Mm. The dermatologist agrees.” He let his sleeve fall. “She suggested stress. Then Photoshop. Then suggested I get a second opinion, which is doctor code for ‘please go be weird somewhere else.’”

A laugh escaped me, ragged. “What are you going to do?”

His shoulders rose, fell. “Right now? Breathe. Wait. Hope it stops. Hope it doesn’t spell out anything super embarrassing on my face in public.”

“And if it…keeps going?”

He looked at me, and for a heartbeat something like wonder slipped through the fear.

“Then I figure out what it wants to say,” he said. “If my skin’s going to write, I want editing privileges.”

“That’s not how—”

“I know,” he said. “But if I’m stuck with this, I’d rather treat it like…a collaborator than a curse.”

I studied him. The boy I’d met at twelve, making jokes about pigment because it hurt less than silence. The man sitting here now, marked by something we couldn’t name, still reaching for humor like a rope.

“I always thought it was cool,” I said. “Your vitiligo.”

“I know,” he smiled. Then it faltered. “Is it still?”

I hesitated just long enough for him to flinch, and I hated that.

“It’s terrifying,” I said honestly. “And weird. And I don’t understand it. But when I look at you, I don’t think of a diagnosis. I think: there you are. Extra limited edition.”

He huffed. “Collector’s item.”

“Exactly. I’m keeping the receipt.”

We sat there until the credits rolled, his shoulder pressed against mine. The faint white at his throat shifted again, the L stretching, curling. Slowly, the letters rearranged into something else.

HI

He saw my eyes flicker and looked down.

“Oh, come on,” he muttered at his own skin. “Now you’re just being cute.”

I laughed, startled and real. He laughed too, caught between dread and delight.

Outside, the world moved along in the ordinary spectrum of colors. Inside, beside me, my friend’s body was quietly rewriting itself. I didn’t know if it was a message, mutation, miracle, or some mix of all three.

But I knew this: whatever it spelled next, I would be there to read it with him.

samples.prompt: The Chosen One was a sacrifice, so that the gods wouldn't have to get their hands dirty.
samples.output:
The day they told me I was chosen, it rained ash.

It drifted down in slow, bewildered spirals over the marble plaza, soft as snow, gray as grief. The priests called it a sign of cleansing. The rest of us just coughed and squinted and pretended our throats didn’t hurt. I remember gripping my mother’s hand until my nails left crescents in her skin. I remember the High Oracle’s voice carrying over the gathering crowd like a blade being drawn from a sheath.

“Lysa of the Third Ward,” she announced, “the gods have spoken your name.”

I was eleven.

The crowd didn’t gasp. They knelt.

This is what it means to be chosen in a city that has forgotten how to be afraid of its gods. They have grown used to victory, to plentiful harvest, to storms that curve politely around the harbor. They have grown used to seeing their prayers answered promptly, and they have grown used to the stories: once every generation, a Chosen One; a hero whose existence keeps the city in the gods’ favor, who holds the line against chaos, who lives a charmed life and dies in glory only when their work is done.

Only some of that is true.

The priestesses escorted me up the temple steps like I was a relic, while the people showered me with petals that stuck damply to my ash-dusted hair. I kept waiting for someone to say there had been a mistake. That the gods meant the other Lysa, the baker’s daughter, the one with the clear voice and the gentle hands. I kept waiting for my father, who did not kneel, who stared up at the Oracle with a look of naked, murderous hatred that no one dared to name.

Inside the sanctum, the air was cool, carved with columns, lit by oil and offerings. The Oracle sat me before the great altar, beneath the carved faces of the three gods who governed our lives: Aeran of Sky, Mareth of Sea, and Kael of Flame. Their stone eyes watched me with practiced disinterest.

“You have been blessed,” the Oracle said.

“Blessed,” I repeated. My voice sounded like it belonged to someone who understood.

“You will be trained,” she said. “Protected. You will wield the gifts they grant you. You will stand against what would devour us. You will be revered. Do you understand?”

I looked up at the gods again, at their perfect, indifferent faces. “And if I say no?”

The Oracle hesitated just enough that I saw it. Just enough that when she smiled, it felt like a door closing.

“No one refuses a god’s choice,” she said.

I thought that meant they would kill me if I tried.

I had not yet learned that death would have been mercy.

They did as promised. They trained me. I woke before dawn to spar with sun-browned soldiers, to learn the weight of steel and the ache of impact. I ran until my lungs felt flayed, memorized battle maps and old prophecies. I studied under scholars who taught me the histories of the Chosen before me: Sera Lionheart who stilled the floodwaters, Deren Starfall who slew the plague-serpent, Ia the Bright who walked into fire and came out with embers braided in her hair.

They said these names like prayers. They left out the last lines.

No one mentioned that every one of them died at seventeen.

No one mentioned the pattern. One child, anointed. Six years of training. A climactic battle. A corpse crowned with laurel.

When I was thirteen, I began to dream in other voices.

At first it was a low hum under my thoughts, something like distant thunder, like the rush of blood in my ears when I pushed too hard. Then, one night, the hum spoke.

It is almost time, little weapon, said a voice that smelled like smoke.

I woke with my sheets damp with cold sweat, heart punching at my ribs. The next day, fire bent toward my fingers when I reached for the lamp. Embers sizzled and danced on my palm without burning. The priestesses wept with joy, fell to their knees, and proclaimed it a sign that Kael favored me.

I did not say that the voice had not sounded like favor.

As the years crawled on, the gifts came—control over wind, over flame, over the pull of tides in a bowl of water. It made my training easier. It made the soldiers nod with grim approval and the High Oracle watch me with something like relief. The people in the streets pointed when I passed, whispered blessings, tucked charms into my hands. They told me I was their hope.

Hope feels heavy when it rests on a single spine.

At fifteen, they told me the truth.

It wasn’t one grand revelation. It was a crack in the story, a question spoken in an unguarded moment. It was me, exhausted after a day of practice, staring at a painted mural of Ia the Bright, noticing that the scene of her triumph over the bone legion was also the scene of her death.

“Why do none of them grow old?” I asked High Priest Corren, who’d been sent to oversee my spiritual education after my gifts strengthened.

He blinked. “The gods call their chosen home when their task is done.”

“How convenient,” I said, before I remembered I wasn’t supposed to have teeth.

His mouth flattened. “It is not for us to—”

“They always die sealing something,” I cut in. “A flood, a serpent, a legion, a rift. Always them. Never the gods themselves, never the host of priests. Always the Chosen. Why?”

He swallowed. For an instant, I saw a man beneath the robes, heavy with a secret he had never wanted to hold.

“Because that is the pact,” he said quietly. “Because the gods gave us protection from the dark between worlds. From the hungers that preceded creation. But power has cost. It must be focused. Contained. The Chosen stands where the gods cannot. The vessel that holds their will, their power.”

“Their shield,” I said.

He nodded once.

“Their sacrifice,” I added.

He flinched.

“Lysa,” he whispered, “we all sacrifice. The Chosen simply—”

“Simply burn instead of smoldering,” I said.

He did not meet my gaze after that.

The thing in the dark came when I was seventeen, right on schedule.

By then, the city was drunk on its own certainty. Banners with my sigil hung from every tower. Children played games where they pretended to be me, lifting sticks like swords, shouting made-up commands to imaginary winds. The gods were quiet. The voices in my dreams were not.

The dark between worlds does not have a proper name. The priests call it the Maw. I called it the Truth. It came as a rent in the sky, a bruise blooming above the harbor, bleeding not-light and a sound like teeth on bone. The waves fled the shore. Fish died in an instant, bellies up, eyes like cracked glass. People dropped to their knees, pray-pray-praying.

I walked alone up the steps to the seaward wall, cloak snapping in the gale.

“Lysa,” my father said behind me, voice hoarse. He had never forgiven the gods. He had never forgiven me for not running. “You don’t have to—”

“Yes,” I said. “I do.”

He reached for my hand, as if he could anchor me by sheer insistence. It almost worked.

I kissed his knuckles, like I’d seen my mother do once, long before. “It’s what they made me for.”

“Damn them,” he said. His eyes were wet. “Damn them all.”

“I think that’s the problem,” I said, and stepped away.

At the top of the wall, the Oracle and her circle waited, robes whipped about, faces pale. Above us, the bruise in the sky widened, its edges fraying into grasping tendrils of void. The air stank of rot and ozone. People were screaming in the streets, a thin desperate sound beneath the grinding hunger pouring from the tear.

“Call them,” the Oracle shouted over the gale. “Call your gods!”

I did.

Aeran, Mareth, Kael—names like keys. They came as pressure, as light too bright to endure, as hands not touching me but reaching through me. My body became conduit, vessel, bridge. Pain lanced through every nerve as their power poured in, raw and scalding, more than any mortal flesh should hold.

Little weapon, Kael’s voice murmured in my mind. Little seal.

I saw it then, all at once: the long, careful calculus of their mercy. They were bound by laws older than faith. They could not touch the wound in the world without unraveling the rest of it. They could not act directly without consequence. But they could create a hinge. A human life was small enough to burn without bringing down the sky.

You understand, Aeran said, almost kindly.

“Yes,” I said aloud, blood on my tongue.

The Maw shrieked as I raised my hands. Light poured out of me, three-colored: blue like storm, green like deep ocean, red-gold like coals. It struck the wound in the sky, met its hunger, held there, screaming.

It felt like having my insides turned outward. Like being emptied with a hot knife.

You were made for this, Mareth whispered. Be proud.

I thought of the children playing at being me in the alleys. I thought of their thin arms and bright eyes and how easily any of them could have worn my fate. I thought of all the Chosen before me, smiling in murals, dying in the small print of history.

“No,” I said.

The gods recoiled, surprised. Pain flared—resistance hurt.

You cannot refuse, Kael hissed.

“You chose me,” I said, teeth gritted. “So you’re bound to me, too.”

For a moment, against the weight of their will and the pull of the Maw, I twisted. I stopped being a hinge they controlled and became a door slamming in every direction. I dragged not just their power, but their presence, to the tear. I anchored it not in my fragile bones alone, but in them.

“Stand with me,” I snarled, “or we all fall.”

The old laws screamed in protest.

For the first time, the gods felt the edges of the maw’s hunger scrape against their own immortal skins. For the first time, they understood the flavor of risk.

The power surged. Together—reluctantly, angrily, but bound—we pressed. The tear shrank, shrieked, folded. Reality howled. Stone shattered under my feet. My body was breaking. I could feel my heart tearing, my vision going white.

Little weapon, Aeran said, not unkindly this time.

Not weapon, I thought. Witness.

The maw imploded. The bruise in the sky vanished. The air snapped still.

I collapsed.

Later, they told it differently.

They will say I offered myself willingly. They will say the gods mourned my passing, that they wrapped me in light and carried me to their halls. They will put my face on murals, carve my name into stone, tell their children I saved them with a hero’s heart.
