Some priest will clear his throat if anyone asks why the gods did not stop the Maw themselves. He’ll talk of balance and destiny. He won’t mention that, for one bright and terrible instant, they were dragged to the edge with me, forced to feel how close it had come.

I am dead, but I am not gone. The place where I closed the tear is thin. Through it, I hear prayers like rain. Through it, I hear the gods, quieter now, less quick to call a child’s name.

The next time they reach down, I will be here in the hinge, watching.

The Chosen One was a sacrifice, yes.

But not so the gods could keep their hands clean.

Not anymore.

samples.prompt: This is a world where excrement is stored, and only released annually in a big event. Tell us the story of your pooping day.
samples.output:
The first thing you hear on Pooping Day is the music.

Thin, reedy flutes before dawn, swelling into brass and drums as the sun lifts over the reservoir domes, a city-wide alarm clock that is more reminder than celebration: Today, you are permitted to let go.

My bladder wakes me before the fanfare, as always. Habit. I roll over, groggy, staring up at the ceiling vents and the soft green indicator light that means my body remains sealed, my waste still imprisoned where the surgeons left the valve when I was five.

There’s a countdown on my wall: 00 days, 02 hours, 17 minutes.

“Happy Pooping Day,” my sister texts, along with a string of brown swirl emojis that the censors allow today and today only.

The message makes my gut clench with an odd mixture of anticipation and nausea. Twelve months of accumulation humming softly just beyond conscious sensation. They say the implants distribute, neutralize smell, keep pressure even. They say it’s not so bad if you don’t fixate on it. They say many things.

Outside, a horn blast rolls down the street: the sanitation parade starting early.

My mother has already been up for an hour when I shuffle into the kitchen. She’s wearing the ceremonial brown sash over her dress, as if she’s an official functionary and not a woman who still insists on boiling eggs on a day like this.

“Eat light,” she says, sliding a plate toward me. One hard-boiled egg, half a slice of toast. “You know the guidelines.”

“I read the guidelines,” I mutter. This is my first adult Pooping Day. At seventeen, I used the adolescent stalls, under supervision, a quick and monitored release into a pediatric line. Today, I’ll stand among the adults, have my valve keyed open by a stranger from the Sanitary Council, and trust that twelve months’ worth of me will behave.

She watches me, fingers tapping. “You signed your time slot?”

“Yes, Mom.” I chew. The government app assigned me 10:40 a.m., Plaza E cluster. “They’ll fine me if I don’t show. I know.”

She exhales. There’s that look again, the one that pretends composure but can’t hide the memory of my father’s last Pooping Day.

“It’ll be fine,” I say, though my voice comes out shaky.

She reaches across the table, curling her hand around mine. “It usually is.”

Outside the kitchen window, the neighbor’s kids are chalking swirls and cartoon piles on the sidewalk. A drone passes low, projecting a chipper voice: “Remember to hydrate! Stay in your assigned queues! Happy Output, Citizens!”

I dress in regulation white shorts and tunic, easy to remove and disinfect. The city prefers the uniform for hygiene and solidarity. We’re all the same today, they say. Everyone carries the year with them.

As I lace my shoes, my mother hovers in the doorway.

“You don’t have to watch the Square feed,” I tell her. “You could go visit Aunt Lila, distract yourself.”

“I’m watching,” she says. “And I’ll be waiting when you get home.”

Downstairs, the building’s lobby is festooned with brown and gold bunting, balloons shaped like little tanks. The concierge offers me a sealed electrolytes packet. “First adult release?” he asks.

“Yeah.”

He gives a solemn nod I think is meant to be reassuring. “Breathe slowly when they key you. Don’t fight it.”

On the street, the city is alive in a way that is part festival, part evacuation drill. Loudspeakers pump out jaunty jingles about “responsible release” in between precise instructions: zone numbers, time blocks, penalty reminders. Lines of portable collection modules—those towering, gleaming brown cylinders—stand at attention like columns of soldiers along every main road, their intake ports closed, awaiting the synchronized unburdening.

It wasn’t always like this, according to the old history vids. People once went anywhere, on any day, into water, into holes, mechanical thrones that whisked it away in anonymous pipes. They let their bodies empty without thought. It seems obscene to me, the randomness, the waste. The Change came after the Blue Years, when water turned bitter and the seas coughed back islands of filth. Concentrate it, they said. Harness it. One day a year, we open the valves, collect, convert. It made sense. It still does, mostly.

But sense doesn’t quiet the panic that lives in my belly.

Plaza E is already thick with white-clad citizens when I arrive—a herd of uneasy smiles and clenched jaws. Sanitary officers wind through the crowd, brown sashes crisp, scanners in hand. An enormous holo-banner overhead pulses with a slogan I’ve read since childhood: “We Release Together. We Renew Together.”

“ID,” an officer says as I reach the front of Queue 10:40.

I tap my wrist to her scanner. My profile blooms on her tablet: NAME: ILEA VERRAN. AGE: 18. IMPLANT SERIAL: V5-08-993-F. STATUS: GREEN.

“First adult?” she asks.

“Yes,” I say.

“You doing okay?”

I surprise myself by answering honestly. “A little scared.”

She softens. “Pressure is normal. Cramping is normal. Panic, sweating, shaking—normal. If you feel faint when the valve opens, lean on the bar. Don’t try to hold. That’s when we get ruptures, okay?”

I nod. Behind me, a little boy snickers at the word “ruptures” until his father hushes him.

The modules along our lane hiss and unfold as the central clock ticks toward our slot. Panels slide aside to reveal recessed alcoves, lined with stabilizing bars and a circular, padded ring. Above each: a discreet funnel, leading into the deep tanks below, into the industrial guts that will turn our bodies’ leavings into fuel, into fertilizer, into heat for the winter.

A drumroll sweeps the plaza. On the central stage, the Mayor steps up, robes magnificent, flanked by the High Sanitarian. Their words are broadcast on every surface:

“Citizens of Halden,” the Mayor booms, “today we perform the most humble and most vital of our duties. Today we remember that nothing is wasted, that even our lowest selves give rise to light, to food, to life. Release with pride. Release as one.”

The crowd murmurs the familiar response: “We release. We renew.”

My palms are slick. My guts twist, a deep, oceanic ache I’ve been trained to ignore all year suddenly surging into focus now that permission looms.

Countdown on the plaza tower: 10:39… 10:40.

Our line moves forward.

A Sanitary tech, younger than my mother and older than me, motions me into an empty alcove. “Step in. Shorts off. Sit when you’re ready.”

My fingers tremble as I slide my shorts down, fold them on the small shelf. The ring is cool beneath my thighs. I grip the metal bar at hip level.

The tech holds up a slim device. “I’m going to ping your valve. You’ll feel warmth, then pressure. Remember: do not clench once it starts. That’s what hurt your father.”

I look up sharply. “You remember—?”

Her eyes flicker. “We all got the training case file. I’m sorry. He fought the flow, tore a tract. We learned a lot from that, Ilea. You’re safer because of him.”

My throat tightens. Nobody had ever put it like that.

“Okay,” I whisper.

She touches the device to the implant node low on my spine. There’s a chime, a brief humming.

Then heat.

A sudden flowering of warmth in my abdomen, blooming outward like someone turned the sun on behind my navel. The pressure builds fast, a colossal tide that was always there but now surges, aware of the open door.

My breath hitches. Instinct screams: Squeeze. Stop. This is too much. My knuckles go white on the bar.

“Breathe into it,” the tech says calmly, her hand hovering near my shoulder but not touching. “This is what your body’s been waiting for. Let it happen.”

I exhale, long and shuddering.

The valve opens.

It is… impossible, at first. A deep internal unhooking, followed by movement that is not like daily digestion—it’s an exodus. Muscles I never knew I had engage. There’s no dainty business here, no veneer. It roars through me, heat and pressure pouring downward, a churning that borders on pain and then breaks past into something else.

The sound is masked by the plaza’s music, by the hush of the crowd, but I can feel it: an immense, solid, steady stream evacuating, on and on. Months of meals, of late-night snacks, of stolen candies, of everything.

Tears prick my eyes—not from pain, but from the sheer animal intensity of it. For a terrifying second I feel like I’m being hollowed out too much, that I’m leaving more of myself behind than intended.

I gasp, “I can’t—”

“You’re okay,” the tech says. “You’re over the peak. Twenty more seconds, maybe. You’re doing perfectly.”

I breathe. The pressure drops gradually, from overwhelming to merely huge, then to a strange fluttering series of spasms. The flow tapers. The warmth cools.

My body shudders one last time and stills.

I am… light.

So light it’s disorienting. My limbs feel full of air and electricity. There’s an absence where the familiar dull fullness has always been. My brain scrabbles for the usual background discomfort and finds… nothing.

“Valve sealed,” the device chimes.

The tech checks her screen. “Excellent output. No tearing. Hydrate at the fountain. Happy Pooping Day, Ilea.”

I pull my shorts back on with slow, shaky hands. When I step out of the alcove, the crowd sound hits me: relieved laughter, a few sobs, the babble of people comparing experiences. The greasy smell I expected isn’t there; the scrubbers and neutralizers do their work relentlessly.

I look down through the transparent band of the collection tube at my feet. A dark, dense river slides past, swept away toward the conversion plants. My contribution disappears into the masses, indistinguishable.

We release. We renew.

I find my way to the plaza’s edge, sipping electrolytes from a paper cone. My legs tremble pleasantly, like after running a race. I check my holo-slate. A new notification blinks:

OUTPUT CREDIT: +74 kJ, +0.9 Fert Units.
CONGRATULATIONS ON YOUR FIRST ADULT RELEASE.

My father’s name isn’t there, but I feel him anyway. Remember the way he used to joke about fueling the city, about “making light” in the least dignified way. Remember the way my mother’s face closed when Pooping Day neared, how she’d hover while the medics adjusted his valve after the rupture. How one year, he didn’t come back from the stall.

I stand there among thousands of emptying, laughing, lighter bodies, and for the first time, I don’t feel just fear or disgust. I feel part of the mechanism. Part of this strange covenant.

When I step back onto our floor an hour later, my mother meets me at the door before I can speak. Her eyes search my face, then drop instinctively to my abdomen.

“Well?” she asks.

I smile, a real one. “I’m okay.”

She exhales, shoulders sagging. The tension that has gripped her every year since my father died seems to slip, just a fraction.

“Was it…” she begins, then stops, embarrassed.

“Intense,” I say. “Good, though. Like… letting go of a year all at once.”

She laughs softly, unexpectedly. “That’s what it is.”

We stand in the kitchen as the city hums with the low satisfaction of millions newly emptied, the conversion plants ramping up to turn our shame into power. The sun angles off the reservoir domes, bright and clean.

Outside, a drone passes, voice warm:

“Thank you for your contribution, citizens. See you next year.”

I touch the small bump of the implant at my spine.

A year to fill. A year to carry.

And, now that I know how it feels, a year to look forward to letting go.

samples.prompt: You are on a school trip to Salem, Massachusetts. The teacher seems suspiciously excited about this particular trip.
samples.output:
By the time the bus turned onto Essex Street, Mr. Parrish had already clapped his hands together so many times the sound felt stitched into the air.

“Eyes up, everyone,” he called, pressing his palm to the fogged front window like he was personally guiding the driver. “Salem. Historic Salem. This is going to be special.”

He’d used that word five times since we crossed the Massachusetts border. Special. The same way people said “interesting” about a casserole they regretted tasting.

In the seat beside me, Jenna tugged her earbuds out. “He’s going to sacrifice us,” she whispered. “I call not it.”

“Relax,” I said. “He’s just a history teacher in his natural habitat.”

“History teachers don’t grin,” she said. “They smirk. That’s a full smile. That’s premeditated.”

I looked up the aisle. She had a point. Mr. Parrish’s usual expression hovered somewhere between sleepy and mildly impressed by his own puns. Now his eyes were bright, fixated on the town rolling into view like he’d been waiting for this exact moment all year. Maybe longer.

The driver pulled up in front of the Salem Witch Museum. Gray stone, red-lit windows, a big sign that screamed FIELD TRIP BROCHURE PHOTO. The sky was low and white, heavy with the kind of clouds that made you think of eraser shavings.

Before anyone could stand, Parrish spun around.

“Okay, scholars,” he said. “Remember, stay with your groups, be respectful, and—”

“Don’t get possessed,” called out Mateo from the back.

Laughter rippled through the bus.

Parrish’s smile didn’t falter. “Actually, possession accusations were more of a European phenomenon,” he said. “But we’ll discuss that. And much more.” His voice dropped just a notch. “Today is about perspective.”

There was something about the way he said that last word that pricked the back of my neck.

We filed out into the cold. It smelled like wet brick and sea salt, and something faintly sweet from a nearby fudge shop where witches with purple hats stared out from the window display.

Jenna zipped her jacket up to her chin. “You’re telling me he isn’t weirdly into this? Look.”

Parrish stood at the front of the group, watching all thirty-two of us gather, his hands behind his back, rocking on his heels. Not impatient exactly. Anticipating. His tie was crooked; it always was. His hair, which usually looked like he’d just run his hands through it in frustration, was combed for once, but there was a wildness at the edges. Like he’d tried to tame it and it had politely refused.

“Okay,” he said, clapping once. “Our first stop: context. We’re not tourists today; we are witnesses. I want you thinking about fear, power, and what people do when they’re convinced they’re right. Stay close.”

The words witnesses and fear made a couple of people snicker, but Parrish didn’t bother to correct them. He led us inside.

The museum’s main exhibit was a dark room with glowing scenes of the 1692 trials. Mannequins frozen mid-accusation. Girls with hands clutched to their throats. Judges leaning forward with carved wooden suspicion. The narration boomed over us, a disembodied voice describing paranoia, grudges, the slow creep of hysteria.

I’d read about Salem before, done the worksheet, regurgitated the dates. But sitting there under the shifting red light, I felt a little tighter in my chest than I wanted to admit.

Jenna leaned over. “I swear one of those mannequins just blinked.”

“Stop.”

“No, like, what if this is one of those immersive educational horror experiences? Sponsored by the PTA.”

The narrator’s voice dropped an octave. Something about spectral evidence. About how easy it was to mistake imagination for truth when everyone agreed to be afraid.

From the corner of my eye, I watched Parrish. He wasn’t looking at the mannequins. He was looking at us.

His lips moved slightly, like he was mouthing along. Not with the narration, though—off by a beat. Almost like he knew a different script.

I shook it off. Creepy environments make people look creepy. That’s all.

After the show, we spilled back out into the gray afternoon. The cold had teeth now.

“Next,” Parrish said, “we’re going to the Old Burying Point, then the memorial.”

“We love a cemetery before lunch,” Mateo muttered.

I fell into step beside Parrish as we walked. I hadn’t meant to, but he slowed down a little, like he wanted someone there.

“Mr. Parrish?” I said.

“Yes, Lila?” He always remembered names. It was one of his better qualities.

“You’re… really into this trip.”

He glanced at me, amused. “It’s an excellent teaching opportunity.”

“Sure. But you fought pretty hard to get permission. Ms. Greene told us in homeroom.”

He didn’t answer right away. The group ahead of us veered around a puddle. He watched them.

“Do you know how many times school boards insist ‘this could be done with a video’?” he said quietly. “How many times we flatten history into three bullet points so it fits on a test?”

“Probably a lot,” I said.

“More than you think. Salem is about how stories get told, and whose stories we believe. Being here matters.” He hesitated, then smiled down at me. “And perhaps I have… affinities.”

“Affinities,” I repeated.

He only shrugged.

The cemetery was old in a way that pressed down on you. Thin slate headstones with skulls and wings carved on top, dates so far back they looked wrong: 1690, 1703, 1717. The ground was uneven and damp, and the trees were stripped fingers against the sky.

Parrish moved through the rows like he knew them. He stopped at one particular headstone and rested his hand on it, almost casually.

“Jonathan Parrish,” he read aloud. “My many-times-great-grandfather. He was here. Different side of the drama, though. One of the ministers.”

A few of us leaned in.

“Wait,” Jenna said. “Like, Salem witch trials minister-minister?”

He shook his head, lips twisting. “He signed some papers. Offered some counsel. Never led the trials, but he didn’t stop them either.” He looked at the name as if expecting it to answer for itself. “We carry our ancestors’ shadows without asking, don’t we?”

It was one of those things that sounded like it belonged in a college lecture, not out loud at a public-school field trip. Still, a little chill snuck down my arms.

“So is that why you’re obsessed?” I asked, trying to keep my tone light. “Ancestral guilt?”

He smiled, but it didn’t reach his eyes. “Let’s say I have a personal stake in remembering how easily good people go along with bad things.”

From there he herded us to the memorial: a stone wall with jutting benches, each carved with the name of someone executed. It was simple. Unadorned. People whispered; even Mateo went quiet.

“Twenty people killed because their neighbors believed lies,” Parrish said softly. “Because girls played a game they didn’t understand. Because authority chose fear over facts.”

His voice was low, but we all heard it. The air felt suddenly heavier.

“Look at the names,” he said. “Say them in your head. One day you’ll be asked to sign something, or support something, that hurts people. It will feel normal. It will feel… expected. Your teacher will be very excited about a particular trip. Your principal will praise your cooperation. Your news will tell you who’s dangerous. And you’ll have to decide whether you go along.”

An uneasy laugh bubbled up from somewhere behind me, but died quickly.

“Okay,” said Ms. Greene, appearing at the edge of the group. She’d come as our other chaperone, perpetually armed with permission slips and hand sanitizer. She gave Parrish a sideways look. “Let’s keep it PG-13, please.”

“What?” he said lightly. “This is PG-13. No entrails.”

She shook her head, but she was smiling. Everyone relaxed a notch. We drifted back toward the visitor center for lunch.

Inside, kids lined up for pizza and soda. Witch souvenirs crowded the shelves: green faces, broomsticks, cartoon cauldrons. The whole city had turned its darkest story into a brand.

I poked at my slice. “It’s weird,” I said to Jenna. “All this cutesy stuff. Then actual graves down the street.”

“It’s America,” she said. “Trauma, but make it merch.” She paused, then squinted at me. “You’re quiet. Are you freaking out? Did Parrish get into your head?”

“I’m fine,” I said.

I wasn’t sure if it was true.

Because somewhere between the mannequins, the family grave, and his speech, I’d started to notice that this wasn’t just pride in a well-planned lesson. It felt personal, like he was testing us. Measuring us against something only he could see.

When lunch ended, he called us together for “one last stop before the gift shops.” Of course there were more stops. There were always more stops with him.

He led us down a narrower street, away from the main drag. The buildings leaned closer here, brick and wood pressed tight like they were sharing secrets.

“We’re running behind,” Ms. Greene said, checking her watch. “We still need time for the House of the Seven Gables.”

“This won’t take long,” Parrish said.

We stopped in front of a small, weathered house with a wooden plaque. Not on our printed itinerary.

“This,” Parrish said, “is one of the parsonage sites. Where some of the first accusations took shape. The records are spotty; the foundation’s a patchwork. But this is where fear started to root.”

The yard was empty, roped off. A cracked stone foundation framed dead leaves.

He turned to us.

“I wanted you to see how ordinary it is,” he said. “No thunderbolts, no swirling dark energy. Just a house where people ate breakfast, argued about chores, complained about the cold. That’s where history shifts, most of the time. Ordinary places. Ordinary choices.”

He wasn’t smiling now.

“You think I’m excited because I like spooky stories,” he went on. “That I dragged you here for atmosphere. But what I want is for you to remember how easily a community can agree to hurt its own. Salem is a warning that doesn’t go away.”

A siren wailed faintly a few streets over. A bus hissed. Someone’s phone buzzed.

“For months, I petitioned to bring you here,” he said. “I got pushback. Too grim. Too far. Not on the standardized exam. But you’re going to grow up in a world that will ask you to choose who deserves empathy. Who deserves punishment. And I am, I admit, suspiciously excited to put you in the place where saying ‘no’ meant everything.”

His gaze traveled over us, and for a second it felt like he was looking straight through our hoodies and backpacks and restless fidgeting to something he hoped was hidden there: a spine.

Jenna nudged me. “Okay,” she whispered. “That’s kind of intense.”

“Yeah,” I said. But my voice came out softer than I expected.

We stood there for a moment, thirty-two eighth-graders staring at a sagging rectangle of stone that once held up a floor where people chose what kind of town this would be. Or failed to.

Then Ms. Greene clapped her hands to break the spell. “All right, folks! Let’s move. House of the Seven Gables, ten minutes, then it’s souvenir time!”

The spell frayed. People cheered for souvenir time. We shuffled away.

As we walked back toward the brighter part of Salem, Mr. Parrish fell into step beside me again.

“Do you think they heard you?” I asked.

He shrugged, eyes on the sidewalk. “You can’t make people listen,” he said. “You can only invite them to pay attention. Sometimes you take them somewhere the walls remember, and hope it echoes later when it matters.”

“That’s why you were so excited,” I said slowly. “Not… you know. For a blood ritual.”

He laughed, the ordinary, mortal sound of it. “Sorry to disappoint.”

“I didn’t say I was disappointed,” I said. “Just… okay. I get it. A little.”

He nodded once, like that was enough.

Behind us, someone shouted about buying a witch hat. Ahead, the bus driver leaned against the bus, scrolling his phone. Salem went on selling its story.

I glanced back, just once, at the quiet house at the end of the street and the teacher who had dragged us here with shining eyes.

Maybe, I thought, some excitements are worth being suspicious of, if they make you look twice.

samples.prompt: If God is a universe, the planets are his cells. Human life is like a virus, destroying one cell until it can populate the next... and God's just discovered the infection.
samples.output:
It began as a tremor.

Not in the soil, not in the sky, not in any measurable vibration of tectonic plates or air currents, but in the way light fell through the atmosphere. The sunrise bled in wrong. Reds too deep, violets too sharp. Birds turned their heads sideways, watching the line of dawn approach as if it were a wall of glass about to shatter.

Most people didn’t notice. Those that did blamed pollution, volcanoes, some anomaly with solar flares. The news cycles chewed on it for a few hours, then spat it out for something easier to monetize.

I was on night shift at the observatory when we picked up the first real sign.

“Something’s off with Jupiter,” Yasmin had said, leaning into my shoulder, eyes narrowed at the screen.

The feed showed Jupiter as always: striped, massive, crowned with storms. But the numbers on the side—magnetic field intensity, gravitational flux, atmospheric composition—were sliding like someone had knocked over a tray of neatly ordered data.

“It’s a glitch,” I muttered.

“It’s all of them,” she replied.

One by one, the giants were changing. Mass increased, density fluctuated, orbit lines thickening in red, then blinking into recalculated projections. Mars brightened a fraction. Venus cooled a fraction. The code didn’t know how to lie that well.

We triple-checked. We called other observatories. We called the university. By morning, the silent channels between institutions were screaming.

And then, globally, the headaches began.

People described it later as pressure behind the eyes, like the air itself remembered gravity wrong for a moment. For about seven minutes, every person conscious enough to notice felt watched. Not metaphorically. Not spiritually. Watched like an insect under a magnifying lens, as the sun’s heat centers on its thorax.

Seven minutes.

Later, we would come to call that interval the First Glance.

It took less than a day for the theories to explode. Apocalyptic forums dragged out every prophecy they could scrape up. Physicists discussed unknown forces on live television, trying to sound calm as their models publicly failed. Conspiracy channels included phrases like “holographic overlay,” “simulation admin,” “planetary correction.”

None of them were wrong enough, and none of them were right.

The second sign came three days later, and it did not care about our capacity for denial.

Saturn’s rings vanished.

Not “drifted” or “collapsed.” Gone. In one recorded instant, the icy debris that had circled the planet for hundreds of millions of years compressed into a thin, luminous band that pulsed once like a tightening belt, then was gone, leaving behind an atmosphere humming in artificial harmonics.

It was Yasmin who said it, voice cracking in the staff kitchen while the others argued.

“He’s counting,” she whispered.

“Who?” I asked, distracted, scrolling through frantic internal memos.

She didn’t look away from the loop of Saturn. “God. The host. Whatever you want to call it.”

I laughed because there was nothing else to do. “That’s poetic, Yas. Not helpful. We need—”

“You know the analogy.” She turned on me then, eyes fever-bright. “God as the universe, planets as his cells. We breed, we consume, we strip each sphere and move on. We’ve been romanticizing ourselves as explorers, but we’re acting like a virus. Saturn’s rings were never for us. They were… his. You don’t see it? He’s feeling for damage.”

Her words clicked into the prompt I’d read years ago, some piece of speculative fiction on an obscure forum. A metaphor. A warning.

Now it felt like diagnosis.

Over the next weeks, it was as if the Solar System answered her.

Celestial mechanics shifted in ways that mocked our math. Orbits fine-tuned. Planetary rotations synced into complex resonances. Jupiter’s Great Red Spot contracted and narrowed into a single, perfect circle of deep black, absorbing light without reflection.

We sent probes. We lost probes. Signals from anything beyond the asteroid belt returned scrambled, overwritten with a pattern that, when parsed, resembled a heartbeat.

We learned two new truths.

First: we lived not in a universe, but in a body.

Second: that body had just located an infection.

The recognition came through dreams first, because that was the only channel that could reach everyone at once.

For a while, I thought it was just me.

I was standing in a city made of stars. Each building an upright column of galaxies, stacked like vertebrae. The sky was inside-out; I could see the curve of something enormous, like the underside of ribs. A presence pressed against my mind—curious, not yet angry. Not human, but vast, carried on a tide of meaning that felt like language if you had a skull big enough to hold it.

“IDENTIFY,” it said, without sound.

I woke choking on light. At 03:17. Pulse racing. The alarm buzzing on my phone with a message: Observatory Emergency Meeting.

In the corridors, people had the same haunted gaze. Later, surveys would confirm that at that exact minute, four billion people woke up from nearly identical dreams. Another two billion would remember only fragments. The rest were too young, too old, strung out, or simply unreachable.

A broadcast went out from the United Nations, hastily assembled, translated into every major language.

“We have reason to believe,” the Secretary-General said carefully, “that a non-localized, system-wide intelligence has become aware of us in a manner resembling immune recognition.”

She did not say God. She did not need to.

“The changes we observe suggest this intelligence is altering the structure of our solar system. We must consider that our extractive expansion—our treatment of Earth and plans for off-world colonization—may be triggering a defensive response.”

She was interrupted, not by a heckler, but by the sky.

Every screen went black. Every device, every broadcast, every HUD, every augmented lens.

Then, an image:

A cell, magnified. Organelles suspended, walls intact. Then a swarm of tiny forms, bright points of gnawing light. They burrowed, multiplied, shredded, moved on. The cell membrane ruptured. The swarm spread to the next.

Over it, a single concept, unvoiced but undeniable:

YOU.

We panicked, naturally.

Some screamed. Some prayed. Some denied the experience even as they lived it, insisting hallucination, mass hysteria, government psy-op. Markets crashed. Borders snapped shut. There were riots at space agency gates and launches canceled under threat of attack; a desperate, irrational desire to prove to whatever watched us that we were not planning to leave our wounded cell and gnaw at another.

There were those who argued the opposite: if we were a virus, then our survival depended on spreading faster than the immune system could respond. They talked of secret launches, of burrowing into asteroids, of hiding in the dark.

But there is no “hiding in the dark” from something for whom darkness and light are just different textures of its own skin.

The next intervention was surgical.

The moon blinked.

For one terrifying second, it vanished, replaced by a silhouette like a pupil constricting. Tides hiccuped, shorelines sighed, and then the moon was back—but altered. Its orbit locked, its wobble smoothed. On its surface, new patterns of shadow etched themselves into rings and spirals visible even to the naked eye.

Global gravitational anomalies ceased. Subduction zones calmed. Storm cycles stabilized.

It felt like a hand pressing gently on a bruise.

A warning. Not yet a strike.

Within the scientific community, debates took on a frantic edge: Could we communicate, demonstrate our value, like bacteria that have learned to fix nitrogen instead of just feeding on flesh? Could an infection convince an immune system that it belonged?

Into this tension, the dreams came again.

This time, there was no city of stars. There was Earth: a blue-green orb suspended in a translucent membrane of atmosphere. Around it, faint filters unfurled, complexes of light arranging themselves like proteins locking into place.

“EXPLAIN,” the Presence pulsed.

Images burst from us—not individually, but as a species: art, music, children’s laughter, mathematics, sacrifices, kindnesses. Also war, oil slicks, forests razed to nubs. Satellites like shrapnel. Rockets like injections aimed outward.

The Presence weighed it.

Here was the unbearable fact: from its perspective, we were not evil. We were not fallen. We were functionally small, mindless, a pattern of replication that did not yet understand it was chewing through nerve tissue.

Still, there was something.

In our art, in our complex self-loathing and self-awareness, there was a flicker that did not match the rest of the viral metaphor. Cancer does not write love songs about the body it is killing.

Perhaps that was why we were not erased that day.

Instead, the message came, not in words, but in an axiom written into physics:

NO MORE SPREAD.

Fusion drives failed beyond a certain orbital radius, their reactions damping as if space itself grew viscous. Uncrewed probes lost coherence as their circuits decohered into gray dust beyond a boundary we soon mapped: a transparent sphere, just past Mars, enclosing us.

A quarantine.

Inside it, subtle changes: yields of fossil fuels dropped as if wells were capped by invisible stones. Industrial accidents averted by freak coincidences—a power plant shut down “by mistake” minutes before critical failure. Viruses lethal to us dissolved mid-mutation. We were being managed: encouraged to live, discouraged from metastasizing.

Our grand plans for Mars domes, Jupiter mining, Titan cities—all evaporated.

The governments blustered. Engineering teams tried to brute-force the barrier: more thrust, different designs. Nothing worked. Some extremists launched nukes at the invisible line. The warheads never detonated. They simply disassembled, shells and cores fluttering apart like ash.

Months passed. The world did not end.

Instead, a strange thing happened: with off-world fantasies cut off, attention turned inward. Not by moral enlightenment, but because there was nowhere else to look.

We watched the forests regrow faster than our models allowed. We watched certain species, on the brink of extinction, rebound mysteriously. We found that some of our most destructive machines failed at critical moments, sparing lives and ecosystems, while our tools for healing and restoration seemed almost… favored. Anomalously efficient. As if the host body, having identified the infection, had decided to experiment: could this cluster of rogue cells be redirected into maintenance?

The theologians called it mercy. The cynics called it control. The biologists called it immunomodulation.

One night, months into quarantine, I dreamed again of the star-city.

This time, the Presence was not a looming pressure, but a fact, like gravity.

“YOU HURT,” it conveyed—not accusation, but observation. Images followed: forests stripped, seas acidifying, atmosphere thickening. The damage we’d done to the cell that housed us.

“YOU LEARN?” it asked.

It could erase us in a cosmic blink. Instead, it was asking.

I thought about viruses then: crude, yes, but also ancient. Some, over time, had threaded themselves into their host genomes, becoming essential. Viral fragments drove the evolution of placentas, of immune systems, of memory. Infection turned symbiosis. Parasitic became co-creative.

We stood on that pivot.

In the dream, with whatever collective voice humanity had in that moment, we answered—not with certainty, not with promise, but with a direction.

We showed rewilding projects, dismantled pipelines, cities redesigned around restoration instead of extraction. We showed the decision not to launch certain rockets. We showed resistance to our worst impulses, even when profit screamed otherwise.

The Presence watched.

It did not say, “I forgive you.”

It did not say, “You belong.”

Instead, I felt an adjustment ripple through everything: constants nudged, probabilities skewed. A gentle bias in favor of our better choices, like an immune system deciding—for now—not to annihilate a suspect cell cluster, but to surround it with regulators, to see if it could be tolerated.

Morning came. The sun rose in proper colors. The headaches were gone.

The quarantine remained.

We still argue about it. Some call for revolt against the cosmic tyrant. Some kneel. Most adapt, as we always do, grumbling, innovating, learning to live inside limits we did not choose.

I still work nights. I still watch the data.

And sometimes, as I trace the perfect resonances of planets in their new, tuned orbits, I feel less like a virus and more like something else trying to be born—something learning, very late, to love the body it lives in.

We were the infection.

Now, perhaps, we have been given the narrowest chance to become an organ.

samples.prompt: You wake one day to find that one of your friends doesn't exist anymore, no one remembers him, and no one thinks he even existed. Later, you get a message with 5 words from an unknown number. you scream in horror as you read the message.
samples.output:
The alarm went off at 7:13 a.m., as always.

I slapped at my phone until the noise stopped and squinted at the screen. Four notifications. Two news alerts, some spam, and a text from Alex.

Except it wasn’t from Alex.

It was from “Unknown.”

The message preview read: “You awake? Need a favor—”

I frowned, opened it. The chat history was empty. No older messages, no photos, no late-night memes. Just the one line.

Unknown: You awake? Need a favor—

The em dash hung there, like the thought had been cut in half.

I typed: Who is this?

Three blinking dots appeared, then vanished. No reply.

I waited for the familiar spiral of annoyance. This felt like the kind of half-baked prank Alex would pull: spoofing his number, freaking me out before coffee.

I scrolled up again, expecting to see months of blue and gray bubbles. There was nothing. My thumb moved faster.

Where’s the thread? I thought.

Because there should have been one: a three-year tower of blunt honesty and bad jokes and arguments about movies; the kind of message history that made your phone feel like a shared brain. Instead there was a void where an entire friendship was supposed to be.

I went to Contacts.

Search: Alex.

No results.

I was still groggy. I tried his last name. Nothing.

That jarred me awake. I sat up, heartbeat starting to tap at my ribs. Maybe I accidentally deleted him. Maybe an update wiped something. Data got lost.

I checked Instagram. Search bar: alex.meyers. The auto-fill didn’t even twitch. No profile picture of him squinting into the sun, no grid of his dog, no highlight labeled “Chaos.”

I checked our group chat: “The Feral Four.” It had always been stupidly named, coined by Alex at 2 a.m. in the student union. The icon was a blurry selfie of the four of us after finals, exhausted and grinning.

Now the chat was named: “The Three of Us.”

The icon showed me, Hannah, and Priyanka. There was a gap where someone should have been, like the framing expected a fourth person and had given up.

I scrolled up. Years of messages. No *him*. No sarcasm, no play-fights with Pri, no unprompted 2 a.m. voice memos. Every joke, every reference that should have belonged to him had rearranged itself. It was like reading a book where someone had surgically removed a supporting character and stitched the pages back together.

I typed, hands colder now:

Me: Did one of you rename this? Where’s Alex in here?

Three dots from Hannah. Then:

Hannah: Who’s Alex?

She had to be kidding. I waited for a laughing emoji. A “lol” tagged on.

Priyanka: You ok? Did you mean Alan from work?

Me: No. Alex. OUR Alex. Don’t screw around.

Hannah: Babe, I think you’re still half-asleep.

Priyanka: Call us. For real.

The room pressed in. I opened Photos.

Search: Alex.

Zero results.

My throat went dry. I tried “April,” the month we’d gone hiking; “museum,” “road trip,” anything that should have dragged his stupid face onto the screen.

The pictures were wrong.

The hiking pic on the cliff edge showed three of us. Same composition—but the person on my left was missing. My arm was lifted like it had been slung around someone’s shoulders, but there was only empty air, a smear of sky. The museum selfie: three of us again, with an awkwardly wide gap between Hannah and me. That gap made my eyes hurt.

I whispered, “No,” and tried not to notice that the whisper sounded exactly like a prayer.

I called Hannah. She picked up on the second ring.

“You’re scaring me,” she said.

“Where is he?” My voice shook. “Where’s Alex?”

“Okay,” she said slowly, “I need you to tell me who you mean. Like, describe him? Because I have literally never had a friend named Alex, and we’ve known each other eleven years.”

“You’re joking. Stop it.”

“I’m not. And your texts just now—are you having a panic attack? Because I can come over.”

Priyanka chimed in on speaker: “I Googled your name plus ‘Alex.’ Nothing. No tags in your photos, no mutuals. If this is a bit, it’s a really messed up one.”

I hung up.

Panic crawled up my spine, cold and precise. I went to Facebook, then to old college group pages. No posts from him. No comments where he’d roasted me. No likes. Nothing.

I tried to recall his number from memory and type it in. The digits slipped, rearranged themselves, vanished like writing in water. I’d never realized how much I relied on my phone to remember for me until that moment—until I found out it didn’t.

My mind rifled desperately through details.

His full name: Alex Meyers. We’d met freshman year when he spilled coffee on my notebook and spent the rest of the semester lending me his laptop. He hated olives. He loved thunderstorms. He’d once driven four hours just to sit with me when my dad went into surgery. He had that tiny scar on his forehead from the “stapler incident.” He called me at midnight every birthday to sing badly on purpose.

I knew him.

I knew him.

I grabbed my keys. Outside, the sky was bright and stupidly cheerful, as if the world wasn’t pulling itself inside out.

I drove to campus. The roads were the same. The deli where he’d insisted on getting those awful pickles was still there. I parked crooked, didn’t care.

The registrar’s office. I pulled open heavy doors with hands that didn’t feel attached to me.

“Hi,” I said too fast to the woman at the front desk. “I’m trying to find records for a student. He went here the same years I did. We had classes together. His name is Alex Meyers.”

She tapped her keyboard, then again, more slowly.

“Spelling?”

I spelled it.

She frowned. “No one by that name in our system. Are you sure he attended this university?”

“Yes, I’m sure.”

“Maybe he went by a middle name? Or another campus?” Her tone was professional sympathy, the voice people used for mix-ups and misunderstandings.

I left before I started yelling.

In the hallway, I called my mom.

“Hey,” she said warmly. “Everything okay?”

“You remember Alex, right? From college?”

Silence.

“Sweetie, you didn’t really have friends in college until junior year, when you met Hannah and Priyanka. Is this about that dream journal stuff again?”

I almost dropped the phone. “The picture on the fridge,” I said. “From graduation. There are four of us.”

“What? No, there’s three. You, Hannah, and Pri with the balloons. It’s been there for years.” A small pause. “Are you sure you’re okay?”

I hung up without answering.

My pulse shouted in my ears. The building’s fluorescent lights hummed like insects. Everyone around me moved normal-speed, unaware.

Back at the car, my phone vibrated.

Unknown: Sorry. Signal bad. Need a favor.

I stared. My own reflection watched me in the dark screen: wide eyes, grayish skin.

Who are you? I typed.

No reply. The typing dots appeared, vanished. Appeared again, then stopped.

I sat with it, lungs straining. My fingers flew.

If this is Alex, this isn’t funny. Everyone’s acting like you never existed. All the photos are wrong. Your number’s gone. What’s happening?

I hit send.

No answer.

I went home because I didn’t know where else to go. I tore through my room like a burglar. Yearbooks, notebooks, shoeboxes of printed photos I hadn’t looked at in years. Every snapshot that should have shown him had been… edited. Not obviously—there were no jagged cuts, no blurred silhouettes. The geometry of the pictures was simply off, like the world had grown around an old absence.

A folded sheet of paper fell out of a book.

It was a doodle. A cartoon version of me with wild hair and fiercer eyebrows, holding a mug labeled “Existential Crisis Fuel.” It was funny. It was his style.

Only the bottom corner, where his name should have been, was empty. A torn edge that had never been torn.

My phone buzzed again.

Unknown: Don’t ask anyone else about me.

Some logic, some survival instinct, screamed at me then, an animal sound in the back of my skull.

I didn’t listen.

I called Priyanka. “Look, just humor me,” I said. “If I asked you yesterday who my closest friends were, what would you say?”

“You mean now? Or in general?”

“Yesterday,” I insisted.

“You, me, and Hannah,” she said slowly. “Same as always.”

“No one else?”

“Should there be? Do you… think there should be?” Concern threaded through her voice. “I’m coming over.”

“No, don’t—” I started, but she’d already hung up.

My chest tightened. Whatever this was, it was getting worse.

My phone buzzed. Another text from Unknown.

Unknown: You shouldn’t have done that.

The room dimmed around the edges. I typed: If this is you, prove it. Tell me something only Alex would know.

A longer pause. Then:

Unknown: When your dad was in surgery, I brought you the wrong coffee but you drank it anyway so I wouldn’t feel bad. You pretended not to cry until I left, but you didn’t know I heard you.

My breath snagged. I had never told anyone that part. The cheap plastic chair, the vending machine hum, the way I’d folded inward once the door swung shut.

I typed with shaking fingers: Alex?

The reply came fast this time.

Unknown: Listen. I don’t have long. They’re fixing it.

My throat closed. Fixing what?

Me: What happened? Why does no one remember you?

Unknown: I wasn’t supposed to be here. Error. Glitch. Whatever word helps. They’re rewriting. Cleaning up.

Cold swept through me.

Me: You’re talking like some kind of system update. You’re a person.

Unknown: I was. To you, at least.

Me: To me? Just me?

Unknown: You noticed first. That’s why they’re mad.

The word “they” sat on the screen, heavy and undefined.

My fingers hovered. I wanted to ask a hundred questions. I settled on the one that terrified me most.

Me: Are you in danger?

Unknown: Already done. I’m not the one you should worry about.

My heart stuttered. A car door slammed outside. Priyanka, coming up the walk.

Unknown: They don’t like loose ends. You remember too much.

I ran to the front door, half to stop Priyanka, half to prove to myself she was real. I flung it open.

She stood there, hand raised to knock, eyes wide. “You look awful,” she said. “What’s going on?”

My phone buzzed again. I didn’t want to look. I did.

Five new words from the unknown number.

Five words that made me scream.

“You weren’t supposed to exist either.”

samples.prompt: 2 serial killers start dating with the intention of making their new SO their next victim. Neither one knows the other is out to get them.
samples.output:
They met on a Tuesday, which seemed like an unlucky day to begin with.

Evan noticed her first. Reddish hair in a knot, black dress with white polka dots, boots too practical for the bar’s sticky floor. She sat angled away from the crowd, one elbow on the counter, fingers circling the rim of a club soda with lime. Watching people, like he was.

He decided in eleven seconds she was perfect.

Target, he thought.

She noticed him noticing her. Dark curls, clean-shaven, a button-down that looked like he’d ironed it himself. No ring. No friends. Drinking something brown and slow. He had that slightly awkward posture of someone who doesn’t quite fit into his own skin.

Victim, she thought.

They locked eyes when the bartender walked away.

“You look as bored as I am,” she said.

“Existentially,” he replied. “I’m Evan.”

“Claire.”

The lie slipped between them like a third person. His real name was Owen. Hers was Mara. Their false names sat there, smiling.

He made her laugh twice in the first three minutes, which irritated her. It complicated things when they were charming. Better when they were already broken and lonely and heavy with whatever they’d done. He looked… gentle. Bookish. The type who apologized for things he didn’t do. Delicious.

She tilted her head, listening to the little edges in his voice. The faint tension in his shoulders. It didn’t fit the soft eyes. There was a coiled quiet underneath.

Better, she thought. He’ll follow me anywhere.

He watched the way she scanned entrances and exits without moving her head. She put her back to a wall despite getting there first. That detail hummed in him. Caution. Maybe trauma. Trauma made people predictable. He liked predictable.

“I don’t usually do this,” she said after he offered to buy her a drink.

He smiled. “You don’t usually accept drinks from strangers or you don’t usually talk to men who look like insurance adjusters?”

“Both.”

He ordered her a tonic with lime. No alcohol. Clocked it. She hadn’t had a real drink all night. Clear head. No drugs. Interesting.

She took a sip, not breaking eye contact. He was careful, she decided. Smart. But if he were dangerous, he’d have pushed something stronger. Men like that liked to speed things along.

She relaxed a fraction.

He noticed.

By the time they left, an hour and a half later, they had each other’s numbers and the vague promise of “Let’s do this again.” Neither pressed for a home address. A courtesy. A warning. A game.

On his way back to his car, Evan ran through her details. “Claire” worked in graphic design. Lived “near the park.” Volunteered occasionally at an animal shelter. Too tidy. He respected that.

He already knew where she really lived. He’d watched her reflection as she typed her number into his phone, read the reversed digits, and had run them as soon as he’d stepped outside. Data came easily to him. He’d find the rest tonight.

Mara walked home instead of taking the rideshare she’d ordered in front of the bar. She’d cancelled it around the corner, slipping down side streets. Evan—no, “Evan,” she corrected herself with a smirk—had been careful, but not careful enough. His phone case had a university logo she traced to a faculty staff listing. “Systems administrator,” it said. That tracked. Neat, quiet, invisible.

Perfect.

She locked her apartment door, opened her laptop, and did not search him yet. She liked to give fate twelve hours before she broke it down.

Second date, they met at a bookstore café. Neutral territory. Public but quiet.

Mara arrived early. Picked a table facing the door. Ordered herbal tea.

Evan arrived with a paperback under his arm. He’d chosen that deliberately. Something literary, unthreatening. White noise of good taste.

“You actually came,” he said.

“You sound surprised.”

“I’m habitually pessimistic.”

She smiled. File that away. “I said I would, didn’t I?”

They traded small histories that weren’t quite lies, just edited. She talked about an “ex” she’d left because he “didn’t see her.” Conveniently omitted the part about the plastic sheeting. He talked about growing up “isolated” and learning “to disappear.” Omitted the basements.

He watched how she stirred her tea, clockwise, slow, never letting the spoon hit the sides. Controlled. Intentional. He wondered about her real tells. About how she’d look afraid.

She watched the way he watched. Not like a man wanted her, like a man in a museum studying vulnerabilities in old glass.

She’d kill him at her cabin, she decided. Third or fourth date, invite him out to “get away from the city.” No cell service. She already had the tarp.

He’d do it in her apartment, he decided. Return from the bathroom with something in his palm. Touch the rim of her wineglass. By dessert, her muscles would stop listening. He would.

They texted after: I had fun. We should do this again.

Third date was dinner. A place with soft lighting, white tablecloths. Too public to act, both knew, but perfect for calibrating.

Mara arrived in a navy dress that hid bruises or restraints if needed. Evan noted that. Evan wore a jacket heavy enough to conceal almost anything.

He ordered the Merlot. She let him.

“Trust me?” he asked.

“For now,” she said.

He watched her glass level. She never drank more than half. Interesting. Maybe she was one of those performative careful types. Or maybe she’d been drugged before. He felt something like anger at another man for getting there first.

She asked about his job. He played up the boredom. She probed for volatility. Prior arrests, bar fights, bad divorces. Nothing. His slate looked clean.

He asked about her art. She spoke in vague gestures. No mention of family. He filed an “estranged, rootless” tag in his mind.

The waiter brought dessert menus. Mara touched her lip with her finger, as if thinking.

“I’ve got better at my place,” she said. “Homemade.”

Risky, Evan thought. Inviting him in this soon. Or confident. Either way, it had to be her ground. He smiled.

“I’d like that.”

Her apartment was small, meticulous. Plants thriving, knives where they belonged. Books, mostly crime novels. He scanned silently.

He thought: Don’t smile at the knives.

She thought: Don’t look at his hands too long.

Mara fetched the dessert—a dark chocolate tart—from the fridge.

“Wine?” she offered.

“Sure.” He watched her pour. From a bottle already open, good. If she’d meant to do something, she’d have opened a new one in front of him, to perform trust.

She watched his eyes as he raised the glass. He drank. She did too. Safe. Mutual.

They ate, made jokes about pretentious pastry chefs. When he kissed her, it was mostly to see if she flinched.

She didn’t. Her hand slid up his neck—a test of his pulse, his calm. He passed.

He left an hour later with her lipstick on his mouth and her taste in his thoughts. He hadn’t killed her. Yet. Patience made better art.

She slid the bolt behind him and leaned against the door. He’d seen her lock choice. High-end deadbolt, extra chain. He’d smelled bleach, faint under lemon. If he was any good, he knew she was dangerous too. Had he noticed? Did he care?

She smiled.

Date five, she invited him to the cabin.

“I like you,” she’d said on the phone, voice light. “I don’t usually… I have this place I go when the city’s too much. You should come.”

He hesitated just long enough to be believable. Cross-country drive, remote location. If it were anyone else, it would’ve pinged every alarm. With her, it was exactly what he wanted.

“Yeah,” he said. “Let’s go.”

He prepared. Switched cars with one of his safe ones. New plates. Packed rope and tools disguised as camping gear. Brought his own food and water, just in case she tried something stupid. It would be almost sweet, he thought, if they both arrived with private murder kits.

She arrived with a duffel bag heavy enough to hold power tools. A cooler. A smile that almost reached her eyes.

The drive north was an easy soundtrack of shared sarcasm and curated vulnerability.

“My ex used to gaslight me,” she said.

“My parents were… cold,” he said.

Each offered a morsel of pain, never the whole carcass.

The cabin sat alone among pines, lake dark and still behind it. No neighbors. No lights but theirs. Perfect.

He stepped inside first, noting the hooks in the ceiling beams. She’d left them up. Bold.

“Nice place,” he said.

“Thanks. It’s my sanctuary.”

He felt her gaze on his back; she felt his on her doorframes.

Later, after a fire and cheap whiskey he pretended to drink, they stood outside under a ribcage of stars. Frogs, crickets, the hush of wind.

She thought: When he comes back inside, I’ll ask him to grab the wine opener. It’s in the drawer with the syringe.

He thought: When she leans in to kiss me next, I’ll push her against the frame. The hypodermic is in my sleeve.

“You’re quiet,” she said.

“Thinking,” he said. “About how weirdly easy this all feels.”

“Yeah,” she said. “Like we’ve known each other longer than we have.”

She stepped closer. He mirrored. Two magnets, same pole, moving anyway.

She lifted her hand, fingertips brushing the back of his neck. He shifted his weight, arm flexing.

Both moved at once.

His hand snapped for her jaw. Her hand drove for his ribs. Metal kissed metal—her blade against the casing of his syringe. Their eyes met over the collision.

The night held its breath.

She saw the needle. He saw the knife. The recognition landed, cold and precise.

“Oh,” she said softly.

“Shit,” he said.

They froze there: her knife half-drawn; his syringe half-bared. Lake black behind them, cabin yawning open.

“You first?” she asked.

“Ladies,” he said automatically.

She huffed a laugh despite herself. “How long?” she asked.

“Since the bar,” he said. “You?”

“Second date.”

“Rude,” he said.

Silence stretched. Calculation. Angles. How fast could she pivot? How quickly could he stab? They were close enough that either would land a blow. Not close enough to guarantee it would be fatal before the other responded.

“Here’s a problem,” she said. “We’re… weirdly compatible.”

“Professionally or personally?” he asked.

“Both.”

“I did come up here prepared to kill you,” he admitted.

“Same,” she said.

The honesty felt indecent.

“We could try,” he said. “Finish what we started.”

“We could,” she said. “And maybe we both die on some stupid gravel driveway over a misunderstanding.”

“I wouldn’t call it a misunderstanding.”

“We have the same hobby,” she said. “That’s something.”

He studied her. The steady hand on the knife. The lack of panic. The curiosity.

“You kill for what?” he asked. “Control? Correction?”

“Art,” she said. “Balance. You?”

“Order,” he said. “Cleaning up messes no one else sees.”

She considered. So did he.

“We could be… efficient,” she said slowly.

“We’d have to trust each other,” he said.

“That’s insane.”

“Absolutely.”

Another pause. Her hand slipped back, covering the knife, not sheathing it. His sleeve relaxed around the hidden syringe, not releasing it.

“One rule,” she said. “We don’t hunt each other.”

“And if one of us tries anyway?”

“Then the other one proves they’re better,” she said. “And walks away.”

He smiled. “I can live with that.”

“Can you?” she asked.

He thought of the bar, her laugh, the way her mind matched his step for step. He thought of what it would feel like to drag her inside and finish this now. The victory would be sharp, but solitary.

“Yeah,” he said slowly. “I think I’d rather see what we can do together.”

She watched him, looking for the flinch. He didn’t.

“Okay,” she said.

They stepped back at the same time, like a choreographed truce. The stars resumed humming, the lake resumed breathing.

Inside the cabin, there was rope that wouldn’t be used on either of them tonight. Plastic sheeting that would remain clean for now. Two sets of tools that would soon, perhaps, share a victim.

Mara—Claire—turned toward the door and glanced over her shoulder.

“Evan,” she said.

He raised an eyebrow.

“If you ever put anything in my drink,” she said, “I’ll make sure you’re awake for everything that happens after.”

“If you ever lure me anywhere with only one exit,” he said, “I’ll bring a second.”

Her mouth curved. “Deal.”

He stepped up beside her. For the first time since they met, his hand found hers without ulterior motive, fingers fitting between fingers like a lock accepting a key.

They went back inside, leaving the almost-murder on the threshold, for later.

samples.prompt: You have a very unique struggle. Your soul can randomly float out of your body, and you actively have to keep them in union for fear of death. Every time your soul leaves, everyone else registers it as a seizure or heart attack.
samples.output:
The first time my soul slipped, I was eight years old and in line for school lunch.

I remember the smell of overcooked broccoli, the squeak of sneakers on tile, the girl in front of me humming something off-key. Then, like a breath drawn in reverse, something inside me shuddered loose.

There was no warning. One moment, I was staring at a tray of chicken nuggets. The next, I was looking at myself from six feet away.

It was terrifying in the way only impossible things are: a terror too large to fit in my skull.

My body collapsed. My lunch tray clattered to the floor. Kids screamed. A teacher shouted my name.

From wherever I was—wherever “soul” counts as—I saw it all in horrible clarity. My face draining of color. My arms jerking. Someone rolling me on my side. The panic, the flurry of hands.

Inside—or outside, rather—I thrashed against something I couldn’t see. It felt like drifting in the deep end, lungs full but forgetting how to swim. There was a pull away and a pull back, and I understood, without words, that if I chose wrong, something permanent would happen.

I clawed my way back.

There isn’t language for it, really. It’s not walking. It’s not falling. It’s intention turned into gravity: I thought myself back into my body and snapped into place.

Pain arrived a moment later: the headache, the sore muscles, the raw throat. The nurse hovered above me; everyone said I’d had a seizure.

“Do you remember anything?” my mother asked in the ER that night.

“Yes,” I said, but not the thing she meant. The doctors talked in slow, careful sentences. "Likely epilepsy," they said. "Stress," they said. "We’ll monitor."

I didn’t argue. What could I say? Actually, my soul took a coffee break?

The second time, three months later, I was prepared.

I’d spent those weeks testing the edges of myself. Staring at my hands, holding my breath, wondering which part of me was the part that leaves. In bed at night, I’d will my soul to stay put like a kid afraid of monsters. Stay. Don’t. Please.

And then in math class, while Mrs. Danvers scribbled fractions on the whiteboard, my vision blurred and I felt that slippery loosening.

“No,” I whispered aloud.

It didn’t matter. The world lurched, and suddenly I was three feet behind my chair, watching my body stiffen and convulse, my desk rattling. A chorus of “oh my God”s rose.

The trick, I learned, is not to panic.

Panic pushes you further from your body. Panic makes you weightless. You start thinking you’re already dead, so why fight your way back into something that looks so fragile?

That time I grabbed onto the sound of my own name. Someone was calling it—Mrs. Danvers, frantic. I thought: That’s me. I belong to that. I followed my name like a rope until I slammed back into myself.

After that, “seizures” became a part of my identity. EEGs, MRIs, neurologist appointments. “Idiopathic epilepsy,” they concluded. Medication that barely helped. My mother’s carefully folded worry. My father’s quiet, practical terror.

“Just tell us if you feel funny,” he’d say.

“Funny” didn’t begin to cover it.

Souls, for the record, don’t feel like ghosts. They feel like density. Like the part of you that decides who you are. When it drifts, it takes your certainty with it. You’re left wondering if you are the body or the watcher.

I only started thinking of it as my soul in high school, when one of the interns at the hospital said, “Some people say seizures feel like their soul leaves their body.”

“It’s not a feeling,” I said before I could stop myself. “It’s an event.”

He laughed, but I wasn’t joking.

By then I knew the rules, or what pass for rules in something like this:

- It can happen anytime: brushing my teeth, crossing the street, kissing someone.
- It looks, to everyone else, like a seizure or a cardiac event. Sometimes my heart stutters. Once, it stopped for six full seconds.
- The farther I drift, the harder it is to get back.
- If I don’t get back—if I hover too long or let go—that’s it. Body vacant, life over. Official cause: heart failure, maybe. They’d never write “soul gone missing” on a certificate.

The unique cruelty of it is how ordinary it looks from the outside. People see me fall, see my limbs jerk, see the foam at my lips, and they think they understand. “Seizure,” they say. “Call 911.” They hold my head. They keep time.

None of them can see me standing three feet away, yelling at my own ribs to keep rising.

The episodes trained me to be vigilant. Hyper-vigilant. I lived like a shepherd guarding a single, disobedient sheep.

Before sleep: ground yourself. Feel your fingers, your toes. Remind yourself of gravity.

In crowds: keep a point of reference. A sound, a color, a person’s voice you can follow back.

At twenty-three, it happened on the subway. Workday evening, fluorescent lights flickering, car packed too tight. I was holding the metal pole, scrolling through emails, when I felt the tug.

It’s subtle at first—a hollowness stretching in my chest, like an elevator dropping one floor too fast.

No, I thought, and tightened my grip.

It was strange, how quickly the soul could stop caring about my schedule.

The car shuddered; the lights flickered. In that pause, something peeled free. I blinked and saw myself from above: head tipped back, knees buckling, the phone slipping from my hand. A woman gasped. Someone shouted for help.

From the near-ceiling vantage point where I hovered, I noticed details I’d never have seen otherwise: the balding man pretending not to look, the kid’s wide eyes, the grime ground into the floor. My own body looked…small.

I understood, suddenly, why people see tunnels of light and don’t always fight them.

It would be so easy, I thought, to just keep floating. No insurance forms, no apologizing to coworkers, no mother’s cracked voice on the phone. Just silence.

Then my heart stopped.

You don’t feel the absence of your own heartbeat when you’re a foot out of alignment, but you sense the void. It’s like realizing the drum track is gone from a song you love. Everything else sounds wrong.

The world around my body sharpened into panic.

“Is she breathing?”

“Check her pulse!”

“Call 911!”

Their fear reached me where logic hadn’t. My mother’s face flashed in my mind, the way she sat in neurologists’ waiting rooms with her hands folded tight. My father pressing two fingers to my wrist after each episode, as if his touch alone could call me back.

I thought: Not yet.

I dove.

The word isn’t accurate. There is no movement, only choice. But I chose as hard as a person can choose. Chose this failing expression of myself, this stuttering heart, these frantic strangers, this godawful fluorescent car.

Re-entry hurt.

Chest like being kicked from the inside, nerves screaming, lungs spasming. Sound came back too loud. Faces loomed. I sucked in air like I’d been drowning.

Later, in the hospital, they called it “a suspected cardiac arrhythmia exacerbating seizure activity.”

“You need to take this more seriously,” the cardiologist said. “If your heart stops and doesn’t restart…”

He didn’t finish. He didn’t have to.

I wanted to say, I am taking it seriously. I am wrestling my soul back from the edge every time it decides to wander. Do you think I like this?

Instead, I nodded and promised to wear the Holter monitor and swallow the new pills that would slow a heart that only sometimes remembers to beat.

The thing no one ever tells you about living like this is how tiring it is to be in constant negotiations with yourself.

I set alarms to remind me to breathe deep, to drink water, to sleep. I avoid standing near edges—not cliffs, not balconies, not train platforms. If I slip too far out while my body is close to falling, I worry I won’t care enough to pull back.

Relationships are…complicated.

“How are you?” people ask after they’ve seen one. “Like, really?”

“I’m fine,” I say. It’s easier than explaining that part of me nearly decided to leave for good in aisle seven of the grocery store.

I’ve tried, once or twice, to be honest.

“I have this thing,” I told Eli, the first person I really loved. “My soul kind of…detaches.”

He laughed at first, thought I was being poetic. Then he saw it happen—my body dropping to the floor of his kitchen, my eyes rolling back, my chest still.

He told me afterward, “You were gone.”

I almost was. That time I’d floated all the way to the ceiling, looking down at him kneeling over me, shouting my name. He slapped my face, pressed his ear to my chest. “Don’t you dare.”

I remember thinking, faintly amused, You’re bossy.

The amusement was the thread I grabbed. The idea of missing the exact way he said “don’t you dare” pulled me back in.

Later that night, he curled around me as if he could anchor me with the simple weight of his body.

“What if one day you don’t come back?” he whispered into my shoulder.

“Then you tell them it wasn’t a seizure,” I said.

“What was it, then?”

“Me,” I said. “For once, just me deciding something.”

It was a cruel thing to say, and we both knew it. The truth is, it never feels like a decision when I slip. It feels like a fault line.

I don’t think I’m chosen or cursed or special. I think some people’s bodies attack their brains, some people’s hearts short-circuit, and mine has this miswired border between flesh and whatever animates it.

So I live carefully.

I drink my water. I take my meds. I let people believe in seizures and heart murmurs and medical terms that fit cleanly into charts.

And when I feel the world tilt, when the edges of my vision go soft and weightlessness tugs, I do the hardest, simplest thing I can:

I choose my body. Over and over and over.

Not because it’s easy, or because I owe it to anyone.

Because despite everything—the fear, the tests, the way strangers stare when I hit the floor—I’m still not done feeling what it’s like to stay.

samples.prompt: Every human has a number above their head that shows their worth as a human being. You just finished posting a shitty writing prompt and noticed your number has just dropped to a 0.
samples.output:
It drops while the cursor is still blinking.

I hit “Post” with that little shiver of embarrassment I always get when I share something online, then flick my eyes up out of habit. The number hangs there, half a foot above my head, softly white, as it has been my entire life—6.8, stable, respectable, comfortably human.

It blinks.

It flips.

0.

The air in my chest leaves like someone’s ripped out the plug. I physically sway. For a moment I’m convinced it’s a rendering glitch. The numbers over people’s heads don’t go to 0. I’ve seen a 1.9 once, on the news, blurred out like gore. But 0?

“Are you okay?” asks Jonah from across the coworking table. He doesn’t have to ask what’s wrong. His gaze has already found the empty space above me like a tongue finding a broken tooth.

“What’s it say?” I ask, because I need to hear it.

His lips part. “Dude.”

“Say it.”

“Zero,” he says quietly.

There’s a hush within three desks. You can feel when multiple people subtly refocus their eyes, when their attentions sync onto one horror.

Someone breathes, “Holy shit.”

I look back at my monitor. The browser shows my new thread on /r/WritingPrompts:

[WP] Every human has a number above their head that shows their worth as a human being. You just finished posting a shitty writing prompt and noticed your number has just dropped to a 0.

It has one upvote. And the automatic bot reply.

A laugh hiccups out of me, small and broken. “Okay,” I say. “Very funny. Good one, universe. I get it: not my best work.”

No one laughs.

Behind Jonah, a woman I’ve only ever known as Podcast Lady is packing her bag with fast, decisive movements. She keeps her eyes down. She leaves without saying goodbye.

“Probably a lag,” Jonah says, but his chair scrapes backwards almost involuntarily.

The System doesn’t lag. It came online when I was six: numbers descending from the sky like tiny personal halos. We learned to read one another like weather. Parents taught us to avoid anyone under 5.0. Laws codified it. HR departments filtered it. Dating apps required minimums. Everyone pretends it’s complicated: algorithms, moral calculus, aggregate good. Everyone knows the shorthand: higher is better. Lower is dangerous.

Zero is… theoretical. The burning center of all those “What if” stories people post.

“I didn’t—” I start, then cut off. Because I did. I wrote a prompt while bored at work about the numbers and hit Post. That’s all. That’s all.

The System doesn’t punish bad writing, I tell myself. It tracks verifiable actions: ethics, empathy, contributions. You don’t lose six point eight points for cringe.

I open my profile page on the civic portal. WORTH INDEX: 0.0. STATUS: AT-RISK.

There’s a new button: “Schedule Review.”

My hand is shaking so badly I miss the click twice.

Jonah stands. “Hey, I remembered, I have to—”

“Sure,” I say automatically. He doesn’t finish the sentence. He just goes.

At the edge of my vision, numbers bob as people angle their screens to use them as mirrors. 7.1, 6.4, 8.3. They glow like accusations.

It’s fine, I think. It’s a bug. Bugs happen.

Except bugs get acknowledged online in seconds. The System’s official feed scrolls by: announcements, inspirational stories, infographics on how to be better.

No error messages.

My phone buzzes. Unknown number.

“This is Worth Administration,” a clean, sexless voice says when I answer. “We’ve detected a significant fluctuation in your Index. You’ve initiated a Review appointment. The earliest available slot is today at 15:00. Attendance is mandatory.”

“Wait, what does zero mean?” My voice comes out too high. People glance.

“Please bring a government-issued ID and any documentation of recent altruistic activities. You have three hours.”

The line clicks dead.

I stare at the phone. I don’t have “documentation.” I have a reusable coffee cup and some ironically self-aware tweets.

On the train, space opens around me without anyone making a show of it. People angle their bodies, hold bags in their laps, forbidden from physically shrinking away, allowed to drift. Their numbers bob in the fluorescent light. Nobody has to ask what happened. They’ve all seen the stories, the horror threads: “I met a 2.0; AMA,” “Saw someone get recalibrated today. Still shaking.”

There’s a boy in the corner with a 4.2 who keeps stealing glances at me like I’m a ruin. His mother pulls him closer.

I unlock my phone and try to delete the prompt. Maybe if I take it back, the System will—

404. Thread removed. “Post unavailable: flagged for meta-violation.”

Meta-violation. Unauthorized speculation about System mechanisms. Spread of inaccurate narratives. Harmful framing.

I want to scream that everyone does it, that the subreddit is full of prompts poking at the numbers, the rules. But I remember the above-my-head 0 and the way the train is a ring and I’m the empty center.

The Worth Administration building is all glass that reflects your own number back at you—a design choice people on the net fetishize. Normally it’s a selfie spot. Not today.

Security gates open as I approach, reading my ID chip. The guard’s number is 6.0. His eyes skip over my forehead once, and to his credit, his expression doesn’t change.

Room 314 is empty except for a table, two chairs, and an oblong device in the corner like a monolith made by people who love terms of service.

A woman walks in. Mid-thirties. Crisp suit. 7.9 hovering over glossy hair. She sits opposite me and sets down a tablet.

“Alex Mercer,” she says. “Do you know why you’re here?”

“No,” I say. “I posted a writing prompt.”

Her eyes flick to something only she can see. “You initiated a meta-narrative that undermines trust in the Worth Index. You implied arbitrary linkage between trivial actions and fundamental human value. You framed the System as petty. This has measurable societal impact.”

“I wrote 60 words of nonsense,” I snap, then flinch at my own tone. “People write worse all the time.”

She swipes. A projection appears between us: a timeline of my online activity. Comments. Likes. Half-finished rants. That prompt at the end, glowing red.

“You have a pattern,” she says. “Sarcasm toward the Index. Casual hypotheticals about collapsing metrics. You hide it as fiction. Fiction shapes expectation. Expectation shapes behavior. Undermining belief in objective worth degrades prosocial compliance.”

It’s like being scolded by a Terms & Conditions pop-up.

“So zero is…” I swallow. “A punishment?”

“Zero is an alarm. A provisional designation. You’ve been flagged as potentially corrosive to collective cohesion.” She says it without malice. Like reading ingredients off a cereal box.

“I recycle,” I blurt. “I donate. I volunteered at a shelter last winter—check December. They posted a photo. I help Jonah with his code sometimes. I call my mother. I have never broken a law. I’ve never— I’ve never hurt anyone.”

She watches me. For just a second, the polished calm cracks and something human peers out. “I see all of that,” she says more gently. “The algorithm doesn’t read intent, just effect. When your prompt began to trend, it triggered a model: rapid propagation of cynicism around the Index correlates with reduced moral compliance in susceptible populations. You were the seed node. The system dropped you to zero to mark and contain.”

“It was shitty,” I whisper. “Nobody even liked it.”

“Algorithms are not literary critics,” she says.

A laugh slips out of me, small, wild. “So what now? Do I get points back for meaning well?”

“Your Review determines whether zero holds,” she says. “You can contextualize your actions, express alignment with collective values, commit to corrective measures. If we’re satisfied, your number adjusts.”

“And if you’re not?”

She doesn’t answer.

I look at the oblong machine in the corner. Stories flicker through my mind: people who went to Review and came out with blank stares and numbers frozen. People made examples of. Of course those are probably just prompts too.

“I thought we were allowed to question things,” I say. “To explore ideas. I thought stories were how we… I don’t know. Safely poke at the edges. Isn’t that worth something?”

“It is,” she says. “But your prompt didn’t question. It asserted: post a ‘shitty’ thought and your worth becomes nothing. It suggested the System condemns for trivialities. That breeds fear, mockery, nihilism. People start saying, if I can be zeroed for nothing, why bother being good at all? Why not burn it all down?”

“I was making fun of myself,” I say. “Not the System.”

“The System doesn’t parse self-loathing as satire.”

I rub my face. My skin feels wrong, like I’ve forgotten how to wear it.

“What do you want me to say?” I ask.

“That you understand your influence is non-zero,” she says. “That you recognize words move people. That you accept responsibility for how you frame our shared reality. That you will, going forward, create in ways that reinforce, not erode, the structures that protect us.”
