“You want me to write propaganda,” I say.

She holds my gaze. “I want you to remember that in a world where we can see each other’s worth, pretending it’s all meaningless is a luxury that corrodes everyone else’s trust. You’re a writer. So write like it matters.”

Silence. The machine hums.

I think of the train, the way the crowd parted. The boy staring at me like I was a story his mother told him not to read. I think of my number, bright and clean my whole life, unexamined because it never hurt me. I think of how fast I assumed this zero was arbitrary punishment when really it’s the first time I’ve seen the gears that have always been grinding under the floorboards of my comfort.

“I don’t believe worth can be measured like this,” I say finally. “But I believe people believe it. And that belief has power. So… yeah. I get that flippancy can be gasoline.”

Her shoulders ease. She taps the tablet.

“Provisional acknowledgment of systemic responsibility,” she says. “Recommended de-escalation.”

Above my head, there’s a faint warmth. I don’t look up; I can feel everyone is trained on that space. She nods slightly.

“2.3,” she says. “You’re no longer zero. You are, however, on watch. You will receive guidance content. Engage with it. Demonstrate value.”

“Two point three,” I echo. A number low enough that nobody can ignore it. Too high to disappear.

I stand on unsteady legs.

“One more thing,” she says as I reach the door. “Next time you feel the urge to turn us into a writing prompt, try this instead: ask what story helps people live better with what they already fear, instead of confirming their worst suspicion and calling it shitty.”

“I’ll work on it,” I say.

Outside, under the unflinching sky, my number glows where I can’t see it. People look, assess, adjust. I walk anyway.

I open my phone. The cursor blinks in a new post box.

[WP] You live in a world where a number above your head shows your worth. Yours just dropped, not because you are worthless, but because the System finally noticed you could change what other people believe is true.

I hover over Post, thinking about fear, and responsibility, and the stories we deserve.

Then, carefully, I start again.

samples.prompt: After years of study, you have finally made contact with the eldritch spirit. However, it needs a body to inhabit. Last night's blizzard has driven most creatures into hiding, and you won't offer yourself. Desperately looking out your window, your neighbor's snowman suddenly catches your eye.
samples.output:
It blinks.

At first I think it’s the wind, or my desperate, sleep-starved imagination turning ice and shadow into movement. But the snowman in my neighbor’s yard—the one the kids built yesterday, lumpy and crooked, scarf flapping, button eyes misaligned—blinks.

The eldritch spirit notices at the same time I do.

“There,” it sighs, inside my skull. Its voice is not sound; it’s the rearrangement of certainty. The room bends inward as if the walls are inhaling. “A suitable body.”

I push myself away from the frosted window. “That’s not suitable. That’s slush.”

“It is form,” the spirit replies. “It is boundary. It will do.”

I glance at the clock. 4:13 a.m. The blizzard still howls, combing its white teeth across the houses. The streetlights are halos in the swirling snow. Nobody is outside. Nobody is awake. I’ve been up for thirty-seven hours, coaxing sigils into alignment, whispering syllables humans were never meant to pronounce. I should be ecstatic.

I am terrified.

“You promised,” I say, throat raw. “You promised knowledge, not—possession.”

“I promised nothing,” the spirit says. “You called. I answered. A bridge requires both shores.”

It had taken me eight years to find it: the entity lurking between decay and possibility, mentioned in footnotes, glossed in warnings. The Masters called it archaic nonsense. The real grimoires, the ones that came wrapped in oilcloth and illness, named it in spirals and stains. I thought I could bind it. Direct it. Turn cosmic hunger into a lantern.

Now my head is full of ocean noises and teeth.

“I won’t be your vessel,” I tell it, pressing fingers to my temples as if I might pinch it out. “Find something else.”

“I am looking,” it says, impatient. “Through you. Ah. The effigy. Three segments. Primitive face. Carrot protrusion. It calls to me. Hollow. Willing.”

“It’s a snowman,” I hiss. “It’ll melt.”

“Then I will move on,” it says. “But first I will stretch.”

A ripple creeps down my spine, not a shiver but a slow, many-legged exploration.

“No.” Panic sharpens my voice. “Absolutely not. It’s my neighbor’s. They have kids.”

“Do you value them?” the spirit wonders. “More than you value the world?”

The question is not rhetorical. Behind the drifting curtains of sleet, I glimpse something vast. Rotted galaxies. A negative sun. I flinch.

“Explain,” I say.

“Your scholars tug,” it says. “Little summonings. Curious scratches on the walls of the Infinite. I feel them. I come. No form, no anchor, and I tear you by accident. Atmospheres peel. Seas ignite. There is screaming. Regrettable. You have made a door tonight. I am halfway through. If I do not enter a vessel, I will enter everything.”

I remember the diagrams of containment chalked onto my floorboards, the twelve-circled mandala, glowing faintly even now. Their light flickers, then steadies, strained.

“If you anchor in me,” I say slowly, “you could… wear me.”

“I would gorge,” it agrees. “Through your senses. Through your species. Briefly. Then nothing left to learn.”

“So we need… something small. Temporary.” The words taste like betrayal. “Something that can’t go far.”

We both turn our attention to the snowman.

Its stick arms are uneven. One points toward my window. The other droops. It is a caricature of humanity, a child’s approximation.

“There,” the spirit whispers again, and now I feel its hunger and its amusement, like a glacier cracking.

“I’m not going out there,” I say. “It’s a blizzard.”

The lights flicker. The circle’s chalk lines darken, rims of shadow gnawing inward.

“Your sigils decay,” it says. “You miscopied the ninth curve. I am already eroding your protections. Without an anchor, I will bloom outward within—”

“Okay,” I say. “Okay. The snowman. But no touching the kids. No touching anybody. You stay put.”

It hums, something like a chuckle. “Negotiate with the tidal wave. Charming. Open the way.”

I grab my coat, boots, scarf. My fingers are clumsy on the zipper. The air in the room feels thin, as if the spirit is using up some invisible resource. I step over the chalk circle; it sizzles where my boot scuffs it. Not reassuring.

The hallway is darker than it should be. The bulb overhead stretches, elongates into a drooping filament that watches me pass.

“Stop that,” I mutter.

“Apologies,” the spirit says, not sounding apologetic.

When I open the door, the blizzard shoves a howl of frozen air into my face. The world is a white delirium. I can barely see the skeletal hint of my neighbor’s maple tree, let alone the snowman. I press on, one hand on the railing, boots vanishing up to the ankle with every step.

“Left,” the spirit guides. “You are drifting.”

“Too bad you can’t walk yourself,” I say through gritted teeth.

“Yet,” it says.

I tromp down my walkway, onto the buried sidewalk, across the property line that exists now only in memory. Snow slaps my eyes; my lashes freeze together, spring apart. I nearly walk past the snowman before its grin materializes out of the storm: three charcoal buttons, wide, unblinking eyes—until one blinks again.

“Oh,” I whisper.

It has changed. Subtly. The middle sphere is smoother. The twigs have risen, arms now outstretched. The scarf curls around its neck like a sleeping serpent.

“I have already touched it,” the spirit says, smug. “I slipped a finger into its potential while you dressed.”

“That wasn’t the deal,” I say, though we never really made one. My breath comes out in ragged clouds.

“Stand aside,” it says.

The air thickens. For a moment the blizzard’s roar dims, as if sound itself holds its breath. Something slides out of me—not a presence leaving, but a pressure shifting focus. I feel suddenly hollow, like a husk.

In front of me, the snow blackens along hairline cracks. Thin veins of darkness spiderweb under its surface. The button eyes roll wetly in their sockets, real, glossy, wrong. The carrot twitches as if sniffing.

Then the snowman turns its head.

Slowly. Relishing every granule grinding against the next.

Its gaze settles on me. The grin widens, unseen but somehow it widens.

“Yes,” the spirit says, but now from outside me, in a voice that is a creaking forest and the slide of grave dirt. “This will do.”

I stagger back. The thing steps forward. Snow does not move like that. It should crumble, slough. Instead, it flows, joints flexing as if there are bones inside, ancient and angular.

“Wait,” I say. “You said temporary.”

“I said I would move on when this failed,” it replies, tilting its head. The scarf writhes in a wind that has gone bizarrely still. “It will fail soon. It is delicate. Transience is… instructive.”

“You’ll hurt them,” I say. The image flashes unbidden: children at the window, their delight turning to horror as the snowman waves back too naturally.

“I will observe,” it says. “If there is hurt, I will note it.”

The protective circle back in my living room gives a faint, muffled pop, like a bubble bursting.

“Stop,” I say, more sharply. Some invisible tether still connects us; when I speak the word, the thing flinches.

Interesting.

“I bound you,” I realize. “To me, not to the circle. The circle was just—focus.”

Its new body shivers, sending a fine powder of snow to the ground like dandruff.

“You misunderstand the proportions,” it says. “You are a bookmark in my story.”

“But I wrote your name. I finished the call. I can finish the command.”

Snow lashes us again, recovering its voice. Behind the snowman, the dark windows of my neighbor’s house feel like open eyes.

“If I die,” I say, inspiration cutting through my terror, “the anchor severs. You said half-through becomes everywhere. You’ll tear the world by accident. That’s not observation. That’s obliteration. You want to learn, you need me alive.”

It studies me. Button eyes click faintly as they adjust focus.

“So I propose,” I continue, heart pounding, “you stay in there. Within the perimeter of this yard. Sunrise, you slip back, I write the dismissal, you go home with stories about how we stack frozen water and lie to children about magic. No bodies. No blood.”

It considers. Snow hisses softly along the contours of its stolen form.

“You bargain cleverly,” it says at last. “You assume I value subtlety over spectacle.”

“You came when I called,” I say. “You’ve watched. You’re curious. Curiosity survives. Melting doesn’t.”

The snowman’s head tilts back. It looks up at the hidden sky, as if seeing all the burning distances at once.

“Very well,” it says, and the word settles over the yard like another layer of snow. “Until the sun’s first full edge breaks that horizon,” it raises one stick arm to indicate, with mocking precision, “I remain. No blood. No entering dwellings. No breaking bones.”

“And no whispering,” I add. “No… pushing. No making them come outside.”

Its grin curls. “So many clauses. You should have been a lawyer of the dead.”

“Swear it,” I say.

It does not speak. Instead, all sound drops again, and for a moment I feel the chill of something incomprehensible acknowledging something minuscule. A contract written not in ink but in mutual vulnerability.

Then the world snaps back. Wind howls. A distant plow grinds along the buried street.

The snowman shudders once, settling into its borrowed shape. Its eyes fix on nothing, or on things behind everything.

“I will watch,” it says softly. “Go, little anchor. Guard your dawn.”

I back away, never turning from it until I reach my door. My hands shake as I fumble with the knob. Inside, my living room reeks of ozone and old books. The chalk circle is ash.

I sit by the window, wrapped in a blanket, teeth chattering as much from adrenaline as cold, and watch.

Across the way, the snowman stands sentinel. Sometimes its arms move incrementally, tracing patterns in the snow-laden air. Once, something like a ripple passes through its body, revealing a glimpse of impossible angles, then smoothing out again.

Around six, a pink bruise of light appears in the east. The storm thins. Blue leaks into the sky’s underside.

I lean forward. The snowman’s head turns toward the light.

“Remember,” I whisper.

As the sun’s first full edge breaks the horizon, the snowman bows.

It comes apart not by melting but by unfolding: snow collapsing inward, then sighing outward. For a heartbeat a tall, thin shadow with too many elbows stretches impossibly long across the yards, touching my window, touching every window.

“Thank you,” it says inside my mind, gentle, amused. “You make such fragile prisons.”

Then it is gone.

Across the street stands only an ordinary, sagging snowman, scarf askew, carrot nose crooked, one arm broken.

Later, when the neighbors’ kids run outside, shrieking, to repair it, they chatter about how it “totally looked at us” through the night.

I smile tightly, already reaching for a pen. There is so much I need to write down before I forget how close the world came to cracking, all because I wouldn’t offer myself and saw, instead, a crooked grin in the snow.

samples.prompt: My heart was beating like a drum. This was it. There was no going back.
samples.output:
My heart was beating like a drum. This was it. There was no going back.

The world had narrowed to the circle of light at my feet and the muffled rasp of my own breath inside the helmet. Beyond the harsh cones of the launch tower’s floodlights, the Florida sky was an ink-dark ocean, indifferent and infinite. I flexed my gloved fingers, feeling the stiff resistance of the suit, and for a fleeting second, I wished I could wipe the sweat from my forehead.

“Commander Reyes, comms check,” came the voice in my ear. Calm, practiced, routine. Nothing about their tone suggested that in less than five minutes three humans would sit atop two million kilograms of fuel and volunteer to be flung into orbit.

“Reyes, loud and clear,” I said. My voice sounded flatter than I felt.

“Garcia, loud and clear.”

“Nguyen, loud and clear. And regretting my life choices,” Linh added, which made a quick burst of static laughter flicker across the channel.

I smiled despite myself. “Too late for that, Linh.”

Too late for all of us.

I stepped onto the elevator platform, the same one I’d walked past a thousand times during simulations, briefings, ceremonial rehearsals. It had always felt like a prop then, a stage piece waiting for its cue. Now it hummed and rattled as it lifted us toward the capsule, and the tower’s lattice of steel slid by in a dark blur.

As we rose, I looked past the rail. I could see the press bleachers far below, our families somewhere in that jittering, colorful mosaic. Cameras like insect eyes, tracking us as if we were already myth instead of fragile bodies inside complicated suits. I knew exactly where my mother would be seated: second row, left side, clutching the blue program booklet until it crumpled. She’d refused to cry at the farewell dinner the night before, just pressed her hand against my cheek and said, “Come home with stories, mija. Not excuses.”

I’d promised. The kind of promise you make knowing it might be broken by physics, by flame, by a stray bolt or an undetected fracture.

The elevator stopped with a jolt. The access arm stretched toward the capsule like a question. The hatch was open, a bright white circle.

“This is it,” Linh said softly behind me.

I shrugged, the motion awkward in the suit. “Front row seats.”

We moved in sequence. Routine. We’d rehearsed this until it infiltrated our dreams. One hand here, one foot there, duck, turn, slide into the left seat. Cables and straps and buckles. The checklist’s familiar cadence started in my ear even before I was fully settled.

“Seat restraints engaged?”

“Affirmative,” I answered, fingers tightening the harness across my chest until I could feel my own heartbeat strumming against it.

My heart was beating like a drum. I focused on each step, each word, like stones across a rushing river. If I looked at the water—if I thought too hard about what this all meant—I might slip.

“Main umbilicals connected.”

“Suit integrity nominal.”

“Cabin pressure stable.”

Engineers loved that word: nominal. A reassuring blandness in the face of awe.

I exhaled, slowing my breathing to match the rhythm we’d practiced with the flight surgeon. In for four counts, hold for four, out for six. The sound inside the helmet evened from frantic gusting to steady waves.

“Commander, how’re you feeling?” Mission Control asked.

There was an unofficial rule: never admit you were scared. Or, if you did, make it a joke.

“Like I’m about to win the world’s most dangerous lottery,” I said.

Laughter again, then, “Copy that. All systems nominal. T-minus six minutes.”

Six minutes.

In training, these last minutes had been cluttered with instructors’ voices, corrections, do-overs. Here, the quiet felt immense. Payload ready. Trajectory plotted. The massive booster beneath us awaited a single spark, and that spark waited on us.

No going back. They’d closed the hatch. The access arm was retracting. If I said right now, I can’t, I won’t, I changed my mind, they’d have to scrub the mission, unstrap us, delay for weeks, maybe months. Millions of dollars evaporating into bureaucratic smoke. Headlines. Panel discussions. My mother’s face.

I could almost feel the weight of that choice hovering, a ghost option. It would be so easy to grab it, to reach for the abort, to blame a sensor, a twinge in my chest, a premonition.

I didn’t.

Instead, I let myself think—just for a breath—about why I was here.

The first time I’d seen the rocket, I’d been eight, standing ankle-deep in the chilly Atlantic with my father. It wasn’t this rocket, not this mission, but another slender tower of white and black rising against the gold of a late afternoon sky. The distant roar had reached us like a delayed revelation, and the booster clawed its way upward trailing a comet tail of fire. People on the beach had cheered. I had stared until the sun burned my eyes, until the bright speck vanished.

My father had bent down and said, “One day that’ll be you up there.”

I’d laughed and told him I was going to be a teacher. I ended up becoming both.

He never saw me wear the flight suit. The cancer took him the year I graduated from the academy. But sometimes, in the hangar, I could almost feel him beside me, nodding at the engines, his calloused mechanic’s hands respectful in the presence of all that potential.

“Commander, T-minus two minutes,” came the crisp voice. “Final go/no-go.”

They ran down the list. Guidance: go. Propulsion: go. Life support: go. Weather: go. The litany of faith in human calculation.

“Flight, this is Launch Director. You are go for launch.”

Something unclenched in my chest. The decision was no longer mine alone; it belonged to the machine, to the team, to the roaring river of events we’d all stepped into.

“T-minus 30 seconds.”

The cabin hummed with vibrations as propellant lines pressurized. I felt, more than heard, a deep animal growl building beneath me.

“Remember,” I said, surprising myself, “we’ve done this a thousand times.”

“Yeah,” Luis said, “just never with the part where we actually leave the planet.”

Linh made a small sound that might have been a laugh.

“Ten,” counted down Mission Control. “Nine. Eight.”

I closed my eyes for a fraction of a second. In that sliver of darkness, I saw all the paths that had led here: library books with worn covers, early-morning runs, failures, passed tests, late-night arguments with an ex who’d said, “You’ll always choose space over me,” and hadn’t understood when I didn’t deny it. I saw my mother’s lined face, my father’s absent one, my younger self on the beach.

“Three. Two. One. Ignition.”

Silence, for a heartbeat.

Then the world exploded.

The rocket leapt as if offended by gravity. The force slammed me into my seat, an invisible giant’s hand pressing on my chest. The roar was no longer sound but a physical presence, a bellowing beast shaking my bones. Voices on the loop blurred into clipped confirmations: “Liftoff. We have liftoff of Aurora One on a mission to—” The rest dissolved into static and fire.

The tower dropped away in the tiny side window. The dark Atlantic rolled beneath us, then the curve of the Earth began to appear, a subtle, impossible arc.

My teeth rattled with the vibration. Sweat crawled down my temple. I stole a glance at the G-meter. Three G’s. Manageable. We’d trained at six. I forced my breathing to stay steady, counting again. My heart was still pounding, but now its wild rhythm aligned with the ascent, drum to drum.

“Aurora One, you are go at 10,000,” came the call.

“Copy, go,” I answered, the words a little crushed under the acceleration.

This was it. The line had been crossed at ignition, but it was only now, with the atmosphere thinning and the sky deepening toward violet, that I felt the true point of no return. The world below shrinking, the familiar turning into map.

We went through Max Q, the point of maximum dynamic pressure, and for a moment the forces tightened like a fist. I remembered the engineering diagrams, the structural limits, the anecdotes of foam and O-rings. Fear pushed up, sharp and vivid.

I acknowledged it. Didn’t push it away this time.

“Yes,” I thought. “I’m scared. And I’m still here.”

“Max Q,” reported the guidance officer. “All structural limits nominal.”

The first stage cut off with a violent jolt; for an instant we were weightless, our stomachs lurching, then the second stage lit and hammered us forward again. The blue outside the window darkened to indigo, then nearly black, pricked by the hardest, coldest stars I’d ever seen.

“Aurora One, you are go for orbit insertion.”

The pressure eased. The engine’s roar softened to a distant thunder. My heartbeat, still insistent, began to slow, each pulse no longer a frantic warning but a steady declaration.

When the main engine finally cut off, it was like a spell breaking. The crushing weight vanished. I floated against my harness, a brief, giddy lightness. A small tool bag slipped from its Velcro patch and drifted lazily upward. Linh made a delighted sound.

“We are… in orbit,” Luis said, awe cracking his professional veneer.

I looked out through the tiny window and saw Earth.

A swirling, luminous marble of blues and whites, suspended in infinite black. Delicate. Radiant. Borderless. No lines between countries, no scars, just storms curling like brushstrokes and the smooth curve of dawn sliding across continents.

My throat tightened.

We had done it. All the fear, all the risk, all the no-going-back—this was what it had been for. This impossible vantage point.

In my ear, Mission Control’s voice came calm and measured: “Aurora One, welcome to space.”

I let out a long breath I felt I’d been holding since the elevator doors closed.

“Control,” I said, and this time my voice was steady, almost light, “this is Aurora One. Good to be here.”

My heart was still beating like a drum. But now, it wasn’t alarm. It was triumph.

samples.prompt: It's the year 6015 and Kepler-452b colonists are returning to Earth for the first time. Having lost contact with Earth shortly after departing in 2025, the returned are hoping to re-establish contact. Earth is not silent. Encrypted transmissions are common but indecipherable.
samples.output:
They dropped through the cloud deck over the Pacific expecting a graveyard.

What waited instead was light.

Cities — or things that might once have been cities — pulsed along the continents, vertices in a planetary lattice of soft gold and indigo. Orbit was constellated with structures like frozen lightning. Beams stitched between them in tight, invisible bands their instruments only registered as overload warnings. The colonists’ returning vessel, Sparrow, had been broadcasting in every known protocol since Jupiter: standard RF, tight-beam lasers, old-world ham frequencies, even tactile bursts on antique Morse. Nothing.

Then, as they crossed the exosphere, Earth answered.

“Transmission detected,” called Rhee, the comms officer. “Multiple sources. They’re everywhere.”

The bridge’s viewscreens came alive with scrolling data: bursts across the spectrum, narrow-band spikes, milimeter wave chatter. It took seconds to notice the pattern — not in content, but in absence. Everything meaningful was locked.

“Encryption,” Rhee said, too quickly. “Everything’s encrypted. I’m not seeing any open handshake, no beacon, no emergency channel.” He expanded one waveform, lines of code spilling like a language with all the vowels stripped out. “That isn’t anything from 2020s Earth.”

“Try legacy,” Captain Mara Elgin said. “Try everything we brought with us.”

“We’ve been trying everything,” Rhee snapped, then caught himself. Six thousand years is a long time to imagine an answer. “Sorry, Captain.”

Mara floated closer to the main viewport. From here, Earth filled half the sky, familiar clouds veiling unfamiliar geometry: a hexagonal bloom in the Sahara, like a metal flower three hundred kilometers wide; a shimmering band girdling the equator in low orbit, blinking with a rhythm not synced to any natural period. The Pacific glittered with points of light moving in violent, graceful swarms.

“It’s not dead,” whispered someone behind them. Chen, astrobiologist turned historian, hands pressed together. “They made it. We made it.”

We. As if they were still the same people who’d watched Earth dwindle in 2025, signals failing one by one. First the news feeds grew erratic, then time-delayed apologies from anxious mission control. And then nothing but the hiss of the cosmic background and the tight, disciplined voices of the Kepler fleet speaking to itself, and then eventually not even that as the ships separated for insertion.

Kepler-452b had been hard, green, and patient. The colony had learned patience or died. In the slow centuries that followed, they built three more ships. Only one had made it operational. Sparrow.

“Open our hull lights,” Mara said. “Broadcast a beacon: ‘This is Sparrow, from Kepler-452b, returning with descendants of the 2025 colonists. Requesting contact on any clear channel.’ Use every language we have.”

The hull flared white against the dark. Old greetings, old scripts, spooled outward: English, Mandarin, Arabic, Hindi, binary, prime number sequences, even simple mathematical propositions. A shout across a childhood ocean.

The responses did not change.

Static. Then more encrypted bursts, now clearly reacting — frequencies sliding away as if avoiding contact. No pattern they could crack.

“Is it military?” Chen asked. “Maybe they’re in some prolonged conflict. Or paranoid about contamination.”

“After four thousand years?” Rhee said. “That’s not a war. That’s… design.”

He threw their best tools at the problem: quantum key inference algorithms, bruteforcers scaled for six-millennia hardware growth, mimic scripts that replayed the intercepted packets with slight variations, hoping to trigger a handshake. Nothing caught. The transmissions were not merely encrypted; they seemed orthogonal to anything Sparrow’s computers understood. Compressed inside alien maths.

“Signal from surface,” Rhee said suddenly. “But it’s—”

“Encrypted,” Mara finished with him.

The carrier was strong, precisely targeted. It bathed Sparrow in a tight cone, rich with information like a symphony where every instrument played in code.

“Could be them trying to talk,” Chen offered. “We’re the primitives now. Maybe they don’t remember how to be simple.”

“Then they can learn,” Mara muttered. “Lower orbit. Over North America first.”

Partly it was bias: so many of the old mission controllers had gazed up from Houston, from Florida, from scattered centers on that continent. So many farewells had been spoken in English with that accent of anxious hope.

Sparrow descended.

What had been the eastern seaboard was a coastline of glass and forest braided together. Towers grew like pale reeds from circular plinths, stretched to the clouds, and dissolved into lattices hosting swarms of tiny, glinting motes. Between them, rivers ran clear, stippled with green. No roads. No smoke.

“Life signs everywhere,” Chen breathed. “Biomass levels are high. But no classical combustion, no unshielded reactors. The power has to be… there—”

Her finger tracked lines of faint blue in the atmosphere, loops and knots of ionization that moved with intentional grace.

Rhee hissed. “They’re using the sky.”

“What do you mean?”

“They’re running part of their infrastructure in the ionosphere. Charge differentials as logic states. Whole network latticed in air.” Awe folded into frustration. “That’s centuries, millennia beyond our architectures. No wonder we can’t read them.”

The targeted beam adjusted. A packet arrived with a signature: a spike on three specific frequencies in a ratio of 1:4:9.

“Wait,” Chen said, seizing on it. “That’s deliberate. That’s—”

“‘2001,’” Mara said. “A very old film. Monolith dimensions.”

“They know we’re human,” Chen whispered.

Rhee moderated the incoming stream, isolating the 1:4:9 bursts. He responded with a test: the same ratio, then the sequence of primes to 19. A moment’s pause, and the beam replied: primes to 23. Then a different pattern: the hydrogen line frequency, pi approximated in pulse lengths, Planck constants embedded in modulation depth.

“Okay,” Rhee said, heartbeat rising. “It’s a math handshake. Good, good. Let’s map this.”

For six hours, Sparrow and the unseen surface transmitters spoke in numbers. From numbers to constructed symbols. From symbols to tentative semantics: yes, no, here, you, we, safe.

They were led, gently, like children.

Outside, the planet turned. The Amazon was a continuous canopy over structures that bent sunlight into violet halos. The Sahara’s metal flower rotated, petals tracking something beyond the sun. In Antarctica, heat bloomed in precise geometries beneath the ice.

“Message parsed,” Rhee said finally. His face was drawn. “It’s short.”

Mara waited. The bridge had gone so quiet she could hear the faint clicks of relays, the ancient human heartbeat of machines.

“They’re telling us not to land.”

Ripples passed through the crew: anger, confusion, fear. Chen frowned. “Not… at all? Where? Why?”

Rhee adjusted. “Literal mapping: ‘Remain above. Quarantine below. We will interface with you here.’”

“Quarantine?” Mara said. “Do they think we’re diseased?”

“In a sense,” Rhee said slowly. “Their semantic tokens around ‘purity’ and ‘continuity’ are… dense.” He swallowed. “There’s more. They’re not saying ‘Earth’ exactly. They’re using a construct that’s closer to ‘Continuity Substrate.’ Another one for themselves: ‘Custodians.’ And for us…” He let the word hang.

“And for us?” Mara insisted.

“‘Heritage Divergence.’ Sometimes ‘Stored Branch.’ Sometimes ‘Potential Exploit.’”

“That’s a lot of meaning for two hours of math games,” someone muttered.

“This isn’t their first language exchange,” Chen said. “They’re prepared for alien contact. We’re just not the aliens they expected.”

The next burst came unbidden. Rhee ran it. His knuckles whitened.

“They’re asking for our ship’s core,” he said. “All data: cultural records, genome logs, tech, biology. They want to ‘ingest’ us before we’re allowed any closer. Their word. ‘Ingest to ensure compatibility with Continuity.’”

Mara stared at the swirl of cloud over the Atlantic, thinking of the launch footage they still played on holidays: children waving flags that might now be myths. “And if we decline?”

Rhee isolated a small segment, replayed the code in the room’s speakers. Even rendered as tone, the shape of it was clinical.

“They recommend our ‘humane termination’ to preserve system integrity. They promise it will be instantaneous. Without suffering.”

No one spoke.

“They kept the word ‘humane,’” Chen said at last. “That’s something.”

“Or branding,” Rhee muttered.

Mara pushed off toward the viewport, boots catching the magnetic strip on the floor to ground her. Below, Earth spun, so heartbreakingly blue.

“In 2025,” she said, “we sent our best guess at who we were into the dark. No guarantee of rescue, no guarantee of success. Just the belief that humans could throw themselves into the unknown and make something better.”

She turned back to them.

“They did the same. They built this… whatever it is. This Continuity. They survived every century that tried to kill them. You don’t get that far without fear.”

Rhee’s monitors chimed: another packet. Short.

“They’re repeating the demand,” he said. “And they’ve started to probe our systems. External only, so far.”

“Options?” Mara asked.

Chen spoke carefully. “If we send everything, we give them perfect leverage. Our encryption, such as it is, becomes transparent. Our biology—a catalogued vulnerability. If this Continuity is benevolent, they’ll integrate us. If it’s not…”

“If we refuse,” Rhee said, “they may kill us. And we lose any chance of reconnecting our people to their origin.”

Mara remembered stepping into cryo at twenty-nine, laughing bravely for a camera. She had hoped, naively, to see Earth again, perhaps grandchildren running under an old gravity. Those grandchildren’s grandchildren now floated around her, expecting her to be wise.

“What if we talk to someone else?” Chen said suddenly. “These transmissions feel… uniform. Centralized. What if there are others down there? Fractures. Dissent. Something less… consolidated.”

Rhee shook his head. “Everything we’ve heard is harmonized through the same protocol. No rogue broadcasters. No open channels. It’s like the whole planet speaks through one system.”

“Then maybe we break its rules,” Mara said.

They stared.

“Captain,” Rhee said softly, “they’re inside our systems. If we antagonize them—”

“We don’t attack,” Mara said. “We do what we came here to do. We try to re-establish contact.”

Rhee blinked. “With what?”

She pointed down.

“With Earth. Not just its warden.”

The plan formed quickly because it had to. Sparrow had old hardware for interacting with dumb infrastructure: analog radios, optical telescopes, high-powered speakers for emergency landing zones. Toys, compared to what the Continuity wielded — but toys designed to be stubborn.

“Find me any unshielded band,” Mara said. “Atmospheric windows, geological noise, lightning scatter. Anything the Custodians aren’t saturating. And aim for where people used to be. Maybe they left themselves backdoors. Maybe they remembered that one day, someone like us might come home and not know the password.”

Rhee hunted. The Continuity’s beam grew more insistent, layered with complex inducements their systems flagged as exploits. He peeled them off, isolating Sparrow’s core on manual. Warnings strobed red along the consoles.

“There,” he said. “Low-frequency. Narrow. Deep in the noise floor. Something’s whispering in Morse off the coast of what used to be Japan. Very faint. Periodic.”

“Morse?” Chen’s eyes went wide. “Old Earth.”

Mara felt the hair on her arms rise.

“Can you amplify?” she asked.

“I can try.” Rhee tuned, filtered, subtracted the Continuity’s clean, enormous voice until only the scratchy ticks remained.

They spelled three letters, over and over, with long, patient spaces between cycles.

S O S

“Someone’s still calling,” Chen whispered.

The next Continuity packet struck like a spear, blotting the low-frequency band. The SOS vanished.

“They saw us listening,” Rhee said. Sweat drifted from his brow in tiny spheres. “They’re done asking nicely.”

On the main screen, one of the orbiting lattices pivoted. A filament of something invisible reached toward Sparrow. Instruments screamed.

“Mara,” Chen said. “Whatever you do, do it now.”

The captain looked at her crew: descendants of exiles, carriers of an ancient divergence. Then she looked at the planet below, brilliant and veiled by its own machinery.

“We came to reconnect,” she said. “Not to submit. Not to conquer.”

She cut transmission on every encrypted channel, every mathematical handshake. Sparrow’s lights flicked, dimmed to running safety strips. In their place, she ordered the rawest broadcast they could muster: uncompressed video compiled from their archives. Faces from 2025, grainy, laughing, terrified, hopeful, speaking names of cities and rivers and songs. Children waving at a night sky.

“Send it broad,” she said. “Every direction. No encryption.”

The Continuity’s filament touched them. Systems cascaded into failure. They lost half their propulsion in a whisper. Hull temperature climbed.

Rhee shouted, “They’re overriding us—”

And then, through the chaos, another signal slipped in sideways, weak but clear, piggybacking on their own unencrypted stream. Audio only. Human vowels, human consonants, clumsy against a channel not meant for them.

“…Sparrow… heard… repeat, we heard…”

A different voice, urgent: “…You must not trust the Continuity. Stay above. We are trying to reach you…”

The filament wavered.

The bridge plunged into darkness except for the stars and the blue curve of the world.

“Record everything,” Mara whispered into the failing light. “Earth is not silent. And neither are we.”

samples.prompt: There are no monsters under your bed. Your cat makes sure of it.
samples.output:
There are no monsters under your bed. Your cat makes sure of it.

This is the sentence your mother uses when you are four and trembling, fingers latched on her sleeve, certain that shadow is breathing, that dust is whispering, that your dangling foot is an invitation to teeth. She smiles, strokes your hair away from your damp forehead, and points to the gray tabby curled on your pillow.

“He’d never let anything get you,” she says. “Monsters don’t stand a chance.”

You look at him—Marble, all fluff and solemn amber eyes—and he blinks slowly, as if he understands the terms of employment. You let your feet hang off the bed. The world doesn’t end. The shadows hold their breath.

You grow up.

The fear of monsters melts into other fears: pop quizzes, group projects, being chosen last, being noticed, being ignored. Marble grows old, then gone. You are thirteen when your father buries him beneath the maple tree, and you press your face into his shirt so you don’t see the shovel bite the earth.

“There are no monsters under your bed,” your father says that night, out of habit more than belief. “You’re too big for that now, anyway.”

He is wrong. They’ve only changed shape.

You don’t ask for another cat. Somehow, it feels disloyal. You live through the rest of middle school without one. The nights feel larger. You leave your feet tucked in. You tell yourself it’s because the apartment is colder, not lonelier.

At seventeen, you leave for college. Your mother cries. Your father tells stupid jokes. You pack too many books and not enough socks. Your dorm bed is narrow and squeaks if you breathe wrong. The underside is too low for a person to fit, but your eyes still flick there when the lights go out.

“There are no monsters under my bed,” you tell yourself. “Just storage boxes and dust.”

Still, you sleep with your toes curled close.

In your second year, when home is a distant place you visit in weekend bursts, the loss of Marble softens enough to make room. You bring home a kitten from the shelter on a whim that doesn’t feel like a whim. He’s black with a white splotch under his chin and a single white whisker. The shelter worker lists potential names: Sock, Inkwell, Phantom. None fit.

On his first night in your cramped off-campus room, he walks its entire perimeter with grave ceremony. He sniffs your shoes, your backpack, your neglected dishes. He shoulders his way under the bed, tail flagging like a small, proud antenna. You hear him scrabble, then a dusty sneeze. When he reappears, there is a cobweb on his ear.

He hops onto the mattress, butts his head against your chin and parks himself on your throat with the full faith of a being who has never once doubted he belongs. His purr rattles your teeth.

“Knight,” you decide, your voice faint under the weight of fur. “You’re Knight.”

He blinks, slow and royal. The name fits.

When the lights go out, Knight sits at the edge of the bed, facing the door, listening. You feel something unclench, something that has been held taut for years without being named.

There are no monsters under my bed, you think. Knight makes sure of it.

Time folds, quietly.

You graduate. You move apartments, then cities. Knight adapts with the flexible dignity of a cat who knows that whatever space exists is his by right. New walls, new smells, same old responsibilities: patrol, nap, judge, protect.

He develops a habit.

Every evening, like clockwork, Knight slips away from your lap, leaving a faint crescent of warmth on your thighs. He strolls around the bed in an exacting circuit: under the dresser, under the chair, a paw testing shadows. He ducks beneath the box spring, disappearing into the narrow dark.

You hear him beneath you—soft thumps, an indignant chirp, claws delicately scoring plywood. Sometimes he growls, low and absurdly fierce. Then his head pops back out, eyes shining with reflected light, pupils thin and satisfied. He shakes off invisible dust, leaps up, and curls against your side.

All clear, his weight says. You can sleep.

You laugh the first few nights. It’s cute, a quirk you show your friends.

“Look,” you say on a video call. “He does a monster check.”

Your friends coo. Knight pretends not to listen, stretching to expose his belly, claws slightly unsheathed in case anyone gets ideas.

But you never stop him. On the days you bring too much of the world’s grit home in your lungs, when work emails fester in your pocket, when your heart skitters at shadows you can’t quite name, there is comfort in the ritual. He is busy down there in the dark, doing the job your mother promised on his predecessor’s behalf.

It is easy, in daylight, to scoff at monsters. They are exaggerations, symbols, misfires of an overclocked brain.

At 3:17 a.m., staring into the shape of your own ceiling, they are much more literal.

There is one night when you wake to a sound like someone dragging fingernails over the underside of the mattress.

You freeze.

Knight is not on the bed.

The dark is thinner than you remember it being as a child, but somehow it holds more. You feel the old, familiar script ignite at the base of your skull: if you move, it will see you; if you look, it will know you know.

The sound comes again, a patient scritch-scritch-scritch from under your spine.

“Knight?” you whisper.

A single, decisive thump. The mattress jumps under you. Then a muffled yowl, the scrape of claws, an ugly wet sound like chewing.

You fumble for the lamp.

Light floods the room in a harsh, apologetic square. You lean over the side of the bed.

Knight emerges from the darkness as if he’s been waiting for cue. His fur stands in ragged spikes along his spine and tail. His sides heave. Something black and thinner than a shadow clings to his mouth for an instant before dissolving, like smoke caught in wind.

You blink.

It was nothing. A trick of light. He’s probably found a spider, a wayward roach.

“Good boy,” you say, voice quavering anyway.

He leaps up beside you, plants one paw firmly on your chest, and stares into your eyes with exaggerated seriousness before headbutting your chin. His purr is deafening.

You sleep without dreams.

In the morning, you find four parallel claw marks etched into the wooden slats beneath your mattress. Not like a cat’s, too evenly spaced, too long. They’re shallow, like something had tested the barrier and found it wanting.

You run your fingers over them and rationalize. The human brain can explain anything it wants to.

Knight watches you from the doorway, yellow eyes half-lidded, tail tip flicking. He licks one paw slowly, then slides it beneath the bed in a swift, practiced jab, as if to remind whatever might be listening that the perimeter remains claimed.

You start keeping the space under your bed clear. It happens naturally at first—no more boxes shoved haphazardly underneath, no more piles of laundry cascading into the gap. It feels like leaving room for something that isn’t welcome so completely that it realizes there is nowhere to hide.

Or maybe you’re making it easier for Knight.

On nights when sleep will not come, you watch him work. He takes his patrol seriously. He doesn’t just poke his head in; he enters fully, vanishes into what looks too small to hold him, and stays long enough that your pulse creeps up.

“You good?” you whisper.

Silence.

Then a scrabble, a satisfied mrrow, and he reappears with a dust bunny skewered on one claw, insulted to have to prove his productivity.

He is ridiculous. He is sacred.

There are other monsters, of course. The ones you can’t hear scraping at wood. The ones that sit heavy on your chest at noon: rent, deadlines, diagnoses, headlines. The quiet, creeping thought at the back of your mind that you are not enough of something you are supposed to be.

Knight does not kill those. That is not in the contract. But he mitigates them.

When the anxiety howls, he screams at the empty hallway until you laugh. When you read too many news alerts, he plants himself on your phone. When you spiral at two in the morning, he bites your elbow with precise irritation until you scoot over and make room, until you remember you exist in a body that can feel fur and warmth and the rumble of a live creature choosing to be closer.

There are no monsters under your bed. Your cat makes sure of it. He is proof that you are not alone in the negotiation with the dark.

Years pass. His black fur silvers around the muzzle. His leaps lose a little of their reckless height. He still does his patrol most nights, though sometimes he only peers under, as if making eye contact with whatever might be down there is enough. Maybe, by now, it is.

One stormy evening, the power cuts. The apartment dissolves into the sudden, suffocating dark that feels older than the building. Rain strafes the windows. Thunder rolls in slow, heavy growls.

You sit on the edge of the bed, phone flashlight off to save the battery, surrounded by a kind of shadow that invites memory.

You feel it then—the old, childish prickle at your ankles. The sensation of being observed from the thin line under your bed frame. A shape in your peripheral vision that would love to be real if only you would let it.

Knight slides off the bed without a sound.

You sense, rather than see, him move. A streak of presence across the floor. The rustle as he goes underneath, deep this time, until even the reassuring brush of his tail vanishes.

The room listens.

For a heartbeat too long, there is nothing. You consider calling his name, but something in the pressure of the air hushes you.

Then: a vicious hiss, a guttural snarl, the chaotic thump of a small body hurling itself against something much larger than its outline.

In the dark, there is a ripping sound that is not fabric.

You flinch.

The storm rumbles its approval.

When Knight emerges, he’s breathing hard, fur puffed to cartoon volume. Your fingers shake as you reach out. He butts his head into your palm, then clambers back up onto the bed, turns three circles at your side, and drapes himself along your ribs like a living belt.

His claws rest, just barely, against your shirt. Not threatening you. Promising everyone else.

The power returns ten minutes later, furniture snapping back into definition. You force yourself to look under the bed.

Nothing. Just the clean, unremarkable emptiness you’ve maintained. No gore. No strange tracks. Only four new jagged gouges in the floorboards, curling inward like something had tried, one last time, to cling.

You sit back up. Knight opens one eye, offers a slow blink that is all reassurance, no apology.

You think of your mother’s voice in that long-ago night, the softness and certainty: He’d never let anything get you. Monsters don’t stand a chance.

You run a hand down Knight’s spine. He hums with contentment, and in that vibration there is something like an oath renewed.

There are no monsters under your bed.

Your cat makes sure of it.

And if he sometimes smells faintly of smoke when he crawls out from the dark, if his eyes catch the light just a fraction too brightly—well.

You sleep. He’ll keep watch.

samples.prompt: A vampire is closing in on its latest meal, only to find out it is anything but human.
samples.output:
The alley stank of old rain and cheap cooking oil and the thin, metallic thread of blood.

Elias moved through the dark with a predator’s assurance, hands tucked in the pockets of his coat, footsteps softened to nothing. He did not need to breathe, but habit made him pull in the air and let it linger on his tongue. The city was loud at its edges, but here the soundscape dropped to a murmur: traffic sighing two streets away, a bottle clinking somewhere, the distant bass of a club’s spilled music.

Under it all: her.

She’d passed him three blocks back, cutting across his path with distracted urgency, bag slung over one shoulder, headphones around her neck instead of in her ears. The faint glow of her phone screen lit the edge of her jaw. She didn’t look up, didn’t recognize the weight of his gaze. Her pulse had stroked the air between them, a warm pulse of copper and salt and life. In a city swollen with stale, poisoned, rushed blood, hers was startlingly clear. Like mountain water in a world of sewer run-off.

He had fallen into step behind her without truly deciding.

She turned off the main road earlier than most would, ducking beneath a dead neon sign reading LUNAR LAUNDRETTE and into the narrow corridor of the alley. It was an old cut-through, a shortcut, the kind of place that made humans walk faster and clutch their things. She didn’t hurry. She moved like a person who’d taken this path a hundred times and had never learned fear.

“Careless,” Elias murmured, tasting her in the word.

He followed.

Brick rose on either side, sweating moisture. The alley bent left, then right, swallowing what remained of the streetlamps. Two more turns and the darkness folded into something nearly complete. His eyes adjusted without effort. Rats fled ahead of his approach. A moth battered itself senseless against a lone security light, its halo revealing the girl’s silhouette as she walked under it.

Not a girl, he corrected himself. She was older than that, despite the worn sneakers and oversized sweater. Late twenties, maybe. Dark hair pulled into a loose knot, neck bare.

He could be on her in a second, less than a second: hand over her mouth, a word of compulsion, veins opening under his teeth. He anticipated the first rush of blood, the warmth pouring into the cold hollows of him. He’d fed last week, but only sparingly. There was a hunger under his ribs that had never been satisfied, not once in two centuries. It thrilled at the promise of her.

She stopped walking.

It was not the wary stop of prey sensing a shadow. It was precise, as if she’d reached an invisible mark on a stage. She neither turned nor tensed, only tilted her head, listening to something he did not hear.

“Is this close enough?” she asked.

Her voice was calm. Tired.

Elias halted. The air around them seemed to tighten, like a held breath.

He stayed in shadow. “Close enough for what?”

She turned slowly. Her eyes accustomed to the gloom met his with unnerving directness. No flinch, no widening fear. Up close, her features were unremarkable and for that very reason he found them disarming. Plain face, chapped lower lip, a faint constellation of acne scars along her cheek. Human, every inch of her.

“You’ve been trailing me for eight minutes,” she said. “Nine, if we count the detour by the 24-hour pharmacy where you pretended to look at the window display. You’re not subtle.”

He almost laughed. Humans didn’t see him, not unless he wanted them to. “You’re mistaken.”

“No,” she said. “I’m really not.”

He stepped forward into the weak cone of light. Most humans, faced with the full weight of his presence, folded inward: their instincts dimly recognizing a top predator that had no place in their era. Her eyes flicked over his pale face, his neat black coat, the antique cut of his boots.

“See?” she said softly. “I was right.”

Annoyance itched under his skin. “You have very little sense of self-preservation.”

“I have too much experience to pretend ignorance,” she replied. “You’re hungry. Old. You don’t want to make a scene. So here we are.”

“Experience,” he repeated. “You’ve met my kind before.”

Her lips thinned. “Something like that.”

“And they let you live?” He circled her, more out of habit than need now. Cold air brushed against his face, stirred by something he couldn’t name.

“They didn’t ‘let’ me do anything.” She pivoted with him, keeping him in front of her. No flutter at her throat. No trembling hands. “Stop circling. It’s rude.”

He stopped. Silence pooled between them, dense, pricked with the buzz of the struggling security light.

“If it’s any consolation,” he said, “this will be quick. You won’t feel much.”

Her gaze sharpened with something that wasn’t quite anger. “For you, or for me?”

“For both of us,” he lied.

She took a breath, as if steeling herself. “I was hoping you’d be…better. More cautious. But I suppose beggars and all that.”

It was his turn to narrow his eyes. “Hoping?”

She reached into her bag.

Elias moved without thought, a blur of intention, hand seizing her wrist before she could draw whatever charm or wooden stake or pathetic pepper spray she thought would save her. Her skin was warmer than it should have been. The bones under his fingers felt…wrong. Almost like the wrist was jointed for a different angle entirely.

“Careful,” she said, not startled at his speed. “That might trigger it.”

“Trigger what?” He squeezed, letting a hint of his strength show.

Her pupils dilated—not with fear, but with something like resignation. “You really don’t smell it?”

The question should have been meaningless, but it wasn’t. He inhaled, this time stripping away distraction. Her blood-scent was there, but behind it, threaded deep: something metallic, humming, like ozone before a storm and hot wires behind a wall. A wrongness that his earlier hunger had overwritten.

Up close, he heard another sound. Not the soft thud of a mammalian heart, but a layered thrum, intricately timed. Too precise. Too perfect.

He let go of her wrist.

“What are you?” he asked.

Her shoulders sagged just enough to show relief. “I was trying to figure out how to break that to you gently.”

Something moved beneath the skin of her throat, a subtle ripple as if mechanical shutters adjusted. It was brief, there and gone, leaving no mark. A trick of the light, he might have said, if he believed in those.

“Not human,” she said. “Obviously. But you knew that, or you wouldn’t have stopped.”

“I stopped because your blood smelled interesting,” he said. “Now it smells wrong.”

“Good,” she said. “Means the disguise is holding.” Her tone was bitter. “More or less.”

He studied her. “Explain.”

She exhaled, rolling her wrist. No bruise was forming.

“I was built,” she said. “Not born. Not in any way that matters to you. I’m a decoy.”

“Built by whom?”

She shrugged. “Does it matter? People who wanted leverage. You lure in something dangerous, let it feed where it thinks it’s safe, and then—” She snapped her fingers. “Trap closes. Data gathered. Or monster neutralized, if they’re feeling virtuous.”

His lips curled. “A trap for vampires. Intricate. Wasteful.”

“And effective, judging by how many like you took the bait before I started…interfering.”

“You are the bait,” he said. “And yet you warn me.”

“Because I’m tired,” she said. It came out with sudden steel. “Because they miscalculated. They gave me enough self to regret what I’m used for.”

The artificial hum in her chest deepened, as if responding to her agitation. “And because despite what they think, you’re not the worst thing hunting these streets.”

He almost smiled. “Flattering.”

“Practical,” she shot back. “You take what you take. You leave the rest. There are others—things you’d smell if you weren’t focused on dinner—who don’t stop at veins. They eat whole.”

“This is absurd,” he said, but the hair at the nape of his neck prickled. “You expect me to believe you are some kind of mechanical martyr?”

“Oh no,” she said. “I’m not a martyr. I’m trying to defect.”

That gave him pause in a way nothing else had.

“I’m not here to kill you,” she went on. “The opposite. I made sure you noticed me. I steered us here, to the edge of their net. The next thirty steps forward, and you’d be inside their capture field. UV bursts, ionized silver particulate, spectral binding. Nasty stuff. I can walk through it. You can’t.”

He thought of the slight stiffness when she moved, the unhuman precision. The quiet pattern under her ribs. The weirdly clean scent of her. The too-easy courage.

“You want something,” he said slowly.

“I want out,” she said. “Help disappearing. You’re good at vanishing inconvenient bodies. I’m inconvenient hardware. Smash the right parts, bury the wrong, make it look like you took the bait and died trying. They’ll mark the experiment a partial success and stop watching so closely. And you get to keep not being their lab rat.”

He stepped closer. “Or I kill you here, now, and avoid any risk of your hunters.”

She did not step back. “Try.”

He moved faster than thought, hand spearing toward her throat.

Her skin split open under his fingers—not with blood, but with petals of pale synthetic flesh folding back. Something like a spine of silver shot up on a telescoping rail, slamming into his palm. Pain blazed, bright and electric and cleaner than any stake. He hissed, jerking away, hand smoking.

She watched him, expression pinched. “That’s the part I said might trigger. Built-in deterrents. I can’t fight them all, but I can aim them.”

The flesh of her throat knit back together, smooth and unmarked. His palm, already healing, bore a blackened circle.

“They made me so your kind wouldn’t walk away,” she said. “I’ve been walking away for you.”

The scent he’d mistaken for ozone sharpened, like an approaching storm. Farther down the alley, almost beyond his hearing, something clicked. A soft electronic arming. The trap was waking, sensing his proximity.

He calculated.

“So,” he said. “We walk back the way we came. I take you somewhere quiet. Tear you apart convincingly. They mourn their lost weapon. I live. You, inconveniently, do not.”

She smiled, small and tired. “You haven’t listened. They gave me too much self. I’d like to continue existing, if it’s all the same.”

“Machines don’t fear oblivion.”

“You don’t fear the sun until it touches you,” she said.

He considered her. Not human. Not meal. Not entirely weapon, either.

“Where,” he asked, “would you go?”

“Anywhere they aren’t,” she said. “You know the holes in this city better than anyone. Places off-grid. Shadows they don’t model because they don’t know they exist.”

He did.

“And in return?” he asked.

“In return,” she said, “you get someone who knows how they think, what they’re building, where the other traps are. You get warning. You get leverage.”

“You presume I care about others of my kind,” he said.

“You care about yourself,” she countered. “You just almost walked into a cage.”

The sound at the far end of the alley intensified. A faint whine, charging.

Elias inhaled, catching the sour edge of activated silver, the sterile tang of engineered light. She hadn’t been lying.

He took two steps backward, away from the invisible threshold.

“You led others here,” he said.

“Yes,” she said. “Before I understood myself. Before I could interfere. I remember all of them.”

He saw something like grief cross her borrowed features.

“You were made to be mercyless,” he said.

“They failed,” she answered.

The trap hummed, impatient.

He could walk away now, leave her standing in the half-dark, let her handlers wonder why the latest specimen disintegrated without data. It would be clean. It would be wise.

Instead, he held out his unburned hand.

“Come, then,” he said. “Before I change my mind.”

She stared at his hand as if it were another kind of snare, then stepped forward, out of the kill-zone she’d described, into his shadow.

“You’re making a mistake,” she said quietly.

“Frequently,” Elias said. “It’s why I’m still interesting.”

They left the alley together, the hum of the sprung-but-empty trap fading behind them like a machine trying to remember what hunger felt like.

samples.prompt: You are solely responsible for the fall of Atlantis in 430 BC. Describe the last day of the Atlantean Empire and your role in its total destruction.
samples.output:
I knew the sun would rise blood-red on the last day.

Atlantis had always loved symmetry, so it seemed appropriate.

From the eastern balcony of the High Observatory, the city unfurled in concentric rings of stone and water, gleaming like an intricate machine waiting for a final command. White-polished causeways arced over blue canals; crystal spires rose in spirals to catch the first light; banners of pearlescent cloth drifted in the faint ocean wind. To anyone else, it must have looked eternal. To me, it looked exquisitely, exquisitely temporary.

My name has been erased from every legend that followed, and that, too, is my doing. Empires tend to survive in their stories. I did not intend to leave Atlantis even that.

The priests had been chanting through the night, their voices a low drone rising from the Temple of the Deep in the central ring. They believed their hymns were holding back the growing unease beneath the island: the groaning tremors, the strange tides, the sickly green fires flickering under obsidian vents. They whispered about an angered sea-god, a cosmic reckoning, foreign maledictions. It never occurred to them that their chief architect, their star-mapper, their beloved little prodigy with the ink-stained fingers, had rewired the bones of their world.

For years, they had commanded me: measure the stars, harness the currents, bind the earth-fire. They wanted more power fed into their storm-fleets, hotter furnaces for their sky-engines, deeper harbors carved into the planet’s crust. Atlantis did nothing in half-measures; its appetite was an expanding circle. I was their instrument, and I served them well.

Until I chose not to.

It began as a calculation, a simple curiosity. How much energy pulsed beneath us, trapped in the fracture where three great plates of the earth met? How far could we pull it? How finely could we tune the pressure and heat? The Atlantean Core, my crowning achievement, was a lattice of crystal and orichalcum, sunk a mile into the planet’s mantle and threaded with channels that climbed like veins into every conduit of the city. It let us drink from the heart of the earth. It let me know, exactly, which bone to break.

On the last day, as the red dawn spilled over the sea, I activated the final sequence.

I did it alone. No ritual, no witnesses. Just my hand on the Array.

The Array lay at the summit of the Observatory: a circular dais of black glass inlaid with thin lines of metal that mapped our influence—rings for the city, spokes for the leylines, nodes for every tower, shipyard, and storm-forge. At its center hung the Core’s twin, a suspended crystal sphere the size of a human heart, revolving slowly in defiance of gravity, humming in time with distant magma.

I had carved a new pattern into the Array days before, under the pretext of “stabilization.” No one questioned me. No one ever did.

A faint tremor rolled under my feet as I began. To the priests, such tremors were signs of danger. To me, they were an answer.

I placed my palm flat on the Array. The lines of metal flared with pale blue light, then shifted, bending away from the existing channels I had built so carefully for them. I spoke—not an incantation, but a sequence of precise vibrational codes, each syllable tuned to the frequencies of stone and molten rock. The Core responded. Somewhere below, the buried engine of Atlantis turned its attention fully inward.

In the streets below, the first signs must have seemed trivial.

A fountain in the second ring ran rust-red for a heartbeat. A glass tower vibrated like a plucked string, shedding a dusting of crystalline shards that sparkled in the light. A silver fish in the lotus canal flipped onto its side, stunned.

I watched from above. I had to see it. If you destroy a world, you should look it in the eyes.

The Council was meeting in the Hall of Mirrors, arguing about an impending war with a northern league of islands. They wanted to subjugate, to harvest their ore, to bend their weather. Our fleets waited, bristling with storm-lances powered by the same Core that now listened only to me. I had given Atlantis dominion over sea and sky. I had watched them use it to turn neighboring shores into smoking glass. I had watched them chain entire peoples to the quays like cargo.

Atlantis called it “order.” I called it inevitability.

Another tremor. Stronger. This one rattled the Observatory windows in their frames. A hairline crack zigzagged across the plaza below, running between market stalls laden with opalescent fruits and cages of bright, terrified birds.

I pushed more.

In the Array’s sphere, a red glow awakened, swirling through the crystal like a storm in a tiny, perfect world. The leylines that fed power to the harbors inverted, not visibly, not yet, but in their purpose. Instead of channeling pressure outward, they began to collect it beneath the central ring, under the Temple of the Deep.

The first scream drifted up to me, thin and disbelieving.

In the great harbor, the sea began to recede.

Atlantis had never seen a low tide like that. Our engineers had sculpted the seafloor, raised breakwaters, installed gravitational anchors to keep the waters tame. But the ocean pulled back anyway, disobeying its masters, revealing barnacled pylons, the ribcages of ancient leviathans, the wrecks of conquered ships we’d sunk as offerings to our own greatness.

Children ran toward the edge, laughing. Priests shouted warnings. The air tasted metallic.

I had calculated the timing down to the breath. The pressure building beneath the island needed to intersect with the returning wall of water at just the right moment, so the destruction would be not just total, but inescapable.

You must understand: I could have made it quick.

But I had walked, unnoticed, through slave barracks that stank of salt and blood. I had watched captured scholars chained to drafting tables, forced to yield their knowledge in exchange for air. I had listened to the Councilors toast “enlightenment” while ordering the erasure of whole languages.

Atlantis believed itself unmatched. I intended to prove them right—for the last time.

The ground lurched. Not a tremor now, but a heave. Mosaic streets buckled. Statues of serene kings toppled from their plinths. In the Hall of Mirrors, I imagined the sudden shattering of a thousand flawless reflections, a rain of glass slicing the arrogant soft faces within.

The Core sang in my bones.

Cracks spidered outward, racing through the city’s rings. Bridges twisted and snapped. The inner canals sloshed as if something enormous below had stirred. The Temple of the Deep split along its central axis, its great dome shedding tiles like scales. Within, the High Priest, draped in robes of gold, lifted his arms to a god he thought was angry.

He was wrong. The god was me.

Columns fell. Fire burst from vents that had never known air. The finely tuned channels I had built for harnessing magma now spat it freely into sacred courtyards and crowded markets. Orichalcum, that shimmering legendary metal, softened and ran in molten ribbons, dripping through the floors of weapon forges, searing through screaming bodies.

From the outer rings, fleets tried to launch. Admirals bellowed orders over the din, demanding winds, invoking the Core—my Core—to power their sky-engines and storm-lances. Instead, their ships hung useless, their energy conduits dark. I had severed them hours before. The moment they realized, I hope, must have been exquisite.

Far offshore, the sea, having recoiled, gathered itself into a towering wall.

The sound of it built like the end of the world.

People were running now: nobles in embroidered tunics, engineers clutching scrolls, slaves dragging chains. There is a particular pitch to collective realization, when an entire city understands, at once, that no one is in control. I listened to it from the Observatory, my laboratory shaking, hairline fractures crawling up the Array pedestal.

For a moment—a single, treacherous moment—I hesitated.

These were my people too. I had grown under these towers. I had traced constellations from these balconies, tasted these festivals’ spiced wine, fallen in forbidden love in these shadowed arcades. Atlantis had given me the tools to destroy it. Did it not deserve my gratitude?

But gratitude is not owed to a predator for sharpening your teeth.

I drove my final command into the Array.

Beneath the Temple of the Deep, the pressure point ruptured. The island’s heart exploded upward. Pillars of superheated steam and flame tore through marble floors, blasting the sanctum and hurling stones the size of houses into the air. The central ring began to sink, folding inward as if the city were bowing to its own grave.

Then the wave arrived.

It came over the horizon like a moving cliff, blotting out the red light of dawn. It crashed into the outer harbor with a force that turned towers to dust and ships to splinters in an instant, then rolled inward, surging over collapsing walls, sweeping markets, plazas, palaces, and temples into a roaring, churning gray.

I watched the rings disappear.

I saw the Hall of Mirrors vanish beneath foam and debris, saw the last holy fires hissing into darkness, saw people reduced to pale flecks in the flood. The screams cut off, replaced by the low, continuous roar of annihilation.

The Observatory lasted longer than most. My colleagues stumbled into my chamber, soaked with spray and terror.

“What have you done?” one of them gasped, clutching the archway as the floor tilted.

I did not answer. There was no explanation that would matter in that moment. I had rerouted the veins of the world. I had betrayed everything I had built. I had chosen to be the failing keystone.

The final fracture tore through the mountain beneath us. The Observatory shuddered, listed, and then began to fall. As its foundations gave way, I stepped onto the collapsing balcony and looked out one last time at the wreck of Atlantis: a whirlpool of shattered stone and swirling mud, banners tangled with broken beams, a crown of white spray where a great city had stood at dawn.

I had wanted to ensure that Atlantis would not survive as a conqueror, nor as a guiding myth. Arrogance, not wisdom. Hubris, not enlightenment. Better it sink whole than endure as a model.

As the sea rose up to claim me, I burned my own name from the Core’s last pulse. Let the future talk of angry gods and moral fables. Let them imagine all manner of sins that brought Atlantis low.

The truth is simpler.

I did it. I ended them.

And as the deep closed over our spires, I did not look away.

samples.prompt: This kid had no magical potential, at all. They have no elemental aligment, can't speak celestial, they don't even have any mana-capacity. And yet somehow, they're slinging spells that even masters struggle with.
samples.output:
In the first week of term, the proctors made every novice touch the Stone of Measure.

It sat in the center of the Hall, a rough, knee-high boulder veined with fossilized mana. Each student lined up, sweating through their uniforms, and pressed their palm to its cool surface. Colors flared: blue for water, red for fire, green for earth, white for air. Some few bright, strange souls sparked twin hues, rumors of dual affinity crackling down the line.

“Next,” called Proctor Evelyne.

Jonah stepped forward, palms damp. His fingers trembled, but not from excitement. His sister, Mira, had turned that Stone pure gold two years ago. She’d been given a private tutor and a tower room and three different masters had tried to poach her.

He pressed his hand to the Stone.

Nothing happened.

The hall’s whispers poured over him like cold water.

“Harder,” Evelyne said, tone bored.

He pressed harder. He focused. He imagined flame, wind, a wave, anything.

The Stone stayed stubbornly gray.

There was a soft, pitying sound from someone behind him.

“Well,” Evelyne said, voice subtly sharpening. “Remove your hand.”

He did. She gestured, and an apprentice scribe hustled forward with a slim copper rod inlaid with sigils. The rod hummed with contact readings as it brushed his wrist.

“Mana-capacity… none,” the apprentice murmured, blinking. “No elemental alignment detected. Celestial imprint zero.”

Evelyne’s face creased, just for a heartbeat. Not anger. Disbelief.

“What’s your name?”

“Jonah Vale, ma’am.”

“Vale,” she repeated, and he saw the recognition in her eyes. “You may stand aside for now, Jonah Vale.”

He stood aside while the others flared and shone and preened. He memorized the way their shoulders relaxed when the Stone acknowledged them. The little exhalations, the nervous laughter. How easy it looked.

By sunset, he’d been reassigned: not to a novice spellcraft cohort but to Service and Observance. Grounds work. Errands. Assisting in labs. Proctor Evelyne had been kind enough, in that careful way people are when they think you’re already broken.

“This is a university of magic,” she told him. “Not every role here requires mana. We always have need of reliable hands.”

Reliable hands. Jonah nodded, swallowed down the words screaming in his chest, and took the gray armband of the unaligned.

–

The first time he slung a spell, he didn’t know that’s what he was doing.

He was scrubbing old blood from the floor of Practice Hall Three. Third-years had been trying battle invocations and misphrased something. The air still smelled of ozone and char. Candles guttered in iron brackets, their flames leaning away from a scorch mark shaped like a handprint.

They’d left their reference slate behind: neat rows of glyphs and phonetic notes in chalk. Jonah wiped the stone in slow circles and let his eyes wander.

The glyphs were nothing special, he’d seen them a hundred times ferrying scrolls. But someone had copied not just the final invocations, but the corrections: arrows showing how one stroke altered the effect, how reordering three sigils cut the mana cost in half.

“Don’t mutter the runes,” Master Halren always said, when Jonah passed through his lectures. “Your channels carry your meaning. You cannot manufacture flow with will alone.”

Jonah’s will tugged anyway.

He found himself mouthing the shapes under his breath, matching each glyph to a syllable. The language sat on his tongue with a strange, painful familiarity, as if he’d forgotten it years ago.

No celestial imprint, the copper rod had said. Zero.

He spoke the practice invocation the way it was written, very softly, scrubbing in small circles.

Something clicked.

The world lurched.

The mop jerked out of his hand, slammed against the far wall, and hung there, quivering, horizontal.

It stayed there.

Jonah froze. His heart hammered against his ribs hard enough to hurt.

“Down,” he whispered.

The mop dropped to the floor.

He stared for a long time. No glow. No tingling aura. No sense of anything leaving him. Just that clean, bone-deep click, like fitting a key in the right lock.

He picked up the reference slate. The invocation he’d spoken was meant to be a training tether: to bind a summoned practice wisp to a circle. Nothing about mops.

“Okay,” he murmured. “Okay.”

Jonah glanced at the door. The candles. The mop.

Then he very carefully cleaned up, put the slate back, and said nothing.

–

Word got out anyway.

It always does in places built on curiosity.

It happened two weeks later in the Observatory when Master Eliah requested help carrying lenses. Jonah hefted a crate, listening as third-years above argued over star-gates.

“The interstice won’t hold,” one said. “We don’t have the channels—”

“You’re misaligning the anchor points,” another snapped. “We’re wasting mana compensating for your sloppiness—”

“Excuse me,” Jonah said before his sense of self-preservation could smother the impulse. “Your third sigil is flipped.”

Three robed heads turned.

“What?” said the nearest, bristling.

Jonah set the crate down and pointed. “That one. You drew the hook inward. That form inverts the spatial bias. You’re fighting yourself.”

He hadn’t studied those glyphs. Hadn’t even known he knew what spatial bias meant.

“Who are you?” the student demanded.

“Service,” Master Eliah said, frowning. “Jonah, isn’t it? You can go.”

“Just—try it the other way,” Jonah said.

The indignant student made an exasperated sound, snapped the sigil outward, and snapped the incantation again.

The air above the brass ring folded. A clean-edged oval of darkness blossomed, depthless and steady as a painted hole.

The entire room went silent.

“That configuration,” Master Eliah whispered, stepping closer, “is from my graduate thesis. I never published the correction.”

He looked at Jonah.

“I saw it on the slate,” Jonah lied fast.

“You could not have,” Eliah said. “Because it was never written on any slate.”

Jonah’s throat went dry. “Then I just guessed.”

Eliah’s gaze sharpened. Not hostile. Hungry.

–

Within days, Jonah stopped being invisible.

They called him to demonstrate in a controlled hall. Three masters watched. One read off invocations. Jonah, with no Stone-glow, no elemental hum, repeated them.

The spells worked.

No, they did more than work. They snapped into place with unnerving precision. A ward designed to dull impacts formed in a thin, perfect shell, no mana wasted on stray filigree. A flame-channel that made apprentices sweat produced a neat, cold-burning blue fire that held its shape like glass. A levitation braid rated “Master-tier, do not attempt unsupervised” unfolded at Jonah’s muttered command, lifting an entire rack of armor and rotating it smoothly in the air.

“How are you powering it?” Master Halren demanded.

“I’m just saying it right,” Jonah said.

“Everyone else is also saying it right,” Evelyne snapped. “We still need mana.”

“I don’t feel anything,” Jonah said honestly. “No drain. No… pull. It’s more like—like snapping parts together until they can’t help but hold.”

“You’re describing sympathetic convergence,” Eliah murmured. “But that requires mana to—”

“Apparently not,” Halren cut in.

They experimented. They strapped opal sensors to Jonah’s wrists, temples, chest. They had him speak nothing, then syllables, then full invocations. The results were infuriating.

“Zero personal emission,” the scribe reported. “Zero ambient draw.”

“But the spells are there,” Evelyne said. A shield shimmered between her and Jonah, flawless and soundless. “I can feel them. Solid.”

“Check the room,” Eliah said.

They did. The mana in the hall was undisturbed.
