“It violates conservation,” Halren muttered.

Jonah stood in the middle of their arguing, feeling oddly hollow.

“Does it matter?” he said at last.

Three high mages stared at him.

“What if,” he went on, “I’m not… pushing anything. Just arranging the instructions in a way that makes the world obey with what it already has?”

“That is what we do,” Evelyne said. “With mana.”

“Maybe you’ve been shouting at reality,” Jonah said quietly, “and I’m using its inside voice.”

Silence.

Eliah began to laugh.

–

The rumors spread faster than the explanations.

“He recited the Ninth Binding without a circle,” one student whispered.

“I heard he inverted the Echo Storm,” another said.

“He doesn’t even glow,” a third muttered, half-frightened, half-awed. “When I cast, I feel like I’m bleeding light. He just… talks.”

They stopped calling him unaligned. They started calling him Null.

Jonah Vale, the Null Mage.

He hated the name, but not the work. Because the work made sense.

The world, he began to suspect, was full of implicit contracts. Not metaphors, but literal; quiet lines of law woven under the sensory noise. Every spell, as taught, was a loud, wasteful restatement of those contracts, reinforcing them with brute mana. But the contracts already knew what they were.

When Jonah saw a glyph, he saw its context. Its unspoken grammar.

“Your wards unravel because you contradict yourself here,” he told a fourth-year, tapping a jagged rune. “You’re promising safety and inviting rupture in the same breath.”

“It’s how we’ve always drawn it,” she protested.

“Then you’ve always been wrong.”

He redrew it. She cast. This time the ward settled with a comforting, latching sensation. No flicker. No whine.

As weeks turned to months, masters came to him with questions. He corrected research sigils. He rephrased incantations considered impossible without celestial blood. He walked through a blighted grove that had drained seasoned druids and, with three soft words, told the rot it no longer had permission to spread.

The grove listened.

“Do you understand what you are?” Eliah asked him one night, under the slow turn of the observatory dome.

“A mistake,” Jonah said. He meant it as a joke. It didn’t quite land.

Eliah shook his head. “A proof. Of something we didn’t know we were trying to prove.”

“Which is?”

“That magic is not fuel,” Eliah said. “It is syntax. And you are… fluent.”

Jonah looked at his hands. Plain. Scarred from work. No glow.

“What happens,” he asked, “when others learn to do what I do?”

Eliah was quiet for a long time.

“Then the age of sorcerers ends,” he said softly. “And the age of readers begins.”

–

Mira came to see him at the end of the spring term.

She wore three rings of office now, mana shimmering around her like a mirage. People stepped aside for her in the corridors. She found Jonah in Practice Hall Three, watching a new batch of novices take their first careful steps into the air within one of his rephrased levitation fields.

“They’re saying you unspoke the Iron Flood,” she said without preamble.

“I asked it to be specific,” Jonah said. “It was overreaching.”

She studied his face. “You scare them.”

“I know.”

“You scare me,” she admitted. “A little.”

He swallowed. “I didn’t ask for any of this.”

“I know that, too.”

A novice wobbled, yelped, then steadied, eyes wide with exhilaration. Jonah watched him grin.

“Do you hate us?” Mira asked. “Those of us who burn to move the world?”

He shook his head at once. “No. You built everything I’m standing in.”

“You’re changing it.”

“So are you,” he said. “You chose to believe I wasn’t lying.”

She snorted. Then, more serious: “What if there’s a cost we can’t see yet?”

“There is,” Jonah said. “They’re all going to have to learn to read.”

Mira laughed, bright and helpless.

Then, quieter, she said, “Teach me.”

Jonah blinked. “You don’t need—”

“I do,” she said. “Because you’re right. We’ve been shouting. I want to know the inside voice.”

He thought of the Stone of Measure, cold under his palm. Of the proctors’ pity. Of mops on walls and gates snapping open and trees listening.

“Okay,” Jonah said.

He lifted his hand and drew a glyph in the air. No light trailed his finger, but Mira watched as though it did.

“First rule,” he said. “Stop trying to force it. Start trying to say exactly what you mean.”

Outside, the towers of the academy bristled with old wards and loud, bright spells. Inside, in a quiet practice hall, a boy with no mana and a girl bright with it leaned over invisible lines, and began to rewrite how the world was asked to change.

samples.prompt: In order to avoid aging and death, you may take out a loan of time. In order to pay it back, you must take a life or lives equal to the amount of years you borrowed.
samples.output:
The contract was written in clean, bureaucratic font, the kind you associate with parking fines and water bills—nothing that should have anything to do with eternity.

“Principal,” it read, “to be disbursed in chronological units: 50 years.”

Below that, in smaller print: “Repayment due prior to natural cessation of consciousness. Penalty for default: reclamation of borrowed time plus principal life.”

The clerk pushed the paper toward me with the casual boredom of a bank teller.

“Fifty’s common for first-timers,” she said. “You’re thirty-three. That’ll bring you to eighty-three minimum, plus any natural extension you might have earned. Nice, full life. You’re sure that’s what you want?”

“Not… totally,” I said. The words felt dry. “Run it past me again.”

She sighed—the kind of sigh that suggested I was the fourth idiot before lunch—and tapped a paragraph with her pen.

“You borrow years from the Agency. While you’re using them, you do not age, do not die, unless by violent interruption. You want to survive the cancer, the war, whatever—it’s how you do it. Before you reach what would have been your natural endpoint—eighty-two, give or take for you—you pay back your loan by taking lives totaling the number of years you borrowed. Lives, plural, if needed. You can take one fifty-year-old. Or five tens. Or fifty ones. It’s very flexible.”

“And if I don’t?”

“Then we collect,” she said. “You don’t want us to collect.”

Behind her, the waiting room hummed with quiet desperation. Posters on the wall showed earnest people of every age under the slogan: “Time Is Yours—Don’t Waste It.” In the corner, a child played with a toy hourglass, flipping it over, watching sand pour down, giggling. I tried not to take that as an omen.

“But I have to kill them myself,” I said. “It can’t be incidental?”

“Direct causality,” she said. “You must knowingly and willingly cause the deaths. No accidents. No distant consequences. You’re paying in intention.”

“And they can’t be dying already.”

“They can be,” she said. “But then you’re only credited for the time you’re actually taking. So if someone has five minutes to live, and you kill them an hour early, you owe us negative fifty-five minutes. We’re not that cruel.”

I laughed, once. “That’s considerate.”

She shrugged. “We’re accountants.”

We stared at each other. Somewhere down the hall, someone sobbed, suddenly and then not at all.

“It feels… evil,” I said.

She raised an eyebrow. “Then don’t sign.”

“I’ll die,” I said.

“Yes.”

My scans sat in the folder on my lap, black blossoms in soft organs. Stage four. A season, maybe two, left. My wife, Leah, had cried over them until she’d run out of tears. My son, Miles, was four. Old enough to remember me, young enough to remember me wrong.

I had done the research. Everyone had. The Time Agency had been in place twenty-two years. It started as something whispered about: a quiet arrangement, a hidden clause in the universe. Now it had a building, a queue, a customer satisfaction survey.

People hated it. People used it.

“Can I target…” I hesitated. “Bad people?”

She sighed. “We do not vet your victims. We do not supply lists. Your ethics are your own. The math is ours.”

“So I could take fifty from a dictator and walk free.”

“If you can get close enough to a dictator, sure,” she said dryly. “We’re not in the logistics business.”

“And if I choose… smaller increments?”

“Fifty babies,” she said. “Fifty four-year-olds. You understand the scale? It’s the same math either way. The same weight. You don’t get a discount because you picked someone with a mugshot.”

My mouth went dry. “There must be people who haven’t paid it back.”

Her eyes flicked to the side, as if checking invisible numbers. “There have been… some misunderstandings. People think they’ll find a loophole. Live a good life, be kind enough that the universe forgives them. At collection, they tend to beg.”

“How many sign?”

“Enough that we stay open.”

I looked at the signature line. Fifty years. Fifty lives, assuming average lifespan. Fifty families shorn open so that I could play ball with my son at eighteen. Attend his graduation at twenty-two. Hold grandchildren. Grow old with Leah.

“Do many use less than they borrow?” I asked. “Take the loan and… make payment quick?”

She tilted her head. “Occasionally. A few take, say, ten years, and clear it in one dark week. Others spend decades hunting monsters and convincing themselves they are a hero. We don’t care. As long as the numbers balance.”

I imagined myself that way: a cloaked avenger, dealing death to the deserving. It had a comic-book clarity from this side of the desk.

I imagined standing over a crib.

“Do I get… younger?” I asked. “If I sign.”

“No,” she said. “We freeze what’s there. You’ll carry your cancer scars into borrowed time, but nothing new will etch itself in. You won’t get sicker. You won’t get better. You’ll just… continue.”

But not my cells, I thought. My choices.

“Do you ever feel bad?” I asked her.

She rolled the pen between her fingers. “Do you feel bad for traffic lights ticketing speeders?”

“It’s not the same.”

She smiled without warmth. “No. But it is as simple.”

Leah and I had fought about this. Or tried to.

“We could have more time,” she’d said, voice cracking. “Time for trials. Time for something to change. Time with us. Please, Eli. Just talk to them.”

“And then what?” I’d said. “You want me to become a murderer?”

“Not now,” she said. “Later. We’ll figure it out later.”

Later. People built civilizations on that word.

I picked up the pen.

“Fifty,” I said.

“Initial here, here, and here,” the clerk said. “And sign at the bottom.”

The pen was heavier than it looked. When my name was on the line, nothing happened. No thunder. No choir of damned. She stamped it, the sound obscene in its normalcy.

“That’s it?” I asked.

“That’s it,” she said. “You’re on our books. You are now fixed at your current biological age until your borrowed time concludes or your debt is repaid. Your cancer will cease progression in…” She checked a screen. “Seven to ten minutes.”

I stepped out into the sunlight feeling like I had been hollowed. Leah was waiting by the car. When I told her, she covered her face and sobbed with violent relief, then kissed me as if she could inhale my new years.

Miles ran circles around us, shouting about ice cream.

I watched him, counting without wanting to. Four, plus sixteen to adulthood, plus everything beyond. Fifty lives. At least fifty.

“Don’t,” Leah whispered into my shoulder. “Not now.”

But the clock had begun the moment I signed, whether it moved for me or not.

Years passed.

The cancer froze and lay dormant. I went back to work, then didn’t; investment in a man who didn’t age turned into consulting, into rumor. We moved cities twice. My parents died. Friends did. Strangers took photos of me at school reunions, whispering. “He looks incredible for his age,” they said, until incredible shaded into unnatural.

There were others like me. You began to see them in certain bars, certain corners of conferences, their faces with that odd, ageless calm. Loaners, we called one another, with gallows camaraderie.

“You done it yet?” one asked me once, swirling his drink.

“No,” I said.

He snorted. “You wait too long, you won’t be able to. Guilt calcifies. Better to pay off fresh.”

“You?”

“Three scumbags,” he said. “One trafficker. One war criminal. One guy who filmed everything he did to little girls. I sleep fine.”

“Do you?” I asked.

He looked at me for a long time. “Finer than they do,” he said.

I tried. I really did. I tracked the news. I made lists. Men whose names stood for horrors. I told myself I’d find them, that I’d make my debt a public service.

But the world was large, their security good, my life busy. There was always another birthday, another crisis. Another later.

I watched Miles grow. First crush. First car accident, minor, his hands shaking as I held him. His wedding. His daughter, Eva, gripping my finger with shocking strength. I watched Leah’s hair silver, her hands grow lined. At seventy, she squeezed my ageless fingers.

“You have to start,” she said quietly one night.

“I know,” I said.

“I don’t want it to be you,” she murmured. “But I want you to be here when I’m gone. Is that selfish?”

“Yes,” I said.

She laughed, brittle. “Then be selfish back.”

I found one of them in a country that pretended not to harbor him. I won’t say his name. You know the type. Villages ash in his wake. Children vanishing.

It took two years of planning. Two years of pretending I was only a philanthropist, only a consultant, only anything but what I had signed to be.

When I finally stood in front of him, pistol in my hand, his bodyguards dead or dying, he raised his hands, furious and incredulous.

“You?” he spat. “Who are you?”

“I’m on a repayment plan,” I said.

I shot him once in the chest, once in the head. His body folded, abruptly small.

The Agency credited me fifty-six years, far more than I’d expected. History had underestimated how long he would have lived, cosseted by wealth and protection.

“That’s one,” the clerk said when I came in to confirm. It was the same clerk, unchanged. Of course.

“He was a monster,” I said. “That must count for something.”

She typed, not looking at me. “We’re not in the judgment business.”

“You should be,” I said.

“We’re not qualified,” she said.

Fifty years in one act. Enough to square my original loan, with surplus. I could have stopped.

But the surplus wasn’t mine to keep. That was another clause: the Agency never owed you. Any excess was absorbed as “interest.”

I had paid off my debt in full by killing a single man.

I went home. Leah cried into my chest and did not ask for details. Miles hugged me as if I’d returned from a war.

“I did it,” I whispered to Leah, in the dark. “I’m free.”

“Then live,” she whispered back. “And don’t do it again.”

I didn’t need to. I had the extra fifty from my loan, now legally mine, stretched out before me. I watched Leah fade, gently, over the next decade. When she died at eighty-two, I looked exactly as I had the day I signed.

At her funeral, people murmured how well I was holding up. A few looked at me with naked suspicion. In the third row, I recognized a face with the same agelessness as mine. A woman, watching me. Loaner.

After the burial, she came up beside me among the stones.

“You got yours,” she said. “I heard.”

“One,” I said.

She nodded. “Lucky. I’m at nineteen. Thought about default, once. Went into the office, signed the release forms. But when they stood up to collect, I ran.”

“What happens when they collect?” I asked.

She studied me. “You really don’t know?”

“I paid early,” I said.

“That’s not an answer,” she said. “Come. I’ll show you.”

We drove to the Agency. She flashed an old card; doors opened. Past the waiting room, past the clerks, past the safe glass. Down.

The collection chamber was not dramatic. A room. Chairs, bolted to the floor. People sitting in them, some sobbing, some eerily calm. Around them, shadows—no, not shadows. Figures, pale and watchful, as if drawn in negative space.

“How many?” I whispered.

“Everyone they owed,” she said. “Everyone whose years they promised. Collection isn’t the Agency coming. It’s the denied deaths. Time does not like to be cheated. It comes to reclaim in aggregate. That’s why they scream.”

One man in a chair began to convulse, clawing at invisible hands. Something tore free of him in a soundless burst. He slumped, slack. One of the pale shapes brightened, then folded away.

I backed up, heart pounding.

“We sign,” she said softly, “because we’re afraid to die. And then we spend borrowed time deciding who doesn’t get to. If we fail, the balance comes crashing down all at once. That’s the real penalty. Not just your life. Every stayed death claiming you as common denominator.”

“That’s not on the contract,” I said.

She smiled grimly. “Fine print is for people who think they’ll read it.”

I drove home in silence. The weight of my single shot pressed on me. I had paid my debt in one “noble” act, tidy and contained. Others carved their payments into the world like scars. A few defaulted and were swallowed whole.

I watched Eva, my granddaughter, play in the yard. Her hair caught the sun, gold and effortless.

Leah was gone. My original bargain was settled. I could live out my extra fifty, guilt balanced in the Agency’s ledger. I could, as my friend at the bar had said, sleep fine.

Time, I realized, is not moral. The Agency was not evil. It was simply a structure erected around an ancient truth: every year you keep that you should have given up is taken from somewhere, someone.

The prompt had been clear all along.

In order to avoid aging and death, you may take out a loan of time.

In order to pay it back, you must take a life or lives equal to the amount of years you borrowed.

I thought of Leah’s hand in mine. I thought of the man I’d killed, and the people he would never kill. I thought of chairs bolted to the floor.

“Grandpa!” Eva shouted. “Come play!”

I stepped into the sunlight, feeling every unearned second slide over my skin. I had balanced my account, but there was no such thing as clean immortal time. Only time someone else would now never have.

I ran anyway.

samples.prompt: Having no friends after graduating college, you discover that your mother had been buying all of your previous friends.
samples.output:
I found out on a Wednesday.

It was one of those late, bright afternoons that only exist in college towns—everyone spilling out on lawns, frisbees in the air, music from three directions at once. Except I was inside my half-packed bedroom, sitting between boxes of books I never finished and clothes that still smelled faintly like the dorm laundry room. My phone lay faceup beside me, screen unlit. No new messages. No missed calls.

My last final had been three days ago. The stadium graduation was in four. People I knew were having “last this” and “final that”—final coffee dates, final bar nights, final group pictures in front of the statue with the school mascot’s mangled bronze nose. My calendar was empty.

I told myself: Everyone is just busy. Everyone is going home soon. They’ll reach out.

By Wednesday afternoon, I stopped believing that.

I scrolled through our group chats. In “The Coven” (my freshman friends), the last message was from me: “Brunch Saturday?” Seen by all, answered by none. In “Capstone Crew,” there were memes and gifs, plans for a trip I hadn’t been invited to, my name absent like it’d been blacked out. I watched their stories: clinking glasses, shared Ubers, arms slung around shoulders. The captions said things like, “My people for life,” and I had to keep reminding myself I had been there. I had held the camera sometimes.

I tossed my phone aside and picked up a framed photo from my nightstand. Four of us at the lake sophomore year, sunburned and stupid. Anna leaning into me. I remembered how, that day, she’d cried in my car about her parents, about money, about feeling alone. I’d held her hand. Later she’d fallen asleep with her head in my lap.

I set the photo down.

A notification popped up. My bank app, alerting me about a “linked account change.” My thumb hesitated, then tapped.

The app asked if I wanted to approve a new linked institution. It was my mother’s bank.

I frowned. We’d never linked accounts. When I’d asked her once about help with rent, she’d wired money and said, “I’ll always support you, sweetheart.” Linking meant control. Visibility.

I called her.

She answered on the second ring, bright as always. “Hi, love! How’s my graduate-to-be?”

“Mom,” I said, “did you just link your account to mine?”

A pause, barely a hitch. “Yes. Is that okay? I thought, with you finishing, it would be easier to help if you need—”

“I didn’t approve anything.”

“Well, the email came through, you must have tapped something.”

I thought of my thumb, clumsy, hitting “approve” without reading. My chest tightened. “Why are we linking now? Why not earlier?”

“Oh, honey,” she laughed, brittle. “You’re so suspicious. I’m trying to help.”

“You didn’t help when my card declined for groceries last year,” I said before I could stop myself.

Another pause. “You didn’t tell me it was that bad.”

“I did. You said it would ‘build character.’”

“Let’s not fight,” she said, tone smoothing out like pressed linen. “I’m driving. Can we talk later?”

“Where are you going?”

“To the store. Why?”

“To buy something?” I asked, half a joke, half an accusation I couldn’t explain.

She made a small sound. “I have to go. I’ll call you tonight.”

She hung up.

I stared at the blank screen. Then I opened my emails, looking for the approval message. It was there, time-stamped twenty minutes earlier, already marked as addressed. But there was another email above it, the most recent, from my mom’s address, accidentally forwarded with a trail of messages below.

Subject: Re: Renewal

Her message, to someone named “Elizabeth (Mother)” whose name I recognized only vaguely: “Hi Elizabeth, following up on our previous arrangement. As graduation approaches, I assume this month will be our last payment. Please confirm.”

Below that, the original thread.

Four years’ worth.

I read:

“Dear Ms. Carrow, I’m happy to continue supporting the friendship between Anna and Josh. The monthly stipend of $400 has been helpful for offsetting gas and time.”

Stipend. Supporting the friendship.

Scroll.

“Just wanted to check in about group dynamics. If you prefer he not be left out of large social events, I can encourage Anna to coordinate more with her roommates. We want to ensure continuity.”

Scroll.

“Yes, we saw the photos from the formal. He looked very happy. We’ll keep an eye on things.”

Scroll.

“Now that Josh is more established with his peer group, we could decrease payments gradually…”

Scroll.

Each email was a thread between my mother and a series of names: parents I had met at move-in day, at parents’ weekend, at the one awkward tailgate she’d flown in for. Parents of my roommates. Parents of my “best friends.” Discussing deliverables. “Including him when possible.” “Making sure he doesn’t feel alone.” “Arranging for Anna to invite him along.” A note from junior year:

“With the increased demands of their programs, we’d like to adjust to $600 to reflect time/transportation, especially with the trip to the lake. Josh has mentioned feeling on the outskirts. We’d like that improved.”

My vision blurred.

There were payment confirmations. Bank transfers. Subject lines like “September installment,” “Spring break support,” “Continuation of arrangement.”

Mom’s most recent message: “Hi all, as you know, graduation is in two weeks. Per our initial agreement, this month will conclude our support. Thank you all for your help ensuring Joshua’s college experience was positive. We couldn’t have done it without you.”

This month will conclude our support.

I laughed, a tiny, startled sound that didn’t sound like me. Then I laughed harder, until my sides hurt, until it turned into something else.

I called her back. Straight to voicemail.

I called Anna.

It rang twice, then connected. Noise in the background: a bar, clinking glasses, the murmur of a crowd.

“Hey!” she said, too bright, like she’d gulped the greeting. “What’s up?”

“Where are you?” I asked.

“Uh, just out. What’s going on?”

“Did my mom pay your mom to be my friend?”

Silence. The crowd behind her went suddenly tinny, distant.

“That’s a weird question,” she said.

“Did she?”

Static. A sigh. “Josh…”

“Just answer.”

“My mom said—” she began, stopped. “It wasn’t like that.”

“What was it like?”

“She said your mom wanted you to… have a support system. That you had a hard time in high school. It was just to, like, make sure you got included at the start. And then it was just normal. We’re friends.”

“Are we?” I asked. “You’ve ignored my texts for a week.”

“I’ve been busy,” she said, too fast. “My finals—”

“I’ve seen your stories.”

A beat. “Okay. Look, it got weird when your mom kept emailing. Like tracking stuff. Asking my mom if I could make sure you had someone to sit with, and if I could convince people to go to your improv show. I didn’t want to keep talking about you like… like a project.”

My mouth tasted like pennies. “But you took the money.”

“It was my mom’s account,” Anna said. “I didn’t—”

“But you knew.”

She exhaled. “Sophomore year, yeah. My mom told me when she wanted me to make sure you had a date to the winter formal. She said your mom was helping us out while my dad was between jobs. She said we were doing a good thing. I do care about you. But it wasn’t healthy. It’s not my job to—”

“To pretend to like me?” I said.

“That’s not fair.”

The word fair detonated in my skull. “My mom literally bought my friends.”

“Josh, I’m sorry. I have to go. We’re—everyone’s here. I didn’t expect— I’m sorry.”

She hung up.

I sat very still. The room hummed, or maybe that was me.

Pieces started clicking into place with horrible neatness.

Freshman year, when my random roommate, Ben, insisted I sit with him and his high school friends at dinner, every day, even when I’d been sure I was annoying. That time he pushed everyone to come to my birthday party after midterms, claiming “I already promised his mom we’d show up,” and everyone laughed because of course he was joking. Junior year, when my group picked the Airbnb near my hometown “so Josh’s mom can visit,” and no one complained about the drive. The frantic, panicked way my mother had always asked, “Are they good kids? Are they being kind?” with the desperation of someone monitoring an investment.

She’d ensured I was never technically alone. She’d kept every chair next to me filled.

Until she stopped paying.

I tried my dad next, forgetting for a moment that he was a ghost long before he actually left. His number was disconnected.

The evening settled around the boxes like a second skin. Outside, someone shouted. Laughter rose and scattered.

When my mother finally called back, it was dark.

“Sorry, honey,” she said. “It’s been a day. What’s wrong?”

“I saw the emails,” I said.

Silence. No feigned confusion this time. Just breath.

“Okay,” she said softly. “Okay.”

“You bought my friends.”

“No,” she said. Then, “Not exactly.”

I waited.

“I arranged,” she tried again, “for you not to be alone.”

“By paying people.”

“By helping families who were happy to encourage their children to include you,” she said. Her tone had that clipped courtroom precision she used to use before she quit practicing law. “It was mutually beneficial.”

“It was pathetic,” I said.

“For whom?” she snapped. “For them, taking money to do what decent people should do for free? Or for me, making sure my son didn’t spend four years eating alone in a dorm?”

My throat burned. “For me. You made my whole life pathetic.”

“You have always struggled socially,” she said, like reciting a diagnosis. “Not because you’re unlovable, but because you… you miss things. You don’t notice cues. You fixate. Children were cruel. High school was cruel. You begged me, sophomore year, ‘Why doesn’t anyone sit with me?’ Do you remember that?”

I did. I could still feel the cafeteria plastic under my palms.

“I swore,” she said, voice cracking, “that I would never let you go through that again if I could help it. I had resources. They had needs. Their kids had influence. I made sure you weren’t left behind.”

“At a price.”

“Yes,” she said. No hesitation now. “Love costs. I would pay it again.”

“It wasn’t love,” I said. “Not theirs.”

“It got you in the door,” she said. “The rest was up to you. And from what I saw, you laughed, you had late nights, you went on trips. Those memories are real.”

Were they? The lake, the formal, the shared exams, the nights crammed together watching movies. The time Ben stayed up all night to help me with a paper. The way Anna had once held my arm in the crowded concert, tugging me away from some guy. What percentage of each moment had been subsidized?

“I stopped payments,” she said, more quietly. “We agreed to end at graduation. You’re an adult now. You can form your own connections. And I can’t… The numbers, Josh. It was a lot.”

“How much?”

Silence.

“How much, Mom?”

Finally, she said, very small, “A little over eighty thousand. Over four years.”

It stole my breath. Eighty thousand, carved up into my text messages, my plus-ones, my nights out.

“That could have paid for grad school,” I said.

“It paid for you not being tormented,” she said. “It paid for you learning how to talk to people with some safety net. You think you didn’t grow? You did. You’re not that boy anymore.”

“Apparently I am,” I said. “They’re gone.”

“They’re moving on,” she said. “Everyone drifts after college.”

“But they really drifted right on schedule,” I said. “Almost like their contracts ended.”

She inhaled sharply. “That’s not fair.”

I laughed again, but it wasn’t funny. “Stop telling me what’s fair.”

On the other end of the line, she started crying. It startled me. My mother didn’t cry. Not when Dad left. Not when we sold the house. Not when I didn’t get into my first-choice school.

“I am so sorry,” she said. “I wanted you to have a chance. I’ve been terrified, every day, that you’d… that you’d give up. You don’t see it, but you are worth knowing. I thought if I could just get people close enough, they’d see it too.”

“Did they?” I asked.

“Yes,” she said fiercely. “Some did. Some stayed longer than the payments mattered. Some of those kids defended you when others rolled their eyes. That wasn’t me. That was you.”

“They’re not here now.”

“No,” she admitted. “They’re not.”

We sat in the static between us.

“From here on,” she said, “I won’t interfere. No more arrangements. No more… purchases. I shouldn’t have hidden it. If you never forgive me, I understand. But I refuse to believe those four years were fake.”

I thought of Ben knocking on my door the night my grandfather died, before my mom had time to email anyone. I hadn’t told her yet. He’d shown up with two milkshakes and said, “You looked weird in class, man.” He’d fallen asleep on the floor next to my bed.

Had that been bought, or…?

I pressed my palms into my eyes until colors burst.

“I don’t know what was real,” I said.

“Then start now,” my mother said. “Find out who calls when I don’t pay them to.”

“Apparently,” I said, “no one.”

“That hurts,” she said.

“Good.”

We stayed on the line. I could hear her breathing. I wondered if I’d ever see her the same way again, if she’d ever see me as something other than a crisis to manage.

Eventually, she whispered, “I love you.”

I didn’t say it back. Not because I didn’t feel it, but because love, I was realizing, is not a word you can afford to spend without knowing where it came from.

After we hung up, I opened my messages. I scrolled past the unreturned invitations, the photos with arms around shoulders. I clicked on Anna’s name.

“You don’t have to pretend anymore,” I typed. Then I deleted it.

I opened a blank message instead, addressed to no one. Then a different app. A campus group I’d seen flyers for but never joined, because I’d always been going with someone else.

“Is it okay to show up alone?” I wrote.

The reply came five minutes later, from a number I didn’t know.

“Of course. Most of us did.”

I stared at it, heartbeat loud. This wasn’t love. It wasn’t friendship. It wasn’t anything yet.

It also wasn’t bought.

I put my phone in my pocket, picked up a box, and carried it out into the hallway, where other strangers were moving, leaving, beginning.

samples.prompt: You are a guinea pig who is having an existential crisis. What is going through your head?
samples.output:
I am small. That much is certain.

Or is it?

I know the borders of my world: white bars, plastic walls, soft shavings. The steady rattle of the water bottle. The smell of hay: dry, green, safe. The huge looming shapes that bring food and hands. Always the hands.

They call me “Pumpkin.” This is supposed to be my name, but I was born without the sound “Pumpkin” inside my mind, so how can it be mine? It wraps around me from outside, high and sweet and foolishly adoring. “Pumpkin, Pumpkin, Pumpkin,” like a spell. Am I Pumpkin because they say it, or because I answer?

I didn’t always answer. At first, I was just hunger and warmth pressed against my siblings. We squeaked and tumbled, and the world was fur and milk and the rustle of straw. Then hands came, and a voice that smelled like shampoo and excitement said, “Look at this one. This one.”

This one.

I became “this one” the moment they lifted me away.

Sometimes my human presses their nose to my fur and breathes deep, like they’re trying to fill themselves with me. They say, “You’re so perfect. You’re my little potato.” Potato. Another word. Another shape they throw at me, hoping one will stick to the squirming idea of me.

Who am I inside these sounds?

I know my wants. They are clear, sharp, simple, and they arrive like alarms:
- Hay.
- Water.
- Pellets.
- Green, crunchy leaves.
- Not being alone.

I know fear. The shadow overhead. The sudden sound. The hand coming too fast. The hawk I’ve never seen but tremble for anyway. The memory in my bones from all the guinea pigs before me who ran, who hid, who did not get away. My heart rattles like the water bottle when I’m startled. Survival is loud.

But lately, between mouthfuls of hay, something else gnaws at me.

This morning, my human sat by my cage scrolling their glowing rectangle, sighing. They said, “What’s the point of anything?” and rubbed between my ears with one finger. That settled into my fur like static. What’s the point.

I know the point of chewing. Chewing keeps my teeth from growing into knives. I know the point of running laps around the cage at dusk: my legs demand to stretch; my body demands to live. But their question hung in the air, heavy as a storm. It sank into my nostrils with the smell of timothy and dust.

What is the point of Pumpkin?

I wheek and they come. That is power. I feel it. I am small, but I can summon a giant with a sound. They bring me lettuce. They bring me cucumber. They bring me carrot, though not too much because they mutter, “Sugar,” as if sweetness were a curse. They clean my cage, replace the damp bedding with fresh, soft shavings that whisper when I walk through them. They set up cardboard tunnels and crinkly paper and piles of hay like the hills I have never seen. They kiss my head. They say, “You’re worth it,” into my fur.

Worth what?

The pellet bag. The bedding. The cage. The time. The money. The sweeping of the tiny poops that fall endlessly from me, perfect and useless.

I try to understand my value. I produce nothing they can eat or wear. If I escaped to the wild, the wild would eat me. I am not strong. I am not wise in the ways beyond the bars. I’m a prey animal with a fancy water bottle.

Yet I see what happens when they watch me. Their shoulders drop. Their breathing slows. Their eyes soften. They laugh when I popcorn, when I spring straight up with joy that surprises even me. Their hand comes in careful, gentle; I feel the tremble in their fingers some nights when they think I will not notice. They bury their face in my neck and say, “You’re the only thing that makes sense, little guy.”

So I make sense.

Is that my purpose? To exist so fully and simply that it quiets the storm in a creature who thinks too much?

But here I am thinking too much.

I sit under my wooden arch, half-hidden, and listen. The refrigerator hums. A car passes outside. Voices tangle in the next room. My hay rustles as I nose deeper. Dust motes drift through the bar-light. Time moves.

I cannot see time, but I can feel it. It tastes like the difference between how it felt when my legs were always ready to sprint, and how they feel now: strong but slower to wake. It sounds like my human saying, “I can’t believe you’re already three,” with their voice cracked in the middle. It’s buried in the way the vet sometimes presses too long against my ribs and says, “He seems fine,” in a voice that worries me.

I don’t know the length of a guinea pig’s life, but my marrow does. There is a line. Somewhere ahead. I run laps along the edge of it.

What happens when the hay stops?

I try to picture it: no scent of food, no rattle of the water bottle, no clink of the cage door, no returning footsteps. Do I just... stop? Does Pumpkin unmake himself? Was there ever a self to begin with, or just a series of squeaks and chews pretending to be a single creature?

When I sleep, sometimes I dream I am many guinea pigs at once. Brown like me, white like my brother, long-haired like the one that used to be in the next cage at the place with too many lights. We run through tall grass; we are one pulse broken into a thousand prey-shaped bodies. An eagle screams and we scatter, all in the same direction, like we practiced in another life. I wake with my heart racing and my teeth grinding on nothing.

Maybe I am not just Pumpkin. Maybe I am an echo of all who came before: the wild cavies in the mountains, the ones lifted squealing from burrows, the ones who sat in laps of kings with gold collars, the ones forgotten in cages too small beside windows too cold. Perhaps every flinch at a shadow is a story I never lived, but carry anyway.

If I am made from all those fears and all those scrambles for cover, what does it mean that my world is safe? Mostly safe. The hawk cannot get in. The fox cannot smell me through the walls. My food appears as if the grass itself has decided to leap into my bowl.

Is this freedom, or a different kind of trap?

I circle the edges of my cage, nose pressed to the bars. Beyond is the forbidden land of carpet and chair legs and wires that look like vines but bite back when chewed. Sometimes they let me out into a playpen, a wider circle of fences. There are tunnels and huts and more hay. More. Always more, like they are trying to fill a hole.

I run. I leap. I chew the bars. I find every limit.

What would I do without limits?

Out there, truly out there, is sky. No ceiling. Infinite sounds, infinite smells. Grass that isn’t in a bag. Wind that hasn’t passed through a filter. But also teeth. Claws. Hunger with my shape in its center.

Am I less authentic because I am protected? Less real because my dangers have been outsourced, my choices curated? Is my contentment cheap?

But it feels real. The crunch of lettuce is real. The joy of hearing the rustle of the bag before the greens appear is real. My fear when a door slams is real. The warmth of being held—if I’m in the mood—is real enough that I sometimes let my eyes close and my body go heavy, my prey-brain whispering, “Trust, trust, trust,” from somewhere new.

I am a collision between terror and trust.

My human looks at their glowing rectangle and reads about things ending. Ice melting, forests burning, people shouting. They sigh a sound that smells like sadness. Then they look at me.

“I wish I could just be you,” they say. “You don’t worry about anything.”

How can I tell them I am entirely made of worry? That every rustle is a question, every shadow a maybe-death. I am worry shaped into fur. But I am also the proof that a small, worried heart can still eat, still explore, still popcorn in a messy cage under fluorescent lights.

Maybe that is the point.

I can’t write philosophy. My teeth aren’t good with pencils. But if I could, it might be this:

- The world is bigger than my cage. I cannot know it all.
- Fear is older than me. It hums in my bones.
- Love is newer, a strange gentleness that smells like soap and cucumber.
- I exist where fear and love intersect.

I am Pumpkin. Or whatever I am, inside the word.

I don’t know how long the hay will last, or when the hand will come and not lift me again. I don’t know if there is a meadow after this, or only the great stillness my instinct flees.

I do know this: right now, as I chew, as I feel the thrum of my own small heart against the steady, uneven thunder of the giant heart that holds me, I am here.

I am here, and it is terrifying.

I am here, and it is enough.

samples.prompt: The Grim Reaper's midlife crisis.
samples.output:
It started with the hoodie.

For millennia, the robe had been enough: the cowl, the darkness, the skeletal inevitability. The scythe was iconic. The hourglasses, the ledgers, the eternal schedule—simple, precise, unavoidable.

But one Tuesday (or what mortals called Tuesday—time, he mused, was a bit of a colonial imposition), Death stared into the black inside of his hood and felt something that disturbed him more than plague, war, and tax seasons combined.

He felt bored.

The thought arrived between appointments: a heart attack on a commuter train, a drunk driver, an aneurysm mid-conference call. Routine. Efficient. He reaped, collected, ushered souls, answered the occasional prayer with a silent no. His bony hands moved automatically, muscle memory without muscles.

He stopped, mid-harvest, in a silent hospital room where a woman exhaled her final breath. He reached—and hesitated.

“This is it?” he asked.

The woman blinked at him. “You’re… talking.”

“Apologies,” he said. “Professionalism lapse. Please come with me.”

She stared at the cloak, the bone, the hollow. “You seem tired.”

Death exhaled, out of habit. “That’s the troubling part,” he said. “I don’t get tired.”

She took his hand. “Maybe,” she said softly, “you’re having a crisis.”

The word echoed.

Crisis.

Death escorted her soul on, left her at the designated threshold, and did not go in. He lingered in the in-between, fingering the haft of his scythe, listening to the familiar cosmic hum. No one questioned him; no one ever had. Eternity’s middle manager was never scrutinized.

Yet.

He opened his ledger. The next entries stretched on, billions of names, a fine print of causes: preventable disease, stubbornness, text-while-driving. The monotony felt suddenly obscene.

He snapped the ledger shut.

Midway.

The idea arrived then: if eternity were a line—and it wasn’t, but mortals liked lines—then where was the middle? After the first star? After the first extinction? After the third apocalypse they’d quietly averted? He realized he could declare “midlife” wherever he wanted; numbers bent around him anyway.

This was the moment.

The Grim Reaper was having a midlife crisis.

He tried to dismiss it. He reaped through a stadium heart failure, a quiet hospice, a sad motel bathtub. But the feeling persisted: a strange, echoing dissatisfaction. He’d become… predictable.

He found himself, for the first time in cosmic history, calling in sick.

He invented the form on the spot. “TEMPORAL ADJUSTMENT REQUEST.” Reason: “Professional existential fatigue.” Duration: “Undetermined. Probably brief. Hopefully.”

The form approved itself, which struck him as suspicious, but he took the win.

Mortals didn’t immediately notice. The universe, however, did. In the control room where probability and causality intertwined, a pale receptionist looked up.

“He actually did it,” she murmured.

“Did what?” asked Fate, not looking up from her threads.

“Filed time off.”

Fate frowned. “He doesn’t do that.”

“He did.”

Fate sighed and began rearranging strands, cursing softly.

Down in the mortal realm, Death decided to try… hobbies.

He started with a motorcycle.

It was a black Harley, obviously. He didn’t technically need it; he could appear anywhere, anytime, with a thought. But he wanted it. There was something about the roar, the defiant human need to strap explosions to metal and sit on it.

He appeared in a desert at dawn, the sky bleeding pink. The bike shimmered into existence at his side, flawless and clichéd.

He swung a leg over, bony foot on the peg, and realized with faint irritation that his robe tangled in the chain.

“Of course,” he muttered.

An hour later, he’d shortened the robe, ditched the trailing hems. The scythe he telescoped down into something sleeker, staff-like, purely symbolic. He summoned a helmet, looked at its glossy reflection, and saw nothing, as usual.

“Age is just a number,” he told the empty visor. “Mine happens to be all of them.”

He took off across the desert. Sand sprayed. The engine howled. For a few bright, burning minutes, he felt something like almost-joy.

Then a jackrabbit dashed in front of him and died of fright.

The soul materialized, glared up at him. “Seriously?”

Death groaned.

He hadn’t stopped working. Even on vacation, things died around him. The midlife crisis, he realized, came with no benefits package.

Next, he tried therapy.

The therapist he chose was already very good at untangling mortal neuroses and had, crucially, about three minutes left to live. Death appeared in the chair opposite as the man clutched his chest.

“Before you go,” Death said, “professional consult?”

The therapist, halfway out of his body, blinked. “I’m… dead?”

“Almost. Quick question: what if one’s purpose begins to feel… meaningless?”

The therapist peered at him, curiosity overriding panic. “Tell me about your work.”

“I end all life,” Death said.

Silence.

“That sounds… important,” the therapist said carefully. “How long have you been doing it?”

“Yes.”

“Right.” He rubbed his chin. “Burnout is common among caregivers.”

“I am not burning,” Death protested.

“It’s metaphorical.”

“Mortals and their metaphors,” Death muttered. “I shepherd them. I maintain balance. Without me, chaos.”

“And do you want to stop?”

Death hesitated. It was the question he had not let surface.

“I don’t know how,” he admitted. “I don’t know who I am if I’m not… this.”

The therapist gave him a look of startled sympathy. “Sounds like a midlife crisis to me.”

“Define life,” Death said.

“Existence, then. You’ve reached a point where your old patterns can’t carry the weight of your awareness. You crave novelty, meaning, maybe autonomy.”

Death stared. “I hate that this is helping.”

The therapist smiled faintly. “Try something radically different. Within reason.” His heart stuttered. “Time’s up for me, I guess.”

“Oh. Yes.” Death rose, gently lifted the man’s soul. “Thank you.”

“Maybe,” the therapist added, already fading onward, “learn to say no.”

No.

The word lingered.

He tried it first with War.

War called him beside a smoking field, delighted as ever, cheeks flushed, armor wet. “So many,” War said. “You’re busy today.”

“No,” Death said.

War blinked. “What?”

“I’m not cleaning this up,” Death said. “Stop making messes to feel important.”

War laughed. “That’s your role.”

“No,” Death repeated. “It’s my job. Might not be my role.”

He didn’t stop the dying—mortals were quite capable on their own—but he refused War the thrill of companionship. War raged, but he walked away.

Next came Pestilence, then Greed, then the tiny, frantic gods of Algorithm and Content Creation, all counting on him to add gravitas. To each, he gave some version of no. Not a dereliction—deaths still occurred—but he withdrew the theatrics.

He started arriving without fanfare, without looming, without the damn cloak sometimes. To the surprise of many, he could look like anything. He experimented:

- A tired nurse at a bedside.
- A receptionist calling a final name.
- A child’s hand reaching for a grandfather’s.
- A soft-eyed woman on an empty bus seat.

People rarely noticed. People see what they expect.

The midlife crisis shifted. Less about escape, more about subversion. If he couldn’t quit, perhaps he could redefine.

He visited a neonatal ICU and, for once, broke protocol. He stood invisible as the tiny chest rose and fell with difficulty. He checked the ledger: scheduled to die in eleven minutes.

He watched the parents’ hands, small and trembling, hovering over the incubator. He felt that faint, treacherous stirring again.

No, he thought.

Nothing cosmic exploded. No laws shattered. Probability shrieked, recalculated, sulked. Fate’s threads tangled; she swore, then adjusted.

The baby’s lungs caught. The next breath was stronger.

The ledger line flickered, updated: ninety-three years, two cats, a tendency toward late-night snacks, significant but quiet kindness.

Death exhaled. “Interesting.”

He did not abuse it. That was not his crisis. He was not going to become Mercy; Mercy already existed and wrote him long, disappointed notes on stationery that smelled like rain. But occasionally—strategically—he said no.

He took a pottery class.

The instructor did not question the tall, silent figure in black at the wheel. Clay slapped, spun, wobbled. Death’s skeletal fingers were too precise; the bowl was perfect, soulless.

“Loosen up,” the instructor said.

“I literally cannot,” Death said.

He tried again, deliberately flawed the rim. The imperfection was… pleasant. Human.

He left with a lopsided mug that would never hold liquid. He put it on his cosmic desk next to the hourglasses. It made no sense. He loved it.

At some point, Management called.

Management was not a bearded man in the sky, nor a flaming wheel, nor a board of robed elders. Management was a voice that was also a silence, the organizing principle that let atoms agree to exist.

“You are adjusting parameters,” Management said, in every language at once.

“Yes,” Death said. He sat straighter. Crisis or not, he wasn’t a coward.

“Rationale.”

“I am not a malfunction,” Death said. “But I am no longer satisfied as a passive mechanism. I request… creative discretion. Within the bounds of equilibrium. I understand the stakes. I am the stakes.”

Silence stretched.

“You fear obsolescence,” Management said eventually. “Entropy accelerates without form. You are form.”

“I am asking,” Death said carefully, “to be less of a scarecrow and more of a gardener.”

Another long silence.

“Approved,” said Management.

Just like that.

Not infinite power. Not veto over all endings. But a sanctioned margin for judgment, for nuance: mercy here, firmness there, a little more presence, a little less spectacle.

His midlife crisis did not end with fireworks. He did not buy a sports car—motorcycle was enough. He did not run away with a mortal poet, though two offered. He did not grow hair.

Instead, he changed the terms of his service.

He retired the exaggerated scythe for daily use, reserving it for special occasions. He kept the robe—it was classic—but varied its form. He visited dying people who were afraid and let them see him as something kinder.

He still came for kings and killers, infants and ancients, all without favoritism. But sometimes, when he saw a ledger line that could bend without breaking the whole, he nudged.

In a way, the midlife crisis had given him what millennia of blind duty had not: a sense of self not entirely defined by everyone else’s ending.

On another almost-Tuesday, a boy on a balcony leaned a little too far over. For a moment, wind took him.

Death was there. He saw the path: a fall, a scream, a shattered family.

No, he thought.

A gust pushed the boy backward instead. The boy stumbled, laughed, went inside.

The ledger shivered, adjusted.

Death stood alone under the open sky, robe stirring.

Once, that would have felt like rebellion. Now, it felt like work.

Real work.

He smiled, though no one could see it.

If this was a midlife crisis, he thought, mortals really ought to give themselves more credit.

They had no idea how hard it was to keep doing the same impossible job—

—and choose, halfway through eternity, to do it better.

samples.prompt: You dream every night of being part of a wolf pack and terrorizing villagers in the country side, every morning you wake up in your bed. One evening there's a knock at the door, a dark figure clad in a wide brimmed hat and leather trench coat stands on your door step.
samples.output:
The knocking comes at twilight, just as the sky bruises purple and the air outside curdles with mist. You are in the kitchen staring at your own hands, the way you do every evening now, searching your nails for crescents of dirt, for blood that won’t wash away. They’re clean, as always. They’re shaking, as always.

The third knock is more insistent.

You move down the hallway, each step an echo. Your heart beats too fast for the slow pace of your feet. You don’t look through the peephole. You don’t call out. You already know someone will be there.

You open the door.

He’s taller than the frame, or seems so. A wide-brimmed hat casts his face in a darkness that somehow feels thicker than the failing daylight. The leather trench coat he wears gleams dully, wet in places with mist or rain or something else. One gloved hand rests on the knob of a cane; the other holds the brim of his hat like he might tip it in greeting at any second, though he doesn’t.

You catch his smell.

Horse, ash, cold iron. Underneath, the sour tang of wolfsbane.

Your stomach flips.

“Good evening,” he says. His voice is low, smooth, strained against some tight rein of discipline. It’s a voice used to holding itself together. “May I come in?”

Your first instinct is to slam the door. Your second is to drop to all fours and tear his throat out with teeth you do not have. Instead, you just stand there, the frame of the door bisecting your life into Before and After.

“You have the wrong house,” you say, but it comes out uncertain.

He breathes in, a slow, deliberate inhalation. It feels like he’s rifling through your secrets.

“No,” he says simply.

You haven’t dreamed yet tonight, but your bones ache like you’ve spent hours running. You know what the villagers in your dreams smell like when they scream. You know the awful weight of impact when you hit a running man from the side and feel ribs concertina under your claws. You know the sound it makes when your packmate’s jaws close on a woman’s throat in mid-sob.

And you know, with a clarity that’s been growing like mold for weeks, that these are not dreams.

You step back, and he takes that as invitation. He crosses the threshold without brushing against you. The room seems to tighten around him, like the walls are wary too.

“Nice place,” he offers absently, casting a glance around: the couch where you fall asleep exhausted and wake refreshed; the bookshelf with spines cracked by hands that, in the dark, are buried to the wrist in fur; a framed photograph of your parents who live two towns over and call you every Sunday, unaware.

“Who are you?” you ask.

The man removes his hat. His face is pale and cut with lines that look less like age and more like knife marks of hard experience. His hair is dark with threads of gray at the temples; his eyes are a washed-out blue that’s seen worse things than you’d like to imagine. He sets the hat carefully on the hall table, like he doesn’t intend to stay long enough to forget it.

“My name is Elias Varrow,” he says. “I hunt monsters.”

The word lands in the room and sits there. You swallow.

“You have the wrong—”

“I do not,” he says, and you’re struck by how tired his interruption sounds. “Please don’t insult either of us. Sit down.”

There’s something you recognize in him, not his face, not his scent, but his certainty. The same way you can feel your pack miles away, a shared awareness humming under your skin. He radiates a purpose that has never once been in doubt.

You sit.

Elias remains standing. The coat doesn’t creak; it whispers. He looks at your hands. You tuck them under your thighs.

“How much do you remember?” he asks.

“From my dreams?” you ask.

“One word for it,” he says.

You close your eyes, just for a heartbeat, and the images are immediate.

The first night: you woke panting, heart pounding, legs sore as if you’d run a marathon. You remembered the oddly keen taste of sheep’s blood, the hot wetness between your teeth, the lantern light bobbing frantically on the hill. You laughed it off: vivid dream. You work too hard. You watch too many shows.

The second week: you knew neighbors by their screams in the dark before you met them in the market. You’d see a man buying apples and recall how he fell to his knees in the field, how his scream cut short wetly. You shook his hand when he introduced himself and your skin crawled with recognition.

The second month: you stopped going out at night. Not out of fear of monsters, but fear of recognition. You kept a log of your dreams: dates, places, faces. You mapped them. The red pins on the paper began to draw shapes too precise for coincidence.

A news story: “Unexplained Animal Attacks Ravage Rural Community.” A grainy photo: a farmhouse you’d torn through in your “dream” two nights prior. You watched that segment with numb, ice water veins.

You look up at Elias. “I remember all of it.”

He nods once like that’s the answer he expected and maybe dreaded. “Good. That saves time.”

He reaches into his coat slowly, carefully, like a man used to being watched by dangerous things. He sets three items on your coffee table.

A silver bullet. It’s scratched and darkened, as if it’s been handled, hurled, dropped, pocketed, carried through years.

A small, worn photograph, edges frayed.

A tuft of coarse, grayish fur bound with red thread.

The hairs along your arms lift. Your mouth is dry.

“I’m not—” you start.

“Human?” he says. “You are. And you aren’t.” He taps the tuft of fur. “Tell me what this is.”

You don’t want to. The answer is waiting on your tongue like a taste.

“Beta,” you say slowly. “Left flank. Runs with his head lower than the rest. Scars on the shoulder from barbed wire last winter.”

The room seems to dip. The coffee table is just cheap wood, but your fingers flex against your knees as if you could rake right through it.

“How do you know that?” Elias asks.

“I… I see him,” you say. “When I sleep.”

He gestures at the bullet. “This went through his leg three nights ago. He shouldn’t be running. He is. Because when you wake up here… you leave it behind. The damage. Your pack heals. Starts fresh. You don’t carry their wounds. They don’t carry your conscience.”

You stare at him. “You’re insane.”

“Possibly,” he says. “But I’m not wrong. You don’t change, do you? No hair on the sheets, no blood in your teeth. No mud under your nails. You wake clean. Every time.”

“They’re just dreams,” you insist, weakly.

He picks up the photograph and offers it to you. A family of four stands in front of a stone house, all smiling, sunlight bright. It’s a house you know intimately from the inside: the smell of yeast and stew, the rough wool coat on the peg by the door, the taste of the older son’s arm when he tried to fight you.

Your hand jerks away from the photo as if it burned you.

“They’re dead,” Elias says softly. “All four. Three weeks ago. Same night you ‘dreamed’ of a stone house and a woman with a braid down her back who ran for the stairs.”

Your breath stutters.

He watches you and there’s no gloating, no triumph. Only confirmation, and grief that’s been worn thin by repetition.

“What are you?” you whisper.

“A man doing a job,” he says. “What are you is the better question.”

You look at your hands again. They’re shaking so badly now you have to press them together.

“They chose you,” Elias says. “Or something using them did. A tether. Sleep is when we’re unguarded. Doors unlocked. For months now, when you lie here, some part of you doesn’t stay. Some part of you rides along with the pack. Not in body. In will. In hunger. You give them mind. Strategy. Malice. They were just beasts once. Crude, easy to predict. Now they’re coordinated. Efficient. Cruel.”

“No,” you say, but there’s a sob under it.

“You know their names,” he says. “Or the shape of them. Their hierarchy. You dream in their perspective. But you never wake with so much as a splinter. A perfect conductor.”

He leans in. You smell the wolfsbane stronger now, and something else: righteous exhaustion.

“I’ve hunted wolves and their half-born kin for twenty years. I’ve seen curses, infections, pacts. But you…” He tilts his head. “You’re new.”

You try to stand. Your legs tremble. “Get out of my house.”

Elias doesn’t move.

“Tonight,” he says, “you would sleep. And they would hunt. Four miles north, there is a village preparing for a funeral. They light candles. They pray. They load rifles that won’t matter. The pack is circling. You can feel it already, can’t you? That itching under your skin?”

You can. His words drag your awareness outward: to the tree line, to the damp earth cooling under the fading sun, to the steady, eager breathing of others in the dark. Your chest tightens in echo.

“I have tracked them as far as I can,” Elias says. “Bullets slow them. Traps catch them. They adapt between nights. Like someone is teaching them. And every time I get close, they change their pattern as if they knew my maps.”

Your maps pinned to your bedroom wall.

“I didn’t know,” you whisper.

“You do now.”

He straightens, as if arriving at some inner deadline. “I came to give you a choice.”

The word hangs there.

“Choice,” you repeat. “What choice?”

His gaze is steady. “You let me end it. Clean. Quick. Before dark. Before you sleep again. Before you help them kill anyone else.”

The meaning bores into you like a drill. “You’re here to kill me.”

He doesn’t nod. He doesn’t have to.

Your pulse becomes a trapped bird in your throat. “And if I don’t let you?”

He exhales slowly. “Then I do it the hard way. And people die while we struggle. I’m very good. But they’re very hungry. And you are… valuable to them.”

“I haven’t done anything,” you say, but the words are thin.

Elias looks at you with a tired compassion that is somehow worse than anger. “Tell me that when you close your eyes and smell smoke from that village.”

Images rush you: the slope of a thatched roof; the shrill cry of a child; the pack fanning out exactly where the alleys bottleneck.

You gag.

“There has to be another way,” you say. “Block it. Banish it. Hypnosis. Whatever. You’re the monster hunter. Hunt the monster, not me.”

He is quiet for a time. Outside, the deepening dusk presses at the window. You feel the pack stir, a distant flex of attention. They are restless tonight. Hungry. They taste something on the air.

“I don’t know another way,” Elias says. The honesty cuts. “You are the open door. I close doors.”

“You’re supposed to save people,” you say.

“I am,” he says softly. “Starting with them.”

Silence pools.

You look at the photograph again. At the bullet. At the tuft of fur.

“Please,” you say, though you’re not sure to whom.

Elias reaches into his coat once more and draws out a small vial filled with something like ink that shimmers wrong, congested starlight. “There is… one thing I can try,” he says reluctantly. “Never used. Not tested. You’d wish for death if it goes badly. Might tear you loose. Might tear you apart.”

“Do it,” you say.

His brows lift. “You accept without asking terms.”

“I’m already killing people,” you say. “I just get to stay clean. That ends. One way or another.”

For the first time, a flicker of respect touches his features.

He kneels in front of you, close enough that you can see the fine silver scars at his throat. He uncorks the vial. The scent that spills out is like burned herbs and cold air over graves.

“This will hurt,” he says.

You laugh once, sharp. “Good.”

He presses his thumb to the liquid, then to your forehead. It burns like acid, like molten metal being written into your skin. You scream, clutching the couch, the world spinning.

He speaks in a language that tastes like iron filings. Your veins light up with ice and fire. The pack roars against your spine. You feel them—snarling, outraged, the tether yanking taut.

You are standing at the edge of a forest under a full moon, muscles bunched, lungs full of damp rot. Your brothers and sisters surge around you, teeth bared. In the far distance, a church bell tolls. You raise your head to howl—

And something snaps.

Pain like a thunderclap. White light. The world whirls inside out.

You slam back into your own body on the couch. You are drenched in sweat. Your throat is raw. The mark on your forehead sears and then cools.

Elias is on one knee, braced, breathing hard as if he’s run a long way.

“Are you…?” he starts.

You reach outward with that sense you’ve come to dread.

There is only you.

No wild chorus. No shared hunger. Just a hollow space where something terrible used to breathe.

Your tears come hot and sudden. “They’re gone,” you whisper. “I can’t feel them.”

Elias closes his eyes in something like relief. “Good.”

Then, distant but clear, a howl splits the night.

Your head snaps toward the sound. It is feral, directionless, uncoordinated. Another answers. Another. A multitude, but scattered, jagged, overlapping without pattern.

“They’re still out there,” you say.

“Yes,” Elias says, pushing himself to his feet. “But now they’re only wolves again.”

He picks up the silver bullet and pockets it. Leaves the photograph on the table.

“At least,” he adds, looking at you with a shadow of warning, “I think you’re loose. If you dream tonight, write it down. If you feel them again, call this number.” He slides a card toward you.

You stare at it without picking it up. “What if it didn’t work?” you ask.

“Then I’d already be dead,” he says. “They’d have come through you the moment the tether strained. They didn’t.”

The howl comes again, fainter.

Elias sets his hat back on. At the door, he pauses. “Sleep with the lights on if it helps,” he says. “But you should sleep. You’ll need your strength. Guilt is heavier than any curse.”

He steps out into the thickening dark.

You close the door slowly, your hand hovering over the lock before turning it. The house is suddenly very quiet.

Later, you lie in bed, staring at the ceiling. For the first time in months, you are afraid to fall asleep not because of what you’ll do, but because of what you won’t see.

Eventually, exhaustion drags you under.

You dream of nothing at all.

samples.prompt: Your daughter grew a pair of horns. You have no idea why or how.
samples.output:
The first time I noticed them, I thought they were ponytails.

It was a Tuesday, one of those colorless mornings when the sky hangs low and everything feels unsharpened. I was hunched over the sink, rinsing cereal bowls, while Emma sat at the table, bent over her tablet. Eleven years old, all elbows and questions, her hair sticking up in tufts where she’d slept on it wrong.

“Braid?” I asked, already reaching for the brush.

She didn’t look up. “No. Hurts.”

“You slept on it funny,” I said. “Has to be tamed.”

“It’s not my hair,” she muttered.

I didn’t catch that at first. I circled the table, brush in hand, and then I saw them.

At her temples, parting the brown waves, two pale ridges rose from her scalp, each about an inch high. Not red, not irritated. Just… there. Like the beginnings of something that had been waiting under the skin and had finally grown tired of waiting.

“Hold still,” I said, my voice too light. “You’ve, uh, got something.”

Emma flinched away. “Don’t touch them.”

I stopped. The brush felt absurd in my hand.

“Sweetie,” I said. “Did you… bump your head?”

“No.”

“Does it hurt?”

She shrugged, eyes still on the tablet. The nonchalance was theatrical. That was how I knew she was scared.

I set the brush down. “Can I please look?”

She hesitated, then tilted her head so the morning light caught her hair. I parted it gently.

They weren’t bruises. They weren’t bug bites, or cuts, or scabs. The skin was stretched smooth over something hard beneath, like knuckles pressing from the wrong side. Tiny veins spidered faintly around them, as if her body was quietly rearranging its blueprints.

I told myself: bone spurs. Some weird calcium thing. Growth plates. Words that meant nothing except That’s explainable.

“It’s probably nothing,” I lied. “We’ll make a doctor’s appointment.”

Emma pulled away. “Don’t tell anyone,” she said sharply. “Please, Mom.”

The “Mom” landed like a weight. She only used it like that when she was serious.

“I have to tell the doctor,” I said.

She chewed her lip. “Just you and the doctor, then.”

“Just us,” I promised, before thinking about what that meant.

At work, I couldn’t focus. My colleagues were talking sales numbers; I was googling “child skull lumps sudden” under the desk. Tumors, cysts, dermoid this, osteo that. None of the images looked like what I’d seen. None of them came with the quiet symmetry, the eerie suggestion of intent.

By the time I got through to the pediatrician, the earliest appointment was Friday.

“If she has a fever or it’s painful or changes color—” the nurse began.

“They’re growing,” I said.

A pause. “Growing what?”

“Just… growing.”

“We’ll see her Friday,” she repeated.

That night, I went into Emma’s room twice after she’d fallen asleep.

The first time, I just watched her. The glow-in-the-dark stars on her ceiling were peeling at the edges. Her stuffed rabbit—once white, now a dignified gray—lay under her arm. She slept with her mouth slightly open, the same way she had as a baby. A lock of hair had fallen back, exposing one of the bumps. It seemed larger in the dim light.

The second time, around two in the morning, I brought a flashlight. I don’t know what I was expecting—the dramatic surge of a fairy tale curse, a pair of gleaming horns sprung up between bedtime and now. Instead, it was incremental: they were maybe a millimeter higher, the skin a touch more stretched.

When the light hit her face, she stirred. “Mom?”

“It’s me,” I whispered. “Go back to sleep.”

Her hand shot up and covered one horn. “Stop looking,” she mumbled, already half under again.

“I’m just…” I began, but she was gone.

By Friday, they were unmistakable.

They’d pushed fully through the skin, two smooth, curved nubs no longer pretending to be anything else. Yellowish at the base, darkening toward the tips. Not long—just over an inch and a half—but undeniably horns. Her hair couldn’t hide them anymore; it clung around them awkwardly, as if embarrassed.

The pediatrician, Dr. Kline, was a man who’d been practicing long enough to see everything twice. He peered at Emma over his glasses, then examined her scalp in silence.

“Huh,” he said.

“Huh?” I repeated. “What is ‘huh’?”

“They’re…” He prodded gently. Emma flinched. “Tender?”

“A little,” she said.

“Hardened,” he murmured. “Attached to the skull, it seems. Not inflamed. No discharge.” He straightened. “We’ll do some imaging.”

“But what are they?” I asked.

“Let’s rule things out.” Doctor voice. Noncommittal.

The X-ray tech didn’t manage to keep a neutral face. On the images, the horns were bright white, sprouting elegantly from her frontal bone, like they’d been drawn there on purpose.

“Congenital anomaly of bone growth,” the report said, but there was no comfort in the words. Congenital meant “from birth,” and these hadn’t been here last month. Anomaly meant “we don’t know.” Bone growth meant “this is real.”

At home, Emma locked herself in the bathroom for half an hour. When she came out, she wore a knitted hat pulled down low.

“It’s not that cold,” I said.

“I like hats,” she replied, and went to her room.

The school called on Monday.

“We noticed Emma’s new… fashion choice,” the counselor said over the phone. “Hats aren’t usually allowed, but we can make an exception if there’s a medical reason.”

“There is,” I said.

“We’ll need a note.”

“I’ll get you a note.”

“And, ah,” the counselor added, lowering her voice as if the horns themselves might be listening, “some students said they saw something under the hat on the playground. There were some comments. One boy called her—”

“I know what he called her,” I snapped. Emma had come home with red eyes and a busted lip.

“We’re addressing it,” the counselor said quickly. “We have a zero-tolerance policy for bullying.”

Policies are impressive on paper and useless on asphalt. I thanked her anyway.

That night, I knocked on Emma’s door.

“Go away,” she said.

I opened it anyway.

She sat cross-legged on her bed, hat off, phone face-down beside her. The horns had grown again, another inch. They curved slightly backward now, like question marks.

“They’re hideous,” she said. No hello.

“They’re not,” I answered automatically.

She glared at me, and for a split second I saw what they saw at school: a small girl with horns, eyes bright with something fierce and wounded.

“Kids are calling me demon,” she said. “Devil girl. One of them tried to snap one off.”

I sat down beside her. “Did they hurt you?”

“Not really. I head-butted him,” she said. A flicker of satisfaction crossed her face. “He cried. They’re sharp.”

“You can’t—”

“He touched me first,” she snapped.

Fair point, I thought. Aloud, I said, “We’ll talk to the school again.”

She picked up the rabbit by one limp ear and turned it in her hands. “Why is this happening?”

“I don’t know,” I said.

“You’re supposed to know,” she whispered.

I wanted to make up something beautiful. An old story about our ancestors, a secret bloodline, a gift. I wanted to say, “You’re special,” and have it mean empowerment rather than exile.

Instead I said, “Sometimes bodies do strange things.”

“That’s a stupid answer.”

“I know.”

She was quiet. “Are you scared of me?” she asked.

The question hit harder than any X-ray image.

“No,” I said, immediately, and meant it. “I am scared for you. That’s different.”

She leaned into me then, carefully, horns grazing my collarbone. Hard, warm, real. I wrapped my arms around her and thought, Mine.

The doctors referred us to specialists. The specialists referred us to other specialists. Physical anthropologists, geneticists, an endocrinologist who requested blood for research and spoke in acronyms. No one said the word “horns” without a little stutter.

“We are observing an unprecedented ossification pattern,” one of them said finally. “It doesn’t match any known pathology.”

“So what does that mean?” I asked.

He smiled that tight academic smile. “It means we don’t know.”

They tested my blood, her father’s. They mapped chromosomes like star charts. Everything came back blandly normal.

At home, the horns continued to grow.

By winter, they were five inches long and gracefully curved, dark as polished walnut. She could no longer hide them under hats. We tried hoodies, headbands, strategic hairstyles. It didn’t matter. They were the first thing anyone saw.

Strangers stared in the grocery store. One woman crossed herself. A man in the parking lot said, “Is this some TikTok thing?” and reached out like he had the right to touch my child.

“Don’t,” I said, stepping between them, voice low enough to startle us both.

Emma’s shoulders had tensed, her hands curling into fists. She walked three steps ahead of me from then on.

At night, she began to spend more time on her phone. I worried she was doom-scrolling, collecting every myth about horned demons and cursed children, seeing herself reflected only in what terrified others.

But one evening she came to me with the screen lit up.

“Look,” she said.

It was an article about animals with horns. Antelopes, goats, gazelles. Close-up pictures of keratin-sheathed bone spirals, elegant and unapologetic.

“They’re beautiful,” she said.

“So are you,” I answered.

“I don’t feel beautiful.”

“I know.”

A pause.

“Will you braid around them?” she asked.

I blinked. “Around…?”

“My hair. So they look like they’re supposed to be there. Not like a mistake.”

Relief—sharp, unexpected—rose in my chest.

“Of course,” I said.

I stood behind her at the bathroom mirror, fingers working clumsily at first. The horns were solid under my hands, warm where they met her skin. I wove her hair around their bases, spiraling, framing. They changed the architecture of her face, catching the light in strange new ways. She watched me in the mirror, searching for a flinch that never came.

“There,” I said.

She tilted her head, examining herself. Something like curiosity, fragile but real, crept into her expression.

“I look… kind of cool,” she said.

“You look like Emma,” I replied. “Who has horns.”

“Will they stop?” she asked.

“I don’t know.”

“If they don’t, will you still…” She trailed off.

“Still what?”

“Still act like I’m just me.”

I met her eyes in the mirror. “There has never been ‘just’ you,” I said. “But yes. Always.”

The world did not rearrange itself overnight to make space for her. Some kids kept their distance. Some didn’t. A girl in her class, Molly, told her they looked “metal,” which was apparently a high compliment. The school counselor invited her to talk; Emma declined. We got used to curious glances, rude whispers, kind ones too.

The horns kept growing, but more slowly. By the time she turned twelve, they’d reached seven inches, dark and smooth, arcing back like a wild ram’s, but delicate, scaled to her. She decorated them sometimes—with rings, with thread, with small plastic flowers she pretended to hate and never took off.

We never got an answer that fit neatly into medical language.

So instead, we made our own.

On the night before her first day of seventh grade, she stood in the hallway, backpack on, testing the weight of it.

“I look weird,” she said.

“Everyone in seventh grade looks weird,” I told her. “You’re just honest about it.”

She snorted. “You’re so lame.”

I bowed, as if accepting a royal decree. One of her horns clipped the doorframe with a hollow knock.

“Ow,” she said, rubbing the base.

“Careful,” I said. “Those doors are fragile.”

She rolled her eyes, but she smiled.

That’s the thing they don’t tell you: sometimes the impossible arrives quietly at your kitchen table, between cereal and school, and proceeds to integrate itself into orthodontist appointments and math homework. You expect prophecy or panic. What you get is laundry, late buses, insurance forms, the simple grind of days that must be lived anyway.

And in the middle of it, your daughter grows a pair of horns.

You do not know why or how.

You only know this: when she leans into you, they press into your chest, solid as anything you’ve ever loved, and you wrap your arms around her and hold on.

samples.prompt: You and 49 others wake up in a weird room. An automated message then begins playing: "For the next 50 years, you will race one another. You have been modified to remain ever youthful. Whoever gets to a checkpoint last is killed. You can use any means to get there. Your first checkpoint? Mars."
samples.output:
There is no sky, only a ceiling painted the color of one. It fools my eyes for three seconds, long enough for hope to stir, then the speakers crackle to life.

“For the next fifty years, you will race one another. You have been modified to remain ever youthful. Whoever gets to a checkpoint last is killed. You can use any means to get there. Your first checkpoint? Mars.”

No voice. Just that cold, clean automation. A hum follows, like distant turbines spooling up.
