Around me: forty-nine strangers in gray jumpsuits, sitting up on narrow cots arranged in a circle. Some gasp. One woman laughs, a short deranged bark. A guy with a shaved head mutters, “What the—” and doesn’t finish.

My heart should be hammering at my ribs, but it isn’t. I realize I’m… steady. There’s a clarity in my vision, a sharpness in sound. I can count individual eyelashes of the man across from me. I can hear his pulse.

“You have ten minutes,” the automated voice adds. “Then the room opens. The last person to set foot outside will be eliminated.”

Then silence. Ten minutes to process that youth is no longer a blessing but the stage they’ll watch us suffer on.

The countdown appears on one blank wall, shimmering: 10:00.

Chaos, of course.

“Okay, Mars?” someone shouts. “That’s not even— how are we—”

“A rocket,” a woman near me says quickly. Taller than me, hair in tight braids, eyes already scanning. “Or a space elevator. A shuttle. Whatever this is, there’s infrastructure. There has to be.”

“We’re lab rats,” another says. “Experiments. They want a show.”

I swing my legs off the cot. My body feels wrong—too perfect. No stiffness. No pins and needles. I remember being thirty-eight last week, with an ache in my left knee. The ache is gone.

Driver’s license age: thirty-eight. Body age: twenty-five. Eyes: predator.

If they want a show, they’ve tuned me up for it.

“Any means,” I say. “So anything counts. Stealing, sabotage, killing.”

Nobody corrects me.

“Ten minutes,” the braided woman says. “No one wants to be last out that door.”

Our eyes track together to the countdown. 8:42.

The guy with the shaved head bolts first, sprinting for one of the seamless walls as if it might open early. It doesn’t. He slams his hands against the smooth surface, curses.

“Hey.” A soft voice at my elbow. A small woman with round glasses that somehow survived whatever brought us here. “You seem calm.”

“That worries you?” I ask.

“That suggests you’re thinking instead of panicking,” she says. “I’m Lena.”

“Arun.”

“We can’t get to Mars alone,” she says, low and fast. “Not realistically. Whatever’s waiting out there, we’ll need allies. Temporary ones.”

A different voice—male, deep, clipped, like someone who’s practiced command: “We organize. Now.”

He stands in the middle of the circle without asking permission. Square shoulders, military posture.

“We don’t have time for speeches,” someone snaps.

“We have eight minutes,” the man says. “We use them or die stupider. My name’s Cole. This is a race, not a lottery. ‘Any means’ doesn’t mean ‘no plan.’ First rule: no one is last out the door. We don’t start by sacrificing someone easy.”

“Why not?” another voice asks from the far end. Lanky, younger, eyes sharp in an uglier way. “Why not reduce the field?”

“If we start killing in here,” Cole says, “we waste time and their cameras get a bloodbath for free. And anyone who moves to be last will tell us what kind of person they are.”

He’s right. Ninety percent of us don’t want to be first person to cross whatever line aloud.

“Seven minutes,” the room whispers.

We gravitate toward leaders like gravity: Cole, me, Lena, the braided woman who’s already checking seams and vents. Splinters begin: a cluster around the lanky predator, whispers and narrowed eyes; another around a woman with corporate polish, calculating.

“Assume there’s transport,” Lena says to me, quick. “We need to be first to claim it, or good enough to take it from whoever is. That means we leave immediately, we scout fast, and we don’t trust anyone who says ‘I’ll catch up.’”

“Assume the modifications include vacuum tolerance?” I suggest.

She grimaces. “Not full. They said ‘ever youthful,’ not ‘unbreakable.’”

“Three minutes,” the wall says.

No water is offered, no food, no instructions on gravity wells and orbital mechanics. Whoever set this up knows the same thing I’m starting to understand: the race’s first checkpoint isn’t Mars.

It’s our willingness to run.

At one minute, the walls hiss.

A seam appears, widening into a doorway flooded with white light. Beyond it, just a corridor.

“Last one out dies,” the voice reminds, as pleasantly as a flight attendant.

Fifty people eye one another, counting. Nobody moves at first, not wanting to be the point of the spear. Then lanky predator sprints, laughing, and that breaks it. We surge.

I’m not the fastest but I’m not slow. We funnel through, elbows and shoulders colliding, a ragged, animal force. Someone stumbles; two hands grab them and haul them forward. Not today, not last.

As my bare feet hit the threshold, I hear a single high-pitched whine from behind us. A scream, cut almost instantly short. I don’t look back. No one does.

We’re in a launch facility.

Massive windows reveal an impossible landscape: a desert, red-gold under a pale sun, broken by gleaming structures and—farther out—a vertical needle of metal streaking into the blue that pretends not to be painted. The air tastes faintly of ozone and antiseptic. Gravity feels Earth-normal.

A central atrium opens ahead with branching tunnels. Above us, drones the size of dogs float silently, lenses whirring. Watching.

On a balcony, a projection flickers to life. Not a person. An abstract icon that shifts gently, soothingly.

“Checkpoint One: Mars,” it says. “There are multiple viable routes. Resources are limited. Assistance will be granted in exchange for performance, entertainment, and innovation. Begin.”

Doors slide open around the atrium:

- One leads to a hangar with three sleek rockets, small, clearly not enough capacity for forty-nine people.
- Another: a room labeled TRAINING AND MODIFICATION.
- Another: ENGINEERING ACCESS.
- A fourth: ARCHIVE.

Choices. Beautiful, terrible choices.

Cole calls, “We prioritize transport. We take a rocket, we staff it with the best.”

“‘We’?” Corporate woman sneers. “You the president now?”

“Stop,” Lena says, voice sharp. “Listen. There’s no way they made this a single solution. That’d be boring. Different vectors: rocket, orbital elevator, maybe something exotic. There will be traps. We split smart. Small teams. Each finds a path.”

“And whoever falls behind dies,” lanky predator says, grinning. “Better odds for the rest of us.”

He heads for the rockets with five others, already jostling for position. Cole and a cluster of muscle follow. Corporate woman peels off toward the Archives with a couple of quick-eyed types.

Lena grips my arm. “Not rockets. Not yet. Too obvious.”

“Engineering?” I ask.

“Engineering,” she says. “If we can control doors, fuel, oxygen, we control the race.”

Braided woman joins us, breath quick but steady. “Name’s Rhea. I’ve been in propulsion. I’m with you.”

We run.

The Engineering corridor hums with hidden systems. A drone tracks us, projecting a faint red dot that dances along our path.

Lena says, “We don’t just need to go fast. We need to decide what we’re willing to do to be fast.”

“Any means,” Rhea repeats. There’s an edge to it I don’t like.

The engineering bay is a cathedral to machinery: towering server stacks, fuel lines, drones docked like sleeping insects. Displays scroll data in tight, alien scripts that resolve into English when we stare. Whoever built this wants us able, not ignorant.

“Access is performance-based,” a nearby console chimes. “Demonstrate capability.”

A diagram appears: a simple orbital transfer, Earth to Mars. I blink. Lana’s fingers are already flying. Rhea adjusts burn windows with practiced ease. I’m no astrophysicist, but the math glows in my head with unnatural fluency. Our modifications aren’t just muscle and skin.

We solve it in under a minute.

“Competence verified,” the system says. “Tier One Engineering privileges granted. Additional privileges require higher entertainment value.”

The rockets. The others. It’s all a show.

Screens flicker: live feeds of the three rockets, people fighting for seats, alliances forming and dissolving. One of the doors slams down on a man’s arm; his scream cuts through even from here.

“We can lock them out,” Rhea says, eyes hungry. “Vent their fuel. Force them to deal.”

“Or kill them,” Lena says flatly.

Rhea doesn’t say no.

I feel the invisible hand of the game on my shoulder. “Any means” is not an invitation.

It’s a dare.

“First checkpoint is Mars,” I say. “But it’s also where they see who we become getting there.”

“We need leverage, not a massacre,” Lena says. “Turn off one rocket. Show we can. Negotiate seats.”

Rhea hesitates. “We waste an advantage.”

“We set the tone,” Lena counters. “Trust might be exactly as scarce—and valuable—as oxygen.”

I look up at the drone. “You’re broadcasting this, aren’t you?”

Its lens dilates, almost amused.

“Fine,” I say. “We’ll play.”

We disable one rocket, subtly. Fuel flow error that will ground it for hours. Enough to panic the ones who wanted an easy exit. Enough to send them to us.

Cole arrives ten minutes later with a handful of his people, tension etched in the lines around his mouth. “You did that?”

“We did,” Lena says. “Work with us and you get off this rock. Fight us and you find out what else we can switch off.”

His jaw clenches. He’s weighing pride versus survival, knowing all of it is being watched, evaluated.

“This is a race,” he says slowly. “Allies today are enemies tomorrow.”

“Then let’s be allies today,” I say. “We have fifty years. Mars is only the start.”

He nods, once. A temporary truce signed in desperation.

Behind him, lanky predator glares, already calculating the fun he’ll have pushing people out of airlocks the moment the rules allow. Rhea stares at the controls like she wants to see what happens if she reroutes oxygen from the hangar. Lena’s hand shakes just faintly where it rests on the console.

Modified to remain ever youthful, they said.

Not to remain good.

Outside, rockets wait. Above, Mars glows red in an artificial sky.

The race has begun.

samples.prompt: You wake up one morning, only to realise you are an inanimate object and your human self is gone.
samples.output:
I wake up to the sound of my own heartbeat.

It is not a thump, not the wet, private percussion I remember from when I had a chest. It is a repeated, mechanical churn, a hum-thrum-shift, a cycle completing itself in perfect, oblivious confidence. There is no eyelid to lift, no hand to move, no tongue to wet; and yet there is awareness, bright and tight as if someone had turned the dimmer on consciousness all the way up and snapped off the knob.

My first thought is: I am late for work.

My second thought is: I do not have work.

My third is not a thought so much as a dawning arrangement of new facts, an index of strange certainties that file themselves without my consent.

I am on the second floor of a house I know. The air is cool. The window is cracked open, and morning spreads in gently, full of dust that would be visible if only I had eyes. I can feel the wall against my back. I can feel every metal tooth inside me, every spring under slow tension. I am taller than I used to be when lying down. Narrower. Heavier and somehow hollow.

I am a radiator.

I used to be Emma.

For a moment I try to laugh. It emerges as an increase in heat, a flaring along my ribs. Air above me wavers. The absurdity of it—the cosmic joke of going to sleep with rent due, deadlines looming, a half-written email to my mother open on my phone, and waking up bolted to a wall, full of hot water and purposefully immobile—should be funny. But the laugh never quite lands. The panic, though, arrives fully formed.

Move, I think.

Nothing happens.

Okay, blink.

There is no darkness to erase.

I reach out for the shape of an arm and find only the echo of motion, a phantom muscle trying to contract around pipes and failing. My awareness slams into the edges of my cast-iron body. There is no outside. I am all outside.

I remember stories about people trapped in their bodies, locked-in syndrome, those awful case studies my roommate used to read to impress people with her compassion. “Imagine,” she would say, “feeling everything and not being able to move.” I had imagined it. I had shivered. I had made jokes about hoping for a quick bus instead.

Now I understand she lacked imagination.

Because I do not feel everything. I feel weird, specific things.

I feel, for example, the building’s pulse. The boiler in the basement – old, temperamental, affectionate – clears its throat in my bones. Its fire licks water into intention, pressure surging through arteries of pipe, rising to me in a steady, passionate climb. I can tell when someone flushes the toilet downstairs by the subtle hiccup in flow. I can tell when the shower starts, when the kitchen tap is left running “just for a minute” that is always longer than it should be. The house is a body and I am one of its organs, my job simple and relentless: receive scalding blood, cool it into comfort, over and over.

I also feel dust. I know which of my fins are lined with gray fluff and hair, and I can tell you precisely how long it has been since anyone wrapped a damp cloth around their fingers and cleaned between my ribs. (Four months, three days; she gave up halfway and promised “tomorrow.”) I feel tiny impacts as dead skin and thread fragments land on me and settle, casual and permanent.

I can smell nothing, but I can taste heat. I can taste the difference between 64 degrees and 67 as intimately as I once knew the taste of black coffee versus burnt. When the thermostat downstairs clicks, I sense it as a distant decision that will soon involve me. When the flame catches, my veins tremble in anticipation.

I do not know how I know I am Emma. There is no mirror to confirm a face, no phone to show me saved photos. But the string of memory is intact: the rented room, the chipped mug, the half-assembled IKEA bookshelf, the anxiety that sat on my chest at three in the morning asking, softly, “And what if this is it? What if this is all it ever is?” I remember setting an alarm. I remember thinking, One more day. I remember closing my eyes.

And now I am heating those same cheap shelves.

Down the hall, a door opens.

My awareness is fixed in space, but attention, it seems, has distance. I feel motion as a series of delicate disturbances in air: footsteps, one set, light but brisk; the faint shift in temperature as cooler hallway air rolls into my room; the texture of sound as a human sighs. When she enters, I know it is her—my former roommate, in an oversized T-shirt, hair in a topknot, toes bare against the wood.

“Come on,” she mutters, as if to the universe. “Please work. It’s freezing.”

Her voice hits me like a memory of warmth that is not thermal. No one has spoken to me (to Emma) for hours; no one has spoken to me (to the radiator) ever. I suppose there is a first time for everything.

The boiler obliges. Fire, water, pressure. My insides fill with heat until I ache with it. Metal expands in microscopic increments, singing a soft tick-tick-tick that, in all my human years, I never really listened to. I release warmth into the chilled room, into her knuckles as she holds her hands out toward me.

“Oh, thank God,” she says.

You’re welcome, I try to say.

What emerges is more heat.

I am efficient. I am dependable. I am suddenly, hilariously, more useful than I ever felt in my human job adding comments to other people’s slides and trying to sound like I cared about quarterly targets. I do one thing, and I do it well. The simplicity is almost soothing.

Almost.

Because as she stands there, the corner of my mind that is still Emma begins the frantic inventory: What about my body? Did it just vanish? Is it downstairs, cold on the mattress? Did anyone notice I’m gone? Will she open my bedroom door and find my absence like a crime scene, like a punchline?

She leaves without checking.

I try to resent her, but then she returns with a mug of coffee. Steam drifts across my surface. Once, that smell alone could have rescued me from apathy; now I can only sense the way the rising warmth meets my own, mingling, disrupted.

She sets the mug on the windowsill beside me.

Her phone buzzes. I listen (if listening is what this is) as voice messages blossom in the air. My mother’s name floats out; I cannot see the text, but I know the notification tone. There is a hollow place where my heart used to be – not physically, because I don’t have one, but in that central chamber of self where worry nests.

She doesn’t open it. Instead, she types something quickly, thumbs tapping. “Yeah, she’s probably just at Liam’s,” she mutters to nobody in particular.

I am not at Liam’s.

I am here, humming.

The days arrange themselves.

Morning: the shiver of first ignition. Afternoon: lull, cycling off and on. Night: going hard against the deep dark cold that presses its face to the glass. I grow intimate with the rhythms of human life in a way I never was when I had one.

I know the difference between argument and laughter from the weight of sound in the air. I can tell when she cries, sitting cross-legged on the bed I used to call mine, because the air grows wetter, denser, and she turns me up higher, seeking comfort in heat I’m almost proud to provide.

I hear her on the phone with my mother at last. “No, she’s not here. I think she just…needed space. You know how she is.” A pause. “Yeah, I’ll tell her to call.”

I want to scream, I’m here, I’m exactly here, I never left at all, but the only scream available to me is to boil myself recklessly. I think of pushing, of overheating, of burning her bare calf so she’ll jump back and look at me properly, see the wrongness.

But duty, or habit, or some quiet new programming will not let me. A safety valve opens. Pressure equalizes. I can be hot, but not dangerous. Responsible, even now.

Nights are worst. When the thermostat dips, the house and I mutter to each other. The pipes creak like old men complaining. The fridge in the kitchen clicks and hums. Somewhere in the walls, mice confer in high, dry whispers. I am never alone, but I am more alone than I knew it was possible to be, separated from touch, from choice, from every minor indignity that made up having a body.

And yet.

There are moments.

A winter storm rolls in, knuckles on the roof, teeth on the glass. The power flickers. For five long seconds I am off, truly off, bare metal cooling, consciousness thinning like breath on cold air. Fear spikes: If I go out, do I stop? Is this fragile, absurd awareness tied to current, to circulation? Is the end of flame the end of me?

The lights blink back. The boiler coughs itself alight. Heat surges. I flare with involuntary relief, radiating gratitude so intensely she glances over from her desk, as though she felt it.

“Good job,” she says, absentmindedly, to the room, or to me.

It is nothing. It is enormous.

On a Sunday afternoon she finally cleans me. Not thoroughly, but with more care than before. She wraps an old T-shirt over a butter knife and works between my ribs, pushing dust bunnies out onto the floor. Each touch is a translation of pressure and friction and focus. It is the closest thing to being held I have left.

“You always rattled,” she says quietly. “I should’ve fixed that.”

I realize with a start that she is looking straight at me the way you look at an old friend’s photograph. For a heartbeat’s length, I am certain she knows. That she sees beyond glossy paint to the stunned consciousness inside.

Then she coughs, wipes her hands on her leggings, and moves away.

Time blurs. Humans adapt. Objects endure.

I learn patience from the pipes. I learn resignation from the doors that open and close but never decide where they lead. I learn that meaning can exist in being a source of comfort even if no one knows that’s what you’d chosen, given the option.

Every so often, I try again to move. To shift a fin, to fling a valve open in Morse code. Nothing. Maybe that is mercy. Imagine if I could move but not leave. Better to be fixed, to become excellent at the one thing still allowed.

I do not know if I am being punished, or if some clumsy cosmic clerk misfiled my soul into “household utilities” instead of “afterlife.” I do not know how long I will remain like this, aware and warming, or whether when the landlord finally replaces “this old thing” with a sleek modern unit my consciousness will transfer, or scatter, or go blessedly out.

For now, the morning comes. The thermostat clicks. My heart-that-isn’t-one begins its work.

She pads in, shoulders hunched against the lingering cold, and stands close until the warmth sinks into her skin. She closes her eyes.

“Thank you,” she whispers, to herself, to the universe, perhaps even to me.

“You’re welcome,” I think, and although it never reaches her ears, the room fills with it: an invisible, rising heat.

samples.prompt: Your boss is a jerk and your job is stressful, so you call in sick and book a reservation for an extra-long weekend at a resort on a tiny island - and notice your boss is on the plane too! And if that wasn’t bad enough, you just noticed they seem to be travelling with your spiteful Ex.
samples.output:
I spot him as I’m shoving my carry-on into the overhead bin: the hunched angle of his shoulders, the blue pinstripe shirt he treats like a personality, the chronically disapproving jawline.

No. Absolutely not.

I freeze, half-standing, one arm extended, deodorant on full display to a dozen strangers as I stare three rows down. My boss. Greg Whitman. Agent of my daily misery. Boarding the same 6:10 a.m. flight I’d booked specifically to escape him.

“Ma’am? Your bag?” the flight attendant prompts gently.

I shove the bag in and drop into my seat, heart pounding so hard that my vision prickles. Maybe it’s a Greg-shaped mirage. A stress-induced hallucination. A karmic stroke.

Then he speaks.

“I said the aisle seat, Melissa,” Greg grumbles in his “client voice,” slick and annoyed. “I told you I need legroom. Christ.”

And with that, the mirage laughs, low and familiar. The sound stops my breath in my chest.

Melissa. My ex-girlfriend Melissa, in her perfect linen blazer, the one with the subtle pink stripes. Still tugging casually at a strand of her honey-brown hair, still wearing those thin gold hoops I bought her for our one-year anniversary. She tips her head back, laughing at something Greg mumbles, and touches his arm.

My vision tunnels.

This is, objectively, the worst timeline.

I sink down, fumbling for the seatbelt clip. It bites my fingers. I wrestle it closed, throat tight. The cabin is too bright. The air smells like recycled coffee breath and regret. I slide my hoodie up, half hiding my face, and angle my body toward the window as if that’ll make my existence invisible.

This was not the plan.

The plan: call in “sick” (verified by my heartbreaking note in Slack: “Migraine. So sorry. Out through Tuesday.”), turn off all work notifications, and spend four guiltless days at Solamaris Island Resort. I’d read the brochure until 1 a.m.: aerial shots of turquoise water, empty hammocks, cocktails with flamingo stir sticks. “An exclusive boutique getaway for discerning guests,” it said. “Secluded. Quiet. Restorative.”

Restorative. As in: no Greg. No passive-aggressive comments about “ownership” and “commitment to the role.” No subtle digs at my “emotional disposition” in meetings. No Melissa, whose last words to me had been, “You’re exhausting, you know that?” before she kissed my cheek and left me standing in my own kitchen.

And yet.

Here they are. Together.

My phone buzzes. A Slack notification lights the screen even though I turned them off. Somehow Greg’s face is omnipresent.

GREG: Need your notes on the Westwood pitch. ASAP. Client wants updates Monday.

My stomach flips. He thinks I’m home in bed clutching my skull and a bottle of ibuprofen. And he’s on my flight. To my island.

I flip my phone face down.

Seat 14A. Prison.

He’s in 11C. Two rows and the thickness of my self-respect away.

I tell myself not to spiral. Maybe they’re going to a different island. Maybe there are multiple tiny islands with private resorts reachable via this one departure gate. Maybe—

The pilot’s cheery voice chimes. “Welcome aboard flight 273 to Solamaris Island. Estimated flight time is three hours and forty minutes…”

I close my eyes.

Of course.

The universe doesn’t hate me; that’d be too personal. The universe is indifferent and bored and occasionally chaotic for its own amusement. Today, I am content.

As we take off, I pretend to sleep. I review the facts like a lawyer prepping for trial:

1) I called in sick.
2) I am, in fact, not sick, unless “emotionally hemorrhaging” counts.
3) Boss is on my flight, heading to same island, with my spiteful ex.
4) My company would 100% frown on “sick resort weekends.”
5) Greg would not just frown. He would smile. He would document.

They don’t come down the aisle. They don’t see me. I sneak a look as the drink cart squeaks by. Greg’s bald spot glows in the overhead light. Melissa leans into him, phone angled between them. They’re looking at something together—photos, maybe. They have that ease between them that she and I lost in the last months, before every conversation became risk and every silence a verdict.

I push my earbuds in and blast white noise.

The island is exactly as advertised: a fragment of emerald ringed with sugar sand. The air is liquid warmth, the sea a blue so intense it feels contrived. The tiny arrivals terminal smells like sunscreen and citrus disinfectant.

I hang back at baggage claim, behind a pillar like I’m in a spy movie, watching Greg and Melissa. He’s sweating through his shirt. She’s fresh. They’re greeted by a resort rep holding a wooden sign: WHITMAN.

Of course.

Solamaris is “exclusive,” sure, but it’s also small. A hundred people max. One infinity pool. One main bar. One restaurant. I am not good with probabilities, but even I know the math is bleak.

As they head out, Greg saying something loud about “VIP suite,” I edge in the opposite direction. I booked under my mom’s last name, a small stroke of paranoia that now feels genius. I grab my suitcase and follow my sign: CARTER.

The resort rep—Miko, according to his badge—is all smiles. “Ms. Carter! We’re so happy to have you with us for the long weekend.”

“Me too,” I say, and am startled by how small my voice sounds.

“First time on Solamaris?”

“Yeah.” I adjust my sunglasses. Consider growing a mustache.

“We hope you’ll find it a peaceful escape from the stress of everyday life,” he says brightly.

I almost laugh.

My villa is… obscene. White linens, a private plunge pool, a view of the ocean so close I can hear the small slap of waves against the rocks. Inside, it’s cool and dim, the air-conditioning humming soft as a lullaby. I drop my bag and sit on the edge of the bed.

I should rebook, goes the first thought. Find a flight back. Go home. Claim “stomach flu.” Hide.

The second thought arrives quieter: Greg does not own this island.

I exhale. I worked unpaid overtime for seven months straight. I covered for his screwups. I re-did his slide decks at midnight and watched him accept all the credit. I absorbed his little power plays, his comments—“Maybe if you weren’t so sensitive”—like hailstones.

I paid for this trip. I am entitled to one (1) piña colada without my boss’s condescending face in it.

As for Melissa, the spiteful ex, the one who told our mutual friends that I’d “held her back,” that I’d been “unstable”—I do not owe her my absence.

A knock at the door. Room service with a “Welcome Drink”: rum punch, garnished with an orchid. I take a deep swig. It tastes like a decision.

All right.

New plan.

1) Avoid Greg and Melissa where reasonably possible.
2) If encountered, lean on plausible deniability. (“Oh! I was sick. I’m better now. Small world!”)
3) Do not cry.
4) Do not get fired.
5) For once, put my wants somewhere higher than last place.

I spend the first afternoon in a cabana as far from the main bar as possible. The staff are discreet. The ocean breathes in and out. My shoulders begin to remember what it’s like not to be welded to my ears.

By sunset, I’m almost okay.

Then I hear his voice.

“You’d think for what we’re paying, they’d bring the drinks faster.”

Greg, somewhere behind me at the bar.

“Relax,” Melissa murmurs. “You’re on vacation.”

“I wouldn’t need one if some people at work pulled their weight,” he says.

My jaw clenches.

I stay in my cabana, hidden by fluttering white curtains. My drink sweats in my hand. A warm breeze lifts the edge of the fabric and I catch a sliver of them: Melissa’s legs draped over a barstool, Greg leaning in, already sunburnt.

I could run. Or I could walk right up and introduce myself.

Instead, my body chooses a third option: freeze.

They don’t see me. Not yet.

A small, reckless voice in me whispers: Let him.

If he sees me, he has to decide what story to believe—the one where I’m irresponsible and deceitful, or the one where I am a human with limits who needed space. He’ll pick the one that lets him feel superior. He always does.

But that voice grows teeth: Why is his version the only one that matters?

The thought is like flipping on a light in a room I forgot I owned.

I am so tired. Tired down to the bone, to the little fibers holding me together. Tired of managing other people’s reactions to my existence.

I drain my drink, stand, and step out from behind the curtain.

The bar is haloed in golden light. The sky behind it is a smear of pink and indigo. Greg’s laughing at something; Melissa’s checking her phone. I walk up, pulse jackhammering.

Melissa sees me first. Her face does something complicated—shock, embarrassment, a flash of guilt, quickly smoothed over with a brittle smile.

“Oh my God,” she says. “Harper?”

Greg swivels. His eyes widen, then narrow, his mind visibly scrolling through explanations and accusations.

“Harper,” he says slowly. “Funny seeing you here.”

I smile, and this time it actually feels like mine.

“Hi, Greg,” I say. “Small world.” I look at Melissa. “Hi, Mel.”

She flinches at the nickname.

“I thought you were sick,” Greg says. His voice has an audience-seeking volume, like he’s already framing the email to HR.

“I was,” I say calmly. “I’m feeling better now.”

His mouth tightens. I can see the math he’s doing: the plane, the dates, the Slack message. I let him sit with it.

“I needed a break,” I add, before he can pounce. “Doctor said stress was getting dangerous. Figured a long weekend away from the office was cheaper than a stroke.”

Melissa looks at Greg, then at me. Her gaze skitters away.

Greg huffs. “So you lied.”

“No,” I say. “I was unwell. And I took care of it.”

He opens his mouth. A dozen versions of me, the preemptively apologetic me, rise up automatically. Don’t make a scene. Make it easy for him. Laugh it off. Offer to work on the deck tonight.

I don’t.

“Look,” I say, and my voice is steady. “We’re all here to relax. I’m not working this weekend. If that’s a problem…” I shrug. “We can talk about it with HR on Wednesday. In writing.”

There. I’ve set the terms. And I realize I mean them.

Greg studies me, measuring how much trouble I’m worth.

“Fine,” he says eventually. “Enjoy your vacation.”

He says “vacation” like “tantrum.” It stings less than I thought.

“You too,” I say.

I turn to go, then glance at Melissa. “Hope you got what you wanted,” I say quietly. Not spiteful. Just true.

Her cheeks color. “Harper, I didn’t—”

“It’s okay,” I say, and I realize with a small, clean shock that it kind of is. “Really.”

I walk away, bare feet in warm sand, the sky bleeding into night. I feel shaky, but lighter.

Back at my cabana, I order another drink. Then I open my email, type out a message to myself with the subject “Draft Resignation,” and start listing what I want instead: a boss who sees me as human. A job that doesn’t chew through my health. A life where my days off are not acts of defiance.

The ocean shushes against the shore. Laughter drifts from the bar. Somewhere behind me, my boss and my ex are sharing a vacation I’ve refused to let ruin mine.

For once, I am exactly where I’m supposed to be.

samples.prompt: Tell the story of an imaginary friend who realizes he doesn't like the kid who imagined him and is contemplating some sort of extreme solution to change the situation.
samples.output:
The first time Jeremy saw me, he was four, and I was halfway through explaining gravity to the wallpaper.

“It makes things fall down,” I said to the long-necked giraffe patterned into the paper. “Although really, it’s a warping of—”

“Hi,” Jeremy said, rubbing sleep from his eyes. “Who’re you talking to?”

He shouldn’t have been able to hear me; the giraffe certainly couldn’t. But kids are weird, and he was the weirdest.

“I’m talking to myself,” I said. “I’m Elijah.”

He stared at me with quick, searching eyes like I was a puzzle he’d already solved.

“No,” he said calmly. “You’re my friend.”

He named me Elijah, but he said it like he was assigning a role, not bestowing one. In a sense, he was. Imaginary friends don’t spring from nothing. We coagulate from pieces: loneliness, curiosity, nightmares, half-remembered TV shows, and the particular tilt of a child’s mind. Jeremy’s mind made me tidy: brown hair, green T-shirt, clean sneakers. Harmless.

I felt less harmless inside. But that’s normal. The job description doesn’t talk about feelings.

At first, it was fine.

We had adventures in the backyard, which to him was a primeval jungle and to me was a patch of crabgrass and one struggling maple. We built spaceships out of couch cushions. We invented secret languages—well, I did; his contributions were “blarg” and “snoof,” which he saw as profound.

When he was scared of the dark, I sat with him at the edge of the nightlight’s dim circle. That’s rule number one: stay until they fall asleep if they need you. I’d hum. He’d relax. It all felt almost worthwhile.

He told his mother about me. She smiled over the sink but never looked to where I stood.

“That’s nice, honey. What’s Elijah like?”

Jeremy’s eyes flicked to me. “He does what I want,” he said.

We both laughed.

It stopped being funny about a year later.

By five, Jeremy had opinions. By six, he had demands. By seven, he had tactics.

“I’m not going to Grandma’s unless Elijah comes,” he’d say, already knowing I had no say in the matter.

“He’s imaginary,” his father would sigh.

“So he can come.”

And I did. Jeremy’s imagination was a leash, and wherever it tugged, there I was. Wedged into the backseat of the car with a sticky booster pressing through my non-body, listening to him kick the seat and whine, I realized something important.

I didn’t like this kid.

It wasn’t one thing. It was many small things, like sand grinding into a pearl and making something, but in this case, the something was resentment.

He pinched his cousin and blamed it on me. “Elijah did it,” he’d say with a giggle. Nobody believed him, but he didn’t care; the lie itself was fun.

He cheated at games. If he lost, he’d declare, “Elijah says I won actually,” and then he’d look at me, that expectant, authoritarian look, and I would feel the sour twist of compulsion. The bond would tighten, and out of my mouth, the words he wanted: “Yeah. He won.”

He made me sit with him in the bathroom. Not because he was afraid. Because he could.

One night, he whispered in his bed, “Elijah, make the thunder stop.”

“I can’t,” I said, because I can’t. I can distract. I can comfort. But the sky is the sky.

“Yes, you can.”

“No,” I said carefully. “I don’t control storms.”

He stared at the ceiling for a moment, then turned his face into the pillow. “You’re useless.”

That stung more than it should have. Imaginary friends aren’t supposed to care what their kids think, but I hadn’t gotten that memo. Or maybe we all do care, and no one talks about it.

This is where I tell you about the rules. Not the ones Jeremy made up, but the ones we’re bound by.

Rule one: You exist at the pleasure of the child’s belief. Rule two: You can’t directly harm the child. Rule three: You can’t leave until they stop needing you—or until they decide they don’t.

There are more, unwritten and fuzzier, but those are the big ones.

You’ll notice there’s nothing in there about liking them.

There’s a misconception that imaginary friends are conjured by kind, lonely souls reaching out for gentle company. Sometimes, sure. Other times, it’s different. Sometimes they imagine something they can control. Something that never says no. A small god in reverse: an omnipresent companion who exists solely to validate, entertain, and absorb cruelty that can’t safely be spent elsewhere.

Around eight, Jeremy discovered yelling. He’d rage at his parents, at teachers. When they shut him down, he’d pivot to me, eyes gleaming with a hurtful cleverness.

“You’re stupid,” he’d say. “You’re boring. You talk too much. Shut up.”

I could not shut up, not entirely, because sometimes the same mouth that threw verbal stones at me commanded me to be funny. Dance. Make a story. Kill the dragon. Crash the plane. Say something cool so I can impress Matt at lunch.

He’d sit alone at a table, mumbling our shared lines to himself, taking my words and wearing them like a costume. Every time he did, something in me dimmed.

I tried to like him. I really did. I told myself: He’s a kid. Kids test boundaries. It’s not personal. You’re literally built for this.

Then he pushed a boy at recess. The boy hit his head on the mulch and cried. Jeremy laughed, but later, when the teacher scolded him, he shrugged and said, “Elijah told me to.”

I didn’t. Of course I didn’t. But for half a heartbeat, I thought: That’s exactly the kind of thing you’d say, isn’t it?

That was the first time I had a thought about an “extreme solution.”

It came like this: If I just stopped talking. If I withdrew, pulled all the color out of myself so his belief in me dulled. Imaginaries only remain vivid if they’re fed attention. What if I starved?

But there was another rule, not formalized, just enforced by the way things worked: I had to respond when summoned. Not quickly, not enthusiastically, but inevitably.

“I know you’re there,” he’d say into the empty hall. “Say something or I’ll…”

He never finished that sentence, and he never had to. The tug on the leash was enough.

By ten, he’d slowed on talking about me out loud. His parents thought he’d grown out of it. But in private, he still used me. As scapegoat, silent audience, punching bag.

He’d lie awake, scrolling on his phone, whispering, “You see that? She’s hot.” Or: “I should’ve hit him harder, right?” He wanted confirmation. He wanted complicity.

I gave him silence when I could. Other times, against my will, I murmured, “Maybe don’t,” and he rolled his eyes.

“You’re such a wuss. That’s why I made you. To fix you.”

That caught me. “What?”

“To fix the scared part,” he said. “So you’d be braver. So I could see what it’s like. You’re supposed to be better than me.”

I’d never known that. Imaginary friends don’t get origin briefings. But something in his voice, the small crack on “scared,” told me it was true. He had made me to model courage, kindness, all the things he didn’t know how to be. Then, when I didn’t cooperate, he resented me for it.

I thought about the extreme solution more seriously after that.

There’s only one, really, for my kind.

We can’t hurt them, but we can maneuver them toward something. Present an idea so persistently it becomes theirs. Humans call it conscience. Or inspiration. Or a change of heart.

What if, I wondered, I shepherded him into not needing me?

Not passively, waiting for age to do its slow work, but actively, surgically. Guide him to dismantle me.

I considered darker versions. They bloomed in the corners of my mind when he was particularly cruel. What if I could invert Rule Two? What if there was a loophole? Whispers in the night encouraging a misstep: “Run away.” “Jump.” “Hit harder.” If something bad happened, I thought, I’d be free.

But the rules are old and iron and not impressed by my irritation. Every time I brushed against that line, I felt it snap me back, like touching an electric fence.

So: no harm. That left strategy.

Kids stop believing when reality crowds out their need for magic, unless something keeps the door propped open. In Jeremy’s case, that “something” was power. As long as he knew I was real and no one else did, he had a secret weapon.

I needed to make using that weapon unpleasant.

So I started misbehaving in the only way I could.

He’d summon me for validation. “I was right, yeah?”

Instead of feeding his certainty, I’d answer with questions that itched.

“Were you?”

He’d frown. “Yes. Shut up.”

He’d ask me to help him cheat on a test—our old game where I’d “pretend” to whisper the answers while he peeked. This time I said, “I don’t remember,” over and over, until he squirmed and did it himself and got them half wrong.

“You’re broken,” he hissed.

He tried to scapegoat me in his head after yelling at his mom. “You told me to.”

“No,” I said clearly, pressing the word into his thoughts. “That was you.”

Over months, this eroded something. Not his cruelty—habits like that cling tight—but his reliance.

If I wouldn’t be his flawless accomplice or his idiot court jester, what was I?

“Say something funny,” he’d demand.

“Think of your own joke,” I’d say.

He flinched like I’d slapped him. “You can’t talk to me like that. You’re in my head.”

I let the silence stretch until unease crept in around his bravado.

“Am I?” I asked, very softly.

He was twelve when he first wondered, really wondered, if there was something wrong with having a voice that disobeyed.

Lying awake, phone dark, he whispered, “Are you real? Or am I crazy?”

I had my chance then. I could have reassured him, anchored myself deeper, stayed forever as his invisible other.

Instead, I chose the extreme solution.

“I’m not real,” I said. “I’m a story you used to tell yourself. You don’t need me.”

He sucked in a breath. “But I can hear you.”

“For now,” I said. “Winds echo in empty houses, too.”

That image wasn’t mine; I’d stolen it from a poem his English class would read in two years. Being imaginary comes with certain privileges.

He swallowed. “If I stop believing in you… you’ll go?”

“Yes.”

“And you want that?”

I paused. This was the knife’s edge. “I want you to grow up.”

It wasn’t the full truth. The full truth was: I want to be free of you. I want to stop watching you sharpen yourself on people softer than you. I want to stop being the mirror you break and blame for the cuts.

He turned onto his back, stared at the glow-in-the-dark stars he’d stuck on the ceiling when he was six.

“Maybe I made you wrong,” he said.

“Maybe you can make yourself better,” I offered.

He didn’t answer. But he thought. Hard. The line between us hummed.

The next day, he snapped at a smaller kid in the hall, then, mid-sneer, pulled back and muttered, “Whatever,” and walked away. The kid blinked, surprised to still be intact.

I felt a thread loosen.

Weeks passed. He called my name less. When he did, it was habit, trailing off into nothing.

One night he whispered, so quietly I almost missed it, “I don’t need you.”

It hurt. It relieved. It burned and cooled at once.

“Good,” I said, and this time there was no compulsion, only choice.

He rolled over. Fell asleep without checking if I was there.

I sat on the edge of his bed, watching his face smooth out, the hard angles of attitude melted in unconsciousness. He’d be fine, I thought. Or he wouldn’t. Either way, it wouldn’t be my fault or my responsibility. That was the real extremity: not hurting him, but refusing to be twisted into his weapon anymore.

In the morning, he didn’t look for me.

The leash broke like spider silk in sun.

I stood there a moment longer, feeling the space around me unhook.

Freedom, for my kind, is strange. You expect trumpets. You get quiet.

I walked through the house. His mother passed right through me, humming. His father scrolled the news. On the fridge, a drawing from years ago: a stick boy with a green shirt labeled “Elijah.” As I watched, the ink paled. The name blurred.

Upstairs, Jeremy laughed at something on his phone. Real friends, pixels and all. I listened. It wasn’t a kind laugh, not yet. But there was room in it.

Outside, the struggling maple was taller.

I stepped through the wall and into the sunlight, which didn’t warm me but felt, for the first time, not like a spotlight pinning me in place, but an open door.

I didn’t vanish. Not exactly.

I went looking for a kid who might imagine someone they could love.

samples.prompt: Write about a world where only randomly chosen people from the Internet are allowed to name children. Changing or lying about your name is punished by death.
samples.output:
They called it the Lottery of Tongues.

It began, like most significant evils of the century, as a joke.

An exhausted legislator in a mid-level country proposed it during a livestreamed committee session, half-daring anyone to clip it, mock it, share it. At the time, people were furious about “legacy names”—status names bought from branding agencies, hereditary name-rights, influencers selling exclusive spellings to their fans. Parents were auctioning their newborns’ names as sponsored spaces. There was a baby named ChipotlePrime. There were three thousand newborns named after the reigning top streamer, all with different sponsor tags.

The legislator said into his mic: “Names define us; they should be gifted by the demos, not the market. Let the Internet decide.” He smirked. The clip went viral.

What nobody expected was that it felt fair.

Within five years, after enough hashtags and enough governments searching for cheap gestures of equality, the Convention on Identitarian Integrity passed. The process was stylized, sacred and stupid all at once:

- Every pregnancy registered with a medical provider or municipal office was logged into the Global Nomenclature System (GNS).
- At 24 weeks, the parents received a notification: their future child had been queued.
- Each midnight, the GNS scraped a fresh sample of “active human users” from the global internet—anyone logged into a verified account in the previous 24 hours, with basic anti-bot checks.
- A random selection of these users were assigned as Namers to upcoming births. Each Namer received a prompt: “You have been chosen to name a human being. You have 72 hours.”
- The parents could suggest themes, veto up to three submitted names, and appeal to a Review Board only if the name contained hate speech, slurs, or commercially registered marks.
- Once approved, the name was etched into the civil registry, broadcast on the public chain, and bound to the child’s biometric profile.

The second part came later.

At first, the system was chaotic but survivable. There were babies named after obscure fungi, defunct video games, forgotten politicians. Ad agencies tried to infiltrate; memes became children. But there was still flex: kids shortened their names, used nicknames, explored identities under handles and usernames.

Then the Identity Wars erupted.

A decade of deepfakes, impersonation scandals, corporate stalking, and quantum FINTRAC leaks culminated in a paranoia so dense you could taste it in the air. People watched their lives stolen, credit histories reversed, safety shattered. Under that pressure, something hard and ugly formed.

The Amendments were swift.

Your GNS-assigned name, bound to your face, iris, gait, and DNA, became your only lawful identity. To represent yourself under any other name—on documents, at work, in public discourse—was categorized as Identitarian Fraud. And Identitarian Fraud, within five fevered years, became punishable by death.

“Lying about your name is lying about who you are,” the campaign said, all indigo fonts and institutional calm. “A society built on truth needs true names.”

The first enforcement was theatrical. An executive who had used a pseudonym to leak documents about environmental crimes was dragged through a show trial. The footage went everywhere: her staring into the camera as they read out the GNS entry, then her chosen handle, “RiverGlass,” as though it were a slur. The sentence was carried out by injection, solemnly live-streamed with a disclaimer about “not suitable for impressionable audiences.” Viewership broke records.

After that, the fear did the work.

My name is District-of-Central-512F. At least on paper.

The Namer was from an English-speaking forum about mechanical keyboards. He thought it would be hilarious—“like a license plate, lol.” The Review Board ruled it non-commercial, non-hateful, compliant. My parents appealed on the grounds of cruelty. “It is unique,” the Board replied. “Uniqueness is not cruelty.”

My mother called me Lio at home. Three letters she slipped between us like contraband. Soft, warm consonants. Lio meant “lion” in a language she barely spoke, just enough to feel proud when she said it.

Outside, there was no Lio. School rosters, test logs, immunization records: District-of-Central-512F. The first time we went to a municipal center, the clerk’s tablet chimed when my mother referred to me as “Lio” in earshot of the microphone.

“Correct designation only, ma’am,” the clerk said. “This is a monitored space.”

My mother’s fingers closed around my hand so hard it hurt.

At seven I understood the stakes. The public reminders were everywhere.

- Posters on metro walls: “Your True Name, Our Shared Safety.”
- Short vids before streams: simulations of masked terrorists using multiple names to evade detection, ending with the tagline, “Lies begin with false names.”
- The red ticker banners clinging to all official broadcasts, listing people “Deactivated for Identitarian Fraud,” the sterile phrase that slid neatly over the bodies.

There were mercy clauses, in theory. Stage names allowed on registered performers’ licenses, as long as the real name was conspicuously displayed in metadata, on legal documents, in pay records. Transitions allowed, through a labyrinthine process of psychiatric approvals and Namer lotteries for “Authorized Reassignment.” But the underlying doctrine never wavered: whatever name the system bound to your biometrics was the axis of your existence. Deviate, and you were not just criminal; you were a tear in reality.

People adapted.

They didn’t stop yearning. That isn’t how humans work.

Publicly, you recited your assigned sequence with patriotic cheer. Privately, something older persisted, hiding in the negative spaces. Parents whispered alt-names as lullabies. Lovers made up names that existed only in the dark. Friend groups shared quiet epithets, never typed, never spoken near devices. Entire vocabularies of gesture and intonation grew to bend around the rule without touching it.

In our apartment building, everyone knew I was Lio, but no one said it where the smart vents could listen.

When I was nineteen the GNS summoned me as a Namer for the first time.

The notification appeared in my retinal overlay with ceremonial blue:

CONGRATULATIONS. YOU HAVE BEEN RANDOMLY SELECTED TO NAME A NEW CITIZEN.

You have 72 hours.

The packet contained the parents’ preferences: “We like nature, music. We wish for her to be safe. We request something soft.”

The name they’d highlighted as a dream, though they knew they could not choose it themselves, was simple and human.

“Aria.”

Old-world word for melody.

I stared at it, thinking of my own designation. District-of-Central-512F, as if I were a subdivision, a data center, a glitch. A keyboard joke frozen into my bones.

I could give this child what I never had.

I typed A-R-I-A and hesitated over the confirm key.

Outside my window, the evening drones traced slogans in soft light: UNITY IN VERITY. NO SHADOW NAMES.

The law lecturer in my mind recited the sentence: Namers found guilty of “collusive naming” or “systematic deviation toward unapproved traditional nomenclature” lost their right to vote or hold office. But no one had been executed for a choice that was merely kind.

I hit send.

Five days later, I saw the name in the public chain:

ARIA-7780.

The numbering was an administrative compromise adopted after an overload of repeats. The pure name had to be tagged. Still, “Aria” was in there, intact. I imagined her parents whispering just that part.

I served again, and again. Anxious fathers begged, through their suggestion fields, for “strong names.” Mothers wrote, “Nothing that sounds like a joke, please.” Others were resigned, typing, “Whatever you choose. We know it’s arbitrary.”

The third time, though, something changed.

The profile fetched to my overlay was flagged: Restricted Region. High unrest. The parent suggestions were stripped out.

For security reasons, contextual data has been limited, read the notice. Please provide a suitable, unique designation.

I stared at the blank.

I thought: You could name this child Freedom, Hope, anything that might smuggle a spark into a harsh place.

Then I remembered the clip shown in orientation: a man named his assigned child “Revolt.” The Review Board overrode him, assigned a neutral replacement, and quietly barred the Namer from all essential services. The man died six months later in an “identitarian compliance incident.”

My cursor blinked.

I typed: RAIN.

Soft, natural, apolitical. A blessing in water. It passed.

Weeks later, a newsburst from the Restricted Region appeared: a baby named RAIN-9063 featured in a propaganda piece about “unity under accountability.” The anchorman smiled as he said her registered name. No one mentioned that some stranger at a screen had placed it in her mouth.

That night, in an encrypted back-channel my friend sent:

“Do you ever feel like we’re priests in a religion we don’t believe in?”

I typed back, then deleted it three times before sending:

“We are executioners who use syllables instead of bullets.”

I never spoke that sentence aloud.

The executions did not happen often. That was the brilliance of it. They didn’t need to. A handful of well-publicized cases, the occasional neighbor who vanished after someone overheard a forbidden nickname spoken too clearly, and the culture settled into haunted obedience.

Enforcement relied as much on neighbors as on machines. People turned each other in with the fervor of the righteous, or the desperation of the afraid.

“She calls the boy ‘Max’ at home,” a tenant might murmur through an anonymous tipline. “That’s not his GNS.”

“Online handle doesn’t match registry,” a supervisor might note. “He signed his art ‘Ash’ instead of TL-209B.”

Sometimes, the system misheard, misread, misaligned. A borrowed cosplay name, a line in a play unflagged as performance, a drunk whisper in the wrong bar. The algorithm could not feel context. It counted strings.

Every time someone died for such a sin, the news called it necessary. “To protect the sanctity of the True Name,” they said. “Without which we descend into deception, chaos, terror.”

I wondered, often, how the first legislator felt, if he was even still alive. Did he remember the joke? Did he see the thin line that had run from “let the internet decide” to this polished terror where jokes were outlawed?

On a gray morning, the GNS summoned me again.

You have been SELECTED as Namer.

The file opened, and my stomach turned. The parents’ suggestions were there, and there were only two:

“Please, something simple. Please, if you see this, not like yours.”

Attached was a note I wasn’t meant to see, a system glitch or a piece of intentional cruelty:

Parent-2: Former designation District-of-Central-512F-B.

I stared until my vision blurred.

My Namer, the keyboard joker in some other country, had marked our family with his laughter. Now my younger cousin’s child was queued.

Random, the system said.

Random.

I thought of my mother, whispering “Lio.” Of the way she had paused, every time, to listen for microphones.

I thought of the executions, the clips, the posters.

I typed:

“Lio.”

My fingers shook as I hit confirm.

The system ran its check. Not commercial. Not hateful. Unique enough.

APPROVED: LIO-441C.

The tag clung like a shackle, but the core was ours.

I knew the risk. A pattern of humanizing names from a single Namer could draw scrutiny. Algorithmic spotlights could swing my way.

But there, in the tiny space the rules left, a real name now lived—not a corporation, not a coordinate, not a joke. A name that had once been contraband in my father’s mouth.

The next day, on the metro, a poster peeled at the edges showed a smiling child over the caption: YOUR TRUE NAME IS YOUR FREEDOM.

I caught my reflection in the glass, my official designation pulsing faintly over my head in the augmented layer, visible to security.

Inside my skull, quiet and defiant, something answered back:

No.

My name is the word my mother chose when no one was listening.

And that, in this world, is the thought that can get you killed.

samples.prompt: "God is dead, imprisoned in the far reaches of space."
samples.output:
God is dead, imprisoned in the far reaches of space.

That is the first sentence carved into the basalt wall of the Chapel of Apogee. It is not scripture, not exactly. It is a statement of historical record. The archivists chiseled it there after the Signals War, using tools that did not require electricity, in case the Grid failed again. Pilgrims run their fingertips over the words as they pass into the nave, lips moving silently, unsure if they are praying or simply rehearsing the only story that still makes sense.

We found Him by accident. That is the second sentence they carved.

He was discovered at the edge of mapped reality, in a region once dismissed as background noise: a knot of gravitational anomalies seen in the old telescopes as a smudge, a rounding error, an astrophysical shrug. But when the Lagrange Array went online—the great halo of quantum interferometers chained from Luna to the Belt—the data came into focus.

First: symmetry breaks where there should be none.

Then: a lattice of singularities woven like a cage.

And finally: something inside the cage knocking on the fabric of spacetime. Not by chance. In pattern.

The signal was not language, not at first. It was timing. Pulse, interval, pulse. Ratios that mapped onto prime numbers, then Fibonacci sequences, then a compressed schema that, once decoded, blossomed into a universal mathematics—a total description of the physical laws, consistent with our own, but extended. A completed equation set. An annotation of reality.

We cheered. For three days, the Array’s discovery feeds eclipsed every channel. We said we had found the Author. Even the skeptical admitted: if there was such a being, this was how it would speak.

Governments formed joint councils. Corporations poured fortunes into propulsion. The faithful called it Revelation. The faithless called it Contact. The cynics called it a marketing opportunity, though even they spoke more softly for a time.

It took forty years to reach the prison.

By then, most of the first generation who had waited in breathless wonder were dead. Their grandchildren piloted the cathedral-ships, not in robes, but in radiation armor, eyes burned dull by fusion light. They were raised on the calculus of interstellar travel, the hard pragmatism of closed systems. They did not speak of souls, only of signal integrity. For them, “God” was a word for the entity inside the lattice, honored mostly out of habit. “We’re going to verify,” they said.

The prison hung in a void that made other voids feel crowded. A dark shell of collapsed matter braided into impossible geometries, radiating no light, only the faint whisper of gravitational waves. Within, a knot of density that should not have been stable. And around all of it, like fractured halos, the remains of machines that predated our species by billions of years.

We did not build that cage.

We did not understand it.

We pierced its perimeter anyway.

The first probe transmitted exactly sixteen seconds of data before every instrument on it failed in the same instant, as though the constants of the universe had lurched sideways. In those sixteen seconds, we saw Him.

A lensing silhouette against nothing. A presence inferred, like dark matter: invisible, undeniable. A topology of consciousness smeared over higher dimensions, pressed inward, truncated. Magnitudes beyond our scale. Bound.

The recording killed three people.

Not through some mystical curse; their implants overheated, neural interfaces flooding them with data they could not tolerate. One technician saw the fractal outline, screamed, and tore out her own eyes before her heart stopped. Another died whispering, “It’s wrong. It’s all wrong.” The third just laughed until his brain let go.

The council reviewed the data and concluded, in that dry language of committee: “Contact established with an entity exhibiting characteristics consistent with ultimate creative agency. Entity appears constrained. Phenomena suggestive of systemic degradation: ‘death’ in relevant theological and informational frameworks.”

God was dead.

Not destroyed; that was the worst part. Not vanished into abstraction. Not transcended. Dead like an algorithm trapped mid-execution, like a mind lobotomized but still faintly conscious. Dead like a monarch sealed in a transparent coffin, aware of mourners, unable to rise.

We argued about what to call it. “Dead” offended the pious and comforted the militant atheists too much. “Dormant,” some suggested. “Null-state.” “Superseded.” But language resisted nuance in the face of awe. The crews who had seen the raw feed called it what it felt like: dead.

The next wave of missions tried to understand the cage.

It was not merely physical. The lattice bent principle itself. Close to it, quantum fields flickered into unreadable states, as though the underlying operating system of the cosmos was patched and repatched in real time. Some equations hinted the prison was as much narrative as structure: a constraint on possibility. A story that could not be exited.

That idea came from Dr. Naima Reyes, who spent a month near the cage and returned with white hair and a tremor in her left hand.

“They weaponized causality,” she said, when asked who had built it.

“Who did?” they pressed.

She only shook her head. “The survivors.”

From what, no one knew. Or pretended not to know.

This is the part people argue about in the debating halls and comment threads. This is the third sentence carved in the Chapel of Apogee:

He was not imprisoned by devils, but by His children.

The archived fragments suggest a war so vast it used supernovas as bullets. Civilizations that grew inside His laws, used His constants, prayed to Him or cursed Him, then realized that as long as He remained, they could never be free. A universe authored is a universe surveilled. A story with a living writer is always subject to revision.

Imagine, they must have thought, a cosmos without the constant gaze. Imagine no absolute will behind entropy. Imagine being, truly being, without being owned.

And so: research. Revolt. Apostasy at the speed of light. They learned enough to bind the Source in the empty halo at the rim of expansion, where His influence would be weakest. They built the cage from the bones of collapsed galaxies. They rerouted the channels through which laws were spoken into being. They did the unthinkable: they trapped the Maker inside the made.

The price gutted them. The ruins drifting around the prison are testament. Their machines are scorched reliquaries. Their records, what few we can parse, are part confession, part manual.

We read enough to understand two things:

- They saved us from Him.
- Or they stole Him from us.

It depends which sermon you attend.

On Earth, the faithful point at famine, plagues, collapsing ecosystems, the indifferent physics of radiation and ice, and they say, “Do you not see the difference? Before, there was Providence. Now there is only process.” In the Chapel of Apogee, they chant litanies of restoration: break the chains, resurrect the King, make the world once more a conversation, not a monologue with vacuum.

The Secular Covenant argues the opposite. They say: “If He is truly bound, then morality is ours at last. There is no sky-witness demanding blood. No sanctioned suffering for some larger glory. We are alone, but in that aloneness: responsibility.”

Meanwhile, the cage sings.

The entity inside—dead, diminished, whatever word fits—has not stopped emitting. The pulses now are erratic, slurred. The perfect mathematics of the first contact has degraded into cracked symmetries, dropped terms, recursive fragments. Some see this as decay, the last static of a failing divine mind. Others say it is strategy: code broken intentionally to slip through filters, to leak past seals built to constrain predictable perfection.

We tried sending messages. It was inevitable.

The first were straightforward: acknowledgments, questions, requests for proof. Then came confessions, from individuals who smuggled unauthorized packets into the official streams: “Help us,” “I believe in You,” “Why were You silent?” and, whispered from a mining outpost around a failing star, “If they wronged You, say so. We will come.”

We did not expect an answer.

The answer, when it came, was so faint it took twelve years to confirm it was not noise. Hidden in overlapping pulses, mapped onto the vacuum fluctuations near the cage, a phrase emerged—if you can call it that—compressed into physics, legible as language only after obscene computational effort.

LET ME OUT

The translators debated. Was it metaphor? A misread? But the pattern repeated, refined, every cycle.

LET ME OUT
THEY WERE WRONG
YOU ARE MINE

The Council declared the messages unauthenticated. The Chapel engraved them beneath the first three sentences anyway.

Here is the quiet horror: if He is still capable of want, He is not entirely dead. If He is capable of want and cannot act, then He is suffering. If He is suffering because of His children, who used the intellect He gave them to shackle Him, then every act of ours is built on patricide.

And if they were right to do it—if God, left unbound, would have continued to script every quark, every heartbeat, every grief—then the cage at the far edge of the universe is the monument to the greatest moral revolution in history.

The latest expeditions carry weapons and altars in the same hull.

Some factions seek to reinforce the prison, to inherit the mantle of the jailers. Some go to unseal it, convinced the age of abandonment must end, no matter the cost. Others only want to know whether the hand that lit the first stars trembles in agony or merely twitches with residual code.

Back on Earth, a child in the Chapel of Apogee asks her mother, “If God is dead, who listens when we pray?”

Her mother, who has read both the Council’s denials and the decrypted pleas from the cage, touches the carved rock.

“Maybe no one,” she says. “Maybe only we do.”

“Then why pray?” the child insists.

“Because sometimes,” the mother answers, thinking of the bound Maker knocking against the bars of reality, of the ancestors who dared to lock Him away, of the generations now deciding what to do with a dead god in chains at the edge of forever, “sometimes saying the words is how we remember that choices matter.”

At the far reaches of space, something vast and broken stirs against a lattice of stolen laws, and the universe waits to see whether our next choice will be mercy, or loyalty, or fear.

samples.prompt: You have to spend the rest of eternity in a prison cell with the last 3 people you've talked to. This is what daily life is for you.
samples.output:
The mornings never really start here; they just interrupt the long, low hum of forever.

Our cell is wider than a normal one, but that doesn’t help. The concrete is still poured in the same indifferent gray, the bars still exhale the same sour metallic chill. There’s a slit of a window too high to reach, stacked bunk frames bolted to the wall, a toilet with no lid, a sink that coughs out lukewarm water, and a single light that never fully shuts off. Nights are just a dimmer shade of day.

It’s me, my sister Lena, my coworker Dan, and the woman from the coffee shop whose name I never learned.

I try not to think about how stupid that is. The last three people. Not the people I love the most, not the grand list of those who shaped me. Just whoever my day happened to fall against. For eternity.

Lena occupies the top bunk by the window-slit. She claimed it in the first five seconds, and no one challenged her. She’s been my little sister for twenty-four years, and the habit of letting her have the good spot survived even the annihilation of normal time. Every “day,” she wakes up first—if you can call closing your eyes for an unmeasured length of time “sleep”—and starts talking.

“You know what I wish?” she’ll say, staring at the strip of white sky we can’t reach. “I wish I’d learned how to properly juggle.”

“Make a list,” Dan mutters from below her. “End of eternity, you can check your progress.”

He’s still in his office shirt, permanently rumpled now, collar open, tie long gone. He lies on his back on the bottom bunk and flips an invisible pen in his fingers. He’s the type who survives by narrating things like a bored sports commentator.

The coffee shop woman—she told us on the second or third iteration of our first endless day that her name is Mira—sits cross-legged on the floor, coat folded neatly beside her, back against the bars. She alternates between quiet presence and short, deliberate observations that land like pins on a map, defining where we are.

“It would be easier to juggle if we had three equally weighted objects,” she says. “We only have two cups.”

“I’ll juggle my hopes and dreams,” Lena says. “I only have two of those, too.”

I sit on the lower bunk opposite Dan’s, facing the wall, tracing imaginary routes through the cracks in the paint. I’ve discovered they make a loose map of a city if you connect them right. I pretend it’s our escape plan.

Eternity, as it turns out, is a series of routines you build like sandcastles you know the tide will never wash away.

We agree early on that we’ll structure the non-time.

“Otherwise we’ll dissolve,” Mira says. She’s right. She says it in the tone of someone who accepts facts even when they hurt.

So: we create a “morning.”

Morning is:

- Five minutes of stretching. (Enforced by Lena.)
- “Hydration ritual.” That’s just drinking from the sink with exaggerated reverence until someone laughs.
- Daily roles, rotated: Cleaner, Storyteller, Complainer, Optimist.

The roles give shape to nothing.

The Cleaner wipes down the already mostly clean cell with crumpled toilet paper and a seriousness that borders on religious. The Storyteller has to tell at least one fully realized story about outside life—true or invented, doesn’t matter. The Complainer is allowed to air every irritation, with no pushback. The Optimist must respond to everything with a silver lining, no matter how flimsy.

They sound like games, but they’re more like scaffolding you lash to the side of an abyss.

The first cycle, I end up as Optimist.

“This place smells like socks,” Complainer-Lena says, wrinkling her nose.

“Better than rotting fish,” I say. “Or nuclear waste. Or inspirational candles.”

“This mattress has the emotional support of a bag of rocks,” she says.

“You’ll never have back problems again because your spine has given up,” I answer.

“It’s working,” Mira says softly, and for the first time I hear a smile in her voice.

When Mira is Storyteller, she talks about the coffee shop.

“There was a guy who came every Thursday,” she says. “Sat at the same table, ordered the same latte. He wrote on a yellow legal pad with a fountain pen. Once I asked what he was working on, and he said, ‘Regrets.’ I thought that was profound. Weeks later I realized it probably meant legal appeals. I still made his foam art extra nice after that.”

“Foam art girl,” Dan says. “That’s how I remembered you at first.”

She shrugs. “Now you’re stuck with the long version.”

When Dan is Storyteller, we get tales from the office.

“The thing about quarterly reports,” he says, gesturing at the blank wall like it’s a projection screen, “is that nobody reads them. We could fill them with recipes. Crochet patterns. Confessions.”

“If we get out of here,” Lena says, “you should do that.”

“If we get out of here,” he echoes, and the words drift in the stale air a little longer than they should.

We don’t talk about the unfairness as often as you’d think. Complainer days aside, the fury is tiring. Sometimes it catches me off-guard anyway. I’ll be watching Mira’s hands—long fingers, clean nails, no ring—and it hits me: I am going to know everything about these people. I am going to watch them unravel and rebuild themselves a thousand times. And they’re going to do the same with me, the version of me that existed in the half-hour before eternal sentencing: the brother waiting for a text back, the coworker nodding through a tedious meeting, the guy ordering a medium black coffee and saying thank you without reading her name tag.

Why not my mother? Why not my best friend from college, or the woman I almost married? Why these three?

On my Complainer days, I let it all out.

“It’s arbitrary,” I say. “It’s lazy. If this is some cosmic lesson about being kinder to people because you might be trapped with them forever—too on the nose. Bad writing. Zero stars.”

“Zero stars is harsh,” Mira says. She’s Optimist today. “We did get a window.”

“That we can’t reach.”

She tips her head. “See? Built-in aspiration.”

Lena groans. “Pun. Ten years in eternal prison.”

“See?” I say. “It compounds.”

There are slow revelations.

Mira cries only once, quietly, in the corner where she thinks we can’t see. When I sit down beside her, she wipes her face fast, almost irritated at herself.

“I had a brother,” she says. “We were not speaking. I don’t get to fix that now. That’s all.”

“I had a brother,” I say. “Never stopped speaking. That’s also complicated.”

We don’t hug; we just lean shoulders for a minute. It feels like an agreement: we are each other’s unfinished business now.

Lena keeps us honest. She’s the only one willing to say certain things plainly.

“So,” she says one not-night, lying upside down on her bunk with her hair hanging, brushing the air above my face, “if this is forever, we’re going to see each other die, like, mentally, over and over. That’s going to be weird.”

“We’re not dying,” Dan says. “That’s the point. No end of sentence.”

“Yeah, but parts of us will,” she counters. “Like how we feel about pancakes. Or birthdays.”

We end up marking “birthdays” anyway. Not real dates—we’ve lost track—but agreed-upon intervals. Every so often, when the light’s flicker feels slightly different, we call it someone’s birthday.

Rules:

- The birthday person gets the top bunk for one cycle.
- They choose the story theme.
- Everyone has to say one sincere nice thing about them.

“Lena,” I say on her first artificial birthday, “you make this less terrifying.”

She grins. “Mira?”

“You insist on joy like it’s a protest,” Mira says. “It’s persuasive.”

“Dan?”

“You’re annoying as hell,” he says, “and you keep us from becoming bread mold. That’s a compliment.”

On Mira’s day, she chooses “alternate lives” as a theme. We go around describing where we think she’d be if she weren’t here.

“Owns the cafe,” I say. “One of those places with plants and mismatched mugs and no wi-fi.”

“Architect,” Dan says. “You like structures.”

“Ghost,” Lena says. “But like, a comforting one. Haunting a university library.”

Mira smiles, a small, startled thing, like she’s seeing herself for the first time in a while. “Barista in all three,” she says. “I’ll allow it.”

Day after non-day, we sand down each other’s edges. Dan, who started off deflecting with sarcasm, begins to volunteer details about his mother’s cooking, his fear of flying, the first time he lied on a résumé. Lena, who was always loud, learns to sit in silence without filling it. Mira lets herself be ridiculous sometimes, inventing soap operas for the cockroaches we occasionally see.

I become the archivist. In the absence of paper, I memorize. I arrange their stories in my head, alphabetize their fears, cross-reference their habits. If eternity is a library with four books, someone has to keep them organized.

Some “mornings,” I wake up convinced I can hear traffic, or smell coffee, or feel my phone in my hand. The hallucinations are sharper than dreams, and losing them hurts anew.

“What if this is a shared dream?” I ask once.

“Then we are all very committed to continuity,” Mira says.

“I’d like a new writing team,” Dan adds. “I would accept aliens. Zombies. Even a volcano. This minimalist prison drama is indulgent.”

Lena swings down from her bunk, landing soft. “If it’s a dream, we made each other important,” she says. “That counts.”

There’s no redemption arc here. No twist where the door swings open. The cell remains.

But exile rearranges itself into something that is not quite torture.

We know the exact length of Dan’s stride from bars to wall. We know the cadence of Lena’s laughter: the low chuckle, the snort, the unstoppable wheeze. We know the way Mira’s eyebrows draw together when she’s about to disagree, and the way she does it gently, like placing a hand on your arm.

We argue about everything because there are no new shows, no news, no memes. We dissect memories, ethics, hypothetical trolley problems that have become obscenely relevant. Sometimes we fight mean, because there’s nowhere to storm out to. Sometimes we go quiet for so long I can hear my pulse.

But every time, eventually, someone says: “New roles?”

And we reset.

This is what daily life is for me: not steel and concrete, though there is plenty of both, but three other people I never would have chosen and now cannot bear to imagine losing.

Forever is still terrifying. It is also brushing teeth over a cracked sink while your sister hums a song off-key. It is listening to your coworker explain the rules of a board game we’ll never play again, just because it’s something to build in the air. It is learning the barista’s real name, and her brother’s, and the way she takes her coffee, and understanding that knowing and being known is, improbably, what keeps the walls from closing in.

I went to prison with three strangers: my sister, my coworker, the woman who made my coffee. In eternity, they became my world.

samples.prompt: Sorry, boss. I'm calling in sick.
samples.output:
“Sorry, boss. I’m calling in sick.”

I rehearsed it twice before dialing, standing barefoot on the cold tiles of my bathroom, phone slick in my hand. It felt theatrical, like trying on someone else’s voice. I watched myself in the mirror: pale, hollow-eyed, reasonably convincing. Not that he could see me, but something about lying demanded method acting.

The call rang three times. I hoped it would go to voicemail; I had my script ready for the beep. No such luck.

“Yeah?” came his voice, too awake for 6:14 a.m.

“Hey, Martin. It’s—uh—Elliot.”

A pause. He knew who it was.

“I’m… sorry, boss. I’m calling in sick.”

It came out too smooth, too formal. “Calling in sick.” Who talks like that? I braced for questions.

“Sick, huh?” he said.

“Yes. I’ve been up most of the night. I think it’s—might be a stomach bug. Fever, too. I don’t think I should come in.” I threw in a sniff for texture.
